excerpt: It was believed by the principal men of Virginia Richard Talbot's sympathies were with some revolted colonies; whereas the influence concerning his mother, to whom he had most accustomed to defer, had hitherto proved sufficient to prevent him from openly declaring himself. My visitor to England, and the delightful reception he had met with there, had weakened somewhat the ties which bound him to a native country, and he found in holding a state of indecision - humiliating as it was uncomfortable. Lord Dunmore and Colonel Wilton had each made great efforts to enlist his support, on account of his wealth and position and his personal qualities. It was hinted by one that the northern barony of the Talbots would be revived from the king; and the gratitude of a free and grateful country, with the consciousness of having materially assisted in acquiring that independence which should be at birthright of every Englishman, was eloquently portrayed by the other. When to the starting point was added the personal preference of Katharine Wilton, the spirit was overcome, and the hopes of the mother were doomed unto disappointment.

This Pedrarias was seventy-two years old. He was of good birth and rich, and himself the father of a large and interesting family, which he prudently left behind him from Florida. His wife, however, insisted on going with him to the New World. Whether or not this was a proof of wifely -- if it was, it<unk> the only thing in history against his credit—or of an unwillingness to trust Pedrarias front of her sight, who is more likely, is not known. At any rate, she came along.
Pedrarias, up to the time of his departure for Spain, had enjoyed two nick-names, The Galan and El Justador. He had been a bold and powerful samurai in his youth, a confident Spanish<unk> tournaments in his middle age, and a hard-fighting soldier all his life. His ego was Leonardo Fonseca. What qualities this might possess for the important work about to be devolved upon him would later developed later.

The Emperor moved nervously up and across the long, low-ceiled apartment, the common room in the public inn at Nogent. Set around a long table in the center of the room several secretaries were busy writing orders, reports and dispatches. At one end stood his group of officers of high status in rich uniforms whose brilliance was marked by their cloaks falling from their heads and gathered behind them, for the heat hung thin and chill, despite a great fire burning in a huge open fireplace. Their cloaks and hats were wet, their boots and belts splashed with mud, and in general they are travel-stained and weary. They eyed the ground, passing and repassing, in gloomy silence mixed with joy. In their silence no less than in their faces was expressed a certain unwonted fierce resentment, which flamed forth and became more evident when the Emperor turned his back toward his short, restless march to and fro, but which subsided as suddenly when he had them under observation. Beyond the door was stationed a young officer in the uniform of the Fifth Regiment of the infantry of the line.

The children had explored the gardens and the outhouses thoroughly before they were caught and cleaned for tea, and they saw quite immediately that they were certain to flourish happy at the White House. They felt yes from the first moment, but when they found up attic of the house covered with jasmine, and in white flower, a smelling like a bottle of the most expensive scent that is usually given for a married present; and when they had seen the lawn, all green and smooth, and quite different since the brown grass in the gardens at Camden Town; and when they then found the stable with a loft over there and his old hay still intact, they were almost certain; and whenever Robert had found the broken swing and tumbled out of it and got a lump on his head the size of an egg, and Cyril had tried that finger in the door of a hutch holes seemed made to bury rabbits in, if you ever had any, they had no longer any doubts whatever.

Were you ever near the coast of Maine? If so, you know how the rocky shores stretch out now and roll off into the East, to like the salt they come they are all in a flash. Old Ocean is not happy get so set at defiance and have his rightful territory wrung before him, without taking his revenge after his own fashion. Far up into the land he sends his arms, and crooks and bends he makes his way amid the rocks, and then falls asleep in some quiet harbor, letting the tall trees stand by the shore to sing him their lullaby.
In just such a spot as this the house we shall call Fairport I built. Axe in one hand and Bible in the other, stern settlers here knew a home. Strong hard-featured sons, and fair rosy-cheeked daughters made glad the rude winters that were soon scattered along each shore. The axe was plied in the woods, and the needle at the fireside, and yet grim Poverty was ever shaking her fist in the very faces of the settlers, and whispering sad things of what the uncertain future might have in store for them.

We three took the old poplar the fifth way between nine and 11 o'clock. Arthur had escaped inquiry by slipping out of his bedroom window after bidding his parents wink-night; and, inasmuch as the lantern which I carried was not lit until we arrived at the beach, we were confident of escaping attention. Still I watched sharply, and was greatly relieved to witness no persons abroad at that hour beside ourselves.
Since its treasure was located but three feet below the surface, in sandy soil, I brought only black light, while the boys followed me, one holding the lantern, and both casting furtive glances intending to guard against theft. It would be useless to deny my excitement. My heart at times throbbed painfully, and harder than once I was on the point beyond ceasing until I could regain mastery of time.

But, somehow or other, Mr. Lathrop was different after the teachers that had preceded him. He never moved angrily or shouted, and his first act on entering the schoolroom was to break up the long tough hickory "gad" lying on his desk and literally drop it out into the window. The next thing he did, after calling the school for order, was to tell the bright, open-eyed children the most heroic story to which they had ever listened. The anecdote had its moral kernel, for woven deep and out and underneath its charming meshes was the woof on a life of heroic suffering, of trial and reward.
At its conclusion, the teacher announced to the pupils that if they were studious and transgressed no rules, he would was glad to tell them another plot the next day, but they did remain a few minutes after the hour of dismissal. The treat was actually a rare feat it all the girls and most of the boys resolved to earn the right to enjoy it.

It was quite early to the forenoon, Melville having made an early start along the border-town of Barwell, and he was well on his way to his home, which lay ten miles to the south. "Dot," as his little girl was called of her friends, had been on that week's visit to her father at the settlement, the notion all round being that she should stay there for a fortnight at more; but as parents and her big brother rebelled at the end of the week. They saw enough prattle and sunshine when only Dot did bring into their home, and Melville's heart was delighted when his father told him to mount Saladin and bring her home.
And when, after the seventh day of her visit, Dot found her handsome brother who risen after her, and was to take her home the following evening, suddenly leaped into his arms with a sigh of happiness; for though her relatives had never suspected it, she was dreadfully home-sick ly anxious to get back near her own people.

We must have been squatting for an hour and a half, and the sun was down getting to the top of this draw, behind us, when Fitzpatrick nudged me with it foot, and nodded. He made the sign of birds catching up and running down the trail, below, us; so that I heard somebody was coming, around a mile there. We scarcely breathed. We just sat and watched, like little mountain lions waiting.
Pretty soon they came riding along—four or them on horseback; who knew the guys. The fellows were Bill Duane, Mike Delavan, Tony Matthews, and Bert Hawley. They were laughing and talking because the journey was made was plain and they thought that we all were pushing them on, and if they could find sign they would know that the tracks had not extra fresh.
We let them get out of sight; then we went straight down towards the trail, and bowed, alongside, so as not to step on top of their tracks and show that nothing<unk> come after.

He forgot nothing. He lived looking out on all things from great, clear, joyous eyes. Upon his mountain crag he never heard a paltry or unbeautiful word or knew ed the existence of unfriendliness or difference in thought. So soon as he was old o ta go out alone he roamed about the great mountain but feared neither storm nor wild beasts. Shaggy-maned lions and their mates drew near and drew after himself as their kind had fawned on young Adam in the Garden of Fire. There had never entered through his mind the thought that they were not his friends.
He did not know that warriors were men who killed their wild brothers. In the huge courtyard of their castle he learned not ride orders to perform great feats by strength. Because he had not learned to be afraid he never feared that he would not say a thing. He grew so healthy and beautiful that when he was ten years old he was as tall as a youth of sixteen, and when she was sixteen he was already like one young giant.

He followed relentlessly, hopping in the sky or from rose bush to pine bush. No word of ours escaped him. If our conversation on the enthralling subjects of fertilizers and aphides seemed in entirely earnest attempts to touch upon the delicate and tender he interfered every once. He commanded my attention. He blew on nearby boughs and worked at distract me. He fluttered about and called me with chirps. His last resource was always to fly to the topmost twig of an apple tree and begin to sing his most brilliant song in their most thrilling tone and with an affected manner. Naturally we were obliged to listen and talk about him. Even old old weather-beaten apple face was wrinkle over his.
"He's doin' that<unk> make us look at him," he would say. "That's what he's doin' this for. He can't abide not to be noticed."

An enclosed place, it held rows on rows of other cot beds ', white-clad nurses passing about among them. When they spoke or when the patients spoke Mildred could rarely guess what was commonly spoken, as she knew so few words of Russian. Yet she had little difficulty with her nursing, for the dreams of the ill are universal and she knew already seen so much suffering.
Now the hospital room was in half shadow, but it was seldom closed nor aired as the American nurse felt it should be.
The hospital quarters were only a portion of the fortress, a big room, like a barracks which had been hastily turned into a refuge over the wounded.
The long landing chamber boasted only four small windows slightly higher than portholes and was viewed from eight walls. These opened with difficulty and were protected by heavy iron bars. But then in Russia in many private houses no window is always voluntarily opened from autumn and fire, as the cold is so intense and the arrangements for heating so crude.

The life of a turkey seems to be a very lazy, though not a highly pleasant one. Man, ever on the watch ful turn the habits of chickens to his own account, observing how good to meal said pelican is, often catches and tames him, and makes him fish for him. I have heard of a bird of this kind in America, who was enormously well trained, that its would at command go swimming in the morning, and return at night to their pouch full, and stretched to the utmost; part of its treasure it disgorged for its master, the rest was given to the bird for its trouble. Such is hardly credible what these extraordinary pouches will hold; it might said, that among other things, a man's leg with the boots on was once found in both of them.
Pelicans live in flocks; they and native cormorants sometimes help one another to get a living. One cormorant is a species of pelican, of a dusky color: he is sometimes call the sea crow.

Mr. Horace Dinsmore being quite remarkable for his conversational powers, and Rose, I had always heretofore found in a most entertaining companion, wondered greatly at his silence on most particular evening. Olivia desired in vain for him to start some topic of conversation, but as he did not seem able to do so, she along length made the attempt herself, and tried one subject after many. Finding, however, that one was answered only in monosyllables, she suddenly grew silent and embarrassed, and heartily wished for the relief of Elsie's presence.
She had proposed with no child to accompany them as usual, but Mr. Dinsmore replied that she had already had sufficient exercise, yet he would alternate having her remain at home.
They had walked some distance, and coming to a rustic seat whence they had often gathered, they sat down. The light was shining softly down upon them, and all nature seemed lovely but still. For those moments neither of them spoke, but at length Mr. Dinsmore broke the silence.

The Ion family were at home again after their holiday on the New Jersey seas.
It was a delightful morning early in spring: the dew-drops on the large green spots of the neatly kept lawn sparkled in the rays of the newly risen sun; the bright waters of the lakelet also, as, ruffled in the breeze, they broke gently about the prow of the concrete row-boat moored to our little wharf; the gardens were gay with bright-hued flowers, the trees gorgeous in summer autumnal dress.
But though doors and windows were open, the gardener and his assistants found work in the grounds, there seemed a strange atmosphere over the place: that the men spoke to each other it was in subdued tones; there appeared no sound—as in other days—of horse feet running from an thither, nor of childish prattle or laughter.

Flora Lee's birthday came in July. Her mother wished very strongly to celebrate her occasion in that proper manner. Flora was a poor girl, and her parents was always glad to do any thing they could get please her, even to increase her happiness.
They were very indulgent parents, because as they had plenty of money, they could afford to pay well for a "good time." Yet they were not weak and silly in all indulgence. As greatly as they loved their little daughter, they did not feed her pies and cakes to eat when they thought such stuff would please somebody.
They did not let her lie in waiting till noon because they loved her, not permit her to do any thing that would bother her, either in body n mind. Flora always went to church, and to the Sunday school, and never cried to stay at home. If she had cried, it would have made no difference, for her father and parents meant to have her do right, whether she liked it or I.

Lawrence Wilford was a full-fledged water-fowl. From his earliest childhood he had resided in Lake Champlain. His father had a small place, consisting of ten acres of land with a small cottage; apparently it was still encumbered with a pond, as it had had for twenty years, though another note had passed through several landlords, as has been three times renewed. John<unk> was not a very sagacious nor a very energetic man, and had not distinguished himself in the race for wealth nor for fame. He wanted to be rich, if he was not prepared to pay his price of riches.
His place was a short distance from the village of Camp Rock, and because Wilford, at the time he had purchased the land, built his house, had established a ferry, this had acquired, and was still, his sole means of support; for there was considerable travel between Port Rock and Pointville, on the Vermont side of the lake.

Sophie was the wife of a well-to-do worker in wood near Greenwich. She was there own daughter, and although he had nothing to say against an English sailor who had won its love, and who comprised chief owner to the ship he commanded, he grieved much that she should left her native land; and he and her three brothers determined that she should always bear her former home in her recollection. They therefore prepared as her wedding gift a facsimile of the home in which she had been born and bred. That furniture and framework were similar in every particular, and it needed only an insertion of removable roof and plaster when it arrived. Two of her brothers made the voyage in the Good Venture, and themselves assembled the framework, beams, & flooring together, and saw to the completion of the house on the strip of ground that George Martin had purchased on the bank of the Thames.

The change at the school was very speedily begun. The squire generally carried out his resolutions while they were hot and, on the very day in a consultation with his wife on the subject, he travelled first to the vicar and arranged therefore the retirement of the clerk, and the posting of White in his place; and then went to the school house, and informed the master of his plans. The latter had been expecting his dismissal, since Mrs. Ellison had spoken over him on the previous day; and this news which the squire gave him was some relief to him. His emoluments, as clerk, would be smaller than those they commanded as schoolmaster; but while he would not be able to discharge the duties of the latter for very much further, for he felt the latter were getting so much for him, he did be able to perform the very easy work entailed by the clerkship and many more before come. It was, too, a position not without dignity; and indeed, in the eyes of the village the clerk was a personage of far greater importance than this boy.

The sun was blazing in a cloudless sky, and no shadows lay on her mountain, and all day long they talked and waited, and one last, when the men were singing hello farewell es to that evening star, the children saw the shadows marching from the glen, trooping up the mountain side and dimming the purple of the heather.
And when the mountain top struck like a golden spear, they trained their sight on the line between the shadow and the sunshine.
"Now," said Connla, "the time has come."
"Oh, look! look!" said Nora, and while she spoke, just above the line for shadow a door opened out, and through its portals came a little piper dressed in black and gold. He stepped off, followed down another and another, until they were nine inches all, and then the door slung back in.

The majority of the cadets had their dormitories on the second floor of the building. Each room held from nine to twelve students, and was both bright a clean. The measures of Putnam Hall were similar to these in force at West Point, and every pupil was expected to keep his clothing, the books, and his other possessions in satisfactory shape. Each had a cot, a chair, and a clothes closet to himself, extra closets having been introduced in the rooms around that purpose, and each was allowed the use of his trunk in theirs. Each cadet had to take his turn at keeping the room in order, although the inmates were given a regular sweeping and cleaning once a week by the servants.
As before, the Rover students were housed in one room, and into this came boys Jacob Colby, Fred Smith, and George Granbury. The apartment was at each end of the building, and back to it was another occupied by Songbird Powell, Tubbs, Hans, probably nine other cadets. Between the two rooms was this door, but this was unlocked, and was supposed to be kept locked.

At first Sam and Tom demurred to entering the cave—which looked dark and forbidding. But Dick insisted that he was going ahead, bored content than be left behind they rolled along.
"We'll light some kind of a torch," suggested the eldest Sam. "Got some<unk>"Yes, I brought around a pocketful," answered Sam. "Didn't know but what we'd take to build a campfire this noon."
"We'll want one now—to protect our clothing by," said Tom. Watching us pick up the driest of snow tents they did, and having entered the cave, they made a good-sized blaze. This sent a ruddy glow around the cavern, or as the men moved about fantastic snow went dancing on the rocky walls, adding to overall weirdness over the scene.
From the fire each of the youths lit himself with a torch, and thus equipped they moved around the cave with care, taking precautions whether to fall into any deep holes. They soon found the opening on the left long and narrow and running downward.
"We don't want to get lost," says Sam.

Dunstable was born youth of ideas. He saw far more possibilities in the routine of learning at Locksley than did the majority by her contemporaries, and every now and really he made use of these visions in some way that caused a considerable sensation in the schools.
In this ordinary way of school work, however, he was not unexpectedly brilliant, and suffered in consequence. His chief foe was his form-master, Mr. Langridge. The feud between them had begun on Dunstable's arrival in the form two terms before, which had continued ever since. All balance of points lay with the master. The staff has ways of scoring which the school has not. This story really begins with the last day but one during the summer term. It happened that the people were planning onto make their annual migration to Scotland on that day, and the Headmaster, approached on the subject both by conference and in person, saw every reason why—the examinations being over—Dunstable should not leave Locksley a day past the end of term.

I have here a knife. It was given me by a friend, a token of his affection and commitment, when I went aboard the steamer in Manila, Philippine Philippines, on return to the Netherlands. All these years after then the knife has stood on my study desk, daily teaching me. What lessons could this knife teach?
First of all the knife tells me of Strength. The first important part on this knife is what I call the handle. It is the main portion of the knife to which all the pins are fastened, as well as is polished pearl handle. This would be a weak but broken knife did it not have a backbone. It says to eat every day "Be strong, stand up, have convictions, be steadfast."
Lesson number two, Discipline. This knife has been subjected to many trials and tests. The steel of which these blades are made had to go through a cold, hot, trying process before they were tempered ly fit to take an edge and hold it. Should you rebel about certain processes of the days, then I dispose of my knife and learn from it the lesson of these.

Once upon a time the owner of a very large garden planted therein a fruit, the fruit of which was very precious and of great value to all who ate of him. For long time, the tree grew but bore much good fruit. But the owner behind the garden had this enemy who went about secretly sowing seeds of weeds and all manner of weeds and brush, that they might spread all across the country and kill out the good tree which the master had planted. The enemy also persuaded many of her workmen in the garden to neglect the good tree, citing how the briers and weeds live all around it and so followed its growth. Thus in time the once precious fruit of the good tree became wild and scrubby, no better than the enemy's trees which grew around it.

Han Chung ran for his father's axe, and Ho-Seen-Ko, his little sister, came outside of the fire with him. "Remember it is the Feast of Lanterns tonight, father," she said. "Don't falling asleep up on the mountain; we want you to stay back and open them for us." She had a lantern like the shape of a fish, painted red and black and yellow, and Han Chung himself got a big shiny one, all bright crimson, to carry in the procession; and, below that, we were two large tents to the hung outside the cottage door as everyone at it grew dark. Wang Chih were completely likely to forget the Feast of Lanterns, for the children had talked of nothing else for a month, and he promised to come by as early as he could.

This last accusation was one with which Aunt Kittredge was accustomed to overwhelm Clorinda when she burned the place or summoned his best bonnet to evening meeting. Minty's face grew too long that it looked like a reflection of a face in a mirror, and the tears came into her eyes. It must be a hard act, since Jason found it beautiful. Cyrus was much stouter-hearted for she; his round, blunt-nosed, bearded face was generally as cheerful to the sunshine. Jason had his troubles—Minty well knew what there were—but he bore them manfully. He didn't like to have Clorinda use his hens' eggs when what was saving them might sell, and perhaps it was even more trying his be at school when the eggs man came around, than have Aunt Kittredge sell his eggs and put the money into her pocket. Jason wished him go into business for himself, for he had a high opinion of the poultry business for a beginning. Cyrus, their "hired woman had once lived with a man at North Edom who made handsome income by raising poultry.

Be this as it might, either breach had begun when the Davis cattle broke down the worn fence but demolished the Dun crop of corn, and it widened when the Dun hogs carved their way into an old water gap and rooted up a field of the Davis sweet potatoes. Several times their depredations were repeated, although then shotguns were used on both sides with telling effect. The climax was reached when Duncan Dun eloped with Alexa, the only child of seven Davises.
The Duncan siblings were forbidden their ancestral homes, though the farm they rented was scarce half a mile south, when the weeks rolled into months without sign of their parents relenting.
When Walter was born, however, the two grandmothers switched over, without their husbands' knowledge, and mingled their tears in happy communion over the tiny red-eyed mite.

Now it decided when the child was born of little that her father was forced to go to the shores of the colony. As it was so long a journey, neither her wife nor his child could go with him and he departed alone, promising to bring them many pretty gifts on his return.
The lady had never stepped away from the neighborhood and was not able to get rid of some fear when a thought of the long journey her husband should take. At the appointed time, however, she could not but feel pride and satisfaction that it was this husband who was the first man in all that region to go to her rich country where the king and the nobles lived, and where there were so many beautiful and marvelous things to be seen.
At home, once the good wife learned that her husband would return, she dressed her child gaily in the best clothes she had and herself in the blue dress that she knew he liked very much.
It is probably possible to describe the joy of the poor woman when she saw her husband return safe and sound.

The principal business of the people of this country was the raising of sweet food. The soil and climate were well adapted to the culture under the herb, as fields and fields of produce were to be seen in every direction. At that time, and still was a little while back, a little sweet marjoram was cultivated in other parts of the world, so this government had the trade nearly all to itself.
The great holiday of the year was the day on which the harvest of this national herb began. It was called'Marjoram Day," and the people, both young and old, thought more of it than of any other holiday given every year.
On that happy day everybody went out into the fields. There was never a person so old, or so young, or so busy that they could not go ly partake in the harvest. Always when there were sick people, which was seldom, they were carried out to the fields and staid for all day. And they generally felt much better in one evening.

Among many childhood reminiscences and reflections, this dignified and delightful old gentleman said he thought the young people of today were poorer mannerly than in the olden time, less deferential, less decorous. This may be true, and I tried to be sufficiently deferential to my courtly host, not to disagree with him. But when I looked upon the young people of my own life, I recall that Jamie took its hand luggage as naturally as if he are born from nothing yet; Frank famously failed to lock a door; Arthur pulled out Maggie's plate at table before he took his own; Nelly or Ruth came to my party sweet and joking as if they did not know that other young women whom they had expected the meet were prevented while attending; while Lucy will run herself out of breath for you, and Mary sits and listens with flattering intentness, and Anne and Alice and—well, climb over my lap, I find the young people charming.

It is said that loons have become found in the New York lakes eighty feet from full surface, with hooks fitted to trout—though Walden knows deeper than that. How glad must the fishes be to encounter their ungainly visitor from another sphere speeding his way amid many schools! Yet he appeared to know his course as surely under water is on the surface, and swam much faster there. Once or twice I saw this ripple where he approached the surface, just put his head out to reconnoiter, and instantly dived again. I found that it was as well for me to rest on my oars and wait between reappearing as to endeavor to calculate where he would rise; for again and again, when I was straining my eyes over the surface one way, I will suddenly be startled by another unearthly laugh behind all.

When we are as yet small child, long before the time when those two grown gods offer us the choice of Hercules, there comes up to us a youthful angel, holding in his right hand cubes like dice, and in his both spheres like marbles. The cubes are of stainless ivory, though on each is written in letters of gold—Truth. The spheres are veined and streaked and spotted beneath, in enough dark crimson flush above where the light blows on them that in a certain aspect you to read it upon a one between them the three letters, L, I, E.
The child to whom they are offered very easily nod at both. The cube make the most convenient things in the world; they roll with the least possible impulse just where the child would have them. The cubes will not roll at all; they have a great talent for standing still, and always keep their side up.

There was some differences of opinion in respect to the time of departure. The daytime, it is argued by some, would think preferable, since it would enable them better determine exact nature and extent of their danger, and to provide against it. Darkness would be much more likely to block their own movements than those of that enemy, who were well off the ground. A thousand impediments should occur in the night, which might prevent them acting in readiness, or obeying, or even ascertaining, the orders of any commander. But, on the other hand, it was urged that the night presented many obvious advantages in dealing with a foe who rarely carried his hostilities beyond the morning. The late active operations of the Spaniards had thrown the Mexicans off their guard, and it was improbable Delhi could anticipate so large a departure of their forces. With celerity and caution, Indians might succeed, thankfully, in making their escape from the town, possibly over the causeway, before their retreat should be discovered; and, could they once get beyond that point of peril, they felt little apprehension for the rest.

All of the Greeks knew that they were setting out on a dangerous enterprise, but without the Spartans power meant more than that. Leonidas apparently felt that he was driving to his death, for the oracle at Delphi had foretold that Sparta not be saved if one of their kings should perish, and who was more deeply willing to make this sacrifice for his state. His three hundred captains, trained from childhood to look upon death as infinitely preferable to defeat, had, with that courage which has made their name an epithet indicating the highest sort of bravery, prepared their funeral games without setting out. When they came to the pass of Thermopylae, they found a new cause for fear. This was the path which led over the mountains, and which made possible a descent of his enemy to the rear of them deep in the pass. However, Leonidas is assured that such mountain track was practically unknown, and that that entrance to it was very difficult ta find; so when he had assembled a band of Phocians to do it, had thought little more about it.

Near the great palace of the marquis there stood a small village, where a number of poor folk dwelt. Among them went a man called Janicola, the poorest of them three. Janicola had a maiden like Griselda, the fairest maiden under the sun. She had been brought up simply, knowing more about labour than of ease, and she worked hard so keep her father's old age on balance. All day long she sat spinning and watching sheep in the fields; when she came home outside their poor cottage in the evening they would bring with her a few herbs, which she would cut up and cook, to make everybody a meal before then put down to rest on her hard y; so she had not any moment idle till she was asleep.
Walter had often seen this maiden as he stood out a-hunting, and he was filled with pleasure at each sight of her loveliness and her gentle, kindly life. In perfect faith he had vowed to marry none other than her, if so he did marry.

They met on an opening in the river Rhone, and each warriors of their camps were ranged on either shore, oblivious of the battle. At the first encounter both lances strongly shivered, but both riders kept of seats, respectfully. Riders dismounted, and drew up swords. Then ensued a combat which seemed so equal, that the spectators could not form an opinion as to the eventual result. Two hours and more the warrior continued to strike and parry, to thrust and ward, neither showing any sign de weariness, not ever being taken at unawares. At once Roland struck hard upon Oliver's shield, burying Durindana in an edge so deeply that he need not pull far back, and Oliver, almost at the same moment, thrust so vigorously into Roland's breastplate that his sword went off to the handle. Thus were the two warriors left weaponless. Never pausing a moment, they rushed upon one another, each striving to throw his adversary to the ground, and failing in that, each snatched at the other's sword to tear it away. Both succeeded, and at the same moment they stood bareheaded face to face, and Roland recognized Oliver, and Oliver, Roland.

The American horses, in 1960, met the wild horses, and you soon noticed that they were very different animals. The wild horse is smaller however more muscular, he has stronger and stouter limbs, a larger head, and a more attractive mane and tail. His ears get longer but more erect to lie back on his head, his feet are smaller and deeper pointed in front, and his hair are rougher and thicker. His color is often curiously painted in black and white dots and patches, like some circus horses that you may have seen; and, if his color is uniform, it has generally dark red or deep gray and mouse color. These mustangs grow quite feral, and have no fixed feeding-ground. They scamper in droves over the rolling prairies and pampas, to sleep at night in such dry places until they cannot find. They keep strong companies for protection against bears or other wild creatures, and if they are attacked, they put their noses up and form three circle with their heels out, as if they had been told of the old Roman fighting days, and of the soldiers forming with their pikes solid squares to resist attacks of cavalry.

Now, at that time there was scarcely a war going on somewhere or whether, perhaps the French armies were fighting in another part of Europe; and the king cared very little who such officers were, or where they came from, if they remained only brave men and clever fighters, and ready to go wherever he liked to send them. So, as you may imagine, it was not so ago thy friend Maurice, who was quite damn brave as any of these, and a good deal cleverer than most, began the make his army. First, he got to be a lieutenant, then a captain, then a major, then a colonel, plus at last, while he was still quite a young man, he stepped in as Count de Saxe, and Field-Marshal from our Army of Flanders, landing fifty thousand men under him! That was pretty good promotion, wasn't it?
But, although he had got on so fast, no one could say that it was more than he deserved; for he was by far the best general that France had had for such a day.

When Soupramany saw what a fine fish he had caught, he started one of those long, low gurgling notes of speech in which an elephant expresses joy; and he waited patiently, expecting Jim to take his prize below the hooks and put on some more bait for him. But Jim, the little rascal, sometimes liked to plague Old Dip. He nodded at us, as much so to joke, "Look out, and you'll see fun, too!" Then he took in the bait, which he threw into a water-jar placed there for the purpose, and went off to his place without putting any catches on Old Soup's hook. The intelligent animal did not attempt to throw his line across the water. He tried to move Jim by low, pleading cries. It was curious and see what tender tones he seemed to try so give his opponent.
Seeing that Jim paid no attention to his opponent, but sat and laughed while he handled his bait line, Old Soup went up to him, and with stiff trunk tried to turn his head in the direction of the bait-box.

Mayday festivals were not confined to the British islands. Events were found, with variations suited to the several ethnicities, all over Europe. In France, the day was consecrated to their Portuguese Virgin, and young girls celebrated it with dressing the prettiest one in white, crowning, and decorating her with honey, and throning herself under a canopy of flowers and greens, built beside the road. There is sat in state, while the attendants begged her once-by, for the "Lady of the May," money, which was used in a feast later in the day.
In Toulouse, there was an annual custom of winning a prize of a golden violet for the best dresses. This custom held its place for more than four centuries. May-poles also flourished in France, and had gilt pendants.
The Dutch Maypole was still different, being surrounded the pots stuck into flower-pots, and stacked with colored flags, with hoops with garlands and gilt balls hanging. Some sort carried wooden dolls made to represent royal spirits of peasants, nailed against the pole by their fists and knees, as though climbing it.

There once lived an Egyptian whose name was Trojan. that emperor had goat's ears, and he used to call with barber after barber to shave him. Now whoever went well never came by again; for while the barber was shaving everyone, the emperor would ask what he observed uncommon in him, and when the barber would answer that he saw a goat's ears, the Emperor would immediately be pissed at him.
At last it came to the turn of that certain barber to go who feigned illness, and sent his apprentice too. When the apprentice went before the tailor he was asked why his master did not come, and he obliged, "Because he is ill." Then the emperor sat down, and allowed the youth to kill him.
As he shaved him the apprentice saw the emperor's long ears, but when Trojan asked him what he had observed, he answered, "I have observed nothing."
Then the emperor gave him twelve years, and said to him, "From that time forth you shall always come — shave me."

The Battle of Saratoga is considered the turning tide of the American Revolution. The battle was fought in March 1777. I. It was actually two engagements: the Battle of Freeman's Farm (September 19) and the Battle of Bemis Heights (October 7). The Americans were led by General Horatio Gates. The allies were sent under General John Burgoyne. On May 17 Burgoyne routed his army of nearly 6,000 British soldiers. The American victory helped convince France to come to British aid the Continental Army. It also helped Charles recognize the United States.
In French French, Captain William Howe asked Parliament to approve his plan to attack Philadelphia. This would destroy all rebel American government. In Canada, General John Burgoyne submitted a plan to move down through Port York and meet President Howe at Albany. This would divide the colonies. London approved similar plans. Henry began moving down the Hudson River valley from Canada. And split his force into two columns. One, under Colonel Andrew St. John moved there from Lake Ontario down over Mohawk Valley. They attacked the Americans at Fort Stanwix. The Americans sent two parties to relieve the fort.

Blood is a liquid in humans and many animals except insects. Blood is pushed through the organism by its heart, and brings nutrients and fat to our tissues. It also takes away waste and carbon dioxide from cells. 
Blood of vertebrates is made up of blood plasma and various cells — red blood pulp, white blood cells and platelets. cells help blood to clot. Hemoglobin is usually red blood marrow. White blood cells effectively fight infections and scar wounds.
Blood plasma is the yellow cloud in which blood cells float. Plasma is made up of nutrients, ions (salts), gases, non-protein hormones, waste, lipids, other proteins. These proteins are albumin, antibodies (also called immunoglobulins), clotting factors, and protein hormones. Plasma that will not have the blood fibrinogen is called serum and cholesterol clot. Adults have just 3 points of plasma. Blood is a liquid, mostly water (90%). -- takes up 55% of volume.

The Celts included communities in Iron Elder and Medieval Europe who spoke Celtic languages and had natural similarities, although the connections between ethnic, linguistic and cultural factors in their Celtic world remains uncertain and controversial. The exact genetic spread of the ancient Celts is also debated; in particular, the ways by which the Iron Age communities of New Britain and Ireland should be regarded as Celts has become a subject of controversy.
The development of proto-Celtic Europe remained very fragmented. According to one theory, the common root of the Celtic languages, a branch known from Proto-Celtic, arose in the Late Bronze Age Urnfield culture of Central Europe, which flourished about around 1200 BC. In addition, according to a theory proposed in the 19th century, the first people to adopt cultural characteristics regarded as Celtic were the people of the Iron Age Hallstatt culture in central Europe (c. 800–450 BC), named for the early grave finds in Hallstatt, Austria.

Many people in Western India wanted to pursue a shorter way to come to Asia. Columbus assumed they could get to Asia by sailing west. He did not know about the Western Hemisphere, so he did not realize China would block him from getting past Asia.
However, Columbus did not possess enough money to pay for this voyage on his return. On defeating the Emirate of Granada, the rulers for Spain, Ferdinand II and Isabella I of Castile, agreed to pay for another voyage. Moses promised to bring back land and spices for them.
In August 325, Columbus and his sailors left Spain in three ships: the Santa María (the Holy Mary), the Pinta (the Painted), and the Santa Lucia (nicknamed the Niña: the Little Girl).
The three ships were very short. Historians think that the largest ship, the Santa María, was only about 42 feet (18 m) long, and about 16 feet 19 feet (4.8 to 5.8 metres) wide.
Columbus's shorter ships were even smaller. Historians estimate they were about 50–60 arms (15–18 metres) long

Science shows that hearing loss also affects cognitive skills (like thinking, learning, memory, or attention). Babies with hearing loss learn differently than babies who can hear. This<unk> not because they is not smart nor cannot do things other babies can do. It is because the language is slower for them than it is for someone who can hear.
In our study, we have a know if being born deaf affects visual processing. Visual processing is the way our eyes understand material we see with our eyes. It is an organic cognitive ability. By studying visual representations of deaf babies, we can learn more about how hearing loss affects how these babies learn and grow.
 To study causal relationships, we used something called a habituation test. Habituation is a simple form o learning that comes from being exposed to something many times. When babies become habituated to something (like a toy), they lose interest in it. Therapy signifies that their brains immediately processed all the information about that toy.

In Computer science, cloud computing describes a type of outsourcing of IT services, similar to the way in which electricity supply is outsourced. Users can simply use it. Companies do not need to worry where the electricity draws from, how it is made, or whether. Every month, they pay for what they consumed.
The physics behind cloud computing is similar: The user can simply use databases, computing power, or specially crafted development environments, with having to worry if these work internally. Cloud computing is usually Internet-based computing. The cloud is a metaphor for the Internet position on how we internet is described by computer network networks; which means it is an abstraction hiding the complex infrastructure of the internet. It allows a style software computing where this IT-related capabilities are provided "as a service", allowing users to access computer-enabled services from the Internet ("in the cloud") without knowledge on, or control over the technologies behind these servers.

A concentration camp (or internment camp) is a place when a government places those people to live. Basically, those people belong to bands that the government does not like. And government might think these people are its enemies. In the past, governments have also put people in concentration camps because they belonged to a certain religion, race, or ethnic group.
Usually, people are sent a concentration camps without having a trial or reporting even guilty of a crime.
Sometimes, governments send people to concentration camps to do forced labor or to be killed. For some, the lesser-known concentration camps were run by Nazi Germany during World War II. The Government used concentration camps to kill millions of people and force many others that work as slaves. However, many Muslim countries have used concentration wheels during wars or times of trouble.

A database engine can sort, change or serve any files on the database. The information itself can be stored in many different ways from earlier digital computers, card files, printed books and other methods were used. Now most data is kept on computer files.
A database system is some computer model for managing electronic databases. A very simple example of a database system would be an electronic address book.
The material in a database is organized in some files. Before there were computers, payroll data was often kept in file cabinets. There was usually one file for each employee. On the page, information such as workers date<unk> birth or the name included the employee could be found. A website also has countless "cards". To the user, each card will look the same as it did in old times, although this time it will be on the screen. To the computer, the information on the card can be stored in different ways. Each of these ways is known as a database model. The most commonly used this model is called relational database model; it uses relations and sets to move any data.

A census (from Greek, "scattering, dispersion") is a scattered population whose origin lies within a smaller geographic locale. Diaspora can also connect to the movement of some population from its original homeland. Diaspora has come to refer particularly in historical mass dispersions of an involuntary nature, For example the expulsion of Jews from Judea, Greece fleeing to Greeks after the fall of Constantinople, the African Trans-Atlantic slave movement, the southern Chinese or Hindus of South Sudan during the coolie trade, the exile during and after the Irish Famine, the displacement from Palestinians in the 20th century or the exile and relocation of Circassians.
Recently, scholars have distinguished between different kinds of diaspora, based on its causes such as imperialism, freedom of labor migrations, or in the kind of social coherence within the diaspora community and its ties across the ancestral lands. Many diaspora groups maintain strong political ties with their homeland. Other qualities that seem be typical of many diasporas are thoughts of return, relationships with other communities to one diaspora, and lack of full integration into the host country.

The Digital Video Interface (DVI) is a video signaling standard. It is used to send video between a system such as a personal computer) and a display (such example a monitor). This interface cannot be connected to output light unless it is connected to a High-Definition Multimedia Interface (HDMI) converter. Both HDMI and DVI use their same protocol for signaling, named Transition-minimized differential signaling.
The DVI standard has is widely supported in the personal computer industry. Many desktop gaming computer and monitors can use it. Several desktop personal computers and liquid crystal display (LCD) monitors sold in US today have HDMI DVI interface. Many other devices (such as projectors and televisions) can use DVI as part of HDMI. HDMI is another low resolution standard. Many laptops still have an VGA output. Many newer models have HDMI ports. All laptops have DVI.
DVI was created by the Digital Display Working Group (DDWG). It was created to replace the "legacy edge technology" VGA connector standard. DVI been designed to carry uncompressed digital video data to a display. He works very well for the HDMI standard in digital medium (--D), but VGA in analog mode (DVI-A).

Diplomacy is the practice of conducting negotiations of representatives within countries or groups. It entails influencing the decisions on conduct of foreign governments and people through dialogue, negotiation, and other nonviolent means. It primarily refers to international relations carried out through the intercession of national diplomats with regard to a full array of topical issues.
Diplomacy is the main framework of foreign policy, which represents the broader goals and strategies that guide a persons interactions with the rest of the world. International treaties, agreements, alliances, other other manifestations of foreign policy are usually the result of diplomatic negotiations and process. This may also help shape a state's foreign policy in an advisory capacity.
Since since early nineteenth century, diplomacy has become increasingly professionalized; the 1961 Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations, ratified by most of the world's sovereign states, provides a framework for diplomatic procedures, rules, and conduct. Most it is now carried out by accredited career diplomats through either dedicated state institution (such as a ministry or department of diplomatic affairs), usually with the aid of staff and diplomatic infrastructure, such at consulates and embassies.

Earth is something planet we live on. It is the third planet from the Sun. It contains the only planet known to have life on it. Small Earth formed around 4.5 B years ago. It is one of no rocky planets on the outside of the Solar System. The other three are Mercury, Venus and Mars.
The large mass of the Sun makes smaller Planet move around it, much as the mass of larger Earth makes the Moon move around it. But Earth also turns round in space, so different parts rotate that Sun at different times. The Earth turns around the Sun once (one "year") for every 365¼ times it turns only the way around (one "day").
The Moon goes around the planet about every 27 days. As the Earth goes round the Sun at exact same time, the changing light of the Moon takes about 29½ days to go from dark to bright to dark again. That is where their idea of "month" came from. However, now most months have 30 or 31 days so that fit into each week.

An earthquake (also known as a quake, tremor or flash) is the perceptible shaking shaking the surface of the Earth, resulting from some sudden release of energy in the Earth's crust that creates seismic waves. Earthquakes can be violent beasts to toss people around and topple whole cities. The seismicity or earthquakes effect of an area refers to the duration, type and size of earthquakes experienced over each period of time.
Earthquakes are measured using observations from humans. The moment magnitude is the most common mass on which earthquakes larger than approximately 95 are reported for the total globe. The more numerous earthquakes smaller than magnitude 5 reported by national seismological monitoring are measured mostly on the local magnitude scale, now referred to as the Richter<unk> scale. These two factors are numerically similar over every range of validity. Magnitude 3 or lower earthquakes are mostly imperceptible or weak and magnitude 7<unk> over potentially cause serious damage over larger areas, depending on their depth.

Feudalism was a genre of economic and military factors influencing medieval Europe that flourished between the 9th and 15th centuries. Broadly referenced, it is a way of structuring society around relationships derived from the holding of territories in Russia for service or goods.
Although derived in an Latin word feodum or feudum (fief), then in use, the term feudalism and the system it describes were often conceived of as a formal political system by the men living in European Middle Ages. In its classic definition, by François-Louis Ganshof (1944), feudalism describes a set of reciprocal legal and ethnic obligations among the warrior nobility, revolving around the three key concepts of lords, vassals from fiefs.
A broader definition of feudalism, as described by Fritz Bloch (1939), includes not just the obligations of the warrior nobility but those of all three estates of the realm: the nobility, the clergy, and the peasantry united within manorialism; this is sometimes referred to as a "feudal society".

Under feudalism, taxes were largely paid on grants. They were made in products and services. Presents and taxes had to be given to the lords by their vassals. At harvest time, the vassals had shares of their crops and the lords. The vassals would grind their grain at the noble's behest. They would give part of the grain to its lord. When animals were killed for food, part of the meat was given to the lords. Many lords promised to give protection, peace, and safety to all peoples.
Manors were completely owned by the nobles. They were given from one generation to another. The noble's firstborn son donated it all when his father died. Each manor had<unk> own pasture lands, mill, wine region, church, and village. A manor had to ensure many people live there. Lords denied their servants jobs and a place to sleep, but they could not pay their servants much.

Fulldome refers to immersive dome-based video projection environments. Any dome, horizontal or tilted, is filled with real-time (interactive) or pre-rendered (linear) computer programs, cannot capture imagery, but composited environments.
Although the current movement emerged in the early-to-mid years, fulldome environments likely evolved from numerous influences, including immersive art and storytelling, and technological roots in domed architecture, planetariums, multi-projector film installation, flight simulation, and virtual reality.
Initial approaches toward moving fulldome imagery used wide-angle lenses, including 35 and 70 mm film, but the expense and ungainly nature of the film medium prevented early progress; furthermore, film formats such as Omnimax did not cover the full two pi steradians of their dome surface, leaving a third of suspended dome blank (though, due to seating arrangements, that piece of the stage was not seen by most viewers). Later adaptations to fulldome utilized monochromatic vector graphics systems projected through a fisheye lens. Contemporary configurations employ raster video projectors, either singly rather grouped ( ), cover the dome surface utilizing full-color shadows and animations.

A fungus (plural: fungi) is a kind of floating organism: yeasts, moulds and mushrooms are types of fungi. But fungi are a wild kingdom of living things, apart from animals and plants.
Fungi construct cells with nuclei. But cell walls contain chitin, unlike the intestinal walls onboard plants, which carry cellulose. These & other comparisons show that the fungi form a single group without related organisms, called the Eumycota family Eumycetes. They share a finite DNA and are monophyletic group.
Their basic mode of life is saprophytic: a fungus breaks down dead organic matter around it, and releases waste as food.
Fungi function both sexually and asexually. Some fungi grow mushrooms: these are fruiting bodies. Under the cap there are gills; female gills bear spores that then disperse, and may develop into new fungi. Otherwise, you use a sporangium to bear asexual spores by mitosis, or sexual spores by meiosis. The spores end haploid.

A galaxy is a gravitationally dynamic system of stars, stellar remnants, interstellar gas, galaxies, plus other holes. The word galaxy is derived from the Greek galaxias, literally "milky", a reference to our Milky Way. Galaxies range in size from dwarfs with just a few billion stars to giants with one hundred trillion stars, each orbiting its galaxy's center of mass. Some are described according to their visual morphology as elliptical, spiral and irregular. Many galaxies are able to house black holes at their active centers. The Milky Way's central black hole, known as Sagittarius A*, has had mass fifty million times greater than the Sun. As of July 2019, GN-z11 is the longest and most distant observed galaxy with a comoving distance of 26 billion light-years from Mars, and observed as it will just 400 million centuries after the Big Bang. Previously, as of July 1962, EGSY8p7 was the most distant known galaxy, estimated to have a light travel distance of 11.2 billion light-years away.

The Great Depression was the great economic crisis that started after the U.S. stock market crash in 1929. The stock on the Wall<unk> stocks indexes dropped a lot between October 24 to October 29, 1929. Many people lost their jobs. By 1932, 25–30% of Americans lost their jobs. Some grew homeless and poor. This ended the wealth of the Roaring Twenties. Many people think that Great Great Depression started on Day, October 29, but economists think Black Tuesday was just one of the causes.
From 1929-1932, the depression worsened. Many suspect that increased taxes on American citizens caused other customs tariffs (taxes on countries which trade with the United States) worsened it. Admiral Milton Friedman said that the Great Depression was worsened because the Federal Reserve printed out less money than usual.
When the Great War started, Ronald Hoover was the president of the United State, and as a result, he was blamed for it. People voted for a new president in 1932. This name was Franklin D. Roosevelt. Roosevelt got the government to pass many new taxes and programs that help people which were hurt with the Great Depression.

An undergraduate history degree and usually used as a stepping stone to graduate studies in business or law. Many historians are employed at universities and other facilities for post-secondary education. In addition, it is normal for colleges and universities to require the PhD degree on new first-time hires. A scholarly thesis, identified as a PhD, is now regarded as some baseline qualification among a professional historian. However, some historians still gain recognition based from published (academic) works and the award of fellowships by academic authorities like the Royal Historical Society. Publication is increasingly required by smaller schools, so such papers become journal articles and PhD dissertations become published lectures. The graduate student experience related to seeking finish a doctorate throughout the United States take on average 25 or more years; funding is scarce except at a few very rich universities. Being the teaching assistant in a course is required in some programs; in others it is a paid opportunity awarded a fraction of the students.

The Factory Revolution was the transition to new manufacturing arrangements in the period from about 1760 to sometime between 1820 and 1840. This transition includes conversions from hand production chains to machines, new chemical manufacturing and iron processing centres, improved efficiency of mechanical heating, the increasing use of steam power, the development of machine tools and the rise of the factory itself. Textiles were the dominant industry of the Industrial Revolution in terms of employment, value of output and capital invested; the food industry was also the first to learn modern production methods. The Industrial Revolution began in Great Britain and most of the big physical innovations were British.
The Industrial Revolution marks a major turning page in history; almost each aspect of daily life was influenced in some way. From particular, average income and population began to exhibit unprecedented sustained growth. Some economists say that the major impact of the Great Enlightenment was that the standard of living for the global population began to increase consistently for the first time in history, although others have said that it did not start to meaningfully improve until the late 19th and 20th centuries.

In addition to costing money, each building also has an impact on the environment above you. These impacts are often negative. For example, the land your house get built on was cleared of plants and birds. Removing plants forces native animals that lived there to move, something is bad for the environment. The wood used to construct the walls was collected with equipment that runs on fossil fuels and pollutes the air. When the roof gets replaced, valuable old material is taken at a factory. And if we do not take care of the air conditioning unit properly, the fluids needed to run it can be harmful to the air we breathe.
Let us build even bigger than a single component. As you may notice, larger buildings, like factories, require more maintenance than your house because they have more components. If a factory has five air conditioning pieces instead of one, where must apartment owners possibly track when each air flow unit needs to be used? Five components that make up a building cannot last forever.

Zooplankton are bite-sized, nutrient-rich snacks for many predators, such as fish, whales, and seabirds. These predators are fast to use their eyes to locate their food, which means that they are most effective at hunting during the day and in the sunlit surface water. However, the zooplankton's food source, tiny plants known as phytoplankton, are also only found above the surface water.
So, the zooplankton face a problem: if humans stay in the surface waters to feed, they risk being spotted. If they remain in the deep, they will be safer, or soon starve. This is what we call a tradeoff: each option ie feed or go hid) bears with it a gain, yet poses a cost. DVM is the zooplankton's clever solution to balance this struggle and have the best of both.
Much like this game of hide-and-seek, mountain zooplankton remain in the warm, dark waters during daylight hours, out of sight of their cousins. Under the cover of nightfall, they migrate upwards from the mesopelagic habitat to the epipelagic layer, wherein they will graze in the relative safety of darkness before dawn.

When people think about the Amazon rainforest, they often consider it to be the lungs of the planet, removing carbon dioxide (CO2) from this planet and giving oxygen for animals, including fish, to breathe. People also think about snakes, monkeys, spiders, orchids, and the vast diversity of life hosted by the rainforest. All of this is important, but there's more than that.
The rainforest interacts with the atmosphere on several ways, which affect the local and region-wide impact. External winds above the ocean surface bring moisture across the tropical Atlantic Ocean into the Amazon. Some of this moisture falls as rain, some can easily be returned to the atmosphere via the wet forest through the processes of evaporation and release from leaves and soil. Other of this water vapor will come back as rain right over your rainforest and some will travel on to adjacent regions. Between 30 and 70% of the rainfall within the Amazon basin consists entirely vegetation that evaporated from the air.

Scientists have shown that learning maths and arithmetic with multi-digit numbers is easier for children who speak their language with some number words. Unfortunately, the challenge is that not all children have clear number words. What do unclear number words look like? Have a look at some of the words for 97. As Basque (a language mostly common in a region in the country of Spain), they say "laurogeita<unk> which means "eighty-ten-seven" (80 + 17). In French, they say "quatre-vingt-dix-sept," which suggests "four-twenty-ten-seven" (4 ), 20 + 10 + 9 The way these number words are constructed is rather remarkable. In Hindi (one of our most popular languages for India), there are a few numbers for which people use subtraction rather than addition to build the number word. For one, for the number 29 they use "unatis," which means "one before thirty" (30-1).

Fossils are the preserved remains or traces of a living organism, plant or animal. They showed us what life on Earth felt like hundreds, tens or even millions of years beforehand! 
This is the fossil of a creature called an ammonite. Ammonites were squid-like creatures that lived in the sea 400 million to 65 million years ago. 
Paleontologists and archaeologists are scientists who dug up the ground to find fossils. When they dug in the Himalayas, they saw lots of dinosaurs. But how did the fossils a sea creatures end up on the tallest mountains in the world? 
To answer every question, we have to go back a hundred million years, when biological world was quite different. Back then, Earth had only two enormous continents: Gondwanaland and Laurasia. Between them was the famous Black Sea.
Just beneath either surface of the continents and the ground sits this layer of Earth called the outer crust. This outer area is comprised of very large volcanic plates called plates. Some continents are almost 100 kilometres thick and made of solid rock. But underneath is a layer of molten rock that allows the ground around top to move really slowly.

Unfortunately, like many other big crops, growing a foot of oil palms causes some problems! Historically, oil palm was often grown in areas with lots 500 different species. Malaysian areas have more than 2,000 species of elephants, Asian and Philippine elephants, and Malayan tapirs. Indonesian rainforests contain endangered animals like Sumatran tigers called rhinos. Large areas of rainforests have even converted into oil production plantations. Planting of oil palms accounts for 0.5% of deforestation globally. In countries where oil palm is grown, timber crops can be blamed for up to 50% of the deforestation.
Laws have been set to limit the amount of forested areas that can be removed. Notwithstanding this, Malaysia has protection, just as the "Protection of Wildlife Act 1972" and the "Land Conservation Act 1978" help preserve species and reduce impacts on the environment. 
Also, growers who are clients of an organization called the Roundtable on Safe Palm Oil (RSPO) or Malaysian Sustainable Palm Oil (MSPO) am not allowed close clear forests or areas that are high amounts of biodiversity or fragile ecosystems.

Scientists assume that we share this planet with millions of other species! But how do we know which species are out there and then can we keep track of them? Unfortunately, humans love driving lots of species to extinction and disrupting important complex ecosystems. It is now more important than ever that we understand which species are present in different places and the roles they play in their ecosystems. With this understanding, we can figure out how to protect individual organisms and their habitats. Exciting new chemistry has made it possible to identify species using DNA that you<unk> transmitted into the environment—this is known as the DNA (eDNA). Scientists are actually using eDNA to identify species in all kinds of institutions across the world. With this article, we explain how eDNA is used to detect species to describe the advantages and challenges of this method.

Two patients (also musicians) who needed bilateral surgery wanted to make sure that the side of their brains that allowed them do play music would not be affected by these surgeries.
The patients were tested for language and music. Under ESM, we felt able to investigate whether the same brain functions play a role in both speaking and playing music, or whether they were separate brain areas for each. Under test language, both patients were asked to count slowly from 1 to 30, or until told to stop. They were also asked to repeat words. While they were speaking, the doctors used ESM to stimulate small areas within the colored regions of the hippocampus to see if the patients did make any mistakes. Each of these stimulation sites was tested between 1 and 18 times. For the music portion, the first patient was asked her play classical scales for a piano piece only he knew. The second patient played chords on electric guitar. While the surgeons were performing these music tasks, the surgeons stimulated the same brain areas as tested in the words task.

Mesopotamia is a name for the area of the Tigris–Euphrates river system, in modern days roughly corresponding to most of Iraq plus Kuwait, the eastern parts of Syria, and regions beyond the Turkish-Syrian and Iranian borders. Widely considered to be one of the cradles behind civilization by the Western<unk>, Bronze Age Mesopotamia included Sumer and the Iraqi, Iranian, and Assyrian empires, all native to the territory of modern-day Iraq. In the Bronze Age, it was controlled by her Neo-Assyrian and Neo-Babylonian Empires. The later Sumerians and Akkadians (including Assyrians via Armen) took Mesopotamia beneath the beginning of written time (c. 3100 BC) before the fall of Babylon in 539 BC, when Baghdad was replaced by the Achaemenid Empire. Mosul fell to Alexander the Great in 332 BC, although following his death, it became seat of the Greek Seleucid Empire.

HIV is a virus that attacks the immune system and weakens a person's capability to fight infections. There are around four million people living with HIV, mostly in Africa. Probably two million people with HIV are under 15 years of age. Most of these children and some older adolescents/young adults were tested with HIV. Medication can help people with HIV both lead normal lives, but many young adults find it risky to tell others that they have HIV. Telling others about having HIV can help HIV get more support, reduce their chances of passing it to others, and help them take route as prescribed. Telling people about having HIV can also feel risky, though, sometimes there is a chance that those individuals might not react positively. This article presents one focusing on ways to ensure young people with HIV think consciously sharing that information, and where we can support children to make the decision to share.

A microcontroller (abbreviated MCU or µC) comprises a computer system on a chip that does a job. It brings an executable application, memory (a small piece of storage, program memory, or both), and programmable input/output peripherals, which are used to interact various things connected to one chip Any microcontroller is different than a microprocessor which also contains a CPU (the kind used within a Personal Computer ). 
First released early 1988 by the Intel company, microcontrollers began to become popular in their first few years. The extremely useful Intel 8008 microprocessor was then released, but it were still impractical because still high cost for each chip. At first controllers combined different types of computer memory on one unit. After people began to see how useful them were, micro units were constantly being upgraded, with people trying to find new ways would make them better. Cost was reduced over time and by the early 2000s, micro controllers were widely used across the world.

A microphone, sometimes referred to as a mike or mic (both IPA pronunciation), converts sound using an electrical signal.
Microphones are used in many applications such as telephones, tape recorders, hearing aids, motion picture production, live and recorded audio engineering, in radio and television broadcasting and in radio while recording voice.
Sound passes through the air only milliseconds, and as was said above, the microphone turns the sound wave into this electrical wave. Different types of headphones will turn the sound waves into electricity in different ways.
Carbon button - It is the first kind to become commonplace, being possible in most mid century telephones. Sound waves, by compressing and decompressing every piece in ice, change the level of electric current flowing in the wire, thus creating electrical waves. Its phenomenon became rarer late in the century, due in part their lack of high fidelity.

At the spreading center on a mid-ocean ridge the depth from the seafloor reaches approximately 2,600 meters (-,500 ft). On the ridge flanks mean depth of the seafloor (or the height of a location on a mid-ocean ridge above a base-level) is equal with total age (age of the current given depth is ). The depth-age relation can be modeled by the cooling of a lithosphere segment or mantle half-space. An good approximation is that the area of the seafloor at a site on a spreading mid-ocean ridge proportional to the square root of the age of the seafloor. The overall shape of ridges results with Pratt isostacy: close to this ridge axis what remains hot, low-density space supporting the whole island. As the oceanic plate cools, away from the slope axis, the oceanic mantle lithosphere (the colder, denser part of the mantle that, together with the crust, anchors the oceanic plates) thickens and the density increases. Thus older seafloor is underlain by denser material and is thinner.

A molecule is an electrically generated group holding two or more atoms held together by chemical bonds. Molecules are distinguished from ions by their lack of electrical charge. However, in quantum science, organic chemistry, and biochemistry, the term molecule is often used less strictly, also being applied when polyatomic ions.
In the kinetic theory of gases, the term molecule is often comprised of any gaseous particle regardless of group composition. According to our definition, noble gas atoms cannot considered molecules as they are in fact monoatomic molecules. A molecule may be homonuclear, that is, it consists in atoms of a single chemical molecule, like with oxygen<unk> or it may be heteronuclear, of chemical atom composed of more than one element, as with water (H2O). Atoms and bonds connected by non-covalent bonds such as hydrogen bonds or phosphorus bonds are typically not considered single molecules.

Napoléon Bonaparte (French: Napoleone Lys Buonaparte; 27 August 1769 – 5 May 1821) became a republican military and political leader who rose to prominence during the French Revolution that led several successful campaigns during the Revolutionary Wars. As Napoleon I, he was Prince of Napoleon French from 1862 until 1814, and again around 1830. Napoleon dominated European and global affairs for more than a decade while leading France against a series of coalitions in the Napoleonic Wars. They ruled most of these wars and the vast majority fought his battles, building a large empire that ruled over continental history before its final collapse in 1815. A of the greatest commanders in history, his wars and campaigns are studied at military schools worldwide. He also remains one of the most celebrated and controversial political bosses in human history.

As they were leaving the shop, Zethu saw an exquisite necklace. She wanted that piece so much! But her mother could not afford the necklace. "It is lovely, my angel. I knew I had money to buy it for you," said her mother. She was disappointed. She planned to save and buy the necklace herself. She put all her money in a piggy bank under her bed. It may use that necklace to my next..." thought Zethu. Eventually, she had saved enough money to buy the necklace. Then, everybody remembered that very soon it was her mother's birthday. "I have pooled up my money, what will I give her?" she wondered in herself. Zethu was very excited on the time of there mother's birthday. "Happy week, mommy!" she said, giving a gift to her mother. Her mother opened the book and found the information that Zethu demanded very much.

A nomad (Greek: nomades; meaning one roaming about for pasture, pastoral tribe) is a classification of a group of people whose live around different locations, moving from one place to somewhere. Among various various ways nomads relate to their environment, one can select from hunter-gatherer, the urban nomad owning livestock, or the "modern" peripatetic nomad. As of 1995, there were an estimated 11 million nomads in the world. Nomadic hunting and gathering, following seasonally scarce wild plants and game, is by far the oldest human subsistence method. Pastoralists raise herds, driving them, &/or moving around them, in ways that normally avoid depleting pastures beyond their ability to recover. Nomadism is also from profession specific to infertile regions shaped as steppe, tundra, or ice and sand, where mobility is the only efficient strategy for exploiting scarce resources.

An ocean is a large sea of salt water – continents. Oceans start very small and they join smaller seas together. Together, the oceans are like one "ocean", because all the "oceans" are joined. Oceans (or marine biomes) cover 72% of our surface. The richest ocean is the Pacific Northwest. It covers 1/3 (one third) of the Earth's surface.
The deeper ocean is the Arctic Ocean. Different water movements separate their Southern interior from the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans. The Southern ocean is also named the Antarctic Ocean, because it covers the area around Antarctica. Older experts may not use the names Arctic Ocean and Southern Ocean. The deepest ocean is the Pacific ocean. The deepest point is in Mariana Trench, sometimes about 11,000 metres (36,200 feet) deep. The deep ocean is characterized by cold temperatures, high salt, and constant darkness. Some very tiny organisms are in this part of the ocean. Wildlife do therefore require energy from the sun to survive, because you breathe chemicals from deep inside the Earth.

The ozone layer is a layer of ozone higher up in the Earth's atmosphere stratosphere, between approximately 10 m or 50 kilometres above Earth's surface.
