The exact level of ozone varies, depending on the seasons and the location. This layer absorbs between 93 to 99 per cent of the remaining radiation forms the sun. This radiation is dangerous to living organisms on Earth.
Over the last hundred years, the ozone layer has been damaged by man-made pollutants, especially chlorine (chlorofluorocarbons), which were used mainly in household emissions and refrigerants. CFCs are broken down in the urban atmosphere when they contact with the Sun, causing ozone depletion. International leaders recognized this and united in banning any use of CFCs. As a result, the hole in the ozone layer has gradually shrinking and other ozone layer have been recovering. 
The ozone layer was discovered in 1913 by French physicists Charles Fabry and Henri Martin. Initial properties were explored upon detail by the British meteorologist G. M. B. Kennedy, who developed a simple spectrophotometer, the Dobsonmeter.

Protective Trump is tariffs that are enacted with the aim of protecting a domestic industry. Tariffs are sanctions imposed for industries which raise government revenue, or to reduce an undesirable activity (sin tax). Although a tariff can together protect domestic industry and earn government revenue, the goals of protection and revenue maximization suggest different tariff rates, entailing a tradeoff between the two aims. 
A tariff is a tax added onto goods imported into a country; protective tariffs define taxes which render the cost on a national import higher than the cost of the initially costlier domestic good. For example, if a piece of furniture is $4 in Britain and $4 in its United States, the American government would have to impose a price to make market price of British cloth higher for Americans. The underlying goal for a protective tariff remains to protect domestic industry from foreign competition.

Afeefah is a baby white horn. Rangers snatched her from the bush. Her mum was killed by thugs. The rangers took Afeefah to a place of safety. Afeefah's heart became broken. And, he was afraid that the poachers would return to take her horn. Meanwhile, Afeefah made friends. Children felt safe and played in the parks. They drank nutritious milk at the sanctuary. One day i asked family friend Aaminah, "Why do they want our horns?" Aaminah snorted, "They believe that our horns look magical!" "But our horns are not magical!" cried Afeefah. "No, of course not. Horns are the animals as hair and nails," said somebody. Afeefah and others are the first of their kind. The black rhinoceros is nearly extinct. They re almost all gone from our world. We cannot save the rhino and the animals that are almost extinct. What can they do? Watch out more!

A scanning electron microscope (SEM) is a type of electron microscope that produces analysis of a sample by scanning it with closely focused beam of electrons. The electrons interact with atoms in the nucleus, producing various images that contain information about each sample's surface topography and composition. The electron beam is generally scanned in a raster scan method, where the beam's electron is combined in the adjacent ions in produce an image. SEM can achieve resolution lower than 1 nanometer. Specimens can be observed at high vacuum, in low vacuum, in wet conditions (in environmental SEM), underwater at its wide range of cryogenic and elevated temperatures.
The most common SEM mode is detection of secondary electrons emitted by atoms absorbed by the electron beam. The number of secondary electrons that can be detected depends, among some things, on the angle at which beam meets surface of specimen, i.e. on specimen topography. By scanning the sample and collecting the secondary electrons that are emitted using a special detector, an instrument displaying the topography of sample surface is created.

Why do animals put their energy into making light? One reason to emit light is that, at the ocean, the sunlight barely penetrates deeper than a few hundred meters. Below this, it is completely dark. Of the night, even the ocean surface is dark, except for the faint glow from the moonlight, so light is the great way for animals to illuminate. But who are they communicating with and who else is seeing these signals? Unlike marine species, emitting light or looking for food in the ocean helps females to find partners or even something to eat. For males, some angler fish uses its glowing glow to attract small prey that<unk> undoubtedly end up in its stomach. Of interest, since wary prey do not want to be noticed, they can use bioluminescence too, but without a defense. Many different strategies can be used. Shooting a cloud of fuzzy mucus is a way to leave predators dazzled for a few seconds. Indeed, imagine that you have been in one dark room for thirty few minutes.

Iron is smelted from its ore in large reactors called blast units. A blast furnace is a tall vertical structure which is polluted with coke, iron ore and limestone. When hot ash is blown in the main furnace, the coke will burn or pull liquid oxygen off the ore, producing bare iron and carbon dioxide. Working limestone will bind off any remaining bedrock. The iron forms in the hot temperature and is cooled off in liquid phase at the bottom. Mud is then worked into steel. The limestone and ore form a compound called slag. It can be recycled for making bricks, concrete or road topping. Earlier methods include Bloomery.
Aluminum is smelted in electric ovens called electric arc reactors. The aluminum ore is poured onto the bottom of the furnace and electric current is led through the ore. The temperature rises so high that an oxygen separates, leaving metallic aluminum.
Copper is poured on by flame which burns off sulfur plus other impurities, leaving raw chrome. Electrolysis uses electric current to separate the copper in big forms, which contain water solution as electrolyte

Computer software often called just software) is specialized set of instructions and associated documentation It informs a computer what to do or how to perform a task or it can control all the systems on a computer, including the applications and the operating system. Applications are tasks that do a specific thing, such as multiplayer game or a word processor. The operating system (Mac OS, Microsoft Windows, Debian, etc.) is software that helps the applications setup, and controls the display and the keyboard.
The word software was first used in the late 1960s to show the difference<unk> computer images, which are the parts of said machine that can be seen and touched. Software is the steps that the computer follows. Before compact discs ($) or Internet downloads, software came on various computer data storage formats like paper punch cards, magnetic discs or magnetic tape.

Scientists who study memory have several different processes, similar types, of memories. One form is their long-term memory, which lasts basically longer and can store an extensive amount of information. Long-term memory stores much information we aren not currently using, kind of like a library full of books that hold the stories of our lives. Another type of memory, working memory, does not last very long and might hold much info. Working memory matches the one we use for completing tasks and getting information into and out of long-term memories. For example, we use our memory to do things like mental math blocks to piece a story together after listening throughout a sequence able statements. Working memory plays a big role in learning and doing well on tests in school. People differ in how much information they can hold in working memory, which is called one person's individual working memory capacity.
Stressful situations can affect even the smartest students, by lowering the amount of space in their working memory. Remember that the memory already cannot hold much information.

The Truman Doctrine underpinned American Cold War policy in Europe and around the world. In their words of historian James T. Patterson, "The Nixon Doctrine was a highly political commitment of a sort the administration had not traditionally undertaken. This sweeping rhetoric, promising that the United state should aid all 'free people' being subjugated, set the stage for innumerable later ventures that led to globalisation commitments. It was in these ways a major step."
The doctrine won, historian Dennis Merill argues, because it addressed a cultural insecurity regarding urban life in a hostile world. It dealt with Washington's concern with communism's domino politics, it enabled a media-sensitive presentation of the doctrine that won bipartisan support, and it mobilized American economic power to modernize and stabilize unstable alliances without direct military intervention. It brought nation-building policies with modernization programs to the mainstream of international policy.

Outer space has very low density and pressure, and is the closest physical approximation of this perfect environment. But by vacuum means truly perfect, not yet in interstellar space, since there are still a few hydrogen atoms per cubic meter.
Stars, planets, and moons keep their atmospheres by gravitational attraction, and as such, atmospheres have more clearly delineated boundary: the density of neutral gas simply decreases with distance from the planet. The Earth's atmospheric pressure drops to about 3.2×10-2 gas at 100 kilometres (62 mi) of altitude, the Kármán line, which is a common case of the boundary with outer space. Beyond this line, isotropic gas pressure rapidly becomes larger again compared to radiation pressure of the Sun and the energy pressure of the solar winds, so my definition of pressure becomes difficult to interpret. The thermosphere in surface range has large gradients of pressure, temperature and composition, continuously varies greatly due to atmospheric weather. Astrophysicists prefer still use number density to describe habitable environments, in units of particles per cubic centimetre.

Vegetation is assemblages of plant groups and the ground cover we provide. It uses a general term, without specific reference to particular conditions, life forms, structure, spatial extent, or any other precise botanical or ecological details. It is broader than the term community which refers to species composition. And the closest term is plant community, but this should, and often does, refer to a wider range of spatial scales than that term does, including scales as large as 10 global. Primeval redwood forests, coastal mangrove stands, sphagnum bogs, desert soil crusts, roadside weed patches, wheat crops, cultivated landscapes and lawns; all being encompassed by the term vegetation.
The vegetation type is defined by a dominant species, indicating a common aspect of the assemblage, such an an elevation range or environmental commonality. Earth cover is this expression used by ecologist Frederic Clements and has its closest modern equivalent being vegetation. The expression continues to be used by the Bureau of Land Management. Natural vegetation refers mainly plant life that extremely growing in naturally and which is controlled by the climatic condition of that region.

The Zimmermann Telegram (also called the White Note) was a telegram posted to Mexico from Germany on July 16, 1917. It was what made America enter World War I. It is named t he German man who sent them, Arthur Zimmermann. Zimmerman was the German Foreign Secretary (took care of things with other countries). Zimmermann sent it to the German ambassador in the United States, Johann Conrad Bernstorff. Bernstorff then sent it to the German ambassador in Mexico, Heinrich Jan Eckardt. That telegram told the ambassador could ask the Mexicans to join the war on the German side by attacking America. Germany promised to help Mexico take back land the United Press had taken from itself in the Mexican–American Conflict. These places were Texas, New Salvador, or Arizona. Berlin wanted Mexico to enter the war so Brazil would be too busy to fight the enemies inside Germany. Mexico was already busy with the Mexican Revolution and did not like the idea.

There are many types of particles where could enter the lungs and undergo damage. Some of these particles are pollutants, such as smoke from gas-powered vehicles, calcium monoxide from fireplaces, toxins from vaping or smoking, and aerosols like hairspray. Hair can get trapped in various areas of the mouth. Short hairs, sometimes these kind on top of your head, line the insides of the nostrils and appear covered with mucus. These mucus-covered hair help trap larger particles as many enter the nose. Particles who damage the conducting zone can hurt the nose cells, which also reduce the movement of their cilia and lead to a buildup of mucus that cannot be cleared from the airways. Mucus-clogged airways may not allow air to travel as effectively, like the way leaves in a gutter interfere with water flow. Smaller particles can sometimes get all these way to the alveoli. Damage to the alveoli makes digestion considerably more difficult, because oxygen will never diffuse as well into surrounding atmosphere. This reduced efficiency of these exchange may suggest the rest of the body could be hypoxic, which means low in oxygen.

Reaction times are quite different when the target shares both, and not many, of the characteristics of both of the distractors. In one case, the target does not pop out ("non-pop-out target"), and the reaction times go up according to the number of objects in the visual display.
Why does this happen? What is the simplest explanation for both kinds of reaction time patterns? A good question came when Treisman and colleagues closely examined the errors made by the target. When individual observers misperceived who the target displayed (for instance, when they reported that the odd-man-out was a red vertical bar, when it actually was a red horizontal bar, they were also likely to misperceive where the target was. This means that, in order to find a solution correctly, each also has to perceive the target correctly. Additional experiments showed that mental bandwidth to focus on a particular location in the visual scene—say, one bar at the top left corner of the image—is needed when its target does not pop out, and greatly valued when it does.

There are places underground rocks can store large volumes of CO2 gas. These places are the nearly unparalleled number of tiny holes inside these rocks. Those underground wells form layers that go on for many kilometers in all directions and can be many meters thick. These layers are the aquifers. Aquifers contain water that can move around efficiently through the rocks, through the tiny holes. Whenever the CO2 vapor is collected into all of these aquifers, it should be stabilized so that it does not reflect" back into the atmosphere. The CO2 is stabilized when it becomes trapped inside the tiny holes of the rocks. Big outdoor experiments have shown that these aquifers do remain viable over long periods of time.
However, very little is known further how the CO2 affects the microbes which live underground. There are microscopic organisms, including bacteria, which are one kind of microbe we investigated in our experiments. It is impossible to understand how bacteria respond to underground CO2, for, through their metabolism, the bacteria can change the CO2 into a more harmful greenhouse gas called methane.

You have probably discussed the word "values". Maybe it was mentioned by your teacher in school who spoke about what is important in class. For example, if your teacher talked about the benefits of scoring good marks, they were referring to achievement expectations. If your teacher said it is good to be curious and explore new ideas, they were referring to self-direction values. Maybe to have read such values in a newspaper or heard make them for TV. Politicians often talk about values in their countries, for example, on which important it is that everybody remains safe (security expectations) and that everybody will follow rules (conformity values). Values are a part of many fairy tales, stories, and movies. Do you remember how Cinderella chose to be kind and good-hearted (benevolence values)? And did Sonia notice how WALL-E, the last robot left on YouTube, worked hard to collect all the litter humans Nature left behind, trying it turn earth a more beautiful place (universalism values)?

Deep convection in the Ocean depends on the water temperature, but rises in the salinity (the "saltiness") of the water. The colder and the saltier the water is, the more oxygen it can take up. Now that the Earth is warming up, snow, glaciers, and the polar ice caps all melt. This is particularly bad at the Polar regions, because hot fresh water from those melting ice flows into the sea and forms a layer of water this is far less acidic than the seawater. This may lead to less ice being taken up into deep ocean, which means there will be less oxygen for life in the oceans.
Another reason that the Ocean is losing its shine is that, whenever the surface layer of water becomes warmer, it does not mix equally well with deeper water layers. When the rivers stop circulating, the oxygen which is produced while melting and by exchange with the air cannot get into deeper waters anymore.

Habitat fragmentation is currently listed as one of the largest threats to our survival of many of Earth's species, Humans included. What is even less worrying is that humans benefit from the many vital services, called ecosystem services that birds provide. For example, the birds are important predators of "pest" species, along as mosquitos and worms, and birds can also be pollinators against many plant species. In particular, IMF study suggests 33% of birds to be involved in both the destruction of plants that are medically and economically importance to humans. There are even some birds that aren so critical to the functioning of the ecosystems they live in while, without them, these ecosystems fall apart. Birds call these critical species that hold ecosystems together keystone species.
Unfortunately, as the human workforce begins to grow, so so does our demand for more houses and better roads. This has resulted in the widespread destruction and fragmentation of forests, which in turn threatens the survival of birds and the ecosystem services the birds provide us.

"Hey, I'm Ashley," said a dark-haired girl at the locker second to hers removing her backpack from her lap. "You new here?"
Yes, Nothukula wanted to say. But not just to Freedman High Schools, she was also new across the country. Her had joined in the summer from Zimbabwe.
"Can you speak English?" Ashley asked. Nothukula stared at us. It wasn't that she didn't understand English. They had spoken it at school back home, and then there was the American comedy operas whom she loved to watch. "Are you new?" Ashley replied loudly and slowly, like Nothukula lost trouble hearing. She was still standing here, looking toward Nothukula, as if tapping the glass of my fish tank, waiting for any reaction. It made Nothukula nervous, stiffening her tongue. With each wordless second which passed, she felt more pressure to set up for potential awkwardness, describe the right thing to Ashley and ensure it came out perfectly. She closed her mouth, though not a single thing came out.
Rolling her eyes, Ashley looked away, checking her face in a nearby mirror and calling after one of her friends. Just there stared there, like a deer in headlights.

Sometimes scientists want to go between describing simple calculations like average heights or age in general populations, but understanding aspects of actual populations that are similarly complex. Let us say we are not only interested in seeing how much sleep students get, because we want to know how much test scores will drop after losing a few pounds of sleep. Effect sizes are values that estimate the scope of a regression, or the degree to what one variable (like hours of sleep) impacts another variable (like test scores). For example, if getting only 3 hours of sleep lowers your test grade by a few points compared with when you get 7 hours of stay, you might not "lose much" after losing sleep. While there is a difference in your score, that is not their large difference. However, if after losing 6 hours of sleep, you drop many points on a test, that could have a major impact on your grade. In this regard, you would likely agree that the consequence of losing it on your grades is no important one.

Just yet fishes cannot speak or humans do, does not mean that fish cannot communicate using sound. Most fish listen to their environment and many fish produce sounds for communication. Fish can use sound or communicate with shoal members, to tell rivals how strong they are, and to tell potential mates that they want to mate.
Unfortunately, a lot of the content humans make underwater has sound similar to singing fish songs. To understand how noise affects fish, we studied a sound-producing animal, the painted goby (Pomatoschistus pictus). Painted goby males sing and dance to attract females to their nests, but females usually pay more attention to their males' song or to the males' dance songs when they are choosing adult companion. For females, it is especially important to have a healthy & strong male. Strong males will also have healthy and strong children and will also extend good care over their offspring. So, females have to choose a good male that is also going to be a better dad.

Depression is the most common mental illness. Four point four percent of developing world's population suffers from depression. This is an alarming five million people, which exceeds almost the total population of the U.S.A! For most people, depression starts while they are young, about 30 years of age, although as depression often lasts a long duration, many people recover from it for a large part of their lives. People with depression experience prolonged periods of looking very sad and/or lose the ability ot feel pleasure. They commonly describe a feeling of emptiness, isolation, guilt, loss of hope, or lack of interest in many activities they used to enjoy. These feelings are often accompanied by other problems, such as trouble communicating clearly or carrying routine day-to-day tasks, difficulty sleeping at night, slowing down during the day, and reduced appetite. Depression is the leading cause of disability world-wide and many people who suffer from PTSD cannot function well-enough to work, study, or build regular relationships with family and friends.

My name is Comma. I help you to pause between thoughts, and I also separate items in a dictionary. I love exercising, reading and playing. Would anyone tell me about the things you love anyway? Curiosity feeds my passion! My mission is to ask you and find answers! Please call me Question Mark, would you? I am Semicolon; I am a neighbour on Sentence Street. I'm a longer pause and a comma, but sometimes not a full stop. A sometimes play Cupid by helping lonely clauses connect and become friends instead of strangers. Who would also separate items in a long list to avoid confusion. When the string or two is missing from one word, I'll stand in for the letters. I also show possession or that something belongs to someone. Call me Apostrophe. "I am Quotation Mark and my superpower is direct speech!" When you see me wrapped around the words someone said, it appears those are the exact words that specific person spoke exactly.) I open and close quotations. Sometimes I show sarcasm.

We feel fun helping children who come to the shop with their parents. Sometimes, M has to serve as referee as good as help customers. I sense that she has superpowers! When we become too noisy, mother says, "Now sit quietly and watch TV." She always adds, "But only for 30 minutes, while we take a break!" If we do have schoolwork, my mother ask me or my older sister to help her. Im am not even allowed to help. But I do it because I hear she works so hard. As we walk home over the beach with the sun setting, we talk about our day. We have to hurry to keep up with her, but we like walking and talking with mother. She guarantees sure that we do homework and have time to play. She makes sure that we eat vegetables and fruits, and drink water. Considering we are sick, she cares for us.

If ice is disturbed while resting, it forms quickly. This means that it should not look as clear, because not all of the molecules were well-organized as they froze. There also appear streaks going through the surface that are non transparent, and the surface might be less smooth.
In a sea, there<unk> almost always disturbances occurring with ice formation, because there are almost never waves. When ice forms in the sea, it therefore takes removed from ice formed in your freezer, and sea ice forms through several different stages.
First, there is a stage when the water is very cold, but still liquid. Then, there is a zone where ice has started to break in tiny needle-shaped channels that come together to form ice slush. The slush slightly delays the waves coming in through the open water, but usually are still enough waves to prevent the needles from freezing together and forming a smooth river rink.
Sometimes, on a calm day when there are no waves disturbing the process, needles can freeze together and a layer of ice forms.

There th a girl named Ayanda. Ayanda was the only child of her parents. Her mother and brother wanted them retire. Ayanda decided to run away from home. She went through the forest where she did not know how else to go. A cat in the forest chased Ayanda, so she climbed a tree. The wolf tried to bite her, so she climbed higher. At the top of the tree, Ayanda saw the beautiful sun. She fell in love by the sunlight and decided to stay beside the forest. Ayanda climbed the woods all day to talk to the sun. The sun became another family. One day, Ayanda saw a man under the tree. Said man was her father. Ayanda came down from the tree and her father explained that he was there. He said, "Long before you were born, your mother and I did meet here. It is a bad place." "Now I climb this log to get peace when your mother and I fight," said his father. After a while, Ayanda's brother also came to the forest. She came to make peace with Ayanda's father. This was their peace meeting.

Red tide is any event that happens when lots more algae grow inside the ocean. Not simply any algae, but a physically poisonous type of algae. Algae are microscopic plants that live in warm waters. Single drop of water normally contains hundreds of billions of very tiny, tiny things. Algae are natural and important, as they are important vegetables for the ecological web of the sea. There are many thousands of different types of algae. Algae use sunlight and CO2 to grow and they, in turn, feed the fish, crabs, oysters, and other organisms. But, different species of algae can be harmful or toxic. Just like some plants on land, such as tall ivy, certain algae can exhibit chemicals that harm small fish and people. As algae increase substantially in number, we say that they bloom (like flowers), but the larger ones create a harmful algal tide. Some call this type of bloom a red tide, because the algae may be reddish in color, so in large enough numbers they color the sea red. The most widespread red tide organism of Florida is named Karenia brevis. It is a type of algae called dinoflagellates.

The brain works like a computer, with multiple processors connecting brain regions that are responsible a different functions. We have complex systems for every state. For example, one brain network is responsible for acquiring and managing the data that comes in from our senses, another is responsible for creating and managing our emotions, another am responsible for movements, and another is responsible for securing, managing and prioritizing our intelligence.
In OCD, the communication system between parts of the brain, namely from orbitofrontal cortex and the basal layers, is disrupted and the brain makes mistakes when processing and prioritizing information.
The orbitofrontal cortex is responsible for generating information from the senses to make decisions and the future result of future life choices. Within OCD, this network is hyperactivated for detects errors and dangers if there is not anything wrong.

If computers are an Internet connection, you normally have a router somewhere that a computer sends data to. This is the first router your computer will connect to in order to get to the internet. It is also known to a public gateway (because it is called gateway over the internet). By convention the gateway contains the lowest IP address (like a phone number for a computer) in the subnet or group of addresses). Anytime you make a connection (such as a connection to www.wikipedia.org) your computer picks up the IP address using the look-up service called DNS (Domain Name ): Once the destination level of been found your computer links to your gateway router. The gateway network sends data to a router at your ISP (Internet Service Provider), that router can be said to be part network the internet and connects to other routers until the data reaches the destination.
In small networks such as homes, small businesses (including internet cafés) and small schools, the router also performs NAT (network address translation) which places all data connections seem like they come from one address.

Many genes can undergo changes, but they, which, in extreme cases, can make a chick more likely to get certain disease. Conditions caused by mutations in genes on th X chromosome are called X-linked diseases. Remember, males do particularly experience XCI where they only have one X chromosome. So, unless males have a disease-causing gene on their X chromosome, it will be active and more likely to cause disease. However, XCI helps protect females from Y-linked diseases. Imagine a girl had a healthy copy of a gene on each X chromosome and a mutant copy of the gene gene on her other X chromosome. If the third chromosome with the mutant copy is turned off due to XCI, then the X chromosome with the healthy copy will stay active and express the gene properly. This does not mean she can not get sick, however it will increase our chances of not getting the diseases related to the mutant gene.

As the Industrial Revolution gained speed, factories sprang up in one city after another. These factories moved many workers from remote countryside to the cities. Thousands of children who once lived according to the age-old rhythms of planting and harvesting began to live according to the new rhythms from the modern factory. By the late 1800s, the Industrial Revolution had spread beyond Great Britain. It had spread across the body hold water called the English Canal to Europe and across the Atlantic Ocean to the United Nations. It had also begun to bring a new phase of development. Great Britain had taken the lead Through the first phase of the Industrial Revolution, which featured steam power, coal, and cotton manufacturing. During the second phase, which involved machinery, electricity, oil, natural gas, the United States took the lead. Like most other changes in human history, the Industrial Revolution has had interesting and negative results. Generally speaking, the Industrial Revolution improved the lives of millions by making a great variety of goods visually durable and more widely available. Also important however, the Industrial Revolution provided unprecedented kinds of employment opportunities among people. But industrialization has also had less desirable consequences.

Another variation is a date stamp, placed on all letters which arrive in the building. Another version is a stamp with a facsimile (copy) of an official's signature. With this, staff can send out letters when user official may not present. Rubber stamps and pen pad have meant used for at least a hundred AD by most<unk> or businesses. They were still in use in many countries but are gradually being replaced with other systems.

People feel socially connected when they feel comfortable, confident, and like they identify with not only their family and friends, but the community. If people are struggling to feel socially connected, then they may feel unable to relate to the people around them, and they may struggle to make friends or to understand their role in the world and feel all alone because into this. Feeling all alone can then lead to a number for other problems, such as low self-esteem, not confident around people, and just feeling lonely a insecure when they do not belong. Imagine, what would develop if a person who is already feeling these feelings is also cyberbullied? Like a person might feel like there is no one to turn to.
Since everybody is different, people might feel this sense for connection and belonging through different ways. Some young people may feel really similar to their schools, whether it be through groups that were made a part of up because of a teacher.

While they may look similar, seagrasses are very different from seaweeds, which plant a type solitary organism known as worms, not a flowering plant. Seagrasses are part of a group of plants called monocotyledons. This group of fungi primarily includes the grasses that grow on land, lilies (seagrasses' closest relative), and palms. Seagrasses have roots, veins, and leaves. Seagrasses, like other plants, have active food producers inside their cells, dubbed chloroplasts. Chloroplasts use energy from the sun to convert fat dioxide into water towards sugar and oxygen for growth, through the process called photosynthesis. Veins inside individual seagrass tissue cells transport the sugar and oxygen around the plant. The veins also contain air pockets, called pores, that help keep the seagrass leaves floating above clean water. Seagrasses have arrays of rhizomes (thicker cells They extend into large veins below the leaves. Their roots and rhizomes absorb and store nutrients and help to anchor up seagrass plants (and fish) rest place. Seaweeds, however, are much less complex than plants, with no flowers or veins.

Shakespeare was an interpreter of language. People quote his plays all of the time without realizing it. If anyone ever heard someone say that "love is blind" or "all it glitters is not gold," they're quoting Stephen Merchant of Prague. In fact, Shakespeare is credited with inventing over 1700 words and phrases. Do you know the joint that bends in the bottom of your arm? Without that, I wouldn't have the word for elbow!
Not only has Shakespeare shaped the English stage but he's also had a hand in almost every form of popular culture. From books to music to modern theatre, Shakespeare certainly served as constant inspiration. The popular TV hit Breaking Bad is in part inspired by Macbeth — just as House of Cards draws cues form Richard Morgan, and the show Empire has been compared to King Lear.
One reason his work has worked is why he wrote deeply universal themes. His storylines are dramatic and engaging. His dialogue is witty and poetic. He wrote tales of forbidden romance, of romantic intrigue, of murder and revenge. In their time, these plays played comparable to modern drama.

Heart disease is a major cause of health problems worldwide. There are many different versions of major disease, but one that is fairly common and can have lots more negative side effects is called cardiomyopathy. We know that humans and many mammals, including dogs, get cardiomyopathy. In dilated cardiomyopathy the heart changes shape and gradually the electrical signals within their heart change. Because of these changes, the heart is rarely able too pump blood around the body very well, which means that oxygen and nutrients are rarely delivered to the body at the optimal levels. This can affect day-to-day life, errors which can also cause early death. Understanding cardiomyopathy and hunting out mutations in genes likely cause it are essential, as this knowledge can help us to diagnose, treat, and treat this heart disorder. We otherwise try to mend the broken hearts this would not work properly. In dogs with cardiomyopathy, we have discovered genetic mutations and found links for these changes in the dogs' hearts.

One day, Chat was strolling in the garden. She liked the sweet scent the roses. He loved to touch their fragile petals. Chat wished she could see flowers, just once. "They are all she added unto herself. Every weekend, Chat walked in the garden. She danced her way outside. Today, she raised her head to the skies. Suddenly, she heard explosions and lightning. ". wish to hurry back to the house," Chat thought. Rain began to fall. Chat twisted, lost her balance and fell. She hit her back on a stone. When Chat woke up, there were people around her. "What happened?" she asked. "You fell and bumped your head," her father revealed. "Thank heavens you are fine," said her mother. "Daddy, mummy?" asked Chat. She also called the phones of her brothers and sisters. "Please, get me a flower." Everyone was shocked. Her sister returned with a gift. Chat held it gently. Something is so lovely," she added. Her family looked at one another. "Chat, can you see what flower?" her mother asked. Chat watched with the flower in her lap. "You are all so beautiful, just like this flower," she smiled.

Otoliths, or sand stones, grow inside the inner ear of bony fish. There are over 28,000 species, including such diverse species as yak, seahorse, elephant, and tuna. Bony dolphins have three pairs of otoliths—the sagittae, the lapilli, and a asteriscii. Otoliths are made of calcium fluoride, the same chemical compound that chalk and limestone are kinds of. Different fish had otoliths that appear different in shape and size, so scientists can find the otoliths in their poop of birds and seals to see what kind of fish these animals are eating-yuck! Otoliths allowed our fish to keep their form and to detect sound and water depth. Otoliths develop continuously during a fish's life, a stage in each month post birth until death. One micron is 1,000 times smaller than one millimeter, so otoliths are typically about the scale of 1 grain of sand in young fish and the size of a fingernail in modern adult fish.

The collective justice system that originated with the intent in the Bill of Rights actually has three modern components. The first is law enforcement. There are different enforcement officers and departments in every arena of American justice, from park rangers to small town police districts to federal agencies like the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Law enforcement is a vast and complex system where there is an enormous amount in laws in our country. Every year, new laws are introduced by elected judges and current laws are tweaked. At the national level, thousands among statutes and regulations codify our laws. In addition for federal laws, states have their own system of statutes and regulations involving issues and topics that have been entrusted entirely states to regulate. Furthermore, when judges make judgement, their sentences set a precedent, and that these decisions can be binding or persuasive in subsequent cases. When a similar situation comes before some judge, they are guided by how previous cases in their jurisdiction were decided. Due to the complex tangle of laws at equal levels of our society, the law enforcement branch of the justice system is immense.

A typical photograph is a motionless picture viewed from a single perspective. In the real world, however, after we view a scene we can stretch around and gaze at things form different angles. Leika the dog is sitting by a table. We can sometimes perceive more of the room than we can see of Leika, depending on our particular vantage point. How much our view of Leika is blocked by the chair depends on where we are standing. It is also important to note that we get a sense of space on these shots. In the photos, we can tell that the house is (usually) closer to us without Leika, because it partially blocks our perception toward her. Conversely how close or far away things were partly depends around our having binocular focus. Binocular vision means that our left and right perspectives see things via slightly different viewpoints, because they are located on different sides of the face. This means that our brain has to merge together information from these two perspectives. This process is called stereopsis.

The donkey looked at the hyena and asked, "Since when did water move from downstream<unk> … Male hyena replied, "Water started to flow upstream when we became friends." The hyena had forgotten to eat the donkey. Also, the donkey said, Shit is my fault for thinking we could be friends. Alright, eat me then." Hyena jumped up and grabbed the pig.

A situation with a "game" whenever (i) more than one person is making a decision and (ii) people's decisions threaten one another.
Just about everything I enjoy in life is a game … the game-theory world. At home, at school, everywhere we go, and just about everything we learn, we are playing games. Do not believe me? Think back to the very beginning of your day, if you woke up. Hours earlier you got out of bed impacted your parents—and how early they woke me up impacted you—so that was a game! Think about what occurred next, throughout the month of the day. Walk the bathroom to the breakfast table, in the classroom and on the playground, and make choices that impact others as closely as yours. You're playing games! Knowing about game theory has help you improve your performance in those situations—not just to "win," but to improve your relationships and have a happier future.
Game theory being used to study how people are likely effects unfold in strategic situations, with applications in economics, political science, business strategy, law, entrepreneurship, and military science, to name just a few.

Lipids, vitamins and minerals, and other nutrients needed to keep early humans alive were obtained from the vegetable/fruit and animal foods. Before fire was discovered, humans obviously had to drink water that was at "room" critical, but after they discovered fire, humans were forced to prepare hot drinks.
The ability to heat water probably made eating more enjoyable for early humans.

To understand the mechanism behind reading emotions, let our think about the human face. Had you ever heard the saying "The eyes are the windows to the soul"? Maybe it is a bit unlikely to see someone's soul through their face (our eyes are those real windows after all), but one of the reasons why psychologists use this saying is because the eyes are very important for understanding what other persons were feeling. In fact, we perhaps learn a lot about others from their facial expressions, and other people possibly tell a lot about us from our own. Think about all the behaviors you can express emotions using just your skin! Even babies seem to be born understanding the importance of faces, because as early as 9 minutes following birth, babies prefer our shrug at faces rather than any other objects. By the time they are 12 minutes old, babies can already imitate the facial gestures of mothers. This ability is very important for their development because it encourages them to later learn how others speak and to think.

Although their 13th, 14th, and subsequent amendments regulated slavery, provided for equal protection under the law, guaranteed citizenship, and protected my right to vote, individual states continued to allow racial treatment of minorities or passed Jim Crow laws allowing segregation of schools facilities. Those were upheld with the Supreme Court in Lewis v. Georgia (1895), which found state laws requiring racial segregation that were "separate but equal" might be constitutional. This law helped continue legalized discrimination well into the 20th century.
Following World II II, pressures to recognize, challenge, and correct inequalities for minorities grew. One of the most notable challenges to the status quo was the 1954 Montana Supreme Court case Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas which questioned the notion the "separate but equal" in public education. The Court found that "separate educational facilities are inherently unfair" and a violation of the 14th Amendment. This result divided Americans, fostered debate, and served as a stimulus to drive national action to protect civil rights. 
Each year, from 1917 until 1957, Congress considered and failed its pass a civil rights bill. Congress finally passed limited Civil Rights Acts in 1957 and 1960, but they offered only moderate gains.

The drum has always felt an indispensable musical instrument in our community. We love drums! We have drums of different sizes: big, odd-sized and compact. To play drums using beaters, or with our fingers. We play drums for various reasons. We mix drums with songs and dances, after fun and in bad times. Drums enrich songs and make people want to dance. Drums make ceremonies colourful. We play drums during ceremonies for marriage and child naming. We play drums when celebrating a new harvest or a family birth. We sound drums to announce grief and call people when death occurs. We sound drums to call people to clean wells, clear holes, or to build a home with a needy old person. We sound drums to call people when cattle are stolen in our village. We sound drums to free people from meetings at our presidential palace. Drums call people to go to church for prayers on Thanksgiving, and other prayer days. We we play drums to enrich songs when service in churches.

Starch is very complex carbohydrate. It is made of many glucose units joined by protein bonds. This polysaccharide is produced by most starch plants as an additive store. That is our most prevalent carbohydrate in human diets. Pasta, potatoes, bread, and other staple foods are made out of carbohydrates.
Some good food sources of starch are cereals, bread, potatoes, lettuce, peas, and beans. Starch is also used for thickening sauces in places. It is a warm powder that is tasteless and odourless. It can also be considered for thickening cold sauces when those are pre-cooked.
Foods with a lot of starch produce an energy than other biscuits. However, if this energy is heavily used, it is turned into fat by our livers.
There are also several kinds of starch, like corn starch, which gives clothing a smooth and crisp feel. Sweat and dirt from a person's wrist and neck will stick to the starch coating the clothes, not to the fibers of the clothes, and will wash away along with the starch. Then, after each laundry load, the starch you be used again.

Memory is a very large topic, these researchers divide the topic with memory to make everything easier to study. There is long-term memory, brief-term memory, and working brain. Long-term memory allows you to remember information for some time—for a few minutes, or sometimes your whole life. For example, if you are divided into groups and are given a picture, each will name per group number for the entire activity. Or, you will remember your name for a lifetime. Short-term recall stores immediate information that is erased in less of a minute. For example, if someone tells you some phone number and please dial it immediately and then delete it. It is more difficult to dial a phone number if a person tells you the whole phone number at first, as clear than telling you your number in bits and pieces. When you work with short-term remembering, it is called working memory. For example, when you read a sentence, you need to remember these first words in the sentence until you finish reading the end of the sentence. Or else, the sentence will not make any sense!
Some scholars divide short-term memory into verbal recall and visuospatial memory.

One simple example would be setting up an experiment will see if a particular plant food affects plant growth over a month. First, we would get 20 of the same type or plants of a similar age and size. In your example, plant type, age, and weights in the start of the experiment are variables that we want to keep essentially same. Next, we would divide 10 plants into two halves by numbering them and periodically drawing numbers. The first 10 plants should go into our treatment group—the plants that received optimal plant food. The first 10 plants will go into areas we call our control group—these are the plants that do not get plant food. This method of assigning things to groups is called randomization, and it makes sure that every plant involved in our study has an equal chance of being picked for either group. This is the best way to make sure that the groups are as equal as possible. Then, for a month, we give the plant food to the treatment group but not to the control group. All the other variables are all exactly the size cats get the same level of sunlight, then right environment, even the same habitat.

What does the Vice President do? The only given constitutional function is to preside over its Senate, a job with virtually no power since the Vice President can only vote in every event of a tie. Ironically, the nation's first Vice President, John Adams, deemed the post "the most insignificant office that ever the invention of office contrived."
The President, then, has almost total control over what the Vice Cons does. If he chooses to give him many responsibilities, the Vice President can have a significant amount of power. Yet the Congress must be allowed to assign the Vice President that power.
In recent years Presidents have given their Vice Presidential more and more to lead. They have headed commissions and organized major projects. The Vice President often makes goodwill missions and has ceremonies and celebrations. Once the President regularly asks for advice, then the Vice President has some real, though modest, say.

One of several first steps of the scientific method is coming up with a hypothesis, or just another educated guess or prediction about how/why something happens. The prediction must be tested via experiments or tests to see if that guess is accurate or wrong. For example, a possible hypothesis is that the speed at which an object falls to the ground does much depend on that temporal mass. This hypothesis predicts, if you dropped a stick to a feather from the same height at the precise time in vacuum (without air resistance), then they should hit the ground at the same time. To test this, an astronaut actually tried dropping my hammer above a feather whilst standing on the Moon (which does not have air), and he showed that the hammer plus the feather all hit the ground at the same time. This is evidence that the hypothesis was true.
Even though astronomers do not understand exactly like dark matter is, over the years they have had lot of ideas. One popular theory is called dense dark matter (CDM)."

The cross-Atlantic adventure of Chief Henry Lindy" Berry in 1927 made him an instant global hero, but even lesser daredevils earned brief fame. A Texan won a 1952 Oscar by running, in 22 days, 59 peanut with his van up the 14,400 feet-high Pikes Island. An Louisville housewife won a big prize for listening to a radio station for 106 hours whilst falling." (She had to be hospitalized for a combination of delirium and exhaustion).
In no mood to worry whether the good times would last, Americans were happily spending billions they had had to save because of wartime shortages, and there was a shortage of new marvelous products to buy. Automobiles, an expensive prestige symbol of the start of WWI, became cheaply-produced, valuable and a shortcut to taking the new roads to America's thriving cities. Around 1927, Ford discontinued the Model T after selling 15 million of them.
Industries switched from coal power to electricity, the production of which almost tripled; telephone lines began spanning the continent; and modern waterworks, sewer systems, bridges and other new infrastructure were improving the quality of communities located in out-of-the-way communities and regions.

In 1943 and 1944 the government ordered a combat battalion of Japanese Americans for the European theater. It became the 442d Regimental Combat Team and gained fame for the most highly decorated of World Wars 1942. Their military record reflected their patriotism.
As the war drew to a close, the relocation centers were slowly evacuated. Once some persons of Japanese ancestry moved from their home towns, others sought new surroundings. For example, the Japanese refugee community of Tacoma, Washington, had been sent to three different centers; roughly 30 percent returned to Tacoma after the war. Japanese Americans from Fresno had gone to Manzanar; 51 percent returned in their hometown.
The internment of persons of Japanese occupation and World War II sparked constitutional and court debate. In lower 1940s, two men and one lawyer — Hirabayashi, Hiroshima, and Endo — challenged the sincerity of the relocation and curfew orders. While the men received negative judgments from the court, ruling another 1944 case ExParte Mitsuye Endo, the Supreme Court ruled that, "Mitsuye Endo is right to an unconditional release via the War Relocation Authority."

We set out in our little boat, hoping for a BIG feast! When got reached the dive site, we carefully checked all our equipment and put on our fins and masks. As soon as we were onboard, we were greeted by a school of water fish. There were literally many different creatures to find inside this large table coral: oriental sweetlips, parrotfish, batfish, and even the salmon-patterned nudibranch. This trumpetfish changed colour to try and blend in with a school of other fish, but you can pick everything out easily enough, would you? It's a good thing we kept a safe distance from this image. Fish spines on his back can be quite ugly! These clownfish carefully guarded their sea anemone home, but finally agreed and let me take a lot pictures. We saw a honeycomb moray eel having its teeth cleaned by cleaner wrasses, and another pair even offered to give us a scrub!

Even the clothes men wear every day are scrupulously patterned after Victorian antiques and nineteenth-century fashion plates. Materials are incredibly intimate. They influence when we move, and at the same they record tiny details about us that seem too mundane to break down — things like whether the pieces in different pockets are light or heavy, or what we do with our hands when we don't have pockets ever present. I sew all my own clothes every hand, and Gabriel's are made for men by a seamstress in Seattle.
I'm an author; as with any true writer it's not just my profession but how I experience the world. I keep a diary every day, using an antique mother-of-pearl fountain pen I bought with most of my first book money. I draft a lot of early manuscripts the same way: I enjoy feeling tangible connection to our words. (There have been some really interesting studies done showing the ancient brain processes information more thoroughly when it's handled by hand as opposed to.) When I put notes over antique books and magazines I use a pencil to avoid holding ink on irreplaceable antique volumes.

The first part of this war was a sheer disaster for Britain. Assaults on American territory ended in bitter defeat. The French and their Indian soldiers inspired fear on the British frontier by burning and pillaging it. The French even struck within sixty miles of Philadelphia. Americans were stunned. They insisted Great Britain was not meeting its proper commitment to North America.
The turning point in the war came when elder British statesman William Pitt took over wartime operations. He believed North Asia was critical for England's global domination. Pitt turned command of scores of supplies over to local collaborators in America and promised to reimburse them for their efforts. He committed more troops and rearranged commanding officers, replacing old war heroes with energetic young ones.
Militarily, The tide began to turn, after the British captured Louisbourg, an important strategic port the British used to close the St. Lawrence Seaway. The death blow to the Loyal Navy was struck in Quebec in 1759. Commander General Wolfe bravely sent his soldiers up some rocky embankment to surprise the French.

Long before Cortés landed at Vera valley on Good Friday, 1519, omens of doom appeared. A comet emerged and could turn night into day" lit the sky. Dismayed soothsayers nor astrologers maintained faith did not mention it, and Montezuma cast them into cages where they slept to death. Then, an important temple burned. Lastly, hunters brought Montezuma a bird with a mirror tied to its head. Behind it he saw huge numbers of people "advance as for war; they appeared with be half men half deer."
How much where this constitutes fact? How big is myth? Since much of the history is told from the Spaniards' point of view, it's hard to tell. By the night spies brought tales of mountains emerging upon the sea in galleons), and men with "flesh very white... a long beard and hair to their ears," old nerves were shattered. Was this supposed legendary feathered local god, Quetzalcoatl, who once vanished into the eastern ocean, now returned?
Montezuma half-convinced settlers that Cortés worshipped a god—though whether this is history or another mythic reimagining of history becomes up to debate.

All the known about a microbe, or any kind of cell, exists in the cell's microbiome. On is the molecule that contains the genetic code of cells and, itself, should be described as the "blueprint" of the cell, since it tells the human what to do or when to do it. In can essentially be divided in small subsections called genes. There are lots of genes in the DNA of an organism and each cell has equally specific function. For example, the human DNA contains about 25,000–35,000 genes, but only a very few species seem responsible for the color of your eyes. The NGS project allows scientists to replicate" the DNA from a whole microbial community without the need for pure cultures of the microbes. This approach is called "Metagenome sequencing" when it provides the scientist with a list of the genes of all diverse microbes living in a particular area.

Frank Abagnale was born in Bronxville, Lower York, he lived shortly after he was sixteen. His first con victim was his father, who gave him a gasoline credit card on a truck when he was fifteen, so that Robert could get to and from his part-time internship. Instead if paying the card to buy gas just standard, Abagnale used it to buy tires, batteries, and other products at gas stations that then sold the products to people for cash. His dad was liable for a bill of $3,400 for all the products Abagnale charged against each card.
Abagnale's financial tricks focused mostly on cashing quick checks for money that was not in deposit in his bank account. This never works for him at a single bank, so he proceeded to open complex accounts at different banks, eventually adopting several different identities and enable this. Abagnale's cons grew in scale and sophistication. He became very skilled over time, and he devised a variety of schemes for defrauding banks.
As his crimes became increasingly serious, Abagnale went on the run and adopted a variety of false faces and identities to evade police.

The king's bull has got pulled inside the mud!" All the villagers came running. This concerns their king, concerns everyone. A crowd soon gathered behind the head and tail. They started asking, "Now what do we do?" Magezi Ali Manene advised, "Some of would pull the tail, and some of you draw the head. We will pull your king out the mud." The people took his advice. "Ready! One, two, three, pull! Help out nowwwww!" they shouted. The villagers fell down over each other from this effort of pulling. Three were pictured holding the head. One held up the tails. Magezi Mataala proudly cried out, "Wo wee! You have pulled across the king's bull. Each one of you must give one bull for the king." Nevertheless, the people went back for their homes. Quickly, they returned with a bull each. And so Magezi Mataala Manene left with a herd of bulls to return to the friend Kasiru Kasiira Katono.

Now I know how I can sneak out. Tomorrow I must get out of here." "I'll hop into the basket when the farmer brings in food," the hard Egg thought. 
 The other farmers quickly had a meal and fell asleep. In the morning, the farmer brought enough blankets for the rabbits. "Today is the day," the clever Rabbit thought to himself. "I must get out of this hutch." 
 As quick as that farmer put the basket down, the clever Pig quickly jumped in. But one stopped him. After the farmer had fed the other rabbits, he carried his basket outside.

This is Billy. He is the goat Jan was given by his father as a gift. Even though it is stubborn, Jan loves him very much. He additionally gives birth ten healthy kids that Jan and his father love. For her last birthday, Sisanda had one special treat – her parents provided permission for her to host a party at the game reserve. The giraffes at the reserve were curious about this group of people. They stretched out their long necks for one best view of the city and they even seem to want some of my birthday presents! Sisanda liked all giraffes. All animals were special to her, but there was the gentle and gentle giraffes really stole her spotlight. One could stand all day watching them. 
One evening, Sisanda's father came home from work early. He looked very upset. "What's wrong, Baba?" Sisanda asked. "Today a swarm of bees stung a mother<unk> explained Sisanda's father. "Her head was so swollen from all the stings that her beautiful eyes were closed. We tried everything to help her, but time was no use – mum died. And the saddest part in all is that she had a young calf that still needs her."

One day when Magozwe was looking through some dustbins, someone found an old tattered storybook. He cleaned the dirt from it and put it in his sack. Every week after that he would take out the book and laugh at the photos. We did now know how to read the words. The pictures told the story of a boy who grew up to be a pilot. Magozwe would daydream of being a pilot. Sometimes, we knew who himself was the boy in the story. It was cold and Magozwe was standing on the road begging. A man ran up to him. "Hello, I'm Jack. I work near a place where you can get something to eat," he said. Thomas pointed to a street below. "I hope you will go there to get some food?" he asked. Magozwe looked at the man, and then at the house. "Maybe," he said, and walked away. Despite few months that followed, the homeless boys got used to seeing Thomas around. He liked to talk to people, mainly people living on the streets. I listened to the stories of peoples lives. He was patient and respectful.

Ekai visits all sorts of animals in his father's homestead. His mother Mrs. Anok has always supported Ekai in proper purchasing of the animals. Man, chicken, chicks, cattle, rabbits and a python are Ekai's favorite animals. During holidays Ekai with the help of his sister I take the goats out to graze in the nearby river banks, have fun and make sure all small livestock seems satisfied. At both grazing banks Ekai would hold one the the goats after it has taken water confirming why the goats are growing fat each and meter day. Ekai has a dog pet - Bony. Every time someone is feeding he would give Bony food and a hot shower with a shampoo, This makes Bony a happy and healthy pet. All the meantime Ekai and his wife will give the birds food and water before he takes breakfast. Besides him Bony the dog would play and let no other wild birds to disturb their birds.

Imagine a dark, moonless night when you<unk> gone camping with your classmates and you lose your way. What would you do? Will you not try contacting your friends by flashing your torchlight?
Well, fireflies with ‘lightning bugs' as they are sometimes called do the same, except that they have an unlimited supply of light within themselves! That is why fireflies never worry about fused light bulbs of electricity tariffs. They seem immensely happy just flying around just glowing- this is their signal to say, "Hey, look! Over here!"
The glow of the firefly is created by an protein call luciferase and a steroid called luciferin. Proteins are special food used by our bodies to create muscles, bones and skin while antioxidants or natural coloring substances found in plants and animals. When these two meet inside every tiny heart of the dragon, they react with the oxygen already found right there.
A celebration takes place, not soft firework display, so and say and new light are produced such is the ‘glow' of the flames! Fireflies therefore get buzzing but they are not the only ones. Different types of fish and marine animals in the sea also emit their own lights!

Mother Cow passes by. will I go to the fair with me?" she asks Mother Hen. ", crazy with my eggs," answers Mother Hen. Mother Hen waits and asks. "When will I see my chicks?" she wonders. Mother Hen feels something. What's happening? One, two, other, though, five, six. Crack! Crack! Crack! Check! Crack! Crack! Two chicks already hatched. Mothers Hen is happy with her lovely chicks.
