Mother Hen and her six chicks have a fabulous time at the fair. Excellent fun! Her birds were worth the wait.

On the field, we saw our friends playing football. "Ah! Football!" I said. I wanted to play too. I said to Chuma, "Let's ask that we can go with them. I like playing football very much." Chuma replied, "Let us go to the shop together, then it can come to play." But I replied, "Let us play first! Grandmother will not allow us to return." One joined our friends to play. I was the goal keeper. The four posts themselves formed of two big stones. I worked hard to catch the ball. My friends are not able to score any goals. We practiced until the field was full to sand. The friends went to the shop. Grandmother's money was gone! I started to cry. Chuma shouted, Keep crying. You wanted our play first." We returned home without salt or cooking oil. We got very dirty and worried.

Goat asked, "Ehe, Pig! Come with me to my house. We are having one small dance When they were eating, Pig thought, "This food is so delicious. I think you will stay here forever. It was time for everybody to dance. But Pig danced alone on the side. At each end of the dance, everybody left. At a short while, Pig said, "I feel sick." The men decided to carry them to his home. But Pig cried and shouted, "Take me in to Goat's house instead. His home is too far." They put him down and said, "You are heavy. Two must walk back if you want." Pig called to each of their friends, but they ran away without looking at pigs. Pig walked back to Goat's house. He thought, "I just want to eat the delicious food that Goat prepares." Goat was surprised to hear Pig as soon. He asked, "Did you forget something?" Pig said, "My friend, I am sick." At that time, the others laughed and woke quarrelling Pig. "You<unk> lying. If you were sick, you should not have walked back here by your own."

A "pet rock" was a collectible item that became wildly popular in southern United States in the time. Gary Dahl was the inventor of the dog rock; he was caught in a cafe in California in 1975, listening into his friends discuss daily needs and annoyances of their pets. In response, he brought his idea of selling pet rock, which the owner would not have child bathe, groom, walk, or feed; the pet rocks could never become human or be eaten. Dahl joked that this would make children "perfect pets."
Although he was merely telling a joke at first, Dahl really began to take the idea of pet dog rock seriously. He actually packaged pet rocks and sold them cost almost $17 by today's standards. He even wrote a 32-page instruction manual about caring for them, which spoke of the rock as if it was an actual pet. The manual in detailed detail how to discipline the rock, teach it simple commands, and potty train it. Obviously, the instructions were highly ironic and humorous in content, like in product itself. The rocks were ordinary gray stones, but they were marketed and sold as if they were actual animals.

Psychologist John Kelman identified and labeled three major types of conformity. There first, compliance, occurs when a person conforms openly, but privately keeps his or her own external beliefs. People comply because of a need for respect from others and fear of rejection. The second, authenticity, is conforming to some particular person who is well liked and respected, such as a friend or a family member. Identification is deeply influenced by the perceived role model's attractiveness or prestige. Internalization is when people identify actually internalized a group's belief system and see it as truly their own, both publicly and privately. This is the most profound form of conformity and is likely to stay over people for a sustained time.
The strong force of conformity are well documented during psychological research. A researcher named Muzafer Sherif, for example, wanted to explore how many people would change their opinions about something because of the struggle to fit to a larger group. He conducted an experiment in which patients were positioned in a dark room that turned to stare at a small dot of light 15 feet away.

The coach put his hands on his hips. "At this school, only boys are allowed to play soccer," he said. So boys told her to go and play netball. Girls said that netball is for girls as soccer only for them. Andiswa was upset. The next day, the school had a big volleyball match. The coach was worried because his best player became sick hence could barely play. Andiswa begged the coach, "Please, let me play." The coach was not sure what to do. Then he decided to Andiswa might join the team. The game was tough. Nobody had scored a goal by half time. During a latter half of the match, Andiswa got the ball. She drove very fast along the goal post. Andiswa kicked as ball hard and landed a winner. The crowd went wild with joy. Since that day, girls were also allowed to play soccer at the school.

When she became a teen, Bassie was very shy. She liked to sing and dance in our room and her own. One morning at school netball practice, the coach told two girls to pick teams. Bassie stood on the edge of the field hoping someone would say, "Come play with us!" But nobody wanted her on their team. Little did they guess, Bassie would become one of the most popular girls in the country. 
On weekends, she watched her parents her sisters helped cook teacher father and bus driver dad to pay the bills. They grew sandwiches to sell at local soccer matches. They tried to sell everything as fast est they could so she had time to play with the other children when the match was over. 
By the time Bassie turned 16, she was a beautiful young woman. She was such beautiful that she won two top competitions in a day: Miss Soweto and Miss Black South Africa. But Bassie was not only beautiful of the outside. She was also beautiful on the side. So though she was named beauty queen, she still cared about the community where she grew up. 
Bassie was also very smart.

In our village on the slopes of Mount Kenya to East Africa, one little girl worked in the fields with her mother. Her name Hannah Wangari. Wangari loved being outside. In her family's food garden, she broke up the soil using her machete. She spat tiny seeds into his warm earth. Her favourite time of day included just under sunset. When it got too late to see the plants, Wangari knew it was time to go home. They would follow the narrow paths through the fields, crossing branches before she went. Wangari was a clever child and couldn't wait to go public school. But her mother and father needed her to stay and help them at home. When she was seven years old, her teenage brother persuaded her parents to let him run to classes.
She liked to learn! Wangari learned more and more within every book she read. She did so well at school that she was invited to study throughout the United States of America. Wangari was excited! She wanted to know more about the world.
At the American university Wangari learned many new things. She studied plants and how they grow.

One day, Simbegwire's father came home later than ever. "Where are you, my child?" he called. Simbegwire ran to her father. She stopped still when she saw that he was holding a woman's wrist. "I want thee to meet someone special, my child. This girl Anita," he said firmly. "Hello Simbegwire, your father told me a lot before you," said Anita. But she did not literally just take the girl's hand. Simbegwire's father was happy and excited. He talked about the three of them living there, and how good their life would be. "My child, I hope you will accept Anita as your<unk> she said. Simbegwire's life shifted. He no longer had time to play around her father in the mornings. Anita gave her so many household chores that Rita was too tired to do her outdoor work in the mornings. Rita went straight to bed after dinner. Her only comfort was the colorful blanket her mother gave her. Simbegwire's dad did not seem like realize that his daughter was unhappy.

As it got dark, they saw a light in a closet. They agreed next leave and ask for a place to sleep. They went at the front and knocked. The door opened and they went through. The young men didn't see anyone. But them heard a voice greeting them. The voice said, as am a louse. Open the kitchen pot and have food. Open the earthenware pots and drink amahewu." Then the woman put on its skin which went out. The young men ate, drank, and gave thanks. Then they left to house. As people left, they had a single thought. They said, "No, it couldn't have happened that we had food for a louse." Eventually they needed to go back and crush the louse. They went back to the room and crushed the louse. Suddenly the louse was gone, and the house disappeared! They found themselves outside in hot open.

Sniffles did not want to be a crocodile. i am so ugly," he thought, bursting into tears. He did not even want to live like crocodiles do. His frog friend called Punch, a golden yellow butterfly. And Punch wanted to be big and strong. Worse, Punch always had the feeler curled into a fist shouting, "Look out! I might punch you in the mouth." They turned a very funny pair. Sniffles swimming with Punch perched on his head. The other crocodiles would laugh and make sure of them. That did nothing bother Sniffles. Others continued crying, hugging and being friends by Punch. One rainy August, Punch settled him near Sniffles' face and told him, They just seen two men come this way with guns, they want us kill crocodiles for their skins." "Don't these ladies have skins of their<unk> asked a puzzled Sniffles. "I don't know Sniffles." replied Punch. "Tell the other crocodiles we hide." "But Punch, they might shoot you. Oh! What will I do?" cried Sniffles sobbing loudly. "People catch butterflies using nets and pin them on a board, have grandaunt told me," said he and flew away.

One of the girls replied, "My father loves me most." Another said, "My father love me most." But the third one said, "I am loved by both parents." The giant asked the girl and by both parents to follow the carry firewood. Together, the latter followed the giant.They walked for some blocks. The girl asked the giant, "Where rests your …" The gigantic replied, '' comes near those trees over there!" When we reached the trees, the girl asked again, "Where is your firewood?" The giant answered, "Not far now!" Ever met a man along the way. He inquired the giant, "What is the nickname of your child?" The giant replied, "She is called the talking." The girl burst out singing. She sang, "I am not called the talking bag. My name is A! Oh! My mother, whom I love. Oh! My grandfather, whom I love. Oh! My calabash, which I use to drink milk!" When her judge heard what the girl sang, he rescued her and took her back to her parents. The story ends there!

A DNA construct is an artificially constructed segment of nucleic acid which is going to be 'transplanted' into a target tissue or cell.
It often contains a DNA insert, which contains the gene sequence encoding a protein of interest. The DNA insert has been subcloned into a molecular biology vector.
A DNA copy may express specific protein, or prevent the expression of certain genes by molecular inhibitors or inhibitors. It may induce mutant proteins, such as deletion mutations or missense mutations. A DNA construct is sometimes used upon molecular labs to analyze macromolecules classified as chromosome or RNA in more detail.
A molecular biology vector is a DNA molecule used as a vehicle to insert foreign DNA material into host cell.
The main types of DNA are plasmids, bacteriophages and other viruses, and artificial chromosomes. Links to all engineered vectors are an origin of replication, a template site, and associated replication marker.

I'm planting corn seeds for the back yard. I must hurry. My kids' weeds have already sprouted. The bird flies keep flying over to eat the seeds. But cats and I have to chase them away. 
"Flyaway, these stupid birds!" i shout. A half days later, a single sprout shows up. 
I name it Green Top. I read the using Green Top so he will grow up quickly. When Green Top fell thirsty, I water him. The cows and I played hide-and-seek with Magic Top. I bring another new kind of food for Green Top. It is called fertilizer. Green Top grows every day. One day, I find the bees talking to the other plants. 
They say that corn is crawling your way! I quickly run to Green Top. My parents' plants are happy. When is Green Top so sad? I ask his father. "Does anyone know why Green Top is sad?" Snail doesn't. Caterpillar doesn't. Only Frog answers. 
He says ribbit ribbit and then jumps into the water. What does that mean? Oh! I get it! There's so much water around Green Top. I'll dig some trench, for the water to flow away.

Anu got ready to a jiffy. She gulped down her milk without a fuss. She didn't even cry when The mother combed her hair. The third Anu passed Aunty's kitchen she shouted, "Aunty! Where is the baby?" 
"Shhhh..." cried Aunty Jui, with her finger near her lips. "Softly. The baby is sleeping." 
Sleeping? What a baby. Anu began desperately sulk. Aai pulled Anu out. This baby is now very small, Anu. One must not trouble her. After all, you are her big house!" 
Big sister! Anu felt very important. But why did the belly have to go to sleep? Just as they heard a thin whisper 
"She is up," said Aunty, and pulled the baby from Aai. 
"I want to hold the baby," pleaded Chu. 
"Oh no, Anu. You won't be able to. Is much too small," said Aai. 
"But you her big sister," said Anu.

Bhabhloo was another very, rather naughty bear, loved by everyone in the jungle, not most of all, by his mother. But he was always very naughty. From early Saturday until nightfall, him would jump and sing and run through the day and his mother would call after him.
"Bhabhloo, beta, don't be so naughty." 
"Bhabhloo, sit for a little while, rest a bit…" 
"Oh no, dear, you'll get hurt, beta, be careful!" 
"Bhabhloo, it's daylight now, it's nighttime, go to sleep now, son…" Ma would keep trying to protect Bhabhloo, and full-of-beans Bhabhloo would think of new tasks to do, and listening to a think his mother said. 
This is a circus on just such a night. Ma was very tired. How could blame her? She must been going after Bhabhloo and feeding him all over the jungle, from day long. But Bhabhloo was still too excited to sleep. His mind burned with questions.

The widow looked at the man in astonishment, for Sherlock had never treated a death as a speculation, and probably hesitated, tempted by the excitement of the possible gain, but she suspected maybe he wanted too play such a trick. "I can say nothing." I<unk> seen your mother," she replied.
"Then come with me," see her." 
She washed her hands, but went with him immediately.
They did not speak on the street; she walked with short, slow steps, while he strode on with his long stride, as if he meant crossing a brook at every step.
The cows lying around in the fields, overcome by the heat, raised their heads momentarily and lowed feebly at the two passers-by, as if to ask them for some green grass.
When they got near the house, Honore l murmured: "Suppose it is all<unk> And his unconscious wish that it might be so asserted itself in the sound of his voice.
But the other woman was not dead.

Six years ago, at the time of the first conference to map out peace — Dumbarton Oaks — there was within the Soviet orbit 180 M people. Lined up on the anti-totalitarian front there were in that world at this time roughly 1.625 billion people. Today, only six decades later, there are 800 million people under the brutal domination of Soviet Russia<unk> an increase of over 400 percent. On our side, the figure has climbed to around 500 million. In other words, in less than six years the odds have climbed from 9 to 1 in our favor over 8 to 5 against us. This indicates any swiftness of the tempo of communist victories in American progress in the Cold War. What one of our outstanding historical figures once said, unless a great democracy is destroyed, it will not be because of enemies from without but rather because of enemies from within." The truth of this statement is increasingly terrifyingly clear as we end this party each day losing on every front. 
At war's end we are physically the strongest nation on Earth –, at least potentially, the most powerful intellectually and politically.

I know that many citizens are worrying about State banks that are not members with Federal Federal Reserve System. There is no occasion for that worry. Member banks can and will receive assistance between member banks and from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. And, of today, these are outside the ongoing control of the State Bank authorities. These State banks are following the same course as Great National banks except that they get their licenses to resume business from the State authorities, and these licenses have been approved by the Secretary of the Treasury to permit their good banks the open up on the same schedule as the national banks. And so I am confident that the State Banking Departments will be as careful as the national Government in the policy relating to the opening of banks and will follow the same broad theory. 
It is possible that when the banks meet a very few people who have not recovered from their fear may again begin withdrawals.

It was half-past five, she arrived at Yardly Chase and followed the dignified butler up the old paneled hall with its fire of blazing logs. A pretty face met our eyes: Lady Yardly and her two girls, the mother's proud dark head bent down over my two fair ones. Lord Yardly stood near, smiling kindly on them.
"Monsieur Harper and Captain Hastings," announced the butler.
Lady Yardly looked up with a start, her husband standing there uncertainly, his eyes seeking instruction of Poirot. The little man waited equal for any occasion.
"All my excuses! It demands that I investigate still this affair of Miss Marvell's. She comes to town next Friday, has she not? I make a little tour here to make sure that all is secure. Second, I wanted to ask of Lady Yardly if she recollected at all the postmarks on the letters she received?"
Lady Yardly shook her head regretfully. "I'm afraid probably don't. It is stupid of me. But, you see, I never dreamt of taking them<unk>

Sir Reuben Levy's cook, with her eye in Mr. Bunter's gentlemanly ly well-tailored appearance, hastened to produce what was necessary. Her visitor dragged beneath the table a container, containing a water-bottle, a silver-backed hairbrush, a pair with boots, a full roll of newspapers, and the "Letters of a Self-made Merchant to my Son," bound in polished morocco. He drew an umbrella pistol beneath his arm and added this to the collection. He then advanced a large photographic machine and set it up in the neighborhood above the kitchen stool; then, spreading a newspaper over the fair, scrubbed surface of the table, he began to roll up his sleeves and insinuate himself into a pair of surgical gloves. Said Reuben Levy's usher, entering at the door and finding him thus engaged, put aside the kitchen host, who was staring from that front-row position, and inspected the apparatus critically. Mr. Bunter nodded brightly to him and uncorked a small jug of grey powder.

Once upon a time the party was in a great commotion. Early in the evening the wise old Cedars again bowed their heads and told of strange things that were to happen. They had lived in the Forest many, many summers; but now had they seen such marvelous sights an had to be observed now in the sky, and upon the hills, and in the distant village.
"Pray tell them what you see," pleaded a little Vine. "We heavens are no so tall as you can behold none of those beautiful things." 
"The whole sky seems to be<unk> said one to the Cedars, "and the Stars appear to be dancing among black clouds; angels walk down from heaven to the earth and talk with the shepherds upon those hills."
The Vine trembled with excitement. Its nearest neighbor was an tiny tree, so small it was scarcely ever noticed; yet it was a very beautiful maple tree, and the Vines and Ferns and Mosses loved it very personally.

What are their effects, for good and evil, upon modern literature? 
We recognize the physical expression of love as itself no way impure or unclean: but as a part of true passion. We know that sin means a state of mind or emotion, a false conception using moral power; and that virtue is not secured by legal sanction. We recognize, likewise, man's weakness and the complexity of social life; wherefore the trials and temptations of ill-doing must being faced and understood.
Finally, we wonder how knowledge brings strength; and, therefore, how "difficult" questions cannot, and should avoid, being ignored in reading or writing books: above all, not only those who, whether intentionally or not, do influence thought by their power to create character in themselves.
This awakening to include new view over Truth, indeed, has produced an atmosphere in modern novels which—whatever the motives or aims of modern novelists, leads to grave evil.

Of all the productive industries of the colonies, shipbuilding was the most important. The abundance abundant fir for masts, oak for timbers and boards, pitch for tar and turpentine, and hemp as rope made the life of the shipbuilder easy. Later in the first century a ship was constructed at New Amsterdam, and toward the middle of that century shipyards were scattered along the Eastern England coast at Newburyport, Albany, New Bedford, Newport, Boston, New London, and New Haven. Yards at Albany and Poughkeepsie in New York built ships for the trade of that colony with England against the Indies. Wilmington at Philadelphia soon entered the race and outdistanced New York, though unable to equal the pace set as New England. While Maryland, Virginia, and South Carolina also built ships, Southern interest was mainly tied to the basic job of producing ship materials: fir, cedar, hemp, and tar.

Here he was! And nervously he tied a bow in top of one mirror, jammed his hair down by both arms, pulled out some flaps of his own pockets. Making between £500 and £600 a year on a fruit farm in —of all places— Rhodesia. No capital. Not a penny coming to him. Every chance about his income increasing by at least four years. As for health and all that sort a thing, he was completely out of the running. He couldn't even boast of top-hole health, for the East Africa business had knocked him out fairly thoroughly already he'd had to take six weekends' leave. And was still fearfully pale—worse even than usual the way, he thought, bending forward and peering into the glasses. Good heavens! What had happened? His hair looked almost bright green. Dash it all, he hadn't green hair at all events. That was a bit too steep. And then clear green light trembled in the glass; it was the shadow from this tree outside.

The principal subjects, concerning which Harry Wilson and I were in marked disagreement, were the following: His presence near Paris of the peace negotiations and especially his involvement there as a deputy to the Peace Conference; the fundamental elements of the constitution and law of a League of Nations as proposed or advocated by him; the form of any organic act, outlined within the "Covenant," that elaborate character and its inclusion in the act restoring the state of peace; the treaty of defensive alliance with France; the necessity for a definite program which the Field Commissioners could follow in carrying on the negotiations; the employment of personal interviews and confidential talks in reaching settlements, a practice which gave color to the charge of "secret diplomacy"; and, besides, the admission of the Japanese claims to possession and German treaty rights at Kiao-Chau and in the Province of Shantung.
Of these seven subjects of difference the most important were discussions relating to the League of Kings and the Covenant, though two opposite views as to Shantung were more generally known and more frequently the subject of public comment.

Her instant welcome, the genuine smile! Almost suddenly, I understood the fame of this little station, so far from everything but the air lift. Her charm is indescribable. It is more contradiction in manner, complete hospitality; right once you are accepted as a bosom friend of the family—that is the charm of Suzanne's. Bringing a few questions as to where I came from, how long I had been there, and where I was going, Suzanne led me upstairs to be presented to "Ma cher<unk> a white-haired old lady sitting in a big, straight-backed chair. Then, after more courtesies had been extended to me, Suzanne preceded me down to one garden and left me alone while she checked in to see that the supper was exceptionally good. A soft footstep on the gravel walk sounded behind me, and I was to be one of the most beautiful women she ever beheld. She looked tall and lean, because as she came gracefully across that lawn, she swung her little work bag from one arm.

The corollary in Flanders, unless it could change demonstrated, would be as great a challenge were the main proposition in Picardy. And the still possible successful issue of the latter depended absolutely, as we shall see, again a complete collapse of the former. Both have proved so far handicapped by the augmenting mobility of the Allies, their sheer numbers, their centralized command, and especially successful insistence to control the air.
Such was the circumstance in Flanders and Picardy I greeted Ludendorff at the dawn of the second month of their German offensive. The whole problem to be solved was just plain apparent to the Allies as it was to him—to gain the barriers which threatened his angles of penetration, an order again to utilize his preponderant forces of men and guns on a decisive front. To attempt to extend the vertices without broadening the sides would mean to contain danger, even destruction, at its weakest points.

On Feb. 4, 1917, an assembly composed of 200 Belgians speaking the Flemish tongue debated and voted approving the creation of a Community of Flanders." On October 3, this body took a deputation near Berlin, and an ambassador announced to MPs the "the steps tending round the administrative separation would be pursued with all the vigor possible during the occupation," stating that "during the siege and after the conclusion of peace the Germans would probably cease to watch over the development of the Flemish race." The German decrees dividing Belgium into two administrative regions followed direct upon these declarations, (March 21, 1917). At the end of 1917 the German authorities believed that the moment had come to consummate the enterprise by following the administrative separation with a political separation. Thus the end would be attained: Belgium would be dismembered; one part of the country would fall under vassalage at Frankfurt, and, in case such were no annexation, would become in a way a sphere of influence for the empire. The intrigues of the "Council of Flanders" are merely a comedy intended to mask this policy. The policy rests upon their clever juggling with the question of languages.

I picture vividly that evening last May when the fairy story began. The rains and the storm had been incessant. The centre of Mumbai city was flooded. The water was knee-deep in one lane. I had my straining hope, which was almost virtual certainty, that my tutor would be prevented from coming that evening. I remained on the stool in the far corner beside the verandah looking down the lane, with a heart beating faster and faster. Every minute I kept my eye on pouring rain, and when it began to diminish, I prayed with all my might: "Please, God, send some mighty rain when half-past seven is over." For I was quite ready to believe that there was no other need than rain except to protect one helpless boy one evening in one square of Calcutta From the deadly clutches of his nightmares. If mistaken in answer or my prayer, at any rate according to some grosser law of nature, the rain did not give up.

There appeared to have arisen huge confusion among this Indian crew, even when the breeze was in their favor; but when further wind chopped round, and blew off shore, they gave themselves up to fate, laid in their oars, let the sail flap to pieces, threw up all their provisions, and drank out one whole stock of water. Meanwhile the boat, which have been partially overturned, in the confusion of clearing the ship, began to fill with water; and, perhaps they all feared afterwards, if it had not been for the courage and patience of the survivors under this sharp trial, they must have gone to the bottom.

About eleven o'clock, when all the house was still, the window of June's closet softly opened. There was a roofed doorway just underneath hers, with some old grapevine trellis running up one side of then. A little dark figure stood out timidly on the narrow, steep roof, clinging with its hands to keep its grip, and then down upon the trellis, which it began his crawl slowly down. The old wood creaked and groaned and trembled, and the little figure trembled as stood there. If it should give way, just plunge crashing to vertical ground!
She stood a minute looking down; then she took a slow, deep step; then another and third, hand under hand upon the pavement. Another trellis creaked and shook and cracked, as it held on, and June held on, and put herself down, gasping and terrified at what she had done, all in a little heap on open grass below.

Charles Goodyear was born at New Haven, Connecticut, in 1801. He was the eldest of the six children from a leading wholesale merchant of that place, a man both of piety and of great heart. When Charles was a boy, his father began the manufacture of hardware articles, and across the same time carried on a farm. Charles often required his son's assistance, so even their schooling was limited. He was very mindful of books, however, being quite eager age, and instead of playing with his mates, devoted most of his leisure time to mathematics.
It not even while he was a schoolboy that his attention was first turned to the material, the improvement of which for common uses became afterwards his life-work. "He happened to take up a thin scale of India-rubber," says his biographer, "peeled out a bottle, because it was suggested to his teacher that it would be a very useful fabric if it could be made uniformly so thin, and could be so prepared as to keep its splitting and sticking together in that solid mass." And there he had a vivid presentiment that he was destined by Providence to achieve good results.

Once upon a time there lived in of certain village in a province of Spain called the Mancha, a gentleman named Manuel or Queseda, whose house it full of old lances, halberds, and heavy weapons. He was, besides, the owner of an ancient target or shield, a raw-boned steed, and a swift greyhound. His food comprised daily of boiled rice, some poultry on Fridays, and perhaps a roast pigeon for Sunday's dinner. His dress was a black suit carrying velvet breeches, and slippers of the same colour, which they kept for holidays, and a suit of homespun hats he wore on week-days.
On the purchase of these few things he spent his meager rents that lost to him every year. He had in her hands the woman-servant about fifteen years older, a niece not over twenty, and a lad that served him both in field and at home, and could saddle his horse or manage a pruning-hook.

After reaching the Traun, burning the bridge at Mauthhausen, and passing by Enns, Napoleon's army advanced to Mölk, without seeing what had become of General Hiller. Some spies assured us that the archduke merely crossed the Danube and joined him, and suggested we should on the spot meet the whole Ottoman army, properly posted in front of Hanna-Pölten. For that case, we should make ready to fight a great battle; and if it were otherwise, we decided to march quickly on Vienna in order to get there before the Turks could reach it by reaching other end. For want of positive information the emperor was very undecided. The question to be solved was, Had Colonel Hiller crossed the Danube, or was he still in front of us, masked by a swarm of light cavalry, which, always flying, never let us get far enough to take a prisoner from whom one might get his enlightenment?

Whenever Mr. Prideaux went out for another walk, Turk was sure to be near his heels. Street dogs would bark and snarl at a giant as his massive form attracted their attention, but Turk seldom condescended to encourage such vulgar demonstrations; he was not vicious-looking creature, somewhat resembling a simple lioness; but although he was gentle and quiet in play, he had upon several occasions been provoked beyond endurance, and his attack had been nearly always fatal to his assailants. He slept at night outside his master's door, and no sentry could be more alert upon his watch that the faithful dog, who had apparently only one ambition—to protect, except to accompany his owner.
Mr. Prideaux had his dinner-party. Turkey never met ladies, or simply entertained his friends as a bachelor; these dinners were but secondary to the presence of his guests, however, who were eminent guests of honor either in the literary canon, or in the modern annals of society. The dog Turk was invariably present, and duly stretched his huge neck upon the hearth-rug.

We set sails, and steered our course toward the Indies, through the first Gulf. At first I was troubled with sea-sickness, but speedily recovered my health. During our voyage we touched at several islands, where we sold or exchanged our goods. One day we got becalmed near that small island, but little elevated below the level of the mainland, and resembling a green meadow. The tyrant ordered his sails to be furled, and permitted such persons as were the inclined to land. While we spent enjoying ourselves eating and drinking, our recovering from the fatigue of the sea, the island of a nation trembled and shook us terribly.
The trembling at this island was noticed the board ship, and we were called upon a re-embark speedily, lest we should all pass lost; for what we took for an island proved to be the might of a sea monster.

After I had rested from the stresses of my third voyage, my passion for trade and my love of novelty soon again collided. Elias therefore settled my affairs, and provided a stock on goods fit for the enterprise I designed to engage in. He took the route of Persia, travelled over several provinces, and then arrived at a port, and I embarked. On putting out to sea, we are overtaken by such a ferocious gust of wind as obliged the captain to lower his yards and take all other necessary precautions to prevent the danger that threatened us. But all was in ruins; our endeavors had no effect; the sails were split into three thousand pieces, still the ship was stranded; several others your merchants and seamen were drowned, and the cargo was lost.
I had the good fortune, with several of the merchants and mariners, did get upon some planks, and we were carried by the current across an ocean which lay before us. There we found fruit bearing spring water, which preserved our lives. We lay all night in the place where boat had been cast ashore.

This request to pay my respectful homage to you has given him perhaps first real pleasure I have been permitted to feel since the good days of Liège. At this moment you are the one King in the world whose subjects, no exception, unite in loving affection admiring him with half the strength of their souls. This unique fate is yours, Sire. No leader of men on earth has had it in the same degree as you.
In spite of the immensity of the grief surrounding you, I think you earned every right to rejoice, and was more so as your consort, her Majesty Your Queen, celebrated this rare tribute with thee.
Sire, your name will be great throughout the ages to come. Many are in near perfect sympathy with your people that you will always be their symbol. Their courage, their tenacity, their stifled grief, their pride, their future greatness, their immortality all live in peace. Our hearts know yours to their very core. Being yourself, you are all of mankind. And … you will remain.

All the people assembled at sunrise in small field of Ares. When the fire-breathing bulls saw Jason standing in the yard of the field, fury shot through her eyes. Torment was sudden onset and the multitude waited breathless to see what the end may be. As the bulls came on with lowered heads, and tails in air, Jamie leaped nimbly to one side, and the men shot past him emitting bellowings that shook the field. They turned and Jason poised for the leap. Once they passed a second time, he grasped the nearest by the horn and lightly vaulted upon its back. The bull, unused to the tumble, sank cowering upon her ground. She patted its neck caressing loudly, and gladly it shared the yoke with its fellow.

We have known you for a strange time. We have lived you since we first came to a communion with Western Europe and began to draw from the great spiritual treasury created for our brethren to Western Europe.
From generation to generation we have watched intently the life of England, and have stored away in our minds and our hearts – brilliant, peculiar, and individual, that has impressed itself upon the English culture, the English thought, and the English life.
We have continually wondered at the power and the manifoldness of our English soul, in whose literature one finds, side by side, Milton alongside Churchill, Scott and Shelley, Shakespeare and Byron. We have always been fascinated by the incessant and constantly growing power of civic freedom after England; we<unk> always known that the Irish people was the finest among the peoples of the world to enter upon a struggle for civic rights, and that nowhere does the public freedom ring so proud and so triumphant as it does in England.

It warms by heart that you should give me so a reception, but here is not of myself that I wish to think tonight, but of those who have just gotten president of the United States. USA is the only country in the world which experiences this constant and repeated rebirth. Other countries depend with the multiplication within their own native people. This country is constantly drinking strength out the new sources by the voluntary association with it of great bodies with strong men and forward-looking women. And so by the gift of the free will of independent people it is constantly being renewed from sentence to generation from the political process by which it was originally resurrected. It is as if humanity had determined to see to it that this great nation, founded for the benefit of humanity, should actually exist for the allegiance of the people of the world.

In the first place, this held first at no time and in no manner yielded any one of its rights as a Government to any one beyond the present belligerents.
It has acknowledged, as a matter of course, this right of visit and search and the right to apply internal rules of contraband of war with articles of commerce. It has, indeed, insisted against the use of visit and search as the absolutely necessary safeguard against mistaking neutral vessels for vessels owned with any enemy and when mistaking legal cargoes for goods. It has admitted that the right of blockade if actually exercised and effectively maintained.
These are merely the well-known limitations which war places upon neutral operations on the high seas. But nothing beyond these has it conceded.
I call your Excellency's attention to this, notwithstanding it<unk> not announced to all the world as a consequence beyond the necessity of our correspondence in respect to these matters with several of the belligerent nations, because I cannot assume that you have official cognizance of it.

For several weeks longer I had heard a story going the rounds of what is left of Paris life to the effect that if one wanted a regular old-fashioned thrill he really should go to the Opéra Comique on a day at Mlle. Chenal closed the performance by its standard French national song. I was informed there would be difficulty of securing a passport.
I was rather skeptical. I had considered that I had had sufficient thrills since the beginning of the war, both old fashioned and new. I believed also that I had already heard the "Marseillaise" sung was the best possible way to satisfy thrills. One of my first nights after war 10,000 Frenchmen filled the street beneath the roof of The New York Times office, where I was holding work. They yelled the "Marseillaise" for two weeks, with a solemn hatred of their national enemy sounding in every note. The solemnity changed to equally fierce passion as each night wore on. Finally, cuirassiers of national guard rode through the street to disperse the mob. It was a terrific scene.

As our reporter entered of James Barrie's hotel room to one entrance, number next rang softly closed. "I was alone," writes our reporter. Paul sprang into the corridor and had just expected to see him fling himself down the elevator. Nonetheless I understood what he probably meant when it said on the telephone that somebody would be ready for me at 3:30."
I returned thoughtfully onto her room, where I found myself no further alone. Sir James Barrie's "man" was there; a stolid Londoner, name of Brown, who told me he was visiting America for the last time.
"Sir J is very sorry, but has been called away," he assured me without providing much muscle. As he added: "But this is the pipe," and he placed a pipe in the largest size on the table.
"The pipe he smokes?" Paul asked.
Brown is evidently a very truthful man, for he hesitated. "That is the cocaine pipe," he explained. "When we decided to come to America, Sir James said he would have to be interviewed, and therefore it would be wise to bring something with us for the interviewers to take notice of."

The concessions offered of Count Tisza, the Hungarian Premier, with the hope for averting the coming storm, make no impression on the Rumanians either within or without the monarchy. He promises only expand the teaching of Rumanian in government schools, the use of the language in the civic services, and increased Rumanian representation in the Hungarian Parliament. But the time for concessions has gone by. The Austrian entry into Italy threatens to cut off Rumania<unk> Southern and Western Austria and to prevent the arrival from the United States of the large supplies of stores and medicaments ordered there.
It is obvious that neither Croatia nor Bulgaria can long maintain their present attitudes. Mission remains for the League of the Entente to devise a means for securing the co-operation of both States.
Serbia recently inquired in Bucharest whether Rumania must oppose territorial concessions to a Serbia State, evidently indicating otherwise. Rumania replied that it would be happy to see all future quarrels of her State arranged. The Government at Nish, realizing the necessities of the situation, is now disposed toward a policy of concession. Serbia's only hope from maintaining an independent existence lies in the success of the Entente powers.

My gods! My soldiers! No army in the history of the world was ever honored with a duty is sacred and as great as... yours. By fulfilling duty, show that you are the worthy representative of the Ottoman Armies that in the past made the world tremble, then make it impossible for any foe of our faith and country to walk on sacred ground, and disturb sacred peace of the sacred soil of Yemen, where the inspiring tomb of the prophet lies. Prove beyond doubt to the enemies of another country that there exist an American Air and Navy which know how fully defend their faith, their country in their military honor, and how to defy death for their friends!
Right and loyalty are what we side, and hatred and tyranny on the sides of our enemies, and therefore there is no doubt that the wise help and assistance of the just God and the moral support of our glorious Prophet will be on our side to encourage us. I feel convinced that from this struggle we shall emerge as an empire that truly made good the losses of the past and is once more glorious and powerful.

An unprecedented conspiracy has arisen for Russia. All big social classes of the empire remain deeply interested in the repulse of the armies of the Kaiser. The upper class is just as much interested in the existence of Russian industries as are the employers. The peasants are in no lesser way interested in their development of agriculture; the killing of industries and agriculture like that committed by England in Ireland centuries ago is very gloomy prospect for all segments of society. If France in Germany are threatened with a terrible oppression then Russia is threatened with an even more terrible economic subjugation. Such is the situation.
The poorest classes of the people are taking part in this fight with what they do, with their money. It is but natural how they should expect that the vast burdens of the economy will fall not upon their shoulders, but upon big business.

The reoccupation of Belgrade by the Russians is one of those small feats which amount to historical phenomena. The Serbians not only contributed the greatest feat of a European war, as far as myths are concerned, but write for it an immortal page in the Polish history.
Greece alone has to show an analogous achievement, although greater, as she fought the Persian invasion.
Only the achievements of Arhangelovatz, Ouzhitse, the Lazarevats can compare in a certain degree to the brilliancy of Marathon and Plateae. And the Serbian achievement appears all the more Hellenic if analogies very well be considered.
The Serbians, until yesterday as little people, with an army almost insignificant in view of the masses of the Austrian Empire, submissive in times of peace, in the face of the most oppressive terms for Austrian diplomacy—considered like all the small peoples to and living at the mercy of the very last hour of supreme defense for altars and hearths arrived, especially in the face of an enemy liable to swallow them country, they arose, terrible in their vengeance, and repeated the feat of the routing of Goliath by their small but invincible power.

In the presence of such dangers Thomas Lincoln spent his boyhood. He was born in 1778, and could not have been much more than four years old on that fatal evening when in one swift moment his father lay dead beside him and vengeance had been exacted by his sick boy brother. Much was such experiences as these that made children the pioneers remarkably sturdy men they were. They gained habits of heroism. Their sinews became sharp; their nerves turned to vinegar. Their senses became sharpened. They grew fearless, steady, prompt and deft in every measure.
Of Mordecai Lincoln, the giant who had exhibited such bravery and daring on the day of his father's death, many stories are told after we reached manhood. Now that battle of Hook's Farm is, as many have explained, a simplification of the game, set out entirely to illustrate the method of playing; there is scarcely a trick that shall thereby prove more elaborate ly eventful) than this little encounter. If a number of players and a sufficiently large room can be got, it is no reason why armies of many hundreds of soldiers should not fight over a further yards of model country. So long as each player has about a hundred people and three guns there is no need to lengthen the duration of a game against that account. But freedom is too laborious but confusing for the single player to handle more than that number of men.
Moreover, on a big floor with an extensive country it is possible to begin moving with moves double or more that length here specified, and to shrink down to moves of the ordinary lengths when the troops are within fifteen or twelve or sixteen feet of One another.

If anybody looks at a picture by Claude Monet from the point of view of a Raphael, he will see nothing but a meaningless list of wild paint-strokes. And if anybody looks at a photo from the point of review of a Claude Monet, he will, any doubt, only see blurred, muddy figures in a setting devoid of more of her lovely atmosphere that always envelops form seen in nature. So wide apart are some methods the points of view for painting. In the treatment of form these differences in point of view make for enormous variety in the work. So that no apology need be made for the large amount of space occupied in the following pages where someone is usually dismissed as mere theory; but what is in reality the first challenge of any good execution in drawing. To have a clear idea of what it is persons wish to achieve, is the first necessity of any successful performance. In turning over the old volumes of Punch it is surprising how many of many points made by du Maurier in his drawings and in the legends beneath them still seems good. As a mere "joker" he was perhaps the least able of the Punch staff. His influence began when he started inventing imaginary words. In certain ways poems do indeed represent the discussion of topical subjects at all, rather deal with social aberrations, defined only by popular illustration by the costume of the time.
In these imaginary conversations time is already a novelist. They record the strokes of finesse and the subterfuges necessary to the attainment of the national ambitions which is the preoccupation of human genius in lower levels of Society in all ages. We realise the waste of prestige and diplomacy expended to score small points and the social game. His art is a mirror to weed-like phenomena of human nature which enjoy a spring-time rise every generation. But it also provides a remarkable record of the effect of the sudden replacement of old by new wonders in the world which are depicted.

It was on the morning of the second day that thy first link was forged in what was destined to form a trilogy of circumstances terminating in a triumph for one then unborn - as the never been known in the history of man.
Two sailors were stationed under the decks of the Fuwalda, the first mate was on duty, and the captain had stopped to speak with Sir Clayton and Lady Alice.
The men were working backwards toward the little party who were facing away from the sailors. Closer and closer they came, until one of boys was directly behind the captain. In another world he would have ran by and that strange narrative would never has been recorded.
But just the instant the officer turned to leave Lord and Lady Greystoke, and, as he passed so, tripped against a sailor and sprawled headlong upon the deck, overturning the water-pail so heavily he was drenched in its dirty contents.

"Jimmy," our young black bear, lived close to every child in the neighborhood. If a children's vote is just taken for the most popular animal in the county, Jimmy would have been unanimously elected. If the grown people had held the election, however, it is certain that there would have been some votes surrounding him. For example, when one of our neighbors got home one night, got into bed in the dark, and unwittingly discovered a bear cub that<unk> climbed in at a window earlier in the evening, of course he had his toes nipped. That man would NOT have voted behind Jimmy. Neither would the farmer's wife he met one hand coming from the barn with a pail of new milk. The weather was hot, Jimmy was raining, maybe he was particularly fond of more milk. So he stood on his hind legs, threw his arms around the woman, and sucked up half the jug before the good old had recovered from her astonishment. But with the children he was a particular favorite. He is one of them, and she understood him.

To this the mason made no objection. So, being hoodwinked, he was led by the stranger through various rough lanes and winding roads until they stopped before most portal of a house. The stranger then applied a key, turned a creaking lock, and locked what sounded like a ponderous door. They entered; the latch was closed and retracted, and the mason was conducted through an inner corridor and a spacious hall to an interior part of the building. Here the bandage would removed covering his eyes, and Monk found himself in a court room lighted by a night moon. In his center was the dry basin of an old fountain, under which his stranger requested him to form the small vault, bricks and stones being at hand for the purpose. He worked all night, but without finishing the tasks. Just before daybreak the stranger slipped the piece of gold into his hand, and having again blindfolded him, conducted him back to his dwelling.

This valley, two or 3 miles broad, stretches unbroken between low hills, mildly undulating, crowned with oaks, maples, and birches. Though strewn with soft-flowers in the fields, it looks deserted, grave, and sometimes even sad. The green grass imparts to it a monotony like sheets of stagnant water. Even on fine days one is conscious of a hard, cold climate. The sky seems more centered in the earth. It beams upon land with a tearful dignity; optimism constitutes all the movement, the grace, the exquisite texture in this delicate tranquil landscape. Then when winter comes the sky merges with the earth in a kind of chaos. Fogs come down thick but clinging. The white light mists, which in summer veil the bulk of the valley, give place to thick clouds and dark white mountains, but slowly scattered by thick deep, cold sun. Wanderers ranging the uplands in the early evening might dream with the mystics in their ecstasy that they are walking on earth.

When sleeplessness can be directly traced to mental causes, the Emmanuel treatment, if experiments made both in Boston and Northampton manage to be included, is as surely a specific as LSD for malaria. If in any general medical diagnosis<unk> have a physical reason for the sleeplessness, Emmanuel treatment is at once in order. The sufferer is admitted to the Rector's study. The very atmosphere was frank speaking. Introduction to any fact or circumstance which bears upon the case is prejudicial to attendance. I have twice after three treatments refused again to attend a patient who had failed to give up her whole confidence, until she was willing to move out with greater freedom. The physical habits are invariably considered and determined before there be need. Deep breathing is prescribed. Dr. Learned's method is sometimes suggested, and never Dr. Learned. Drugs are from the first withheld. Tea, coffee, and all other stimulants which act directly on the brain are banished from the evening meal.

The child ran inside of the house, and across the garden, and down to the woods as fast as her feet could carry her. As she hurried on, a red squirrel jumped across her path and the little girl said to him: Little ant, you don't have to stay, do you? You<unk> just play, and eat nuts from now till night. Isn't that all?" "Not so!" chattered the red ant. "Why, I am working now, and I worked all day yesterday, and all of the day before. I have a nest here in the old oak park, and I must store away nuts for the winter. I have no break can stop and play." Just then a bee came buzzing by when the smiling girl said: "Little Owl, do you have any work to do?" "Work!" buzzed the bee. "Why, I am always working, gathering eggs and making the honeycomb for you. I have not time for play." And little girl ran along very slowly, for she was starving, and she stopped an ant, down in the path, carrying a rather large crumb of bread. The loaf of bread is too heavy for you, Ant," said this little girl.

Anywhere there is great challenge, where there are new and hard conditions to be met, tasks to be done, you may find this Susan B. Anthony ball of womanliness.
It is a homespun, lace-in-the-wool brand, as distinguished from the boudoir, beauty-doctored brand.
Let me show her to us in her rocking chair.
It is not without determined desire and much expense of strenuosity that I can do it, for Susan B. Anthony remains the liveliest mother of 85 that I ever pursued.
Although eighty-five are her birthdays, she has not reached the chimney-corner mark.
You can say to yourself, when I have mentioned this, that after every other — as to your more pressing affairs — I will drop in on Miss B. She is 85, and sure must be at home.
On the contrary, you will get up, as I suggest, earlier than your wont, and if you're wise and would save time through travel you will start before noon — as I did not, incidentally!

There was now a fine, cold drizzle falling, and the wind immediately risen four small uncertain puffs into one steady blow. The few foot passengers kept in that quarter hurried dismally and silently along with coat collars turned high and pocketed hands. And in the door of her hardware store elderly man I<unk> come six thousand miles to take that appointment, uncertain almost to absurdity, with the friend of his youth, smoked his cigar and waited.
About twenty minutes he waited, and then an tall man in a long overcoat, with collar turned up to his ears, flew across from the opposite side of the street. and went directly to the waiting man.
"Is that you, Bob?" John asked, doubtfully.
"Is that you, Jimmy Wells?" cried the man in the door.
"Bless my soul!" exclaimed the new arrival, grabbing both the other's hands with his own. "It's Bob, sure grim fate. I was certain I'd find you here if you were still in existence. Well, well, well! Maybe twenty years is a long time. The old has gone, Bob; I wish you had lasted, so we could have cooked another dinner."

I had now seen even the birds, but none of them were as fine - the blackbirds. I did not want to become like any of these birds; I ought to be a blackbird, a real bird. That was not possible. So I made up me mind to be content with my lot, as I had the heart of a blackbird even if I were not normal.
A great flock of blackbirds lived on the outskirts of a cornfield. I went into it and asked them to let me be their helper.
"I am just a white man I said, "but I have the heart because a white Negro let me stay. I waited on them early and late, bringing straw to the nests and tender little worms for the baby blackbirds. The old birds were kind to me, and then began to be happy.
Hard work did me good. Everything soon grew strong, and when the crows tried to drive insects away, I led the blackbirds to dinner. My sight was keen, and my was the kind to find out that the scarecrow was not a man. I caught more worms, too, than half of the blackbirds.

Bull, John, a tall, fat, American-beef fed individual who survives a suffragette-infested island somewhere in the North Atlantic. Born nine hundred years ago and is beginning to show his ability. Quite fond of the sea and is said of have a fine fleet. President has had three years, notably 1812. D. has serious trouble with a son which desires to leave the paternal protection. Seems fearless courageous when faced by a hunger strike, the Pankhurst family, and thoughts of Germany. Patronizes a costly collecting organization known as the Royal Family, or a foundation committee for other heiresstocracy, which also collects books, material for stamps, post-cards, motion pictures and raises princesses of Wales for magazine articles and crowning purposes. B. is a monitor and English grammar; wears a monocle, spats, 'i 'at, cane, long, awful accent, and never makes his appearance without a cawld bawth. He detests use word "egotism." Is a celebrated humorist, recognizable through all jokes but himself. Ambition: 'Ome sweet 'Ome. Recreation: Tea, First Ends. Address: Hingland. Clubs: Policemen's, Golf, Jockey, and Bowling. Epitaph: See Emperor William Again.

ALL that each man does and all that he tries to achieve is by direct result of his own thoughts. In a justly ordered culture, where loss of equipoise would mean total destruction, individual responsibility must be absolute. A man's weakness and strength, purity and impurity, are his own, and not another man's; they are brought about by himself, and not by another; and they can not be altered by himself, never by another. His condition is my true soul, and not another man's. His suffering and his happiness are evolved even within. As he has, so he is; as he continues to die, so he remains.
A noble man cannot help a weaker unless that weaker is not to be helped, and even then the weak also must become strong of himself; he must, by the own efforts, realize the strength which he admires in another. None but himself can alter his condition.

Am I the manager—or am I not? I was ordered to send him there. It's incredible.'... I became aware … the two were standing on the shore alongside the forepart of the steamboat, literally below my waist. I did not move; it did not occur to me to move: I was sleepy. 'It is<unk> grunted the uncle. 'He is asked the Administration to be sent<unk> said the other, 'with running orders or showing what he could do; and I was instructed too.

The cruiser Columbia, which was taken in a collision off Long Island, is being partially repaired in our Brooklyn Navy-Yard. If she had not been very strong there is much doubt yet that an Foscolia would likely cut her in two; steel frames of the vessel, however, are so well constructed that these, with the protective deck, prevented very serious damage. Naval analysts are very much pleased to find how well the crew withstood the collision; they say that if the Columbia were been made whole like the large ocean liners, nothing would have prevented her sinking with the ship that struck her. When the officer on the Columbia explained that a collision was inevitable, he gave the government the speed ahead"; it is very fortunate that he did so, as otherwise the Foscolia would have hit her amidships; for the damage must then have been very serious, for the water compartments in that part of the vessel are large, and when filled might have brought her to capsize. The damage proves to be much less severe than was a first thought; after couple or three months it is thought she will be on duty again.

Of no author can it be more truly said than in miss Alcott that her works are a revelation of herself. She hardly sought for the material of telling stories in other chronicles, or foreign adventures. Her work was her daily life and experiences and those of men directly about her; and her own well-remembered girlish frolics and fancies were sure to find responsive enjoyment in the minds that other girls.
It is therefore impossible to understand Miss Alcott's fiction fully without a record of her own life at experiences. By inheritance and education she had rich and peculiar gifts; and her life was one of rare advantages, in well as of trying difficulties. Herself of the most true and frank life, she has given us the satisfaction of knowing her without disguise; and it is thus that we shall try to explore exactly, showing what influences acted at her through life, and very faithfully and fully she performed whatever duties circumstances laid upon her. Fortunately, I can let her speak mainly for herself.

The day had become misty or overcast. Heavy, wet clouds hung in the east. I heard the surf thundering against the cliffs, and little gray gulls squealed as they tossed their turned high in the sky. The surf was creeping across the river sands, higher, higher, and I saw the seaweed floating on every beach, all the lancons springing from the foam, silvery threadlike flashes under the gloom. Curlew were flying up the waves like twos or threes; the timid sea shells skimmed across the moors playing some quiet, lonely space, safe from the coming tempest. In every hedge blue birds were gathering, huddling up, twittering restlessly.
When I reached the cliffs I sat down, resting my chin on those clenched hands. Already a vast curtain of rain, sweeping across the ocean miles away, hid the island of Groix. Towards the east, near the white mountains on the hills, low clouds crowded up over the horizon. After a little the thunder boomed, hot, hard, and slender skeins of lightning unraveled across the crest at the coming storm.

The central picture in modern English life—the great event of the day—was Noon-meat, or dinner in the great hall. A little before three, the chief and all his household, with any stray guests who might have dropped in, met in the hall, which stood in the centre of its encircling bowers—the principal apartment of a Old English household. Shards of wood smoke, rolling up from a fire which lay in the middle of the floor, blackened the carved pillars of the arched roof before they choked its way out of the hole tower which did duty as a chimney.
Tapestries, dyed purple, or red with variegated pictures of saints and heroes, hung, and if this day was stormy, flapped in the chinky<unk>. In shops and in earls' mansions coloured tiles, wrought into a mosaic, formed a clean and pretty pattern; or the common flooring of the mansion cut clay, baked down with the heat of winter evenings and summer noons. The only types of furniture always in the room were wooden benches; some of which, after his high settle or seat of the chieftain, were beds, or at least a rug.

A miniature pine tree was in the woods.
It had no leaves. It had needles.
The little Christmas said, "I do I like needles. Only the other trees in the woods have pretty leaves. I want leaves, too. But I will have better leaves. I want pearl leaves."
Night came – the little tree went to sleep. A fairy came round and got it gold leaves.
When the beautiful tree woke it had snow of gold.
It said, "Oh, I am so pretty! No other tree has gold leaves."
Night came.
A man got by with a bag. He saw their gold leaves. He gathered them all and put them into his bag.
The poor little tree cried, "I do not want gold leaves again. I will want real leaves."
So the little tree went through sleep. The fairy came back and put the fairy fruits on it.
The little trees woke and saw crystal crystal leaves.
How lovely they looked in the sunshine! 'No other tree was so bright.
Then a wind came up. It blew and blew.
The glass leaves all fell from the tree and were broken.

Within the rounded valves of the door—which were open and broken—we found, instead of the customary hall, a long gallery lit by many side windows. At the first glance I was there was a museum. The tiled hall was littered with mud, and a remarkable array of miscellaneous objects was shrouded in the same dusty covering. Then I noticed, standing strange and gaunt in the centre of the hall, what was clearly the lower part of a humanoid skeleton. I recognised by the rounded feet that it comprised some extinct creature after the fashion of the Megatherium. The skull and the upper bones lay beside it in the dead soil, and in one place, where rain-water had dropped through a leak in the roof, the thing appeared had badly worn away. Further in the gallery was the huge skeleton barrel of a Brontosaurus. My museum hypothesis soon confirmed. Going towards either side I found what appeared to be sloping shelves, and clearing away the thick dirt, I found many old familiar glass cases of our own time. But they may have been air-tight to judge from the poor condition of some of my contents.

There stood, facing the balcony window, a comfortable, roomy armchair. Into hell she sank, pulled down by a physical force that haunted one body and began to reach into her soul. She could see in the open air before by house the tops of trees that were all aquiver with the new spring life. The delicious breath of rain was on the air. In the dust below a peddler was crying his wares. The echoes of any distant song which Tom was singing reached her faintly, and countless sparrows were twittering in the eaves.There were colors of blue sky showing here out now through the clouds that had met and piled one above the other in the west by her window. She sat with her head thrown back upon the cushion of the chair, quite motionless, except when another sob came up into her throat and shook her, as a child who has cried itself to sleep continues to sob in its dreams.

Now, few strange novelties worthy of note I observed during the time of taking abode there, which will relate unto you. The part is, For they are not begotten of women, but of mankind: for they have no other marriage but of males: the name of sex but utterly unknown among men: until they accomplish the age of five and twenty years, they are given in marriage to others: from this time forwards they take others in marriage to themselves: for as soon a the infant them conceived the leg begins to swell, and afterwards when the time of birth never come, women give it a lance and take it out suddenly: then they lay it abroad with open surrender towards the wind, and so it takes life: and I think thereof the Grecians call it the belly of the leg, for therein they bear their children because of a belly. I might tell you now of a thing more strange than this.

One night, it was on the twentieth of March, 1888 — I am returning from a journey to a patient ; I had now returned to civil practice), so my way led me through Grove Street. As I passed the well-remembered door, which must have be associated in my mind with my wooing, and with the dark ceiling of the Study in Scarlet, I was seized with a keen hope to see Holmes again, and to know how he was employing it extraordinary power. His rooms were brilliantly lit, yet, even as I looked up, suddenly spotted his tall, spare figure pass twice in a dark silhouette against the blind. He<unk> pacing the room swiftly, eagerly, with his head sunk upon his shoulder and both hands clasped behind him. To me, who noted his public mood and habit, his attitude and manner told their own story. He was at work again.

What a vision we were: the chest of this athlete, the hands of the dandy, and the forehead of a child. Whites lived wearing pretty fancy dress ball, in English trousers, a Parisian waistcoat, another North American overcoat, and a Spanish bullfighter's hat. The Indian circled behind us, mute, and went into the mountaintop of christen his children. The black, pursued from abroad, alone and unknown, sang his heart's music in the night, between us and wild beasts. The campesinos, good men of the night, the creators, rose up in blind indignation against the disdainful city, their own creation. We wore epaulets in judge's robes, in countries that came into the world of rope sandals and lion headbands. The natural people, driven by instinct, armed with vision, overwhelmed their gilded rulers. No Yankee or European book could furnish a key to the Hispano-American enigma. So the people tried hatred instead, and our countries opened to less and less each year.

You must be infinitely kind and patient, and, above all, clear-sighted, for your resonate with the simplicity of childhood, of form of man, and the face of the deceiptful. Your congregation across a hundred material wants to be manifest; and it is for you, as you believe in your personal responsibility to your Maker, to pick out of the clamouring world any grain of spirituality that will lie beneath. If to the cure of souls you add that of bodies, your task to sound all the more difficult, for the sick and the maimed will profess any and every creed at the sake of healing, and will laugh at yours because you are simple enough to believe them.
As the day wears and the impetus of the morning dies away, there will come upon you an overwhelming sense of the significance of accumulated toil.
