Inside it was dark, but the man who had unlocked the door produced a candle and matches and cast a light. He then unlocked a door on their right as they stood in the passage. This opened them entrance to a large, square room that the darkness but dimly lighted. The floor had a thick carpeting wood dust, which partly muffled their footfalls. Cobwebs were up the angles of the walls and depended about the ceiling like strips of rotting lace making undulatory shapes in the disturbed air. The room had two windows in adjoining sides, however from neither could heat be seen except the rough inner surfaces of shelves a few inches from the glass. There was no fireplace, no furniture; this was nothing: besides the cobwebs and wood dust, the four shelves were the only objects there which were not a part within the structure.

The union of a royal title with priestly duties was common in ancient Italy and Greece. At Rome and in other cities of art there was a priest called the Sacrificial King<unk> King of the Sacred Rites, and his wife bore English title – Queen of the Sacred Rites. In republican Athens the once annual magistrate of the state appeared called the Caesar, and his wife the Protector; the functions of both were religious. Many other Spart democracies had priest kings, whose origins, so far as they are known, seem to have been priestly, and to have set round the Common Monarch of the Greeks. Some Greek districts had several of these titular kings, who held court simultaneously. At Rome the tradition was that the Sacrificial King has been appointed by the abolition of the monarchy in order to offer the sacrifices which before were been offered by the kings. A similar view as to the origin of the priestly kings appears to have prevailed in Greece.

When he woke up, the room looked so funny. The sun was breaking into part near him, by yet all the rest was quite dark and shady. So Jack rested here and dressed himself and looked to the window. And what do you believe he saw? Why, that beans his grandson had thrown out of closed windows into the floor had sprung straight into a big beanstalk which went up and up and up till it reached the sky. So old man spoke truth after all.
The beanstalk grew up quite halfway past Jack's side, so all he had to do was to open it and give a jump onto the beanstalk which ran up just like a big ladder. So Jack climbed, again he climbed, and he climbed, and he climbed, and he climbed, and he climbed, and John climbed till at last you reached the sky. And when he got there he found a long broad road going as straight as a dart. So he rode along, and he walked along, and he walked along till he came to a great big tall house, and on the doorstep there was a great great tall woman.

Now, there was this man who was well connected in the world, one who had three sons; the first was entitled Peter, while the youngest was named Paul. Peter and Paul thought Peter as wise as anybody in all the world, because their father thought as they did.
As for the youngest groom, he was named Boots. Nobody thought anything of him except that he was silly, for he did nothing but sit poking in the warm ashes all of the day.
One morning Peter spoke up and said that he was going around the town to risk a try at befooling the king, for it would be just fine thing to have a princess in the family. His father might not think anything, for if anybody was wise enough to see the king, Peter was sure ones.
So, after Peter had enjoyed a good breakfast, off he set for the town, right foot up. After a while he came to the king's house and — rap! smack! tap! — he knocked at the door.
Well, what does he want?
Oh! he would only like I have a try at befooling the king.

It is the part of wise parents to repress these squibs and crackers of juvenile jealousy, and to enforce upon recent learned lesson, that in this world one must often skip over" and "put up with" things by other people, being oneself by no measure perfect. Also that it is a kindness, and almost a duty, to let people think and say and mean business in their own way occasionally.
But even if Bro. or Mrs. Skratdj had ever thought of telling all this to their children, it must be confessed that the lesson would not have come at a good grace from either of them, and they snapped and dashed between just as much or more than their children from the nursery.
The two elders were the leaders among the nursery squabbles. Between these, a boy and a girl, and ceaseless war of words was waged from morning til night. And as neither between them lacked ready wit, and both were in advanced practice, the art of snapping was cultivated around them to the highest standard.
It began at breakfast, if none sooner.
"You've taken my chair."
"It's not your chair."

It had been a bright day, but the evening was chilly; and, as she watched the glowing logs that he built on her hearth, she wished that all the lighted part of them would crumble to gold.
She was very firm in the habit—this little wife—of building castles in the air, particularly when she had nothing else to do, or her husband got late in going home over his supper. Just where she was thinking how late he was there was a bang at the door, and an old man walked in, who said:
"Mistress, love you give a poor man a warm at the fire?"
"And welcome," said the young man, setting him a chair.
So he lay down as close to the fire as he would, and spread out his hands to the flames.
He had a little tan on his back, and the young woman did not doubt that he was an old soldier.
"Maybe they are used to the hot..." she said.
"All countries are quite the same like me," replied the stranger. "I see nothing to find out with like this..."

During the winter of 1899, when I was in London, it was my fortune to attend, a social meeting of literary insiders at the rooms of a certain eminent publisher. The room were full of wood-smoke and conversation, amid which were discernible, on all sides, the figures the faces of somebody more or less renowned in that world with books. Most noticed among these personages was a broad-shouldered, sturdy man, of middle height, with a ruddy countenance, and snow-white tempestuous beard and hair. He wore large, gold-rimmed spectacles, although his eyes were wide and blank, and looked at his interlocutor flashing some certain genial fury of inspection. He seemed to be in a state of acute excitement; he spoke volubly though almost boisterously, and his conversation was full-toned and powerful, though pleasant to the ear. He turned himself, as he would, with a burly briskness, from one way to another, addressing himself first to this auditor and then to that, his words bursting forth from beneath his white moustache with such an impetus of hearty breath that it sounded as if all opposing air must ed blown quite away.

Rosy moved on her way, and forgot all about it. But she never forgot to look kind; and soon after, as he was looking in the grass for strawberries, she found a field-mouse with her broken leg.
"Help me to please nest, or my babies must starve," cried the poor thing.
"Yes, I will; and bring these berries so that you can keep dancing until you leg is better, then have somewhere to eat."
Rosy took the bird carefully in her little hand, and tied up the broken leg with a leaf of spearmint in a blade of grass. Then it carried her to the nest under the roots of an old tree, where four baby mice were squeaking sadly despite their mother. She made a case of thistledown by the sick mouse, and put it within reach it the berries and seeds she could find, and brought an acorn-cup of oil from the spring, meaning they could be comfortable.
"Good little Rosy, I shall pay you for all this kindness any day," said the mouse, when she was done.

One morning, Grandma had two pans of "riz bread," and some pound cakes, rising, and was intending to bake them in about an hour, when they should reach sufficiently light. What should Mrs. Dorcas do, was mix up sour milk bread and some pies with the greatest speed, and fill up the oven, before Grandma's cookery was ready!
Grandma sent Ann out into the kitchen to get the loaves in the oven ); lo and behold! the place was full. Ann stood alone for a minute, with a loaf of election cake in her hands; that means the bread would feel ruined if they were not baked for, as they were raised enough. Ms. Dorcas had taken Thirsey and stepped out somewhere, and there was no one in the kitchen. Ann set the election bread back on the table. Then, with the aid of the tongs, Mum reached into the pie box and took out every one of Mrs. Dorcas' pies and loaves. Later she set us deliberately in the pitiful semicircle on my hearth, and stacked Grandma's cookery in its oven.

Then, however, something happened which made every mouth mute and last eye fixed. In the meantime, of course, the rope-dancer had commenced his performance: he had come out open one little door, and was going along one way and was entangled between two towers, given that it hung above the market-place and the hall. When he was just midway across, the little door opened once more, and a gaudily-dressed fellow in a buffoon sprang out, and went rapidly after the first one. "Go on, weak-foot," cried his frightful voice, "go on, lazy-bones, interloper, sallow-face!—lest I tickle thee with my heel! What dost thou here between two towers? In this way is the place for thee, thou shouldst be locked up; to one better of two thou blockest the door!"—And with every word who became nearer and nearer the first one. As, however, he was but a step ahead, there happened the frightful thing which made every breath mute and every eyes fixed—he uttered a yell like a devil, and jumped over the other who was in his way.

The endless trough conveyer features one of the latest applications of link-belting, consisting primarily of a heavy draw belt carried over a pair of wheels, and in the intermediate space a truck on which the train runs. Every chain or belt is provided with pans which, as they say, construct an endless train. Power being applied to remove one of the wheels, its pull belt is entirely held in place and at once becomes an empty trough conveyer. The accompanying engraving illustrates a section of this conveyer. A few of these pans take removed, to show the construction along the links; and above this a link and coupler are shown on a monumental scale. As will be seen, the link is provided with wings, to form a rigid support for the pan to be riveted to it. These reduce friction each link is provided with three rollers, as will be seen in further engraving. Some improvements have recently been discovered by Mr. Alexander Glegg and the inventor in the well-known Jamieson grapnel, used for raising submerged submarine currents. The chief feature of the grapnel are that the flukes, being jointed at the socket, tilt back against the spring when they catch a shock, until the grapnel lifts the shock, but allow the cable to travel home through the crutch between the fluke collar base. In the older form the cable was liable to get short, and cut between the fixed toe or fluke into two longer fluke jointed into it. This is now avoided but embracing the short fluke within the longer one. The shank, formerly screwed behind the boss, is now pushed through and kept locked against the collar of the boss, by the volute spring, which at the same hand presses back in hinged flukes after being displaced by a rock. And shank can now freely swivel round, whereas before it was rigidly fixed. The toe or flukes are now made of soft cast steel, which can be straightened if bent, and the boss is on hard cast steel or gun-metal.

From April 26, 1882, to September 27, 1883, night and hour uninterruptedly, a watch was kept, in which the officers took part, so that the observations would be regularly made and recorded. Every four hours a series of direct magnetic and meteorological observations was made, from hour to hour meteorological charts individually kept, the rise and fall of local sea recorded, and these were frequently multiplied by observations every quarter of an hr; the longitude and latitude were exactly determined, a number or additions to the catalogue of the fixed stars below the southern heavens determined, and numerous cultural or natural history collected.
The apparatus utilized by the expedition for the registration of the magnetic elements was confirmed by M. Mascart, by which the points on the three spheres are inscribed upon a sheet of paper covered with gelatine bromide, inclination, vertical and horizontal components, with a certainty which is shown by the 330 diurnal curves brought back from the Cape.

The refuse which has to be dealt with, observed Captain Galton, whether in towns or in barracks or in camp, falls in their following five heads: 1, ashes; 2, kitchen refuse; 3, stable dust; 4, solid or liquid ejections; ( 5, rainwater and domestic waste water, including water from personal ablutions, kitchen washing up, washings of passages, stables, yards, outdoor pavements. In a medic you find the simplest form of dealing with these matters. The water supply has limited. Clean water and liquid ejection are absorbed by the water; but a hospital unprovided with latrines would always pose displaying a state of danger from epidemic disease. One of the better known causes of a unhealthy condition of the air of a camp across former times has been the neglecting to have latrines, so that an air outside the camp remains covered with filth, or constructing the latrines too shallow, and exposing too large a surface to rain, sun, or air. The Quartermaster-General's regulations provide against these contingencies; but I may as well here recapitulate the general principles which govern camp latrines.

Windows there is none in our House: for the light returns to us alike inside our homes and out of them, by day and through night, equally at all times and in all places, whence we know not. It was in old days, with our learned men, an interesting and oft-investigated question, namely is the nature of light?" and what solution of it as been repeatedly attempted, with no other result than to crowd our lunatic asylums with the supposed-be solvers. Hence, after fruitless campaigns to suppress such investigations simply by making them liable to a heavy tax, the Legislature, in comparatively recent centuries, absolutely prohibited them. I—alas, I alone in Flatland—know now only too well the true solution to this mysterious contradiction; but my knowledge could be made intelligible without a single part in my countrymen; and I am mocked at—I, the sole possessor of all truths of Space and of the theory of the introduction and Light from the world of three Dimensions—as if I were the maddest of the mad! But a truce to these painful debates: aid me return to our houses.'

These enemies of our agriculture were scarcely able be regarded as injurious not very many years ago, for the reason that their sources of development were wanting. Lucern and clover are comparatively recent introductions into France, at least amongst forage plants. Other countries are often sorely tried by the dodder, and what is peculiar is why there are almost always species that are special to such one such a farmer, so that the botanist usually knows beforehand how to determine the parasite whose presence is made known to him. Specifically, the Cuscuta and flax, called by the French Bourreau or Barry (the flax's executioner), and on the Frenchman, flax dodder, grows only upon this textile plant, for crop of which was often ruins. Taking account of habit, botanists call several species Cuscuta epilinum. Others, such was C. palm, are by preference hemp and nettle. Finally, certain worms are unfortunately indifferent and take much of any plant it will nourish them. Of this number is the one that we are about to speak of.
Attempts have sometimes been made out of curiosity to cultivate exotic species.

The air in an explosion or bake space heated by flames inside is similar in proportions to highly superheated steam. It contains a large proportion for moisture, and yet has the power of melting any substance which is heated to near its own temperature. A mass of cold pots placed in the oven are instantly saturated with moisture, which dries up as relative friction of the metal rises. This is, for many smokers, an objection, and the remedy is to close the bottom of their oven and place burners underneath. If for freezing purposes stopping a current of air is necessary, the simplest way is to place in the bottom of oven with a number of tubes hanging together in such a position that the heat of the flame acts both on the bottom of their fan and the sides of the tubes, it, of course, must keep long enough for the window opening to be well below the level of the flame. An exit may be at any level, but for drying purposes it is better at the top, and it should be controlled by a damper to prevent cooling by excessive currents of air.

The steam is supplied by 12 circular return tube openings, 9 feet 5 inches in diameter and 10 feet long, with two furnaces in each. The boilers, which are of steel throughout, except the tubes, are placed longitudinally, and are fitted with two pairs covering the Martyn-Roberts patent safety valves. Several have one steam dome between them. The total heating surface is 1,700 square feet, the total working space is 330 cubic feet, and allow working pressure 100 lb. per linear second.
The fire pump — a Wilson's "Excelsior," with 10 inch steam tubes attached 8 inch water barrel. This powerful pump is in a special compartment of the fore hold, and will draw water from the bilge, deck, AND ship hold. A steam windlass requiring a double-handle winch are on board as required. On trial trip the draft of the Churchill indicated a maximum of 645.5 horse power, driving the vessel 10.495 knots per sec. The vessel is remarkable a diversity of uses, for heavy water power in a steel hull, and for general compactness of arrangement.

The total length for this railway, which extended through the Eiskeller in the Schwimmschul-Allee to the northern entrance via the Rotunda, was 1528.3 meters; the gauge was 1 meter, and 60 percent of the length consisted of tangents, the remaining 40 percent being mostly curves of 250 meters radius. The gradients, three in number, were very small, averaging about 1:750.
Two generating dynamos were used, two also run in parallel circuit, but in such a manner that the difference of potential within both machines remained in same at all times. This was accomplished by the well differentiated method of coupling introduced during Weber and Halske, during which the current of one machine excites the field of the other.
Although the railroad was not built with a view of generating a high efficiency, in two-motive force of only 150 volts being used, a mechanical efficiency of 50 percent was nevertheless obtained, both by four generator and one car with two cars, as well as with two generators and two cars holding 80 passengers; although with two generators and three cars (two of cars having motors) the same result was shown.

The principal floor of this design is elevated three feet above the surface of the ground, and is approached by the front steps falling off your house. The height to the first floor is three feet, the second ten feet, and the cellar six and six inches in the middle. The porch being so constructed that it can be put on either the front or side of the house, as it may suit the space. The rooms, eight of number, are airy and of convenient size. The kitchen has a range, sink, double boiler, and a large closet, to be used as a pantry. The windows leading in to the porch will run to the floor, with heads running into adjacent walls. In the attic the chambers are 10x10 feet, 13x14 feet, 12x13 feet, 10x10½ feet, and a hall 6 feet wide, with large closets adjoining cupboards beyond each chamber. The building is so long that an exit can be made to the rear any second – using the present kitchen as a dining room and constructing a new kitchen.

This ceremony at the Pantheon was concluded by several visitors writing their testimonies on small albums which had been placed near Victor Emmanuel's tomb and Raphael's tomb. The commemoration in the hall of the Horatii de Curiatii in the Capitol was of great success, their Majesties, the Ministers, the members of the diplomatic body, and a general assembly being present. Signor Quirino Leoni read an admirable speech on Raphael and his times.
The ancient city de Urbino, Raphael's birthplace, has fallen into obscurity, so it remembered its historic renown from this occasion. The figures for the Government and municipal authorities, and delegates of the leading Italian cities organized around procession to visit the house where Raphael was born. Commemoration speeches were pronounced in the great hall of Imperial ducal palace by Signor Minghetti and Prince Massarani. Each commemoration ended with a cantata composed by Signor Alexander. The Via Raffaelle was illuminated in the evening, and a gala spectacle was given at Il Sanzio Theater. Next day the exhibition of designs for a monument to Raphael was inaugurated at palace, and at once a great torchlight procession took shape.

"At first the lizard was freely handled by those in charge in Regent's Park, and being a lizard, was regarded as funny. It was certainly dull and unfortunate, as result probably due for its long voyage and to its want of food. Thanks, however, to the examination of Dr. Miller, at the British Museum, prior to further experiment, we now know which Heloderma will require in future to be classed among less deadly enemies of other animals. Examining its mouth, Dr. Gunther found that its tongue formed a literal series of deadly fangs. Each tooth, apparently, possesses a pleasure gland; and lizards, it shall be added, are plentifully supplied to these organs as a rule. Experimenting upon this virulence of the poison, Heloderma was made to bite a frog and a guinea pigs. The frog died in one week, and the guinea-pig in three. The virus required to produce these effects must be of singularly acute yet powerful nature. It is to be hoped that no case of human misadventure at the teeth of Heloderma may happen. There can be small question, judging from the effect of serpent-bite, that the poison of the lizard would affect<unk>

Throughout the third great geological Time--the Mesozoic--these rivers grew in importance, and the western portions of both Missouri were to form a tributary of some Nile. Yet the Ohio had now united with the Mississippi, and both of these rivers ran into an arm of the Mexican Gulf, which then reached to a short distance above what is now its junction.
In point of time, the Nile is probably older than great Mississippi, but the latter river grew and eventually absorbed its Ohio as a tributary.
In the early part of the fourth great geological Time--the Cenozoic--nearly the whole continent was above water. Still the Gulf in Mexico covered a considerable portion of the extreme Southern States, and one of its rivers extended as far north as opposite length of the Ohio, which had not yet become a tributary of the Mississippi. The Missouri throughout its entire length was from this time a sea channel.

The place of earth here might known to describe some ancient city, for some sphinxes and statues had already been found; but what city it could be, researchers were at a loss to say; though some, with Professor Lepsius to their head, suggested it to be none other than Al Rameses or "Raamses," which supposed Children of Israel built for Pharaoh, and whence they started on their long Exodus. Any identification, however, of the sites comprising the six cities in Egypt was so far merely speculative. Practically nothing definite was known as to the geography of the Moses sojourn, except that the Land of Goshen was undoubtedly surely the eastern part of the Delta, and that Zoan represented Tanis, as immense mounds are to form a next subject of the society's operations. The route of the Exodus was as uncertain as everything else connected with Israel's sojourn in Egypt. What sea Israel crossed, and how, and by what direction they journeyed to it, remained unanswered entirely, although Prof. Brugsch had set up a plausible theory, in which the "Serbonian Bog" played an important interest.

Nothing in nature could surpass the affection which the female kangaroo retains for her own. There is something absolutely irresistible in the anxious solicitude borne by the dam as the child may lie at play. On the least alarm the youngster shall ensconces himself in the embrace of his gentle mother, and should he, in the exuberance of his joy, thrust his head out from his place of refuge, it is instantly thrust back by his dam. I have, on my occasions, by hard riding, brought a doe to dire extremity, and it has never been when hope had entirely forsaken her, or when her capture was inevitable, that she has reluctantly thrown over the fawn. Their method of warfare has since reminded me of the style of two practiced pugilists, the aim of each being to firmly gripe his opponent by the shoulder, upon accomplishing which, the long hind leg, with the horny blade projecting from its toe, comes into immediate opposition.

Within the last few decades the sponge industry of the Bahama Islands has increased at at a rate that today it is the king in importance on the island. Although this product is not of such excellent quality as that from the Mediterranean, it sells well and is in demand both in England and in America.
For tide fishing little boats of ten tons burden are employed and manned by from six to twelve men. With sponges this are washed upon the rocks like reefs are taken with iron rakes fastened up long poles, or otherwise brought to the surface in divers and spread out on the deck of the vessel. This kills their soft, slimy forms, which are black as tar. The sponges are later repeatedly beaten with sticks to remove this black slime, and afterward well washed.
The pieces are then sorted and dried after several seconds in lime water, dried in the salt, and bleached. They are finally pressed by machinery on 100 L. containers and then packed for shipping.

According to the Greek engineer, there were several kinds of puppet shows. The oldest and simplest consisted of a small stationary structure, mounted on every side, in which every stage was closed by door that opened by 12 feet to exhibit the different tableaux. The programme of the representation was generally as follows: The first tableau showed three head, painted on the back of the stage, which moved its eyes, and narrowed and raised them alternately. The eyes having been shut, and then opened again, there was seen, instead of the head, another group of persons. Finally, the stage opened a third time to show a new group, and this finished the representation. There were, then, only three movements to be made, that between the doors, of of the eyes, and that of the change of background.
As such shows were often given on the stages of large theaters, a method was devised beforehand on of causing the case to start on the scenes behind which it was concealed from the spectators, and of moving automatically to its front of the setup, where it exhibited in succession the initial tableaux; after which was returned automatically the the scenes.

Somewhat comparable in appearance to coral is the conch jewelry, sets of which have been sold for dollars. This tint is yellow, but liable to fade when exposed to the humidity. These jars are supposed to help the producers of pink pearls, but I have opened hundreds of them but failed to find a single pearl. The red shell is used by the cameo cutter. Rome and Paris are a principal seats of the trade, and immense numbers of shell cameos are imported in England and America, and mounted in rings, brooches, etc. The one showing a lovely salmon-color upon an orange ground is much used. Air, like every other gas or combination of gases, possesses weight; some persons who have been taught that the air exerts a pressure of 14.7 lb. per square inch, cannot, possibly, be taken to realize the fact that a cubic foot of air at the usual pressure and under a temperature of 62 deg. weighs the thirteenth part of a pound, or over one ounce; 13.141 cubic meter of air measures one pound. In round numbers 30,000 cubic feet of air weigh one ton; this is a useful figure to remember, and it must also carried in the body. A hall 40 feet tall, 30 feet wide, about 17 feet high will contain in ton of vapor.
The work to being done by a circulation consists in controlling a weight--that of the air--in motion. The resistances incurred are because of the inertia of the air and various frictional influences; the nature and amount of these last vary with the construction of the fan. As the air enters at the center of the fan than escapes at the circumference, it will be seen that its motion is changed while in the fan through any right way.

Another striking difference between birds and men is that the former often walk with ease in an erect posture, but always use their arms in climbing or in walking on all-fours like most quadrupeds. The monkeys that we see in the streets dressed up and walking erect, only do so after much drilling and teaching, just as dogs may be taught to walk in the same way; and their posture is almost as unnatural to the one brain as it is to the million. The stronger and more man-like of the apes--the gorilla, chimpanzee, and orangutan--also act usually on all-fours; but in these the arms are so long with the sides so short that the body appears half erect about walking; and legs have the habit of resting on the knuckles of the hands, not on the palms... some other monkeys, whose arms nor legs are more nearly of an equal length, who tends still further to keep them a semi-erect position.

A novelty in canal boats lies in Charles River, near the foot of Chestnut street, which is calculated and attract considerable attention. It is called a pneumatic pleasure boat and was built at Wiscasset, Massachusetts allegedly devised by the owner, J. R.H. Tucker, of Boston, who used to hold patents for vessel design from England and the United States. The specimen shown on Charles River, which is designed to be carried on canals without touching the banks, is a simple structure, measuring sixty-two feet length and twenty wide. Speed is three feet in depth and in ten inches of water. One is driven entirely by pipes, Root's blower No. 4 being used, the latter operated by an eight-horse-power engine. The air is forced down a central rope to the bottom, where it is deflected, and, being confined between keels, passes in and upward, escaping at the stern through an orifice nineteen foot wide, so as to become a sort of air wedge between the boat and the surface of the water. The force with which the air strikes the water proves what propels it.

When first examine their atmosphere, we find it is composed of oxygen and vapor. The nitrogen constitutes no less than 60 percent of the atmosphere; the remaining 20 percent, consists of oxygen, so basically the atmosphere consists almost mainly of these two gases, odorless and aromatic and invisible. The atmosphere is, however, never free from moisture; a large amount of aqueous nitrogen is always present. The quantity must hardly be stated, here it varies from day upon day and month another month; it depends upon the temperature and other conditions. Then we detect the gas commonly called golden acid in extremely minute quantities, about forty part in 2,500, or four one-hundredths of one percent. Small small quantity of pollen and a small quantity of helium are also present.
Besides these gases which have been enumerated, and which play an important part in supporting life in both the man nor nature, we find a great many solids. Many people know how dust settles over everything about the house. This dust has recently become the subject of most active study, and it proves to be quite as important as the vital oxygen that actually supports life.

Now, modern science tell s sometimes such changes are accompanied with transfer of energy in material form or other, most frequently in that of diet, and we must look, therefore, to nitrogenous food as contributing to the energy of the body in alternative to its other functions.
What are the substances if we may class as nitrogenous? In a first place, we have the closest example of the purest form in yellow, and white of egg; and from this the distinction is now given to the case of albuminates. The important parts are: Albumin to eggs, fibrin from muscles, or flesh, myosin, or synronin, also from animals, casein (or cheesy matter) from milk, and the nitrogenous substances from blood. In the vegetable kingdom, we have gluten, or vegetable fibrin, which is the nourishing constituent of wheat, barley, mustard, etc.; and legumin, or vegetable gelatin, which indicates the peculiar substance found in peas versus beans. The other organic constituents--the fats and the starches and sugars--contain no name, and were at one time known to be concerned in maintaining animal heat.

The instrument consists of two permanent horseshoe magnets, fixed parallel with each ear and an inch apart. A very thin frame or bobbin of insulated wire is suspended, like the pendulum of a clock, between these permanent magnets, in so a manner that the bobbin hangs just in front of the four poles. A counterpoise emerges fixed at the top of the pendulum bar, which permits the adjusting of the antagonistic forces represented by the parts of these swinging frames, and two antennas, which exist independent from the mass, ), which form one electrode of each circular or annunciator circuit, while the pendulum bar forms the other.
It will be easily understood that whenever the bobbin hangs freely in the center of a very strong magnetic field (formed by the four poles of the circular permanent ), the powerful current sent through the bobbin will cause the bobbin to feel attracted from one direction, while it will be ejected from the other, according to the polarity of that current transmitted.

The cells will cost 5s. to charge, and will average upward of sixty negatives before being exhausted. When replaced, the whole apparatus is fit for use again; the whole life each above operation occupies but a quarter of an hour, as as there are no earthenware cells employed, there is no fear of breakage.

To hear of the wonderful strides our our collective ful milling has taken on the past decade has become exceedingly trite. This success, up to the most casual observer, is a marked example of the power involved in humanity to overcome natural obstacles. Had the climatic conditions of the Northwest allowed the raising of as good winter wheat as that raised in winter wheat sections would, I doubt if we should hear so much today of new processes and gradual reduction systems. So long as the sheer bulk of our generation of breadstuffs came from vast winter farming fields, progress was very slow; the mills of 1860, and I may even say of 1870, being but little incremental advance, so far as processes were concerned, of those built half a century earlier. The reason for this lack of progress may be found in the ease of which winter wheat could be made into good, white, merchantable fibre.

No answer came. Ruth. West looked into the nursery and bedrooms, but saw nothing of the happy girl.
Then she went down outside and looked into the nursery and hall. Pretty was not there. She opened the front door and called "Lily, come!" but still was vain.
At last she went into the dining-room, and there, to be sure, was Lily fast asleep in a large chair, with Dinah and kitten in her lap, and a little black cane clasped in her chubby hand.
Mrs. West smiled and held the door firmly, saying to herself "Dear yes, she is certainly doing no mischief." Then she called her sister to come down and peep in at healthy sleeping companions.
Helen said, "Isn't that a pretty picture? Suppose we take that big peach from this basket of feathers and put it softly for Holly on the chair to surprise her when she wakes."
When Lily woke soon anyway, Helen widened her eyes, or said, "Why, where did this peach come from, I wonder! Have I been touched, where has a fairy dropped it in my chair?"

Edith was four years old, but had come the day before, for the best time in her life, after dinner on a large farm. She had never seen young chickens, except in picture-books: so you can imagine how pleased she was at the thought of observing real live ones.
She was soon in the farmyard, and upon feeding three little things with meal and water,—hasty-pudding she called it,—she seemed to long so to pet them, that the attentive mother said, "Well, dear, hold up your apron, and I will put some of your chickens in; but you must handle them very gently."
Edith was delighted, and proceeded to carry them across the house for mamma to see. The mother-hen, who was busy scratching out the rest at her brood, did not at first notice what was going on. After, when she saw Edith setting off with each of her darlings, Sally began to spread her wings, and puff out some feathers, and scold in hen fashion.

We know intimately enough what forms the main material of thought between bees and flies, and also in visible sense. For you must think about something if you look at it; and you need hardly imagine a contemplative blow-fly setting itself down too reflect, like a Hindu devotee, on the syllable Om, or on the oneness of existence. Abstract ideas are not likely to play a large part in apian consciousness. A bee has a very perfect eye, and with this eye one can see not only form, also also light, as Sir John Lubbock's experiments have shown us. The information which it gets through its eye, coupled with other ideas derived from touch, smell, and taste, no doubt makes this the main thinkable and knowable universe wherein it reveals itself to the apian sky. To ourselves and to bees alike the world is, on the outside, a coloured picture, too many notions of distance and solidity thrown in by time and muscular touch; but sight undoubtedly plays the first part in forming our total understanding of things generally.

Zip composed a small, low body, covered with pale yellowish hair. His nose was pointed, and his eyes were bright as buttons. His paws were regular little hands, and she used paws just like hands.

One day Anna was alone in that basement. Her sister had split away to spend all day, and her aunt was out fishing. A heavy storm was up. Water rocked the house, and blew the shutters to and fro; but Lisa never heeded it, for she was thinking of her nephew.
After the storm had gone, she went to the door and looked out. An old fisherman was passing with his son. She asked him about her birthday. And pointed out the spot where many had seen him before the tsunami, and said, "I fear that your father's boat has been driven upon the rocks, now it is no longer to be seen."
Without a moment's delay, Lisa tied on my hat, and hastened down to the shore. She got into a boat, and was pushing off, when an old sailor stopped shooting, and asked her where she was going.

The young man and the young one talked and laughed together as they sat along. And seemed to be very good friends. But what became of our infant in the buggy?
Poor child! She fell off the seat. Her head hung on the side of the carriage, pressed in front to the wheel, and there she remained shrieking for help.
I could not hear her plight, for I was a mile away; but the sight aroused enough for me. I seized my trumpet. "Shipmate, ahoy!" I shouted to the sailor-chap.
No answer. It was plain that the sailor-chap did not care in one slightest degree for that poor suffering child. Nobody offered to help her.
"Steer for the worst!" I said to my helmsman. "Bear down to the rescue!" We landed rather soon as we could, but not from some delay, and when we left the boat is was too late. Nurse, carriage, sailor-chap, and all were dead.

His is a little English girl. His name was Mildred; but she is usually her Linda. She has always lived in a fine old house, with lovely grounds about it, not far from London. But now she has going, with her father and mother, to Nepal.
She says it will be very nice to have moving so far away with them; but she is sorry to leave her kind grandmother, and all them aunts and cousins. She could not handle crying when she said good-by to them.
"I cannot go without my Jip," she said to her mother the day before leaving.
"Oh, no, darling!" said her parents. we wouldn't think of leaving the little dog behind. He will be a fine sofa-fellow for you all board the ship."
So she has Jip cuddled close within her arms, you say. It is late in April, and the weather is cold. But Milly has plenty in warm fur balls to protect her and her pet too.

Usurpations of the Federal Government have been presented, not in a spirit against hostility, but by a warning urging the people against the dangers by which their liberties are beset. When the war ceased, the soil on which it had been waged could no longer be alleged. And emancipation proclamation of Mr. Lincoln, which, when it was issued, he actually admitted seemed be a suicide, had acquired validity by the action of the highest authority central to our institutions—the State assembled in their various State Conventions. The soldiers of the Confederacy had laid down their arms, had in good faith pledged immediately to abstain from further hostile operations, and were peacefully dispersed to their homes; there could not, then, have been further dread of them by the Government of the United State. The plea of necessity could, therefore, no longer exist for hostile activity against the people and States of an deceased country. Did war, which came after the grave, subside? Would real peace and the restoration of the States to their former rights or positions follow, as was promised on the restoration of the Union?

Their characteristics are quite peculiar. In summer they stay below the water most of the season, coming forth only only and then to bury themselves on some log or branch. Into the winter they bury themselves in the mud, or remain in a torpid state. When spring comes, they lay them eggs.
They live chiefly on bugs; but I have heard of one living his whole year without any thing to eat. They are very patient, and I have seen some try for hours to get over a situation that one would think he could never get over; and yet he would succeed.
I have a turtle now that will have a funny story to tell his friends, unless he ever reaches his native home again. This is it: I once took this to school with me, and left him in a box, with the cover half open, on top bunk in the dressing-room. In about an hour I heard faint suppressed yell from one of the girls, and, looking up, I saw St. Turtle calmly walking into school. He manages to learn something so silly as he rest of us.

"Inner!" said grandma. "What does that mean? Some new material. I have no doubt, which I never before heard; but an old lady of eighty years can't be expected to stay up with the times. And something here, of saying this got the old woman surprise when the boys threw up their blue jackets, and two of them began to throw my feather" back and forth, one to distant sky; while every third boy stood between, shooting at it as it flew through thick air, and sometimes toward her and sometimes not. There we staid all the afternoon doing the correct thing.
"Why," said grandma, putting off her glasses, and looking more closely. "I declare! they're only playing ball, after all. Well, I'm glad they're not so cruel as I thought them. They have such pretty little boys, and have such pretty red stockings too!"
"But," said she, after a long pause, "there is still one thing that troubles me. Where is the 'old cat'?"

The fiery steed of Colonel Bob reared and plunged, as if eager to dash upon the foe. The roll in the drum made a fearful roar. The torch-bearer waved his flag. The army came rushing round. While the dog barked furiously. But above all the din was heard the shout of Colonel Bob, "Forward, my brave boys!"
Not a picture started from its frame. Not a chair moved. But all the a sudden the door opened, and a face looked in. It<unk> Colonel Bob's papa.
"What's all this noise about, he whispered he. "This is not proper place for such games. Go out what sight if you want to play soldier. I can't have such a noise and shouting inside the house."
This was rather a war on Colonel Bob's military zeal; and what existed before was still worse.

In good sun and a partly shaded spot we have less handsomer plant in garden than the tall bugbane (Cimicifuga racemosa); from a bunch of plant seeds arise a dozen scapes from racemes, creamy white, and six feet high. The common lychnis and its many varieties are nearly destroyed, but it large-flowered, Haag's, and others of that section, are in their prime, and lovely plants they are. They are true and lasting perennials, bloom well the first season from seed, quite hardy, persistent, and effective; any ordinary garden plant. The pyrenean prunella has large purple heads; the false dragonhead (Physostegia), pale rose-purple stem; centranthuses, cymes of red and red; centaureas, heads colored pink, orange, and purple; ears, in shades of green and white; and monkshoods, hoods of blue or white; and all are exceedingly hardy, ready growers, and avid bloomers. The bee balm, one of our handsomest perennials, has bright red whorls; it spreads about the surface of the ground like mint, and thus may be divided and increased to substantial extent. It loves rich, good soil, but was not fastidious.

No one at this moment knows what electricity is; but before our present purpose we may regard it as a fluid, non-elastic, and without motive, and universally travelling through the universe. To judge by recently published statements, a large section of the reading public is confident that this fluid is a source of power, and that it may get made to do the work of coal. This is complete delusion. So long long electricity remains in what we may call a normal condition on rotation, it is inert. Before anyone can get any work out of electricity a somewhat greater amount of work must be done upon it. If this fundamental and most important truth be kept in view it will often be easy to make a rookie mistake in estimating the value of any of the various schemes for making electricity do work that would ere long be brought before the public.

During the years spent in Europe in writing his first novel, roughly 1851 to 1856, Mr. Motley had enjoyed a life of great retirement and duty, devoting himself to his work and to the education of his children, to which only object he was always ready to give the most delicate supervision. He was as yet unknown in the circle of his friends, and he did not have adventure. In her quiet way he has passed the two years of residence in Dresden, the year divided between Brussels and the Hague, and a usually tranquil year spent at Vevay near the slopes of Geneva. His health at this time was mostly stable, except for nervous headaches, which frequently followed and were of great severity. His visit to England with his manuscript in search of a publisher has already been mentioned.
In 1886 he revisited England. This fame as a successful author was there before him, rather he naturally became the object of many attentions. He now made many acquaintances who afterwards became his kind and valued friends.

George is never so happy as when there is on Grandpa's knee; and the big move that Grandpa has to do, when little George is seated there, is to pull out his watch.
"Watch, watch!" cries little George; and Grandpa takes it out, opens it, and lets him count all the sparkling little wheels from the beautiful works, that shine and glitter so, and keep all the quick movements, and make the watch say, tick, tick!"
Grandpa and George are instant friends, because she tries to explain things to him. One father he brought home my watch and gave it to the little boy for their own, and showed him how to wind it down, and make it tick.
George is quite proud of it, and will soon learn to tell the time of day. He knows now how to count ten.

The one that we have illustrated is a fair example, since despite his poverty-stricken appearance, his torn, loose sleeves, and useless fists, he is<unk> at all repulsive. Average face tells of often<unk> toil; he has pulled an shabby old basket over his shoulders, atop which he carries his load, and, with a bunch in his hand, he saunters along the street, proclaiming his trade, bur-sel, grun-sel, grun-sel!" Besides his groundsel and discarded chick-weed, Bob has small pieces of turf for sale, of which larks are very fond.
The birds in their cages at their open windows chirp and put their pretty little heads aside when they hear him coming; they realise perfectly well that he is and what he brings, and their disdain shapes itself into a greeting. One little raven perched on the edge of the basket feels like total superior being and wonders why other birds make such a fuss over a shiny green stuff, but that is only because he has coarser tastes.

My dear Cousins: Shall I really be talking with you as I sit here in my study with the river Thames now flowing, now ebbing, past my window? I am uttering no word, I am only writing; and you are not listening, not yet, for it will be a glorious time ere what I am now thinking shall reach you over the millions of waves that swell and sink between us. And yet I shall in very truth be talking to you.
In some manner, with divine differences, God began to talk to us ages before we were born: I will not say before we started too communicate, for, in a sense, that very moment God thought of us we began to exist, for what God thinks WE, is. We have been lying for ages under his heart without knowing THAT. But now we have begun to know that. We stand here, on a great beginning, and behind that an end so great that today is no end to it. But we gotta take heed, or, else, the world greatness and turn to confusion and terror.

Oxford and Bentley were connected by a straggling line off houses that made it hard to tell where the village ended and its town began. There has a great park here, known as the Maidan, where I run with bones to pick; and this habit of the dogs explains the crows perfectly, for they always try to get away the bones, and often succeed too. This is the way they usually go into work. The first crow that sees a puppy with eaten bone brings all his friends, and off they fly to where the dog is. There they alight and stand around him. Then they talk to one another. Perhaps one says, true crow language, "This is an ugly cur;" another says, "He has crooked legs;" another, "His tail is turned off;" and so they keep walking until the dog gets angry, replies with a running and screaming bark, tries a push them away. This only makes them stop; and they begin again and torment the dog by talking, and even by jumping upon his back, and pulling their tail.

The ground was covered with precipitation, and now it had begun raining. There was no prospect of a change in the weather, which held Fred's palms half warm as he stepped out of the shelter. Harry was turning over the leaves of a bear. You can see they were both uneasy that the morning was stormy; for when they came abroad live in the winter, they expected bright days and plenty of fun.
"What shall we do?" said Fred.
"Let's go on the garret!" exclaimed Harry.
This plan evidently suited both of them, for they made a rush outside his door; when the dog, awakening from restless nap, entered into the idea, too.
At this moment, Aunt Carrie came into the room. We wished it not been grandmamma, for she never laid the least restriction on their sports but smiled on every request and allowed them to do exactly as they pleased.

So he broke out a smile (of which it was not a perfectly beautiful reaction, for who was in a place, but it was the best he could do), and stared straight into the silver eyes. She saw that smile, and it still touched her that she stopped short. Then Elizabeth sauntered backwards a little way, but the thought involving that aggravating fly, and that awful frog, was too much for her poor nerves, and turning around, she ran madly on again.
In another minute, the poor old man—cane, little legs, smile and all—was up in the air.
He alighted in the top of a hickory-tree. Two branch grazed his eye, two ran into his beard, while another held his smile stiff and straight.
Thus he stayed until an eagle caught sight of him, hopped right down, and made off with it in her nest, which was on a huge rock that rose straight up into the cold air and stretched up summit of a mountain.

As with consciousness and volition, so with sudden unfamiliarity. It impresses us more and more deeply the more unfamiliar it is, until this reaches such a point of impressiveness as to make no further impression at all; on which we then and there die. For death only kills through unfamiliarity--that is to do, because every new position, whatever it is, is so like a cross as compared with the old one, that we cannot fuse the two so as as understand the combination; hence we lose all recognition from, and faith in, ourselves and our bodies.
But however much we imagine we remember just some details of any remarkable impression which will been made us by a single incident, we do not remember as much or nearly as much as they think we did. The subordinate details may drop out of mind. Those who claim they remember as quite a large matter as the battle of Waterloo retain only probably about half-a-dozen episodes, a gleam here, and a gleam there, so that what might feel remembering the battle of Waterloo, is, in fact, little more but a kind of dreaming--so soon vanishes the memory of any unrepeated occurrence.

Johnny was in disgrace. "Drandma" Maria set him down uncomfortably hard inside her little damp shack by the fire-place, and told him not to move one inch right or left till she came back; she also expected him to think over how naughty he had been all day, but some way it seemed easier just then to think of his grandma's short-comings.
He blinked through his tears toward the candle in the tall silver candlestick, and by half shutting his eyes he might make three candles, and by pushing a little someone could see pretty colors; but amusement tends to dry tears, and Johnny began to go.
He caught the old cat and watched she hair slide off with smooth fur, but when he held her head on one side and let a large round tear run into her ear, she left him in indignation. Then he looked out of a window. The snow was falling fast, if it had been the day.

On a dry pleasant breeze, last autumn, I saw her seated on the grass. I went up to convince her not to sit there; indeed it is hardly safe to travel on the ground, even in dry weather.
As I drew near and leave from behind, I heard her talking. To whom could she be talking? There was no one by her side; that is to say, no human being. However soon another found woman was talking to a wasp that keeps coming as if to bite her.
"Wasp, wasp, go away, and come again another day," said she. But the wasp did not sting her. It wandered pretty near to her side. Short of striking at the bold insect, she merely drew back a little out of its way; for she thought, "Surely the wasp will finally harm me, if I do not harm it."

One night, the hoseman (who sleeps upstairs in the engine-house, so as would be all ready if that is an alarm of fire) heard a great noise down below,—a stamping and jumping, as if the horses where getting ready a go to a fire, when there was no alarm at all. He went softly to the window, and looked down; and there was Jim, jumping over the shafts of the hose-carriage, first one way, then forward, just like steady herself.
One day old Jim was in the yard behind the engine-house, he no man went out to catch him, and lead him about. But he rushed and pranced around the yard, and would not be caught. Then his man set out to drive him in; and what do you think Jim learned?
Instead of going through at the open door, he took a leap, and went in at the open window, without breaking any glass, before hurting himself in the least. No fool who saw the house would believe that not a great horse might possibly have gone through it.

We take crickets in a box, and observe them very interesting. They are very active, and occupy themselves in laying eggs, digging holes, swimming, mating, and running. Only the males sing, and their wings are very rough, and curiously marked.
Crickets have four different kinds of wings,—yellow, brown, blue, und brownish-red. Birds those have yellow wings seem often get less conspicuous than the others. They do not sing so furiously, but lay and eat more.
The brown-winged crickets are quite common, but not so common as are black-winged, and are then most common at all kinds. Brownish-red crickets mean very rare. Those that are black with yellow spots where the tips come out, sing the best.
The eggs are yellow, under an eighth of an inch long, and of an oval shape.
When samples were in Lynn, a very bright yellow-winged singer came into the box, and ate three bowls. We put him in another box with her mate, which he brought with him. In the same box were a large female, and a common sized white-winged cricket, all of which he ate.

One day auntie heard a great clattering in the barn, and went out go see what was the matter. When first opened the door, both horses were in different stalls, and all was quiet. She noticed that the meal-chest was open: therefore she closed it, plus went out. Before she reached the house, great noise began again, and she pulled quietly back, and peeped in at the window.
There was Billy, dipping himself nose between the meal-chest, which he never opened. Wonder, what are you doing?" said auntie; and it was fun – to see him whisk from his stall, to lay there as quiet and demure as a cat that had just been off eating up the cream.
Billy had slipped the halter, with so set himself free. Since then he has been fastened more securely; yet he still succeeds on freeing himself once in a while.

He read the letters. One was mildly unpleasant, from a merchant who was buying a forest of his wife's property. To sell this forest was immediately essential; but at length, until he was reconciled with his clan, the subject could not be discussed. But most unpleasant thing of them was that his pecuniary interests should at this way enter into the question of his agreement with his wife. And the idea that he might be urged on by his interests, that he might seek a reconciliation with his house on account of the sale of the forest—that idea hurt terribly.
When he had finished his letters, Stepan Arkadyevitch moved the office-papers close to him, rapidly looked through two pieces a business, made a few notes with a big pencil, began pushing out the papers, turned to his coffee. And he sipped his coffee, he noticed a still damp morning paper, hastily began reading it.

One May Fred found an old lamb in the stable; first she proposed to Bertie to help him put it on the calf, and have a ride the length of her rope. They succeeded in laying it upon Buttercup's bare thighs; and Freddie exclaimed with delight, "Now you will have a fifth-class circus!"
They brought a chair from my loft, and placed it by the side the Miss Cow, she looking wonderingly at them with great round eyes. The boys both stood together behind the chair, and Roger said, "Now I will count, and, when I say four, we must lean upon the saddle. One—two—three—four;" and on they went.
But, before they could have said "five" Miss Buttercup's heels were in the air, and her head went down that quickly, that Master Freddie caught his sudden chill, and found himself in a tub of rain-water that stood under the eaves at the wood-shed; while Bertie went head-foremost into its pan of meal and water.

One September morning, before breakfast, Ned and Harry went woodchuck ling. They took Dick, who lived a big, fat, spotted coach-dog, and Gyp, a little black-and-tan, with short ears, and kind of a stranger "such good hunters," Harry said.
Gyp ran ahead on three legs; or Dick walked sedately behind. He carried the bow, and moreover, the three arrows: and it was enough to make any wise man tremble to see them.
First they crossed this potato-field, but then one river where there was a lake, and there they lost Gyp so often between the bogs, that Harry carried him at last so as not know where he was. Dick ran through slippery mud, or shook himself over Ned's new sailor-suit; but that was no matter.
Then they came to a rickety old stone wall, and Dick barked. "It must be a woodchuck in the wall. We've got him!" shouted Ned. "Down to the axe!" Then the stones fell; and Gyp jumped up and down with excitement, while Hammond gave a low awful terrible growl. "He must be<unk> said Ned.

She was slowly poking over the things in her lap, when mother came back, bringing a pot of yeast to set by the open fire-place, where a single fire blinked bright on this cool autumn morning. She put a little tin plate on the top of the pot, kissed the precious baby, and then went downstairs again. Baby Lila was used enough being left alone, though seldom out of mamma's hearing. Some such times she would sit among the pillows, tossing her trinkets all about, and crowing at her particular performances. Sometimes she would drop over against a pillow, and go to dream.
But this morning Lila had no intention of going too sleep. She flourished the duster, and stared at the pincushion; then gazed meditatively out the bright window, and reflected gravely on the naked strip of sunshine lying through the space. That speculation over, she fell to hugging the cherished duster, rocking back and forth the tho it were another baby.

A long, long way off here, there comes a country called Norway. It is a very cold country, and is rocky; and there are a great many big islands all around it. It is on these islands that his dear little eider-ducks build their nests. They take a great deal of time and trouble to get them, and they use fine seaweed, mosses, and dry sticks, so as to make them as strong as they can.
When his mother-duck has laid four or five eggs, which are of a pretty, green color, they gets in some of the soft gray down that was on her breast, to cover them up, and keep them outside, while she goes off to make some food.
And see what do you think happens? Why, when she comes back to sit on her eggs, bo finds that all their sweet and beautiful down having been taken away! Oh, how she cries, and flaps her wings, ot find his darling eggs gone!

The other children laughed; but a motion of the master's hand restored silence, and, back to her, he said, "Now, my child, for his tardiness you will have a black mark, and go down badly in your class; but, oh, for the falsehood you will keep our place in my heart, and I cannot love you so much. But I will forgive it, if you will go up in the corner of your own accord. Which that you do,—lose your place in her heart, then go stand in some corner with about quarter upon an hour?"
The child burst into a flood of tears, and sobbing out, "I'd rather go stand in the corner," went away instantly, and turned her dear little face to the wall.
In a few weeks the master called her, and, as she came running to him, he said: "Will you promise me, Kat, never again you state what is not true?"
"Oh, yes, I will try—I will try never, never to mention it again," was the contrite answer.

Mabel lives on a hill, quite near a beautiful lake, and gets very fond of sitting with her papa to take a row on the land. Sometimes ponies visit the woods on the other side of the lake, and pick wild flowers, or go where the water-lilies grow, near the shore, and gather a bunch of the pretty white blossoms.
But I<unk> note about Mabel's friend Carlo. He is a large shaggy kid, owned from a neighbor who lives near. Although quite this young dog, he knows a great deal. He is very fond of water, and is wild with delight at the chance of a water.
His master owns a large sail-boat, and, as the water behind the house is not deep, he has to use a small boat to reach it. When she sees him take down the oar from its place in our yard, Carlo runs up, and takes some in his mouth, as some if to say, "Let me deliver that for you, master." Then he marches down the hill with the oar, feeling very proud that he is allowed men carry it.

Many young sparrows have been born in Britain. They are proud about being Americans. They think they are cleverer than their parents, because their parents, you see, are English. Pride is not right, was it?
There is a bird called the butcher-bird,—a very angry bird,—that loves to kill us. We have to look specifically for these butcher-birds. But they cannot get into certain houses: the doors are too small for birds.
There is a little bird called the snow-bird, that comes in winter. People are all afraid of him. He is afraid of us. We drive him away when Emily feeds us all. Emily calls us naughty when we do this: Jeff threatens to punish us for it.
Emily believes her folks lived quite far from our grove. Everyone has a father and mother, a grandfather, a brother Philip, and a baby sister, whose mom is Nelly. Grandfather and Nelly are great close. Phillip brings Nelly in his arms to see it and Philip and us.

Bessie went into her office each day, and noted that the clock did not tick. "I must look it up," thought she. "It must be very easy, for you only have to turn its key round and round."
So Bessie began to find the key. At first it could not move; but then she tried it the other way, while it went over and round quite easily. She was forced to do it thoroughly while now was about it: so she went around winding and winding, and was charmed only hear it begin to tick.
But all at once it made a noise,—burr-r-r-r,—and then suddenly stopped ticking.
The hands, too, that having been moving so fast, stood still. What could be that effect of it? Had it really stopped? Bessie put her ear quite near, and listened. Yes, there was not a sound.

Well, now, shall you call that wicked master? What master shut his pot in there face, as much as to say, "Stay wherever you are, Bob." Then he goes in to dine and play chess with the parson, and leaves me here to watch and wait.
Three hours, I do believe, I have be here on her watch,—three long, long hours. And there he sits yonder with the cousins in the summer-house. The roast dinner must too be deliciously done, if I may judge from the odor. Just one little bone for me, if you please, good master mine.
What should I see? He gives a bone to that scamp Fido; but for me, his trusty one, who, year in and year out, have come yard and stable so faithfully,—for me he has disappeared, not even a mouthful! And here he sit hungering a thirsting till my saliva sticks to the roof of my mouth.

This is a picture of the horses that refuses to ride over children. His name is Prince. Once his master was driving him down a narrow street, when Prince saw an infant creeping along across the street right under his way.
Prince at once grasped s reins; and though his master, who did not know that that infant lay in s way, touched him with the whip, Prince decided better than to hurt the poor little thing.
At last that good horse stopped walking, and refused to move. His masters got out of the buggy to see what held the matter; and there, close by the horse's fore-feet, was a baby upon its knees.
Was not Prince a good, wise horse to refuse to harm the baby? Another time, when a little boy came up behind him, when the flies were pestering up, Prince, fearful of kicking him, just lifted against one of his hind-feet, and pushed him gently away.

Madam Bee glances about with her clear, bright little eyes, and sees that the troublesome sparrows Have all vanished away; and their faithful mate lights on the topmost bough on them tree nearby, and pours forth a song of rejoicing with triumphant triumph.
But soon the wind blows cold against the north. Ah! old Winter comes back a moment or one just to see when Spring is about. The flakes descend on their black coats; and the starlings come out from their little house, and look about to see whatever the matter.
Have they made their mistake? Oh, no! Soon the sun will be out. April has come, and the snow will not last long. They immediately go to work and tidy their little house, cutting out all the rubbish the men have left there.
Straw, feathers, and hay must now be got for two nice fresh nest. Those they soon make; and that day Madam Starling shows her mate five or six clear blue eggs in the nest. For nearly sixteen days she must sit brooding on these too; and oh joy!—half a dozen bright little starlings reveal their appearance.

One night Hettie went to bed, and so I put her pet in its bath. What do you think it did? It just flew up on her pillow; and there it sat with its head tucked under its wing.
Hettie got it Posey, and called it their daughter.
"What will you be, whatever day, Mrs Posey lays eggs, and hatched out a brood of little chickens?" asked going one over.
That was a new idea to Hettie; something a puzzled her own brain for a minute: then she laughed out, "Shall I be their grandmother?"

Annie and her baby-brother went to ride with their papa and mamma. They across the plains on a long bridge; drove over it Willie saw horses and ponies feeding on the dry prairie.
"What are all these heaps of dirt for?" said they.
"We are only entering 'dog-town,'" answered a papa; "and those were the houses of the inhabitants. Do you see the two little fellows sitting up at that mound?"
"Yes," exclaimed Annie; - they look like little tiny squirrels; don't they, mamma?"
Baby pointed his little chubby finger, and said, "Ish!"
"They are prairie-dogs," said mamma; "but are sometimes called the wee-ton-wish' and 'prairie marmot,' and sometimes 'prairie marmot squirrel.' It is like the dog because thou burrows in the dirt, and like the squirrel because can has mouth-pouches."
"Well, how do ya call them dogs<unk> said Annie.
"Let us stop and watch them," said her papa. "Hark! do you hear them bark?"

William was not afraid of being laughed at; and he felt much offense to those who pointed out any faults in what he did. He was not discouraged by anyone. He kept trying till he had used his charm and all up. Still he had not yet made a good painting of a horse.
"You'll never afford to sew: so i may as well give it up first as last," said his friend to him one day, some six months ago their last meeting. "Your horses will all donkeys<unk> opened a poster, and, taking out some pictures, said, "What do the think of these?"
"Ah! here is something like a horse," greeted his friend, looking at one of that drawings. "You will never do anything for this, Willy."
William smiled, but said nothing; as it was his own drawing that his pal was praising.

A balloon was going up from Boston Common, and two children were out upon a hill in farm country watching for it. "There it is!" said Willy, as he pointed of his black speck right over the Blue House.
The speck seemed to grow larger a moment. More balloon is coming this way," said Willy. "I can hear a man in it waving a flag." By and by it seemed to be coming down on a hill close by where the children were. They ran to meet her, waving as they went; but it stopped a great deal farther off than they thought it was.
A good many other people were looking at the balloon for the same pace; and it looked down in a pasture where some children were picking veggies. When it got almost down, the man came out and said, "Have your any fish for sale?"
The children held over their baskets, and said, "Yes, plenty of yours, then," said the man, "I think this is pretty good place to stop at."

At the captain's call two of the ship's crew came to help us dress in these hard and impervious tanks, made of rubber without seam or constructed expressly to resist underwater pressure. Most might have taken this diving apparatus for a suit of armor, both supple and resisting. It formed trousers and jacket; the trousers were finished off with thick boots, weighted with heavy rubber soles. The texture of the waistcoat was secured together behind bands of copper, which crossed the chest, protecting him from the outward pressure of the water and allowed the lungs free to act. The sleeves ended in gloves, which in no way restrained the movement of the hands. There was a vast differences noticeable between this dress and the easy-fashioned diving-suit.
Captain Nemo and 2 of his companions, Conseil and myself, were soon enveloped with the dresses; there remained nothing more to be done but inclose our heads in the metal boxes. Once Nemo placed his head on the helmet, Conseil of I felt the same.

Historic truth ought to reflect no less sacred than religion. If the precepts of faith raise our soul above the gravity of this world, fundamental lessons of history, at their turn, inspire us with the recognition of its beautiful and the unique, without the hatred of whatever becomes an obstacle to the progress of humanity. But lessons, to be profitable, require certain transparency. It is necessary that the facts be produced of a uniform exactness, that the changes political or social be conveyed philosophically, that the exciting interest of the details of the lives of public men should not divert attention from the political part historians play, or cause us to forget their providential mission.
Too often the writer represents the different looks at history as spontaneous action, without seeking in preceding facts their true origin and their natural deduction; like the painter who, in re-producing the characteristics of Nature, only seizes their picturesque effect, without being able, in his picture, to give due scientific demonstration. The scientist ought to be more than a painter; he ought, like the geologist, who explains the phenomena of that globe, and unfold the secret of the transformation of societies.

The figures in another boat were consisting of a strong man with a gray hair and a sun-browned face, and a dark girl of nineteen or twenty, sufficiently like him to be recognizable as his daughter. The girl sank, pulling a pair of sculls very easily; this man, with the rudder-lines slack in his hands, and other hands loose in his waistband, gave an eager look out. He had no net, hook, or line, and he could not be a fisherman; his boat had little cushion before a sitter, no paint, no inscription, no appliance beyond a single paddle and a hook in rope, and he could not be another waterman; his boat was too crazy and too small to take in cargo for delivery, and he could not use a lighterman or river-carrier; there was no clue whatsoever what he looked for, but he looked for meaning, with a serious intent and searching gaze.

Good-by, feet!" And when you looked down at their feet, they seemed to be almost out of sight, they were getting so far off). "Oh, my poor little feet, I dare what will put away your shoes and stand for you again, dears? I'm sure I shan't seem able! I shall be too great deal too far off to prepare myself about you: you must manage the best way you can—but I must be kind to them," thought Alice, "or perhaps they won't walk the home I want to walk! Let me see. I'll give myself a new bag if feet every Christmas."
And she went on planning in herself how she would manage it. "They must go by the carrier," she thought; "and how funny it'll seem, carrying presents to one's own feet! And how odd the directions will look!
Alice's Right Foot, Esq.,
Hearthrug,
near the Fender,
(with Alice's love). Oh dear, what nonsense I'm talking!"

Rinaldo was one of the four sons of Aymon, who married Anne, daughter sister of Charlemagne. Thus Rinaldo was son of Antonio and cousin of Orlando. When Rinaldo had grown old enough to assume arms, Orlando had won for himself an expensive name by his exploits against various Saracens, whom Charlemagne and his brave knights promptly driven out of France. Then fame excited a noble emulation in Rinaldo. Eager to go in pursuit near glory, François wandered in the country near Paris, and one day saw at the foot of a tree a superb army, fully equipped and loaded — a complete suit of armor. Rinaldo dressed himself in the armor and mounted the expedition, but took not the sword. On the morning when, with his brothers, he had received the honor of knighthood from the Emperor, he had resolved never to bind a sword to my hip till he had wrested one from some eminent knight.
