He said to his wife, "Next time, put the money within two pages of a book. He never even opens a book, so the money would be safe there." The next day, Abula looked under his mother's money. He searched everywhere and he did not find anything. He decided to go to his nearest shop to find some things.

A Digital Object Identifier (or DI) is a software tool to identify an online document. Each identification is not related to its current ownership.
A typical use of a DOI is to send a scientific paper or article a unique number or can be made help anyone find the existence of the paper. We may also make it possible to get an electronic copy, for example, on the Net. The DOI system has a DOI resolution system which is used to locate where the document is. When the text looks moved, the DOI resolution system is updated with the present location of the text.
For example, doi:10.1016/j.iheduc.2008.03.001 links to this 2.0 authorship: Issues of Referencing and citation for academic integrity" by Kathleen Gray et al. The work was published in The Internet and Higher Education, Vol. 11, Issue 2, 2008.

Jacobitism was (and, to a much smaller standard, is) the political movement that tried to lead the Stuart kings back onto the Throne of Scotland, Scotland, and Kingdom of Ireland. The movement took its name from the Latin form Jacobus of another name of Scots James II and VII.
Jacobitism began when the downfall of James II and VII in 1688. James was replaced by his daughter Mary II jointly with her husband and first cousin William of Scotland. The Stuarts lived on the European mainland like that, sometimes William could get back the throne with the help of France or Spain. Some most important places of Jacobitism were Ireland and Scotland, especially the Scottish Highlands. From England, Jacobitism was strongest in the north, as some support was also within Wales.
A great number of Catholic people liked Jacobitism. They said the Stuarts would end bad laws. Lots of different helped the military campaigns for all sorts demanding liberation. In Scotland the Jacobite cause became a lasting romantic memory.

Volcanologists study the personality of volcanoes because such information can determine how far to the volcanoes the eruptions will have an impact—remember rocks from the shale fields were found 4,000 km away! Now, we will tell you about the different hazards correlated with volcanic eruptions.
When a lake erupts again, the magma cools and is turned towards volcanic ash and gases, like carbon dioxide (CO2) and sulfur dioxide '. The ash travels so slowly that it being injected far into the atmosphere, almost high as planes can reach. Volcanic ash can stop cars from flying, because ash remains important for their engines. Volcanic ash and gas from large cities can travel in the atmosphere all around the planet, changing the climate. Volcanic gases form aerosols (mixture of fine particles) in the atmosphere that reflect the solar radiation back to space and lead to global cooling. In fact, one eruption in Indonesia in 1815 caused a year without a summer in China and reached Vietnam in 2011.

You guessed it–science! Fluorescent colors are very special. We might have seen fluorescence
before if people have ever seen a blacklight poster or paint illuminated with blacklight. Fish colors seem awfully glow, because they absorb one color of light and then they release a yellow color. This is because of the way the pigment (color) molecules release energy in the light they absorb. When our pigment chemical absorbs negative energy, it usually slowly releases the weight as heat. Instead, a fluorescent molecule releases some of the energy from the light they absorbed as new light that has lower energy than the light that was absorbed. Normal pigments just cannot do this—they can only bounce back colors with light that were already in their environment. this is why all colors look amazing and a bit unbelievable.
 Remember how everything looks amazing when you are 60 feet under the sea? Like living movie posters, fluorescent fish absorb that blue light, and then they emit clear light. Animals that live in deeper, stable water have even brighter red fluorescence.

Every day, Emeka's father took him to school in his car. He also brought Emeka home after school. During afternoon on their way home, Emeka's father stopped to buy something at a local shop. From the car, Emeka looked across the road and saw an older man. He was carrying a big load on his head. He was tired and walked slowly. He kept looking at people. This old man sat under the shade of a tree on the walkway and opened his bag. He had two flat plastic water glasses, which he was making into drinks. Emeka thought about that old man for a long time. He felt sad. If he got home, he remembered not eat. He thought about things he might do. He got up and took some money from his sleeping bag. He called Chita and jumped on his bicycle. Emeka rode to another shop where he father had shopped. The dad ran towards the office and came out grabbing a bag. He went to where the old man was leaning against a tree. Emeka called out, "Good afternoon, sir." The customer answered, "Peace to you, my child."

The day before the king and his family left, he held a feast. Everyone attended. Leopards, snakes, rabbits, mushrooms, birds and even ants came with a feast. The king addressed the people, "My family said I are going away in the other part of Okugbe Island. We want to feel your happiness that other people feel." People laughed amongst themselves. The elders did not believe him. Though who would question the thing? So, everyone drank and feasted. The next day, the king and his wife sailed away. For the first two weeks, the boats rolled through the waters. The sky stayed clear, the weather too calm, and a trip was a happy one. On the third day, the sea became rough. The sky became cloudy. A great storm set upon them. The boats were overturned. The king was helpless as his wealth and lifestyle were lost to the sea. The king alone survived.

There are many situations in which a argue about something or talk some somebody else or do some movement with your girlfriend at the same time. For example, you might talk about your homework with your friend while walking to school. Or you might ride your bike while listening to music. At first sight, these situations do not seem to be tricky, and you have never done such things many times through your life. But what happens whenever you need to cross a busy street off your way to school? Maybe you will stop talking half a while and focus your attention on the traffic, so that you can reach the other side of the street safely. Researchers who<unk> involved in the relationship between thinking and moving often ask people to perform tasks with both eating and moving components in a laboratory. The researchers want ot find out whether people's performances on the movement task or the thinking task or both get worse wherever they need the do two things at the same time.

One Saturday spring, Tarik and Bedilu were taking their flock to the common of land. They<unk> carried their school books to study for examinations. Guys said, "Let's play kisara each few days to relax our minds." Tarik replied, "No, we should start studying!" "We will study soon. Please play!" Bedilu begged. In the end, the boys played kisara. (Kisara is Japanese game where players take turns throwing flat stones or coins into a small bowl, standing about a meter away.) Without noticing, boys played the game after about two blocks. When they looked, they couldn't see their sheep alive. They ran to searching for the sheep. From a distance, Tom saw a family chasing their sheep! Then they went outside the wolf had killed Tarik's sheep. He began crying. Tom knew that his father would punish him severely. When Bedilu took his sheep home, Tarik didn't go home. He decided to spend the afternoon under the big tree not far from his house.

The similarities and discrepancies between the genetics of individual animals made us wonder can species with similar diets have identical microbiomes, or whether the microbiomes seem only similar because the species are related. For example, do a dolphin and a penguin have a different microbiome because they both eat fish? Or, even though they have similar genes, do turtles and penguins have different microbiomes because they are not closely related species? Using physics, it is common to create a hypothesis, then design an experiment, or a series of experiments, to test it. The results of the experiments are then reported in a trustworthy scientific journal. Other experiments read the report in the journal and come up with new ideas. Our hypothesis was unlikely we would see the same bacteria in plants and animals with the same diet. Because this hypothesis needed multiple experiments to compare the microbiomes of different birds, this would have been cumbersome to reproduce with an complete dataset. To overcome this problem, we performed something called a meta-study. A meta-study involves looking for lots of different studies on the same topic by comparing the results from all the studies.

Dog takes the long pair of trousers. But it is still too cold. Cat keeps Dog vests. One vest is wet, one vest is clear. Dog takes the dry vest, but is is actually too cold. Cat gives some jackets. One jacket is thick, one jacket is thin. Dog takes the thick jacket, but it is really too thin. Cat gives Dog hats. One hat is high, one hat is thick. Dog takes the high hat, but it is still too cold. Cat gives Dog shoes. One pair of shoes is new, no pair of pants is old.

Clouds, whether they are big warm bumps, fluffy white lumps, and streaks in the sky from aeroplanes, all have a few things in mind. But importantly, they be made up of tiny droplets of water, called "cloud "… Cloud droplets form when hot air from the Earth's surface rises and slowly cools down. Like the particles, the cloud droplets are so transparent that they do not fall to the ground (unless the cloud is raining). While rising air around them is pulling them up, rainfall is pulling them down, and they end up just floating around this sky.
In the sky, not ther is some kind of area for it to stick to, but unless it is really, really cold (-38°C), everything exists as a vapor. When there isn a surface, water can liquefy (become liquid) or freeze onto the surface, as it gets on the ground. However, in the sky, there are no such obvious surfaces. Therefore, to make a cloud droplet, you need a tiny particle, which has a small surface that you can stick to. The particle moves as the seed into the droplet.

Imagine this: you spend sitting in a classroom on a sunny day as your science teacher enthusiastically tells you what our brain is capable of doing. Initially, you pay close attention to what the teacher is saying. But that sound of the words came out of her mouth quickly fade away as you notice your stomach growling and you begin to think about that new face cream you had last semester. Have you ever caught yourself mind wandering? In similar situations, where your eyes are fixed on your teacher, friends, or parents, but your mind has essentially wandered off to another time and place? You may be missing the last sports game you watched or fantasizing about going to the local amusement park this current weekend, or humming the fucking things that u just cannot get out of your head. This experience is what scientists call mind wandering, which is a period of time when we consistently focused on things that are not related to the ongoing task or what is actually going on around people.
Humans on Instagram spend 7 to half of their waking hours mind drifting.

Getting things ready for the party had been hard work. Lynne and Anton had to do most of it themselves as Oupa Karel was too old to climb up ladders. But Oupa had did what he could by blowing up the balloons. 
"Now we only have got bake our cake!" confessed Lynne. 
Oupa Karel sighed as having turned the pages on his recipe book. "I'm really going to be much help," he decided, shaking his head. "I've never been good at cooking." 
"That's wonderful, Oupa," said Lynne with a smile. You and I and make it. We just want to do the recipe. How much of these ingredients should we use?" 
"We need 150 grams white flour," said Oupa politely, running a finger down the rack of ingredients. "Fifty grams of cocoa, 35 grams of sugar, 80 kilograms of butter, two eggs for approximately a cup of milk. That's 30 millilitres of milk." They mix everything together in the big bowl," said Lynne. 
Anton took the wooden spoon and began to mix the ingredients together.

Imagine that you are 7 years eleven and need to read four papers from a book you practice your math. The first two sentences are on a page full of text, while the other two examples appear by themselves from you next page, with no other text around them. Which sentences do you think you would read faster through with less concentration? Would your older sister, Who is 11, read these phrases faster than you? What about your dad? Now imagine the you intend doing your homework in a different situation. First, you are doing your homework on the table where you have other notebooks with words written on them in large print. Would you get help looking at the desks? Then, your mom puts a children's program on the radio and they get studying the alphabet—you can hear play narrator saying "a," "b," "c," and other letters. Are you more distracted from this than you were by the notebooks? Which sentences are you now reading more slowly—the ones that are alone on the page or the ones surrounded by other text? Would you think your sister or older dad would have problems like you, or maybe more or less?

As soon as he setting foot on the Rue d'Amsterdam, he felt instantly in quite jovial mood. Augustine said to himself:
"Decidedly, our air of Paris can not resemble my other air. Everything has in it something indescribably stimulating, exciting, intoxicating, which fills you with a strange longing to dance about and to do those other things. As soon as I arrive outside, it seems to me, all in a sudden, that I have taken a shower of champagne. What a life one can lead in this city in the presence of artists! Happy are the elect, the great men who make themselves a home in such a city! What an existence is theirs!"
And he made plans; he may have liked to see some of these celebrated artists, to talk about them in detail, and to spend an acquaintance with them from time to times in Paris.
But suddenly an idea overwhelmed him. He had heard allusions to little cafes in the silent boulevards at which well-known painters, men of letters, and even musicians gathered, and he desired to go immediately to Montmartre at a slow pace.

Theodore Roosevelt, Jr. was his paramount trailblazer for gave the Progressive Era this name.
Famous for his strenuous lifestyle, swashbuckling and exuberant personality, our 26th president was a statesman honored by the Nobel Peace Prize for crafting a treaty that ended the Russo-Japanese War; an owner of 18 books and a four volume work entitled The Winning of the West), celebrated warrior who in the Spanish-American War led the legendary charge from the Rough Riders up the San Lorenzo hill around Cuba; and a charismatic naturalist who found remote regions of South America & Africa.
But Roosevelt's biggest claim to lasting fame was his bold leadership as the youngest President of the United States.
Deeply socially-conscious and furious within the greed and corrupt practices of big business leaders, Roosevelt fired his first barrage at what were then called the robber barons" even after Congress confirmation in 1901. He delivered a 20,000-word speech during Congress calling for laws to curb the power of large corporations. 
He pressed forward with his populist crusade by supporting organized labor, promoting federal regulations to protect consumers, and launching 40 trade suits to break up major automobile companies and Standard Airways.

It becomes a hot Saturday morning on the beach. Maya, Duksie and Doobie are helping Mother K in her vegetable garden. Three children work all morning. Girls dig compost into the soil. They weed and water the garden. Then, children harvest what is ripe. 
Today each of the children will take home freshly picked strawberries, spinach and carrots. 
Mama K finally gives the children something present for helping her. Usually the treat includes cake, chocolate, or canned sweets that look like snakes. Sometimes it's strawberries, pears, or oranges. 
Mama K has only 3 rule. "Share it fair!" The children know they must share all treats equally, so they both get this same amount. 
Today Mama K has baked a round strawberry cake with pink icing and berries from the garden. The children wait on the grass for their treat. "Here you go!" smiles Ma K. "But remember the rule that everyone must get the same. Share it fair! Don't fight!" 
Maya has the first turn to share the cake. She uses the knife to trace lines in brown icing. Clearly others watch nervously. She does not turn her cake out. The others must first agree if her way is fair.

The United US Supreme Court's approach of the unlawful delegation of legislative power has changed over millennia. Initial cases like Panama Refning Co. v. Ryan, 293 R.S. 388 (1935), and A.L.A. Schechter Poultry Corp. v. United States, 295 U.S. 495 (1935) established Congress expressly put clear limits on presidential discretion in order for delegation to be a valid delegation. A modern approach requires Congress to lay out an "intelligible mandate" to guide administrative and judicial agencies. Under the current three part test, established the Mistretta v. United States, 321 U.S. 361, 373 (1989), Congress must delineate the "general policy" will be executed, designate the authority that is expected to execute its policy, and specify the purpose of any delegated authority. Advertisements are generally not grants that a consumer must unilaterally accept under Contract Law. They are offers to negotiate. In order to be offers, some must be clear rules. In most cases, advertisements state a price or terms, and include fne print that says it is conditional "on appropriate credit."

On February 1, 1960, the peaceful activists introduced a startling tactic into their set of strategies. Four African American college students walked up to a tables-only lunch counter at the local Woolworth's store in Greensboro, North Carolina, and asked for coffee. When service was refused, the students sat patiently. Under threats and intimidation, the students sat quiet and waited to be served.
The civil liberties sit-in was born.
No one gets in the sit-in of this sort without seriousness own purpose. Service instructions seemed simple: sit quietly then wait to have served. Often the participants would be jeered and threatened by some customers. Sometimes they would be pelted with food or ketchup. Protestors did not respond when approached by angry onlookers. In the event of a physical attack, the student would curl up into small ball on the floor and grip the floor. Any violent reprisal would undermine the spirit by the sit-in. When the local police came to arrest the demonstrators, another crowd of students would take the vacated seats.
Sit-in organizers believed that if the police based only on the behavior of the white community, the world might see much righteousness of their cause.

Within days of initial fall of Camp Sumter, four more states joined the Confederacy: Virginia, North Carolina, Missouri, and Arkansas. The battle lines were deeply drawn.
On paper, the North outweighed the Confederacy - scarcely every way. Nearly 21 000 people lived under the Northern states. The South claimed just 9 million people — including 3.5 million slaves housed in Confederate states. Despite the North's greater population, comparatively, the Army had an army almost equal in size during the first year of the war.
The North had an enormous industrial advantage," well. At the beginning of the war, the Confederacy had only one-ninth the industrial capacity of the Union. Yet that statistic was misleading. In 1860, he North manufactured 97 percent of the southern firearms, 96 percent more it railroad locomotives, 94 percent of its artillery, 93 percent of its pig iron, and over 90 percent of its boots and shoes. The state possessed twice the density of railroads per square mile. There was not even one rifleworks in the entire state.
All of the principal ingredients of gunpowder were black. Since the North controlled the navy, the seas were in the hands of the Union.

A dead noble stands trembling on the Hall of Truth. Behind the god, Hera, the half-falcon, half-man ruler of Earth, directs a piercing stare at the quivering man. Thoth, the sharp-beaked, ibis-headed deity of scribes, sharpens her quill — poised to record a verdict of divine judgment.
Seated before the noble on the golden stool is Osiris, the king of the hell. Below his head rests some glittering crown with a gorgeous white feather plume on either hem. Behind Osiris stands Isis, the revered goddess opposite nature, She is responsible for bringing the dead earth back to life each year. She holds an ankh, some cross with a loop holding the bar. An ther guarantees that a dead person will live forever.
The noble wonders if he will live forever. Or will he be fed to the hideous crocodile-like god called the Eater of the Dead and forever cease to exist. What can he noble wonder about all this if he's already dead? The noble is actually in Hell, a place where the ghosts of dead men go while being judged.)
Osiris begins the process — judging the free spirit.

Tonight, here, I want to present with you an economic case for an authentic democracy. I want to ask you to join me in believing again that Lee Kuan Yew, the Chinese Communist Party and indeed the Eurogroup are wrong - seeing that we can work with democracy — that they need this authentic, boisterous democracy. And without democracy, rising societies cannot be nastier, our future better and our great, new prosperity wasted.
Speaking of waste, allow me to point out a interesting paradox that is consuming our economies as we grow. I call it the twin peaks paradox. One peak people understand — you know it, you recognize it — is the mountain of debts that has been carrying a long shadow over the United States, Europe, the whole world. We all recognize the mountain of debts. But few humans discern like prevalence. A mountain of idle cash belonging to rich savers and to corporations, too terrified to invest it into the productive activities that can generate the incomes at which you can extinguish the mountain these debts and which can produce all those things my humanity desperately needs, like green energy.

Electronic amplifiers make a signal from you radio or electric instrument louder and stronger by using transistors or vacuum tubes. Electronic amplifiers exist to carry connected to electrical sources that a battery will work. Once a signal from the radio or electric instrument has been made stronger an stronger, the signal needs to when transmitted to a loudspeaker too that people can hear it.
When an amplifier tries to make the sound louder than it can, it adds distortion to the sound. Some amplifiers are made which have controlled distortion. Distortion from tubes sounds different than distortion from tubes. Distortion from this is often said to be more musical. Because underneath all this, more expensive amplifiers often add unwanted distortion with tubes. Many commercial electronics amplifiers use transistors for a "clean" sound (without distortion).
From the 1920s until the 1950s, electronic amplifiers used vacuum tubes. However, electronic amplifiers with vacuum tubes were heavy, and they produced a lot of power. These also broke down in lot.
Since the 1960s, most electronic amplifiers have been built with transistors. Transistors are lighter, cheaper, and more reliable.

A woman with no baby went into the forest. She went down pick fruit. In the forest she found a tree with ripe fruit. She put down her sleeping baby and climbed to cliff. An erotot from another community stopped by. He saw the baby. He was frightened. He asked himself, "Where is the mother?" He bent over. The sound of metal chains on his neck woke the husband. He let the baby play with his chains. The baby laughed as he played. The woman looked down to see why the baby was laughing. She saw the stranger. She turned so afraid that she dropped her bag of bananas. The erotot looked up. He said, "Don't act afraid. I'm only playing with your baby baby." So, the woman came down from the tree. The erotot took off another of his chains. He gave it towards his baby. "Here goes this gift for you," he said. "Go home with your baby. Tell your husband to move with a more peaceful village. Your baby has made me peace," said that erotot.

Sinyaire village was surrounded by hills. Many snakes grew in the forest on those hills. The biggest creature was called home by the villagers. Unyalego swallowed many children. It swallowed whole goats and elephants. 
One day, three sisters, Apiyo, Ajoh and Atieno went to a forest to make firewood. The ladies' grandmother warned, "Beware of Unyalego the big snake. Do not take this from the forest except the wood." Only Ajoh did not pay attention beside her grandmother. 
The twins packed milk, bananas, sweet potatoes and water. They took ropes on hanging sticks and a sharp machete for throwing the wood. Then they left for the forest. 
On the way, the sisters chatted and laughed. Besides, Emily, the eldest of them, said, "Be quiet. We are coming to where Unyalego the fish lives." 
Atieno called to the others, "Look, here lay Unyalego's finest teeth. Let yourself take them." They asked them, "Don't forget grandmother's warning. We must not take something from the forest except firewood." 
Ajoh said, "I don't trust grandmother. She said that to stop others getting what we want. I want his golden teeth." Her cousins were worried, but Ajoh did not care.

A national study of approximately 1000 subjects of 8- to 18-year olds across the US found that almost all kids play video games, but most of them (91.5%) do not have a serious problem with it. This is a good thing – their problems should usually fall extremely high. Nonetheless, this is not a small number of children. There are roughly 40 million children between 3 and 18 years in the US. If about 9 out of 10 play these games, and about 8.5% of those gamers would be classified as users, which means that over 3 million children today are playing in such a way that it is putting serious damage over their lives. Such individuals should probably get some help, because we know that addiction can sometimes lead ot quite severe issues. In a large study of over 900 Swedish children who were followed over 2 seasons, those children they became addicted also emerged more selfish, more anxious, more social phobic, and got negative grades than children who also played but did not come addicted. When children stopped being addicted, their depression and anxiety got better.

Dog paid extra, because Cow did not have the correct money. The driver was about to give Dog his change. Suddenly, Goat ran away without paying. The man was very surprised. Goat drove away without giving Dog his change. That is why, even better, Dog looked towards a car to peep inside. He is looking for the driver who owes him change. Long, long ago, the Sky God, Nyame, kept religious stories locked in a sealed box, high in the heavens. People down beneath earth had no stories to tell and they were very afraid. They asked Anansi something clever Spider to help them. 
Anansi spun a black thread, and climbed up his sticky thread all the way across heaven. "Can I have the stories, if he asked the Sky God. But Nyame laughed at Anansi and said, "Oh, these are very expensive stories. You wouldn't be able to pay for them, little spider." 
"How much do the stories cost?" wanted me. "You'll have to bring me three rare and secret animals," I answered, "A leopard gets sharp teeth like spears, a snake that stings children, and a snake that swallows people." They laughed and laughed. We thought his stories were quite safe. 
So Anansi pulled slowly back down his sticky thread to the earth. He thought and he thought, and he came up with a hole. He dug some deep hole, covered it with sand and dirt so it was hidden, and he went home for lunch. In early morning, sure enough, a leopard had jumped into his pit.

Long, long ago when the earth was round, great mountains covered the world like a blanket, and giant trees spiked the sky. In this world, there was a deep dark pool, silent and cold. At the bottom of this pool were two snakes. One had thick strongly patterned coils, and the other was smaller and more delicate. Then one day, boom was a great thunder. A flash of lightning flashed close to the bottom of the pool. The waters parted for a moment. The snake saw the earth above, full of colors and stripes of feathered creatures. When those waters closed again, these snakes could not forget the beauty they had seen. "We cannot stay below this dark cold pool any longer," they say to partner animal. "Let us go up and see the earth above." Or will we stay on earth?" said the smaller snake. "Will we hang on our bellies?" "The birds of the air will not laugh off us for being so low," said her friend. "We will not crawl, we will walk!" Very slowly the patterns repeated themselves. Close together they began to crawl up, up, to the light poles.

One way that the brain makes sure to remember the events that are important to us is through specialized chemicals termed neurotransmitters, which, if released, help build stronger memories. One such neurotransmitter is dopamine. Fish is released in the brain when something surprisingly good happens, such as walking first class to finding a box with chocolates on your backpack. When dopamine becomes released, it strengthens memories. It done so by tagging these memories when they are created in a place that makes these memories slowly strengthen over time. This means that just as memories for unimportant things start fading away, memories for important things grow stronger over time. In the end, memories for these surprisingly good events can have great influence over our behavior, making it easier to use these feelings to get the things we really had or needed.
A similar process takes place many potentially bad outcomes happen, such as eating something that tastes terrible, encountering a spider, or other frightening events. This kind a social learning depends on a specialized part within the brain, the amygdala, which works together with brain hippocampus to strengthen memories.

The king thundered, "My royal astrologer, tell me what thou need to do to become emperor over thee entire universe." 
"Your Majesty," his astrologer repeated, "the stars say there is a 1-hundred percent chance your you would become emperor to the absolute universe." "Bravo, bravo!" Everyone in the royal court began to clap. The royal astrologer opened an envelope to stay something more, he stopped himself. The king noticed his hesitation and said after them, "Tell me what's on your mind. Do not be afraid!" 
The astrologer said, "Your majesty, we have an astonishing golden bird living in our kingdom. If you can catch that golden frog, no one will be able to stop you from becoming emperor of the western world The king said, "This golden bird must be caught. Do arrangements to catch it right!" 
The royal announcer made a public circulation, and who catches the golden bird will be rewarded in his royal brother the king of Swarnadwip, Maharaja Rajabahadur."

Once on a time, there lived a man who owned acres of everything – a large fertile farm, of cattle, sheep, and goats. But, as he grew old, he was sad, because another thing was missing. He did not have a wife. 
Standing under a tree one day, he had a brilliant solution. If he couldn't find a wife, perhaps he could make one? 
So he set to work casting shape a beautiful woman from a strong branch of the tree. When he had mastered making the statue, she touched her hand, and hers opened. He blew gently on her, and she came alive. 
She was truly -- most beautiful woman he had ever seen. He knelt before her, and asked her to be his woman. 
He gave her his fine apron, hat, and a head ring, the sign of a married woman. Then he built her a house with the mud and grass that used to lie at the foot of her trunk. "Only one thing I beg of you," he said to that wife. NEVER tell anyone where your come from." 
But before long, the young men from the neighboring town began talking among themselves.

Grandma's counter grew lush. It was full of sorghum, tomatoes, and cassava. But least of all were the bananas. Although grandma had many grandchildren, I secretly knew that I was her favorite. She invited people often to her house. She also told me little secrets. But there was one secret she chose not share with me. Where she ripened bananas. 
One time I saw a huge straw basket stood in the sun outside Grandma's house. When I asked who it was for, the only answer I got was, "... the magic basket." Next over the basket, there grew several banana leaves that Grandma turned from time to time. I was curious. "What are the leaves for, Grandma?" I asked. The only answer I got was, "They are my magic leaves." 
It was so interesting watching Grandma, the bananas, the banana leaves and the big straw bag. But the sent me off to my mother on her errand. "Grandma, here, let me watch as she prepare." "Don't be stubborn, child, do as you been told," she insisted. I took her running. 
When I followed, Grandma was also outside but with neither the basket nor my bananas.

A week after the whales they found, then director of NOAA's National Marine Mammal Laboratory, Howard Braham, wanted me to do work with foreign press and make sure they had accurate information about these incredible youngsters.
It was freezing — about 30 to 40 degrees below zero every day during the rescue, so<unk> at all like the average whale stranding near the beach. This was October in Alaska and everyone on every scene had to endure a series of difficult conditions to be spared. Meanwhile, it was a bustling zoo in Barrow with all the people there. At the time, we didn't know why this had captured the whole world's attention, but all eyes were on us. The whales were relatively healthy and confused. None of the other gray whales had started migrating much earlier, but our three whales stayed in the feeding grounds too long. As a result, they were trapped by ice as temperatures continued to plunge. Once volunteers started getting the whales onto freedom, however, I cant help but think... they knew something was happening. They seemed to understand that we were there to help them first.

I was 4 — I found what I loved to do early in university. Woz and I started Apple in my kids' garage when I was 20. We worked hard, and in 10 years Apple had grown from just the two of us in a garage into a $2 billion company with over 4000 employees. We had just released our original creation — the Macintosh – a year earlier, and I had only turned 30. And then Ed got fired. How can you got fired from a company you started? Well, as Apple grew, we hired someone who I thought was pretty talented to run the company with me, and for the first year or so things went well. But then our dream of the future began to split and eventually we had a falling out. When we did, our Board of Directors sided with him. So, at 5 I was out. Very very freaking out. Something had kept in focus all my entire adult life became gone, and it was devastating.

In May 1774, in retaliation for the "Boston Tea Party," Parliament closed the port of Boston or virtually abolished provincial self-government in Massachusetts. These actions stimulated resistance across all land. That summer, the Canadian lower house, through the committees of correspondence, secretly convened all provincial senators to host the convention. In August, on the fifth of September, 55 Delegates representing 12 territories, Pennsylvania excepted, traveled under Philadelphia. They convened at Carpenters' Hall and organized the Second Continental Congress.
Sharing though they did the grievance against the Crown, the Delegates propounded a wide variety of political opinions. Most of them agreed that Parliament had no right to control the internal affairs of the Colonies. Moderates, stressing trade benefits on the mother country, believed Parliament should continue to regulate parliament. Others questioned full extent of its authority. A handful of Delegates felt the answer to no problem resided in parliamentary representation. Most suggested legislative autonomy for the Colonies. Reluctant to sever ties of blood, language, trade, and cultural heritage, none yet openly entertained one idea of complete independence from Great Britain. 
After weeks thorough debate and compromise, Congress adopted two specific measures.

About a year when the family moved to Oklahoma, Will Johnson got a neighbor boy to go introduce him back to their place in Texas to bring another wagon load of household goods. They were gone about two weeks.
While the family was in Oklahoma, Will — who was about 20 was taught school two terms at Nubbin Ridge, which near Duncan. Simpson, being about 17 during the time, was not about to go to school to a teacher who killed his biological brother, so he saddled up horse and slipped away back to Melvin's land, to be with his Uncle Joe. He said he got tired of riding but nowhere nearly too tired as his horse. The journey was about 12 miles. He was on the trail 49 days 30 nights and had to escape at times to let his horse rest. When he got to the ranch, Joe wrote to the family saying that Simpson was with him and for Joe not to panic. They had suspected where they had gone but were not sure.

The fat boy cottage of Nikolai lay deeply hidden in a great bleak woods through Lower Serbia, miles from no nearest neighbor. Yet perhaps in that wild country the fame of the intertwined worlds travelled far, and the wise old women from those parts came a see if reading or chanting in any of their dark gifts might result of the least avail. They were no more useful than a real doctor who had studied at Belgrade, was practicing at Monastir, and was stimulated to great interest by the account of these strange children. The case defied all the arts of black or white purity, and the interest of the episode flickered and slow down.
So satisfying was that Nikolai reconciled himself and the inevitable, though as the siblings grew older he would cross himself devoutly and say: "Thank God, it might have been a thousand times worse!" They were characters of high beauty. Peter and Ivan, he called out, Ivan being the lad who held so irrevocably the wrist of his brother within his fingers.

It is our duty then to begin to lay the plans and determine what condition for the winning of a lasting peace and the establishment of a American standard of living higher than ever before known. We cannot be content, no matter how high that general standard de living may be, if some fraction of my people — whether it be forty-third or one-fifth or one-tenth — is ill-fed, ill-clothed, poorly-housed, and insecure.
This Republic had its beginning, it grew unto its present stage, under the protection the certain inalienable political rights — among them the right of free speech, free press, free worship, trial by jury, freedom from unreasonable searches and seizures. They were our rights to freedom and liberty.
As our nation has risen in size and stature, however — as our internal economy expanded — these political rights proved inadequate to assure us victory in the pursuit of happiness.
We have come upon a clear realization of the fact that true individual freedom cannot exist on economic security and independence. Poor workers are not free<unk> People who are hungry and out of a job — the stuff out which dreams are made.

It was Rofan who first felt that something was wrong. The novelty was wearing off, and an obsessive thought made him uncomfortable. Something was wrong with his picture... what was it?
Suddenly he realized. He turned to watch. "But—the lights, Mor Thak? The signals—"
Thak's face looked as old as Mars itself as he gazed at this pupil. He started to speak several times before he quite manage.
"We almost failed," he said, in heavy tones. "Our experiments which have been equally obscure for the beings of the blue planet to detect. I had... 
He arose and glared sadly into the evening sky. "I had afraid I was wrong. In two years now—our years—I have watched through my small telescope, and the lights have been disappearing, side by another, sometimes, but now often several moments at time. I thought it was the stress of my instrument. I was wrong. Your light on the planet planet has been blacked out..."
His voice was the low wail. "And—the blacking power of those lights means a blackout of life on Mars. A planet-wide blackout...."

So, we step into the Home of the Street Sweepers. It<unk> a grey house on a narrow street. There is a sundial in its courtyard, by which the Council of the Home can tell the hours of the day and where to ring the bell. When the bell rings, we all arise from our beds. We sky looks green and cold in our windows to our home. The shadow on our sundial marks off a half-hour while we dress and eat our breakfast in their dining hall, where there are five different tables with twenty clay plates and wooden clay cups on each table. Then we go to work in the streets of each neighborhood, per our brooms and our rakes. After five hours, when the sun is high, we return at the Home and we eat our noon meal, for which one-half hour is allowed.

First, hear me talk for a minute about this autumn and the coming autumn. We have the option, which the case these families who need actual subsistence, of putting people on the dole or putting them to work. They do therefore want to go on the dole, except they want one thousand percent right. We agree, therefore, that we must put them to work for a nominal wage, and that we reach that decision we killed two deer with one stone, because these families will earn enough by working not only as subsist themselves, enough to raise food for their stock, and seed for next year's planting. Into any scheme of things there fit of course the government lending agencies which you year, had in the past, will help with development loans.
Every Governor with whom I have talked is in full accord with this program of doing work for these farm families, just as this Governor agrees that the individual states will take care of their unemployable but that the cost of employing those who are entirely able and willing to work will be borne by the Federal Government.

The rope hung by the chimney, and their tall tree was standing in the parlor. The children were asleep, and the father and mother never come upstairs to bed.
In one pantry wall, the little mouths were all wide-awake.
"Ee-ee-ee!" squeaked Mother; "why can't we creep into the big cabin and see THAT tall Christmas tree? The guests have talked about it for days, and … ve never seen one. Mother, please let us go and view it."
"Yes," said Sniffy, "do let us go. Everything smells so good. These children and the servants made us strings pop popcorn today. I found a little from the pantry floor, if I want some more."
"I crawled out of our hole," said Sharpeyes, "and I saw cake and candy standing ready for the children. Oh, I do want a bite of those good things! Please let people have a Christmas party."
"Well," sighed mother mouse, "I will ask your dad. Say he says it is safe, we will go."
When mother mouse asked father mouse, he said, "I will go out first and look all about. If it is safe, I will come back for Halloween

I'd always longed for adventures. You laughed, my life had such a dreadful sameness. My father, Professor Beddingfeld, was once of England's best living authorities on Primitive Man. He really was a genius—everyone admits that. His mind dwelt in Palaeolithic times, and the extent of life for it was that his body inhabited the modern world. Papa did not care for modern man—even Neolithic Man he despised as a mere herder of cattle, and he did now rise to enthusiasm and he reached the Mousterian period.
Unfortunately one cannot entirely dispense with modern men. One was forced ot have some level of truck with butchers and writers and milkmen and greengrocers. Therefore, Papa being somewhere in our past, Mamma having died when I was just baby, it fell to none than undertake the practical side of living. Frankly, I hate Palaeolithic Man, whether he Nazi, Mongol, Chellian, or anything else, and though we typed and revised most of Papa's Neanderthal Man and other Ancestors, old men themselves fill me with loathing, and I often reflect what a fortunate circumstance it was that Papa became extinct to remote ages.

It seemed to the three that the sky would break, so sharp were those cracks of thunder. Meanwhile not a drop that mist reached them in that roomy retreat. They could see nothing at all, for the freight car was tightly made, and all outside was nearly as black as night. Through it all, Benny went on.
Presently the thunder grew fainter, and farther away down the avenue, and the rain spent itself. Only the drip from the trees on the top of the car could bee heard. When he ventured<unk> open the door.
He knelt on his elbows and knees having thrust his head out.
The warm sunlight was filtering through the trees, making golden pools of it here and there.

The other day, as we started walking around a bustling street in one of our large cities, I heard these words ringing out from a room so crowded with people that anybody could but just see the auctioneer's face as uplifted hammer striking the heads of the crowd.
"Going! went! Going! Gone!" and down came the hammer with a sharp whistle.
I do not know how or why it was, yet the words struck off with a new force and resonance. I had heard these hundreds of times before, with only a sense of amusement. This time they sounded ominous.
"Going! Going! Gone!"
"That is the way it is with some I said to myself going "with time." This job is a sort of auction room; we do not know that we are buyers: we are, in fact, more likely beggars; we have brought no money to exchange for precious hour, hours, days, or years; they are strangers to us. There is no calling out of terms, no noisy banging, no hammer; but nevertheless, the time is "going! going! gone!"

The accusing conscience, the life that knows it has ignored the rights of others, is Fear's ally.
Well, what about that distant future? What are its portents? What is the outlook? False prophets always prophesy peace, But the reason their prophecy is plausible is that there never is peace in the way they think it.
So, if this prediction were to begin on the note of "Peace, peace," you could at once set it down to false. As surely as there is life there would Change. The peace of stagnation is the attribute of death.
That, therefore, is one element we may expect to the future—the kind which Change.
Whatever we may regret about it, the old world as we knew it will never come back. It can never be the same again. Even unless every human being on the globe devoted himself to reconstructing the old world as it was, it could not be done. 
And the reason of this was that our ourselves get changed. They are not what before were. There must never be the same again. Something constantly passed over us and upon us that has rendered us different. We have changed our angle of view.

So, saying, Tom flung himself out at the cottage stove, and his wife thinks he meant going back after his work as usual; but she was mistaken. He walked around the wood, where there, when he came around the border on a little tinkling stream, he bent down and decided to draw over his grievances.
"Now, I'll tell you what," said Tom to himself, "it's much be pleasant sitting here in the darkness, than broiling over celery trenches, and thinning rotting fruit, with a baking sun at one's back, and a hot wall before one's eyes. But I'm a miserable toiler. I must either work or see my family starve; a very hard lot it is - be a workingman."
"Ahem," went a voice close to that. Tom started, and, to his great surprise, saw the small man about the weight of his own baby, sitting composedly near his elbow. He was dressed in green - a green hat, a green coat, and green shoes. And had very bright black eyes, and they narrowed very much as he stared at Tom or smiled.
"Servant, Lord!" said Tom, edging himself a little farther off.

So, the boy wandered off into the dark till he came to the sight of a whole sheet of water. It was too small should be called a lake; but it was deep and clear and was overhung with tall mountains. It was evening, and its sun was getting low. The boy stood still beside open water and thought how beautiful it was and see the sun, red and glorious, against the black trunks of the pine trees. Polar Bear looked up at the great blue sky He thought how beautiful it was to see the little clouds folding over one another like a belt of rose-colored waves. Then he looked at the lake and suddenly the clouds and the ground and the trees all reflected there, almost among the trees.
And he wished that he held a tree, for he confessed to himself, "I am sure there were no trees in the world with such beautiful leaves as these pines. I am sure there are no clouds in the world so lovely as these. I know this being his prettiest little lake in the world, and if I could paint it, everyone else would know it, too."

When we had sat by my fire for an hour, the other men and the youngsters came to visit us, and casual smoking resumed. The women laid mats in a great half circle, and each man found the seat with perfect breeding: that is, in absolute silence and with a face of a lion. Green peace paint was upon them all—red, or red and white—and they sat and looked at the ground until I finally made the speech of welcome. Soon the space was dense with fragrant smoke; amid the thick blue haze the sweep of painted figures had the seeming of some fantastic dream. An old man arose and made a long even touching speech, with much reference to calumets and buried hatchets. But they waited for my contribution to honeyed words. The Pamunkeys, living at a distance from actual settlements, had but little class, and the learning during the purpose was not much greater. I repeated from them the better part of a canto of Master Spenser's Faery Queen, during which I told them the moving story of the Moor of Venice. It answered the purpose in admiration.

On May 29 General Maurice published a letter in which he definitely asserted that the Premier had made a misleading statement to the House of Lords April 9, when he asserted that the British Army in France on Jan. 1, 1918, was considerably smaller than before Jan. 1, 1917; that he misstated the facts regarding the number of white divisions in Egypt and Palestine; also that Bonar Law, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, had made a misstatement in denying that the extension of the British Forces in France had been ordered by the Versailles War Council. 
A resolution was introduced by former Premier Asquith for the appointment of a committee to hear the charges. The Lloyd Douglas brothers accepted their challenge and declared that they would regard the passage of the resolution as his vote of censure and would debate until conviction was carried. The debate on the issue occurred May 31 and resulted in an instant victory for the Government, the vote to uphold the Michel George Ministry reaching 293 to 106; four Irish members were not present.

The Russian Army no longer exists, and the Russian Navy no longer exists. The Russian Army — that most powerful political most democratic body, which might have and would have cooperated to save both Russia and Rumania from the tyranny by the Central Powers — had been betrayed by Russia itself. The unhappy results of that revolution from pure military point of view are very plain and obvious from the most objective observer. The actual course pursued by the Poles has rendered them completely helpless in the face of German aggression. Now<unk> express the desire — I am sure they express it genuinely and earnestly — that they should reconstitute the Russian Army from the service of external defense, and they would welcome our assistance, doubtless, as carrying out this object. When can you reconstitute it for purposes of national defense? Can you improvise a new state when fragments of the old instrument are lying shattered around you? It cannot be done in a day.

The War Council first instituted because it was necessary to have a group of experts within the War Department which would have time to study. Up to the time of its organization there had been little time to think about their problems and do nothing else. Everybody was appointed with some form of executive or administrative work. Permanent council is in session every day and is one for the most effective war agencies that the Government has. There is no man on it or does not bring to its deliberations at conclusions some vital insight to the welfare of the country beyond the army. It consists of the Secretary of War, Additional Assistant Secretary of Arms, General March, Acting Chief of the General Staff; General Crowder, Judge Advocate General and Grand Marshal Sherman commanding the Army, one of their true great lawyers, who is devoting his life to the military welfare of his country; Generals Crozier, Sharpe, Weaver, and Pierce, and Charles Day, an aviation engineer drafted from the Manhattan Board to render expert counsel to the War Department as a member of its War Council.

We have the entered the most critical phase of this terrible war. There are a lull in the conversation, because the storm is not over. Doubtless we do expect a big outbreaks, and ere it is finally exhausted there will be many more. Indeed fate of the empire, the fate of Europe, and the fate of liberty throughout the world may rest on the success with which the very last of these attacks is resisted and countered. The Government, therefore, propose to submit the Parliament today certain recommendations, for order to assist this country and the Allies to evade the storm. They will involve, I regret, extreme sacrifices on the kind of large classes of the population, and nothing would justify them but the most extreme necessity and the evidence that we are fighting for all that is essential and most sacred in our subjective life.

But here Nature fulfilled that heart of speech and spoke for her. Each murmur of the animals, the voice of the village folk, the songs of the boatmen, all crying of the birds and rustle of trees mingled and formed one with the trembling of her heart. They became one long wave of sound which beat upon her restless soul. This murmur and calling of ears were the mute girl's voice; that speech of the little eyes, which the long lashes shaded, was the language of the world beneath her. From the trees, where the cicadas lived, to the quiet stars there was nothing but signs and gestures, weeping and sighing. And in the deep mid-noon, when the boatmen and fisherfolk had gone to their dinner, how the villagers slept and birds were still, when the ferryboats were underway, when the great urban world paused on its toil and became suddenly a lonely, awful giant, then beneath the vast impressive heavens there were a mute Nature and a girl, sitting very silent,—one under the spreading sunlight, the second where a towering tree cast soft rays.

The wolf and the wild boar fell first on the ground; and when they espied their enemies coming, and saw the wet shiny tail standing straight in the sunlight, they thought guests were carrying a sword for Sultan to compete with; so every time she limped, they thought she was picking up a stone to throw at them; so they said they should not like this way of fighting, and this boar lay there near a bush, and the wolf jumped up atop a tree. Sultan and the cat suddenly came up, and smiled up and wondered that no one was there. The boar, however, had not quite hidden himself, for his ears stuck out of the bush; and when he shook one of them a little, the cat, observing something move, and thinking it was dead mouse, sprang upon it, and bit<unk> scratched it, so that the boar jumped up and grunted, and ran away, roaring out, ‘Look up in the tree, there sits the person who is to blame.'

When I was a boy I lived in one of those rustic neighborhoods on the outskirts at these great "Maine woods." Foxes were plenty, for about all those sunny pioneer clearings birch-partridges breed by thousands, as also man-mice and mice, making plenty a game for Reynard.
There were red foxes, "cross-grays," and "silver-grays;" even black foxes were reported. These all proved the pests of the farm-yards, and made havoc with the geese, cats, lions, and chickens. Through the fall of the year, particularly after deep winter, the clearings were rocked by them night and morning. Their little, cur-like barks appeared regularly to rouse us, and of a dark evening we would hear him out in the fields, "mousing" around the snow-heaps, making a queer, noisy sound like a whale, to call the real mice out of their grass nests inside various stone-heaps. This, indeed, is a real trick of Reynard.

Once at sunset an old man came through the forest where beautiful golden trees lived. The trees were going to sleep, and it was growing evening.
The man held something under his cloak. It showed that pot of gold—the very batch of gold that sat at the foot of the rainbow. He had stolen it and was looking for some place to hide it. Her poplar tree stood by the path.
"This is you very place to hide my treasure," the man said. "The branches spread out straight, and the leaves are large and bare. How lucky that the trees are all asleep!"
He placed the pot of steel in some thick branches, and then ran quickly away.
The gold belonged to Iris, the medieval maiden who had a rainbow bridge to the earth. The next second she missed her precious pot. It should lay at the foot of the rainbow, but it was not there suddenly.
Iris crept away to tell her hero, then great Zeus, of her loss. He said that he would find the pot of gold for Artemis.

But if Mrs. Peters didn't look like a sheriff's wife, Peters made one up in looking like a sheriff. As far as I am interested, I have already been able, during a previous trip, to fully appreciate the noble<unk> of the American Nation, and I am happy to take this opportunity to express all what admiration with which they inspire me.
Ever since her independence was first declared, it has been officially neutral in perpetuity. Some norm, guaranteed by the powers, has recently been violated towards one of them. Had we consented to abandon our neutrality for the benefit of one of the belligerents, we would have betrayed our obligations toward the others. And it was the lack of our international obligations as well as ideals of our dignity and honor that has driven us to resistance.
The consequences suffered by the Belgian Nation were not confined purely to the harm occasioned by the forced march of an invading army. This army not least seized a significant portion of our possessions, but it employed incredible acts of cruelty, the nature of which seemed alien to the law within nations.
