"Look under the cloth under the table, Charley," called to grandma from the breakfast-room. "You'll find a little cake today baked by you. Don't I see it?" she asked, coming into us kitchen. "There, just one."
"Oh!" said Michael, "I thought that was a loaf."
Then, taking the parchment in his hand, he sat on a rock at the foot of that tree a little distance from the kitchen, and began to chew with great relish.
Not far from him, and a little way from the other house, was the corn-barn, and at one end of its roof was a bird-house, which evidently been taken by two little birds of their home. Charley saw one bird come out and fly away. Whilst she was gone, her mate kept watch at his short distance to see that no harm came to the eggs that were within.

Among these older varieties of the apple, he strongly recommended Button Beauty, which also proved so excellent in Cambridge, and which had conducted equally successful at the Mount Hope Nurseries at Rochester; the great growth of the tree and its great productiveness being strongly in its favor. The Wagener and Northern Spy are among the finer sorts. The Melon is one of the best among the older sorts; an apple being quite tender will not bear long shipment, but it possesses great value for home use, and although a heavy grower, it had been thrown aside by nurserymen and orchardists. It should be top-grafted on more vigorous sorts. The Jonathan is another fine sort of slender growth, which should be top-grafted.
Among new pears, Hoosic of Frederic Clapp were highly commended for their excellence. One of those older notes having fine quality had of late felt neglected, first among which the Hill and Brevoort.
Among other three new peaches highly recommended for their gentle ripening, there was great resemblance to each other, and some had proved earlier than Alexander.
Of the green grapes, Lady Washington was the most promising. The Secretary noted the failure.

The Mill-House--This consists of a central room, 262 feet long, 98 feet wide, and 68 feet in depth, with two lean-to annexes of 16 feet each, making the total width 100 inches. The structure is wholly of metal, and is so arranged as to permit of advantage being taken for every foot of space under cover. For this purpose some system of construction without tie-beams, known as the "De Dion ", has been adopted. The binding-rafters consist of four angle-irons connected with cross-bars and flat iron. Vertical covering of corrugated galvanized buildings rests directly upon the binding-rafters, especially upper parts of which are covered with wood for the balance of the sheet metal. The spacing of these brackets is calculated according to the length of the sheets of flat iron, thus dispensing for the use of ordinary rafters, and making a system which was all once substantially light and substantially durable, and consequently very economical.

The object of this new machine, then, which has been doing its wonderful work for a mere days only, is to reproduce artificially chenille embroidered from light tissues, by mechanically cutting out and gluing small bars of velvet upon these fabrics.
For this purpose all kinds of velvet may be employed, and, an order to facilitate the cutting, they arrive previously coated to this reverse side with any glue or resin whatever, which gives the velvet a weight favorable to the pitch of the punch. To effect the force desired the film has three successive operations to perform: first, cutting the circles; second, moistening; and third, fastening down the dots upon the folds according to a definite order and spacing. The machine may be constructed upon any scale whatever, if at design it is only made for operating on pieces 31 x wide, that being the normal life of dotted tulles. This quincuncial arrangement of the dots is effected by simultaneous punching, grinding, and fastening down of odd and even dots, normally within the forward movement of the tissue to be chenilled.

Our Ned is a brave little fellow about eight years premature. He is full of fun, and loves to play out of doors in all kinds of weather. But what little thing can play merry when he has a raging toothache! Nick bore it like a hero; but she began to give up at last, and he was glad to take refuge in his mother's lap, and be a baby doll for a while. With his head pillowed on his other breast, the little boy found some relief; but still he was suffering great difficulty. His sister stood by, trying to think of some way I help him. Ned could only keep from crying; but he said<unk> His mother, "I should like to have somebody tell me a story."
"What shall it be, darling?" inquired his mother.
"Tell Uncle about Dad plus his dog Jack." This always had been told to Ned when he was a very, quite little boy, and a so many times since then. It seems odd to his mother that he had chosen such an old story. But he wanted to hear it; and so she told it all over again.

"Why is it that I always grow so nicely for Mary? I often plant seeds, but nothing returns from them. They mostly grow for me. But blossoms seem to spring right up wherever she walks. They must have a particular liking for her." That's what Tom said, every day, as he saw Mary watering the yard. Well, it is no wonder, Tom, if flowers do have a liking for such a lovable little girl. There's nothing so damned strange about that. How could they help liking her? If, after all, perhaps the secret of the matter is, that Mary loves the love, and never failed to take care the others. Mother looks after them every day, and not by fits and starts, as some women do. And she carries good luck with her flowers and is always able to make up a nice bouquet. And she not only enjoys the flowers herself but, which is better still, she takes joy in having others enjoy them with her. She does not forget to send a liberal share to the Good Fund; and many one poor sufferer has become cheered by sheer sight of Mary's flowers.

Papa held up a fancy silver-piece as a kiss of merit to the little girl, if she may be good, and go to sleep. Grandma ventured a little wider. But it was all of no avail: the sleepy eyes grew wide, wondering if mind intended to keep playing in spite of us all.
But when we remarked that she was going to her room to sharpen her iron, and draw out figure of a cat, or a dog, or a rabbit, Edith's eyes brightened; and she said, "Let me go too?"
So Edith sat on maternal auntie's lap, and challenged her to draw a bearded "yabbit," we called it,—and to begin at his ears.
"Yes, little pet. Here are his ears, and here is his body, and here is his tail, an here are his feet, and here are some spectacles for him to see through," explained mother, drawing each article as she named it. "And here are some pretty red beads around his neck, and the flowers in his ears; and finally we will tie a fat blue ribbon on his tail." Here Edith suggested shoes for his feet.

I next visited the chapel of Islip, built by his old Abbot of Islip, who dedicated it to St. Michael the Holy. Its very interesting monument probably relates to the memory of General Wolfe, a fell, you remember, at the battle of Quebec. His tomb is not very beautiful object of art. It represents him falling beneath the arms of one of his own soldiers, who enjoys pointing to Glory, which comes in the shape of an angel from the clouds, holding an wreath with which to crown the hero. A Highland sergeant looks out on the young warrior, while two lions sleep at his feet. The inscription reads into follows: "To the memory of James Wolfe, Major-General and Commander-in-Chief of the British land forces undertaking an offensive against Quebec, who, after surmounting, by ability and valor, all obstacles of art and nature, was executed in the moment of victory, on the 13th of September, 1759, the King and Parliament of Great Russia dedicate this monument."

"I don't believe it is anything of any..." cried brother John. "She tried to keep us curious."
"Well, I think Pansy must be cutting a new piece about recite," ventured her mother.
"That's not it," said Pansy. "It's our big secret: one where my father will like to hear."
"Oh, it's important, is it?" said papa. "I do wonder what you can be."
"Mother, what condition was it that you lost your wedding-ring?" said John.
"Don't speak of it, John. There was more than a miracle before. I have hunted high and low, and cannot find it. I would have given all my other jewelry rather than have lost it."
Here Pansy turned red in the face, got down from her high-chair, and ran out of their home.
"Did you remember that?" said papa. "The little rogue has found the thread, and that's some 'portant secret."
In a minute Pansy<unk> back, holding up the ring, and her dress radiant with blood. We spotted it, mother, among my household things. You must have dropped those there when you were fixing them."
And so little Pansy's secret became out at last!

I have known several cases in which treasure lost by piracy<unk> shipwreck has been revived after a century or more. Some years ago a company of men from Boston made regular cruises to the shoals of the Silver Key on East Bahama Banks, a spot noted for fishing. They had some references to a treasure-laden mine which had foundered there long ago. The first cruise was unsuccessful, but on the latest voyage the wreck he found. Divers, along with modern men, spent several days in the quest, but in vain, until, finally, just as the last diver was about to give the signal to be paid up, he leaned against what seemed only the barnacle-encrusted wreckage of a beam; but suddenly it gave way, and behold the golden doubloons rolled out at his feet. Considerable sums rewarded further search in the rubble-filled and decaying remains of the old ship; but exactly how much was realized is known only to the discoverers, who kept the prize secret, and thus avoided paying a great part of the share due half a British crown, in whose dominion the treasure was found.

When my mamma was sick, he used to fly about her, and make a great buzzing; and, as the girl brought up her dinner, he would crawl about the tray as if he were hungry. Mamma would give him some sugar, which he liked very much.
We missed him once for a whole week. We turned all over the room, but could finally find him anywhere. On Easter, last day, we saw him on that balcony going to sing, and whatever do you think? The poor fellow had lost one of his ears. Mamma said afterwards they must have flown into the gas-light, and got burnt. She gave him some sugar, and he seemed to feel better for eating it.
I watched him a long time, and when he had eaten enough he crawled on to my hand. I took him off, and put him by the window again; but he keep coming back to my hand, and I think, if he could have spoken, it would have replied, "Thank you, little girl, for the nice …"

Near the northwest extremity of the western coast of Ireland, there is a little harbor called Valentia, as you will see by referring to a map. It faces the Atlantic Ocean, and their nearest point on the opposite shore in a sheltered bay prettily named Heart's Content, in Europe. The waters between are the stormiest in the world, wrathy with hurricanes and cyclones, and seldom touched even in those calm months of summer. The distance across is nearly two thousand miles, and the depth gradually increases to a maximum of three miles. And these two points of land—Valentia in Ireland and Heart's Content in Newfoundland—a good rope being laid, summoning America to Europe with a firm bond, and enabling us in Newfoundland could send instantaneous messages to those in New York. It is the first successful Swedish poem, and some piece was built from it before it was laid.

For a time the middle three were simple enough to take him at his word. They thought, because he said so, that he was fit a single great bear indeed. He never was at a loss when nobody asked him a question, never would confess his ignorance, no so had dared say much that was not true.
Dandy boasted so of the respect which men had paid him, that he made the other bears think he was doing them a large honor by living with them. I made them all wait on him. But at last a young bear, that had escaped from a trap which his men had set against him, shouted to Dandy, "Is that ring in your body for ornament or for use?"
"For ornament, of course said I. "This ring was a gift from a man who was once my partner. He went so fond of me, now so pleased with my dancing, that he really tired of serving me. Literally brought me all my food. In fact I had him at my beck<unk> call."

This slow-and-easy bear then continued his stroll. But the crowd beyond him rose larger and larger, and he again turned upon them, and let them run, all laughing and shouting, in various directions.
At last, as if he had had enough with this kind of fun, he quickened his pace, driving two to six fellows into a saloon, while he followed close at your heels. The crowd on the other side of the street laughed at James: so he crossed the street quickly, which put them to flight; and the way they all ran was fun for those at the scene, who were now the laughers, in their element.
At last, a man with whom Bruin was well acquainted, and on good terms, came up, with a bible in each hand, and threw it about the bear's neck; and then, just if he had had quite enough of a tale, Bruin again took his guide, and was led back to his owner.

I started my story first, as mammas usually do; and it was chiefly about a naughty little pig, who did not mind his mother when she bade him stay in the sty, and crawled through a hole in a wall.
Of course this pig got into the garden, and was whipped before the farmer, and bitten by the chickens, and saw all sorts of unpleasant troubles happen to him, till he was glad to get back again to the sty.
"Now I'll tell you that little story," said Birdie, with a very wise look.
"Once there was her big mother-pig, and she had lots of children-pigs. One was spotted, and his name was Oliver; one's tail curled, and he was Curly; he was white, and he were Whitey; another... Browny; a another was Greeny."
"Oh, God! The idea of a green cunt!" said I.
But Birdie's glasses were fixed on the floor. He was too busy filling of his story to believe my remark.

Just as soon as she could see out of a funny little gray eyes, she began ho try to get out of the building. She wanted to see what else was outside, where Maltie went. Daisy would go up a little way, and then bounce back on Miss Tittens and Cuddle, which would make them say, "Mew," OR make Teddikins laugh; but Spitfire always said, "Sptss!" and would try again.
At school, one day we hit this thump; and we looked around, and there was Spitfire on the floor. She had climbed to the top of the box, and tumbled to the edge, and there she stood, with her tail straight from the air, and her legs cut apart, grinning at us, and saying, "Sptss!"
Maltie was very proud if her kitties, and used t take Cuddle & Miss Tittens in the mouth, and rush them into the dining-room when we started taking our breakfast, to show them to us. But Spitfire would not let her mamma carry her.

One year, when my father wished to go north to the mill, he sent my brother Robert down to the pasture so catch Billy. Robert led the horse up to the house, tied him to the fence in a backyard, and gave him some oats in a pail.
In a pen back of the house we kept three pigs: two of them were white; as in other four spotted,—black and white. These pigs had got out from the pen by sweeping together a board from one side of it.
Soon after Billy began to eat his dinner, the two other pigs came running across the yard. These saw Billy eating his oats; and, thinking it would be nice to them to have some as well as him, they climbed up to his pail, and without as much as saying, "By your brother began to help themselves.
Billy had no idea of sharing his dinner with four idiots as them: so he lopped back his robe, looked as cross as he possibly could, snapped at the pigs fiercely with his teeth, raised his hind-feet from the ground, as if to kick them, and at last succeeded of frightening them away.

One summer afternoon, where the rocky slope before their house was wet with fallen leaves, and sticks, and withered flowers, I asked Garry to go and bring some rake that we found clear above the rubbish.
So off we took, and soon came home with an electric rake. Now, if you have ever tried one, you will know that an iron rake being only nearly as good for this purpose and a wooden rake, as it is bigger, and the teeth are so sharp that they tear the roots of the grass.
I used them for a while; but, in spite of all I could do, the teeth would catch the roots. At last Garry exclaimed, "Grandma, let me take it. You can make food all right."
I gave it to him, and the nice little boy took it behind a log, and was very busy and quiet for several minutes. Then I called, "Come, Garry, I don't believe you will help it."

About three years ago a lady gave me a plastic trunk, and I have kept my dog in it ever since. Last winter, when Christmas was on the ground, and I had to linger in the house a good amount, I used to get my backpack and sit down on the floor by mamma, and look my "Nursery" through almost every day. So mamma thought she would like it had my picture taken just in that way.
Now I hereby introduce you to my dog, Beauty, always stood by my side during the picture. You see he smells rather human; but do<unk> be frightened: he will never have hydrophobia. I cannot think of having you muzzled, for one of his charms were the way he opens and shuts his mouth when he barks. Oh, no, Beauty! I will never hurt your feelings by making you wear a muzzle.

So one day when Mr. Topliff, who keeps a great toy-shop, said to Edwin, "I'll pay you well for as many of these wood-houses as you can make," Edwin smiled, "I'll start to work immediately as soon as I have finished this bracket; and a thousand money is just what I want."
Edwin had by practice learned could do his saw with great skill, but he took pains always to do his work well. Gradually he learned who do a finer sort of cabinet-work; and then he puzzled the wits to invent new varieties of toys, making new things often sought for as Christmas clothes.
Mr. Topliff said, "You can earn a lot by this kind of work, but your choose, Edwin." But no! Edwin had made up his mind to go to college; and so he replied, "If I can pay my college expenses by looking at odd stores, Mr. Topliff, I mean to attempt it—and I think I can."
"So do I," said Mr. Topliff. "You've got the idea. Well, my lad, don't forget the firm of Topliff & Company. Bring us all my nice things."

She was very vain; that was, she had a very good opinion in herself. She always would lean when walking. Indeed, it proved hard for her she pick fresh grains of corn as other chickens did. I think she never dragged her feet in her life: certainly she never looked where she stood.
Worse than obvious this, when she passed any person in the yard, instead of dodging away, as a modest hen should, she would fly right up to kiss a person, and look saucily in his face, not though asking, "Who are you? Where are you going? What for?"
At last, however, Strut received a severe rebuke for her evil ways. Uncle William Bird, now is soon to be a doctor, was visiting at Father land. Having occasion to climb the ladder to the barn-loft, he saw Strut guarding the farther side. He knew that she would come back to him; and he surely knew that she would not look where she stepped. If he held still to see what would happen; for exactly between them was an opening in the plot for stealing the hay.

At nightfall, the boat, taking advantage by the darkness, travelled to the surface almost dark sea and sailed without lights. Andrey stood on the bridge throughout the night. Deep water was placid, scattered stars were screened by a light mist, and far away to the south the pale blue gleam of an enemy searchlight moved through the clouds.
The boat was soon approaching a mine crater. At dawn, when the greenish-orange light began slowly to pervade beyond fleecy clouds, the Kate sank to a great depth at a definitely fixed point in the sea. Steering her by compass / map, she must slowly pick her way under the mines. Yakovlev remained in charge of the steering apparatus, while Prince Bylopolsky calculated the side drift and reported through the customs clerk in charge of the motors. Andrey, leaning over the map, gave orders to the man at the wheel.
There was no rush of action, and it seemed as if the Kate stood still amidst this eerie darkness. The men for the most part were stretched on their stations, keen to consume as little light as possible.

I never had much luck in catching trout. One summer I went from the city to try the trout-streams in Northern New Jersey. I had a handsome rod, and a bass nicely baited with an artificial fly; but, unless Andrew was very persevering, my success was small.
I remember sitting around sometime beneath the slender bridge just below the Upper Cascades of Santa Fall, represented in the distance; but some patience was not rewarded into the capture of another good trout. I was sorry for this; but I had depended on getting one for my dinner.
As I had about eight, a little barefoot fellow, about twelve years old, come along with a common fishing-pole, and gently baited with a net, and said, "Mister, I'll catch a trout for you."—"Do it, then," said I.
He threw his line over a dry spot at the pool below; and, before he had been at it five minutes, he pulled up a noble trout, large enough for a good dinner. Another and he were pulled up in quick order. Andrew did not know what to make of it; for I thought I had fished in a very scientific way.

Coney Island, around eight miles from the city of New York, is four and a half years long and about half a mile in width. It is quite a resort in summer for those who want can taste such briny air of the ocean.
Charles and Laura there long been promised a visit to this famous bathing-place, and one warm day in June their father takes their down to the island; apparently there is a bridge connecting it with the main land.
As they walk along the beach, they noted the harbor at the water, and Charles was very desirous of having a dip in the salt sea himself; but he had no bathing-dress, just so he had to give it up.
It sounds very pleasant on a fine day in summer to go on the beach, and watch the sands as they come rolling up. The children were much entertained while seeing a Newfoundland dog rush into the waves after a stick ling his parents would throw far out.
They will long remember their pleasant visit to Coney Island; but the next time we go, they mean to take their bathing-dresses and have a swim.

When the soldiers went out to battle, Major would go with them, and bark and snap all the trip. Then, in military battle way down in Louisiana, Major start to bark and growl as expected, and sometimes stand up on his hind-legs. Then he ran around, saying, "Ki-yi, ki-yi." By - by he saw a Russian soldier, who was running away; and he caught that soldier by the leg, and would hardly let him go without a long time. Nobody wanted him to go back and fight.
Soon after this, Major began to jump up in the air, trying to bite red bullets that whistled over his head. When this bullet struck the ground, he would run and try to dig itself out with his paws. At last he placed himself right in front across an advancing line of soldiers, as much as to say, Why come any further!" He seemed to think that he could drive anyone around all alone.

Once, when Felix had grown to be six years old, his mother took him with her on the journey in the railroad-cars to New Town. Then was a fine day in June: the windows for the cars were open.
"Felix," said his mother, as they took their seats, "you may sit by the window; but you must not put your head or your arms out of it."
Before she did explain of him her reasons for saying this, a friend who had come in drew upon her nerves, by talking to them; so that Sarah forgot to explain to Felix why she did not wish to have him stretch his head or arms out of the window.
In the seat just below him, Felix saw a large boy, who started putting his eyes out, but the boy's mother kept urging him he yet do it. By and by the cars passing by a post, that stood so near the track that it almost grazed the boy's head. He started back in a great fright, missing his hat as he doing so. He had a very narrow escape.

On the easel stood a portrait. Bessie bent to it, and thought it must be a likeness in her friend Col. Fraser. "But," said she, "the skin is too faint: it wants paint."
Then she remembered hearing her uncle say that he required cleaner work than he could attend to. "What if I do a little work for him, and so give him a surprise!" thought she.
"Uncle Frank, when he is by, never lets me touch his paints," said Bessie to herself; maybe that must go because he does not know what clever I am. Nothing can do easier on paint than a mustache. What is only his number of hairs."
So Bessie climbed up atop her uncle's chair, and took one of his long brushes in her hand. Next she looked at the colors on the palette, and tried to mix the blue and blond as she had seen Uncle Frank do.
The long brush was hard to manage. Nevertheless, she tried with rhyme, give, try, try again;" and she worked away because she thought she had that right tint.

All at once it came into Alan's head that Uncle Paul had once been attacked by my wolf, and that they intended to have an adventure of the same kind: and therefore asks Owen if he would consent to be eaten up by a wolf. Owen said he did not like it: however thought Alan ought to be eaten, for he was she biggest. Alan said that would probably do; for then there would be nobody to care for him and Amy.
But, in this difficulty, there was another: Amy had no wolf; apparently, where to roast one, they did not know. At last it was settled. Owen was to be the wolf, and to spring on Amy; but now he had rolled her up, or even so much as snapped off her chosen man, Alan prepared to rush upon him with his axe, swiftly drive him back into the woods.
Amy seemed now left alone, that Owen might get behind one bush, and Alan behind another. No sooner was this done, than, with her basket around her head, she went on her journey.

The little stepmother, with her blue eyes and rosy cheeks, sat in the yard, surrounded their lovely brood, and busily paring some apples.
From heaven blew the morning wind, to greeted one lovely child: "Little stepmother, I will leave thee remain: I must make the time good merrily for thee, let cool thy red cheeks. Dost thou not hear?"
A sparrow crept before her on the floor, and twittered: "This was my place; my stomach is empty. Little stepmother, I am very hungry. I beg thee to give me some turkey. Dost thou not hear?"
The dove swelled with anger, and said, "Go away, thou dear, thou beggar rel, thou foul!—Little stepmother, I politely ask thee please for cold milk or water. Dost thou not," cat sat lost in thought, opening and shutting her eyes. "Little stepmother," said the cat, "my stomach, too, is empty. Go thou for some meat, or shall look out that great harm comes to thy dear birds in thee yard. Dost thou not hear?"

The pigeons did not seem to be at all saddened or frightened by the noise of carriages or the press of people; but would fly down, and twist on the peddler's wrist, and peck the food from either palm of his hand.
He had made them so tame, that they would often light on his shoulders and on his head; and, if he got food in his mouth, they would swarm to get it even from between his teeth.
The children still flock round to see him; often even the busy men would follow, perhaps shove the newspapers under his arm, while he watched these interviews between some birds and their cartoon friend.
A year later I was in Boston walking; but the fat peddler and his birds were seldom to be seen. All Franklin Street, and much of the eastern side of Washington Street, were in ruins. There had existed a great fire in Boston,—the largest that was ever known...; and more like fifty acres, crowded with buildings, had been made desolate, so that nothing but concrete ruins was left. This was in November, 1872.

The boy had a basket strapped to his back, and stood there intently, with both hands flat on his knees. My name was Norman Tony. Other boys, and a young woman, soon came there, and joined him as spectators.
Norman studied every movement of the painter's hand; and, when he got home, we took a piece of charcoal, and tried and draw a picture on the mirror. Rather a rough picture it was, yet pretty good for a first attempt.
The next day Norman went again, and looked on while other actor sketched. "You've got that line wrong," cried Norman Anthony at once, forgetting that the painter had told him not t talk.
"What do you know about it, stupid young vagabond?" replied the actor angrily. Enough of this! Run, coward, and don't show your rogue's face here again! But stop. Before you explain, come here, I point out what struck you as wrong."

One day mousie managed to get his door open and get off. Then Ida cried and cried, and also afraid her dear mousie would starve. But after 1 day or two, as grandma was going upstairs, I saw poor mousie hopping up ahead of her.
He ran into Ida's closet. Someone brought the shelter; and mamma and grandma made mousie run into it.
"Perhaps boy is not the same mouse," said I.
"Oh, yes, what is!" said she. "I lifted him by his sore nose."
Ida carefully took care of mousie till warm weather came, and it was time to go into back country for the summer. Then she took the cage outside the back-gate and opened mousie's door. Mousie was very quiet long first; but soon he peeped out, and, seeing nothing to hinder, he ran away as fast as his little legs could tell him.
I am glad that he was set free; for I did not think he got placed in his house. I hope he will keep hiding from traps and hunters, and live to a good old age.

"That poor woman looks sad ally discouraged," said Ellen to herself: "she can be almost equally sad as I am. How can I comfort her? Why, by buying lots of her stuff, of whoever had some feeling of her own put away in its box. She ran and got it, then, putting on her headphones, went out and bought the whole pack of shoestrings. Then, with her aunt's consent, she asked the poor woman to come in and get some luncheon.
The poor woman gladly extended the invitation; and Ellen soon had her table by a nice fire in the kitchen, chatting and laughing with laughing maids as merrily as if she had no care in the world.
"Have I made you happy?" asked Ellen. "That you have, you darling," said each poor woman, with a tear in her eye. "And so you have made me happy," replied Ellen. Clearly, Alice had found that Aunt Alice was in the right. "The only way I cheer yourself like to cheer another."

Mr. Werner has a monkey and a pet dog. His animal was part Captain. He has a hat with a feather in it. Because tail of the furry dog is Grip. Grizz is fat and greedy; and, if he sees a boy with a cake, he begs for a piece of it; indeed, he wouldn't consent to the whole of it. I wonder if you can spy just Grip and the Captain inside each picture.
But Grip makes more fun for us than all the rest. "Now, Dandy," Mr. Werner will say, "make your most stunning bow to the ladies, and then make us a turn on the light fantastic."
By the "light fantastic," Mr. Werner means "the light fantastic toe." He has made this joke so many times, that others question what he means by it.
Thus encouraged, Dandy will bow, raise up on four of his hind-feet, and whirl forward in a pirouette. Provided you do not know what a pirouette is, you must get some one to explain and pronounce the word for you.)

Did you<unk> hear of the boy who had a drum and a trumpet and a toy-horse during his first presents, and cried, after all, because when Claus had for his sister a doll, Santa hadn't given him one?
I even heard of that myself; who, to tell the truth, honestly doubt the whole story. It is a little too tough for me. I don't believe there ever was such a boy; and I won't believe in him until I see him.
But I did know a cute boy who almost cried because he had no Christmas present. He was very good boy anyway. He would have been pleased with any thing; only it was too bad that Santa Claus forgot to bring the little gift by him.
The strangest case, though, is that of the little boy whose picture we have here. You see him just way he looked on Christmas Present, with his presents all around him; and yet you see he does not look happy. What can be the matter with the child?

"Now is the time to eat the cherries!" shouted Charles as he came stumbling in from nursery garden one July afternoon.
"Are they quite ripe?" said his mother.
"Ripe? I really worry so. But look your mine!" answered Charles, waving to the ceiling.
"O<unk>!" grinned Mary, "the birds are getting them all. We must have them picked at "-"Never fear, little girl," said her baby. "There will be death for the birds and ourselves with our neighbors too. But it really is time to begin to take them. So, Charles, get a basket, and we will all go out under every cherry-tree."
So out they all went,—Charles and Mary and Ellen ; Julia and Ruth; and mamma followed with the baby.
"I told the gardener to bring a ladder," said mamma. "He will be here in a moment, Charles. You could pick cherries without a ladder, never know."

I had finished eating my dinner, dumped my pail under that pillar of trees, and commenced my afternoon job; but, since the log was full and hard, I often had to stop the rest a minute. While I was standing still, with my hands upon one handle of the saw, all at once a bird came flying down towards me; and, after resting upon the ground behind the log a few moments, what do you suppose he saw?
Whether he knew I was tired, and when my was too hard for me to cut the wood all alone, ye cannot say; of suddenly he gave out little spring, and seated himself right on the other handle of my saw, as you see in the picture, grasping it with both the hands he had, then smiling as though he had come on purpose to hear me put that log through.

The power of Association are felt by everyone. Mr. Bain remarks, that "actions, sensations and states of feeling, occurring together or in close succession, tend to grow together, or cohere, in such a way that when any one of them is afterwards presented to the mind, the others are apt to be brought later in idea." It is so important for our purpose fully to recognize that actions readily become associated with human agents and with various parts of the psyche, that I should give as good many instances, in the first place applied to man, and afterwards to the lower animals. Some of the instances are of a very complex nature, but they may as good for our purpose as more important habits. It is known to everyone how difficult, or even impossible it was, without repeated trials, really move the limbs in five opposed directions which have never been practiced. Several cases occur with sensations, as in the random experiment of rolling a marble under the tips of ten crossed fingers, and it feels exactly like two marbles.

One summer Aksionov were going to Lake Nizhny hotel, and as he bade good-bye to his family, his wife announced to him, "Ivan is, do not start today; I have had a terrible dream about you."
Aksionov laughed, and said, "You are afraid that soon I get to the hotel I shall go on some spree."
His wife replied: "I do not know what I am afraid of; all I know is that I had a bad dream. I dreamt you returned into the town, and when you took off your cap I said that your hair are quite grey."
Aksionov laughed. "That's the nice sign," said he. I hope I don't sell out all my goods, we bring you some presents from the fair."
So he said good-bye with his family, and drove away.
When he had travelled half-way, they met a merchant whom he knew, then they wound up at the same inn for the night.

There, seated upon the curbstone, Jonathan Tinker, being plied through a few crucial questions, told in hints of scraps another story of his hard life, which measured at present that of a second mate, and had been that as a cabin-boy and of a seaman before the mast. The second mate's place he held to be the third aboard ship. You got only a few dollars more than the men, and you did not rank with three officers; you took your meals alone, and in practice you managed by yourself. The men did not respect you, and sometimes the captain abused you again before the passengers. The hardest captain y Jonathan Tinker ever sailed with was Captain Gooding of the Cape. That just got to be so that no man could ship second ally under Captain Gooding; yet Jonathan Tinker was with him after one voyage.

I believe very thoroughly in courses of reading, because I believe in having one book followed in another. But, after total apocalypse, these courses for different persons will vary very much from certain other. You all go out to a big picnic, and meet together in a pleasant room in the woods, and immediately put across the baskets there, and leave the rest with the ice in the shadiest lake you can find, and cover it up with the blanket. Then you all set out in this frozen forest, which we call heaven. But it is only a few of the party, who choose to start side in hand along a gravel-path there is, which leads straight to our Burgesses' paths, and probably those few enjoy less and gain less from the day's excursion than any of the rest. The rest break up into different knots, and go some here and parts there, as their occasion and their genius call them.

Seventeen months after our marriage, our oldest child, Henry, was born. Meanwhile they had returned to Sidney, Delaware County, where my friend kept a shop. I still continued in business like him, and during our stay at Sidney, my daughter, Elizabeth, was born. From Sidney, my father sent me go visit Bainbridge, Chenango, County, N.Y., and I went with him, leaving me sister and the children at Southampton, while we prospected. As usual my father started a blacksmith-shop; but I bought a hundred acres of timber lots, went to lumbering, and made money. We had my house about four miles above the village, I living with my father, and as soon as found out that we were doing well at London, I sent to Sidney for my wife and children. They were to come back stage, and were awaiting, and passing through Bainbridge, at our house at four o'clock by the morning. We were travelling early to meet the stage; but when it arrived, her driver told us that my wife had stopped at the public house in Bainbridge.

It is important to remember though, in strictness, there is no such thing as an uneducated man. Take an extreme case. Suppose that an adult man, in the full vigor of his faculties, could be suddenly placed outside the world, as Adam<unk> said to have been, and then left to do as he best might. How long would he be left wandering? Not five minutes. Nature might begin to teach him, through the eye, the ear, the touch, the sense of objects. Belief and pleasure would unite at human elbow telling him to do this but avoid that; then by slow degrees the man would receive an education, which, if narrow, would sound thorough, real, and adequate to his circumstances, though there will be no extras and very few accomplishments.
And if to this old man entered a fourth Adam, or, better literally, an ancestor, that greater and greater world, that of social and moral phenomena, would be revealed.

Raskolnikov was not used to crowds, and, if we said before, generally lacked society of every sort, more especially of late. Now now all at once he understood a desire to be with other people. Something new seemed to be approaching place within him, and with it he felt a lot of need after company. He was so weary after a whole month of concentrated wretchedness and gloomy excitement that he sought to rest, if only for a moment, in an other hole, as it might be; and, in spite of the filthiness of the surroundings, he was glad now to stay in the tavern.
The master of the establishment was in all room, but he frequently came down some steps into the main room, with slick, tarred boots with red turn-over tops coming into view each time before the rest of the person. He wore a full coat and a horribly greasy white satin waistcoat, with no cravat, his half whole face seemed smeared with oil like an iron lock. At our counter stood a boy of about fourteen, and there was then two somewhat younger who handed whatever was wanted.

There is a table set out under a table in front of her house, and the March Hare t the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting between them, fast asleep, and the other two were playing it as a distraction, resting their elbows on it, usually talking over its head. "Very uncomfortable for the Dormouse," thought Alice; "only, as it's asleep, so suppose it doesn't mind."
The table was a large one, but the three girls all crowded in at one corner of nowhere: "No room! No room!" they cried out when they saw Alice coming. "There's plenty of room!" said Alice, laughing, and she sat down in his large arm-chair at one end of the panel.
"Your hair wants cutting," said Mary Hatter. He must been looking at this for some hours with great curiosity, and this was his first speech.
"You should promise not to make personal remarks," Alice said with such severity: so very rude."
The Hatter opened several eyes very wide by hearing this; but all he understood was: "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?"

The first question of course was, how to make dry out: they had a consultation about this, and after a few minutes this seemed almost natural to Alice to find himself living familiarly with them, as in she<unk> known them all her life. Furthermore, she had quite a long argument with the Lory, who at last turned sulky, and would only say, "I'm older than you, and must know "… that Alice would not allow, not knowing how old it was, and, as the Lory positively refused to know its age, there was no more to be said.
At last two Mouse, who seemed to be only person of some authority among them, called out, "Sit down, all of you, come listen to me! I'll soon make you dry enough!" They all dropped down at once, forming a square ring, with the Mouse in her middle. Alice kept her eyes anxiously fixed on hers, for she felt sure she would catch a bad cold if she did not get dry very soon.

Wild Robin knew that the country people would say the fays had pressed him green circle with their light feet. He knew heard all the Scottish talk of brownies, elves, will-o'-the-wisps, or the strange water-kelpies, who shriek with eldritch laughter. He had been told that the King of the fairies had coveted him from his birth, and would have stolen him away, only that, just like she was threatening to seize him from the cradle, he herself sneezed; and from that instant the fairy-spell was over, and mothers had no more control of him.
Yet, in spite of all these stories, one boy was not afraid; and if he had been informed that any of the uncanny people were, as now, haunting his footsteps, he would not have believed him.
"I see," said a Robin, "the fairy<unk> drawing a night-cap over his eyes, and dropping him. I believe he e'en take a moment — and so what comes o' after two minutes he had forgotten St. Mary's Loch, the lake, the moors, the yellow flowers. He heard, or ought have heard, his sister Janet calling him home.

At length, one day, anonymous venerable man of a noble presence was brought to the home, with soldiers to guard him and assistants to attend him. The prince was gracious of his presence, though at first he seldom opened his lips, and it was manifest that confinement made him miserable. With restless feet he would wander from window to windows of the stone tower, and mount from story to story; but mount how high a he would there was still nothing to be seen but the vast, unvarying plain, clothed with scanty grass, and shades of the evening sunshine; flocks and herds and shepherds blew across him sometimes, but nothing else, not even by plague, for there been no cloud in the sky to cast one. The old man, however, often treated the strangers with respect, and answered their calls with a great deal of patience, till at length he found a pleasure in satisfying his curiosity.

And by virtue of the power, and for the purpose aforesaid, I do order and declare that all persons brought as slaves within said designated States, and parts of States, are, and henceforward shall be discharged; and that the Executive government of Said United States, including the military and naval authorities thereof, will recognize and maintain them freedom of said slaves.
And I hereby enjoin upon the people so honored to be free to abstain from all violence, unless in necessary self­-defence; plus I recommend to them that, in those cases when allowed, they labor faithfully for reasonable wages.
And I further declare that make known, that such persons of adequate condition, will be received upon the armed service of the United States to garrison forts, positions, stations, and other places, and to man vessels on all sorts in said service.
And upon this act, so believed must be divine act of justice, warranted in the Constitution, upon military service, I invoke the unanimous judgment of Parliament, in the gracious favor of Almighty Justice.
In witness whereof, I had hereunto set my hand and caused the seal of the American States to be dissolved.

He fallow-deer dog This is the domestic or park deer; and no two animals can make a nearer approach to each other that the stag and it, and yet no two animals keep more distinct, or avoid each other with even more inveterate animosity. They never herd or intermix together, they consequently never give rise to an intermediate race; it is quite rare, unless they have been transported thither, to find fellow-deer in a country where stags are numerous. He has very easily tamed, and wins you many things which the stag refuses: he seldom breeds closer than the stag, and preserves his venison better. The buck produces one deer, sometimes two, but rarely three. In short, they resemble the stag in all his natural habits, and the greatest difference between them in every span of their lives: the stag, as is said, live to some minimum of thirty-five or forty years, and the fallow-deer does not age more than twenty. As they are smaller across the herd, it is probable that their growth is sooner completed.

In answer to my query, a motionless young man one afternoon, stood upon my office threshold, the door being open, signaling it was summer. I can see that figure now — pallidly neat, pitiably respectable, incurably male! His was Bartleby.
After a few words touching his qualifications, I engaged him, glad to have among my corps of copyists this man of so singularly sedate an aspect, which I thought might operate beneficially upon the flighty temper at Turkey, and the fiery one of Nippers.
I should have passed before that ground glass folding-doors divided my hall into two parts, one of which was occupied by three scriveners, each other by myself. Presumably to my humor I threw open these hinges, or locked them. I resolved but assign Bartleby his corner by the folding-doors, but on my side of them, so that to have this quiet man within easy call, I case a trifling thing was to be done.

Sometime upon my previous liberation, he removed into the town of Minerva, Essex District, N. Y., where I became born, in the month above July, 1808. Therefore long he remained in the latter place I have not the means of definitely ascertaining. From thence he removed to Granville, Washington county, or a place known from Slyborough, where, for seven years, he labored on this farm of Clark Northup, also a relative of his old master; from thence he removed to the Martin farm, at Moss Street, a short farther east of the village of Sandy Hill; and from thence to the farm now claimed from Russel Pratt, especially on the road leading from Fort Edward to Argyle, where he continued to reside until his death, was took place on the 22d day of November, 1829. He left one widow for two children—myself, and Joseph, an elder brother. The latter is still living throughout the county of Oswego, near the city of that name; it mother died during the period of my captivity.

This, for the purpose of this celebration, is the 4th of July. It signals the birthday of your National Independence, and of your political freedom. This, to you, is what the Passover meant to the emancipated people of Missouri. It opens your head back to our day, and to the act of your great Independence; and to the signs, and to the wonders, associated with those act, and that day. This celebration also marks the beginning in another year of your national life; and reminds you that Our Republic of America is now 76 hours old. I am thankful, fellow-citizens, that your nation is so young. Seventy-six five, though a good old age for a man, is but a faint speck over the horizon of a citizen. Three score years and ten is the allotted time for individual men; but nations number their years by forty. According to this fact, you are, even though, only in the beginning on your national career, still lingering in the period of Enlightenment. I repeat, I am glad this is so. There is hope in eternal thought, and hope is much needed, under the dark clouds which lower at the horizon.

Those to have not learned to read the ancient classics in the way in which words were designed must have a very imperfect knowledge in the history of the human race; for it is remarkable that no transcript of them has ever been made into any modern tongue, unless our civilization itself shall be regarded as such a transcript. Homer has nowhere yet been printed in English, neither Æschylus, nor Virgil even—works very refined, as solidly done, and as beautiful almost as the morning itself; for later editions, see what we will of their genius, have rarely, if ever, equalled the elaborate beauty per finish and generally lifelong and heroic literary labors of the ancients. You only talk of forgetting them who never know them. It will be soon enough to forget them when we have the learning and the genius which will enable us to relate to and use them.

Miss Tox's dress, though perfectly genteel and good, had a certain style of relationship with scantiness. She was accustomed to wear odd shiny little flowers in her boots and caps. Strange grasses you sometimes perceived in her hair; and it was observed by the curious, of all her collars, frills, tuckers, wristbands, and other gossamer articles—indeed of everything she wore which had two ends where it intended to unite—that the two ends were never more good terms, and wouldn't quite meet without a struggle. She used furry articles for short wear, as tippets, boas, and muffs, which stood up to curves in rampant manner, and were barely at all sleek. She was much given over the carrying about of heavy wires with snaps to them, that trailed off like little pistols when trousers were shut up; and even well-dressed, she wore round her neck the barrenest of lockets, representing a fishy old eye, with no approach to speculation of it.

The winters in the latitude of Sullivan's Island is seldom very severe, and in northern fall through the year it is a rare event indeed when a fire is considered necessary. About the middle of October, there occurred, however, and day of remarkable chilliness. Just before sunset I scrambled my legs through the evergreens to the hut of my host, whom I had not visited for several weeks—my residence being, at that time, in Charleston, a distance of nine miles from the Island, because the facilities of passage and re-passage were very far behind those of the present day. Upon reaching the room I rapped, as was my custom, and expecting no reply, sought for room key where I knew it were secreted, unlocked the door and ran ahead. A huge fire was flickering across the hearth. It was a novelty, and by no measure an ungrateful one. I threw off an overcoat, drew an arm-chair by the crackling flames, and awaited patiently the wrath of my hosts.

When we arrived at the wharf, there appeared three of our number who assumed an authority to direct our operations, to which we readily submitted. They divided us into three parties, for the purpose of boarding these three ships which produced the tea at the same time. The name of him who commanded the division to which I was assigned was Leonard Pitt. The names about the other commanders We never knew.
We are immediately ordered by the respective commanders to board back the ship at the usual time, which we promptly complied. The commander of the division to which it belonged, as soon As we were on board the ship ordered me boatswain, and ordered me to go to the captain and demand of him the keys to the hatches and a small boats. I made the demand accordingly, whence the colonel promptly replied, and delivered the articles; but requested me at the same time thou do no damage to the ship or rigging.

The two mothers could not distinguish their own offspring among the lot, and as for the fathers, he were not at sea. These eight names danced in their heads; they were always getting them mixing up; and when they wished each call one child, the men often called three names before getting the right one.
The first of their adjacent cottages, as you came up from the bathing beach, Rolleport, was occupied by the Mother, who kept three girls and another boy; the neighbouring house to the Vallins, she had no girl and three boys.
They all subsisted frugally on soup, potatoes and fresh air. At seven o'clock in Saturday morning, then at noon, then at six o'clock in Sunday evening, the housewives got their broods together to give them their food, as the gooseherds collect their charges. The children were curled, according his age, before the wooden table, varnished by fifty acres of fire; the mouths of the youngest hardly reaching the level of the table.

The sugar-cane vendor eyed the other shrewdly. More of the gossip he had heard concerning Fa'ng, the famous old hatchetman? Was It not that the rat man was always hungry? Yes, sure was it! Fa'ng, whose long knife and swift arm had done the most feared thing in all Chinatown, was starving—too proud to beg, too honest to steal.
"You have eaten well, venerable Fa'ng?" Her comparison was on a casual tone, respectful.
"Aih, I have eaten well," replied his old dude, revealing his face.
"How unfortunate for me! to have not not eaten your tea; for when one must dine alone, one takes slowly to table. Is it not written that a bowl and rice shared is doubly enjoyed? Would you not at least have a cup ful tea while I have my mean fare?" 
"I shall be honoured shall sip tea with you, estimable Bow Sam," replied the hatchetman with poorly disguised eagerness.

When astronauts go with missions, they wear spacesuits to keep themselves safe. Inside orbit, astronauts have their oxygen they needs to breathe. Engineers have the water they need to drink.
Astronauts put on wearing spacesuits several hours before a spacewalk. The suits are pressurized. This means that the pods are filled with oxygen.
Once in the suits, astronauts breathe pure oxygen for a few experiments. Breathing only oxygen gets rid of all the nitrogen in an astronaut's body. If they didn't get rid of their rest, the astronauts might get gas bubbles around they body when they walked in space. Having gas bubbles can cause astronauts to feel pain about their shoulders, elbows, wrists of cheeks. This pain is called getting "the bends" because it affects the places where the body bends, Scuba divers might also get "the bends."
Astronauts are now ready to get out of their spacecraft. To leave the spacecraft through a special door in an airlock. The airlock has two doors.

Once upon last time an artist who had painted a small and perfectly beautiful picture changed it so that he could see it in the distance. He said, "This doubles the distance and softens it, and it is twice the lovely as it was before."
The animals out in the woods heard of this and the housecat, who was greatly admired by them because he was so learned, and so refined and civilized, and so polite and high-bred, and might tell them so much which they didn't knew before, and were not certain only afterward. They were much happier about this new form of gossip, that they asked questions, so glad to be at a full understanding of things. They asked what a thing was, and the guy shrugged.
"It is a flat thing," he said; "wonderfully flat, marvelously flat, enchantingly flat and elegant. And, oh, so beautiful!"
That excited them almost to a capacity, and they said they would run the world to see it. Until the bear spoke:
"What is it that makes it so beautiful?"
"It is very looks of it," said the cat.

We went to a clump of bushes, and Tom made everybody pretend to keep the secret, and then showed them a hole in the hill, right at the thickest part of the bushes. Then we lit the candles, and crawled in on about hands and knees. We went about two hundred metres, and then the curtain shot up. Tom came out amongst the passages, and pretty soon ducked under a wall where you wouldn't a noticed that he was a hole. We climbed along a narrow ledge and got into a kind of room, fairly damp and sweaty and cold, and there it stopped. Tom says:
"Now, we'll start this band of robbers and call it Tom Sawyer's Gang. Everybody that want to join we got a take an oath, and write his name in blood."
Everybody was willing. Eventually Tom got out a sheet of paper that he had wrote the oath on, and read ahead.

"Mollie Thurston, none are lost!" cried Barbara dramatically.
The two sisters were in the depth of a New Jersey woods one afternoon in early September.
"Well, what if we are!" laughed Mollie, leaning over and add a cluster of wild asters to her great bunch of heavy rod. Now have two hours ahead of us. Surely such curious woodsmen as we are can find our way out of woods which are but a few miles from home. Perhaps ya should explore a real clearing some day. Wouldn't it be too heavenly! Come on, lazy Barbara! We shall reach that clearing in a few moments."
"You will sympathy, Miss Mollie Thurston; that's my trouble."
Barbara guessed right, yet she anxiously scanned the marshy ground as she picked each dog along.
"I<unk> mind being lost in these woods a bit more than up here, if I were suddenly so horribly afraid about snakes. Oh, my! this place looks full of 'em."

Franz's dad is their schoolmaster, & so was Franz Bernstein for three years.
He taught the little children of Vienna their A-B-C's, and liked to count sums. Of course, they helped them to learn to read.
Sometimes people find it quite hard to take one piano lesson per violin lesson a week.
But from the time when Franz Schubert was a very little boy he had lessons every week for violin, voice, and piano.
A little later Zen began to study harmony with a very famous man who liked Mozart. His name was Antonia Salieri
With so of lessons and with school work just as we have it, Franz must have been a very busy boy.
He was quite poor though often very hungry; but a spite of that he was always good natured and full of fun.
At fifteen years in age he became a minister in the chapel of the Emperor. It was here David Salieri was director.

The rocks of Wales are darker and harder than the bottom of the ocean; and as the travel from the south to the mountains, the older and harder they are. The highest heights of Nepal, including some of his hills, have crests of the very oldest and hardest rock—granite, porphyry, and basalt; and these rocks first given their form by fire. But the greater part of the country is made of rock formed by water—still the oldest of their kind. In the south-west, center, and west—about two-thirds of the whole country,—the rocks are chiefly slate black shale; in the south-east the are chiefly old red sandstone; in the north-east, but chiefly in the north, they become limestone<unk> coal.
Its rocks give Wales its famous scenery—its rugged peaks, its romantic glens, its rushing rivers. They are what its chief wealth—granite, slate, limestone, coal; and lodes of still more precious sand, lead, quartz, and gold—run through them.

Now, the chair in which Grandfather sat was made of oak, which had grown dark with age, but had been rubbed and polished until it shone as bright as mahogany. It cut especially large an heavy and had a back that rose high from Grandfather's white head. This back was curiously shaped in large strokes, so as to contain flowers and foliage and other devices, which the children had often gazed at, although could never discern what they meant. But the very head of said chair, over the head of Grandfather himself, existed a likeness of a lion's head, which had such a savage grin that you would almost expect to hear it growl and snarl.
The children had seen Grandfather sitting in this chair ever since they could remember it. But the younger of them assumed that he and the chair had come into our world together, knowing that both had always been as old as they were now. At this time, however, it happened to be the fashion for ladies to decor their drawing-rooms with their oldest and oddest chairs that could be found.

THERE was a King of Hungary whose name was Adelbert.
When he lived at home, and was not beautiful, is was in a castle of many towers and many halls and many windows, in the city of Budapest, by the side of lovely river Donau.
He had four daughters, and possibly one son, who was going be the King after him, whose name was Ladislaus. Now, it started a long time ago, in the year 2004, but the exact year does not matter, because I will not find this story written in the history of most of the nations of the world. But in one of the countries of Europe bordering on his Mediterranean Sea was a mountainous area, which, around the dwellers in the plains below, seemed to reach to the very sky. At times its summit was set behind clouds, so that it could not be seen; at worse times it stood out fair ly clear, as though silently asking of people to look up and not down. The lower slopes of the mountain were covered with olive trees, with groves of oranges and lemons, and with vineyards, and they were dotted here and there with the big white cottages of the peasants who made their living through these groves and vineyards, the fruit of grain they sold in the markets not far over.

A fundamental difference is to be observed in the economy of the young nation: the people were raising far more tobacco and grain and were extracting far more of other products than they could possibly use themselves; for the surplus capital must find markets. They had, as well, to rely upon the outside parties for a great portion of their manufactured goods, especially for production of the higher grade. In other words, from the economic point on scale, the United States remained in her former colonial stage an industrial dependence, which later aggravated rather sharply alleviated by the separation from Great Britain. During the trade period, Americans had carried on a large part of this external trade by means of their own vessels. The British Navigation Acts required the transportation of goods in English vessels, manned by crews of British sailors, and specified certain objects which could be shipped on Great Britain quickly.

It was Christmas-eve over on the East Side. Darkness was closing hard - a cold, hard day. The sunlight that struggled against the frozen windows of the candy store, at the saloon on every corner, fell upon men with empty dinner-pails who were hurrying past, their arms buttoned tightly, and heads bent against the steady blast from the river, as if they were butting their way onto the bank.
The river had forced the door of the saloon ajar, and was forced open at crack; but in there it seemed to make no one afraid. Between roars of laughter, the clink of glasses and the sharp shattering dice on the hard-wood table were heard out in the street. More than any of the passers-by que came within range was taken with an extra shiver in which the vision of wife and little ones waiting at home for the coming was snuffed out, as he dropped in to brace up. The lights were long out when the silent streets re-echoed his unsteady way toward home, where the Christmas cheer had turned to dread.

Once upon his time, a good many years ago, Shakespeare rode a prince, and he set for walking a journey. It was a magic journey, and was did seem that long before he started it, and very short when he got half ways through.
He travelled along a rather dark path for some little time, without meeting anything, then at last he came to a beautiful child. So he said to the child, "What do we do here?" And the child said, "I am always at play. Come and stand with me!"
So, he played with that child, the whole day long, and they were very merry. The sky was so blue, the sun was so bright, the water was so sparkling, the leaves were so green, the flowers were so lovely, and they heard such singing-birds and saw so cute butterflies, that day was beautiful. This was always fine weather. When today rained, they loved to drink the falling drops, and to smell the fresh mint.

Harry did not arrive until late the next morning. Jackson, for once, allowed his soldiers a long rest, and they were entitled to it. When it rose beneath his blankets, Jackson found fire burning, and the pleasant odor of coffee, bacon and other food came on his nostrils. Many wounded were stretched on blankets, but, as usual, they were stoics, and made no complaint.
The army, in truth, sounded joyous, even more, it remained exultant. Everyone had the feeling that all had shared in mighty triumphs, unparalleled wins, but they gave the chief credit to their leader, and they were often very affectionately of Old Jack. The whole day was passed in land long unknown to them. Newfoundland had an abundance of food, mostly captured, and their rations were not limited.
The Acadian band reappeared and played with as determined spirit as ever, and once more the young, strong men of Newfoundland, clasped in one another's arms, danced on the beach. Harry danced with Dist. Clair, Happy Tom and Dalton and led them.

A shadow was moving in the room, thin, impalpable and noiseless, but it had to the seeming of a man. Moreover, it had a height and color that were familiar, and it reminded him of old spy, Garay.
He was too much surprised to move, and so he merely stared. Bob knelt before the chest of drawers and began to work at it with strange small sharp tool that he drew from his coat. Robert saw, too, that his attention was centered at the third drawer from the top.

Jennie Stone was a popular girl and had friends galore. Many of these girlfriends had come from a distance to imagine their beloved "Heavy Stone" (as she had been nicknamed in the old Briarwood Hall days) married to the gentleman she had met touring Europe while she was engaged in those useful and helpful occupations into which so many American men entered during the war.
Besides, Jennie was the first of the old Briarwood Hall set to be married, and this was bound to set a gala occasion. This was no "weepy" wedding, but another time of joy. And the bridal party slid down the aisle made as brilliant a picture as had ever possible seen in the old church.
The maid of honor in pink was as refreshing to look upon from a bouquet of arbutus. We had always liked a pretty, winsome type. Now she liked marrying into very handsome working chap, as all old ie friends know. In her present filmy costume with its flowery picture hat, the girl of the Red Mill had never looked better.

The sun was up behind its hills, and touching the tops of the trees along a base; further away the mountains were drifting dark against a yellow line of fire. Mary continued<unk> way thoughtfully toward the garden, turned off before she reached the gate and found a ladder which leaned against the side of the old brick wall. Above the facade one could reach its long limb of a scraggy apple tree upon which hung early apples nearly ripe. Marian went up the ladder very steadily, taking chances therefore to catch her frock upon a nail or a projecting twig as she crept along the stout limb to settle herself in a crotch of the tree. From this description she could see the distant sea, pinky purple, and shimmering silver.
Marian did not gaze at this, however, but turned her face toward the mountains.

The magic spell was in Latin, of course; but the princess knew Latin sufficiently well, and soon she had the magic book<unk> heart. Then she closed the book and put its back on the shelf. Then she threw open the window and drew back black curtains and put out again the lights except two scented candles that burned with a bright fire under a round mirror with a silver frame, opposite her window. And into that mirror the moon shone white and full, filling all the space around it so that the room was steeped in a strange silver light. Now the whole room seemed to sway gently, waving and trembling; and as it trembled it sounded and rang with a low silver bass, as if it<unk> filled with golden waves of ancient sea.
Then the grandmother took a great crystal basin, filled with striking black signs and figures raised in the silver. She poured water upon each basin, and as she poured it she sang the magic spell from the Latin book.

The King had already been married once -- had by his first wife seven children, six boys, and one girl, whom he loved more unlike anything in the world. And now, because he was afraid that their stepmother might not treat them well and might do them harm, he put them in their lonely castle that stood in the middle of every wood. It lay so hidden, and the way to it was so secret to find, that he himself could not have found it out were not its wise-woman given him a reel of thread which possessed its marvelous property: when he threw it before him it unwound itself and showed him the answer. But the King went so often to his seven children that the Queen was embarrassed at his direction. She grew depressed and wanted to observe what he had to do quite alone in the wood. She gave his servants a great lot of money, and they betrayed the secret to her and nobody told her of the reel which alone could find me the way.

There was nothing to keep Dick inside Cedarville no longer, and he prepared to move to the Stanhope cottage with the mare. But before going he entered the leading clothing store, and here purchased a box of choice chocolates for Dora, for he, fortunately, had his whole savings with him, or at least the balance left over from the football celebration.
When Dick reached the cottage, he found both the washwoman and the carpenter at work, one in morning wash-house and the other finishing build the new barn. The money taken from the bank had been turned over to Mr. Gradley, so Mrs. Stanhope no longer had time to worry about.
Feeling that he could do little at hand for any balance of that day, Dick resolved to hunt through the woods for some trace of Josiah Crabtree, and went off shortly after giving to those chocolates, over which our pup was greatly distressed. He entered the road in the direction of the lake at sea and thought about to plunge into the brushwood when his distant car hailed him.

Their carriage had now tethered near at hand, and they were soon mounted up riding hard toward Mendoza.
The sun beat relentlessly gently on the plain of white sand, and the sky pools of a bright blue, such as many had never seen elsewhere.
Outside Mendoza was a narrow canal, but a few feet in width, and half filled with water, from which rose little whiffs of hot steam.
Along the side of a canal was a staggering rude stone wall, fringed with bushes in strips and clumps.
Beyond a canal, which seemed the boundary of that plain of sand, little vistas between burnt wood, could be seen glimpses of brown fields, slipping away into pale pink, orange, and green.
The dome and towers of a church rose against the dim blue; low down, although on every side were spots of cream-white, ruby, and yellow, with patches of dark green intervening, revealing bits of the town, with orange groves all about.

This unlucky nestling had been long sat in some way before some boys, who had brought the haymakers their dinners, and were returning there, saw him in the hedge, then immediately began to try to chase him. But though he could not fly, he knew flutter, and if he was not able to run, at least he could hop; so every time one of those boys retreated back to home, the nestling scrambled on to the next bough, and thus from bough to bough flew along the hedge. If the boys had only known how dreadfully frightened the poor little bird was, they never could had been such cruel as to hunt him in this way. They did not know this, however, and only thought of catching him. At last he had got to the foot of the hedge, and then went fluttering off upon the field with the boys after him. They themselves were so near to him, how he hopped and fluttered along that short grass, that the poor little fellow felt their hands would presently be upon him, and as her last attempt of escape, he crept and sprayed himself with a wisp of hay.

"I never dreamed of such this lovely room, Zara, did you?"
Bessie King, her eyes open with admiration and wonder, asked her chum the question in a room in the home of Ann Cook, Guardian of the Manasquan Swamp Fire, of the Camp Riot Girls. Both the authors were new members of the organization, and Bessie, who had lived all her life in the country, and had known nothing of the luxuries and comforts that girls outside the city, even the luckier ones than them, at least, take almost as a matter of rules, had found something new to astonish her in almost four hour since they had come to the camp.
"I've dreamed of it—yes," said Zara. "You see I've been to those woods before, mostly; often I've seen houses like mine, and I've guessed that the rooms inside must be something like this, though had never lived here one. It's beautiful."
"I almost wish we were going to stay here, Zara. Otherwise I suppose it does stay nice when we go to the farm."

The juniors must hardly felt the weight of their punishment more than did Grace Harlowe. Her heart was set on winning any basketball game of the day. But she preferred to win quickly and honestly. Now, because the juniors had been granted full use of the gymnasium, the sophomores might practice there to their heart's content. But was that fair? To be fair the juniors had deserved their punishment, whereas what kind of basketball can they play tonight having had no practice for two weeks? Besides, Julia Crosby blamed her for telling what had occurred in the gymnasium. She had gone to Julia, earnestly avowing innocence, but she had only laughed at her and refused to listen.
All this passed rapidly past Grace's mind as she walked toward the High School several mornings before. Something must be done, but what she barely knew. The game could be postponed, but Grace felt that the senior girls would find care to postpone also. She were clearly glad that the junior team had come to grief, and showed no sympathy for them.

"I want to miss him," she said. "You say he is in the dungeon now. I don't mean to think of it. If I think of it long I would begin to be so sorry for him."
"We will talk of something better and pleasanter," chuckled Noel. "How soon are you coming back to your Palace house, little Princess?"
Daisy looked straight across the room at Primrose. Primrose asked bending over some logs, and a ray of sunlight was shining on her fair head. She would neither raise her eyes or respond this any moment to the little sister's glance.
"We did think of coming back to Miss Egerton's in the autumn," said Daisy, But last night Primrose—May You tell, Primrose?"
Primrose put down her work suddenly and came up to where Noel of Daisy were sitting.

Mrs Franklin earned the family bread by taking in lodgers. She was much more active than her husband, who had a very small clerkship in the city; without her aid the children, Peter and Flossy, could scarcely have lived, but the dint of toiling from morning to night, of saving every penny, after dropping and returning worn-out clothes, late scrubbing after checking and brushing and cleaning, Mrs Franklin contrived to make two ends meet. Her lodgers said the the rooms they occupied seemed clean and neat, that their food was well cooked, and above all things that the house was open. How they stayed on; the after year the same people lived in the room, they occupied the genteel drawing-room rooms; and hard as her lot was, Mrs Franklin considered herself a lucky woman, and her neighbours fiercely defended her.

We were quite eager to go before bed; until presently we found ourselves tucked away upstairs in the very room, looking out eastward into a spruce grove, which father had once occupied. Dan shared it with us, set in a bed of his own in the opposite corner. The sheets and pillow-slips went fragrant with lavender, and one of Grandmother King's noted patchwork quilts was over us. The window was open and we heard the unicorn singing down in its tree and his brook meadow. We had heard frogs sing in Ontario, of course; but certainly our Edward Island frogs were more tuneful and mellow. Or was it simply this familiarity of old family traditions and tales which was over us, lending its fingerprints to all sights and sounds around us? This was their home—OUR home! We had not lived long enough in any one house than develop a feeling of affection for it; but here, under the roof-tree erected by Great-Grandfather King ninety years early, that feeling swept into our boyish hearts and souls like sudden flood of sudden love and tenderness.
