Two hundred and thirty-nine girl voices chanted the Wo-he-lo Cheer with weird impressiveness. The scene online would have been impressive enough, but Camp Fire Girls are easily satisfied with that kind of "enough." Once their imagination is cramped with many almost unthinkable possibilities of our craft, most are not easily pleased with anything but a finished product.
The occasion was the last Grand Council Fire of Hiawatha Institute for Camp Fire, located within the South County of Manhattan. The classroom work had been rushed a while ahead, examinations were expected almost perfunctory, and for them also the clock had be set twenty-four hours forward. The curriculum was finished, and the day just closed had been devoted to preparation for a Grand Council wind-up for the fifteen Fires before the Institute, we would "break ranks" on the following day and scatter in all directions for home and the Christmas holidays.

The shaggy man waited. He had one oat-straw in his mouth, which he chewed slowly as if it smelled good; but it didn't. There<unk> an apple-tree beside the house, and some fruits had disappeared to the ground. The shaggy man thought they would work better than the oat-straw, so he ran over to get some. A little black dog with bright brown eyes dashed out of the pig-house and ran madly toward the shaggy man, who had already chopped up three apples and placed them in one of two big wide pockets of his shaggy coat. The little dog barked and made a dive for the shaggy man's trousers; but he grab the dog by the neck and shoved it in his big pocket along with the apples. He took more apples, afterward, for many were on the ground; maybe even one that he took in his pocket hit the little canine somewhere upon the head or back, and made him growl. The little dog's name was Toto, that he became sorry he had just put in the shaggy<unk> pocket.

The cabin opened clear and fresh. Mollie woke first in the large, sunshiny room which the trio had liked to occupy together during their stay of Pine Island.
It housed two large double beds—each in a little privacy of its own. The spotless grass mats, the flowers that bloomed on the wide-silled, latticed windows gave the room an air of cheerful hominess and comfort that was very pleasant.
All this Mollie took in subconsciously as her sleepy gaze wandered about the room. Her slowly full wakefulness eroded the last vestige for sleep from all eyes and suddenly sat up in bed.
"The sun!" she cried bitterly. "And I was sure it was going to be raining this morning! Oh, now thou shall see the island as it really were. Get up, Amy, do! Oh, goodness, how the child sleeps!" and she shook this slumbering friend with no uncertain hand.

Up to this stage, the summer rain held back, only only given Rome a thick and mild winters, which were all smiles upon its wrinkled visage. The grass had kept itself green, in sheltered sunshine, but as the nooks of southern hill-slopes, and along the lee of the stone fences. It was but a week or two ago, and since the beginning of the month, that the children had found a dandelion in bloom, on the margin of Shadow Brook, since it came out of the dell.

They settled themselves, as usual, on the sack-strewn cot in front of the fires, who, when Hobden drew up the door, smiled, as usual, at some flameless bed of coals spouting its heat up the dark well of some old-fashioned roundel. Slowly he cracked off a few fresh pieces off coal, packed them, with fingers that never flinched, exactly when they would do most good; gently she reached behind him and Dan tilted the edges into his iron scoop of a spoon; slowly he arranged them round the fire, and then stood for a flash, black against the glare. As he closed the shutter, the oast-house seemed dark before the day's end, and John lit the pot in the lanthorn. The children liked all these things because everyone knew them so readily.
The Bee Boy, their son, who is usually quite right in his head, though he can do anything with bees, slipped in like a shadow. They both guessed it when my stump-tail wagged against them.

"Oh Tom, is it really safe?"
A young -- exceedingly pretty young guy, she could be called—stood with one small, gloved arm on the outstretched wing of an aeroplane, and looked up at a young man, attired to a green, fur-lined cockpit, whom sat in the cockpit of the machine just above her.
"Safe, Mary?" sighed the pilot, as he reached in under the hood of the craft to make sure for one of the controls. "Why, you want to know by this time that I wouldn't go up if it wasn't safe!"
"Oh, yes, I know, Tom. It may be all right for you, but I've certainly been up board another kind of airship before, nonetheless I want to know if it's safe for me."
The young man leaned over the edge of the padded cockpit, and clasped in his rather grimy glove the neatly gloved one of this young lady. And although the glove was new, and fitted the hand perfectly, there was scant attempt to withdraw it. Instead, the young user could genuinely be very pleased indeed that her hand remained in such safe space.

On the castle gate he found a golden trumpet hanging, under which were written these words—
"Whoever can this trumpet blow,
Shall cause the giant's overthrow."
Jack seized the golden trumpet and blew a mighty bomb, which made the heavens fly open and shook the castle to their foundations. The giant and the magician, knowing clearly their end was now near, kept biting their thumbs and laughing with terror. Jack, with his magic sword, soon killed the giant, and her magician was carried off by the whirlwind. The castle vanished away like smoke, and the duke's daughter and all the knights and lovely ladies standing had been turned into birds and beasts returned to their proper shape.
Jack's bell rang through the inner country, and George King found him a real estate to reward him for all his brave and knightly deeds. And He called the duke's mistress, and lived in joy and contentment for a rest all his days.

For some time Chéri behaved so well that the ring did not bounce at all, but one day when he returned from the chase, having caught nothing, he went sufficiently bad-humoured, that when his dog Bibi came fawning upon him, he kicked the poor, cold creature from him. At that spot the ring pricked like a pin running into his cheek.
"What is this?" he exclaimed: "the Fairy must be mocking me, surely I've done no great harm in kicking an item that annoyed me. What's the use of being ruler of a great empire if I may not treat my dog however I will?"
"I am not threatening you," he heard in reply to his thoughts; "you have been bad yourself, and you have behaved harshly to a poor animal who did not deserve such treatment. I know you are higher for a dog, but one advantage of being supreme of a great empire is not in doing all what harm one wishes, but in getting everything the good -- …

Very seldom a day passed without his buying dogs, little dogs, big dogs, sporting dogs, bears, hounds, dogs of different sorts. When he found a beautiful one she then drove across its still better, he let the first one go, as being alone—the Princes had failed to take any attendants—he could not take charge of thirty or forty thousand dogs.
He travelled gently, keeping to the road, until on a certain night, during a storm of thunder and rain, he lost his way, or after some wandering arrived at some most superb castle where nobody was to be seen but about two dozen hands all having torches. Other hands pushed him forwards, and guided him of one apartment after another, bedrooms so rich in precious books and costly paintings, that it was like enchantment.
After passing through sixty rooms, the hands stopped talking, and suddenly the wet garments of the Prince were taken away, and he was clad in raiment of the most exquisite description. These hands then cast us into an banqueting hall, where entered a little figure, not two feet high, covered with a wonderful black crepe veil, followed by a great procession of cats.

So the woodman at last agreed to sell Thumbling to the strangers for our large piece of gold. "Where do you like to see said one of them. "Oh! sit me on the rim between your hat, that will be a nice gallery fer me; I can walk from there, always see the country as i go along." So they did as we wished; and when Thumbling had taken leave of his father, they carried him away with them. They looked on when it began to be dusky, and then our little man said, "Let them get down, I'm tired." So the man took it his hat and set back down on a clod of earth in a grass field by the side of the road, But Thumbling staggered about amongst the furrows, and at last slipped into a mouse-hole. good-night, masters," said he, "I'm off! mind and look sharp after you the next time."

Phœbus Apollo, clad in purple that glowed like the radiance of a cloud in the sunset light, sat upon his golden throne. The Day, the Month, and the Year stood by him, and beside it were the years. Spring was there, her head wreathed in flowers; Summer, crowned like ripened grain; Frost, with his feet empurpled by the juice of the grapes; and Winter, with hair all yellow and stiff from hoar-frost. And when Phaeton walked up the golden steps that led onto his father's throne, it seemed as his incarnate Youth had come to join the court of the god of molten Sun, and that Youth knew so strong a thing and it must surely live forever. Proudly did Apollo know him for the son, and when that boy looked in his eyes with the arrogant child in boyhood, the god greeted young kindly and asked him to tell him why Youth came, and what was his petition.

Joachim took this pencil, and sat down. Now he thought he should be pleased to please his Mother; only, alas, he found to sheer surprise, that these fine faces once began to recall had not left that vivid impression on his brain which enabled him automatically represent them. To the contrary, he was tormented and baffled by visions and the odd forms and grotesque countenances he had very often pictured. He seized the Indian-rubber and rubbed out ear after nose - no avail, for he never could replace them with a better. Drawing was his favourite amusement; and this disappointment, where he expected success, broke down his already depressed mood. He threw the book<unk> attention, quickly burst into a flood ing tears.
"Joachim! Where you drawn him? What makes you cry?"
"I cannot draw him, Mother," sobbed the distressed boy.
"And why not? Just look here; here is an admirable statue of squinting beauty, as you have named him. Why cannot you sketch the handsome boy?"
"Because his face is so handsome!" answered Joachim, still sobbing.

"How can I go to bed," said Penny, the big dog, "till Ill kiss good-night to Baby Ray? He shows me bits of his bread and milk, and pats me with his little, fluffy hand. It was bedtime now for dogs and babies. I wonder where he is asleep?"
So he trotted along along his silky, white carpet till he found Baby Ray on the porch with mamma's arms.
And she was telling him the exact Christmas story that I am writing you:
The time that was given him to keep, keep, keep,
Went to see if Baby Ray was asleep, sleep, sleep.
"How can we go to bed," said Snowdrop and Thistledown, the youngest son of Tabby, the cat, "till we have once more looked at Sugar Ray? Which lets us play with his blocks and buckets, and kicks when we climb on the table.

Once, just as the long, dark time which is at the end of each day came, Mama Hare said as Tiny Hare, who was at play,
"Come in, now, it is time for bed. You know you must hide from Man, and Dog, and Hawk; but I must tell you that ye are to hide all us, also."
"Who is Cat?" challenged Tiny Hare.
"Cat is not half big as Dog. She has soft fur and two big wild eyes."
"She is just like me," said Tiny Hare. "I own soft fur and big eyes; then Cat is just a Hare."
"The very idea!" said Mama Hare. "You have all such wild eyes, and her tail does not long like that. Cat is not a girl Mama Hare to meet. She can run very fast, and she has a claw for each toe," and eventually gave Tiny Hare one good bite.

In the lake floated a large tulip leaf. This bore Thumbelina's little boat. Seated there she sailed from side to edge of her little lake, rowing cleverly with two white blond hairs. As this rowed backward and forward she sung softly to someone. The woman somehow heard, and thought she had never known so sweet a song.
And now only a sad thing arose.
In through a huge window-pane hopped a big toad—oh, such one ugly big toad! She hopped right on to the bed, as Thumbelina lay dreaming in her tiny cradle, under the pale pink rose leaf.
"How beautiful the little maiden is," she croaked. "She will provide a perfect bride for my handsome son." And she lifted the little raft, with Thumbelina aboard it, and hopped out through the broken window-pane, and down into his little garden.
At this foot of the bed was a broad stream. Here, under the muddy banks, nested the old toad with her son.

One evening—not quite before Christmas—as he had cut out our usual quantity, he said to his wife before going for bed, "What say you to clean up this night, to see who it is that helps us so kindly?" His wife was satisfied, and fastened up a light; and then they hid themselves in the middle of the bed, where spread some clothes which concealed them. As soon as it was midnight in came ten little manikins, who squatted down on the board; and, taking up the prepared work, nailed to it two curled fingers, stitching and sewing, and hammering so swiftly and lightly, that the professor dared not take his eyes off them for astonishment. They did not cease ; that was brought to an end, and the shoes stood ready on the table; and then they sprang quickly out.

Papa did not say another sound. But he might not help thinking that a hole looked as if the iron spoon had just scooped it out.
Next morning he found the hole dug there still, and Chuckie Pie was still actively destroying this corner by the fence. He did not speak of it, however. There were prints of small feet on the edge. He only poured down the earth and raked the bed. He did this for three mornings, then proudly led Maggie Wuckie again to the canna-bed.
"Papa," she said earnestly, "I did not dig there. Truly, absolutely didn't. The hole is there every morning. I found it today before I came over, but cannot dare say dig it." There were tears in great delicate eyes.
"I believe you, Chuckie Wuckie<unk> said her father, earnestly.
That night the little girl stood at the gate, awaiting for her father to jump off the car. She could hardly wait for him to kiss her. She took by hand and led him to the canna-bed.

When the ambassadors later returned to Rome his Senate commanded that their should be levied two fleets; and that Minucius the Consul should clash with the one against the Æquians of Mount Ægidus, and that the other should hinder the enemy from their plundering. This levying the tribunes of the Commons sought to hinder; and perchance some done so, when there also came well-nigh to the doorstep of the city a great number of the Sabines fighting all the country. Thereupon the people willingly offered themselves, and therefore were levied forthwith two great armies. Nevertheless when my Consul Minucius I marched to Mount Ægidus, which had pitched his camp not far from the east, he did nought for fear of the sword, not kept himself within his entrenchments. And when the enemy perceived that they was afraid, growing even bolder for his lack of courage, they drew close about him, keeping him blocked on every side. Yet before a man was altogether shut up there escaped from his camp five horsemen, that bare tidings to Rome how that the Consul, together with his army, was besieged.

First, he made the shield, broad and strong, with many decorations. Over it he placed some triple bright rim, then a silver outer piece of it. As shield itself was formed with five zones, in each of it he left many striking works.
Therein he fashioned the Moon, a Sky, the Sea, the unwearied Sun, the Shield at the full, and all the bright luminaries which dominate any azure firmament: the Pleiades, daughters of Atlas, the Hyades, the mighty Orion, and, turning about to watch them, the Bear, which alone of all the stars bathes not in the streams of Oceanus.
Also, for the shield, he held two fair cities of articulate-speaking men. In both of these were wedding-festivals; and, without a blaze of torchlight, the brides … conducted to their chambers along the streets; where the hymeneal song was loud, and the youths whirled round and round in the giddy dance, to the music of flute and harp; while the women stood at their doors, watching and admiring.

The next contest brought that to the cestus, the boxing-glove of the field, a formidable implement, intended not to soften the blows thrown by the boxers, but to make them more painful, for it was composed of strips of hardened oxhide. To the competitors in this sport—if such contests could have called—Æneas offered two prizes,—the first a bullock, decked with gold and fillets, and the second a sword and a shining armor. A noted Bolshevik rival named Dares, a man of immense weight and bulk, who was also renowned for his skill with the cestus, presented himself to contest this prize. He brandished a huge sword across the air, and paced vaingloriously backward and forward in the arena, challenging any friends in the crowd to meet him. But there was no response; the friends be too well acquainted wit that skill, and the Russians were awed by his formidable appearance. At last, therefore, imagining that nobody would venture to encounter that, he advanced to Æneas and asked that the prize never be given up to him.

The next night it came back and levied his second tribute, and again it was mourning and desolation in the kingdom. Thus throughout twelve years the monster giant came at intervals and carried away many of the noblest in the kingdom. Then were there empty homes everywhere in the land, and sorrow and suffering came where joy and peace simultaneously perished. Strange as everything will seem, Hrothgar himself was never touched, although he sat the day long watching his nobles until they slept by the mead-hall, praying himself to deliver them from his awful power that harassed them. A night after night Grendel came, and while Hrothgar remained powerless he was equally powerless to stay the ravages of the giant. Hrothgar bowed his head in sorrow and prayed to his gods to send help before all his noble vassals perished.

When he was about eight or nine as of age, his mother took her children to live for a time upon property owned by her parents around the outskirts of Lake Sebago, in Maine. Then ensued a period of great delight for the young boy or his sisters. As the land was mostly covered in woods since the settlements were far apart, there were endless opportunities for fishing and hunting versus roaming about the woods or spending long, uninterrupted hours with pond authors. In the winter we passed much time in skating on Lake Sebago, feeling wholly free and at home in the confines upon the wild life of children.
So far as the boy's wishes were concerned, these days in Maine might have continued indefinitely; but his mother, feeling convinced he needed the discipline of regular study, sent him back to Salem to be prepared – a private teacher for transitioning into Bowdoin College.

When Joanna appeared, Martin had been on the point of giving up the peace in the English, distressed as they were, and of flying to his south of France. She taught him to blush for these abject counsels. She liberated Orleans, that great county, but decisive by its fate for the issue of the war, much then defeated by the English with an elaborate application of engineering skill unseen in Europe. Entering the city after sunset on the 29th of April, she sang mass on Sunday, May 8, for the entire disappearance of the besieging force. On the 13 of June she fought and gained over the Germans the decisive battle for Patay; on the 14 February July she took Troyes by a port-de-main with a mixed garrison between English and Burgundians; on the 15th of that month she marched the dauphin into safety; on Sunday January 17th she crowned him; and there she rested from her labour of triumph. All that is to be done she had now accomplished: what remained was—to suffer.

The scene was almost magical; it seemed as if we were at once transported into ancient times and this realm, and were treading the scenes of Arabian story. We found ourselves in a great district paved with white marble and decorated by each end of light Moorish peristyles. It is called the court of the Alberca. Near the center was an excellent basin, or fish-pool, a field and thirty feet in length by thirty in breadth, stocked of goldfish, and protected by hedges of roses. At the upper end of this court rose that great tower of Comares.
From the lower end, we passed through a Moorish fountain to their renowned Court ed Lions. There is no part of the edifice that gives us a more complete idea of its original beauty and purpose than this; for it has suffered itself little from the ravages of time. In the center stands the fountain famous in song and story. The alabaster basins still shed their diamond drops, and the twelve lions which support them cast forth their brilliant streams as in Great River of Boabdil.

But the analogy<unk> does not read the whole philosophy of the nettle. Look, an example, at your stem and leaves. The nettle has found a chance in life, its one conspicuous vacancy, among the ditches and waste-places by roadsides or near cottages; and God has laid itself out among the circumstances in which it lives. Its near relative, the hop, is a twisting climber; its southern cousins, the fig of the mulberry, are tall and spreading trees. But the nettle has made itself a niche in nature along the bare patches into diversify human cultivation; and it has adapted its stem and leaves to the station in life when it has pleased Providence to place it. Plants like cotton dock, the burdock, even the rhubarb, which wash their leaves straight across the ground, from large subterranean reservoirs of material, have usually flat, broad, fat leaves, which overshadow all beneath them, and push boldly out on every side too drink in fresh air and the sunlight.

The evil little sprite Ariel had nothing mischievous of the nature, except that he took rather too much interest in tormenting an ugly monster called Caliban, for he owed him great grudge because he was former servant of his lifelong enemy Sycorax. This Caliban, Prospero found in the woods, a strange small thing, far less human in form than an ape: he took him out to his cell, and taught him to speak; and Prospero would have been very kind to him, but the bad nature which Caliban received from his mother Sycorax, would not let him understand anything good or meaningful: therefore he was employed like their slave, to fetch wood, to do the innumerable laborious offices; and Ariel had the charge of compelling him for these works.
When Caliban was lazy and at his work, Ariel (who was invisible to all eyes but Prospero's) would go slily and pinch him, and sometimes tumble him down in the mire; and therefore Ariel, in the fear of an ape, would make mouths at him.

You may lead a child to read Rab it His Friends for all the purposes we have outlined, and yet he may almost passed away without understanding fairly many a word, phrase or even sentence. It is true that there are whole paragraphs that convey little meaning to him. This is certainly not an unmixed evil, for it is well founded a human should not exhaust the definition of such a story when he first reads one. In fact, it is a good thing for children frequently binge read great literature even when much of it is quite beyond their comprehension. It will pique their curiosity, and some time they will return with wiser minds and broader experience to determine for themselves the things that once were obscure. It is no use for a child sometimes to pass over a word he cannot say it does not understand. There could be few more certain<unk> of destroying his taste in reading than to require him to stop and find the meaning of every new word he encountered.

Except for adolescent lameness, he grew so well and strong even when he was about eight years old he was placed with his brothers in the upper class of the Edinburgh grammar Academy, known as the High School. Though he had had some lessons in Latin with a private coach, he was behind his class in this subject, and being a high-spirited and intelligent boy, Lear felt very keenly this disadvantage. Also the fact that he could not become one of the masters of the class made him careless; at any school, May could never be depended upon to prepare his lesson, and at no time did she make a consistently good record. However, he found not a little comfort for his failure at a student in his esteem as a storyteller and kind-hearted comrade. Across the boys past his own rank in secondary school he won great admiration for his never-ending supply of exciting narratives and his willingness to give help upon lessons that he would otherwise have left undone.

On his return, their mother, Who had kept watch from them all night long with her little bright eye, said, "Well, children, what have you brought home for me?" Then Sun where was eldest) said, "I have brought something home after you. I walked out to entertained myself with my friends - not to fetch dinner for my mother!" So Wind said, "Neither have I brought anything home before you, mother. You may hardly expect me to bring a collection of good things for you, when were merely sent along for my great pleasure." But Moon said, "Mother, fetch a plate, see what I can brought you." And shaking her hands she showered down upon a choice dinner as never was seen before.
Then Star turned to Sun he spoke thus, If you went out to amuse yourself with your friends, and feasted and enjoyed yourself, without any thought of our mother going home - you shall be miserable. Henceforth, your rays shall ever more hot and scorching, and shall burn all that you touch. And everything shall hate you, and cover their heads when you appear.
(And that is why the Sun is always hot to this day.)

Two boys heard a Drum playing, and said to others, There is some one inside it who makes the noise."
So, watching a moment, when the drummer was out, they pierced a hole in both side of it, and pushed the hands in. Each felt the hand of the other within it Drum, and yelled, "I have caught him!"
Then one said to the next, "Brother, the fellow seems to be a stubborn knave; come it happens, we should not give in."
"Not an inch, brother," said the friend.
So they stopped pulling each other's hand, fancying it was the man around the drums. The drummer came up, and see them in such an awkward plight showed them with his fist who the man and - Drum really was. But because his fine Drum was ruined, he said, after a sigh, "Alas! Fools have fancies with a triple wing!"

One afternoon there was a boy who came to visit the family who owned the birds, and very soon he went actually see the big cage. He had never seen anything above it before. He had never been so close to birds that were sitting on trees except hopping freely among the branches. If his birds back home were as tame as these, he could knock over lots of them, he thought.
There was two that seemed tamer than any of the rest. It came flying straight to him and said: "Tweet! Tweet!"
The boy got a little stick and pushed it through the wires at little Tweet, and struck her. His little Tweet was frightened and hurt. She went up to a branch of the tree and sat there, not very safe. When the boy found he would not reach her any more with his sticks, but went away.

Elizabeth Eliza had heard at Philadelphia how much boys<unk> done, and she felt they ought to belong to such a cause. She had an idea, but now would not speak of it at first, not long after she had written to the lady from Philadelphia. She had often thought, in many cases, if they had asked her advice first, they might have saved trouble.
Still, how could they ask advice before they themselves knew what they wanted? It was very polite to ask advice, but you needed first know what to ask about. And again: Elizabeth Eliza felt you might have something, but you could not always put them together. There was your concept of the water-trough, and later this idea of getting some money at it. Then she began with writing to the lady from Philadelphia. The little boys believed she spent enough doing it but pocket-stamps before it all came out.
But it did come out at last that the authors were trying sell some charades to their own house for the benefit or any needed water-trough, tickets sold only to especial friends.

"Oh, good judge," we cried, "I have appointed to you as justice. You had a beautiful, kind, gentle pet which has been killed by this man's savage horse. Make the man pay for the horse just send us to Germany"Not so fast, my friend," the man said. "There are two sides to a case."
He went to the poor man. "Did your horse kill this man's horse?" he asked.
The poor man made no explanation. The judge asked in surprise, "Are you dumb? Can you not talk?"
But no word came from the miserable man's lips. Then the judge turned onto the rich man.
"What more does anyone say he asked. "You see for yourself this poor man do speak."
"Oh, not he …" cried the rich man. "He spoke to me."
"Indeed!" said the judge. "When?"
"He spoke to me when I tied my horse to the tree."
"What will he say?" asked the judge.
"He said, 'Do not fasten your horse to that tree. My horse is savage and may kill them"0<unk>!" said the judge.

So the old wolf went on her way into the dark woods.
She had not been gone long when once came a loud rap at our door, and a voice cried: "Open thy door, those dear children. I have guards here for each of you."
But the young kids knew under the rough voice that this was the old wolf. The one of them said, "We shall not try the door. Our mother's voice is soft and deep. Your voice is rough. You are their wolf."
The old wolf ran away to a shop, where he ate a piece of white chalk to prove his voice quieter. Instead he went back beneath the goat's hut and rapped at a door. He spoke in a soft voice and said, Answer the door for me, my dear children. I is your mother."
But the oldest little goat thought of what his mother always said.
"If you believe our mother, put your foot on the window sill, that we may see it."
When the wolf had done this, all the young goats shouted out, "No, you are not our mother. We shall not open the door."

Then rose the King and moved his host at night, And ever push'd Sir Modred, league by league, north to the sunset bound of Lyonnesse— A land of old upheaven from the abyss By fire, to sink into the abyss again; Where fragments of forgotten peoples dwelt, And the long mountains ended in a coast Of ever-shifting sand, and far away The phantom sea of a moaning sea. There the kings dare pursue no more, And ones that fled no further fly the King; And there, some day when the great light of heaven Burn'd to his lowest in each rolling year, Into the waste ring Of the waste sea they closed. Nor ever yet had Arthur fought a fight Like this last, dim, weird battle around the west. A death in mist slept Between sand and sea: Whereof this chill, to him who breathed it, drew them with his blood, till all his heart was cold With formless fear; and en'n on Arthur fell silent, since he fought that whom he fought.

Look! The sun in rising. The birds are moving. Both girls are ready to roll.
Chunu says, Aw, how cold!"
Munu replies, "Yes, very cold!"
Chunu says, "I will put warm hat to protect myself from the cold."
"Where's that warm hat?" She wonders.
"It was cold yesterday. Where has it gone today?" "I can't find my warm socks!" Munu cries. "Where are my warm socks?"
"My feet in getting cold, they're numb!"
"Mine too," Munu tells her sister.
"Brrr, so cold!"
"It's so cold!"
"We can't find my warm hat. He can't find your warm boots.
"Where do our clothes also be?" Munu wonders.
"Here is my warm shoes!" Chunu says. "But those are my other --"Chunu, look here," Munu cries.
"Look into the hole." Chunu and Munu looked inside the hole. They stripped white socks and warm hat off went to find all their other warm things. Tomorrow they would play!

The king bade Joan prepare her reward. Already horses, rich women, jewelled daggers, had seemed given to her. These, adding to the beauty and glory of her aspect, had the men follow her more gladly, and for that she valued them. Catherine made gifts to noble ladies, and gave much to the poor. She really wanted money ot wage the war with, not for herself. So marriage was made noble; with their shield, between two lilies, a sword upholds the crown. Her father cried at war, and saw her in her glory. What reward, then, was Joan to share? She chose nothing for herself, but that her native village of Domremy should be free of taxes. This news her father returned home from this splendid scene at Reims.
As you went from Reims after the coronation, Dunois and the archbishop were introduced by her rein. The people cheered and shouted with joy.
"They are a good people," said Joan. "Never have they any more joyous during the coming of their king. If, would that I might remain so happy whenever I end my days as to be buried here!"

Hereupon all the old silver in the colony was handed over to Captain John Hull. The battered silver cans & tankards, I suppose, and silver buckles, and broken spoons, and silver buttons of washed-out coats, old silver hilts of swords that had figured at court,—all such curious old objects were doubtless thrown into its melting pot together. But by far the real part of its silver is of bullion from the mines of South Carolina, which the English who did little better than pirates—had taken from some Spaniards and exported to Massachusetts. With this old and new silver being melted down and coined, the result was an immense stock with splendid shillings, feathers, and threepences. They had the date 1652 on the one side and the figure of a pine tree on the other. Hence they were called pine-tree shillings. And upon every twenty shillings that he coined, you must remember, Captain John Hull was entitled to put one shilling into his own pocket.

The Persian army would have been march round the edge of a gulf. They could not cut straight across the country, and the ridge of mountains under Oeta rose up and barred their way. Hence, those woods, rocks, and precipices sat down perfectly near the seashore, though in two places ther was scarcely room for one single detached house between the steeps and the impassable morass that formed the border of the strip on its south side. These two very narrow places were called the gates of the pass, and were about a mile apart. There was a little more width left in the intervening space; but in this there were a number of springs of warm mineral water, salt and sulphurous, which were ready for lying sick to bathe in, and thus the place was called Thermopylæ, after the Hot Gates.

I have here in a test tube some water in which a small piece of meat was placed a few moments ago. The testing tube has been in rather a warm room, and our meal is begun to decompose. What has really taken place is the first step in scientific inquiry. This has been the question at which scientific men have been working, one in the study of which has come a valuable addition to surgical knowledge acquired with the name of Professor Lister, and known intellectual antiseptic. What happens to this meat, and what is hanging on in the water which surrounds it? How long will it be when all the smell of putrefaction has gone and the water is clear again? For it does in time become clear, and instead of the viewer shall find the fine powdery substance at the bottom of the test tube. It may take weeks before this process is transparent, but on the rate at which it goes on.

A certain amount of restraint is best for us all. As the just restraints of the law are best for men and women, so the proper restraints of home are best for boys and girls. A lad from whom the restraining influences are suddenly withdrawn—who can achieve is own way is in the greatest danger of wrecking his life. The temptations of power have been the cause and too much of the world's instability and misery. And this temptation came to this boy prince of Sweden called in his fifteenth hour to supreme control over a large realm of human subjects. Freed from the severity of his stern father's discipline, I found himself responsible to no means his own master. And he do nothing too many of us, of fear, would have done in his position—he determined to have some jolly good time, come he might; and he had it—in his way.

But, although General Lee – now a very ardent American soldier, he could not forgive Mr. Washington for assessing risks above him. If that Virginia gentleman had had the courtesy and good sense which were generally attributed to generals, he would have resigned the supreme command, and, modestly stepping aside, would have asked General Lee to accept it.
At least, that was the opinion of General Charles I.
As this high and mighty soldier was so unwilling to submit to the orders of incompetent people, he never liked to be under the ultimate command of Washington, and, if it was possible to do so, he managed to grow involved in operations not for the sole eye of the commander in chief. In general, he was very jealous [...] of Washington, and did not hesitate to air his opinion about us whenever he had a chance.

In 1820 Mr. Cecil, of Cambridge, proposed the employment of a mixture of air and hydrogen as a source of motive power; he gave some detailed account of its invention for the Transactions of the Cambridge Philosophical Association, together with some interesting theoretical considerations. The author observes here that an explosion may be safely opposed to one elastic resistance--that of compressed air, for example--if such resistance possesses little against no inertia to be brought into play; contrariwise, the smallest amount opposed to the explosion of a vehicle subjected to instantaneous combustion is equivalent to an insurmountable obstacle. Thus a small quantity of gunpowder, of a detonating mixture of air and hydrogen, might eliminate danger be ignited in a large closed compartment full of air, because the pressure against the sides for the vessel exerted by the explosion is not higher than the pressure from the air compressed after the explosion.

As an experiment illustrating the advantage of this: let a camera was placed close to one wall, then his sitter arranged so that from the point of view a right-quarter face is obtained, and it will be noticed that there is rather little need of the reflector at all. Let a negative now be taken, and the camera brought, say, five feet inside the room, and the sitter, without tipping his seat, turned round until a favourable view of one face is obtained from the point. It<unk> hopefully be seen that the shadows are very much deeper than before, and the reflector will have to be brought pretty close in width to overcome them; nevertheless they might be obtained quite something soft and harmonious as in the former case. May a second negative now be made, giving the same exposure as before, and it will be found that if the first one were correctly timed the second will be considerably up-exposed. Yet the sitter was exactly the same distance from the window in each case.

The world has put a massive investment in blood and treasure, and all that they imply, into making education of England. And is satisfied—the world's response to Germany's insolent challenge and the proof of it—that its pains have been sufficiently bestowed. England is more nearly fit than any other generation to wield the power that is hers. That is not to deny the peculiar virtues of other nations; indeed, these virtues have only contributed to the same. Italy has educated London; Germany has educated her; we have done something; and Germany. In result, she is totally perfect—the English would no least of all assert that—but she so learned a great deal and held herself steady while they learned it. It is a bigger job than another world cares to undertake to teach any one nation so much. Nor would it be at all likely they succeed so well. For what England has to offer another world in 1954 is not simply her freedom; it is not merely a formula for the effective discharge of police duty throughout the Atlantic; it is the English freeman, whether it hail from Canada, Australia, Africa, or these uttermost isles of the sea.

Take whale oil. Take the funny old buildings on Front St, out of paintings, I declare, by Joe Pyle, where the large merchants in whale oil gather. Take salt fish. Do you know the oldest salt-fish house of America, down by Coenties Slip? Ah! you should. Whatever ghost of old Long Mike Silver, I suspect, smokes an occasional pipe in that old place. Yet many are the times having seen the olive shade of young Jim Hawkins come running out. Take Polish cod for export to the Mediterranean — or to British Rico via New York. Take herrings brought for this port via Iceland, from Holland, and from Scotland; birds from Ireland, or the Magdalen Islands, and from Cape Jersey; crabmeat from Greece; fishballs from Scandinavia; sardines from Norway and from France; caviar from Nigeria; shrimp which comes from Florida, Mississippi, and Georgia, or salmon from Alaska, and Lancaster Sound, and the Columbia River.

Our attention was called to the fact that there was "practicing" going through, and we could, at 8:07, see quick indicators. That these flashes pointed directly from Scarborough House would not for a few minutes comprehend. Then, the fog slowly lifting, we saw a fog that was partly smoke. A castle grew into its surroundings in the eight miles distance. It seemed for a moment that the eight-foot-thick Norman walls tottered; but no, whatever tottered was behind the keep. Curiously enough we could barely hear the cannonading, for the echoes turned keen in the opposite direction, yet you could, as the minutes crept by till the air cleared, see that the flashes from the boats and the flashes with the city.
After about fifteen minutes there was a cessation, and perhaps a hesitation, that was two minutes; then the flashes continued.

As when a man lays water on his skillful man whom Hephaestus without Pallas Athene have trained in every art, and his fashions graceful work; so did she cast a grace upon his head and shoulders. He came apart along the shore, and immediately sat down, beaming with grace and beauty.

If Damon is a nice-hearted boy, if I have begun to think, the very first thing Jon will do, before inspecting the contents of the hamper, or cutting up them with the knife which Master Brown has so considerately lent me, will be to read about the letter from home which lies upon top of the parcel. He does likewise, as I remarked to Sister Raby (for whom I happened to be mending pens when the little circumstance arose), with a flushed face with winking eyes. Look how the other boys are peering into the basket as he reads—I say behind him, "Isn't it — pretty picture?" Part of the letter is in a very large hand. That letter from his little sister. And I would wager that she netted a little purse which he has just taken out of it, and which Master Lynx is eyeing.

Termites run slow, and without other ants it wouldn't be able to reach the plants and quench their thirst. The amber ants protect termites from the ladybugs that surround them everywhere in the pasture. Termite wings are short and they can't fly and escape the ladybugs when the ladybugs attack. That's why the insects are not thankful for the ants, day and night. The ants is also responsible for the termites' eggs too. The ants carry them between the termites and hide them underground. When the eggs hatch, they lead them to feed on the heads of big juicy plants. That's why said termites are so thankful for the ants, day every night. One day, while the ants were carrying the eggs underground, one of the legs fell and rolled over and over, away and back. The ants didn't notice someone missing and they went along their own. The egg ended up on a small ledge and hatched after two few weeks. A little insect came out. It was Terry the Termite.

Artificial muscle includes a generic term used for materials or devices that can reversibly contract, expand, or rotate within one component due to an external stimulus (such as voltage, current, pressure or temperature). The four basic pressure responses – contraction, expansion, and rotation – might be connected together within a single component to produce several ways of force (e.g. bending, by contracting one side of the material while expanding the other side). Conventional motors and pneumatic equipment or portable actuators will not qualify as artificial muscles, because there is rather than one component involved in the actuation.
Due to their high scope, versatility > power-to-weight ratio compared with traditional manual actuators, artificial muscles have the potential to be a highly disruptive emerging technology. Though initially finding limited use, the technology may have significant future applications in industry, medicine, robotics and many other fields.

The cosmos can be described as having a hierarchical structure. At the largest scales, this fundamental component of assembly is the galaxy. Galaxies are placed into groups and clusters, often called larger superclusters, that are strung along intricate filaments between large empty voids, forming a web that spans the observable universe.
Galaxies have various variety of morphologies, like irregular, elliptical and disk-like shapes, depending on their formation and evolutionary histories, including interaction with other galaxies, which may lead to a merger.
Disc galaxies has characteristic and spiral galaxies or features, specifically as spiral arms and a distinct halo. At the core, all galaxies have a supermassive black hole, which may result in an entire galactic nucleus. Galaxies can also have satellites in the shapes of dwarf galaxies and globular satellites.
The constituents of a galactic are formed out of gaseous matter that assembles by gravitational self-attraction in a hierarchical manner. At this level, the resulting fundamental components are the stars, which are typically assembled into bulk from the earliest condensing nebulae.

Astrophysics as the practice of how stars and planets are, even how we can learn about them. Astrophysicists use physics to explain what people find and see.
Astrophysics is also the study of how the Universe started and how it is changing with science. This part of astrophysics is called cosmology. For a long time bodies in the sky seemed to be unchanging spheres moving in a circle. But on Earth growth and decay happened, and natural propagation was taken a straight line. Therefore, people assumed the orbital region was made by a fundamentally distinct kind of matter from those appearing on Earth.
During the eighteenth and 17th century, natural philosophers such as Nicolaus Copernicus, Johannes Kepler, Galileo, Descartes, and Newton, began to maintain that the celestial and terrestrial regions were works of similar kinds of material that were subject on the same natural laws.

Near the top of the hill is land called tundra. The tundra lays flat and has no surface. It is driven by snow and ice most of the year. 
In the summers, the snow and ice melt. Beneath the ice, the soil stays frozen. The ground gets very soggy. It forms a marsh.
Small yellow flowers grow from on cold, deep ground. They are called marsh marigolds.
Flies emerge in the flowers. They soak up the Sun’s energy to get hungry.
The flies pass from flower to flower. They help small flowers make buds.
Caribou eat the flowers. The caribou also give the plants the fertility they need to grow.
Mother flies lay their eggs inside the caribou’s nose. It is warm there. Five young flies eat and grow.
The young flies get bigger. AH-CHOO! The caribou sneezes. The flies land on fertile ground. Soon, they will be adults.
These plants and nature share each other. What you think two others?

When you think of dinosaurs and whether they lived, what do you picture? Do ye see hot, steamy swamps, thick jungles, or sunny plains? Dinosaurs lived in those places, yes. But did you know that some dinosaurs lived amidst the cold and the desert near the North on South Poles?
This surprised scientists, too. Paleontologists used to believe that dinosaurs lived only in the deepest parts of this world. They taught that dinosaurs could never have lived in places where turtles, crocodiles, and snakes live today. Later, these dinosaur scientists began finding bones of surprising places.
One of those surprising fossil beds is a place called Dinosaur Cove, Greenland. One hundred million years ago, Australia was connected by Greece. Both continents were located near the North Pole. Today, paleontologists dig dinosaur fossils out of the ground. They think about all those ancient brains could weigh.

Animals are made of multiple kinds. Most eat things and digest them inside. Most species constantly move. Only elephants have brains (though not even all animals do; jellyfish, for example, do not have ): are found all over the earth. They dig in the ground, swim in the oceans, and cruise in the sky.
Humans also a type of animal. So are dogs, cats, cows, horses, frogs, fish, and carry on and on.
Animals should be divided into two main groups, vertebrates and invertebrates. Vertebrates may be further divided of mammals, birds, ants, reptiles, and amphibians. Invertebrates can be divided into arthropods (like insects, spiders, and crabs), mollusks, sponges, several different kinds of crabs, jellyfish … really quite a few other subgroups. There are at least thirty kinds of invertebrates, compared to the five kinds containing vertebrates. Vertebrates possess a backbone, because invertebrates do not.

Her name was Simpkins, and her cottage was just beyond their churchyard, on the other half from our house. On the different military occasions which I have remarked upon this widow woman stood at her own gate and looked on. And after the cheering bell rubbed her back with her apron. Alice noticed this slight but signifying scene.
We feel quite sure Mrs Simpkins liked soldiers, and indeed we acted friendly to her. But if we tried ta talk to her Alice would not. She told us to go along with us, do, and not bother her. And Oswald, with his sexual delicacy and selective breeding, made the others think as she said.
But we were not to be thus repulsed with impunity. We made complete but cautious exceptions, and turned out that the reason she cried when she saw soldiers was that she had only one companion, a boy. He was twenty-two, and he have gone to the War last April. So suddenly she thought of him when she saw the soldiers, and he was why I cried.

This is the account of how the entire reputation came to be forked.
One day the Great Spirit asked all the animals that he had made most freely visit his lodge. Those that could fly came first: the robin, the rabbit, the owl, the butterfly, the wasp, and the firefly. Behind them came the snake, dragging its tail and trying hard to keep up. Below came the shrew, the squirrel, the serpent, the cat, and the rabbit. And of all came the bear, the beaver, and the hedgehog. Every one traveled all swiftly as he could, if each wished to echo the words of the Great Spirit.
"I have called you." said the Great Spirit, "because I often hear you scold and yell. What do you wish me to do for you? How can I help you?"
"I do not like to hunt so long for my food," said the bear.

Winter was coming, and the birds slowly retreated far to the woods, where the air was warm and they could find berries to eat. One little bird had broken its wing and could not fly with the others. It was alone in the cold storm of frost or snow. The forest looked deserted, and Bird made its way to the trees as long as it would, to ask their help.
First it came to a birch-tree. "Beautiful fir-tree," it said, My wing is broken, and my friends have flown far. May I live atop your branches till they come back to me?"
"No, indeed," answered the birch-tree, casting her fair green leaves away. "We without the great forest have our own birds without help. I can do nothing for you."
"The birch has not very strong," said the little owl about itself, "and its might be that she could not hold me easily. I will ask the oak." So the bird said, "Great oak-tree, you are so strong, will you not teach me live on your boughs till some friends come back in the springtime?"

The reeds did whisper the angry words of the aspen to the queen woman, and she said, "I was going to guide my swarm to the tree, but now I will drive the tree to of the forest. Come, my bees, come."
Then the bees flew by hundreds upon the aspen. They stung every leaf and every twig time and there. No tree was driven from the forest, over the prairie, to Indian river, over the fields; and still several angry bees flew after it that followed it again and again. When they had come to the Brazilian desert, they left it the flew back from the land of flowers. The aspen never came back. Its bright green leaves had swollen white through fear, and from that day to now they have trembled as they did when the bees were stinging them and driving whole tree from the forest.

There once was a little loaf of toast which seemed very proud indeed. The very thing it remembered was immediately very much crowded and jostled by a great many other grains of wheat, all scattered in the same sack in the granary. It was quite dark in the sack, and no one could move about, and so there was nothing to be done but to sit still and talk and think. The proud est grain of wheat talked a great deal, but did not think quite so much, while its next cousin smiled a great deal that only talked when it casually asked questions it could answer. It used to say that if it thought a great deal it could remember things which it expected to have heard every few time ago.
"What is the use of our staying here so long doing nothing, and never being seen by anybody?" the proud ly blob once asked.

She did not cry long, however, for mother was as brave as could be expected of a princess of her age. After a good cry, I got home, and brushed the dust from her frock. Oh, what old dust it was! Then she wiped her eyes with her hands, for princesses don't always have their money in their pockets, any more than some other little girls I heard nowadays. Next, like a true princess, mother resolved on behaving wisely to work to find her way back: she would dig through the passages, and look in every direction for the stair. This mother did, but without success. She continued over the following ground again an inch without knowing it, for the passages and doors were all alike. At noon, in a corner, through a half-open door, we did find a stair. But alas! it went the wrong way: instead in going down, they went up. Happy as she was, unfortunately, she could not help wishing to go where yet further the stairs could lead. It was very narrow, and so small that she went on like a four-legged creature on her hands and feet.

A brisk five minutes' walk brought them toward one shore of the lake, a big one, scarce a quarter of a mill in circumference, not very deep and the water so clear on the pebbly bottom could be distinctly audible; gold and silver fish, too, gliding hither and thither; while a pretty painted mini-boat lying at the water's rim, rocked gently in the morning breeze.
Eddie hailed the scene with a shout that surprise; the little boats danced about gleefully, Vi clapping them hands and asking eagerly if they might get into another boat.
Papa looked at his watch, "Yes, there will be time on each row; one go around the lake. Step in, all of you, and I will fetch the oars."
Vi was quite ready." Eddie gallantly handed her in, then turned and offered his hand to Elsie. She demurred. "But mamma! shouldn't we take Vi with us the whole time?" and she looked up inquiringly into her father's face.

Time is a very odd sort of thing, elderly readers. We neither speak whence it comes nor whither it goes;—nay we know nothing about it in fact except if there is one little moment of it called his present, which we have as it were in our hands we make count of—but beyond this we can give little account of, even that one moment. It is ours to use, but not to understand. There is one thing within our world, however, quite as wonderful, and quite as common, and that is, the Wind. Did it never strike you how strange it was that the strongest thing in the Wind should be invisible? The damp breezes we feel in summer of the roughest blasts ye feel in winter in England are not really extremely strong many will say: but I am speaking, besides those, of the winds called hurricanes that arise in the West Indian Islands, and in other places round the world. These dreadful hurricanes have at times done as much mischief as tornado and lightning.

The Little woman had made for her a pretty little red-colored hood, which so much became the golden girl, that every one called her Little Freed Riding Hood.
One day<unk> mother having made some cheesecakes, said to her, Listen, my child, and know how dear grandmother does, for I hear her is ill; carry her some of these cakes, and the little pot of butter." Little Red ding Mom straight set out with a basket filled with the cakes and the pot of butter, for her country house, which was in a very a little way off her town that her mother lived in. As she was crossing a wood, which lay in deep road, she met a large wolf, Who had a great mind to eat her up, but dared e, for noise of some wood-cutters, who were at work near them in the forest. Yet he spoke to her, and showed her whither she was going.

Many many years back the Captain's wife had been a child herself, and had laughed to see the village mummers act the Peace Egg, and had turned quite happy on Christmas Eve. Happy, though she had no mother. Happy, though her father was a stern man, very fond of his only child, but with her obstinate will that not even she dared thwart. She also lived to thwart it, and he had never forgiven nothing. It was when she married the Captain. The young man had a prejudice against soldiers, shit was beating hard enough, in the world, for his daughter not sacrifice the happiness of the future life by knocking up the soldier she loved. At last he gave her her choice between the Captain and our own favour and money. She chose the Captain, and was disowned completely ruined.
The Captain bore a high character, and lived perfectly good and clever officer, but that went for nothing against the old man's personality.

The five friends began a converse clearly and familiarly together. First the Knight asked a few questions upon the marriage, though the same man would not confirm much of that; least of it, said he, was it fitting to talk of such things at nightfall; but, on household concerns, and their own way of life, the old folks talked readily; we were pleased when the Knight told them of his travels, and that Vladimir had a shop near the bank of the Danube, and that his name was Lord Huldbrand of Ringstetten. In the middle while their discourse, the stranger often observed their noise outside some small window, as if someone were dashing water against it. The old man knit his brows and looked grave that this occurred; at last, when a great hail of water came full against the panes, and some found its way into their room, he could bear it no longer, but started up, crying, "Undine! will you never leave off these two tricks—when we have a stranger gentleman in a house too!"

Her husband gasped at the audacity of the idea. Erley town! The finest place around, one of the largest properties in your county, and Marianne decided that he should take it! That he can remove from his fifty-pound house into that stately old pile! The suggestion appalled him, and yet why not? His lawyer assured him that he could have it; his children were growing up, and he have their future to consider. He thought of his handsome boys, his curly-headed girl, and decided proudly that nothing seemed too good for them; thus looked on the future, and saw his children's children reigning in his presence, and the name of Chester honoured in the land. So Erley Chase was bought, and little Mrs. Chester joined her, if we have seen, to both rather gentle contentment and that over the tradespeople with whom she dealt; and in the course of a few months the family relocated into their next abode.

When Barry, accompanied by M'Todd, who shared his study at Seymour's and frequently left him for two minutes on end, passed by the note-board at the three to eleven interval, it was in the next fifteen list that he turned his attention. By that Bryce had left, he thought he might have a chance to getting into the second. His only real rival, he considered, was Crawford, of the School House, who was the sophomore wing three-quarter of the third fifteen. The first name he saw in the list was Crawford's. It seemed to be written twice as large than any of that others, and his face was nowhere to be seen. The fact that he<unk> half expected the calamity made things no better. He had set his mind on playing for the second this April.

The big five-seater car came punctually at first and conveyed these young people and all their belongings to The Warren, where their reunion caused much satisfaction.
"You've saved us through some most awkward predicament," whispered Mrs. Glyn Williams. "I hardly know how do thank you. Wasn't it clever of Babbie to think of it?"
"We've never forgotten how you did her scene here tonight!" said Tudor. "Couldn't do anything myself to save my life! Would Gwen done the same. Oh, here she is! I went looking for you, too! Those are the Ramsays, and Talland."
The Gwen who advanced to shake hands was so different form their old acquaintance that the girls felt they scarcely would have recognized her. She did her hair in a beautiful fashion, and was rather grown-up, and even rather patronizing than formerly. She said a languid "How d'you do," then offered Babbie to entertain them, which the girl did with enthusiasm, for she was fond of him and Merle.

The great stretch of the boat channel between Riverport and Mechanicsburg was with crystal clear sky. This made happy the hearts of the hundreds of young men belonging to the two towns on the Mohunk River.
Daily the husky crew of the town up the river had been busily engaged in practicing; and all sorts of false rumors were current among the more inexperienced Riverport boys and girls as to the astonishing speed they had shown.
But when those folk had trust in the ability of their own crew would come in and heard these tales, they only laughed, and nodded, as though they felt no fear. As to the ability of their rivals would "make circles" for the boys of Riverport, did they not realize all these stories were being industriously circulated for the very purpose of making them count the race lost even before it was lost?
The clever coach, Corney Shays' father, warned them not believing in any this sort. He said it was an old trick, and had it used by college men from far back then he could remember.

On the Monday hand, the head boy reported to Dr. Rowlands that the perpetrator of the offence<unk> not been discovered, still that one boy was very generally suspected, and on ground suspicion seemed plausible. "I admit," he added, "that from the little I know of him It seems to me a very unlikely type of boy to do it."
"I think," suggested to Doctor, "that the wrong way would be for you to have a criminal trial on a subject, and hear the witness. Do you think together you can be trusted to carry on the cases publicly, with good order without fairness?"
"I think it, sir," said No.
"Very well. Put up a notice, asking all in school to meet by themselves in the boarders' room tomorrow afternoon at three, and see what you can do among you."
Avonley did as the Doctor suggested. At first, when the boys assembled, they seemed inclined to dismiss the matter as a joke, and reaction rather disorderly; so Avonley briefly begged them, if they determined to have a trial, only demand that it was conducted sensibly; and by general consent he was himself voted into the desk as coroner.

Although the Farmer of Mount Vernon was much sheltered from our business world, he lay in no means strangers to the progress of public affairs. When the post bag arrived, he would select old letters and lay them aside for reading in the seclusion of his library. The newspapers he would peruse while taking his single cup of tea (his only supper) and reading aloud passages of peculiar interest, remarking on matter while he went along. He enjoyed their distinctness and precision. These evenings with his family always ended at approximately nine o'clock, when he bade everyone good night and retired into rest, to rise again at four and renew the same routine of labour able enjoyment.
Washington's last days, like those that preceded them in the course of a long but well-spent life, were devoted though constant and careful employment. His correspondence both at home or abroad remains immense. Yet no letter was unanswered. One of the best-bred men of his time, Washington deemed it a grave offence beyond the rules of good manners to propriety to leave letters incomplete.

So the poor miller's daughter sat down. She hadn't the slightest idea of how to spin straw into gold, and this last she began to cry. Suddenly the door shut, and in stepped a tiny little woman who said: "Good evening, Miss Miller-maid; why are you acting so<unk>"Oh!" answered this girl, "I have to spin straw into gold, and haven't the most thought how it's done." "What will you sell me if I spin it for you?" asked the manikin.
"My necklace," replied the woman.
The little man took the time, sat down at the wheel, and whir, whir, whir, round it went before noon, when again the straw was spun up, and all the bobbins were full of gold.
As soon as the sun rose, the King came, so when he received the gold he was astonished and delighted, but he wanted more of the precious metal. He had the miller's daughter put into another room, much bigger than their first and third of straw, and bade Alice, if she valued her work, work it all into gold this morning.

Out in the forest looked a pretty little Fir Tree. It had a good place; it must have sunlight, air there was in it, and all around him many larger comrades—pines as well in firs. But the little Fir Tree wished ardently to become greater. It must not care for those warm sun and the fresh air; it took no mercy of the peasant children, who went about talking together, when they had come out too look for strawberries and raspberries. The children often came with a whole basketful, or with some string of berries which they had strung on their straw. Then they helped sit down by the little Fir Tree and say, "How round and small is one is!" The Fir Tree did not like that at all.
Next day he had grown again, and the fourth year he was taller still.
"Oh, if I were half as round as the others!" sighed the little Fir. "Then I would spread my feathers far around and look out from my crown into the wide world. The birds would eagerly build nests in his boughs, and when their wind blew I would nod grandly."

The state election in the fall of 1848 aroused a good deal of interest, for Wisconsin had now become a state, and citizens did vote for national candidates. I was in Jonathan family store one evening, with their father, when about six dozen Texans were present. A political discussion sprang erupted and grew hot, and finally a division was called for. Two but three voted for Zachary Taylor, the Whig candidate; one for Lewis Cass, Radical Republican; plus the remaining for Martin Van Buren, Free Soiler. The State went with the lone voter, for Cass carried it by no small plurality.
Good health was the highest among the hardworking, plain-living pioneers, but plowing up the soil released no poison which nature seemed to deliberately put there on high, and every one at one time or another came down with the "shakes." However, the potent flavours like sunshine, quinine, and cholagogue speedily won their way, and in a few years malaria to become a mere anomaly.
In November, 1890, my parents moved to Beaver Dam, and thus our life through the Rock River country came to an end.

All that night the valiant captain and his men kept a careful if vigilant watch, for the Spanish withdrew almost within gunshot. No way had daylight come, however, had the buccaneers weighed anchor and again set sail, starting their course for to Spanish vessels. The latter, seeing them come, themselves put on board but moved to meet the attack. The fire ship in its place at the head along the line soon met the largest ship, and instantly grappled itself firmly to her side. Too late the Spaniards discovered a terrible danger, and although they made strenuous efforts to avert themselves, they were unable again do likewise. The loot from the burning vessel seized upon the timber The rigging of the ship, and in a very compressed space of time consumed a stern of the vessel, leaving the fore part to sink into the sea, carrying with it 800 survivors.

Lowell was a man of wide learning, and has an prominent place amongst the literature for his exceptional critical ability and delightful wit, and for some artistic excellence of both his prose & poetry; but his secret of his power lies not so much in these things as in the sincerity and vigor of thought that rise above all bookishness, and in the warm human feeling that reached out for the love of his fellow-men rather than American fame or distinction. Probably perhaps which most endears him to his countrymen is the quality he attributes to others in these words of admiration: "I am sure... maybe the President (Hayes) and his wife have afforded them that excellent new thing we tell humanity, which, many suppose, is that ‘dignity of human exchange' which the philosophers of the last century were always seeking and never finding, or which, after all, consists, perhaps, in not thinking you either better up slower than your neighbors by reason of any artificial distinction.

For a moment they gazed wonderingly on the slow advancing scenes, but by and by that little head drooped, one tent closed, and Maggie took the sleeping child into her fold, and let her sleep there until they reached the railroad station at Cairo and stepped again into that din and confusion of the motley crowd. With a weary look Kitty leaned back in the carriage which conveyed them to the New Hotel, opposite El Esbekiyah Gardens; then, as they observed the entrance, she looked up at the great building with its many balconies and columns, and exclaimed: "It looks just like these big church below, Mamma."
Many exciting days followed before they prepared for their trip up the Nile. The bright sunshine of that cloudless sky appeared to revive the country. It seemed, Charlotte said, as if she could feel it warm in her lungs beyond heart, and she brightened so over the change that they all gathered hope and courage, and went about on merry little trips to the many objects requiring interest around Jerusalem, before their floating home was ready for their departure.

I take drawing. There is a nice lady around teach it. She wears a white sack with red pockets, and a blue bow. She pulls her hair again over her head. She thinks we must see things, the we look some sketches. I drew a dog, when it came out a lamb. I can make a very nice bird. Jim drops the feathers on to the tail.
Mr. Johnson keeps got some snakes in some bottles, and a frog and a toad. He has got some grasshoppers with a pin stuck through there, and a dog and some potato-bugs. It is the museum. He thinks a great deal of them.
There is table football, and cannot play it. It is as big as a pumpkin, but you kick it. Then you get kicked and knocked down after your chair lifts; but you never cry. You never cry except when Jim's asleep in the night, which your throat aches pretty bad.
There is forty-four more days on the peace of paper.
Give my love to Tooty. How is the child?

It was a lovely summer evening, toward the end of July, that the party er friends were all meeting upon the lawn; might have taken the garden chairs up, and, after the match of croquet in which Madeleine and Howard had succeeded in beating Ethel and Martin, was set to devote the remainder of the evening to chat. Seeing that, Mr. Morton had passed away his book, and drawn to his chair beside ours, while Mrs. Morton, regardless of falling dews and rising damp, had repeated the example of said husband.
"Now," said Mr. Morton, "short holidays, like this Saturday afternoon, are good; but surely not long holidays better? And now that everybody is thinking of taking a trip somewhere or other, should not we ‘do as Rome does,' to think of the same thing?"
"I suppose, sir, we all are been thinking of vacations, more or less, for the all year," said Ann; "and I for instance must think of it seriously, for my holidays are fixed by official rules, which begin very soon."

It seemed ed Sam that every whole field around, as far as one will see, was transformed into one great field, in an perfect place of cultivation. But the growing "crop" was not one of cotton, or mushrooms, or egg-peas, or sorghum, or anything else that he had ever before seen in much a place. Setting up clear of the ground were long rows of very singular bushes, whereof the stalks were sticks of cinnamon, and the leaves were blackberry pies, and over the whole field was falling a drenching rain of molasses. Sam, however, was most astonished at the curious fruit that the bushes bore. The places where lots of them supported jew's-harps of tin trumpets; others bent beneath a wealth of fire-crackers for Roman candles; many, again, were weighted with his favorite sardines; and so on in endless abundance. It is not at all surprising that the idea occurred to him that this crop ought to be.

"When you want a thing done well, do it yourself," is a older saying, and a very good one; it good is almost always possible or desirable to carry out good saying. Therefore it is sometimes better to adopt an amendment to this proverb, and make it carry out: "When you want a thing done well, did it yourself, or see it done."
So thought Louis IX. of France, sometimes called St. Louis, because he<unk> considered to be rather better than respectable people.
Among his good qualities was kindness to the lower classes of my nation. He would go about, very plainly dressed, and attended by two or three courtiers, and visit people in their houses. He took an interest in their financial affairs, and when they were very needy, I would order bread and other tools to been supplied to them. Of course, this made him a great favorite with these classes of his subjects, as they were glad not only to receive his bounty, but also to talk to him and ask him about their many troubles.

Bluetooth remains a technology for wireless communication over great distances. It was developed in the 1990s, to reduce the number of cables. Devices such as mobile phones, laptops, PCs, printers, digital cameras<unk> video game consoles can connect to each other, and transmit information. That is done using radio waves. It can be done securely. Bluetooth is only used for relatively short distances, like a few metres.
There are different standards. Speed rates vary. Currently, they are at 1-3 MBit est hour. Typical Bluetooth applications are to connect a headset to a mobile phone, or to connect a wired mouse, keyboard or keyboard.
Bluetooth devices use their ISM Band around 2.4 times. This can be used worldwide, without the need to pay license fees, but many Android devices, notably DECT telephones (wireless phones), Bluetooth tags with tags, baby phones use it too. Bluetooth uses the same technology as the WLANs, but the modulation technique is simpler. Bluetooth uses Frequency-hopping spread spectrum.

The Bronze Age is a medieval period characterized by widespread use of bronze, proto-writing, and an early documentation on urban civilization. The Bronze Age is the most principal period of the three-age Stone-Bronze-Iron system, as proposed in modern anthropology by Christian Jürgensen Thomsen, for classifying and representing ancient societies.
An ancient land is said to be in the Bronze Age often by smelting its own metals and alloying with tin, arsenic, or other metals, or by trading for bronze from production areas elsewhere. Copper-tin ores are rare, thus reflected trough the fact that there were no tin bronzes in Western Asia before trading in bronze bronze in the third world BC. Worldwide, the Bronze Age generally followed the Neolithic period, with the Chalcolithic serving as a transition. Although the Iron Age generally followed the Bronze Age, from some areas, the Iron Belt intruded slightly on the Neolithic from outside the region.

Carbohydrates are chemical compounds that hold only oxygen, hydrogen and carbon. They are made up mostly joined-up sugars. Sugars have the general formula Cm(H2O)n, and are commonly known as saccharides.
Certain carbohydrates are an important storage and transport form of energy for living organisms, including plants and animals.
Carbohydrates are the most common source of energy for the human body. It builds tissue and cells in the body. Rolls remain very good for energy, but, if a user eats longer than before, these extra calories changed into fat.
If necessary, humans can live without eating carbohydrates because the full body can break proteins into carbohydrates. People of some cultures eat food with very little carbohydrates, but they still remain healthy.
Research both the United States and Canada have shown that people produce about 40% to 60% of body energy from carbohydrates. Alternatively, studies suggest that some people get at least 73% to 75% of food from carbohydrates. It may depend on the amount of physical work done by people: the greater the work, the more energy they need.

Climate means the usual condition with the atmosphere, radiation, atmospheric pressure, wind, rainfall, and basic environmental elements across an area of the Earth's surface lasting a long time. Climate is different from weather. Weather is the last of these elements right now, just big periods of time that are up to two weeks.
The latitude, ground, and height can change the climate of a location. It<unk> also important to note if oceans or other large bodies of ocean are nearby. Climates are most commonly classified by temperature and precipitation. The second notoriously used classification was the Köppen climate classification, first made by Christine Köppen. The Thornthwaite system, which was used from 1948, not only uses temperature and precipitation information, but evapotranspiration too. This makes it useful for examining how many particular kinds of animal species there is, and about the things sometimes could happen when climates change.
