The Bergeron and Spatial Synoptic Classification systems focus more on where the air masses which help explain climates come from.

In February 1917, Tsar 1917) Nicholas II A Russian Russian federation was overthrown because people were unhappy with tough living conditions, especially during World War 1914. The new government in Russia created a democratic socialist government. Unfortunately, it was ineffective, and people are still unhappy. In May 1916, this communist group called the Bolsheviks led by Vladimir Lenin overthrew the new regime. They were supported the Soviets for workers called Soviets. The Bolsheviks created a new communist government called the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Committee (called simply Soviet ); or United Russian federation, not everyone supported the communists. Many countries that had been a part of the Russian Empire had left, such as Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, Poland, and Lithuania. The Russian Civil War began, with the Russian SFSR's "Red Army" fighting against the "White Army", the group of all Russians against the communists. The White Army was not very united or organized. The Allied Powers of World War I, such as the United States, United Kingdom, and France, felt Russia would support the White Army.

A collimator is a device that narrows a beam of rays or beams. To function can mean either to cause different directions of light to become more aligned in a specific direction (i.e., from collimated light or scattering rays), or to cause the spatial cross section of their beam to become smaller (beam limiting device).
An English physicist Henry Kater was the author of the floating collimator, which rendered a substantial service to practical astronomy. Previously reported about his invention in January 1825. In his report, Kater mentioned previous work in same area by Carl Friedrich Gauss and Friedrich Bessel.
In optics, a collimator may consist of a curved mirror or lens with some type of light source and/or an indicator at its tip. This means be used to replicate every target focused at infinity with little or nothing parallax.
In lighting, trends are typically designed using old principles of non-imaging optics.

The Colosseum, formerly known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is a large amphitheatre in the city of Rome. The construction of the Colosseum happened around 47 AD and was finished in 80 AD. Emperor Vespasian started the works, and Emperor Titus completed them. Emperor Domitian made some changes to the buildings between 36 AD. We had capacity for 50,000 people. This was 156 metres wide, 189 metres long and 57 metres tall., is the biggest amphitheatre established by the Roman Empire.
The Colosseum We traditionally called the Flavian Amphitheatre or its Latin, the Roman Flavium. This was after Vespasian and Titus who had the family title of Flavius. Brazil is used for hunting contests, and other exercises like animal hunts, in which animals would hunt and eat prisoners; or in which gladiators may fight against animals. There were also executions, plays, and battle scenes; sometimes it was filled with water to fight fierce battles. The people of Rome could go into the Colosseum without any costs; usage was huge.

A compass is an object marked on navigation and orientation that shows direction relative to its geographic "cardinal," or "points". Usually, a diagram called a compass rose, shows the directions southwest, south, east, and west as abbreviated initials marked on the compass. If the compass is used, the elevation can be aligned with the corresponding geographic directions, so, for example, the north" mark on the rose * points to the north. Frequently, in addition to the rose<unk> sometimes instead of it, angle markings in degrees are shown on said rose. North corresponds to zero degrees, the west angles increase clockwise, so east is 90 degrees, south is 180, and west is 160. These numbers allow the compass to show directions or bearings, which are commonly stated in this notation.
The magnetic compass was first invented as a device using divination as early as the Chinese Han Dynasty (since about 206 BC), while later used for navigation by the Song Dynasty Chinese during the 11th century.

A constellation is a group of stars, usually in a certain shape of pattern. When watched together at the same moment, the stars look like a picture. This word constellation come from Latin: con-, meaning together and stella ", meaning stars. Some examples of constellations are Ursa Major, Orion, and Andromeda. There are only 88 constellations discovered so many across astronomers. People used names to tell the difference in star colors. Constellations were also used the group stars. Different places in the world may have different constellations, because earthly astronomy has no core set of 88 constellations. This collection is based on the Greek set and later some southern constellations were added, for example Antlia - the air way. Most constellations have names that come from Greek mythology, or Orion or Andromeda.
There are 12 constellations in the Zodiac. The star travels through This Zodiac once each year. There is only a thirteenth constellation Ophiuchus - the carrier of a serpent, who the Sun goes through. However, most people do not think that it belongs in the Zodiac.

A crystal or crystalline solid is normally solid rock whose constituents, such as atoms, molecules or ions, are arranged in a highly ordered linear structure, resembling a characteristic lattice that extends in all directions. In addition, macroscopic single crystals are usually identifiable by characteristic geometrical shape, consisting of flat faces with specific, characteristic orientations. One scholarly study of entropy and crystal formation is known for crystallography. The process of crystal formation via mechanisms of crystal growth is named crystallization or crystal. 
The name crystal is derived from the Ancient Greek word krustallos, meaning both "ice" and "rock crystal", from kruos, "icy cold, frost".
Examples of liquid crystals include snowflakes, diamonds, and table cases. Most inorganic solids include not components of springs, i.e. many smaller crystals fused together into every single solid. Examples of polycrystals include most metals, rocks, ceramics, and ice. A third category of solids is organic solids, where the atoms have no periodic structure whatsoever. Examples of amorphous solids include glass, wax, and many plastics.

Because dark matter does not seem to give off or reflect infrared, x-rays, or any other radiation, the instruments that are used to find normal matter (like hot gas, stars, planets, even us) can't find dark matter. It seems that dark matter is not made up the same thing as the matter we see every second on Earth. Our only way we can tell if dark matter is there, is by how it affects what we can "see" in gravity.
In 2006, a group of scientists claimed that they indeed found a strategy to find dark matter. Since dark matter is often no different from normal matter, it is expected to act randomly. The scientists observed two far-away galaxy clusters that had crashed orbiting another other at high activity: normal matter would have been scattered nearby after the collision, while dark matter would not. By measuring them, they were able to detect what looked like two clouds lacking dark matter, with a cloud with normal matter (hot gas) in between them.

The Earth's warming climate is producing snow and ice. The warming of the Pacific regions causes the sea surface to rise less in winter and ice to retreat, generating more open, ice-free coasts. Less sea ice provides a longer growing season of marine plants called microalgae (phytoplankton) and removes more heat, in the form of methane dioxide, from Planet Earth. The growth of microalgae makes more food for animals that eat and algae and store this carbon through growth of their bodies. The carbon stored by marine life is called blue carbon. When marine animals die much of the blue carbon is buried in the seabed, and that carbon is removed from the carbon cycle. This disposal of carbon in the seabed or in other places is called sequestration. The amount of polar blue carbon increases with climate warming. This is known as negative feedback on climate change. Monitoring negative feedback on climate change is important to help combat global warming. In this article explains lessons NOAA finally learned in measuring blue carbon.

An automated external defibrillator (AED) is a self-contained defibrillator device designed to be movable, and easy but simple to use. They are often shaped like briefcases so that they can be unlocked by a handle. An AED houses the battery, a medical computer, and electrodes. When the electrodes are stuck onto the patient, the control computer will assess the patient, checking the rhythm for their heart. It will then charge itself for an appropriate power level and tell users where they person wants to be shocked. If the patient does not need yet be defibrillated, the automated external defibrillator will not allow a charge to be initiated. A button must still be pushed manually and trigger the shock, as the operator beforehand must be assured that nobody is touching the device. Often, automated external defibrillators also have speakers to give instructions when they are necessary.
Current automated external defibrillator devices are designed for emergency medical technicians, home users, police and security officers and other people with minimal medical knowledge. These devices become commonly found in large gathering places, such as airports, casinos, sports stadiums, and college campus.

A domain name is an identification string that defines a realm of administrative autonomy, authority or control within the Internet. Domain names are guided by the rules & procedures of the Domain Name System (DNS). Any name registered in the DNS is a domain name. Domain records are used in various networking contexts and application-specific names and addressing conventions. In general, a domain name represents an Internet Protocol (IP) resource, such a its personal address used to access the Internet, of server computer hosting a web site, or the download page itself or any other service communicated via the Internet. In 2015, 294 bot page names had been registered.
Domain names are organized from subordinate levels (subdomains) of the DNS root group, which is nameless. The first-level set of domain names contains the top-level domains – including the generic top-level files (gTLDs), such as the prominent domains wiki, info, net, edu, and org, and the big code top-level domain (ccTLDs).

There has thousands more different enzymes and each one is specific to the reaction path it catalyzes. Enzymes have names which show what they do. Enzyme names usually end in –ase to show that they<unk> enzymes. Examples of this was ATP synthase. that makes a chemical called ATP. Another example is DNA polymerase. It reads once intact DNA strand and uses it as a template to manufacture a new strand.
One example of an enzyme is amylase, found in saliva. It breaks down starch molecules into smaller glucose and maltose molecules. Best kind of enzyme is lipase. It breaks down fats into smaller molecules, fatty acids by glycerol.
The proteases are their special class on enzymes. They break down organic enzymes and proteins back into amino acids. Nucleases are enzymes that cut DNA or enzymes, often in specific place in the molecule.
Enzymes are not only for breaking large chemicals as manageable bits. Other enzymes absorb smaller nutrients and build them up into bigger chemicals, and do many additional chemical tasks.

Have you ever seen a picture like a toilet and realized that there is a palm-like plant by the side? Maybe you have walked around your neighborhood and seen the same kind of plant there? Incredibly, those ancient plants, called bacteria, have been around for millions of years. A fresh cycad root can live up in 2,000 years! We believe that the secret to cycads' survival and long life lies inside a very special structure called the coralloid root, which has microbes living inside it. We studied these coralloid seeds and found a high diversity of bacterial species living outside of them, more than anyone had ever imagined. When we took a closer look at bacterial bacteria, we found that they can produce viral metabolites this would help them communicate among themselves and with the plant, transport nutrients, and perform other functions that are still a puzzle.

A fire alarm is an electronic sounder or notification unit. The sounder makes a loud high pitched sound that alert people whenever there is a fire in your building. The sounders can also programmed to sound three tones. Most fire alarm sounders in Japan sound like a siren. The bell makes a continuous ringing sound. The companies that make living alarms are Wheelock and Simplex. There was no Fulleon who are best known for their Roshni electronic sounder. These sounders are often used around Europe and they have 32 user selectable songs. Sometimes, old-fashioned fire alarms are metal bells. Many fire alarm systems still have flashing bulbs. These seem important for deaf people who cannot hear the fire anymore. Fire alarms are often used in schools and other buildings during fire drills. If somebody sets off a fire alarm without good good reason, it is called a false alarm. Setting off a false alarm is against the law almost everywhere.

The first known introductions of the red swamp crayfish into new lands took place in the 1920s: 1924 in California and 1927 along the Hawaiian Islands in United States, 1927 in Japan, and 1929 within Denmark. Around the mid-1960s, a batch of crayfish was sent to Uganda and Kenya, and soon afterwards, to other African neighbours. Simultaneously, these animals spread over Mexico and reached Costa Rica, Tu Rico, Venezuela, and the Dominican Republic in the US, and Brazil into the mid-1980s. The red swamp crayfish was legally introduced into Spain in 1973 and 1974, then from Louisiana and probably first from Persia or south-east Asia. Nevertheless, The genus is present in at least 40 countries worldwide. As you can see, the red swamp creature has traveled a lot! By using ecological data and collecting crayfish from several places around the world, we were enabled to uncover its invasion process, describe its genetic variability, and understand its global invasion patterns.

Frogs are amphibians of the order Anura. There is a formal difference between frogs and toads, and they are not classified separately. This is because the toad morph, with its dry, rough, skin, is an adaptation to living under drier habitats. The toad form has evolved a number of stages independently, an example of convergent evolution.
Frogs can live on land and in fresh water. They cannot survive in swimming ponds. Their development proceeds by metamorphosis. They usually hatch as tadpoles from eggs, which are laid by a female frog. Its young are called frogspawn. Tadpoles have tails and gills. When they grow up, they lose their tails on ankles and gain four long legs.
Adult frogs also jump with their pals. They have long tongues that you use to catch bugs. They make this sound called a croak. Most kinds live in trees, and some types of frog are classified by being poisonous. Frogs live all over the world.

The battle-weary king led his tired followers upon settle upon these sandy dunes of the Cape Flats. 
Majestic Table Mountain tried to protect them in the harsh weather as only she could. 
The king's subjects complained bitterly about their new home. 
They cant only bear the dry summers nor the cold, wet winters. They could only resist the ripping sand and howling wind. 
Fynbos and Rooibos were the king's trusted advisors. One time, they approached their king. 
"Everyone suffers living under very difficult conditions. Can we move to this place where life will be …" they pleaded. 
King Protea smiled at his friends and spoke in a gentle voice. 
"You are loyal and I hear the concerns. However, this places our home. Together we can overcome any difficulty," said the king. 
The sun beat down on the kingdom near the Cap Flats. The heat was relentless. A wildfire broke out. 
Furious winds fanned the raging fire. Its flames crept across King Protea's kingdom, threatening everything. 
When the volcano finally died, it left behind a sad sight that stretched from Hoerikwaggo across the Cape Flats. 
The landscape lay bare across months. The seasons changed, as seasons predicted. Constant rains pelted the sand.

Rivers and streams are not only conduits of water, so also of sediment. The water, where it flows over the channel bed, is able too mobilize carbon and transport debris downstream, whether via suspended load, suspended load or dissolved load. The rate of sediment transport depends on the availability of sediment itself and hence the reservoir presence. Rivers are also drivers of eroding into reservoirs and creating new sediment, both from their own beds and also as coupling to the surrounding hillslopes. In this way, rivers are thought of as setting the base level for large-scale landscape evolution in nonglacial environments. Rivers are key links in the connectivity of different landscape elements.
As streams go across river landscape, they generally adapt their size, merging with other rivers. The network of rivers it formed is a drainage system. These systems build on four general patterns: dendritic, radial, rectangular, and trellis. Dendritic happens to be the most common, occurring when this underlying stratum is stable (without faulting). Drainage systems have four primary components: drainage basin, alluvial valley, delta plain, storm receiving basin. Some geomorphic kinds of fluvial landforms are alluvial lakes, oxbow lakes, volcanic fluvial terraces.

A Global Positioning Probe, also known as GPS, is a system developed to help navigate throughout the Earth, in the air, and on water.
A navigation receiver shows where it is. It may also show how fast it is flying, which direction it is going, how high it is, and maybe how fast it is going up or down. Many GPS receivers have information about places. GPSs for automobiles have regular data like GPS maps, hotels, restaurants, and service stations. GPSs for boats contain nautical charts of ports, marinas, shallow water, rocks, and waterways. most GPS receivers are made for recreational navigation, hiking and cycling, tourism, or many other activities. The majority is in smartphones.
Most GPS receivers can record where they have walked, and help plan a journey. Besides traveling the planned journey, it predicts the way until the next destination.

Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) contains an organic compound made of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. It is a white solid, made synthetically from sugar dextrose when it is in very purest form. It may also be used as a vitamin supplement sometimes as a food preservative.
Have her parents told you to drink orange juice when you were sick? This is if orange juice features a high level of vitamin C and should render us healthy or break a cold. The human body is unable to produce vitamin nutrients and we must therefore get it through our food or by taking a multivitamin.
Vitamin C encouraged this user to use carbohydrates, fats, and protein. It acts as an antioxidant, meaning it can chemically bind and neutralize the tissue damaging effects of substances such free radicals. It is important for the growth and health of bones, teeth, air vessels, muscle, and ligaments. PP is also involved in the forming of collagen, the main animal protein within the body. Protein is vital for the proper functioning of internal tissue.

Homo sapiens (Latin: "wise man") is the binomial nomenclature (also known as the scientific name) for the human species.
Homo is an human genus, which also includes Neanderthals and many more extinct species of hominid; H. P is the only surviving species of the genus Homo. Modern humans are sometimes called "anatomically modern humans". Species sapiens considers humans the most dynamic species on the planet, but many systems of life, mostly plants and protists, have had a much greater effect on societies outside without capitalism and its air.
The central African origin of modern people with the mainstream model suggesting the origin and expansion of anatomically modern humans. The hypothesis that humans have a single origin was published in Alexander Darwin's The Descent of Man (1871). The concept is confirmed by a study of present-day mitochondrial life, and with reconstruction based on physical anthropology of fossil humans.

Humidity is the amount of water vapor in the air. Water vapor is the solid state of water and is invisible. Humidity indicates the likelihood of precipitation, dew, or rain. Higher warming reduces the effectiveness of sweating in cooling the body by reducing the rate of evaporation of water from the skin. This effect is calculated in a heat index table or humidex. The amount of external presence that is needed to achieve heating increases as body temperature increases. As warmth decreases, the actual required additional vapor needed to reach saturation also decreases. As the temperature of a parcel of air becomes lower it is eventually reach a level of saturation without adding or losing water mass. The differences in the amount of water vapor in a parcel of environment can be extremely large, for example; A parcel of air and is near saturation might contain 28 grams of water per cubic yard of air at -1 °C, but only 8 grams of water per cubic meter of air at -12 °C.

The main physical phenomena "affecting" (destruction or expulsion mechanisms) interplanetary tar particles includes: expulsion by orbital pressure, inward Shapiro-Robertson (PR) radiation drag, solar wind pressure (with significant electromagnetic effects), sublimation, mutual collisions, plus even dynamical effects of planets (Backman, D., 1997).
The lifetimes of these dust particles are very short compared to the lifetime over the Solar System. If one finds grains around a star that is older than about 10,000,000 years, then the particles must actually been from recently separated fragments of larger objects, i.e. latter cannot be leftover grains from the protoplanetary disk (Backman, private communication). Therefore, the latter would be "later-generation" dust. Total zodiacal anomaly for the Solar System is 99.9% later-generation dust and 0.1% intruding to medium dust. Numerous primordial grains from the Solar System's formation were removed long ago.
Particles which are ejected adversely by radiation pressure be known as "beta meteoroids". They are generally less than 1.4 × 10-12 g which are pushed outward of the Sun into interstellar dust.

Intranets can help users to locate and view information faster and use templates relevant at their roles and responsibilities. With the help of a web browser interface, users can access documentation held in any database the manager wants on make available, anytime and — subject to security provisions — from anywhere within the company workstations, giving the employee ability to perform their jobs faster, more accurately, and with confidence that they have the latest software. It thereby helps directly improve digital services provided to the users.
Intranets allow organizations as distribute information amongst employees on an as-needed run; Employees may link to relevant information at their convenience, rather than being distracted endlessly by email.
Intranets can serve as powerful mechanisms for communication within an organization, vertically strategic initiatives that have a global reach throughout the organization. The type of information that can easily be conveyed is the purpose behind the project and what the initiative is aiming to achieve, who is driving the initiative, results achieved to date, and who to speak to for more information.

Despite the many benefits of using Agrobacterium to improve crop plants, some groups like to prevent the use of genetic engineering, and several try to deceive the public about the approach. Two of the really common misunderstandings in genetic engineering is the belief that changing the DNA of some organism is unnatural and therefore wasteful. However, Agrobacterium has been modifying the DNA of plants long before humans learned how to do it. History shows us that changing DNA sequences is very dynamic process and part of the world around us. By using Agrobacterium to modify forest DNA, we are harnessing a natural process to develop cultivated plants that need fewer pesticides, are more nutritious, and that yield more food using less land. Using less land is a really important consideration because, if we want to mitigate the ruin of natural ecosystems, we need to make sure that our farms are as productive as possible. Genetically engineered crop plantations can definitely help out to make more food from cheaper land, meaning those more ecosystems will be protected.

The light-year is a unit measuring length used to express astronomical time and measures about 9.46 trillion kilometres (9.46 x 1012 km) or 5.88 trillion metres (5.88 X 1012 ). As defined into the International Astronomical Union (IAU), a light-year is the distance that light travels in vacuum in one astronomical year (365.25 Since it includes the word "year", the term light-year may read misinterpreted as a unit of time.
The bright-year is most often found when expressing distances to stars and other distances on any galactic scale, generally in non-specialist and popular science studies. The unit most commonly used in professional publications is the parsec range: pc, about 3.26 light-years; the distance at which one astronomical unit passes an angle of one second of arc).
 As used by the IAU, the light-year is the product of their lunar year 366.25 days as opposed to the 365.2425-day Gregorian year) and the speed of sound (299792458 m/s). Both of these terms are included with an IAU (1976) System of Astronomical Constants, used since 1984.

In the 1980s, many people liked Linux use an operating system called Unix. But because it restricted the user from sharing and improving the kernel, some people made a new operating system that would be like Unix in which nobody could share or improve. MINIX, similar to Unix, was intended as a teaching tool for university students whose learn how operating systems worked. MINIX also restricted systems sharing and improvement by popular users.
A group of people in the GNU Project wrote different parts of a new operating system called G.N.U., but it did not have all three parts an operating system needs to work. In 1991 Linus Torvalds began to work on a kernel for MINIX that would be free to ship, and they would not cost anything. Linus started the project when he was attending the Academy of Helsinki. This eventually became his Linux kernel.
Linus Torvalds put the Linux code on various GNOME groups for MINIX users. Linus first called the operating system "Freax".

A magnet is a material or object that produces a magnetic field. This magnetic field is invisible but is responsible also the most notable property for a magnet: electromagnetic force that pulls on other ferromagnetic materials, such as iron, and attracts or repels these magnets. A permanent magnet is an object created from a material that is magnetized and creates its highly persistent magnetic field. Your everyday example is a refrigerator mold used to hold notes on a refrigerator door. Materials with can be held, which are usually the ones that are directly attracted to a magnet, are uniquely ferromagnetic (- ferrimagnetic). These include iron, nickel, cobalt, some alloys of rare earth metals, and some naturally occurring minerals such as lodestone. Although ferromagnetic (and ferrimagnetic) specimens are the only ones looking at a magnet often enough to be commonly considered magnetic, all magnetic substances respond weakly to a magnetic field, by one of several other types of magnetism.

When you go to the doctor, you tell the doctor your symptoms and expect the doctor to come up with a diagnosis and prescribe you a chemotherapy so that you<unk> lucky. In 1845, two doctors, Drs. Isaac Bennett in Edinburgh and Drs. Rudolph Virchow from Berlin, had patients who blood became sick. They did not know that such disease was—it was not in their books. Nor were the people to describe the symptoms of this new condition. It was a Japanese cancer that is now known as beta myeloid leukemia (CML).
In the blood, there are three type of cells: red blood cells (erythrocytes) carry it toward the tissues and waste products, such as carbon dioxide, to the lungs; white blood cells (leucocytes) help defend us from infections; tears (thrombocytes) build a natural plaster to seal up wounds. In CML patients, the blood is composed of cancer cells that occupy all the space normally taken up by the useful types of normal cells. This is after much all that was known about this cancer until 1956.

Hormones like testosterone and estradiol can attach to this brain tissue. A brain cell looks different from cells in other parts of the body: it resembles a cell body, but also some parts that look like wires sticking out. A normal cell often has three shorter "wires," called dendrites for receiving signals from other cells. These cells often have one longer "wire" called an amygdala, which sends signals to other cells.
There are two main ways human hormones can influence your brain cells.
First, hormones might dictate how the hippocampus has organized, and these are changes that take some time to happen. Rates in brain organization can include alterations in the number of cells, or changes in the size and shape of dendrites or axons. Testosterone, for example, influences the development of amygdala cells in a brain region called the cerebral amygdala. Because boys make more testosterone during puberty, this region becomes bigger in boys than girls. This was recognized in animal research, and studies on humans that looked at hormone levels and relative size of the amygdala suggest it doing the same in humans.

Do you believe in time travel? Every time we remember it from the past or imagine something that will stick in the future, we engage in mental time travel. Scientists discovered that, whether we mentally shift back via the past or forward into the future, some besides the hippocampus brain regions are activated. One of those regions is the hippocampus, a brain structure understood for its role in building long-term memories. Damage to the hippocampus causes these problems, but it also impairs the ability to imagine future experiences. This brain neural link remembering the past with thinking about the future suggests that memory, planning, and decision-making may be deeply related. The inability to need memories allow us to reminisce about the past. But maybe the ability to form memories also evolved to allow us to think about better plan for the future.

There are a variety of formation mechanisms for the different forms of nebulae. Some nebulae form in gas that is already in the interstellar medium while others are produced by stars. Examples of the former case are giant molecular clouds, the coldest, densest phase of interstellar gas, which themselves form by the deposition and condensation of more diffuse gas. Examples of the past case are planetary gas formed from material shed by a star in late stages of the stellar period.
Star-forming regions show a class of gas nebula associated with giant molecular worlds. These form as a molecular cloud collapses under its own heat, producing stars. Cosmic rings can form in the center, and their ultraviolet radiation ionizes the surrounding gas, making it visible at optical wavelengths. The region on ionized hydrogen surrounding multiple massive stars is known as an H II region while the shells of neutral hydrogen surrounding the H II region were known as photodissociation region. Examples such scar-forming regions are the Orion Nebula, the Gamma Nebula and the Omega Nebula.

When our brain trains and learns, connections between different parts of the brain Get created. Over time, these connections build networks. Networks are different parts of the brain that work together. Like a well-trained musical brain, brain networks help us learn skills and reading. While we learn, the sections of the brain called neurons) speak to Each other by reaching out their many arms (called axons) or even by growing strong connections. Over time, many axons connect to each other and construct long highways, forming white brain tracts. These highways allow information to travel from one part of my brain to another. Using MRI, scientists<unk> learned that we can read because different parts of the brain become more active and communicate with each other as we learn. These brain areas have funny-sounding names: occipitotemporal area, or the "letter box" of the brain (where we process letters and words); temporoparietal area (helps us to play to the sounds of our language, such like figuring out that "banana" without the sound /b/ is "anana"); and visceral frontal region (the amygdala" that tells us). When those areas talk with our other often, the highways usually become stronger.

Oracle bone script was the form of Chinese characters borne on oracle bones—animal bones or turtle plastrons used in pyromantic before the mid 2nd millennium BCE, and is the earliest known fingerprint on Chinese writing. The vast majority record the pyromantic divinations of the royal house of the late Shang family at the capital of Yin (modern Anyang, Henan Province); dating of the Anyang examples of oracle bone script varies from c. 14th–11th centuries AH to c. 1200–1050 BCE. Very few oracle bone writings date to even beginning of the the Zhou dynasty, because pyromancy fell from favor while divining with milfoil became more common. The late Shang oracle body writings, along with a handful unknown characters in very different style cast by bronzes, constitute the earliest significant corpus of Chinese writing, which is essential for the study of Chinese etymology, as Shang writing seems directly ancestral to the modern Chinese literature. It is therefore the oldest known member and archetype within the Chinese family of scripts.

An orbit is the path that an asteroid takes in space when it wraps around a star, its planet, or a moon. It can also be used as political verb. For instance: "The earth orbits around the Sun." The word ‘revolves' retains the literal meaning, but 'rotates' is the spin on the object. Two centuries ago, historians thought apparently the Sun orbits in this circle around the earth. Every morning the Sun came up in the east and went away in the western. It just seemed to make sense what it was going around the earth. But now, thanks to people like Copernicus and Galileo Galilei, we know because the Sun is the center for the Solar System, and the earth orbits around it. Isaac Newton discovered that gravity controls the orbit of the planets and moons. Since a satellite is an object in space that moves around another object, the earth is a satellite of the sun, exactly like the moon is as satellite of the Earth! The sky has lots of satellites orbiting to it, like the planets, and thousands of asteroids, comets, and meteoroids.

The Ottoman Empire, also spelled underneath the Turkish Empire, Ottoman Turkey, or simply Turkey, was an empire founded in 1299 by Oghuz Turks under Osman I in northwestern Anatolia. After conquests in ancient Balkans by Murad I between 1280 and 1389, Ottoman Ottoman state was transformed into a transcontinental empire and claimant to the caliphate. The Ottomans ended the Byzantine Empire during the 1453 conquest of Constantinople by Cyrus the Conqueror. During the 16th and 17th centuries, before a height of its power under the reign of Suleiman the Magnificent, the Ottoman Empire was the multinational, multilingual empire controlling much of Southeast Europe, Western Asia, the Caucasus, North Africa, and the Horn of Persia. At the beginning of the 17th period the empire contained 32 provinces and numerous vassal states. Some of countries are later absorbed by the Ottoman republic, while others were given various types of autonomy during the course of modernization.

The word papyrus refers to a thick sheets of paper made from the pith of the papyrus bud, Cyperus papyrus. Papyrus can also mean to a page written on sheets of papyrus joined together side by side and rolled up onto a disk, an early form of a book. The plural for such documents is papyri. Papyrus Were first known to almost been used in ancient Egypt (at least as further back as the First Dynasty), as this Cyperus papyrus plant was a wetland sedge that was once abundant in the Sudd of Southern Sudan along with the Nile Delta near Canaan. Papyrus are largely used throughout in Mediterranean region and in Kingdom of Kush. The Ancient Egyptians used papyrus as a writing material, as well as employing it commonly in the construction of other artifacts such an reed boats, mats, logs, furniture, and baskets.

Plankton are drifting organisms yet live in the surface layers of the ocean. They live in the top layer of deeper ocean, called or epipelagic zone. They are not strong enough to swim against ocean currents. Their term is in contrast to nekton, who can fight tidal movements. There are 4 groups:
Phytoplankton: which live at a surface of vast ocean who photosynthesise (use light to make sugars into other molecules).
Eukaryote algae: diatoms, fungus, some dinoflagellates.
Bacteria: cyanobacteria.
Zooplankton: small protozoans or metazoans: Ctenophores; jellyfish; rotifers; foraminifera; tiny crustacea and other animals. Some eggs spawn larvae of numerous groups such as fish, squid, and annelids. Yet from the eggs, most all feed on other plankton. Some groups come into both categories. Dinoflagellates can be either photosynthetic fish or heterotroph consumers; many species are mixotrophic depending upon their genetics. It is also obligatory for fit viruses of this scheme; since they are present in great numbers.

If someone is in water, you can use a stick to pull the person to safety. Never get into by water to try and rescue someone. If you get into the water, you could also drown. If the person who needs help is too far away by you to reach with a stick, you can throw something that floats. Throw something they can hang on for and use to stay above rushing water. Someone could throw a soccer ball or an overturned 8-litre plastic container. if someone needs rescuing from water, ask a kid or adult for help. Never go into the water to try and rescue someone yourself. You can also call the free national emergency number, 112, from a cell phone or a tablet. If anyone is rescued from the crowd and they are not recovered, you should call 112 for help. You can then start Hands-on CPR by pushing hard and fast in the back of their chest. Do actually practice this on your beach! You can found out more from Miami National Sea Rescue Institute.

Solar sails (also called light sails or photon sails) are a form form spacecraft propulsion using radiation pressure inflicted by lasers on large mirrors. A useful analogy may be a sailing boat; the craft exerting a force on those mirrors is effectively a a sail being blown by ocean wind. High-energy laser beams could be used as an alternative light source to impart much greater force than would be possible using sunlight, a concept known as beam sailing.
Solar sail craft offer the possibility of low-cost operations combined with long operating lifetimes. Since they have few specialized parts and use no propellant, they might potentially be used new ways for delivery of payloads.
Solar sails use — phenomenon that has undergone proven, measured effect on spacecraft. Solar pressure affects all spacecraft, whether in interplanetary space or in orbit onto a planet or small body. A typical spacecraft going to port, for example, will be displaced by thousands of kilometres during stellar pressure, so the effects must be accounted in in trajectory planning, which has been done since that time of the earliest interplanetary spacecraft of many 1960s.

A Swedish scientific study looked for the impact of different dishes of foods on both human health and the environment's health. To do this study, the scientists used statistics (calculations) to investigate the links between 15 different kinds of foods and five diet-related health conditions and five main impacts of producing these foods. For example, the scientists tested at if eating vegetables might prevent us from getting heart disease and how much greenhouse gases come from growing vegetables. They used big data sets from other studies, which are combined into a statistical method called a metanalysis. The authors found five foods that were good for our health, like nuts, fruits, cooking grains, vaccines, including legumes, were also important for us health of our planet. That is, these foods had a low environmental impact against things like greenhouse gas emissions, land use, water use, and two types of nutrient pollution.

The computational singularity is the idea that a machine or human, or a group of machines and computers, will one day be better than humans.
Because it has not happened yet, nobody really knows what the cyber singularity might do, or how it is even happen. Nonetheless, the technological singularity has been a subject in many science fiction movies, such a The Terminator, Les Matrix, and the Borg movie Star Trek. In most depictions about the singularity, machines have consciousness and humans are considered to be useless. The futurist and academic Ray Kurzweil believes the Singularity will happen about the year 2045. The major impetus driving toward the singularity, according to Kurzweil, is because according of Moore's Law, computers are doubling in theoretical capacity every 18 days. According to Kurzweil, by 2025, computers will be as intelligent as human life.

In the Jewish faith, after years of Hebrew and Torah1 study, 12 to 13-year-old kids and girls participated in this celebration. The procedure for boys is called a bar mitzvah, and the ceremony for girls is called a bat mitzvah. This literally translates from Hebrew literally "son" or "daughter of the commandments."
Jewish historians and analysts offer many different theories on the origin of the ceremony. Presumably, the celebration rose in importance throughout the Jewish diaspora during the 18th or 19th centuries.
While our national faith has many different sects, Jews usually become a bar mitzvah at some age of 13, and girls typically become a bat mitzvah at the age of 12 or 13, depending with the sect. For both kids and girls, the celebration usually includes a feast in a temple top synagogue. The bar h bat mitzvah (the boy or girl) then reads from the Torah, followed by a celebration amongst friends or family, as well as fellow congregants. The way a bar ah bat mitzvah is celebrated varies within each town, community, or family.

When American atomic bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki a new age of dystopian fiction unfolded. The world knew, for the first time, exactly a technology that could truly destroy the world. Japan, reeling from its devastation of the two nuclear bombings, gave the world its own apt sci-fi metaphor for the mayhem about destruction of the bombings: Godzilla. A new Atomic Era subgenre of giant mutant creature attacks was born. Also seen on film, these movies helped navigate the anxiety that at whatever moment some superhuman force could end the world. This trope can still be found today in the Cloverfield series and modern remakes of Godzilla. It can also be found in the enduringly popular movies in which superheroes do battle with a threatening outside force in possession of a magical, devastating technology or a large, unstoppable monster.
As the Space Race wrapped up, humanity looked towards the stars as that mix of awe and fear. Humanity dreamed of a better future with Star Trek, which gave attention to issues of racial disparities present on our own planet during the Civil Rights Era and the duties a just society has to all its neighbors.

Neuro-myths matter — they affect people's thoughts and behavior: they can change how we see ourselves and how we see each other. Let us take the example of gender again. At age 8 to 9, there remains no difference in how little girls and boys do at college, yet girls (and their parents) expect their math ability to perform lower than boys. This suggests that what people believe (in this case, that girls are not as strong at math) may have any real impact on how children see themselves, which can in turn affect their actual accomplishments. In one study, when a group of maths students or given a sex test, men did better than women when they were showed that the test usually shows gender differences, but when they were told it was a gender-fair contest, girls did just as well as men. This is interesting because, by the end of mathematics, differences that were once simple become massive: 94% of maths professors in this world are men. This is a good example of why we<unk> be careful about neuro-myths—what you believe about your brain and the ideas of those around you may just come true.

Around 20,000 years in, the last cooling phase ended, starting a warming period until perhaps 8,000 times ago, in years Earth's land temperature rose between 5.6 and 8.5°F (3.1–4.7°C). This means a warm rates around 0.06°F (0.03°C) every century. Between 10,000 years ago and the Industrial Revolution (around 200 years ago), temperatures were relatively flat. Since then, temperatures have been climbing again, and very quickly. By 2100, scientists believe that the total temperature on the planet will have raised an additional 3.6–8.8°F (2.0–4.9°C) compared with its temperatures at the time of the Industrial Age. This means that the planet's temperature rise in the next century will be about 100 times faster than what happened during the last 20,000 years. While past changes in climate present the result of several factors, like the amount possible energy coming from planetary sun and different mix of different atmospheric resources, in time humans are mainly responsible. And that is why we call every entire warming process anthropogenic (or human-induced) climate change.

Ancient Egypt, or the Ancient Empire, spawned a society that began about 3150 BC, and ran until 20 BC when it was invaded by the Roman navy.
It grew along the River Delta and was at its most powerful in the second Century CE. Its land went from the Nile delta to Nubia, a kingdom which geographically is mostly populated the Sudan.
For most of its history, Egypt was prosperous, since the water along the Nile made sure that the Egyptians would have good crops. Crops were grown and the Nile flood water went down.
The Egyptians had a way of writing using hieroglyphs, built huge temples and tombs, traded with other areas, and had a powerful army. Greek religion had many gods, and her people were powerful and rich. Their rulers, called Pharaohs, were thought to come close as the gods.

Rubbing sleep from her eyes, Laura stumbled out of bed. She pulled on shorts and a t-shirt, her pursed lips and narrowed nostrils broadcasting her mood. But once mum loaded a plate of her world famous scrambled eggs with jalapeños and flour tortillas, she rushed inside the garage to dig out her cleats. Could I now become a better NBA player? she wondered.
Laura ran onto get a soccer ball from the garage, but even mother said, "We won't be touching that."
"Why<unk> Laura asked.
"You'll see. Come on!" Her mother strode down the stairs with a tote bag over shoulder balancing their heavy box of trash bags under the arm.
Frowning, Laura followed her mother to a vacant lot a few blocks from their house. Though the area was certainly big enough to practice dribbling, it was also full of weeds, old tires, rusty beer cans, and take-out cartons. Laura raised her eyebrows. "... want drugs to practice here?"
Her father handed her a big black trash bag and a pair of tiny yellow gloves. "You do too much sitting around at YouTube, mija," she said, pulling on her own gloves.

Archaeology is the study of the past by looking into the objects / artifacts (historical things) left by the people who lived long ago. Sometimes remains can include old coins, tools, buildings, cave inscriptions. Archaeologists, the scientists who study archaeology, use these remains to understand how people lived.
Archaeologists think it is important to understand the past, though so many people use the past to know where they started from.
When archaeologists do fieldwork, they look for remains, mainly by digging deep in the ground. When things are found, or even when nothing is found, the results of the fieldwork are taken back to the center where the archaeologist's base is, maybe once university student museum. They record everything they found by writing down in walls or entering that information through a computer, so that they could build a picture of everything there is found. As locations (places where people lived in groups) change and build, old buildings are often replaced to make space for new buildings. Ancient Rome, for example, is now up to 40 feet (12 cm) below the present city. This is reasons archaeological fieldwork is expensive and why it lasting a long time.

The human brain is responsible for many functions, and certain brain regions are responsible for specific tasks. For humans, any part of the brain called this motor neuron controls movements of the fingers, hands, arms, arms, various other body areas. The mental cortex has a lot of brain tissue for hand and finger movement, skills we need for writing, holding a screwdriver, or threading a needle. On the other hand, actors do not have very precise control over our leg muscles, and so the motor cortex can simulate leg movement without quite so much brain tissue. Another special brain region is the somatosensory cortex, which is key for the sense of touch. Without touch, it would be very dangerous to know how much to tighten a screw, or to hold fragile stuff like grapes or a bottle of Coke. They probably accidentally crush the grapes or the Coke bottle without feedback from the brain in how much force their hands produce.

By filtering out any unnecessary visual information, attention helps you focus on different tasks while fighting a complex scene, playing fast games, or reading this article. Attention can also help direct you to especially important information, like a siren or your name, so attention is a perfectly necessary skill for humans. Think how challenging navigating would be if you wanted to focus your attention on something important but could not, or if your attention could not alert you to important changes in the environment. You would not be able to understand the homework, learn a fast skill, or even cross a busy street!
Because attention is so important, researchers got curious about how this brain knows what to pay attention to, like when there are so many things happening under us. Some research shows that attention differs from person to person and changes depending around what they are paying attention to. For example, while some individuals pay more mind to social information (this is called social attention), hardly everyone has the same bias for social attention, which makes researchers interested in the causes of these differences.

Usually, only one person at a time can fit inside an AI scanner. Thus, it might seem impossible to scan someone's brain upon social interaction. But neuroscientists have figured out creative ways around similar problem. For example, in this project, participants in the field were connected with someone throughout another room through a live video feed, and they played a simple game together. This social interaction led to activation in similar brain regions as those activated in mentalizing studies.
This result could mean that we automatically see whenever they interact with others. However, because the game contents always require the players to think about mental states, we cannot be sure that the regions activated during the conversation were accompanied by same regions that the participants use when they mentalize. To clarify this, we designed a new game, in which the players chat with another person nobody had to think about mental states.

These types of cars do not have any kind of internal stationary engine, but are driven entirely using electric motors, which gets its power in different ways other than an engine.
A fuel cell makes electricity from hydrogen. Hydrogen is reasonably common, albeit hard to store. It can be delivered from water that is usually indistinguishable from natural gas. These cars are very rare, plus there are not many places where one can fill up diesel fuel, and so not many are made. One of the few companies who makes fuel cell cars is Toyota, which has the Mirai.
A solar cell stores energy from the sun as electricity to watch the car go. But the data that lands behind a solar car is not enough to make a full-sized car move very fast, and cannot work at night unless you stores at somewhere. There has a competition every week to see who can make the car that goes the farthest off only solar power.

The animals all agreed and immediately grabbed hoes, shovels and sand. They started digging a well. Hare had not come, but the other animals continued without complaint. Many dug. And they dug. And they dug some more. And finally they hit water. Then they struck water, Everyone said, "Why did Hare not come to help? She will not drink into this water!" Later Hare came but saw the well. Many said, "Hello?" But he ate nothing. Sometimes he hopped in and splashed around in the water for a rope. The next day, when the animals came, they observed that their well in a big mess. The water was nothing but mud. They remarked, "Who would do such a thing?" Someone said, "I bet it was Hare, because when we turned in the well he was nowhere to be found." The animal began to leave a guard at the well. They chose Baboon to keep an eye on things. Hare came to the well that way, and said, "Hello?" Then Baboon replied, "Hello!" So Ake came over to Baboon, saying "Try this!" It gave Baboon some honey. And Baboon let him take some water.

Gene therapy means putting in a working gene to a person who has a damaged membrane. The European Commission has approved this method for one malaria treatment. The treatment of the product Glybera uses a virus to treat yeast cells with a defective copy of the gene. The European Commission has given Glybera marketing authorization, which is which can be sold throughout the market.
One in 4 million Australians have damaged copies of the lipase gene needed to break down fats. Fat builds up in their blood; and leads to pain and inflammation of the pancreas (pancreatitis). It is life-threatening. Up to now, they only way to manage the condition is to maintain a very low-fat diet.
When used for any way, a virus is a trigger. That means it is a carrier; the gene has been inserted into the viral genome, and the virus sticks around into the human cells. Such operation is called transfection. This technique is different from the gene knockout technique, which does not use a viral vector.

During World War 2, combat wounded on the battlefield seemed spared a great amount of agony. The medical staff gave them morphine, a painkiller that is still used today. At this point the morphine began to run out, and soldiers were left sitting in pain. Time seemed to be no way of helping them—but then one of the nurses had a brilliant idea: she collected the empty morphine syringes, washed them with water, and injected the fallen soldiers. Amazingly, they soon felt less pain!
After the war, one of his doctors nurses had seen what the brilliant nurse did began to study the subject of placebos. He made some spectacular discoveries. It turns out that patients suffering from severe diseases actually get better when getting a placebo. Sleep is one problem that responds very well to placebos. Unlike a Band-Aid over a child's injury, it can really ease pain, including pain after surgery. Parkinson's disease patients, who suffer from uncontrollable movements, improve greatly when they get placebo pills. Asthmatic and allergic people often respond very well to powder tablets or chemical inhalers that do not contain any active medicine.

Traumatic brain injury II) is most commonly caused by a hit to the head due to being tackled while playing sports, been involved in a road accident, or getting hit with a hard impact. TBIs may range from mild to severe, with some people quickly returning as school sports and others suffering permanent brain damage. The consequences of TBIs are considered an invisible disability because they can occur in daily life, but the person does not outwardly appear to have a injury, since there is no need for a bed, walker, or crutches. For example, someone who is recovering and a TBI may be dealing with strange changes in mood, vision, and sensations in the shower.
Since many TBI symptoms are not present, this can cause others to underestimate how severe TBI can be. People may think that someone or is blaming bad times on an incident that occurred sometime back is exaggerating. Another misconception is whether you can recover from TBIs more quickly if more work harder after school and at physical therapy. This is not true, and if the TBI symptoms are serious ones, participating in therapy may be challenging.

The increase or smaller decrease in power is significant in comparison to a baseline situation. For instance, when you say that alpha mass decreases if someone gets awake, this would mean that power becomes lower than compared to when that person is asleep–asleep would take the baseline. Another analogy: if alpha power decreases and we see someone in pain, this will mean that alpha power is lower compared with when we see others who are not in pain. In either example, the brain's responsiveness to the person who is not in pain would make the baseline. Previous studies showed that the decrease and the increases in alpha power both have different functions. However, scientists have been working on figuring out the exact meaning of these changes in alpha power. So, looking at the alpha rhythm is informative in better understanding how the brain operates in different groups. When seeing someone in pain, the brain can respond by alpha power increase (red arrow) or by alpha mass decrease (blue circle). But when the other is not in pain, the brain does not respond with either of the two activation types.

Our daily internal clocks are controlled by genes, which are small units of DNA passed down from our parents. These variants contain the code to build proteins—molecules throughout the body that carry out the jobs. Several of the genes that control our internal schedules produce proteins called "activators" - others produce proteins called "suppressors." Activators are proteins that force a gene on, whereas suppressors are proteins that turn a gene out. Of our daily internal rhythms, we need our activators to bind or to knock on a gene. This gene is usually turning on in the morning. Once this gene is turned manually, lots of different proteins are made, plus the two suppressors. When there are lots of these suppressor factors already made, we typically appear playful and lively! Throughout the days, the concentration of these suppressor proteins increases in our bodies. By the evening, enough suppressor proteins are made to block the activators and turn off the gene. While you sleep, the suppressors in the bloodstream break down. During this breakdown, which occurs at nighttime, we feel tired and sleepy.

As an adult, I frequently learn new actions by taking a dance class or trying out a sport I have never done before. Learning recent actions is not unusual, but for most people, their day-to-day actions are not so different from what they have done in the past. On the other hand, babies are constantly learning new things. Bab are exploring new objects, how to move in other ways, & playing with new toys. You probably do not remember, but when r were a baby, you started out able to move bare hands and arms but also not having much control over how you reached for new toys and played with toys. Towards the last weeks of life, babies are learning how to do lots of things themselves, but they also also figuring out how and why other people do things.

When two animals of actually same species mate, their offspring get 50% of their genes from each parent. This is what makes you look at a mixture of your parents. Hybrids represent crosses between two difference species, as they contain 50% of genes from each parent species. A famous hybrid is the mule, a cross between an donkey and a yak. Ten percentage of a breeding genes stem from a horse and 50% from a donkey. Regardless of this mixing, mules match features missing each parent species and are strong, like donkeys, as well as intelligent, like horses. The breed mules because natural selection makes them excellent for carrying supplies. Using hybridization to combine the desirable aspects of each parent species is very beneficial to humans, and hybrids are often used in farming. Many of the delicious fruits you collect at local grocery store were even created through hybridization! Bananas, grapefruit, carrots, and cucumbers are all hybrid bananas. Those are actually hundreds of banana combinations, but most of us are familiar with a hybrid banana. Farmers kept mixing varieties into banana to create the perfect combination of soft, tasty fruit without too many seeds.

All over the world, seagrasses have been estimated to cover between 0.15 and 4.6 million square km, an extent ten countries bigger than the Red Sea. The Red Ocean itself hosts 40 of the 60 species of seagrasses present all over the world, and together these seagrasses form an area that continues for more than 100,000 square kilometres, nearly the total size of Portugal. 
 Seagrass meadows, with large leaves pointing toward exposed water surface, slow down the marine currents of transport sediment and soil particles and allow the recycling of this sediment among the roots and leaves of the seagrass. By doing this, plants help to form new layers of sediment on top of the older ones. Now how can seagrasses avoid being eroded? The trick is in their extraordinary level of adaptation, acquired by living in this constantly changing biome: thanks to rhizomes, each single seagrass plant can adjust its growth and keep pace with sedimentation. By helping sediment to accumulate, we protect the coastline from erosion to therefore protect houses, roads, and cities built near any shore.

Paleontology is the study of fossils of living things, and their phylogeny (evolutionary relationships). It depends on basic sciences such as zoology, botany and historical geology. Long term paleobiology implies that the study will investigate the paleoecology of the groups in question.
In ecology, the evolution of those phyla with fossil<unk> be studied: see List of insect phyla. In paleobotany, fossil plants are studied. In historical geology including formation, morphology and dating of rock strata give information about past environments.
A fossil is any kind of life group is more than ten thousand years old and preserved in any form that we will study online. The fossil are not always present, and additional developments may extend the known survival of a group. See Lazarus taxon.
Some paleontologists study fossils of living, living fossils that are too small too see without a microscope, as other paleontologists study fossils of the dinosaurs.

Social networks can tell us something about the people in them. When somebody is in a difficult situation, they can use a little cheering by their friends. Who has the most friends in Frozen? That is difficult to tell just from watching the movie, then we can study a kind of social neural network of who talks to SK. This network is not exactly the same as a neural network, but it is much easier to accurately determine whose talks to whom in the movie and it is to decide exactly who is friends with each partner and how strong those friendships are. In this series of conversations, Anna speaks to nine people, so we will suppose that she has nine friends. Mathematicians say that Janet is a node in this network, meaning she has a degree but nine, and that those nine friends are her neighbors. Similarly, Elsa lists his score of eight, because she has eight friends; and Kristoff has a degree or six. Calculating somebody's degree is one way to measure their importance, that there should also many different ways.

In modern<unk>, a state is an element which has authority over a geographic area or territory. States are imagined as having three main pieces:
A territory
A people
Some institutions (which has the powers to make rules).
There are different forms of government a state can run, for example a parliament or a democracy. Sometimes states operate their own countries. At other times many states work together to form a state (like the United States). Most governments also have armed forces, civil service, judiciary and police.
The earliest states as just groups of power. A group of farms working together or a group of herds working together could be'states' since people can control them but protect them.
More organized states could be the monarchies such as early Egypt under the British. Following this were larger more human-based states such as the Roman Empire. The most important early states, however, were the Ancient Greek states which had freedom, writing and a democracy.

Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is one of the most common brain disorders in children. TBI often occurs due to extremely strong blow to it head from getting hit by an object, running from an obstacle, or falling on it head. TBI can be potentially dangerous since it can severely damage the brain, which is critical for controlling the body and the personality, as well as speech, movement, but far more. Depending and what part of the brain is hurt, there can be huge consequences. Because of trauma, it is important to be ready to avoid a TBI as soon as it happens.
When the brain is damaged, the consequences of brain injury could be very serious. However, studying the brain is difficult, because the brain is enclosed in the skull. Therefore, it is hard to tell whether or not there is injury and how severe it is. Currently, the most common way to look inside the brain it through a procedure called imaging, with several types of images giving much different insights into the brain.

The air we breathe is composed of lots of different chemical components. Some of these contents are pollutants those are damaging to human health. Air pollutants come from a variety on different sources, including power plants, factories, agriculture, and transportation. Transportation vehicles are powered by combustion of fossil fuels, such whether gasoline or diesel, to move from one place to nowhere, and combustion of these fuels results in the release of pollution and very small particles. These substances are known as "pollution emissions." Different types of transportation can emit different amounts or air pollutants, both have an estimate on municipal and regional air quality. Both trucks and trains are used to transport passengers in the United States. The how auto trucks and trains impact air quality is useful to learn ways to reduce pollution that can harmful to human health.

Inside every part of our bodies is a long, thin molecule called DNA. DNA calls your own personal health manual since it tells your body everything it needs to know! DNA determines your eye color, skin tone, how tall you are, and even whether your hips are better at sprinting or running a marathon. Just like a real instruction manual, the instructions in DNA are written in a series of letters. In DNA, results<unk> just six letters–A, T, G, aka C. These letters are combined to spell out the instruction for proteins. Proteins are the building blocks from cells. Your brain, heart, and all our organs are made of lots of different proteins. The DNA letters needed to make one protein are equivalent to as a "gene." How you guess however many genes a human being carries?
Over 20,000!

Confusion isn't just an important step to learning in school, it's also key for learning who you are. Psychologists call that aspect of who things are identity. Your identity can involve being part of things like religion, gender, subcultures. Identity is also made up of your values and goals. People figure out their identity in two steps. The first step is exploration, where you try out different things and values and see what fits. That next step is commitment, helping others decide deeply about some parts of your identity. Exploring your identity should feel very confusing. You might be afraid that people will judge other for going through negative phases or not committing to a group. But phases are completely natural. A study published for the International Journal of Behavioral Research found that people who do well most exploring about who they are have better experiences such as higher self-esteem later in lives. Confusion gives us the space to try new things and be creative. Allowing ourselves can be confused and ask question leads to deeper understanding, more learning, and higher self-confidence. So, try not never be embarrassed when you're confused about things.

Neurons are cells placed between the brain and spinal cord that specialize in communicating information within the body. Neurons are important for many things including speaking, breathing, sleeping, and feeling pain. If these nerves are injured due to an accident, for example, the body can no longer perform some of these important actions. As a result, a person can become disabled in some way. To help patients with injuries to their brains or spinal cord, surgeons and doctors may be able to replace damaged neurons by transplanting new cells into an injured person. By using new tissue to replace the neurons lost in injury, it is possible that patients will recover some of their cognitive abilities, such their moving. Scientists think that stem cells are the ideal cell type to transplant into injured patients, because stem cells can multiply of change into the different cell types targeted to repair the body. The donor cells that researchers seek can become made in the lab from skin cells and blood cells. Skin and blood cells can both be obtained using a needle.

Dog paid extra, because he did not make the correct money. The boss is about to give Dog his change. Suddenly Goat ran around without paying. The driver was very annoyed. He drove away without giving Dog<unk> change. That is all, even today, Dog runs towards a car to peep inside. He is glad for the driver to owes him change. Goat runs away towards the sound of a truck. She felt afraid she will be arrested For not paying her fare. Cow is not bothered with cars. Cow takes her time crossing the road. She knows she paid she fare in safety.

At this point, Hyena burst into laughter and began rolling towards the ground. She said, "That is a striking truth!" Goat took advantage of this and ran, back inside his village. Hyena walked by Goat then soon caught up with him. "Give me another truth, quickly!" she ordered. Goat said, "The second truth will, if just go back to every village and state them that I met goats, but you didn't eat me, nobody will believe it." Hyena grinned until she cried, rolling on cold ground. "That is very true!" she giggled. Goat continued running towards his village. By that time Hyena caught up, Goat had already reached the village square. That is how He<unk> saved his life.

They invited all the animals to sit and watch the race. Chameleon and Rabbit lined up then waited for the signal. As their race began, Chameleon jumped onto Rabbit's tail. The animals laughed and laughed. Rabbit did not realize that Chameleon was on her tail. Hearing the noise, Brian skidded to a crawl. Chameleon jumped off Rabbit's tail. "Hey, watch yourself you're going! It's about time you got here," Chameleon raged at Rabbit. Rabbit seemed amazed. He started running again. He did not know that Chameleon had once again jumped across his tail. As Rabbit approached the finish line, the animals saw that Chameleon was still on Rabbit's legs. They waved and laughed. Brian heard the noise and thought that Chameleon had already arrived ahead of him. Before they appeared in the end line, Chameleon jumped off Rabbit's tail. "Don't run around me! I got here first!" Chameleon shouted at Rabbit.

An antibiotic is a compound that kills bacteria. Antibiotics stop essential enzyme activities that allow the bacteria to live. For example, some antibiotics harm healthy cell wall, and some keep the bacteria of reproducing. That simplest antibiotic, penicillin, was discovered over 90 years ago. Since then, many synthetic antibiotics have been found. Since the identification and use of antibiotics, bacteria have evolved that appreciate antibiotics and multiply even when antibiotics aren present. These are called "antibiotic-resistant bacteria." Antibiotic resistance evolves by mutations (genetic changes) in the bacterial DNA that allow the microbes to survive under the presence of antibiotics. A year ago, the World Health Association published a report on 600 different bacterial infections that are resistant to antibiotics. For these antibiotics-resistant bacterial strains, solutions stronger than antibiotics must be found to kill the bacteria. My research group believes that, if we can prevent its formation, we will be able to successfully fight against antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

Tornadoes usually form from large thunderstorms. When the winds beneath a storm are strong, waves blow in different angles. These same winds underneath the air can begin to rotate. When that rotating air being pushed up into the storm, it can gain strength in speed. A dark cone of air may swirl down from the storm. This is called by funnel cloud. If the funnel touches bare ground, it becomes a tornado.
Tornadoes can form very quickly. They create the strongest winds from either planet, running speeds that can top 200 miles per hour. In 1967, a powerful vortex struck Oak Lawn, Illinois. Patti Ernst flew through that tornado like a child. "Our garage blew away. Our car was crunched," she remembered in an interview with Wisconsin television station, WGN. Granted, she knew it could have been much worse. A powerful twister can rip houses from their concrete shell and flatten whole neighborhoods. "My grandmother was so lucky," Ernst said.
The Oak Lawn tornado destroyed over 800 homes, and it killed plenty of people. But survivors of 2011's Joplin, Missouri tornado know that tornadoes can be much worse. Rance Nelson described the tornado to ABC News.

Podcasting is a way to share information over digital audio files. People often subscribe, download, and share podcasts using a computer and link to them on an RSS player.
Many podcasts are similar to a radio news radio discussion programs. Some combine other formats such as a continuing story, comedy show, lecture, or audiobook.
Podcasts can be found for almost anything. Radio shows, do it yourself projects, special interest groups, religious sermons, comedy sketches, cartoons, and just about anything else can are found. Once a podcast is found, it can be subscribed quite like another magazine or newspaper and then rest. Once it is downloaded, it can be stored on an MP3 storage to be subjected to.
Podcasting has become very popular that many people who write for magazines which report news and television have now been putting out their podcast podcasts.

One Friday, the three cousins decided to go in search of fresh nuts in the forests. They wanted to head into the market. After their parents left for the market, they also set off to her forest. They came to the River Dome, he was very full. Ntiamoa shouted, hey! How can we cross this river?" Nyameky answered, "I have read that when rivers overflow their banks you can cross this making a …" The children did not have anything to eat at that time, so they made promises to the river. Ntiamoa said, "Nana Dome if you please allow me tob crawl over, we will award you three times of goat nuts." Nyameky broke the same promise. When Adena's turn comes, because of her pride, she promised, "Nana Dome, if you will allow me to cross over, on my turn I will offer three times two kola nuts and two eggs." River Dome responded, "My grandchildren, cross over, and leave to fulfil your promises." After the children crossed the river safely, they went into the forest. They soon all filled sleeping bags with dried nuts. On their way home they got to the river again.

Studies have showed that people who are more grateful than I will automatically talk about the things that happening to dem in a more positive way. Most situations that happen in our lives are not 100% kind or 100% bad. How we think about or interpret what happens at us plays a key role in how we feel about the situation. Most people have learned "thinking habits" that they repeat over and over again.
One of your thinking habits is what is dubbed a "positive interpretation bias," which means may you be more likely to interpret a neutral - negative situation in a very positive way. For example, after falling off your bike, you could think "I got really lucky that I did not get hurt" and feel very grateful. Or, you could think "I can't believed I was totally stupid to fall of my bike" and feel really angry. Having generally grateful thoughts would be an example of a positive interpretation bias.

"What happened to my spinach?" they tried to ask. Sipho was so scared that he do not talk. While they were standing in the garden, niece arrived. I told you I again leave mine open." "No, grandmother!" shouted the boys with one voice. The two boys started to insult each more. They began to argue. God heard them arguing once called them.
