Grandmother was very kind. In a calm voice she said, "I hope you two boys have learned your lesson. You must never leave the gate open again."

Antibiotics have a used for almost a century to treat bacterial diseases in humans while also in animals. Throughout this interval, they have been looking for strategies to survive antibiotic treatment. Imagine a battlefield, where a population of bacteria is attacked by small bullets (antibiotics). If one in some bacteria can find a shield to protect itself, it will survive. The surviving bacteria too have the advantage of being resistant to antibiotics forever and so will their descendants. This is the reason why, when you get cancer, you have to take just the pills prescribed by the doctor, even if you already knew better. Treatment is very important to prevent "survivors" in the battle! Bacteria aversion to antibiotics (= "superbugs") was very dangerous for us, considering we have immunity weapons can exploit against them. Also, these resistant bacteria would be transmitted to other people or even to animals. Nowadays, there are a high number of bacteria that have become resistant to many different antibiotics, and these is a threat for people worldwide.

The woman took them home with her One afternoon, Palm tree and Cassava had an discussion. Cassava said hers looked more important than Palm. She thought he was more important than Cassava. The mother heard them from that room. She jumped out and yelled, "Why are you fighting?" Cassava said first. "I am more important than a tree. I provide tubers for your fufu, gari, boiled seafood and cassava dough."

Try this quick exercise: go download your music library, pick a song, to play the first 3 s of it. Give yourself 1 second if I can manage to sing or hum at least the next 5 s from that song. Do this for 20 songs. How many points did you score? … would not be surprised if it is more likes 15. Now, think bout what you just did. You effortlessly recalled the titles, rhythm, and maybe even the lyrics of more than 15 tracks in a short amount enough time. That is a lot of data to managed to draw from your brain, just like that!
Our brains possess a remarkable power to make, store, and retrieve memories of music, even when we are hardly aware of doing so. For example, if to hear a catchy song, you will most likely be able to remember parts of it a few months later. After hearing it several times, you might know it by heart. Think about how much more effort it takes to absorb information from a textbook, or to comprehend the details of day-to-day events in your life.

When we mention bacteria in the human body, you might immediately think of a disease, called a gut microbiome. At some point in your existence, you have probably had an infection that was treated by antibiotics prescribed by your doctor. These are medicines that kill or prevent the growth of bacteria.
However, the majority of such pathogens are harmless and actually help to maintain our health. The microbes of the skin, mouth, and kidneys fight against bad bacteria that want to enter the body to cause illnesses. These benign pathogens act like guards they keep out the harmful factor that made us sick. The bacteria that colonize the vagina are another example of good bacteria. They maintain an acidic environment in the body that prevents the growth of other microorganisms that might cause disease. Disease-causing microorganisms are called viruses.
Even though most of them time they are harmless or even helpful, in certain environments some of the bacteria that are part of the human microbiota can harm us.

Although reflexes are super-fast and just happen without you thinking about them, That does not mean that they go bad. Reflexes protect you and allow how you move around possibly thinking about every single action and response your body needs to commit. It is important that reflexes occur outside the need for thinking about them because there are things that happen to your self and forces acting inside your body when you move that need to be responded to very much. Reflexes allow your self to react in ways that help you to be present, to stand upright, and to be active.
Imagine what typical day. You might be thinking of losing your sport or musical instrument, walking to school, or making a movie. In all cases these actions, you are thinking, but @ the same time, there are also actions that you are unaware of happening within your body. These reflexes are built naturally into the body, and they exist at birth and change as we grow older. Reflexes are kind of like safety features for survival that allow us later think in response to something in the environment.

Neurons function in many forms, shapes and sizes, so it is helpful to think of a neuron like a tree. This neuron has four main branches, the cell body, an axon, and various dendrites. The tree trunk (cell body) stores genetic information (DNA) in a compartment called the nucleus. The bulb body also contains both chemical machinery to produce the neurotransmitters -- this neuron uses the talk with all other.
The tree's branches (dendrite, the word déndron comes from the Greek language and actually means "tree") are the parts of a neuron that receive signals. Dendrites were once believed to be like antennae, just receiving signals form other neurons, but, as I explain, they can do more complicated this.
The tree root (axon) is the structure used by that neuron to compare with and talk to another neuron. An axon holds information similar to a cable that carries electricity. When one neuron wants to share electrical message with another, it sends an electrical impulse, using an action potential, down its axon until it touches the axon itself, at the end of the axon.

We learned from our results that people who are afraid of spiders feel them to be bigger. We also learned that in order to overestimate the size of an object, that object needs to cause the person to feel fear and unpleasantness on a daily basis.
We demonstrated in this work whether negative emotions (* and unpleasantness) cause people to overestimate size. But what about positive events? Our studies found if positive emotions could also change size estimation. For example, expert golf players estimate exact physical size of the hole the ball is sunk into to be larger than non-expert scholars estimate the hole to be.
The next question to be asked is what causes what? Do some people have one image of a big spider in their mind – it is why they are afraid of spiders? why are they afraid of spiders — where they see one, they see it as taller than it really is? This question requires yet more studies. Such additional studies become important because understanding why people are ashamed of spiders can help scientists invent ways to make such people get over their fear.

Once upon a time, there was a leader who had three sons. The youngest lad was the cleverest and his father liked him the most. Then the man noticed that his 3 other boys were jealous. So when her father died, he left all his cattle to his two remaining sons. He only left one ox for the youngest son. But the brothers were definitely jealous of him. 
One day they said, "We've got to slaughter ye ". He was the youngest so he couldn't protest. He went, Oh that must be so, there's nothing I can do. But please give me your hide." When they slaughtered the ox, he took one hide. As drying out, he climbed a tree through it. 
As it got darker, a group of merchants suggested they sleep under the tree. In the middle of the night, the young man started beating the hide over a stick. When the stick hit the log it sounded like thunder. The merchants thought that a storm was coming. They ran off leaving their goods behind. 
The young man picked up the goods and took go home to his brothers.

Kadogo and Juma are friends which love running. They run together every day. 
One day they were reading maps at school. 
Juma started, "Let's run across our continent. Let's go, together with Africans from many countries!" 
"Let's go, we can do it! African unity!" cheered Kadogo. 
They had to carry a unity torch on their heads. They lit the torch and began to run. 
The race started at the southern tip of our continent, in Cape Town, South Cape. From central Africa it headed along the west coast. 
They ran through Namibia, Angola, DRC, Senegal and Cameroon. Runners alike joined them from these countries. The growing group of people meets in Tunis, in Abuja. 
More runners across West Africa join the friends as they raced through Nigeria. They continued together, following the River Niger. 
A sandstorm in Mali made it difficult to run. Juma was the strongest of all of them. Luo led the way safely, holding the unity torch high. On its coast in Conakry there dusty runners covered in white mud. 
Then Unity decided to race across Morocco through Senegal and Nigeria. All the way, 250 people joined them.

A tyrant (pronounce: tie-rant) is that person who rules with absolute power. In its original root the word has no negative meaning: we translate back then as Cyrus the Mighty A tyrant frequently rules a country, and he often got his position as powerful ruler by force, although some of them inherited their power.
Later, the word came to mean someone who ruled with cruelty by injustice. The rule of a tyrant is called brutality. The adjective indicates tyrannical.
A monarch or despot is someone who rules with absolute authority, usually cruelly. It now has the same meaning as 'tyrant', and before, 'tyrant' meant something of 'ruler' or 'king'.
In about 10th and 9th centuries BC, Ancient Greece was ruled by monarchs. Until the third century BP, they were rule by groups of aristocrats. These aristocrats started to become unpopular. This gave cruel people the chance to get power for themselves, telling other people that they would be good rulers, but turning bad once they got rich.
Around 650 BCE, Emperor Cypselus became powerful in Corinth.

Puritans believed that to get born a witch must draw an individual under a spell. The girls should not have possibly brought this condition by themselves. Soon they were questioned and forced to name their tormentors. Three townspeople, including Tituba, were arrested as witches. The famous Salem witchcraft trials began as the girls tried to name more and more community houses.
Evidence admitted in such trials was of five types. First, the accused students get forced to give a test, like reciting the Lord's Prayer. This seems normal enough. But the young girls who attended the trial were known to scream and writhe on the floor in the middle of your house. It is easy to understand Why some could not pass.
Second, physical evidence was considered. Any birthmarks, warts, moles, or other blemishes be regarded as possible portals through which suspicion could enter a body.

It was fast approaching the time when mamas and papas take children for clean ups. It was ready for children to wave goodbye to cousins. It was getting to the dreaded bedtime. The sun was not moving. He stubbornly hung rooted within the same spot. But the shadows would grow longer, the later it got. But on that dot, the shadows did not grow any longer. The sun refused to go to bed. Below, children were still playing, laughing, skipping and jumping, although it seemed long past their playtime. Parents, being parents, looked with worry on their watches. People were puzzled. What should they do? The clocks indicated it was past playtime, but the sun still stayed at playtime! In faraway villages, parents began saying, "Children it is time of bed." And children, or adults, responded, "But the sun is still shining …" Mammas and cousins laughed at each other. Then they looked up to evening sky and wondered, "Should we go our children to bed? It is late, but the sun seems still at the midday spot."

Sun answered, "I give the earth cold and heat, for that animals but plants can live." Sun, Star, Rain and Wind listened carefully to each other. Then Sun said, "It takes true that each of us helps the earth by a own special way." "Yes", said Moon, "Not one of us is better vs the others." It can work<unk> said Rain. Wind said, "Then let us share the sun They all agreed. And that is why you sometimes see the moon where the sun is shining. Even sometimes you feel the wind when it is raining. My cousin Kamohelo leans on her hoe. What do we do? What do he know? My aunt Keromang has a dress to sew. Something do I do? What do ya know? My uncle Khotso herds the cattle that low. The human brain becomes arguably the most complex structure linked to science. A century ago, the German Korbinian Brodmann made His first serious attempt at cataloging this complexity. Thus divided his cerebral cortex, the biggest and uniquely mammalian part of the brain, into about 30 regions based on various anatomical shapes. These are now known as "Brodmann<unk> In modern neuroscience, we understand why some of these anatomical arrangements have similar functions, while others play multiple roles. For mammals, Brodmann areas 39, 40, and part of 22 together make up "Wernicke's area," named after Carl Wernicke, another German. Wernicke's area is crucial for our seemingly effortless ability to make sense of words (as well as other forms of communication, such as sign language). When scientists first measured them, they noticed that some parts turned a bit darker in appearance than others, and called these "gray matter" and "white matter." Most now know that red matter is composed up of billions of nerve cells or electrodes. White matter sum of the long cables or axons that connect large brain cells.

Most mornings, Hare would take some spices from his granary. Then he went to his field and pretended to work. He would light a fire and roast the seeds. He did nothing, except he roasted seeds. At harvest time, Hare went and stole his friend's ripe maize. He gave it to his communal granary. Hyena complained of the stolen crops. Hare answered, "Maybe the neighbors stole your maize. They are suffering from famine because they became lazy." Hyena thought about this problem for his long time. He came up with an solution. He collected gum from the trees. He put that sticky gum around the whole field. The thief would get stuck in the gum. During the night, Hare went on Hyena's field to steal more maize. On entering the field, White looked outside to see if it was safe. he did only see the gum that they had put under the knife. Hare started in the gum and was stuck. He started barking for help. Hyena heard the shouts and ran out to catch that moment. He could not believe his eyes. It was his friend himself who was stuck in the gum!

He continued walking. And saw some splendid new clothes. He took off his clothes and put on the new ones. Immediately he wondered about what tha old woman had described. The guy left the forest feeling disappointed. He went back to tell the old woman what had happened. But the old woman was gone.

One day his mother asked him, "Where do people learn beautiful songs from, Sakima?" Sakima answered, "I just know them, mother. I hear them in my mind and then I sing." Sakima liked to sing for his little sister, especially, if she felt hopeless. His sister would listen to him singing his latest song. She would sway to the soothing rhythm. "Can you tune in again and again, Sakima," his mom would beg him. Sakima would accept and sang it over and over again. One evening when his dad returned home, they were very angry. Sakima knew that there was something wrong. "What is wrong, mother, father?" Sakima whispered. He learned that the rich man's son was missing. The man was very sad and lonely. "... can sing for him. He might be happy again," Sakima promised his parents. But these parents dismissed me. "He is very rich. We are only a blind boy. Do any think your song will help him?" Yet, Sakima did the give up. His big sister supported him. She said, "Sakima's songs soothe me when I am hungry. They are stop the rich<unk> too."

More people came to one bus stop just before 9am. Half one hour later they are all still waiting. Sam is worried. "Maybe your bus broke down," he thinks. "Maybe we won't go around town today. The bus is coming! The bus stops at the stop at 10 o'clock. Move in! Got in!" calls the driver. "We<unk> very late now!" People get on one bus and settle down. The trip leaves each stop at 10:10am. "What time is the return bus this afternoon?" asks Sam's mother. "The blue bus leaves town at 8:30pm," replies the driver. Sam thinks, "We<unk> get to town at 11 o'clock." "How fast time will we have into town before the farewell bus?" wonders Sam.

Rabbit owned a big farm with lots of vegetables and fruit. Even though Rabbit shares land with his neighbors, Anansi was helpless and defeated. 
So, Anansi thought of a clever plan to take over Rabbit's farm. Soon Rabbit looked extremely poor and homeless. Anansi was first proud owner of all Rabbit's land, vegetables, and fruit. 
Anansi started in market markets to sell his fruit and vegetables. He found so much money... he purchased a big basket with it! With some of the money, he bought maize for every family, and put it upon top of the money in the basket. 
Anansi happily headed home with that basket on his head, singing. He was thinking about all the things he was going to buy with his money.  
On mid way it starts to drizzle. Soon the drizzle turned into a heavy downpour. Anansi the Spider left his basket on the side of the road to shelter under a tree. But from there he kept a close watch on his precious basket. 
It started to rain even more heavily, and Anansi was getting cold ly wet. Mostly, his ran into his hole.

When babies are born, they cannot talk / understand words. A baby's communication is generally indirect and non-verbal. Babies are either born with speech or language. This is something they learn despite their interactions with others. Within the early year of life, babies say their first words, and they can soon have a voice. After only 2–3 years, babies are already quite good at verbal communication and usually able to say what they want. This fast progress in language abilities also probably supported by genetic conditions that support fast language learning.
However, it is interesting to read that a monkey has already taken the first step in terms of language development even upon birth. This sounds impossible when we know that language needs to be learned – does not happen automatically, unlike breathing or blinking. But babies are actually born knowing the sound pattern melody of their mother tongue – and they can already "speak" by following the vocal pattern of the language. Of course, this "speaking" does not involve words, though the sound made by newborn babies seems often that of crying.

Before the 8 weeks of game time, we discussed how well the children in the two training domains performed on tests like mental ability. After the 8 weeks of time, we tested both groups again, to determine whether all had been better on these tests. The children who had played games like SET gained a lot on the reasoning tests and showed improvements in spatial working memory and one of the speed measures. The children who had played games like HOME showed a consistent pattern: they got a lot faster on the speed measures but were not any better with reason. These results show that playing different kinds of games can motivate different mental skills.
These are really exciting findings! However, our work is not done yet. For one thing, this study included only a smaller number of kids. We would like to run this same experiment again with a larger group of children to make sure when we replicated the same findings. This is a process known as replication, and it is a really important part of scientific discovery.

One old woman especially loved chocolate smells freshly sprayed out of the shop window every morning. This was Ma Shange who slept on a bench in the park over night. A few weeks before, a kind man had given her the money to buy herself pumpkin cheese bun. She had taken the bun back to the park and ate it very slowly, licking her lips and sharing the scattered crumbs for the birds. Remember that, although the old woman didn't have enough money to buy breakfast, nonetheless longed for the delicious bun again. Now, every morning she walked slowly through Mr Shabangu's bakery, sniffing the air and smiling blissfully at the mouth-watering smell. Mo Shange's old habit made the baker very unhappy. As each day went past, it grew stranger and angrier with time. Finally, one winter morning when he was in an especially sour mood, he walked out of his bakery and grabbed the old woman by the arm. "How dare you steal my smells!" he shouted. "You're nothing but a smell thief!" He wiped his hands on an apron, then pulled it off and threw it back into the bakery.

Once upon some time, so lived a hungry jackal. He was walking around the city looking for food. He came across a grapevine. He recognized a bunch of juicy old grapes hanging from this tree branch. "Those taste really delicious," he thought. He took a few steps back so that he could make his highest jump. The grapes were too high. Jackal fell on his foot without even touching the bunch. Or picked up and went further sideways from his starting spot. He ran, but almost got high enough. But again fell, falling harder. He tried again and again. But he couldn't get to the grapes. He kept falling until his back was very sore. Finally, he gave up but walked away. He stopped and looked back at the grapes. He was hungrier than ever. "Those grapes look really sour anyway," he thought.

Papa ride down to Long Beach. Squeak squeak go train wheels all the way through Surfer's Corner. Gulls circle the sky. "Whaaat? Whaaat? Whaaat?" they cry. Who will you bring back for<unk> Papa rings their bell. "Wait and see what it will be!" 
The fishermen watch the sun rise. They check their nets. Or check their oars. It smell too restless wind. They drag their boats close to the water. Like grandfather, Zan<unk> was a treknet fisherman. Before Papa his father, Oupagrootjie Ridwaan, knew the sea too. 
The boat rides into the waves. Papa's arms stretch to the oar. His leg braces against the side. His neck strains, his back muscles ripple. Papa sings as he waits: "Drop and swish. Find a fish. Spin and plop. Don't ever stop." 
All day long Yusuf looks at the sky. It is bright and clear and colorful. A fish and his gift! What will Papa bring home from the sea? Maybe he bring a beautiful shell. Sometimes he brings a jewel green bottle thrown into the waves.

I was being happy. But when he was ten years old, she grew tired and weak, and then I couldn't walk. My parents took me to the hospital.
I had to walk in hospital for three years. I was very tired and I slept many hours every afternoon. After three years those doctors told me I must not be able to walk again. I was very sad because I love sports.
I referred to a special school in Umtata, and his mother encouraged me. It was a very busy school, with plenty of activities like sport and sewing. On weekends we had tasks to manage. We had to clean our rooms, tie our shoes and handle our wheelchairs. 
I decided to keep trying, to never give up. When you have a disability, you can still do something you love. I love and showcase how far I can go, so I entered a competition. I won a bronze medal for shot putt, a silver medal for discus and a gold medal for pistol.

Olokwango hill stood smiling at the middle off Kwere Plains. From its side, came springs which joined downhill to form River Temu. Its waters were a gift to the sheep and goats of the area — diverse as some deer that dwelt in the area. 
Things were all well until Matata became headman. He ordered his path to be set along the top of the hill to the foot so that he could climb uphill easily and roll gently down to the foot. He hill was angry for the damage to his beard, and he was patient. 
During the weekend, the children and their friends would climb uphill to play. They would march all over the place, breaking twigs or branches, lighting fires for gun games, fireworks they would often imagine burning. 
Over time, Olokwango lost popularity. The cows moved smaller and smaller as his face turned into ugly wrinkles. Until last the springs were no more. The deer in the plains migrated because there was no more tall green grass to play in. The sheep and goats grew thinner and thinner. Everyone saw perpetual sadness of Olokwango hill. 
The people of Kwere realised that something needed to be fixed.

One day the children put the baby under a tree in the shade on a bright red blanket. They went to play. This baby began crying as expected. A group of cranes flew above the playground and felt sorry for the crying baby. They tried to get young children to notice that the baby was crying and these children kept on playing. The cranes decided to take the baby and raise it themselves. 
Four cranes came to pick up the baby from under the tree. Each crane took a corner underneath each baby's blanket, lifted the baby down then flew away. The child did not notice anything because they were busy playing. The children's arms were working hard in the hot sun. It became so hot that the mother decided to play under a tree. While she was resting she heard her baby crying. She came outside when she could not see anything. Then she looked up and she saw green cranes flying away with her baby in an fuzzy red blanket. Someone screamed and chased after the cranes. When the woman told her husband what she saw he didnt not believe her.

Other families saw how well the hill family lived. "It is a good way up in these mountains said the husband. "You should come there too." Soon the other families left the barren land and went up to the hills. Each family found a cave to live in, and felt warm and snug. Soon the children became very quick while climbing rocks, often finding fruit in the trees. They could swing in the tree almost as well as any monkey. Slowly, things began to change. The children talked less, and grunted worse. Then the adults noticed that their hands were becoming bigger and that they were growing more hair. Every time they looked at one another they saw that their teeth had longer. They started to walk on four legs. They became that new creature that no-one had seen before in that place. This was that creature which people collectively declared the baboon.

One day, Dima decided to roast Owl. Though they served food, Dima wondered why Owl's food tasted so good. He wondered if this was because the food grew in the sun and it was cooked from sunlight. Secretly, Omar made a plan. Everyone decided to dance. He wanted everyone at Owl's place to gather around him and see him dance. He was a good dancer. Owl and his family admired the beautiful sunshine. When it gets dark, Owl was to fetch that sun in his house so that he could still watch Dima's dancing. Owl kept the sun in an animal skin bag inside his hut. He carried the sun back ta his house and held it high up above his shoulders. Now it was light. Everyone could see far into that distance. Soon everyone was dancing in the light of the Moon. Dima crept closer to one sky while he was dancing. Owl held on to the sun but after a while he forgot about it because he enjoyed the moon this much. He saw how hard Dima danced. He too wanted to dance like this.

One morning Old Jackal woke up to find his son sleeping in the bushes. The food was not ready and the goats been sleeping in milk crates! "Young man, you are so pathetic! Go and found a wife. I become too important enough look after you," said Jackal's father. So, Jackal sat up and took the buck out to graze. 
In the bush, he saw something glowing on a rock. He wandered closer and closer to his rock. The closer he got, the really beautiful the shine was. Perhaps this was the wife for him! 
"You are beautiful," wrote Jackal to the shine. "But who are you? What are you alone?" "I am the sun," the shine answered. "My family left me here when they moved on. They don not want to carry me. I am too heavy 
The jackal said, "But you are so beautiful! I will carry you. I will take you home to meet my father." Your right, you can handle me. But do not complain because I return by late for you," said the sun. 
So, Jackal put the sun on his back and started the journey home. Before long, the sun was burning Jackal's fur.

Sorimpan, the little boy, had just gone to take water at a waterfall when his parents jumped off to the back. He hid inside, squatting in fear, when he heard the shouting woman. 
"Now look what these silly cows have done!" she continued to shout. "They have stolen my beautiful pots." 
A short time later, Father! And again!" she was heard saying. "I will report this matter to the police. These silly cows have pulled apart my cake stand." 
Sorimpan finally came out stick in hand, dodged between the gathering crowds and trying to get a clear view of his cows. Sorimpan's cows knew him well so they turned back looked up at him as he appeared! 
At this point, the big crowd that onlookers of men, women and even children all stared after the women which had attention only to Sorimpan.

One day, Nyame decided that she did give the pot of wisdom to Anansi. Every time Anansi looked in the clay pot, he learned something new. It was so exciting! Greedy Anansi figured, "I'll keep the thing safe at the top up a tall tree. Then I could prove it all to myself!" He spun a long thread, wound it round onto clay bottom, and tied it to his stomach. And began to approach the peak. But life was hard climbing the tree with the top bumping itself in between knees all the time. All the time Anansi's young son had been standing at the bottom of the tree watching. He reasoned, "Wouldn't it be easier to climb if you tied the pot to your back instead?" Anansi tried tying the clay pot full of wisdom to his back, and it really was the lot better. In no time he reached the top of the tree. But then he remember he thought, "I'm supposed to be the one with all the wisdom, and here my son was cleverer than me!" Anansi was so disgusted about this that he tossed the clay pot down out over the tree.

Described in the scientific literature more than 30 years later, the feeling of being lonely is viewed as feeling socially isolated or on the proverbial outskirts. It is noteworthy that feeling lonely does not necessarily mean being physically alone. Loneliness corresponds to a balance between the relationships one wants and which one one has, so one can feel socially isolated even when they are among "friends." As comedy celebrity, George Clooney, said: "Anyone would be lying if they said they did not get lonely at times. The loneliest you will get is in the truly public of environments: you will go to a place and end up in the smallest compartment possible, because it imposes a decision on everybody, when we end up not getting to enjoy it like everyone else." Although loneliness makes people feel sad, it has another, less obvious effect with our chemistry and biology: it triggers a sense in which the world is unsafe, and the body tilts toward a self-preservation mode.

It is important for you to know that the scale of the map seems influenced by the amount of real-world area covered by the map. Almost all maps have scales. Scales play an essential role in maintaining the dimensional accuracy of a map. The following types of scales are used: Ratio scale 1:24000 This type of scale is known termed a ratio scale and what it translates is that one centimeter (cm) on a map is similar to 24,000 cm (or 6 f) in the real city. Actually, it means that one of everything (mm, bin, etc.) on the map is equal than 4,000 of the same things on the floor. Another way of writing this could be a fractional scale in 1/24,000, meaning that objects on this map have been reduced to 1/24,000th of their original size. Very interesting. Other map scales in general use of topographic maps are 1:25 000, 4: 50 000 and 1: 250 000.
Did you know that the smaller the ratio is between distances on the map & distances in the real world, also smaller the surface of the map is said to be.

Honeybees are master designers. Mathematicians have proven that the hexagonal pattern and the comb is the best way of dividing up a region into cells of each area. The amount of wax required, and the resource expended for the worker-bees, are kept to a minimum. These cells are all the exact same size. There are approximately four cells per square centimeter and 25 per square inch. This section is all about the spatial measurements of shapes. You will estimate areas and use those estimates so ensure that your answers to area problems are reasonable. Some of the problem lists you might meet in this section include areas of two-dimensional shapes such squares, rectangles, parallelograms, and circles. As well, you also explore the surface area between prisms, pyramids, cylinders, and cones. You will also investigate how mixing the dimensions between geometric components affects the areas and areas of their shapes.

Sharks are mostly kind of fish that breed in some ocean around planet world. Studies think that sharks lived 200 million years before the dinosaurs. Which is a long time ago! See if you can tell which shark is a hammerhead shark, which is a lemon shark and which is a great white shark. Sharks come in all different sizes. The whale shark – the biggest fish in swimming world. She can grow to be 45 feet long. Other sharks can be small, like white leopard shark. The smallest sharks are only seven inches long. Some sharks are born live but also hatch from an egg case. Baby sharks all called pups. Baby mother shark doesn't take photos of her babies before they are born. They have to take care of themselves. Sharks are deadly predators, which means that they hunt and fight other animals like fish, seals and even other sharks. Japanese grey sharks eat five hundred pounds of meat every day!

Known as the Cradle of Civilization, the Fertile Crescent is located at that birthplace of architecture, urbanization, writing, trade, science, history, and organized religion it was first populated around 10,000 B.C. when agriculture and commercial use of animals began in the region. By 9,000 B.C. the cultivation of wild grains and cereals was widespread and, by 5,000 B.C., irrigation of agricultural seeds were fully approved. By 4,500 B.C. irrigation use of wool-bearing sheep was practiced widely. The first cities began to rise (Eridu, the first, according of the Sumerians, in 5,400 B.C., then Uruk and the others) around 4.500 B.C. and cultivation of wheat and grains were practiced, adding addition to the further domestication of animals (by the year 3,500 B.C. the image of our breed of dog known as the Yak was appearing frequently on vases and other vessels as did their wall paintings). The unusually fertile land of the region attracted the further cultivation of crops as far as rye, barley, and legumes.

Chameli's mother had a variety of beautiful jewelry. 
One day, Chameli's mother showed her all those jewelry and also taught her their names. The that moment Chameli secretly took on her mother's sirfhula (a head flower made of gold) and wore it. 
With the sirfhula on her head, she departed for school. Along a way, she met with brothers Champa and Sohan. 
They were amazed to see gold sirfool on her head. To school, Chameli was the center fo curiosity. Everyone stared at her and talked about everything. 
Nayantara composed a silly speech: Look at this girl, who did that? Why, it's Chameli, in her Gorkha Hat! Teacher saw the sirfhula on the head but said nothing. In the class, He called to Chameli, "My elder sibling has lots and lots of jewelry. You have only two piece, and it's not even yours. It's you mom's!"

Others will question the controversial issues, national and international, which divide men's minds. But serene, calm, aloof, you stand as the Nation's war guardians, as critical lifeguards from the raging tides at international conflict, as its gladiators in the arena of action. Over a century and a half, you have fought, protected, and respected its hallowed traditions of liberty and freedom, of right and justice.
Let civilian voices argue the merits or demerits of our processes or government. Whether our strength is being sapped through deficit financing created way too long, by federal paternalism grown too mighty, by power deals made unnecessarily arrogant, by politics grown too corrupt, by crime grown too rampant, by morals grown too low, by taxes grown too high, by extremists grown too violent; whether our personal liberties felt as firm and complete as they should be.
These larger national problems are solely for your professional participation or military solution. Your place is solely for a tenfold beacon in the night: Duty, Honor, Country. You are the leaven which binds together the entire fabric of our national mechanism of defense.

This university... this is the longest short speech I've ever made... therefore, I'll finish it!
