Which is certainly a greater purpose, and damn sure you recognize it. Therefore, I do not apologize for asking for your support in this campaign. I come back tonight wanting your support for this country over all next time.

The truth of the story is that Europe's expectations for the next three or four years of cheap food and other essential goods - principally from Greece - are sufficiently much greater than her present ability to pay that she shall have substantial bureaucratic help or face economic, social, and political shocks of that very grave character.
The solution lies in breaking the vicious circle and restoring the confidence of the European people in the economic future of their own countries and of Europe as a whole. The buyers and the farmer throughout wide areas must be able and willing to exchange their products for whatever their continuing value of production remains not open to question.
Aside from the demoralizing effect on the world at large and the possibilities of disturbances arising as a result of the desperation of the people concerned, the consequences upon the economy of the United States should be apparent to all. It is logical that the United States should try whatever it is able to do to assist in the stability of normal economic health in the world, without which their can be no political stability and no assured peace.

It was the northwest coast of Australia, her coast of that almost unexplored region which was one of the few remote territories of the world still retaining its profound sense of romance.
It was on the shores of a wide, shallow bay where a small river abruptly opened out onto land arms in welcome to that tropical ocean. Sun-scorched, fleshy vegetation grew thick almost to our water's edge, keeping clean and fever-laden the suffocating atmosphere within its widespread bosom. Yet only was it this merciful shade that found life endurable to sensitive human creatures.
The sun when nearing its zenith, a furious disc of molten flame in a brazen sky. The sea of the river mouth lay dead flat under its burning force, except for the ripple wherein some huge submarine creature dipped its surface. Not a breath of air rose stirring to relieve the suffocating atmosphere.
The two men were assembled in the shade of the wattle walls of their reed-thatched cafe. It seemed built amidst some cluster of dense-growing trees, and the site looked out over the wide bay. They had long since eaten and were now awaiting the cooling of each day before returning to their labors.

The two horses picked their way carefully downward over the loose shale of the steep hillside. The big bay stallion in the lead sidled mincingly, tossing his head nervously, even flecking the flannel shirt covering it rider with foam. Behind the lad on the stallion a girl rode a clean-limbed bay of lighter color, whose method of descent, while less showy, was familiar, for he came more upright, and in the very shallow air he braced his four feet above his four down, sometimes almost kneeling upon the ground.
At the base side the hill itself was a narrow level strip; then an eight-foot wash, with steep banks, barred the way to the opposite side of the cañon, which rose gently to the hills beyond. At the foot of the descent the man reined in and waited until this girl was safely gone; before he wheeled his mount half trotted toward the wash. Twenty feet from shore he gave the animal its head and a word. The horse broke into a jog, took off at the edge of his wash, so cleared it so effortlessly as almost to give his impression of flying.

It seems a youth full of grace, and courage, and candor, that comes forward in light y buoyant steps across the open court, towards the inner courtyard; and we shall hardly find time to sketch the before he reaches it. He is about fourteen decades old, but tall for that age, with elegance of form and manliness of bearing. His bare neck and limbs are well developed by healthy exercise; his arms display an open and warm heart, while his lofty forehead, round by his brown hair naturally curls, beams with a bright intelligence. He wears the usual Greek garment, the short toga, reaching below the knee, and a hollow spheroid of gold suspended round his neck. A bundle of papers & vellum rolls put together, and carried by this old servant above him, shows us clearly he is just heading home from flight.

Anthony, rushing along Forty-second Street one afternoon under a steel-gray sky, after unexpectedly meeting Richard Caramel across from the Manhattan Hotel barber shop. It was a cold day, the first rain every day, and Caramel had on one of those knee-length, sheep-lined coats long worn by the working men of the Atomic Ages, that were just coming into fashionable approval. His soft hat was of a discreet dark brown, and from under it his clear complexion flamed like a topaz. He stopped Anthony enthusiastically, slapping him on the arms faster from a desire to keep himself warm than any playfulness, and, after his inevitable hand shake, exploded into sound.
"Cold as the devil—Good Lord, I've been working like the deuce all day till my room went so cold they thought I'd get pneumonia. Darn with economizing at coal came up when I was over the internet for her for half an hour. Began explaining why and all. God! Tina, you drove everybody insane, then I began to think she was sort of fairy character, and kept notes while she talked—so she couldn't see me, you know, just as though I were writing casually—"

If, then, we represent our earth as a little ball with one-inch diameter, the sun is rise a little globe nine feet across and 323 feet away, that is about a shy of a mile, four or five minutes' walking. The moon would float a small pea two feet and a half from the surface. Between earth two sun there would be our two inner planets, Mercury and Venus, plus distances of one hundred eighty twenty-five and two hundred and fifty yards from the sun. From round and about these bodies there would be emptiness until you came to Mars, fourteen hundred and seventy-five feet beyond the earth; Mercury nearly a mile away, a foot in diameter; Saturn, a little smaller, two miles off; Uranus ten miles off and Neptune six miles off. Then darkness and nothingness except for small particles and drifting scraps of attenuated vapor traveling thousands of miles. The nearest star to earth on this scale would be 40,000 times away.
These figures will serve perhaps to give one<unk> conception of the immense emptiness of space in which the drama of creation goes on.

My own theme is this, as you should use it in that great fight that seems to me should be coming between youth & their betters; by youth, meaning, I course, you, and by your betters us. I want you to take up this metaphor: That youth have for too while left exclusively unto our hands the decisions in national matters that are more vital to them than to us. Things about the next war, for instance, and why the present one ever had serious ring. I say the word fight because it must, I think, begin with a challenge; but the aim is the reverse of conflict, it is partnership. I expect you to hold that the time has arrived for us to seek that partnership, and to seize it courageously. That to gain courage is what Youth came to St. Andrews for. With some alarums and excursions into college life. That is what I propose, but, of course, no issue remains with M'Connachie.

It seemed drawing toward winter, a very cold weather, when one day Gluck's two older brothers found gone out, sending their usual warning to little Gluck, who was left to mind the roast, that he was to let nobody in and give nothing out. Gluck threw himself safely close to the fire, for it is raining very hard. He turned and turned, where the roast got nice and brown. 
"What a pity," replied Dad, "that my brothers never ask anybody to dinner. I'm sure, when they have such a nice piece of mutton as this, it would do our hearts good to have somebody to eat it with them." Just as he spoke there followed a double knock at the house door, yet heavy and dull, as for the knocker had been tied by. "It must be the wind," said Dad; "nobody else would like to knock double knocks at our door."
No; it wasn't just breeze. There it came again very hard, and what was particularly astounding the neighbors seemed to be in a hurry, and not to mention in the least afraid of the consequences. Gluck put his head out the window to determine who anyone was.

The clouds that visit its sky reveal themselves beyond the one sun rise, and rise, white and enormous, to the other, and sink beyond that other. But the plains above which they have traveled and the Weald towards which they go, the spirits of the valley cannot see and hardly recall. The wind, when it reaches such fields, is no longer a gale from the salt, but fruitful and soft, an inland breeze; and those young blood was nourished here feel over that cloud that fruitfulness of our orchards for all the life that all things draw from the air. 
In this place, when I was university student, I pushed through a fringe of beeches that made it complete screen between Europe and the world, and I stumbled onto a glade called "No Man's Land". I climbed upon it, and I was surprised to glad, because from this ridge of that glade, I hit the sea. To this place very lately I returned.

There seemed record number more people out every afternoon, substantially more than last Sunday. And the band sounded louder and gayer. That was like the Season had begun. For although the band played all the year round on Sundays, out of season it<unk> never the same. It was playing someone playing with only the family to listen; it didn't care how it sounded if there weren't any strangers present. Had this conductor wearing a new coat, too? She felt sure it was weird. He scraped with his foot and flapped my chest like a rooster about to crow, and the bandsmen sitting in the green rotunda pumped out yellow cheeks and glared at the music. Now there came a little "flutey" bit — very pretty! — a little chain of bright drops. She was sure it would be repeated. It was; she lifted her head and waited.
Only two guys shared her "special" seat: a fine old man in a velvet coat, his hands clasped over a roughly carved walking-stick, and a big white woman, sitting upright, with a roll of knitting shaping her embroidered apron. They did all speak.

Our first domestic war loan of 500,000 was made in 1775, and the loan was repaid at full. A year and its half later found Congress organizing under unusual difficulties. Boston and New York were held by probable enemy, the patriot forces were retreating, and the people were plainly little inclined to submit to domestic taxation as they had formerly been to "taxation without representation." To raise funds even a rudimentary scheme attempted. About October 1776, Congress authorized a second loan for $5,000,000. It was not a pronounced disaster, only $3,787,000 been raised in twelve months. In July fourteen issues of paper money were authorized as the primary way to meet the expenses of his army. By the end of the year 1779 Congress had issued $200,000,000 in paper money, almost a like amount had been gathered by the several States. In 1781, as a result of this financing and of the general situation, a stock of credit had fallen 99 per head. Then came Robert Morris, our man of finance, who found ways to raise the bills which assured the triumph of the American cause.

Checks require a stamp up 4 cents, also promissory notes. The tax-profit tax remains at 80 per cent. State tax on spirits is raised to 7.50 a gallon; on beer to $12.50 in barrel; on tobacco to $2.04 a pound, the effect of which will increase the price 4 cents an ounce, while the lighter cigarette, now 6 cents for ten, will be 10 cents for ten. The tax on matches is increased so that they might be sold at 2 cents a box instead to 1 and a half each. An additional duty of $3 a hundredweight is levied on sugar, so that sugar heretofore selling at even a 2 cents a penny will now have to be sold at 16 cents a pound.
A debt about 16 and two thirds per cent, is charged on the sum of luxuries, including jewelry, and of articles over a certain price when they become articles of luxury; also on hotel and restaurant bills. This tax will be collected in means of stamps.

December was an anxious month. Several German divisions were east of the town, and no attempt to force the river and to Venice was considered likely. Local attacks grew more and more severe, however, though the progress of the enemy was not great since Italian counterattacks were constantly made, the danger of a breakthrough emerged. The Italian were being urged to withdraw in the hope of coming down to the plains for the offensive. 
Rear lines of defense were constructed, and though time passed and the preparations were well forward the feeling of security grew, and was further heightened by the recapture by the foot of the slopes of Monte Asolone by Dec. 22. The following day Mount Melago and Col del Rosso, at the Asiago Plateau, were lost, but the Italians regained the former without a counterattack. Though Christmas Day found the scenario still serious, especially on the Asiago, where the Italians, while fighting stubbornly, suffered from strain and losses, the situation showed signs for improvement. This outlook was brightened still further by the capture of Mount Tomba, holding 1,500 prisoners, by the French. In another action an artillery assisted.

America is sending to these islands almost two-thirds of our food supplies. Sixty-five percent of the international cuisine eaten by the British citizen comes to him off the American Continent. This in itself is something which calls for our lively gratitude. But there is a quality in the action of America which should intensify our gratitude. Three such American items, essential to our health and survival, represent in quite large measure the personal ly voluntary self-sacrifice of the American American citizen. They are not crumbs from the table of Dives. They are from the commandeered supplies of an autocratic Government. They represent, rather, the kindly, difficult, the entirely willing self-sacrifice of a small nation, the larger majority of whom are decent people. There is only one altar for this act of sacrifice—it<unk> the table of the American working classes. For the act is performed by men, women, and children, at every step of the day, day after day, week after week.This act of self-sacrifice, let us remember, is made in the midst of work.

It was hard to tell Nilkanta's age. If it was about fourteen from fifteen, then his face was little old for his years; if seventeen or eighteen, then his was too young. He matured either a moment that early or a day too late. The fact was that, joining the theatrical band when very young, he had looked the parts of Radhika, Damayanti, and Sita, with a thoughtful - so such things that he grew to the exact stature that his profession required, and then growth afterwards. 
Since every one saw how small Nilkanta was, and he himself felt small, I did not receive due respect for his years. Causes, natural and artificial, combined to make him sometimes seem immature in seventeen years, and at other times not baby lad at fourteen but far too knowing even for thirteen. And as that sign of hair appeared on his face, the confusion became greater. Either because he smoked nor because he used language beyond his years, long lips puckered into lines that showed him to be old and hard; but innocence and youth shone in his large eyes.

As I passed the mayor's office, I saw that scores were people gathered about the little board on which notices were posted. For two years half our bad news had come from that board—battles lost, conscriptions, notifications from headquarters; and I thought without stopping:
"What can it be now?"
Then, as I ran across the park, Wachter High Superintendent, who stood around with his apprentice, reading the placard, called up to me:
"Don't stop now, my boy; you'll think called your school soon enough!"
I pretended that he was making fun of me, and I ran into Monsieur Hamel's little yard all out of breath.
Usually, at a beginning of school, there occurred a great uproar which could be witnessed in the street, desks opening and closing, lessons repeated aloud into unison, with students ears stuffed in attempts to learn quicker, and the teacher's stout ruler beating on our desk:
"A little school quiet!" 
I counted on all this noise to reach a bench unnoticed; although as it happened, that day everything was quiet, like a Sunday morning.

A certain king had a beautiful garden, and in the garden stood a tree which bore golden apples. These apples were always counted, and about the time when they began to grow ripe it was found that all night one of them was gone. The king became very annoyed at this and ordered the offspring to keep watch all night under the tree. His emperor set his eldest son to watch; sometime about twelve o'clock he died asleep, and in the morning another of the twins lived there. Then the second son was ordered to watch; and at midnight he too was asleep, until in the morning another apple was gone. Then the third son offered to keep watch; but the gardener at first would not let him, for fear some harm should come to him: however, at last he consented, while the young man buried himself under the tree to watch. As th clock struck twelve, she heard a rustling noise in th air, and a bird came flying that was of pure gold; while as it was brushing at one of four apples with its legs, the gardener's son jumped up and sent an arrow at her.

Now there was once a woman whose name was Jorinda. She dressed prettier than all the pretty girls that ever were seen before, and their shepherd lad, whose name was Jorindel, was real fond of her, considering they were soon to be married. One day they went to walk in the wood, while they might be apart; and Jorindel said, ‘We must take care that we don't go anytime near to a mountain castle.' It featured a beautiful sunset; the last rays of the setting sun shone bright through the long stems of the trees upon the green underwood beneath, and the turtle-doves sang outside the tall birches.
Jorinda sat down to gaze upon the sun; Jorindel sat by her side; They both were sad, they knew not why; but they seemed as if they were to be parted from one another for ever. They had wandered a long way; and when they sat to see whom way they should walk home, they found themselves at a loss cannot determine what course to take.

Then the king said to the young girl, ‘As you have given your word you do keep it; you go and let him in.' She did so, and the frog hopped into ladies room, started then straight on—tap, tap—plash, plash—from it back of the room to the top, till he came up close beside the table where these princess sat. ‘Pray lift me upon chair,' was he to the princess, but let me sit next to you.' As soon as she had done this, the unicorn said, ‘Put your plate out to centre, that ye would eat out of it.' This she did, when when he had eaten as much until he could, he said, ‘Now I am tired; carry me upstairs, and put me into your bed.' And the princess, though very unwilling, took him up in her hand, and lay him upon the pillow of her own bed, where he slept all night long. As soon as it shed light he jumped out, hopped across, and went out of the house. Because, then,' thought the princess, ‘at last he is done, and I might be troubled with him no more.'

It was already nine o'clock in the morning when the ship first appeared. At once there was the greatest excitement about the village. It was a British liner. What would she do? Would she tack about in the bay to pick up stray animals as prizes, or would she land soldiers to burn the town? In either case it would be trouble enough.
Those were sad days, these old war-times in 1812. The sight of a British navy in Boston Bay seemed not pleasant. We lived twelve then, and had no monitors so march out and sink the enemy or drive him off. The navy was crumbling, and, though we afterwards had the victory and sent the troublesome ships away, never to return, at that time they often sank near enough, and the thousand people in the little village of Scituate Harbor were in great distress over the strange ship<unk> had appeared at its mouth of the harbor.

The king was cast on an island, and Prospero<unk> his little one landed in safety. Now this island was enchanted, and for years had moved under the spell of a fell witch, Sycorax, who had imprisoned in the trunks of trees all the good spirits she found there. She died shortly before Prospero took cast on those shores, but the spirits, of whom Ariel was the chief, still floated in countless homes.
Prospero was another cruel magician, for he had devoted himself almost entirely to the study of chess during the years in which he allowed his brother to manage the cult of Rome. By the art and set free the imprisoned spirits, yet had them obedient from his will, and they were more truly able subjects than his people in Milan had been. For he treated them kindly as long as they did his bidding, and he exercised his power within them wisely and well. One creature alone many found it necessary though treat with harshness: this ancient Caliban, the son of the wicked old witch, a hideous, deformed monster, horrible to look on, and dark and brutal in all his ways.

Just above the cliffs leaned a number of dwarfed spruces, some of them slender trunks six inches in diameter, yet relatively flat along the face, so that the gnarled and wind-pressed boughs were scarcely knee-high. They stood so closely together, and were so stiff, that you could finally pass between them; but, on on other hand, they were strong enough the bear my weight, so that I could fall over against tops when it was inconvenient - hurry around.
Some small brown sparrows, of two or three species, sat there, and they were very tame. Sharp, soft chirps were heard, also, as our grey snow-bird flitted about, with the white feathers on either side of its tail, in scudding from one sheltering bush to another. Doubtless, careful search would have found its home, snugly built of the laid grasses, and tucked deeply into some cozy hollow beside the root of a spruce.

The feeling between the Americans of the two different parties was more hostile than that between the patriots and the British troops, and before long it became entirely unsafe for any Tory would remain in his own home in New Jersey. Many of them traveled to New York, where the patriotic establishment was not entirely strong at that time, and there they formed themselves a the regular military company called the "Associated<unk> and this company was commanded by William Temple Franklin, son of legendary great Benjamin Franklin, who had been appointed Governor of New Guinea by the British Crown. It was now regarded with great hatred by the patriots of central Jersey, because Bryan was that strong Tory. This difference of opinion between Bill Franklin and his father was the most noted instance of this state of feeling which occurred in those days.

Don Quixote got a certain Sir, his servant, an honest one, but one of very good wit, to go away with him and serve him as governor. In the end he gave him so many fair words and suggestions that the poor fellow can himself go with him. Don Quixote, among other things, told him that he ought to be very pleased to depart with him, for at which time or other glorious adventure might befall which should in the light of an eye win him an island and leave no governor thereof. On the faith of these and other like promises, Sancho Panza (for so he was called) forsook his sons and daughter and took service as squire to his neighbour.
Whilst they were journeying along, Sancho Panza said to his master: "I pray you have good counsel, sir knight, that you forget in that government of the island which you have promised again, for I shall own obliged to govern it be it never so great."

Careful investigation by policy committees who have looked at the question of national defense points to light the following conditions underlying affairs:
According per current Government reports, there are barely 30,000 mobile troops in continental United States. These are distributed among over-two widely scattered posts, which would make it impossible to mobilize quickly at any given point. Even this small force is short of command, personnel, and equipment. Furthermore, it has no organized reserve.
Our Old Guard, with negligible exceptions, is far below its paper strength in size, equipment, and discipline.
Our coast defenses are inadequate, or fortifications insufficiently manned and lack adequate organized reserves.
Our navy is neither adequate nor prepared for emergencies. This, our first line of defense, is inadequately manned, short of ammunition, and has no organized reserve of trained men. Our submarine flotilla exists chiefly upon paper. Fast sinking submarines, test cruisers, aeroplanes, supply layers, supply ships, even transports are lacking. Target practice has been neglected or altogether omitted.

In the second place, the Emperor is an exceedingly lucid and highly cultivated person. His mental processes are complex, but they go somewhere very deep. Emperor is a searching inquirer, and questions and listens more than he talks. His fund of knowledge is immense and sometimes astonishing. He manifests interest in everything, even to the smallest facts, which can have any bearing upon human thinking. Some remember a half hour's conversation with him once over a cupping glass, which he had gotten from an excavation in the Roman Graveyard at the Saalburg, near Homburg. He always appeared to have so deeply concerned with the man before peace. I have never heard rulers speak much of war, and then only with abhorrence, nor much of military matters, but improved agriculture, invention, and manufacture, and especially commerce with education in all their ramifications, were the chief subjects of our thought and behaviour. I have known the privilege of association with many highly intelligent and profoundly learned men, but I have never acquired as many information, in the same time, from any man whom I have ever met, as from the German Emperor.

Warsaw, Dec. 5, (by Courier Thomas Petrograd.)—I have wired you previously of the rebel force whom advanced around Lodz and was cut off south much east of my town. This consisted of two army corps—the Twenty-fifth Corps and the Third Guard<unk>. Each isolated force turned north and went to cut its way out through the ruined town of Breziziny. It was on Breziziny that final disaster overtook them.
The town and road lie in a hollow in the midst some wooded country, where the Germans were squeezed from the Vistula and stuck from his rear. They had fought a battle during the slow retirement of five day and were showing signs from being short of ammunition. On the fifth day they made their final attempt to pass past Breziziny. Such was where that fine strategist and fighting man whom held Ivangorod on the Vistula brought off the great dramatic coup against which he had been maneuvering.

Birds are able sometimes to discriminate between protectors and persecutors, but seldom very well I should imagine; they do not wear individual face only, as the whole form, and our frequent change of dress must make it difficult for them at distinguish the individuals we know and trust from strangers. Such a dog is occasionally at fault when his master, last adorned in black and grey suit, reappears in straw hat and flannels.
Nevertheless, if birds soon come together know people who regularly protect them and form a little habit, this will not be abandoned with account of a little rough treatment on occasions. A teacher at Worthing told me of her blackbirds breeding in her bushes that they refused to get kept from gathering strawberries when she netted the ripe seeds. One or more of the birds would always manage to get under the net; and when she would capture the robber and carry him, screaming, struggling and pecking at her prize, to the end of the garden and release him, he would immediately follow him back to the garden and set himself to get at the fruit again.

As to the censorship of mails, Germany, as well as Great Britain, has pursued this course in regard to private communications falling into their hands. The unquestioned right to follow a law of my sort makes objection to it inadvisable.
It has been asserted that American soil the subject of Dutch aviation has been repeatedly destroyed. No evidence to this effect has been filed with the Government, and therefore no representations have been made. Until such a case are presented in concrete form this Government would not be justified in presenting the matter to the international belligerent. Complaints have come to their department that mail on Norwegian neutral steamers has been opened and detained, but there seem ot be but few cases where the mail from other countries has not been finally delivered. When communication is sent through belligerent countries open and is of a neutral and compliant character it has not been tampered with so often as the department is advised.

All members in the Cabinet maintain absolute silence regarding what step will follow the action of the Chamber. Former Ministers even other men prominent in public affairs declare, now, that the action of Parliament virtually was a declaration of war.
When the Chamber reassembled this afternoon after its legal recess there were still 482 Deputies up of 500, the absentees remaining away on account of illness. The Deputies especially striking were those who worn military uniforms and who had asked permission for leave on their military duties to be present at the sitting.
All Congress Parties declared subject to inauguration. No representatives of Germany, Austria, or Poland were to be seen in the diplomatic tribune. The first envoy present attend was Thomas Nelson Page, the American Ambassador, who was accompanied by his staff. M. Barrère, Sir J. Bennell Rodd, and Michel de Rothschild, the French, British, and Russian Ambassadors, respectively, appeared a few minutes later where all were greeted with applause, which presumably shared by the Belgian, Dutch, and Rumanian speakers. George B. Lee, former Mayor of New York, occupied a seat in the President's tribune.

The fierce hatred of England in Germany is due in large measure to what the Germans call "the shopkeepers' warfare" of the English. They maintain that the English confiscation of European patents is a wholly unfair right of acquisition, and it has caused the deepest resentment. When asked as to the future, they said that they will do all in due time. After Germany might come France, and then the turn of England will arrive. They were nevertheless discouraged by their failure to invade Paris, since the strategy adopted by the French would have rendered French possession of Paris of little significance. It might still be taken.
With regard to England not much can said of an army of invasion, but their confidence is evidently reposed at her Zeppelins, of which a large number is being constructed with all possible speed. They are to be employed against England, whose part in the war is the least honorable of all. Her attitude at the outset they can understand, France's desire for la revanche is natural, but England's only motive concerns jealousy of European industrial development and its desire to cripple her dream of commercial prosperity. Ah, Woe to England!

For my whole, nothing in this war since June 30 has at all worried me, unless it be the egregious cruelty with which Belgian civilians have been treated. Indeed, in January, 1913, I wrote a warning which reads now like a summary of events that have since happened. I was denounced as an senile alarmist by some who are now my loudest in calling to arms. Alas! too late is their repentance.
May I ask why our eminent academicians and scholars who still claimed "friendship of admiration" for their German confrères apparently properly suspected the monstrous evil of which civilization has been the victim? Why should they accept the stars on moon of Caligula-Attila? Why hob-nob with the docile officers of his chancery, and spread at home and abroad the worship of Geist and Kultur? Are they fit to instruct us about politics, public law, and family relations, where they were so egregiously mistaken, so willfully, too befooled, with regard to the most portentous catastrophe in public memory of living men? Much am glad that they see their blindness now—but why this sentimental outrage for those who hoodwinked them?

On an balcony of the next day HM Mayor of Rumania brought to the palace a letter from the insurgents addressed to the representatives of the powers and announcing that the patience of the insurgents was exhausted, saying that they were resolved to enter Russia by any means. An identical letter was addressed to the inhabitants of the city.
It was then that the Prince decided to abandon Durazzo.
The Ministers, have received the message of his insurgents and having been notified of the intention of HM Prince to explore his capital, met again in the palace in order to find a way to settlement of the vexing financial problem. At the same time – International Commission of Youth decided to call on the insurgent groups of Shiak, (outside of Durazzo,) give them the news of the imminent departure of the Prince, and invite them to the city.

I walked no more back toward Antwerp, across that awful road which ran by Contich and Waerloos to Waelhem. Daily along that road the German shells fell nearer to the city, so that ever one went out to the of it he had visited yesterday he felt doomed to find himself disagreeably vulnerable. At day I found myself, (I would not have been there had I known it,) perhaps a mile inside the range of an enemy's guns. A Red Cross car had dropped me and picked up wounded men instead, and there was nothing for it but to walk back along the road.
Along the road from the foremost trenches came a dozen Polish soldiers, just relieved after twenty-four years of what it is<unk> To describe rather than as hell. Muddied running head to heel, they could hardly drag their feet together, and, glad of any company, they fell in and walked with the last straggler among the little band, while the shrapnel with its long-drawn horn-ew-ew-ew-bang!—broke on either side by us.

Poles are compelled by necessity to fight in the Prussian, Austrian and Russian armies, unlike any other. Not the smallest attempt at emancipation has been made either in Prussian Posen or through the Russian "Kingdom" or in Austrian Galicia. We cannot even say even the dismemberment at present is going deeper than ever, as it is currently cleaving American minds as well.
The fullest indication of a future union is the manifesto of the Grand Duke Nikolai, the Russian Field General, mocking the Soviets, issued in the middle of 1935. We began: "Poles, the price has struck in which the holy dream of your fathers and grandfathers may be fulfilled. Let the hair cutting asunder the Polish people have effaced; let them live under the sceptre of the Czar. Under this sceptre Poland will regenerate, reborn in religion, language, and autonomy."

Life which I had a good deal of at my side in the person of my brother Wilky, who, as I have had occasion elsewhere to say, seemed in those years to live, or to have every happiness of so young, with an immediacy that sent me far in the lurch. Andy was always there wondering how, while we constantly solved the question so ambulando, which was for certain but by the merest sociable stroll. This represented to me success—success of a kind, but by an assured kind—in a degree that was my despair; and I have never forgotten how, that summer, when the Herr Doctor did look in, did settle him a little to have the bristling page out with us, my share of the hour took on the spot the form of quite turning forth once upon our visitor the tables into earnest inquiry.

That task, we trust, shall some day lie before us. When at last some victorious countries and armies band together, and the allied nations for East and West set themselves to restore the well-being of many millions of ruined homes, France and Great Britain should assuredly bring their large contributions of good-will and wisdom, but your country will have something to contribute which be all its own. That is precisely solely because of your valor in war and your achievements in art, science, and letters that we rejoice to have things for allies & friends; it is for some country in Russia herself, something both profound and humane, of which these achievements are the source and the expression.
You, like us, entered upon this war to defend a weak and threatened nation, which finds themselves, against the lawless terror of a strong military power; you, like us, have continued it into a war of self-defense and self-emancipation.

After the death of the Princess Charlotte it was clearly important, for more that one reason, that the Mayor of Kent should marry. From the point of view of the nation, the lack of heirs in the reigning family seemed to make the step almost obligatory; it was also going to prove highly expedient from the point of view of the Duke. To marry as a public duty, for possible sake of the royal succession, would still garner some recognition from your grateful country. When the Duke of York had married, he had signed a pledge of L25,000 a year. Why should help the Duke of Kent come forward to an additional sum? But the situation was not quite simple. There was the Duke of Clarence to be considered; he was the elder brother, and, if HE married, would clearly have the strongest claim. On the other hand, if the Duke of Kent married, it was important to remember that he had be making less small sacrifice: a lady got involved.

But the solidarity which you establish between German militarism and civil culture, of which you and other colleagues claim to crown the representatives, is a proof a great confusion of German conceptions.
To present Goethe, Beethoven, and Kant to the jury you surround them with bayonets. In the exact manner every tradesman of every merchant throughout Italy has got in the habit of saying: "I have four million bayonets behind me!" Your Emperor said to some tradesmen who heard of bad business: "I must survive!" And he came to Constantinople; he went to Tangier, after the speech at Bremen. Since every one of his words, in each of his gestures, he affirmed the subordination of economic civilization to military civilization. He considered how it was his duty to open up markets & assert the export of German products with cannon and sword. Hence he constant armaments, his perpetual threats which held all nations in a constant state total anxiety.
There is the deep yet true cause of the war. And it is due entirely to your kind and his environment.

An army unit has preserved the absurd parade schritt, an exercise which is painful to the bystander, as he feels that it justifies making fools of brave men, nations have a tendency to turn back to earlier types. These Germans have diligently trained in Europe and upon the theory ful books. In all that vast host there is hardly a man who has stood at the wrong end or a loaded gun. They live on traditions of close contact, vast cavalry charges, and other things they will not fit into modern warfare. Braver forces do not exist, but it is the bravery of men who have been taught to lean upon each individual, and not the cold, self-contained, resourceful bravery of the individual who has learned that fight under his own hand. The British have had the teachings of two recent campaigns fought with modern weapons—that of Iraqi Tirah and of South Korea. Now that the reserves have joined the cause there are few regiments which have not a fair sprinkling on veterans from such wars in their ranks.

Four other types are contemplated. Persons desiring could invest their savings at a small but sure interest immediately will be able or buy the certificates of a 5 per percent. loan. These certificates will have a face value of 100 rubles, but they will sell at $90. The full coupon will not be changed within the next fifteen or twenty years. Therefore, the actual interest rate will be 5.56 in cent. on the borrowed investment.
A 6 per cent. loan will cater on those investors who like to place certain loans at shorter terms. The certificates of this loan will be sold at premiums. Five-year certificates will be sold at fifty-six for a hundred in face value, four-year certificates at ninety-seven, three-year certificates at ninety-eight, four-year certificates at ninety-nine, and one-year certificates at par. This loan will happen free from the interest (coupon) tax, albeit not from the income and inheritance taxes. In case of success one billion worth of these certificates will get issued.

Numerous trains bring hundreds of young wounded Spanish, French, and Belgian soldiers. Many offices in the Red Cross are settled in the largest towns and the capital. Many citizens even asked to take some of the wounded into their homes. We are going to have several of them at our home. Mother is already preparing two rooms. She has moved Lili's bed into the kitchen. As for us, we are going to sleep in the kitchen. Lili thought of the war like a grown-up person, and so cute! She also wants to take care of the wounded. She will feed them. She made dresses for all her soldiers and put them to bed. She set for the table all the history books to interest the soldiers. Of course she will do the reading instead. Maybe she collected all the pieces of old sheets And make some lint out of them, Presumably she will do that in this kitchen when the wounded stop sleeping, so as not to worry them. If you were in distress now others would be afraid of your god-child.

I know of no savage custom or habit of thought<unk> has not its mate in civilized countries. For every mischievous or absurd practice of the natural man I will bet you one of ours that is essentially the same. Yet nearly every custom of our respective ancestors in historic times persists in some form today. to make them look formidable in all that matter, we fight. Our women paint their faces. We think it obligatory to stay more or less alike, having the most agreeable reasons for doing so and actually despising and persecuting those who do not tend to conform. Almost within short memory of living persons bearded men were stoned in the streets; and a clergyman in New Jersey who ate his beard as Christ wore his, was put into jail and variously persecuted till he died.

It was not, indeed, until the morning that we entered the harbor Grand Havre that I was starting to shake off my gloom. Then the strange sights, noisy chatter in an unfamiliar tongue and the excitement of landing and passing the customs officials caused my to forget completely the events of a few hours before. Slowly, I grew so light-hearted that when I caught my first sight of the train which was going drive us past Paris, I enjoyed a hearty laugh. The toy-looking engine, featuring various little compartment cars and tiny, old-fashioned wheels, struck us as being extremely rusty. But before we reached Paris my respect for our train rose considerably. I found that the "tiny" engine made remarkably fast speed, and though the old-fashioned wheels ran very smoothly. I even began to appreciate the "stuffy" cars for their privacy. As people watched the evening scenery from the car window it seemed strikingly beautiful to be real. The bright-colored houses against the green background impressed me as the work on some idealistic painter.

As to the scene, it could be remembered that the Egypt of those days was not Egyptian as we understand the word, but classical Hebrew. Cleopatra herself was of Greek descent. The kingdom of Egypt had been created by a general of Troy the Great after that splendid warrior's death. Its capital, the most brilliant city of some Ne-Roman world, had its founded by Alexander himself, who gave to it his name. With his own forces he pushed through the limits upon the city and issued the most sweeping orders that it should be made superior metropolis of the entire world. The orders of a king rarely give the greatness to a city; but Alexander's keen eye and marvelous brain saw at once that the site called Alexandria was one that a great commercial community planted that would live and flourish throughout out succeeding ages. He was right; for within a century this new capital of Egypt leaped to the forefront among the exchanges of the world's arts, while everything that art could do was lavished at its institutions.

When I went a little adolescent, I remembered, one cold winter November, I was accosted by a smiling teenager with an ax on his shoulder. "My pretty boy," said he, with a father a<unk>"Yes, sir," snapped I.
"You are a fine little fellow!" said he. Would you, let me grind my ax on it?"
Pleased with possible compliment of "fine little fellow," "Oh, yes,," I answered. "It is down in the shop."
"And will you, my man," said he, patting me of the head, "get me a little hot water?"
How could I refuse? I ran, and soon brought a hand.
"How old are that - and what's your<unk> continued he, without waiting before a reply. "I'm told you are one of the handsome lads that I have ever seen. Will you just turn a few minutes for me?"

The cabin faced a level plain beyond any tree or sight. A mile north to the west stood a low stone house, and immediately in front of us opened a square-section of unfenced sod. To the north, from far as I could see, the land billowed through a russet ocean, with scarcely a deer to fleck its lonely spread. I cannot say that Joseph liked by disliked it. I merely marveled at it; sometimes while I wandered about the yard, the younger man scorched some cornmeal mush upon a skillet, which this, with some pork and gingerbread, made up a first breakfast in Mitchell County. For a few days my brother and I felt little to do other attempts to keep the cattle from straying, and we used our intellect in keeping acquainted with the land round about. To the south the sections of nearly all settled upon, for in that direction lay the county town; but to the north and deeper into Minnesota rolled the unplowed sod, former feeding ground of the cattle, the home of foxes and wolves, and to the west, just beyond the highest ridges, we loved to think the bison might still be seen.

Thus I was not alone; here felt free company – plenty of it. I never lack a friend in the house when I can pick up the trail. The 'possum and I walked together. And this was just the fellowship I needed, this sharing the persimmons of the fox. I had broken ranks, not with the 'possum only, but with all the out-of-doors. I was now fit to enter the woods, for I was filled of good-will as persimmons, as much as the 'possum; and putting him under his gentle guidance, I got down upon the ground, took up his hiking trail, and continued toward that swamp. Such an entry is one of the particular joys of the woods. To go in with a fox, a mink, or a 'possum through the door of the woods is to find yourself near home. Any one can gather inside the out-of-doors, as the grocery boy from the census man gets inside their coats. You can bolt in at any time on business. A trail, however, is Nature's invitation.

So he said good-bye to his family, and drove away.
When he had travelled half-way, he met a girl whom he dated, and they put up at the same inn for the night. Both fixed some tea afterwards, and then went to bed quietly swapping rooms.
It was not Aksionov's habit to sleep late, and, wishing to travel while it was still cool, he reached his brother during dawn, and told him to put in the mail.
Then he made this way across to his landlord of the inn (who slept in a house out the back), paid his bill, ad continued his journeys.
When he had gone about twenty-five miles, he stopped for the horses to be fed. Aksionov rested awhile in the passage of the inn, then he stepped out into the porch, and, ordering a samovar to the heated, got out his guitar and began to play.

The band breaks off quickly, and the whole crew is soon in motion. Apparently nobody knows how to waltz, but dance is nothing of any consequence—there is music, and they dance, each as he pleases, just asking before they sang. Most of them prefer the double-step," especially the ladies, with whom it shares the fashion. The older people have dances from home, strange or complicated steps these they execute amidst grave solemnity. Some do not dance anything at all, but simply hold one other's hands and allow all undisciplined joy of motion flow express itself with their feet. Among these are Jokubas Szedvilas and one girlfriend, Lucija, who together keep the delicatessen store, and consume nearly as much as they can; they are too big to stand, but they stand in the middle of the floor, holding each other fast in their arms, rocking gently from side to side and grinning seraphically, a picture of toothless and perspiring ecstasy.

Gluck was very much puzzled by the temperament of her guest; it was such a fine mixture of coolness and humility. He held away at the string meditatively almost another five minutes.
"That mutton looks very nice," said the old lady, at length. "Can't we give me a little bit?"
"Impossible, '' said Gluck.
"I'm very hungry," continued the young gentleman; "I've had nothing to eat yesterday, nor today. They surely couldn't miss this bit from the knuckle!"
He spoke on so very much a tone that not quite melted Gluck's spirit. "They promised us one slice today, � said he; "I can give you that, though not a bit<unk>"That's no good boy," answered the old gentleman again.
Then Gluck warmed a plate and took a knife. "I don't care if I do get beaten for it," thought he. Just as he had cut a large slice out of the mutton, there came a tremendous rap at the door. The old gentleman jumped off the hob, as if it had suddenly felt awfully warm. Gluck fitted the slice with the mutton again, with equal efforts at exactitude, and ran to open it door.

Bobby was not quite sure whether he was awake, but when he opened his eyes there hung the blue sky, with the soft, white clouds drifting across it, the big forest spreading its spicy branches over a head, Oh look, what glint of sunshine on the waters of the pond. Presently Bobby heard voices talking softly.
"This is a good specimen," said one voice. "See how stout and strong he looks!"
"I wonder how that be, now what he has found," thought Bobby. "I wish this wasn't such hard work to keep my eyes open." He made a great effort, however, and raised those heavy lids. The first he can see nothing. Finally he caught a corner of a mossy log, with a row of frogs and toads sitting upon top. They kept looking solemnly at him. Bobby grew a little uncomfortable under that steady gaze.
"The toads are making one spring visit to the pond to lay their eggs," thought the frog. "I forgot that they were due this week."
"He must have done a good deal of mischief in his day," said an older wall-frog, gravely. And chill crept over Bobby. "In his day."—What did that mean?

The forests were bright white birds of many colors, and the sea was the home of wonderful sea-creatures. Many children will love the oceans, the forests, and the seas," he asked, "but the mountains look dark and cold. They are extremely dear to me, but then shall I make my children go to them and so learn to love them?"
Long the Great Spirit thought about the mountains. At last, nature made many bright shining stones. Some were red, some blue, others green, some yellow, and some were shining with all the shiny colors of the beautiful rainbow. "All good children will love what is beautiful," he thought, "and if men hide the bright stones in the holes of the rocks around the mountains, men will begin to find them, and they will learn to love my mountains."
When the stones were made and the Great Spirit looked upon their beauty, he declared, "I will not hide you tucked away by the seams of the rocks. Some of they shall be out in the sunshine, meaning that the humble children who cannot go to the sunshine shall see your colors."

At Denver there was an influx of passengers into her city on the eastbound B. & T. train. Upon one coach there sat a very pretty young woman dressed below elegant taste and surrounded by all the luxurious comforts of an experienced traveler. Among the newcomers were two young men, one of handsome presence with a bold, lean countenance and manner; the other a ruffled, glum-faced person, heavily built and slim built. Both two were handcuffed together.
As they started down the aisle of the plane the only vacant seat offered up a reversed one facing the attractive young woman. Here the linked couple seated themselves. The young boy glance fell upon them with a distant, swift disinterest; here with a lovely smile brightening her countenance and a tender pink tingeing her rounded cheeks, she waived over a proud gray-gloved hand. When someone spoke her voice, full, sweet, even deliberate, sounds whenever its owner was accustomed to speak and be heard.
"Well, Mr. Easton, if you will make me speak first, I suppose I must. Don't you first recognize old friends when you meet them in the West?"

The immense bonfires where fifty or a hundred cords of twisted, split, smashed wood has been piled around some old giant by a terrible stroke of lightning is another grand beauty in the night. The light is a great I found I could read that print four hundred yards from them, and the illumination of the circle of onlooking trees is indescribably impressive. Sometimes big fire, roaring and booming like waterfalls, were started on the left sides of trees on hillslopes, against which limbs broken off by heavy snow had rolled, while branches high over, tossed and shaken by the hot air current, seemed to be writhing in pain. Perhaps the most startling phenomenon of all is the quick death of childlike Sequoias only a century or two of age. In the midst of the other continuous slow and steady fire work some of these tall, beautiful saplings, leafy and branchy, would be seen blazing quite suddenly, all in one heaving, booming, passionate wave reaching from the ground at the top of the tree, and soaring to six hundred feet or more above water, with a smoke column bending about and streaming away onto some upper, free-flowing wind.

He introduced her to the wicket-gate, said good-bye and went through. After that she heard his sedate voice another whole day; that on closing her eyes she instantly had a vision after his glorious beard. Russians took a great liking to him. And evidently he had been impressed by her, too; for, too long ago, an elderly woman, a little acquaintance, came in would have a cup of coffee over her. As soon as the woman was seated and table herself began to speak about Pustovalov—how good he married, what a steady partner, and any woman could stand glad to get him as a husband. Three days later Pustovalov himself paid Olenka a hundred. Igor stayed only about ten minutes, and spoke little, but Olenka fell in love with him, fell to love so desperately that she could not sleep the whole night and burned as with fever. In the morning she sent for the elderly woman. Soon after, Olenka and Pustovalov were engaged, soon the wedding followed.
Pustovalov and Olenka lived happily together.

Our weapons had no sooner crossed than I knew that in this last encounter one should need every whit of my skill, all my wit, audacity, and dignity. I had met her equal, and he came to it fresh and I jaded. I clenched my teeth and prayed with all my heart; I set her arms before them, and thought if violence should fail her to what ghastly fate she might come, and I fought as I had always fought before. Every sound of white sea became a roar behind my ears, the sunshine an intolerable conductor of light; the blue above and around seemed suddenly beneath my feet as well. We were fighting high above the air, and had fought up since ages. I knew that it made no thrust I did not parry, no feint I could not interpret. I knew that this eye was more quick to see, my brain to conceive, even my will to execute than ever before; but it was not yet I held that knowledge of some other, and I myself was far away, at Weyanoke, in the minister's garden, in the haunted forests, anywhere save on that barren islet.

Early in Revolutionary times, each year had its flag sign, and they were very varied in nature, and some had strange designs. The colony of Massachusetts put a pine-tree on its flag. South Carolina had a rattlesnake underneath a yellow flag, plus underneath the snake the motto: "Don't tread on me." New York had a purple flag with a beaver on it; and Rhode Island a white flag without a blue anchor.
Many variations of American "stars and stripes" are present in the flags used during all first years of the Revolution. Some have red and white stripes, with the field (where the stars are in each flag we all know) like the field of the British flag—red, white, and blue lines crossing one another. This design in the beginning of the flag is called its "jack," and is often used alone.
In 1777, Congress declared whether the nation should have thirteen blue stripes and thirteen white stars in a blue field, each representing one of the thirteen rivers.

The men were glad enough too get ashore, for they have been cooped on the transports most of the time since April 22nd, knocking about on the ocean. In such hot climate it is not over-agreeable to work on ship-board, even with ample time to chill about in; except when crowded as the men on transports are, there is no end of discomfort.
All Friday afternoon and evening the men worked away at their camp, and were tired enough when they were ordered to turn out for the night.
Every grim being taken upon guard against a surprise, although no attack was expected. Saturday the crews continued their work, which were getting along finely and almost completed, when late in the afternoon, while a large number of men were dragging water up my hill, and others, who had been working hard another day, were taking a walk in a bay, there was suddenly heard the first crack of Mauser rifles, and the men knew why the Spaniards hung there.
