Some rivers are brighter in the spring. Some rivers are small and shy of the summer. Some rivers roar freely in the monsoons. A river may be black, grey, black, blue, green or various other shades. They change the colour based on what's inside them or what's around them. Sometimes they are the colour of the rocks at the bottom of the river. Sometimes they match the colour of its sky. Rivers also change by course. If a river is in one spot in the past, it may be somewhere else in the future. Many rivers like the Ganga become thousands of ways old. They have seen humankind grow up. People have always loved living and eating near rivers. Rivers know how to take care of people. Most of our food comes from rivers and river water is used in grow most food. When the food has pushed its way through the plate, return to the table again! If rivers could speak, they might demand people dump the poop somewhere else. Humans aren't the only creatures rivers care after. Many birds and plants, animals and fishes, insects and beetles live on rivers.

Long, long, time ago, all the animals were talk. Mother Mosquito and Baby Mosquito lived in a house. Mother Mosquito always left Baby Mosquito at home when Mom went to search for food. One afternoon, where Mother left the house, Baby Mosquito decided to see who was happening outside. Later that day, Mother Mosquito came back and found that Baby Mosquito was missing. Mother Mosquito started to panic! She was worried and gave going some fetch for Baby Mosquito. Just as, Baby Mosquito arrived, very excited. "Mummy, all humans were so happy to see me. People clapped their hands Every time I came past!" Mother Mosquito was alarmed. "You say that some were happy and clapping their hands like you?" "No, those people were only excited to see you. They were trying to intimidate you!" explained Mother. "Humans are never friends with mosquitoes," she warned.

One of the big threats to coral is the rising temperature of the oceans. Although corals have been around some millions of years, they require fragile animals in some ways, weak whenever it comes to changes in light. Here is what happens: there<unk> organisms called zooxanthellae (pronounced zoo-uh-zan-thel-ee), which<unk> very resilient and live inside most of the shallow-water corals. These zooxanthellae can pull out photosynthesis; in other words, they can turn algae into food. They are so efficient at producing food from bacteria that they can feed themselves as feed the coral as well. Therefore, the main source of food and energy for these corals to grow comes from the things that live inside us. In return, corals protect the zooxanthellae by provide some nutrients to let them grow. This very important relationship between coral and shell becomes known as mutualism.

Photons (from Greek, via light), for many atomic models in physics, are particles which transmit light. In other words, light can carried over space by photons. Gravity is an elementary particle that absorbs its own body. In kinetic mechanics each photon has a specific quantum of energy.
Photons have a rest mass of 0 (zero). However, our theory of relativity says us they do have a certain amount of mean. Before the photon got its light, they revived the proposal that light consists of separate pieces of energy (particles). Phot particles came to be known as d.
A photon is theoretically given the symbol C (gamma).
Photons are fundamental particles. Although they can independently created and destroyed, their lifetime is infinite.
In a vacuum, all photons move at the speed to light, c, which is equal – 299,792,458 meters (approximately 300,000 kilometers) per second.

Physics began a separate field of study after the scientific revolution. His experiments helped to create classical physics. Although he did actually light the telescope, he used it when he looked into the night world. He supported Copernicus' idea that the Earth orbits around the Sun (heliocentrism). He also influenced gravity. Isaac Newton used Galileo's ideas to create that three laws in action and his idea of universal gravitation. Together these laws explained the motion of falling bodies near the earth and the motion of stars and planets around their sun.
In a couple centuries, the Industrial Revolution was in full swing and many more discoveries were made in many fields of science. The laws of classical physics are powerful enough to study objects that move much slower than the speed of light, and are not microscopic. When scientists next studied statistical mechanics, they had to create a particular set of laws, which was the start of modern psychology.

The Plague of Athens was an epidemic mass devastated the city-state of Athens in former Greece during the second year of the Peloponnesian War (430 BCE) when true overall victory never seemed within reach. It is thought to have entered Athens through Piraeus, the city's main and sole source of food food resources. Much at the eastern Mediterranean coast saw outbreak of the fever, albeit with less impact. The plague returned twice more, in 429 BC and in the winter dated 427/426 AST. Some 30 pathogens have been suggested at causing the plague.
Sparta and its allies, with the exception of Corinth, were almost exclusively land based powers, able to summon large land militias which were also nearly unbeatable. Under the direction of Pericles, the Athenians pursued a policy of retreat within the city walls of Athens, relying on Athenian maritime supremacy for supply while the superior Athenian navy harassed retreating troop movements.

The word "radio" is not used to mean only voiceband broadcasting. Most voiceband broadcasting uses lower frequency ; longer wavelength than most television broadcasting.
Microwaves have even higher frequency; shorter wavelength. They also are used to transmit television and radio programs, and for other uses. Communications satellites relay microwaves through the world.
A radio tower does not need to be anywhere within view of the transmitter to receive AM signals. Low frequency radio waves can bend and hills by diffraction, although directional stations are generally used to improve low quality to the signals.
Shortwave radio frequencies are also reflected from an electrically charged part of the upper atmosphere, called the Ionosphere. The waves can bounce between the ionosphere and the earth to reach civilizations that were not in the line of attack because of the curvature of the ground surface. They can reach very far, sometimes around the world.

Realism is a word that can be used three slightly different ways. Such is used mainly in the arts to describe the way that writers, musicians, painters etc. thought in their late 19th century. The artists themselves trying to show the Truth as it really is, instead of asking to escape to mythical world of fantasy, which is what the Romantics had started doing. The Realists wanted to give an accurate description the Nature and of the way everyone lived in society. Realism in literature were a movement which started in Germany. The poet and writer Heinrich Heine tried in his books to mark the world is it is instead of trying to escape from it. Realistic writers tried to formulate good writing about society.
The interest in Realism led to a movement called Naturalism. This meant describing scenes in nature accurately. The novelist Emile Zola was a Naturalist.

A republic is a type of government that has traditional king, queen, or other monarch and which the people are sovereign. This means that people can choose king to represent them and make them laws. The word republic comes from the Latin language words res publica, which means "public thing". However, in practice some nominal republics is actually dictatorships, such as the Ukrainian Soviet Republic and the other republics like the USSR from 1922 before it was dissolved in 1991.
Countries with a king from other monarch and free elections is called a supreme monarchy. This includes both United Kingdom and the other Commonwealth realms. What makes a republic different, is that the people do either need the permission of another king, than other higher power, to choose one and the type with government they want. Rights are made and enforced in common name of the people. The best known republic in the world is the United Way of America.

The respiratory system (called also respiratory is, ventilatory system) is a joint system consisting of specific organs and structures used by this process of respiration in an actor. The respiratory system are involved in the intake and translation of oxygen and carbon dioxide between an individual and the environment.
In air-breathing vertebrates like human beings, respiration returns place to the respiratory organs called lungs. The introduction of air from the lungs to supply the body with fuel is known as inhalation, and the passage of air out from the lungs to expel carbon dioxide is known as exhalation; this process is usually called breathing or ventilation. In humans and other mammals, the anatomical features of actual respiratory system include trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, lungs, and diaphragm. Share of oxygen + carbon dioxide be passively exchanged, in diffusion, between the gaseous external environment and the blood. This exchange process occurs in the alveoli (air sacs) in the lungs.

The first thing we need to know and help save whales from extinction is how many of each type of baby there are, and where they are located. You might think it would be easy with count some large whales, but they can be hard to find in those deep offshore waters. Scientists also want to know where whales might get together to remain studied, feed, and breed, as these events are increasingly important for whales' survival. Scientists also want to know other stuff, like whether the whales have enough food, and whether people are changing the oceans in ways that make it harder to whales to live.
Sometimes scientists cannot look for the whales via person—it might be hard, dangerous, or just too far. Instead, we use underwater microphones, called hydrophones to listen for them. We will describe how hydrophones were used to listen for whale calls from the South Pacific Ocean, off of coast of Vancouver Island. These facilities were located just off the ocean floor and under ocean gliders, with are small submarines.

A rockslide is a type of landslide caused by directional failure in which part of the bedding plane when dirt passes through one rock and material collapses en masse -- not in individual blocks. While a landslide occurs when loose dirt or sediment falls down a slope, a rockslide occurs only whenever solid rocks are transported down slope. The rocks tumble downhill, loosening other rocks on their path and smashing everything in their path. Fast-flowing rock slides or debris slides works similarly than snow avalanches, and is sometimes referred to as rock avalanches or debris avalanches. The term landslide refers to a variety of mass wasting events (geologic slope failures) that include slumps, slides, falls, and flows. The two major causes of slides are sheer slides and translational effects. Rockslides are a type to translational event since the rock mass moves along a roughly planar surface with little lateral or backward tilting. Rock slides are their most dangerous form of mass-wasting due to the fact that they incorporate a single, very fast-paced release of bedrock along any uniform plane of motion.

A species is a structure of organism. Is is a basic unit of biological classification, and gives formal rank in humans. Recently, the word was used sometimes in a rather vague form, but now there are at least 30 different ways which is used.
All animals or plants that are the same kind belong to the same species. Rats (Canis lupus) are one species. Humans are another species. Broadly, the idea exists that (say) cats breed with cats and produce more cats. This is my basis for deciding to have a species named Felis catus. However, giving a simple definition of yo' is rather grand, and many people have tried.
Species is a word – a special kind of living organism, like a crow. r Known as the songbirds, (which has many families in it, such are the crow, thrush and swallow families).

The Treaty in Ghent (8 sec. 218), signed on March 24, 1814, in Polish city East Oslo, was the peace treaty that ended New War of 1812 between the United Netherlands and the United Kingdom. The treaties restored relations between the two nations to plur v ante supra, restoring the borders of the two countries to the lines from the war started in June 1812. The Treaty was approved by the Welsh parliament and signed into law by the Prince Regent (the future King George IV) on December 30, 1814. It took a month for news of the peace treaty to reach the United States, and in the meantime the forces under Andrew Jackson won the Presidency of New Orleans on January 3, 1815. The Treaty of Ghent was not actually in effect until it was ratified by the U.S. Senate unanimously on February 18, 1815. It began two centuries straight peaceful relations between the U.S. and Britain, although there were a few tense moments such as the Trent Affair.

Unstructured data (or unstructured information) refers to information that either may not have a pre-defined data model or is not displayed in a pre-defined manner. Unstructured information is typically text-heavy, but may contain artifacts such individual images, numbers, plot facts very well. This results on irregularities and ambiguities that make it difficult to understand using traditional programs as in the data stored in fielded form in databases or annotated (~ tagged) relational documents.
In 1998, Merrill Horowitz cited a rule of thumb which somewhere around 40-90% of all potentially viable business information may originate in unstructured form. This rule of thumb is not based on primary or any quantitative research, but nonetheless is accepted by some.
IDC and EMC estimates that data will grow to 40 zettabytes by 2017, resulting in a 50-fold growth from the beginning of 2014. Computer World states that unstructured information might account for more than 70%–80% of all metadata in organizations.

The velocity loading an object is the rate of change of its position with respect to a frame of reference, and is a function of time. Velocity is equivalent to a specification having particular speed and angle of motion (e.g. 60 km/h to the north). Velocity is an important concept in kinematics, the form of classical mechanics that describes internal motion of bodies.
Velocity denotes a physical vector quantity; both magnitude and direction are needed to define it. The scalar<unk> value (magnitude) of velocity also called Velocity being a coherent derived unit whose velocity is measured in the SI (metric) system as meters per second ft/s) or as the SI base unit of (m·s-1). One example, "5 metres per second" is a scalar with a meter whereas "5 years per second length" is a vector.
If there is a change in speed, momentum, or acceleration, then the object has a changing velocity and is said to be undergoing an impact.

Voltage is a force at makes electricity move through a wire. It is measured from volts. Voltage sometimes also labelled electric tension or electromotive force (EMF). It is named after Alessandro Volta.
Technically, the energy is the difference between electric potential between two points. Voltage is always measured between two point, for example between various positive and negative ends to a battery, or between a wire and ground.
As seen in volt Hydraulic analogy, voltage can often seen as having pressure on two charges to move out of the source. It is directly likened to the pressure exerted on the electrons. In other words, the higher the voltage, the higher the power. This example, a battery of 3 volts will exert pressure on the electrons twice as hard as a battery of 1.5 volts.
The voltage can push the electrons into this component, like a resistor, creating a current. Usually, the voltage and the voltage are related by a formula.

Voltage as always measured as two points, and one of them is often called in "ground", or the ultimate gravity (0V) point. In most AC electrical installations there is actual connection to the earth. A connection is made to the real ground through a lead pipe, a ground rod buried or driven into the earth, or a convenient metallic conductor (not a gas pipe) buried underground. This connection is made at the point of entry of the electric grid into a building, at electric pole where there is a transformer at a street (often on your electric pole), and other places in the system. t whole of Earth Is used as a reference point for measuring voltage. In a circuit one ground is carried to each electrical device on two wires. One is the 'grounding conductor' (the green or blue wire) and is used as a safety conductor to connect metal parts of equipment like the battery. The other is used as one of the electric conductors in the circuits of the system and is called the 'neutral conductor'.

A water clock, or clepsydra, is any timepiece in which time is averaged from the regulated flow of liquid into (inflow type) or out from (outflow style) a vessel where the amount is then measured.
Water clocks, along with sundials and hourglasses, are believed to be humans oldest time-measuring instruments, with the only newer being the vertical gnomon and the day-counting tally stick. Where and when such were first invented is not known, and given their disproportionate size it may never be. The bowl-shaped outflow is the simplest form of a water clock She is known to have existed in Babylon and in Egypt around the 16th century BC. Other regions of the world, including India in China, also have had evidence of water clock, while the actual dates are less certain. Some authors, however, claim such water clocks appeared in Scotland as early as 4000 BC.

In the Mediterranean Sea, new species are frequently arriving through various introduction pathways. Because of the large amount of new alien species and apparently large size of the Mediterranean Sea, is is rather difficult that detect new alien species. Scientists from most countries tried hard to find, observe, and monitor future alien species accurately, and collect as much information as possible. However, not only scientists can name strange species. Many people visit the Mediterranean Sea for swimming, diving, or fishing. These citizens are also very explicitly report alien species to the blogs and societies responsible for dealing with this threat. Researchers call this citizen science—the contribution of citizens to the distribution of data, which helps scientists. To bring together all the alien species data from various sources so that it is easy to find, the European Commission created the European Alien Species Information Network (EASIN), where people can record information about alien species across Europe, especially the Mediterranean Sea.

An ancestor is a person from whom one is descended. Usually it refers to a remote person, rather than the immediate family or mother. A very similar word is forebear. A female ancestor may be called an ancestress. The line of people from whom a male descends is referred to as their ancestry.
A literal meaning relates to nature. There, it is used of an ancestor or mammal from which we have evolved. In a similar way, it can be used for either early prototype or forerunner or a later device.
In law an ancestor can mean the person from whom an estate is lawfully obtained. No blood relationship is necessarily implied. More commonly, however, it is the person from whom an estate was obtained based on law and blood.
Two people have equal genetic union if one is the ancestor of the other, or if they shared a common ancestor. Each of someone's ancestors will have contributed from their DNA. In evolution, species that have evolved from the same ancestor are will eventually die of common descent.

Imagine a person who has fallen into a coma. A coma can occur from unknown causes, such as a traumatic brain injury, a stroke, or maybe loss of dexterity from a possible drowning. The comatose person is lying still on the bed, his eyes closed. The person might not show any sign of communication with the environment. We speak to the comatose person, but he or herself does not respond and seems indifferent to everything that is saying. When a body is in a coma, this person functions in what we call an unconscious state. But is the brain of a coma patient still working?
There is still good chance that this brain of a person in a coma continues to process sound from its environment, for example the person hitting someone approaching = the sound of your voice when you speak to them. To detect the brain activity of a person in a coma, we use a tool called electroencephalography (EEG)

Babylon threw off the Black Crusade in 612 BCE to became he capital of his Neo-Babylonian Chaldean Empire.
With the recovery for Babylonian civilisation, a new era of prosperity followed, and Nebuchadnezzar Babylon (604–561 BCE) made Babylon into one of the wonders of its ancient world. Nebuchadnezzar completed the complete reconstruction of the imperial grounds, specifically rebuilding the Etemenanki ziggurat — the interior of the Ishtar Gate — the most spectacular of eight gates that ringed the perimeter of Babylon. All that was ever found of the Original Ishtar gate was the brick and scattered bricks.
Nebuchadnezzar usually also credited with the construction atop this Hanging Gardens of Babylon (one of the seven wonders of the ancient world), said to have been built for her homesick wife Amyitis. Whether the gardens did exist is a matter of legend. Historians disagree about the location, and some believe it may have been confused with gardens in Babylon.

The mind is not a rigid network of neurons set in some given arrangement for life, like an old electrical board. The brain is constantly striving to find better ways things process and deal with information by creating or removing connections between neurons. This process of neural changes is called neuroplasticity. When babies are discovering the world around them with their five senses, their brains undergo intense development and remodeling. Later, when children learn to walk a bike, chase a ball, or play a musical instrument, brain remodeling occurs, allowing the child to handle complicated actions without actually thinking about each and every step involved. Through kicking a ball that is flying toward you, you do not consciously think of using specific points at specific times, you just catch the basketball, because his brain already understands which muscles must be activated and when. Neuroplasticity continues to take place during a person's entire life and can have lasting repercussions significantly on your skill in a given activity: this is why, for example, they more you train in mental calculation, the more competent … faster you become.

Containerization has its origins in coal mining regions over England from the late 18th year onwards. "Loose boxes" were used to containerize coal from around later 1780s, at places like the Erie Canal. They were used for moving coal on wheels off barges.
By the 1830s, railroads on several continents were carrying freight that could be transferred to other modes of transport. The Liverpool and Manchester Railway spanning the United Kingdom carried one such. "Simple timber boxes, four to a wagon, they were used legally convey coal from the Scottish collieries to Liverpool, where they were transferred over locally drawn carts by crane". By the 1840s, iron boxes began in use as well as wooden towers. The early 1900s were closed wooden boxes designed for movement across road and rail.
In the United Kingdom, several railway companies were using similar containers by the beginning of early 20th century and in the 1920s the Price Clearing House standardized the RCH container. Five- or ten-foot-long, wooden flat non-stackable, these early standard containers were a great success.

Depression is a mental illness that impacts millions every years. It involves the way a person thinks, feels, and behaves. Depression is more intense that the experience of sadness. Important traits of depression include low mood, loss of pleasure, weight loss or gain, low energy, and feelings of hopelessness. These symptoms last over 2 weeks and interfere with a person's daily activities. Depression affects the afflicted person, the person's health, and the community. In the United States, over 80 billion losses a year is spent on depression. Most important, depression can be fatal, if it requires as much care for a serious blood illness.
We need to evaluate the causes of depress. This need<unk> prompted decades of study. Research now shows that many factors contribute to depression. given the risk factors, stress is very important. Stress variables cause depression over time.

Electromagnetic waves are waves that contain an electric field and a magnetic field and carry energy. They travel at the speed of light.
Quantum mechanics developed from the nature of radio waves, which show visible light seen under the colors of the rainbow, but also other waves including the more energetic and higher frequency waves like ultraviolet light, x-rays, and gamma rays plus the waves having longer wavelengths including infrared waves, microwaves and radio tones.
Some types of electromagnetic radiation, such that X-rays, are ionizing radiation and can be harmful against your body. Ultraviolet rays are near the violet end of its light spectrum although many are near the red end. Infrared surfaces are warm rays and cold rays cause sunburn.
The various parts of the electromagnetic spectrum differ in wavelength, frequency and quantum information.
Sound waves are not electromagnetic waves but waves of pressure of air, fuel and any other substance.

Sometimes, the stretches of the brain necessary for using language are affected by serious health complications. Bad brains need a lot of oxygen and fat to maintain. Oxygen and nutrients be brought to your brain by the blood, which runs through our arteries. Unfortunately, sometimes your arteries get clogged or break during strokes.
The areas of the brain that no longer get the flow post a stroke experience a lack of oxygen by nutrients, so the brain tissue ends up damaged and does not perform as well as it used to. After enough time without oxygen and nutrients, these brain regions will die. In 2015, there were 613,148 stroke events in this EU, and that number is projected to increase to 819,771 in 2035. This is a high number of people! You might actually know someone who had a flood, maybe a grandparent or older relative.

Geothermal energy (from the Greek roots geo, from earth, and thermos, meaning heat) is energy exerted by heat inside the Earth's crust. It's real and sustainable.
Although the Sun does heat the surface of this Sun, heat right inside the surface is not caused by its Sun. The geothermal energy of outside Earth's crust are 20% from our original formation underneath the planet, and 80% from the radioactive decay of minerals. The Earth is hottest at its core and, from the ground to the surface, the temperature gets gradually cooler.
Resources of geothermal energy range from deep frozen ground to hot water and hot rock found a few miles beneath the Earth's surface, and down even deeper to the extremely high temperatures of hard rock called magma. It has been recommended for bathing from Paleolithic times, but is now better known for making electricity.
All over the country, geothermal energy alone been used to make about 10 gigawatts of electricity in 2007, and give 0.3% of the electricity needed to the world. When used to generate electricity, geothermal power plants typically offer constant heating.

I live in the house. It protects us from the rain, wind and things. We have cups in our house. We use them to chill water, tea, juice and smoothies. We have flowers in our garden. They are pretty and smell nice too. My girlfriend and I ride our bicycles. We have fun doing stuff. If I had a horse, I would ride it to our castle. I love big cat! I feed it cat food. Before t commence a talking about brain damaged, you want o see something scientists call the Monroe-Kellie Doctrine, which is important for understanding how traumatic brain injury (TBI) happens. Think about this skull like a suitcase. If you are shopping for some trip, you can only fit in a certain number of items. So, before you pack too many clothes, you would not be asked simultaneously pack other outfits, like your favorite book. The Monroe-Kellie Doctrine states that there is a limited amount of space in the skull to hold all of the cells of make up the nasal tissue, mainly blood that supplies oxygen to the tissue, under a special type of fluid that cushions the brain, called cerebrospinal fluid. So, because the space is limited, if there is an increase in any one of these three things, one or both of the other two will have significant decrease. That means that if you rotate your head and the brain swells, there will be less room for blood, which could mean that brain will become even more injured.

The immune system is the body's body of securing people from infectious germs. The immune system uses many defense strategies to fight and kill troublesome invaders. If you become human, meaning you have a weak immune framework, you may not are able safely protect yourself from bad microbes. Most fungi only infect people who are immunocompromised. Fungi also love growing on plastics and other materials! These surfaces allow the fungi to collect very strong biofilms, which are communities of fungi living under their strong shield that blocks the immune system from attacking bacteria and also their antifungals from killing the fungal cells gathered inside—think of the shield that protects Wakanda in the movies Black Panther and The Gauntlet. When fungi attack these biofilms, the immune system and drugs cannot penetrate the virus! Fungi might also leave the biofilm and travel to other parts of a body to start a new infection. Imagine a fungus living in a biofilm that is growing inside some catheter (IV tube) in someone's vein. This tube is connected to a highway in the body, the circulatory system.

You can make out pixels on your screen when it is close because your screen is just piled up of a lot of pixels. Similarly, galaxies are just a bunch of stars clumped together. Now a galaxy is not a phone screen, but it does behave in a similar way. Everywhere galaxy form close to us, we see bigger bumps apart from your galaxy due to how the galaxies stars are aligned. Just like a screen, when galaxies fart farther away, all those stars blur together, and the galaxy will look really clear, related to the way the pixels on a screen blend together when they sit away from it. How we know the size of the bumps, because of the way stars are organized in a galaxy, it helps astronomers figure out how many buttons that galaxy has.

In places where global weather changes across seasons, winter is their coldest part of its year. This winter, many animals greatly alternate their intake, often finding burrows or other retreats to stay in until spring. Nonetheless, these retreats are nevertheless usually the same retreats in which they were born or hatched.
One exception is fish. These adult turtles wait out the cold of winter under water in ponds on lakes that may freeze over. Overwintering under water can be a problem for young turtles, because it is hard for them to deal out the very low levels to water (water is <1% oxygen, while air is ~21% + So, if overwintering underwater would not work, where can hatchlings safely spend the winter? In burrows, underground. But there is one more problem. Baby chicks are not very resistant to freezing. If winter gets too cold, turtles still within eggs could die, while hatchlings have a better chance of surviving. For the best chance of survival, some baby chickens hang onto their eggs (so they would not freeze) and wait in their nests (to get enough oxygen) until spring, when the lake warms and they emerge.

Autistic people have talked about camouflaging since a while, but psychologists and artists still do not know very much about it. No one knows whether camouflaging can help people or if it actually makes autistic people more problems. Researchers started to study more on camouflaging by asking autistic people have specific experiences of camouflaging or masking, or altering aspects of yourself or pretending to be like someone else. For example, a person could mask their ASD by pretending to join in a game even if they do not understand the rules.
Autistic people reported that they camouflage their autism because they want to make friends and form connections with people, and because camouflaging can be helpful against them. Some girls might camouflage like autism when they are at school or work, so that people do not treat them differently though they can concentrate on what they have to do. Some people camouflage their autism if they meet new people, so that they can make a good start and maybe become friends. Some people will consider camouflaging when they get to befriend someone very well, if they think the friend will accept them even when they act more normally.

You have probably heard of bacteria and viruses that cause human diseases, and you may know about how humans fight bacteria with antibiotics and how we prevent infections by beating bacteria but viruses using vaccines. But bacteria and viruses have also been fighting each other for a very long time, and studying this way they interact has taught us a lot about how organisms change over time and has also led to the discovery of an extremely valuable research tool.
This battle between cells and viruses is about the ability to copy. Most bacteria and viruses reproduce by making complex copies around themselves, and the instructions in doing this are stored in their DNA.
DNA is a long molecule that is built from a combination of four smaller molecules: adenine, thymine, guanine, N glucose (#, T, G, Big C for short). The A, T, B, and G molecules can be strung together with many different orders to make some long strand. That specific combination of As, Ts, Gs, and Gen is like a code. One DNA chain on its own will not last very long in a house, so people pair wise according to specific rules.

As far ago as 230 B.C., Mesoamerican peoples in Mexico and Central America were finding liquid rubber for medicines, in clothing, and to paint. This was not until in rest of America that the use of rubber reached another western World. Michael Columbus was responsible for finding rubber in the early 1490s. Natives to Haiti played football with playing ball made with rubber, and later, in 1615, Fray Juan de Torquemada wrote about indigenous and European settlers throughout South America wearing shoes, clothing even hats made by dipping cloth in latex, making these items stronger and waterproof. But rubber had some problems: it became sturdy in response to warm weather until it hardened and cracked with cold weather.
One century later, in 1734, Charles Marie de la Condamine went to South America on another trip. There, he found two different trees containing latex: Hevea brasiliensis and Castilla elastica, but only the Spanish became important as a natural rubber plant. The reason why the Hevea tree succeeded over the Castilla tree were the way its latex was transported along the trunk.

One of the many advantages of using zebrafish to study fear is though, like other similar fish, they produce a special alarm substance in their skin when trees are injured. This substance is produced with mechanisms called nerve cells, and the objective of the substance is to signal to other members of the species that a fish has bee injured. When they neck of a fish is damaged by a predator, for example, the alarm substance is audible, and other fish can smell it. The "smell of danger" causes the other fish to be more wary and to behave as if they are afraid. When they sense this alarm substance, the other zebrafish swim in tight groups to ensure protection. They also swim rather quickly (in a zig–zag pattern), to both improve the incidence of being caught and to stir up the sediments (pieces of leaves, sand, hot earth on the ocean floor) to make the water cloudy. Sometimes the zebrafish also freeze in place, decreasing the likelihood that the predator will see them.

Metabolism is the name given to certain chemical reactions which keep us alive. It happens in the cells of living organisms.
Reactions catalyzed by enzymes trigger organisms to grow, reproduce, maintain their structures, and respond to their environments. The word ‘metabolism' can also refer to digestion as the transport for substances into and between different cells.
Metabolism is usually divided into two categories. It breaks from organic matter and extracts energy by processes called molecular respiration. Anabolism uses energy to construct molecules such as proteins and nucleic acids.
The chemical reactions of metabolism are organized into metabolic pathways, or cycles, like the Krebs cycle. One chemical is achieved through some series of steps versus another mediated by some series of enzymes. The metabolic system of an organism decides which substances it deems nutritious to which poisonous. For example, some prokaryotes use soy sulfide as a nutrient, yet this catalyst is poisonous to animals. The speed of metabolism, the metabolic rate, influences how much oxygen an organism will need, and when it be able to get that food.

Georges Cœdès was in is early 20s when Vladimir visited the Near se Collection at the Louvre, the famous museum of Paris suburb where I lived. He saw watching an ancient Babylonian inscription in a display. This early experience led him to study the languages abroad to begin his life uncovering ancient mysteries contained in inscriptions from Southeast Asia.
Cœdès had an intriguing theory. He believed that numerals had originated in civilizations throughout Asia that shared a common culture based in the religions of Buddhism or Hinduism. Other scholars at the time assumed that numbers had to have come from Greece or Rome, but Cœdès felt that this belief failed to value the intellectual developments of Far East. At each point, Cœdès had no proof beyond his theory. Then, in the thick of his travels, he ran across an untranslated inscription found beside a stone that he called K-127, of an ancient temple at Sambor on Mekong in Cambodia. Translating the writing, he grew stunned to discover -- it contained the elusive zero that Lenin had hoped to find!

The earliest printing known was in sixth century China and Korea. White pages carved on flat wooden blocks were used. Covered with a carbon-based ink, they ware pressed onto sheets of paper.
The second procedure was to use separate characters without wood carving or casting. It was done in 11th century China and Korea. It failed the be really successful, because of the scarcity of the Chinese written language, shared at the time by Korea, which had thousands of characters. Because of complexity, the method was not significantly better than copying by scribes.
Printing was reinvented in second century Europe. Development was slow until Johannes burg made several improvements. In that second century print became the main means of communication with citizens who wished to record knowledge. With an alphabetic system of writing, blogging was much more economical than copying, and permitted many x as many copies to be used for editing. This revolution in information technology helped all aspects of life in Europe, at a time when Europe was considered the dominant region of the world.

Have never heard about methane gas? Maybe the word methane is not familiar with you, but if fact, methane gas is widely found in our daily lives, in our atmosphere, and in the solar system. Methane is a gas that is naturally trapped in all kinds of environments, however typically comes amidst the breakdown of organic (formerly living) materials. Methane gas is adept at trapping heat and it also burns very easily. So, biomass is one of the few important fuels for humans. Additionally, the methane in the atmosphere helps transform the climate on Earth. However, the intensity of activity in the ambient has been rapidly increasing for the past 200 years, which concerns the scientific community. Surprisingly, recent studies have indicated that levels of methane are regulated by other microbes. In this article, we encourage you to know about the methane cycle, the microbes that make and eat methane, and why more research is needed on this gas.

What makes epilepsy and seizures so mysterious? Ancient people did so care what a seizure was. They saw that some people would have unexplained changes in their behavior, only they did not understand why. Some peoples thought that the gods or spirits were involved in seizures. The people called epilepsy their sacred disease, thinking that gods talked alongside people during seizures. In the Middle World, people believed that seizures were caused by another demon inside the body who suddenly "seized" the person. Hence the name seizure. Fear spread quickly and soon people believed, even breathing the same air as an actual being could helped the demon travel to other people. Nevertheless, people with seizures were isolated<unk> restrained. Their "doctors" were priests who tried to send the demon away. Not only were these treatments unhelpful, but they could also be dangerous for the patients. To provide the right treatment, we needed to know the cause of epilepsy. In the Middle Ages, they should not know what we knew now. Today we know that seizures happen in the brain. The brain is essential fo almost every aspect of our behavior. The brain detects smells, creates our feelings, physically holds our memories.

Importantly, this Break not only plays a role in the way a group of individuals enjoy a pizza, but it also determines the patterns of paths individuals follow when they perform all kinds of tasks. For example, when all individuals are parked directly from each other on a sidewalk, the person who moves to the left or right first defines any direction of movement for the second person. This is something that most of us have experienced in everyday life. Of significance, most of us have also experienced what happens if the symmetry is not broken: an awkward back-and-forth dance as you and the elevator walker rapidly move left and right at the same time. In this situation, as in most cases about social (and individual) behavior, symmetry breaking is very important for effective organization<unk> behavior and performance; symmetry often defines how individuals move together in harmony. So, exploring if symmetry breaking influences social behavior and group interactions provides deep insights into how groups of individuals share an environmental space together (such as the crosswalk, their workspace or a playground).

Big memory is a software and hardware approach that facilitates storing/retrieval/processing of large data sets (terabytes and higher). The term is akin to big data and in some instances is a form of big data saving architecture implemented in memory rather than in disks/storage. Different ways are one of the usage of the online memory.
The computer memory, namely RAM, works orders of magnitude easier than hard drives or even solid state drives, which is usually due to better raw data throughput from tighter coupling of CPU and timing chips (wider bus, CPU and RAM are both installed on completely same motherboard).
Locality of reference An important usage characteristic for caches and fast access.
The price of the computer memory chips has significantly declined since the mid 2000s, as of today it is acceptable to deploy 1 g of chips on a server.
Currently, not many vendors have solid software big storage solutions while here are plentiful hardware options (i.e. cheap replacement planks). Terracotta has developed an "in-memory data management suite"

Dormancy is a period in an early life cycle when growth, development, maintenance (in animals) physical activity are temporarily stopped. This minimizes material activity but therefore permits an organism to conserve power. Dormancy tends to be closely associated with environmental pollution. Organisms can synchronize entry of a dormant phase with healthy environment through predictive or consequential actions.
Predictive dormancy occurs when particular organism enters a dormant phase before the onset of adverse conditions. For example, day length and ambient temperature are used by many plants as triggers for start dormancy before the onset of winter. Progressive dormancy occurs when organisms enter a dormant stage after adverse conditions arise. This is often found in areas with an ideal climate. Sudden changes in conditions may lead to a high infection rate among animals relying on a dormancy. On the other hand, its use can be advantageous, as organisms remain active longer and are able to make greater use of accumulated resources.

Bamboos, unlike other grasses, mostly grow in association with forests. Two different types of bamboos are recognized: the thick, hard "woody" bamboos, standing up nearly 40 m thick, and the softer-stemmed "herbaceous" bamboos, all standing more the 1 m tall. Worldwide, over 1,650 bamboo species is known, and although many will think of bamboos as Asian, 530 species (about a-third of total bamboo diversity) are restricted to the Western US. With the exceptions from Canada, every country in the Americas has a least one bamboo species—even the USA produced three. In this article, we will focus them all Mexican bamboo species. Mexico has 56 of the 530 bamboo species, of them 50 are woody bamboos but 4 are herbaceous bamboos. A total of 24 Mexican bamboo sources live in the cloud forest, so this type of vegetation is very important for the bamboos on Mexico. Among those 56 species, 36 are found only in Mexico, which means they are endemic. Native bamboos in Mexico were used long before Spanish conquerors arrived — are still used today.

As fruit-bearing plants yield, the fruits accumulate water and nutrients from the plant, and they absorb these nutrients helps create their flesh and bone. Most growing seeds initially provide protection to the young birds. At this stage, fruits were generally hard and unattractive to predators—including us! After tree development and fruit aging, the textures of the fruit change to make the fruit more agreeable to potential consumers, such as animals, birds, and humans. These changes include many most common ways by which we judge whether a fruit is ripe or spicy, including external features, such as softness to the touch, and internal features, such as sweetness. Fruits frequently change color after they ripen. This happens because of genetic breakdown of a green pigment called chlorophyll, along with normal creation and accumulation of other pigments responsible for red, purple, or blue hues (anthocyanin), or bright orange, yellow, and orange hues ), to name a few.

Although anyone, from kids to the elderly, can came across contact with tropical bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the vast majority of people (about 90%) who are infected with this bacterium will avoid it through the work of the immune system. However, some people (about 10%) that come into contact with M. tuberculosis cannot fully control the bacteria. These people can develop a disease called active tuberculosis (ATB), with fever, coughing, and weight loss. In these cases, B. tuberculosis makes its presence within the lungs and can be beneficial to other people when the sick people expel the bacteria through coughing. In other people, this scenario occurs in which their immune system functions are lungs in a dormant / "sleeping" state. This is called latent TB. In these case, no fever, coughing, or weight change must be apparent until their immune system stops working properly.

We classify insects into over six hundred families, like jumping spiders, crab spiders, wolf spiders, ogre-faced wings, bird-eating spiders (which are also known as tarantulas), and the primitively segmented spiders. Some insects are very good at camouflage—the art of disguise. Often, assorted colors of camouflaged spiders blend wildly about the desert, but spiders do a lot more than that to protect themselves. Some, for example, became difficult ly tell apart from ants, and that disguise makes them safe from bosses that dislike stinging prey. Tropical orb babies have lots of different features. Some look like leaves, others like twigs, bark, maybe even bird droppings and guts in order to fool their predators. Other spiders may cover spiders with armor. Spiny orb weavers, for example, have various thorny projections that predators will want to avoid. Some other parasites show flashy displays intended to warn potential predators that they are not the kind of prey that should be meddled with. Recently, we discovered an orb-weaver spider in the tropical forests of China whose abdomen resembles both a large leaf and a dried-up leaf at the same time.

"The rainbow is a magical river with healing powers. But it is so high up toward the sky that you can't climb it. when you catch a cold, the rainbow can't help you." 
The children thought about this. "Mother, please tell us our rainbow story," said Erdoo. "Yes, please mother, I want to hear it too," Udoo chimed in. "Me three," Eryum begged, lifting up three little hands. 
"Well, let me see, …" she said playfully. "Okay lovelies, gather round. Mother, our storyteller knows real!" 
Erdoo ran in the cane, an stirring stick they used by their totem. She handed it over to Mary. Eryum got the headgear for mother should wear. Father never failed to put her on character. 
They all sat quietly to listen to the story they had heard many times. Udoo blew the whistle, telling mum to start. Then said story began. 
"Once, the rainbow was the magical river. All was hidden in the green clouds of Mbadede. Because you had healing powers, everything was magic. 
If you were sick, you drank the river. The rainbow was always nearby to share. But it didn't like badly behaved people."

There are two ways that scientists usually bout amnesia. First, amnesia can happen alongside brain problems. For example, there are some diseases and injuries that can induce damage to the hippocampus and cause memory loss. These include Alzheimer's disease and traumatic brain issue. Both of these changes can cause memory impairment, but they can also cause more problems for a human ability to think. For example, a person with Alzheimer's disease or traumatic brain injury might have difficulty planning for the day or making good decisions. So, when people with Alzheimer's disease or traumatic / injury have memory loss, we say that they have amnesia as one of their symptoms. People in many different people give amnesia as a symptom, about mild balance problems to severe memory problems. Having amnesia as part of a large set of problems is fairly common. But amnesia can also occur by itself, without other problems.

A nerve is a group of special nerve cells grouped together in parallel. Another jargon for neuron network is neuron. The nerves neurons grouped together in nerves take information (messages) to and transmit the human body to the central nerves system. The central nervous system (acronym) CNS is the brain and spinal cord. The spinal cord is the big cord that goes from the brain into the back. It carries all electrical information that goes from the brain to the nerves in the body.
All the nerves in the spine make the peripheral nerve system (acronym<unk> The brain and spinal cord are the CNS. All the nerves that come from the central cord make the PNS. Together the CNS and PNS are the nervous system. The nervous organ contains neurons and cells called brains. Glia cells keep the neurons safe and healthy. These take messages to and from the CNS to activate neurons. The dendrite and axon are fibers you operate on from the cell body. Axons take information away from its cell body. Dendrites take signals to the cell body.

The oldest thing said, "Let the strongest hyena stand on the ground and then let the rest of us stand on each other's backs. We will step onto 1 another's back until we reach the clouds." They stopped and started climbing up from one another's backs. Soon, there still twenty more hyenas left remaining on the ground except the strongest one. After the last hyena climbed up, the hyena on the ground thought that the others had started eating. she asked, "Why don't you give me some of the food you're<unk> However, the hyenas were not reach the clouds. They didn't find any room and so it had nothing to give to the strongest hyena standing on the ground. The strongest guy became impatient and moved to the other side. All the others came falling down to the air side. Be a result, even today all hyenas limp on their right side.

To maintain context in social settings, your brain relies on a range in brain regions, including the frontal, temporal, and insular regions. Some regions help you update contextual information when you focus on something (say, the bright light as you are walking along the street). That information helps you anticipate what might arise next, based upon the previous experiences. If there is a change in what you are seeing (as you keep walking down the street, a mean-looking Doberman appears), the frontal regions will activate and prepare predictions ("this may be dangerous!"). These predictions will be guided by contextual context ("oh, the dog is on a leash") and your previous experience ("yeah, but... you was attacked by a dog and it got very bad!"). If a person's frontal regions are damaged, he may she will find it difficult to recognize the influence through context. Thus, the Doberman may not be perceived as a threat, even if my person has been attacked by bad dogs before! The main role upon the frontal boundaries is to predict the severity of actions by analyzing the contextual events that surround the actions.

Kwesi's parents were Papa and Maame. Maame always advised her child, "Don't go in any river and sea because it is dangerous." 
During the school vacation, Kweku Twum travelled to Simpa (Winneba). He went an spend the holiday in his dad, Kobina Amfo who was a very good fisherman. Kobina Amfo had seen canoes at Simpa. 
When Kweku briefly returned from hunting, he visited his friend Kwesi Gyasi. He told her about his time and enjoyment, especially swimming in the sea! 
Kwesi was interested and wished he also travelled with Kweku to deep sea. 
One afternoon, the four friends decided to get in the village stream. They ran out when nobody was watching. 
As soon as they came to the lake, Kweku Twum jumped into hot water with a splash. He warned Kwesi Gyasi to join him but he did not. He remembered their own advice. 
But Kweku finally convinced his friend to swim. They really enjoyed themselves in the water. 
It was getting late cos the sun was setting. Kweku offered Kwesi to get ready to go home. Kw got out of the water, dried himself, put on his clothes. Kwesi drowned still in the river.

Nowadays, many of our think about corn for primarily food for chickens, pigs, and other farm animals, yet corn has many other uses. In the food industry, corn starch, derived from ground corn kernels, is added into fried foods such as pasta, noodles, sauces, breads, soups, stews, fried baby food. Some edible oils and fats are also made from corn, such as fructose and other sweeteners, used in most sodas – clear juices sold in supermarkets. Processed corn is also used in medicines, cosmetics, glues, paper, paint, paints, wood solvents. Corn residues or "scraps" have already been used to manufacture biodegradable materials prone to plastics. Another use for corn is to use its sugars to make biodiesel fuel for use with cars and other vehicles.
So, not only can we eat corn as an additive mixed into different foods, or as a side sauce on delicious corn on one cob, or grits, or as a snack in the form of nachos and drinks: around the Earth, worldwide remain many dishes—and cultures—that totally revolve around corn. In such cultures, corn constitutes a fundamental component of their cuisines.

There were four lambs living in a town with their sow. Mother was on her duty around the market. "You will open the door only when I say open your door, your children," she warned her lambs. Meanwhile, a fox was nearby and heard the mother. He moved towards the house and demanded, "My children, open the door." One of the lambs said, Man, that is not our mother's voice. Our mother's voice is." The fox was angry. The sow wanted to make his voice like the lambs' mother. They decided to eat butter. He go to a shopkeeper. "Give me some butter, or I will eat you," threatened the fox. The shopkeeper gave him butter. The fox went to the butcher and said, "My children, open the door." A goat peer through the keyhole of the opening and felt the black leg of a fox. "No, our mother's legs are red!" shouted the lamb. Fox was not discouraged. Fox thought of another way. This time he planned to paint his face as pepper powder. Betty went to her miller. "Give me pepper powder, or I will eat you," the fox threatened. The miller gave him pepper powder.

There lived a smart lady. One day she felt very hungry. She thought three ways of getting something good eat. She met a man who asked her, "How are you, young girl? What makes you sad?" The girl answered, "I am<unk> The man was sorry for the girl. He told her there was a feast in the yard and she should go and steal food. The girl had already stolen before. The girl stood up quickly and went to the home that been holding that feast. When she got near, they forgot the lessons on how to steal. She said repeatedly: I have started to eat food, f-o-o-d, I am walking slowly, slo-wly. People heard the song of my girl from far until she got at the homestead. People were amazed by the nature of the song and asked her, "Where do you come from? What can you want? Why are ya singing?" The gal told them how hungry was was, and they gave her food. Later, she was advised that stealing is bad!

Although people have known about liver regeneration for a long time, it was never until the 1960 where liver regeneration was formally studied and discovered to occur in all mammals. To study liver regeneration, since 1931, Higgins and Chapman performed an experiment in rats, in which the two largest lobes of the liver it very carefully removed. Work with animals involves the use of painful instruments, anesthesia, avoiding respectful treatment. Because the liver has a lot of blood vessels, to avoid bleeding, the main vessels of their liver were tied with a special thread. Higgins and Anderson found that the rat liver returned to its normal size in 7 days. Even today, this is still the most popular way for people to simulate liver regeneration. Using experiments of this type, we were able clearly understand which kind of genes, hormones, and growth factor proteins participate in real acceleration of liver regeneration.

A delegate someone who is officially chosen or elected to vote or act for others. In organizations like the United Nations, each party sends delegates to represent them.
Before a general election in the US, the process to select them begins with delegates. At the state level each of the major party parties selects delegates to attend a national convention. The two ways delegates are selected are the caucus and the Primary election. Both state levels have different ways to chose delegates like do political parties. The Republican Party lets its state decide how to select delegates. The Democratic Party uses a proportional method for awarding delegates. The percentage of delegates each candidate is awarded depends around the caucus or how to get allocated for each candidate. Candidate "X" may have 40 50, candidate "Y" may have 20 percent while machine "Z" may have 50 percent. Any remaining percent may be undecided votes or for other campaigns.

Optogenetics are a method to controlling a neuron's activity using light and genetic engineering. Molecular engineering is a process where scientists embed the information in the genetic code (the blueprints) of each living thing. In optogenetic studies, scientists write the genetic code of the neurons they want to study and add a new piece of code to it. This new code allows these neurons to make special proteins, called opsins, which respond to light. Opsins occur naturally and were first discovered in algae, which use these proteins to help them move toward light. But how does the gene get into the neuron? This requires some specialized feeding techniques. Let's look into a mouse as super example. How get that opsin into new neurons of a mouse, the genetic structure for the opsin should be carefully inserted into the synaptic machinery for the neurons in the mouse. If this is done naturally, now every neuron with the mouse should have the opsin. Because we understand a lot about the genetic code of the mouse, we can choose where to put the opsin. One might insert the code into a given type of neuron, or into a specific location in the brain.

Electronic engineering was a discipline whereby investigates all kinds of situations related to electricity and magnetism. Electronic engineers are concerned with such processes as; the transfer of information using radio waves, the design of electronic circuits, the design of computer systems, and the building of control systems such as manual autopilots and other embedded systems. The term electronic engineering started to evolve in the late 1980. Before an East Korean war, electronic engineering was commonly known as a 'radio '. At that time, studying radio engineering at the lab was part on a physics track. Later, as consumer systems started to be developed, the field evolved to include modern TV, audio systems, Hi-Fi and later computers and microprocessors. In the intermediate to late 1950s, the term radio engineering gradually gave way to the name 'electronic engineering', which then constituted a regular university degree subject. Fundamental studies of the discipline are the sciences of physics and mathematics as these help to get both qualitative and literal descriptions of how such systems will work.

Neuroscientists, scientists who study how the brain works, have been very interested in learning whether memories were stored in the brain. Nevertheless, neuroscientists have only very recently begun to study forgetting. To understand how the human brain forgets, we can study how fruit flies forget. Fruit flies are awesome, small insects that are great for scientific research. Either grow very fast in the womb or hence can produce as tissue flies if we want. Their genetic material, or genome, is also very easy to change. DNA is a very long, thin thing that contains the instructions to build any living organism. DNA contains genes, Genetics are sections of the DNA that tell a cell what to make a protein. The instructions contained in the DNA mean any flies can be changed in the lab. Genes is switch removed, making a mutant fly. In this way, we may explore what happens to this fly if a piece of these instructions is removed.

Little Jojo and Tata Rectangle looked everywhere but they couldn not find a spring way. "Go and see why Mama Triangle has the spring horn," said Tata Rectangle. Little Jojo stopped at his house to pour a glass of cold water. Jojo saw Dudu Diamond and wondered if they would go with him. "It's not far but I will pack some food to drink with," said Dudu. Dudu and Jojo stopped at eat and rest at the bottom of the triangle mountain. When they were halfway across the mountain, they saw a strange spider web. Jojo and Dudu arrived at Mama Triangle's mansion. "The chief did not leave his spring horn<unk> said Mama Triangle. Mama Triangle knew where they could see the spring horn. Night became evening when they arrived at Chief Short and Round's house. Papa Triangle pointed towards the chief. They are wearing this spring horn on your head." Chief Short and Round gave Little Jojo the spring horn to enjoy. They were happy.

Tuberculosis (TB) is a very important public health problem. It is estimated that in 2014, 9.6 million people developed TB, and almost 2 million people died by this disease, where India, Indonesia, in China comprise almost half of the cases occurring in this world. TB is triggered by parasitic bacteria called respiratory tuberculosis that often spread from person to people through the air, when someone with the disease coughs, talks, or sneezes. It has estimated that one third to the people concerned with smoking species do not get sick but still have the bacteria hiding in their bodies, in what doctors call a "latent" (or dormant) state.
There remains only one vaccine currently approved prevent TB in humans, and it is called Mycobacterium bovis Bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG). This vaccine has been given to more than 3<unk> people since it was developed in 1921, with around 115 million doses per year donated to us. This BCG vaccine is made from living bacteria that have been weakened in their lab so that they appear unable to cause disease. This type of vaccine, using weak but still living bacteria, is NOT a live attenuated toxin.

The next day he was building a huge compound in Miami to entertain his friend. As soon as the compound was completed, he wished Water to come and visit them. When Water arrived, he asked Sun whether Sun would not safe for him to enter. "Yes, come in, my friend," Sun answered. Water began a flow in. He were accompanied with crocodiles, fish, frogs, snakes, snails, flukes, turtles, and all good water animals. Very soon Water returned knee deep. He asked Sun if she was still there. "Yes," Sun surprisingly answered. So more of water's people came in. Water reached the level of the top of a person's head. He asked Sun, did more of my people come in?" Sun and Water each answered, "Yes." Water flowed on, until Sun and Moon had to perch themselves on the top of the roof. Other people continued its rush in. Very soon they reached the top from the roof. Sun and Sun were forced to go up towards the sky. They have remained in the sky ever since.

The development of antibiotics are one of the biggest successes of modern medicine. Antibiotics have helped millions of lives since doctors started using them in the 1940s. Antibiotics have helped humans to have much better lives by successfully treating almost all types of bacterial infections. But like us, bacteria are changing, too! Since the 1940s, bacteria have been developing tactics to overcome the effects of antibiotics, and nowadays we are seeing further and more bacteria that can no longer be killed by antibiotics at all. These have became known as antibiotic-resistant bacteria or "superbugs," that routinely present a serious threat between the health and people all throughout the world. If parents do not learn tools to stop bacterial infections, even anything as simple as a small infected cut on the finger could become life-threatening. Therefore, new weapons, in the form of new medicines, are needed to treat the infections caused by antibiotic-resistant cells.

Our immune systems work to protect us from illness by recognizing foreign invaders, like those of samples including viruses, while not connecting to our own bodies. Bacteria and viruses that cause infection are known as bugs. When your cells are infected by a pathogen, the pathogen will start to reproduce by making copies of specific DNA through bacteria (cellular instructions) so will ultimately produce a lot of molecules that fight defense mechanisms like human immune system. These pathogen's DNA and the molecules it produces are foreign to our human cells and, therefore, act as a "danger" signal indicating that something has wrong with the infected cell. This danger signal causes phosphatidylserine to be exposed onto the surface of the infected cell to attract it. After macrophages arrive at the infected cell and phagocytose it, they present pieces of the pathogen, known as antigens, from other immune cells, so that the immune response may create a memory of any specific pathogen. If the infected cells are not phagocytosed by macrophages, then more cells, or even the whole organ, can become infected with the pathogen.

The sound is funneled through the outside of the ear, which they called the pinna, into the ear canal. These two parts are called the outer ear. The sound then vibrates the ear skin, which in return sets the ossicles (a set is three tiny bones in the middle ears) up motion. This motion of the ossicles creates fractures in the fluid surrounding the snail-shaped cochlea. The cochlea is located deep inside, at an area called the inner ear. The cochlea is is place where the sound energy is converted into electrical impulses by thousands by neural hair cells. The auditory nerve passes off information to the brain, where the details of the sound such as its characteristics, frequency, width, and direction, are then understood, so that the teenager recognizes the sound of the engine as a car waiting just behind him. This is a time process that happens in less than 2 second. The speed associated each hearing process allows the boy to naturally react.
Our hearing system, especially the hair cells in the inner ear, is very sensitive and would easily be damaged by loud sounds. Once these hair cells are damaged, the damage is permanent.

A long times ago in the reign of the Zulu people, the King Mo ka Ndaba was very beloved, wise, fair and courageous. 
But he had no children and he was worried that he would not have an heir. 
He prayed and requested offerings the the gods but little happened. 
One night while the king was asleep, a witch came in a trance. 
"The gods have heard your plea and the queen will bear twins. Someone can rule the Zulu nation than the other will have magical powers," the witch said. 
Twins Mkabayi and Mmama been born but the king cried for Mkabayi because the rule said that the first- born twin must be offered the the gods. 
Seeing his queen's sadness, the king said, hopefully today, when babies get born, both people will rule 
The people protested but not all were happy with the mysterious new rule. 
The little girls grew beautifully. One time Mkabayi had a stick fight and defeated a boy who bullied him. 
"Go back, you cursed girl!" said one boy. 
"Come back, Mkabayi!" 
Mkabayi cried and ran into the forest where the frightening ghosts, Hornhead and Longtom lived.

One of the best ways parents have found students study impulsivity is with an experiment called the marshmallow test. At the marshmallow test, a kid is marched into a room with a single marshmallow on a roll. The kid sits down in front of the bowl where is told "If this marshmallow is still here in 20 minutes, I'll give you two marshmallows. But if your eat this one boy now, you won't get the second marshmallow." Then, he scientist leaves the room, leaving the kid playing with the marshmallow. Most children spend their time desperately trying to not eat the marshmallow, looking away, closing their eyes, smelling in but not tasting it, trying not to touch it than think about chocolate. Just as with the impulsivity examples discussed at my start of this article, there are two selves in most children—one self wants to eat the marshmallow now, and the other wants to wait to get two marshmallows. Playing is like locking the marshmallow in a box before wandering the room.
Precommitment is the best response to impulsivity. Whatever less we understand about precommitment, the more we can find more novel ways to help people make worse decisions.

If we want to see if kids learn new words from Watching a movie, there are different ways we could do this. We would, of course, show them our story and then measure how many words from the story they know. But is it really that obvious? How would we know that the kids did really already know those words before they heard the stories? We find a really fun solution: we write our own storybooks so we can substitute special words in scripts! These special words are called "target words." The special words we use are bent-up words like "sprock" and "manu." They developed from real words but we make them up. That way, we can know that kids do not already know the words before we even read the stories. Lots on studies use made-up words like these for very same reason. a famous study is named Ear Test". Kids will not heard the word wug before, and if you tell them "Here has a wug, here is another wug, now there are two bottles" they know the next word besides "wugs."

Feedback signals are used all the while to analyze our behavior. They can also be very useful when certain parts for your body are not working well. Should this happens, a doctor may use a small machine to help the actual body parts do their job, and a feedback panel can be used to tell the machine when to help. This way, the machine and feedback device can work along with the rest of your body to make sure everything is working correctly.
Have you heard a the "pacemaker" with a heart? This<unk> a small gadget that patients use to help someone whose heart is not working properly. If you put your ear on your parent's chest you can hear their heart beating. Do you mention how regular this beat is? This regular rhythm is very scary. Your heart needs absolutely beat regularly, with beats evenly split in time, so it can pump blood throughout this body. Unfortunately, some people's heartbeats beat too fast or too slow, and this can be very dangerous.

It is nearly break time at Peace Primary Farm. The two spaza shop owners at primary school are preparing lunch they sell to hungry children. 
In Mr. Tea shop, the bread is cut and ready for making kotas. He rub cuts out to soft middle of each quarter loaf. Then he puts polony and chips in good space inside. Motaung puts two spoonfuls of his wife's homemade atchar in each kota. He likes to boast that his kotas have pockets inside and atchar on top! 
In Mr Mkhize's shop, the chips is nearly ready, but he is still cutting up bread for kotas. He is worried so things are not managing well with his shop. "It started well," thinks Mkhize. "But now I get fewer and fewer customers. At l I'm reducing all of his costs from cutting five kotas from every loaf." 
Jabu and Zodwa are buying lunch. Zodwa eats from Mr. Mkhize. Jabu takes from the Motaung. Everybody believes that Motaung's kota now got more chips and atchar than Mkhize's kota. The queue at Dr. Coffee shop is always longer. Zodwa waits beside Jabu. Eventually the friends sit down in the library to enjoy their kotas.

Leopard were always trying to catch Antelope. And God was always escaping from food. One day, he called out towards Antelope, "Let's be friends. What you eat, I don't eat. Nothing makes us enemies." He agreed. So Leopard proposed, "Let's keep an oath to be together. Since either of us breaks the oath, her child will die." They made their election to be friends. At night, Antelope slept under some tree. Leopard slept in the tree under. Antelope soon became fat. Leopard became thin. Leopard was tempted to breed fat Antelope. She said to herself, "I don't care about the oath. I actually even have a child!" Leopard jumped around to catch Antelope. But she got caught between two branches. Antelope appeared shocked. She leaped up and cried, "Beh! Beh!" Leopard begged, "My friend, help me. We agreed that whoever broke our oath to be friends, would lose a child." Antelope replied, "It must have been your parent who made my oath. Now who is right for you!"

In March of 1897, William McKinley was inaugurated as one of the United States. McKinley was in favor of annexation, and the change in leadership was soon inevitable. On June 16, 1897, McKinley and his representatives of the government of the Republic of Delaware --Lorrin Thurston, Francis Hawkins, Edmund Thomas Kinney-- signed a treaty of annexation. President McKinley then submitted the treaty to the U.S. Senate for approval.
The Hui Ala Aina for Women and the Te Aloha Aina for Men now organized a mass petition drive. They prayed that if the D.S. government realized that the majority of native Hawaiian citizens opposed annexation, the move to annex Hawaii would be stopped. Between September 11 and October 2, 1897, the two volunteers collected petition signatures at several meetings held on each of her three principal rivers of Hawaii. The petition, clearly marked "Petition Against Annexation" and written in both the Hawaiian and English languages, was signed by 21,269 native Hawaiian people, or more than half the 39,000 ethnic Hawaiians + mixed-blood persons reported by the 1921 national census for April same year.

The most selfish part of the biological mind, the id is the source fo our bodily needs, wants, desires, and impulses. Freud believes that the id acts according to our "pleasure principle" – the psychic principle that motivates the tendency to seek immediate fulfillment of any impulse. Its id is the only component and personality that is present from birth, and for good reason. Infants depend on others to provide them with food, help change their diaper, and to avoid pain or discomfort. The id is the part or the mind that compels each baby to cry when he or she is feeling need of something, ensuring a healthy and strong upbringing.
The id, according to Freud, is the most selfish part of our mind. It is only concerned with seeking immediate satisfaction of whatever want or need each body its facing at one moment. Freud stated that the gene "knows no judgements of value: no good and evil, no morality" – only the fulfillment of immediate desires. Infants, for example, do not honor the needs of their parents when they cry.

Once upon a time, its was a man called Byantaka who had a cow. Each day Byantaka washed his cow. He also charged the cow water to drink, but Byantaka only had a very small pot for winter. So, he tried in his neighborhood home a borrow a large pot for water. His neighbor chose to lend Byantaka his biggest clay pot saying, our neighbor's problem solved my problem." After a few days, Byantaka went to a potter and bought a small pot. He took it home. He placed his small pot inside their big pot that he had borrowed from his neighbor. Then, he put this big pot, with their small pot inside it, on his own. He carried a big pot to the neighbor who loaned it to him. Byantaka told him, "I am returning your pot, yours has reproduced." The neighbor was amazed that his pot had produced another pot. He praised Byantaka adding, "Your home is blessed." After a while, Byantaka went back to his neighbour to get the pot again. He did truly have good intentions.
