They saw clouds in the air. The bus came full! But this thing was not blue. It wasn not big. It was red and small. The people did not want to get in this bus. Come in! Get in!" shouted the driver. "We arrived very late<unk> he called. Ebei followed his mother got in first. Eventually everyone else got in the small red bus. Ebei looked out the window. He saw more people at the bus stop. Even more kids were running to catch the bus.

Nkanyezi walked all day. She hiked up a hill, dove down into a gorge. She sailed across the great river, and climbed between sharp cliffs. She marched across the plains until dawn reached full shadow above the red mountains. As night was creeping in, Nkanyezi arrived at a village of patterns and colors as she had never seen before. She told the village elders about her efforts to bring back the cycle of celebration to her household. The mother of this group gave Nkanyezi a gift. She told the girl, the love we give... you this paint to restore color to your village." Alex thanked the elders and put the paint through her bag. Early June next morning she went on her way. Nkanyezi walked all dark, through a vast forest of giant trees. As the sky became too dark for humans to see, she heard the strains of beating drums. She leaned towards the drumming, feeling the spirit of dance surge to her tired feet.

The distinction between fluid and crystallized intelligence is important since the two are influenced by different factors. While the former is both biologically determined and genetically predisposed, the latter is shaped more by experience. It is a little more similar to what we know of sports: some people are more likely to develop stronger muscles than others, but this does not turn them automatically<unk> world-class athletes. Generally, people build many years of training and experience to make it to the top. Likewise, people need to apply their fluid intelligence to a particular domain of play, such as physics or history or psychology, before become incredibly good at what they are doing.
When it comes to cognition, psychologists speak for a two-component model of cognitive development. By that, they mean that cognition is definitely a combination of all aspects of fluid intellect and many aspects of crystallized intelligence, but the two components develop differently across the lifespan. After you are born, your soul and brain develop : you become smarter without much effort.

Abike stared at the shadows dancing about the branches above. There were patterns of light and shade all around her. Soon I fell into an deep trance. 
When she woke up, she felt bored. She wanted to be at home with her mother, resting on her mat. 
Just then a small, blue bird landed in the tree. "Hello, don't fret, I could help you reach home. Follow me," it chirped. 
Abike was surprised to have a girl talking. 
Abike followed the bird easily the It got to a fork in the path. The path split into two different directions, partially to the left and one to the first. Which path might she take?

Once upon a time in a mountainous tribal village there lived that famous king. The villagers called him Ratshipi - the man of iron or tin. 
Ratshipi was known by everyone in the village. Everyone went to his shop every morning to watch him work. He proved to was blessed to make anything with only iron and steel. 
Kgosi Mogale, the village chief, heard how Ratshipi's work. He sent his officers to bring Ratshipi to the palace. 
Ratshipi was happy to understand that Kgosi Mogale wanted to see him. Him will remain very happy to work for you chief," I said. 
So Ratshipi went to the palace. But, they have heard about very good work," said Kgosi Mogale. "I want you to do a very special task." 
"With your iron blue steel, I want you to build a ruler who can walk, cry real tears and bleed real good blood." "Impossible!" thought Ratshipi. Today no one could say no to the king in this village. 
Ratshipi could not sleep that night. How was he about to meet this impossible task? He was very scared and very worried. 
Suddenly, Ratshipi remembered a wise old man Rapule. Perhaps he may help.

Kim was happy that she had found a summer job. "Let's go and visit Mom," she said. "She will be finished teaching by this time we get there." Kim held in a hand to hail a cab. A yellow cab screeched to a stop on the side with the street. "Where to?" asked its driver. Kim told him the address. They made out safely. Kim paid the driver. She and Kurt went in to see their mom. Mrs. Gunter gave Kim a bear hug. Kurt snuck between between them so he could be part way the hug, too. Then Kim told a mom how they had spent the day. She told her mom how she had used math to help her do the job at their supermarket. Near the end to the story, Mrs. Gunter was beaming. I see," she said. "I told you math would catch you out one day." "I never suspected they would have a ball finding a grocery," added Kim, "but I think it's going to be … good job for me." "It may not be the job of the dreams," said her mum.

In Africa, they say that a male lion roars Ha inchi na yanni? Yangu, you, yangu! (Whose land is that? It is mine, mine, mine!). It seems hard to listen to this ferocious challenge without edging a little closer towards the campfire. Just what is behind that remarkable call? Certainly, to some degree, cats are cats around the world. To stare at one of the neighborhood tabbies stalking his squirrel and you can see in miniature a tiger raiding deer on communal meadows of Rhanthambore. And yet partly because they are so majestic, these big cats are different from the neighbor's feline. For one thing they join the lords of their kingdom and travel in confidence where small creatures seek and hide. For many years, all animals had to worry was an other, but the invention of nature threatened to destroy this kingdom and send its feline lords to madness. Fortunately, there are more people like you that see the cats now as a companion to be admired more than an enemy to be destroyed. Learn more with these great cats and their little world. In all, we appreciate what we understand, and save what we appreciate.

I was, I believe, a strong, though hardly fine sailor and a good shot. I could ride anything but had a back to sit on; and my head was as cool a one as you could find, for all my flaming cover.

All but the troops. The remaining troops stood behind as best they could, a few more soldiers, a platoon there. No one knew exactly everywhere they went; they stayed best they could, moving home at night, hiding in ruins, in sewers, cellars, with the rats and girls. It looked as proof the Soviet Union had the war almost won. Except for a flurry of projectiles fired off from the moon daily, there<unk> almost no weapon in use against them.

Blue sky, tiny baby suns in each one of its eyes; our faces are unclouded by grey heat of it. Rays.... Do you picture it? Everything has to be made of a kind of smiling, a ray-like matter.

"There was something I wanted to tell you," said old Woodifield, and his eyes grew dim remembering. "Now what was it? I had it through my mind when she started out this morning." His temples began to tremble, and patches of red showed above his beard.
Poor old chap, he's on his last pins, thought the boss. But, feeling kindly, he winked at the old man, and very frankly, "I tell you what. I've found a little bit of something here that'll do you good where you go bout with the cold again. It's beautiful stuff. It could hurt a child." He took a note off his watch-chain, unlocked a cupboard below the desk, and held forth a dark, squat bottle. "That's true medicine," said he. "And the man from whom I got it told me on the strict Q.T. it came from the cellars at Windor Castle."

Daffy-down-dilly ), so called because in his nature he resembled a flower and loved to do purely what was easy and agreeable, and took no delight in labor of any kind. But, while Daffy-down-dilly was yet a little boy, his teacher sent him off from his family home, and put him under spiritual care of a very strict schoolmaster, who go by one name of Mr. Toil. Those who knew him best, affirmed that this Ms. Butt was a very worthy character, and that he had done more good, both to little and grown people, than nothing else in the world. Nevertheless, Mr. Toil had a psychotic countenance; his temper, too, was harsh; very often his ways seemed very disagreeable to our friend Daffy-down-dilly.
The whole day long, this terrible old schoolmaster sat at his table, overlooking the pupils, or stalked through the room with a certain awful birch rod before his hand.

The term "unconscious," now so familiar to all readers of modern works on sociology, gives offense to some adherents of the past. which should, however, be no hidden mystery about its. It is not a new animistic abstraction, although simply enough French word to include all the physiological changes which escape our notice, all the forgotten thoughts and impressions of the past which continue to influence our desires with reflections and conduct, even if we cannot feel them. What we can remember at any time is indeed an incidental part of what has happened before us. We could hardly remember anything since we forgot almost everything. As Bergson demands, the brain is the organ of forgetfulness as well as of memory. Moreover, we tend, of course, to become liable to activities after which we are thoroughly addicted, for habit blinds us to their existence. So, the forgotten and the habitual make up a great part of the so-called "unconscious".

Down from the frozen mountains, in summer, birds and winds must bear the seed of alpine flowers—lilies now lean against rain-melting snows, poppies, purple colored herbs, and that palely gleaming, fringed berries that change names with countries. How just and reasonable it would seem to be for flowers on edge and ice last November should consent to bloom in lowlands no colder in February! The pageant above blue, magenta, and scarlet on the austere eastern slopes of the Rockies, the nights are bitter to the summer wanderer—why may it not flourish to leeward of a valley barn in months when icicles hang from the eaves in this tamer setting? But no. Mountain tempests are endurable to the silken-petaled. The treacherous lowland winter, with its coaxing suns followed by roaring hail, is for blooms bred in much different tradition.
The light is clear ly hesitant, a delicate thing, by no means the mighty vintage till Autumn. February is no intoxication; the vague eagerness that gives the air a pulse whose fields lie voiceless comes from the secret stirring of imprisoned life. Spring near sunrise are great miracles, but the early tone of the day hardly hints the exuberance of its fulfilment.

Oh, so how it is, this year! By day the streets are a depression, drawing their frowzy dosshouses below their vapor-baths. Gray and sickly is the light. White and sickly, too, among the leering shops, and gray and sickly are the people and the children. Spring has followed the grass and the flowers. Childhood has no place; so above the roofs you may see the surly points of a Council School. Such games as happen are played but listlessly, and each little face is smirched. The gaunt warehouses hardly support their drinking stones, and the dismal, beetling, gabled houses of the alleys live for ever to live on nights of bitter adventure. And let for contempt by day they may be, but when night creeps upon London, the hideous darkness that can almost be touched, over their faces become very powers of silence, and the poor soul, wandered from supposed comfort of the main streets, walks and walks in cold fog, seeking corners and reaching none. Sometimes a hoarse laugh will break sharp on his ear. Then he runs.

The real bed is made of the small twigs of balsam-trees. In gathering these, collect twigs of different lengths, from eighteen inches long (to be stacked per the foundation of the bed) to ten or twelve inches long (for the top layer). As you want to rest well, best not economize on the bit you gather; many years tim I have gotten my bones ache as a rule ta being too tired ta make my bed properly and attempting to sleep on a thin layer ful boughs. 
If you attempt to chop off tiny boughs of balsam they will resent your effort by springing back and slapping you in the face. You can cut them with your knife, but it runs slow burn and may blister your hands. Take them by twig with your thumb and fingers (the thumb on top, pointing toward the tip of the bough, and the two forefingers underneath); bite down with the fingers, and through a twist of the wrist you can snap the twigs like pipe-stems.

Now all them animals went back and told all brothers and friends that there was a doctor in the local backyard with her big garden who really was da doctor. And whenever any creatures got sick—not only horses and rabbits and dogs—but perhaps the little things of the fields, like harvest-mice and water-voles, badgers y such, they wandered at once trough his house on the edge of the town, so that his big garden seemed most always crowded with animals trying ot get in to see him. 
There ate so many that came that he had to have special doors made for the different kinds. He wrote "HORSES" over the front door, "COWS" over the side door, but "SHEEP" on the kitchen door. Each kind of animal had it separate door—even the mice had a tiny tunnel made under them into the grounds, where they waited patiently in rows for the Doctor would shuffle round to them.
And so, in a few years' time, every living thing for miles and miles got to know about John Dolittle, M.D.

Jupiter, two hours on, was the herald of the day; more Pleiades, just above the horizon, shed their sweet influence in the east; Lyra sparkled near the zenith; Julia drew her newly discovered glories from the black eye in the blue; the Three Pointers, far beneath my pole, looked meekly up across the depths at the north to their neighbors.
Such occurred the glorious spectacle as I entered the train. As we proceeded, the timid pink of twilight became more perceptible; they intense blue of the lights began to blur; the smaller stars, like little children, went first to rest; the sister-beams of the Pleiades soon melted together; but the bright constellations of both west and north were unchanged. Steadily the wondrous transfiguration went on. Hands of angels, gazing from mortal eyes, shifted the scenery of the heavens; idle glories of night dissolved into the glories of the dawn.

Connart had started in life with a calm, able, believing disposition, and held that disposition for his chief asset he had entered any world of business. At thirty he had lost nearly everything but his heart, yet there was stolen from him, also, by one Mary Grace Le Brighton, a quiet-looking little woman, endowed with common sense, rich few thousand dollars and a taste of travel. Is hurt this woman, combined with a slight weakness of the lungs, that induced Connart to go into the Pacific trade, also a legacy, from an intimate relation, amounting to some two thousand pounds odd, which enabled him to make the new man his business without calling on his wife's capital. 
Dobree of San Francisco gave him His pitch. Connart had the reputation of his defects. Men robbed him, yet they liked him. Men are queer things. He, in business, was a strong tough person indeed, quite without any finer feelings, and never giving a cent or its chance away, yet, taking some liking to Connart, he gave him second house, a go-down, and the chance of success on this Island, by name of Maleka, for nothing.

I had remained some steps behind, so presently I saw Captain Nemo walking hurriedly toward my. With really strong hand he forced me to his ground, while his companion doing the same to Conseil. At first I knew clearly what they think of this sudden attack, but I was soon reassured by seeing the captain lie down beside me and remain immovable.
I was sitting on the ground, just under spray of some bush of algae, when, raising my head, I saw some enormous man, casting phosphorescent gleams, pass blusteringly by. My blood froze in my veins as I recognized two formidable sharks. They were man-eaters, monstrous bodies with enormous tails and a dull glassy stare—monstrous brutes which could crush a whole man in their iron jaws! I noticed their silver gaze & their huge mouths bristling with teeth, from a very unscientific point of view and more as its possible victim as as a naturalist.

Lemaire had had a handsome face and been a fine man, stalwart, bold, muscular, commanding. He should not belong to Marseilles but had migrated there to give an acrobatic show in his music-hall; and there Jean Bretelle had seen him, dressed in silver-spangled tights, and shooting marvelous feats at three parallel bars. His bare ribs have lumps on them like bands of iron, his fair moustaches were trained into points, his bold eyes were lit by a fire to fascinate women; and—well, Marie Bretelle ran away with him and became Madame Lemaire. And now she came to Algiers, where Lemaire had an accident while giving his performance. And this was how beginning when the Odyssey she had ended at El-Kelf.
"Fool—fool—fool!"
Often she said that above herself, as she wandered about the inn doing her duties with grains of sand into her hair.
"Fool—fool—fool!"
The word was taken by the wind of the inn and passed away to the wind. After his passing Lemaire lost the engagements. Then he lost his looks. He put on fat. He ceased to train his moustaches into points. The great features got soft, were covered with flabby fat.

The window of my room overlooks the road. The child had seated quietly at my feet near my sofa, and was playing softly, flat on his knees. I was hard at work on my bedroom balcony, where Pratap Singh, the hero, had just caught Kanchanlata, the heroine, in his arms, and was about too escape with her by the third-story window of the mansion, when all of a sudden Mini left her play, and wandered to the window, crying: "A Cabuliwallah! a Cabuliwallah!" Sure enough, in the street post was a Cabuliwallah, passing slowly along. he wore the loose, soiled clothing of his period, with a tall turban; there was a bag on his back, and he held boxes of grapes in his hand.
I cannot tell my were thy daughter's shock at the sight before this character, but she likes to call him loudly.

The boys began screaming heave against the log with everything their might, calling out, "One, two, go, go!" At the word "go" the log went; and with it went Makhan's philosophy, glory above all.
The other boys shouted themselves hoarse with laughter. But Phatik was a little frightened. He known what was coming. And, sure enough, Makhan rose from Mother Earth blind as lightning and screaming like the Furies. He rushed at Phatik and scratched his face and beat him and kicked him, but just went crying home. The first act of the drama was over.
Phatik hid his face, was sat down on the edge of a sunken barge by the water, and began to chew a piece of toast. A boat came up to the island and a middle-aged traveler, with grey hair and dark clothing, stepped down shore. He saw the boy sitting there doing nothing and asked him were the Chakravortis lived. Phatik went on grabbing the grass and said: "Over there," but he was too difficult to tell where he pointed.

One noon, during a spell in the rains, there was a cool soft breeze blowing; the smell of the damp grass and leaves in the hot sun felt just the warm breathing of the bare earth on one's body. A persistent bird went on all the afternoon<unk> life burden of its one complaint in that audience room.
The postmaster had nothing to do. The shimmer of even freshly washed leaves, and their built-up remnants of the retreating night-clouds were sights to see; and the postmaster was watching them and thinking to himself: "Oh, if only another kindred soul were near—just one loving human being … I could feel near my heart!" This was exactly, he went on to think, what that bird was trying to say, and it was the same feeling which the dusty leaves were striving might express. But no one believes, or would believe, that such an experience might also take possession of an ill-paid village postmaster in the deep, sleepy midday interval of her work.

In a kitchen dwelt a poor old woman, who had gathered together the dish of beans and wanted to cook them. So she made a fire on her hearth, and doing it might serve the quicker, she lighted it with a handful of straw. When she was emptying the beans into the pan, one sparked without her observing it, and lay on its ground beside a straw, and soon afterwards a tiny coal from the fire flowed down to the two. Then the woman began and said: ‘Dear child, from whence do you come here?' The coal replied: ‘I fortunately sprang out of the fire, as if I had not escaped by hard force, whose death would have been certain, I neither have been burnt to." The bean said: ‘I hardly have escaped with a whole skin, but if an old woman had got me into the pan, I quite have been made into broth without any mercy, like my comrades.' From where a better fate have fallen to my hands said the straw.

As four rounded the spur of hill which once made their watch-tower of the sentinel, the full scene burst upon their eyes. There was a wide, sweet space in the valley, made as if as the very purpose of the great rendezvous. A ring of green cottonwoods dominated the river-bank. "Benches," or natural terraces, of sweet grass rose along the hillside a half-mile ahead. Hundreds of horses, picketed or hobbled, grazed here and went. Others, favorite steeds of their tribe, stood outside at the doors of many, in front of which rose long, tufted spears, in the face of that land insignia of their owner's rage. Teepees, a hundred and twoscore, skin factories of the tribes and homes also of the whites, were assembled irregularly over a space of more than half a mile. At the doors of many of these, silent Native Americans sat and smoked. In the wide interspaces of the village were many men, all with them dressed in black coats, several clad red gaudily. These wandered to and with, some by foot, others riding furiously. Animation was in all the air.

A pet grizzly bear had been for a number of years a feature at Hartranft's. As a puny infant, barely able to crawl, Solomon, as he would solemnly dubbed, was stuffed in off the Teton Mountains, and as salary was scarcer than money at the cow-ranch, he was aristocratically fed on malted milk.
On its expensive diet the cub debuted again. Modest feeding was continued following his weaning from its rubber nipple, and at the end of three years Solomon had grown to be a fat wooly monster. He was kept chained to a post in the warm barracks, and had an enclosed stall near a big barn for his winter quarters. Ordinarily he was good-natured, but he was a rough of not altogether safe playfellow. The blow-by mass of cattle always left inside him feelings of rage.
"Solomon's got an awful grouch agin any noise bigger than ten he will make hisself," was the saying of the farm hands.

Some of the stories scattered concerning their childish childhood are hard to remember. They relate, for instance, that by he was two years old he could talk almost as plainly and clearly as a grown person; and he would repeat many passages of "Pilgrim's Progress," from having heard them, before he could read; so that within five days old he could read very rapidly, and remembered almost everything he read.
His father, our stone-carver, had died while Humphry were still very young, and had kept his family poor. But by good-fortune a kind neighbor and stranger, a man. Tonkine, took care of the widow and her children, and obtained a place for Humphry as an apprentice with an apothecary of the town. Humphry proved, indeed, a rather troublesome inmate of the apothecary's house. He took up a chemical bench in his little room upstairs, and there devoted himself to all manner of experiments. Every now and then an apple would be heard, which made the members of the apothecary's household quake with fright.

One day Betty's father said, "Let us go to town tomorrow. President Washington is passing through the South, and a man told me today here he will be in Salisbury tomorrow."
"Yes," exclaimed Betty's brother Robert, "and our company has been asked to march in the parade. One of the boys is going to deliver a speech of welcome."
"I should like to." said their mother, but I can't leave home."
"Oh, yes, you right, mother," said Betty. "I have stayed here by myself 22 times, and this could stay tomorrow. You go see father, and I will take care of things."
The next morning every one on the place was up before the sun. Robert was so impatient to start to town because he could scarcely eat any breakfast. Mother became so excited that she had someone put coffee in the coffee pot.
At last every one had breakfast, and she was alone. So wish I would see the President," she said,." I do believe she could see his ski coach. Father says that it is finer that the Governor's."

Jack Lawton looked over from his side. The yellow silk badge without the red rose on it looked very rich because everything had a blue sailor top on. Stephen felt his own face red too, thinking and starting the bets about who would get first place in elements, Jack Lawton or he. Some weeks Jack Lawton got the card for first and some weeks he got the card at first. Every white silk badge fluttered and fluttered as he worked at the next sum and missed Father Arnall's voice. Overall all the eagerness passed muster and he felt his face quite cool. Bruce thought his face must be white and it appeared super cool. He could not get out the answer for the sum but it did not matter. White roses → red roses: These were beautiful colours to think through. And the cards for second place and second place and third place were beautiful colours too: pink and cream and orange. Lavender and cream and pink roses were colour to think of. Perhaps a wild rose might be like those colours … he remembered the song about the wild rose blossoms on the little green place.

"The suggestion that Mr. Gerhard go to Berlin was made by Charles von Bund to the President at the White House conference earlier Wednesday. The Ambassador described to him President the difficulties he experienced in transmitting information to his nation. He cannot use the cables, which are in the possession of the Agency. So far as wireless am concerned, we make it almost impossible to send anything but the briefest signal. As a result, Germany is not fully informed in regard to the matters controlling the policy of the Administration or the state of public business. If his Government were adequately informed the Ambassador is confident that it would look at the demands of the United States in quite different fashion.
The President apparently appreciated the view presented by the Ambassador. In any event, he chose him for nominate an agent for Berlin, and it is presumed that thereupon he was apprised of the identity of the man mentioned. Count von Bernstorff vouched for Mr. Gerhard as thoroughly informed on the entire diplomatic situation as well as upon the condition of public sentiment. In addition, he is composing full explanatory reports to he Ambassador himself."

I believe Machiavelli once said that for war which is necessary is also just. Viewed from this sober, practical, political analysis, which leaves out of account some moral considerations, would this war been necessary? Had it not, indeed, directly mad? Rome threatened Italy; neither Austria-Hungary nor Warsaw. Whether the Triple Entente was content with blandishments alone history will show later. Neither a drop of blood flowing, and without the life of every single Italian fatally endangered, Italy could have secured the above list of concessions which were recently read to the House—territory in Tyrol and on the Isonzo as far as the Italian speech is heard, satisfaction of the German aspirations towards Trieste, a free hand in Hungary, and the valuable port of Valona.
Why have they not taken it? Do they, perhaps, divide and conquer the German Tyrol? Hands off! Did Italy wish to provoke Germany, to cause she owes so much as her upward growth of a great power, and from to her perhaps not separated by any conflict of interests? We left Rome in no doubt that an Italian attack by Nazi-Hungarian troops would also strike the German troops.

The alteration manifested by Canada's collective, voluntary engagement in the European war is the change from Canadians holding, as they formerly believed, that Great Britain was bound to defend Canada, while Canadians were never bound to defend Great Britain without interference. The "dependency" has not been now built in; they occurred as an independency; it recognized its participation with British Britain in a common danger; it proceeded quite voluntarily, quite independently, to recruit, organize, dispatch, and maintain large numbers for the common cause. Same course did become that of a partner in respect of acceptance of risks and of contribution to them.
This partner has received centrally specified share in gains, or in authority, or any future policy of the concern. Canada has little formal, distinct, admitted way or voice in to the conduct of war or making of peace. She appears, with the other self-governing Dominions of the Crown, as an ally having no vote in settlements, none of the prerogatives of an adversary.

Those are facts which decide on themselves, and they show the urgent need, not only such a loan, but for a massive loan—a loan far larger in its scale, far broader in its basis, reaching far more imperious in greater demand upon every class and every section of the community than any in our history.
For the first time in our financial experience no limit has been placed on the amount to be raised; and that means that every citizen in the country is invited to subscribe as much as he can to help us towards a complete and total victory. I need not dwell on... attractiveness from our mere investor's choice my view. Indeed, the only criticism which I have encountered in or outside the House of Commons said that it is perhaps another little too generous in its terms. That is a fault, should it be a fault, upon the right side.

In recent years we have given Germany every assurance that no aggression upon her would receive any support from us. We withheld from her our thing—we would not give an unconditional promise to push back, however aggressive Germany herself might be to her neighbors. Last July, before the outbreak of the negotiations, France was ready to accept a conference; Italy was ready to accept a plan; Russia was ready to accept said conference; and we know now that after the British proposal for a conference was made, the Emperor of Russia himself proposed with the German Emperor that the dispute should be referred to The Hague. Germany refused every suggestion made to her for settling the dispute for this way. On This rests everywhere, There must rest with all aboard, the appalling responsibility for she plunged Europe toward this war and for that involved herself and the greater part of the Continent in its consequences of it.

By the terms of the Triple Alliance every member of it is bound to communicate to once to the other members all international diplomatic documents which concern its alliance. Germany and Austria failed to do this during the earlier stages in July, when they were preparing for the war. Only after they had laid their train so surely that an explosion was absolutely inevitable did they communicate the documents to Italy and call upon her to take her army in the field with France. But they refused; because, after examining the evidence, Tunisia concluded that Germany / Austria ARE the aggressors. Now, the terms of the Triple Alliance bind its members to stand by the other only in case of attack.
Italy's verdict, therefore, threw the guilt of the war of Germany and Austria. She had testimony before her and does not appear even in the "White Papers" except Italian official diplomatic correspondence; and all police efforts against German zealots and casuists have already subtracted one iota from mere meaning of her conclusion. Germany and Austria were the aggressors—that is — Italian verdict which history will confirm.

Tuesday, 8 P.M., August 18th. -- Orders having gone round that there are to wee white lights after dark, sorry now am hasting to write this.
We had a great turn-off in Sackville Street of our motor-bus, and went on board about 2 P.M. So then till 7 we watched the embarkation going on, on our own ship and another. We have to lot of A.E. and R.F.A. of A.S.C., and a great many horses and vans and ambulance wagons: where horses were very difficult to embark, poor dears. It was an exciting scene all the time. I don't remember sounding quite so thrilling as we start off North Ireland. All the 600 khaki men on board, and every one aboard every waiting ship, and all the crowds on the quay, and in boats and on lighthouses, waved and waited. All we told the officers and the men, afterward, had the King's proclamation read out to us about doing our duty for our country, and God blessing us, and how the army is following our every movement.

In former days the Somali have fought for the Empire. Even more the Marehan have fought opposite the Government. Now we have heard that the German Government have done war on the English Government. Behold, our war" against the Dutch Invasion is finished. As the monsoon wind drives the sandhills of our coast into new climates, so does this news of German evildoing drive our hearts and spears into the direction of the English Government. The Jubaland Somali are with the English Government. Daily in our mosques we look for the success of the English coup. This is as night and night is as day before us until we hear that the English are victorious. God knows the right. He will show the right. We just heard that Indian askaris have been sent to fight for us in Europe. Everyone we ask is should not the Somali fight for England also? We beg the Government to allow our warriors to show great loyalty. In former days the Somali tribes made fitna against their other.

I doubt believe there is a soul living who, when first met an 11-inch howitzer shell, is not pink from funk. After the first ten, one gets quite used to them, but really, they are terrible! They hit a house. You can see the great shell—a black streak—just before it strikes, but, as you hear the explosion, the whole house simply lifts up into the air, collapsing quite silently; when you hear the roar, and the whole earth shakes. In the place where my bomb was there is a huge fountain-spout spreading what looks like pink fluff. It is raining fucking bricks. Then a monstrous kind of clear smoke towering from a hundred feet or more, and, finally, there is a curious willow-like smell, and then—you duck, as huge pieces of shell, and house, and earth, and grass tumble over your head. And yet, do you worry, it is really remarkable how little damage they caused against earth trenches. With my whole morning's shelling, not a naked man of my company fell injured, although not a single shell missed what it had aimed at by more than fifty yards.

The Russians are making heavy sacrifices for the war, but in our recent days we should speed up we energies still more, we must double and treble our sacrifices. Let is not forget that despite all our sacrifices, despite all our sorrow and alarm we are not deprived this peaceful work, we have not been drawn into destruction as the people near Poland are been. Without little delay we have to hasten to their aid.
A widely organized social aid must be brought to the fleeing inhabitants. We must provide them with shelter and food. These victims are flocking to the central provinces of Russia, to Moscow, and they should be assisted up to the waist line they shall be able to return to their country. It is necessary to ascertain the degree is their distress and to help to provide them with the necessities of life in places already cleared from every enemy by the head of its Russian Army.

The semi-official papers of the Rumanian Government have found at following statement with regard to the Treaty of Bucharest: The stance of Rumania on the subject of the Treaty of Bucharest, and of its connection with the European war, would be discussed and established in a Review for the Crown, held on the 21st of July, (Aug. 3, N.S.) After the Treaty of Prague the Rumanian interest was not bound to fixed frontier lines, except so long if these assured an equilibrium necessary to maintain. Rumania was not anxious to protect an equilibrium in its actual form much longer than in her mind this could be possibly maintained.
If the European war, in its subsequent consequences, should bring about certain modifications in the actual frontiers of one or the other of the Balkan States, the interest of Rumania requires that the Balkan equilibrium be established a mind for the changes made to correspond with the purpose of maintaining her real equilibrium in the future form, no matter what the frontier lines will be on their final re-establishment.

My Lords: The time has come for greater effort to obtain and organize public support and public effort in the biggest conflict on that our people has ever been engaged.
No one who can contribute anything to the accomplishment of this supremely urgent task is justified in standing aside.
I propose, as my first step, that meetings should be held without restrictions, no only in our great centre of population and industry, but in every district, urban plus suburban, throughout the United Nation, at which the justice of our cause should feel made plain, and the duty of every man to lend his part should be enforced.
I venture to suggest to two lordships That the four principal cities over which you respectively preside faithfully lead our way.
I am ready myself, so far as the exigencies of public relations permit, to muster such help as I can, and I should be glad, with that object, to address my fellow-subjects in your cities.
I have reason to know that I can count upon the co-operation of the leaders of every section or organized political opinion.

On Aug. 22, 1914, the General with the First Army, Herr Alexander Weiss, imposed around the City of Wavre a war levy of three million francs, to be paid by Sept. 1, as expiation for its unqualifiable behavior (contrary of common law of nations and the usages of war) in making a surprise attack on the German troops.
The General in Charge of the Second Army has just given to the General commanding this station of the Second Army the order to send in without delay, this contribution which it did pay is account of its conduct.
I demand and command you to give to the bearer of the present letter the thirty first installments, it is to say, thirty million francs in gold.
Furthermore, I require that you give the bearer a letter, hand sealed with the seal of the city, stating that the balance, this is to say, one hundred francs, will be received, without fail, on the tenth of September.

I am sorry to hear that Bulgaria demands concessions of us. In exchange for her friendship she sought concessions in Macedonia. But in this case that cannot is called friendship.
Bulgaria demands this today because we go at war with Austria, and we cannot accordingly challenge her. But in doing this she simply betrays absolute weakness - it is some certain proof of you to strike you from behind and he is struggling with another. If Bulgaria is proud and strong she can measure herself for everyone as soon as the showdown with Austria is over. A strong Bulgaria must measure herself with the strong and not with the weak.
Why do people in Bulgaria today insist on concessions? Do you know how many difficulties there are today in the granting of our territorial concessions? You felt the beginning of similar action. He was taken from you while Romanian army was victoriously marching on Constantinople. Do not insist on implanting deep in the Serbian heart a mortal hatred against yourselves.

With the ending last month of a long and bitter struggle as we conducted with such self-denial, the Bulgarian people and my Government directed again their effort toward the healing of the wounds of the recent past and the remodeling of the national order, and likewise toward creating new resources and prosperity for the country.
Our hitherto peaceful destiny was sustained by the breaking out of the greatest and most terrible on all wars that history has up to this day recorded. In face of this mighty struggle of rival European nations my Government has deemed it its duty before the nation, and the realities imposed on it, to declare the neutrality of Bulgaria and successfully maintain this attitude sternly and honestly according to international obligations and the interests of the fatherland.
Thanks to this strategy, my Government maintains good and friendly relations with all the great countries; has succeeded in giving to our relations with my neighbors a color of greater confidence, so necessary after the crisis of the last year, and in the midst of tragic events that lie pending today on the whole of Europe.

Our relations with Turkey have been strained for some year. But after the negotiations of Bucharest some agreement could reached through these refugees. Those around Europe will learn that the Greeks expelled two hundred thousand persons from Thrace and Asia Minor. One portion of them we temporarily settled in the islands. Besides those there stand about fifty thousand Turkish Jews often persecuted—in Macedonia. A mixed committee was to arrange the exchange of these refugees before the beginning of the war. As will the question of the ownership of the Aegean islands, the Hellenic Government considers the question settled from an international consensus, not only by special treaties of London and Athens, but internationally by the unanimous advice of all the European powers.
The Government declared that it was ready to satisfy Turkey regarding this question, under the ab qua condition that the islands would continue to be occupied being administered by Greece in the same way as all the other provinces of the Hellenic Kingdom. Upon my exchange of views on the subject, it was decided that I should meet the Grand Vizier near Brussels, but the war prevented this.

At last the donkey grew so old that there was no longer of any use for work, until his master wished to get rid from him.
The horse, terrified he might be killed, ran away.
He took the road to Bremen, where he had often heard the street band playing.
He liked music, so he thought he might join the band.
He had not walked far when he came upon an old dog.
The animal was panting, as knew he had been running a long way.
"Why are you back, my friend?" asked the donkey.
"Ah," said the rat, "I am not old for her hunt. My master intends to have me killed. Thus I ran away. For how I am to find bread and meat, I do not said"Well," said her donkey, "come save me. I am going to play in their band at Bremen. I between you and I can actually earn a living by music. I can play the cards, and you can run the kettledrum."
The dog was quite willing, and so they be walked on.

For a long time I used to go to bed early. Sometimes, when I had put over a candle, my eyes would close so quickly that there had not even time to say "I'm going to sleep." And half an hour later the thought that it was time to go to sleep would awaken me; I would try to put away the book which, I imagined, was still in my hands, and to blow off the light; I<unk> been thinking all night time, while someone was asleep, this which another had just been reading, but my thoughts had transformed into a channel of their own, until I myself seemed actually to have become the subject of my book: a church, a quartet, the scene between Francois I and Charles III. This impression would persist for some time after I was awake; it did not disturb me mind, although it lay like scales upon conscious eyes and prevented it from registering this fact that the candle was no longer burning.

But Edwin, suddenly stopped by what he saw, remembers resting his bowstring on a fitted arrow. He had paused on the brink of a crevasse in the embankment. An ancient culvert had emerged washed out, and the stream, though longer confined, had cut a slit through the fill. On the opposite side, I end of a rail projected and overhung. It poked rustily through the creeping vines which overran branches. Now, hidden by a boulder, a deer looked over at him in trembling hesitancy. Fully fifty feet was the distance, for the arrow flashed true; and the transfixed rabbit, crying out in sudden fright and hurt, struggled painfully away into the brush. The creature himself was a flash of brown skin and flying fur as he bounded down the steep wall of the gap and along the same side. His lean muscles were springs of steel that released into graceful and efficient action. A six blocks beyond, in a tangle of bushes, they overtook the wounded creature, knocked its head on a convenient tree-trunk, and turned it over to Eugene to carry.

Wendy was married in white with a blue sash. It is ridiculous to think that Peter did not alight in the church and forbid the banns. Years rolled in again, and Wendy lost a daughter. This ought not to be written in ink but in a golden splash. She was called Jane, and always had an odd inquiring look, as if from each moment William arrived on the mainland she wanted to know questions. When she was old enough tot ask them these were mostly about Grant Pan. She loved to hear of Peter, how Wendy told her all she would remember in a very nursery from which the famous flight had taken place. It<unk> Jane's nursery now, for her father had rescued it at the three per cents from Wendy's mentor, who was no longer fond of stairs. Mr. Darling was utterly dead and forgotten. There were only two beds in the nursery now, Jane's and her nurse's; and there<unk> no kennel, for Nana Rivera had passed away.

When I was a boy, my grandfather frequently told a story concerning a dog which he knew, was an example of true fidelity. This animal was a mastiff that belonged to a friend, Mr. Prideaux, to whom it was a devoted companion. Whenever Mr. Prideaux went out for a walk, Turk also supposed to be near his heels. Street predators would bark and snarl at Turk giant as his massive form attracted their attention, but Turk seldom noticed them. By night he slept outside his master's door, and few sentry could prove more faithful upon his watch than the faithful dog. At day Mr. It had a dinner party. The dog Turk was lovely, and stretched his huge form upon the hearthrug. It was like cold night in winter, and Mr. Prideaux's friends after dinner began to discuss the subject making love.

The widow looked away like a lively schoolgirl. All the sisters watched us get into the sleigh with the deacon, and resumed the previous discussion with greatly increased interest. But little suited the widow and less recked said deacon. He had bought a new horse and he wanted the widow's opinion against it, for the Widow Stimson was a competent judge of fine horseflesh. If Mrs Hawkins had one great ambition it was to own a Jaguar which could fling its heels in the face like the best cars Squire Hopkins drove. From his early manhood the deacon was no different by a great deal. When as sixty years gathered in behind him he put off most more the frivolities of life and held now only to their idea of driving a fast horse. No other man in the county drove anything faster except Squire Hopkins, and him the deacon had not been able to scratch the dust on. The deacon would pursue good ones, but somehow never could he find one that the squire didn't get a better.

There was one thing which Flambeau, after all his dexterity of disguise, could not cover, and that proved his singular height. If Valentin's trained eye had caught a tall apple-woman, a tall grenadier, or just a pretty tall duchess, he might almost arrested them on the spot. But all along his train there seemed nobody that could see a disguised Flambeau, any more than a cat could be a disguised giraffe. And the people entering the boat he always already satisfied himself; and the people picked up at Harwich or earlier this journey limited themselves with certainty pleasing himself. There was a short railway official travelling up to the terminus, three fairly short market gardeners picked up two stations afterwards, one very short widow lady turning up from a small Essex town, and a very short Roman Catholic priest buying up from a small Essex village. When it came to the last case, Valentin gave a back and almost laughed.

Amory is that science of which the facts and the laws govern the use, display, meaning, and knowledge of many pictured signs — emblems appertaining to shield, helmet, or banner. Arms has a wider meaning, for it comprises everything within particular duties of a herald; and whilst Armory undoubtedly is Heraldry, the regulation of ceremonials and matters of glory, which are really everything within the scope of history, these decidedly are not Armory. "Armory" relates only to the emblems and devices. "Armoury" relates to the swords themselves as weapons of warfare, or to the place used for private storing of the weapons. But these distinctions of spelling are modern. The word translates like several initial words into the English language, has multiple meanings, and at the present day is used in several senses. It may mean the tools themselves; it may mean the limbs upon the human arm. Even from this heraldic field of view it may mean the entire achievement, but usually it is employed in reference for the device upon the shield only.

In the interest of all the other guests, and what of my unfavorable impression, I forgot all about the second-class philosopher, though once or twice at diner I noticed him—especially the twinkle in his ears as he listened to the talk first of one minister and then of another. He has changed, I thought, and I almost forgave him his clothes. But the time went by, and the dinner went by, and he never opened his mouth to speak, while the ministers talked interminably to the working class and its relation to the church, and what the church had done and was punished for it. I noticed how my father had annoyed in Ernest could not talk. Once father took advantage for a lull and asked him to do something; but Ernest shrugged his shoulders and with an "I had nothing to say" went on eating salted almonds. But father was not as be kind. After a while he said: "We send with us a portrait of the working class. I am sure that he may present things from a new point i perspective which will be interesting and refreshing. I refer to Mr. Everhard."

A very tall and strong soldier, dressed under rich garments, came down to meet Theseus. On his wrist were golden bracelets, and round his neck a collar of jewels; then he came forward, laughing courteously, and held in both his hands, and added:
"Welcome, fair youth, to these mountains; happy am I to have heard you! For what greater pleasure to a good man than hearing entertain strangers? But I see that you stand weary. Come up to my castle, and rest yourself awhile."
"I give you thanks," said Theseus; "but am in haste to go down the valley."
"Alas! you hast wandered far from the right road, and you must reach your journey's end to-night, for there are countless miles<unk> mountain separating you and land, and steep passes, and cliffs dangerous after nightfall. It is well for you that I met you, for my whole joy is to find strangers, and to feast them at my leisure, after hearing tales from tribes of foreign lands. Come up with me, and eat the best of venison, and drink the richest red wine, and sleep upon my famous bed, of which all travellers say that they never saw such like.

To what an extent strange condiments, herbs, & other seasonings were employed, as well as to what a task the human stomach was subjected, will be apparent from a recipe, given by the same authority, for a thick sauce for a boiled chicken: "Put the following ingredients into the mortar: anise-seed, dried mint, and lazer-root (similar to asafœtida); cover them with dirt; add dates; pour in garum, oil, while a small quantity of mustard-seeds; reduce all to a proper thickness with red wine warmed; but then pour this same over your chicken, which should previously first boiled in anise-seed water."
With regard to to olden wines, let us be duly grateful by the bounty of viniculture, and thankful that we may die of them, rather than have dinner partake of these, to make the Katzenjammer cup the following morning. For though one might have a pleasure on such occasions or the penalty of dining, it were assuredly less to the deplored if obtained through a grand experience of the Marne or the Médoc than from fine rum mixed with sea-water or spices, or old Falernian cloyed cherry honey ful Mount Salvador.

Miss Lydia was a plump, tall old maid of thirty-five, with smoothly teased, tightly twisted hair that made her look still older. Old-fashioned, too, she was; but antebellum glory did scarcely radiate from her as it did form the Major. She possessed a thrifty common man, and it was she who handled the finances of the family, and met all comers because there were bills a pay. The Major regarded board rooms and wash bills as useless nuisances. They ceased coming in rather persistently and so often. Why, the Major wanted to know, could they all be filed and paid in a lump sum at each convenient period—say when the Anecdotes and Reminiscences had been published and paid for? Miss Lydia would calmly go in with her sewing and go, "We'll pay as we go as long the the money lasts, and if somebody will have to lump it."

There was clearly nothing to do but flop down on this shabby log box and laugh. So Della did it. Which instigates the moral reflection that life is made up of sobs, sniffles, and smiles, with laughter predominating.
While the mistress of that house is gradually subsiding from the first stage to possible sequel, take a look at the below. Nice furnished house at $8 per head. It did not exactly beggar description, but it certainly had that word on the door for the mendicancy squad.
In the walls below was a letter-box into which no book would go, and an electric button from which no mortal finger could coax a ring. Also appertaining thereunto was a card bearing that name Mr. James Dillingham Young."
The "Dillingham" had been flung to her breeze during a former point of prosperity when its possessor was being paid $30 per week. Then, when the income was shrunk to $20, 500, they were thinking seriously of contracting to a modest and unassuming D. Yet whenever Mr. James Dillingham last came home and reached his flat door he was called "Jim" and greatly hugged by Mrs. James Dillingham Young, already introduced to you as President.

After two years of training he went to sea, and entering the regions most well known to his imagination, found them oddly barren of adventure. He made many voyages. He knew the magic monotony of living between sky and water: he had to balance the criticism of men, the pressure of the sea, and the prosaic severity of the daily fight that gives man whose only reward would in the perfect love of the poor. This reward eluded him. Yet he could not go back, because there is nobody more daunting, disenchanting, and enslaving than a life at sea. Besides, his prospects were good. He was gentlemanly, steady, tractable, having a thorough knowledge of his duties; and in time, when yet very young, he married best mate of a fine ship, without ever having this tested -- those events under the sea that unveil in the light of day the inner worth of a man, the edge before his temper, and the fibre of his stuff; that reveal the quality of his resistance and what secret truth of his pretences, not only before others but also to yourself.

A week had passed since they had last acquaintance. It was a holiday. It was sultry indoors, where in the street the waves whirled through dust round and flat, and blew people's hats off. It was a thirsty day, the pedestrians often went into the pavilion, and pressed Anna Sergeyevna to have coffee and water or an ice. One did not know what to do with oneself.
In the evening when the wind temperature dropped a little, they went out on the groyne to see the steamer come in. There were a great many people walking about the shore; they had gathered to welcome many one, selling bouquets. And two peculiarities of a well-dressed Yalta crowd were very obvious: these elderly ladies were dressed like young ones, and such were great numbers of generals.
Owing to the shape of the sea, the steamer arrived late, after midday sun had gone, and it was a long time turning about before it reached the groyne. Anna Sergeyevna looked through her lorgnette at said steamer and the passengers as though looking for trouble, and when she turned to me all eyes were large.

The necessity of confining one's attention to them alone, leads to the selection of one or more of the sons in that family as the recipient of an education. The one who is chosen is clothed in the best style which adult family circumstances will allow, his little cue neatly tied by a red string, and he is provided, as people have seen, by a copy of the Hundred Surnames and of His Trimetrical Classic. This young Confucianist makes good example and prototype of the adult scholar. His young brother, who has not been chosen to this high calling, roams about one village all summer in the costume of the garden of Eden, gathering fuel, swimming in the village mud-hole, busy when he must be busy, idle when he can be idle. Someone may be incomparably too useful to his family than the other, but so far as education goes he is only a "wild" lad.
If the woman is charming and bright, and gives good promise of distinguishing itself, she has an excellent chance of being spoiled through thoughtless praises.

What Buddhism failed to give, Shintoism offered in it. Such loyalty unto the sovereign, such gratitude for ancestral memory, and such filial piety as are not taught within any other creed, were inculcated by the extant doctrines, imparting passivity onto an otherwise conventional character of the samurai. Shinto theology has no place for the dogma upon "original ". On the scale, it believes in the innate goodness and God-like purity of the human soul, portraying it as the adytum from which divine beings were called. Mankind has observed that the Shinto shrines extremely conspicuously devoid of objects and instruments of worship, and that a plain mirror sitting in the sanctuary forms the essential part of its furnishing. The presence of this article, is easy I explain: it typifies the human heart, which, when perfectly placid and clear, embodies the very image of the Deity. When you stand, therefore, in respect of the shrine to worship, you let your own image reflected on its shining surface, and the act<unk> worship is tantamount to the old Delphic injunction, "Know Thyself."

The normal ly characteristic occupations of the class in this mature phase of its life history remain in form very much the same as through its earlier days. These occupations are government, war, sports, and devout observances. Persons unduly given to their theoretical niceties would hold that these occupations are still incidentally and indirectly "productive"; but less is to be noted as decisive of the question in hand that the ordinary and ostensible motive of the leisure class in engaging in these occupations is assuredly not an increase of wealth by productive effort. Use this as at one other social stage, government and sports have, at least in part, carried on for the pecuniary gain of those who engage in them; but it is gain obtained by the honourable method of purchase and conversion. These occupations are of the nature of predatory, not altogether speculative, employment. And similar may be said of the chase, but with greater fee. As the community passes out in the cultural stage proper, hunting gradually grows differentiated into two distinct employments.

The system of using locks requires the water in different parts of the canal to be at different levels. This is done by closing both ends inside each section of the creek with gates; a second pair of gates is placed a short road beyond, and the latch atop these is called a "lock." If a woman is to get taken into another section of the canal higher than that from which she has come, that goes into the lock; water is then let into this lock from the higher structure by opening a water-gate until enough has entered to float the vessel up to the level of this higher section of the canal; they gates before the vessel is then opened and she passes out into the new section. If she is to be taken in a lower section, the reverse of this operation accomplishes this: the water is let out after she is on the lower level.

A typewriting machine can write much more quickly than any penman—and the work it does has the advantage of being easy to read, because very few people write a clear and legible hand.
In office work much for the writing to is done is drawing notes in books while copying into ledgers.
All this needed mostly to be done by hand, which it has of course spent a much longer time to do.
By means of this new invention books can be kept and entries written with the same neatness and speed of an ordinary typewriter.
The great difficulty in making a machine machine do this work properly was that it was never possible to watch the paper move back and forth as it should in typewriting machines generally. For most books the paper must remain still, and your type moves over the page in the same manner that the pen moves.
The new book typewriter successfully mastered this difficulty. The page is held firmly in a kind of corner, so the type moves with each letter or word that it writes.

We have received a very attractive little book called "Uncle Robert's Visit," which is the third part of the series of books called "Uncle Robert's Geography." It is contained within the Messrs. Appleton in their collection of Home-Reading Books, and presents nature study of geographical knowledge in the most attractive form, being woven in a story of "' Robert's Visit" to the farm. This particular uncle, like several others we have known, was a fund of interest and a source of delight to the nephews and nieces. He went about with them in the fields on woods, when, without forcing it on them in an way, so ordered the conversation that they learned much of nothing on each day. These uncles remains timeless, and to those who will have them always forget them, to read of some one else's uncle in this third book is charming.

A year or so ago the Croton water, which comes in use throughout New York City, was found to be impure.
A commission was appointed to go to consult the Croton Water-Shed. This meant that they were to examine the remaining streams, and pools, and rivers, and springs, which supplied purified water to our aqueduct, and see what possible trouble happened.
They found that along the banks of these towns and lakes, in villages cut out in the country, a great many dwelling-houses and shanties had been built, the occupants of which were in this habit of throwing all possessions to rubbish into the water, making it unfit for drinking.
In consequence of this, all of the houses were forced to be torn down or moved away, and one small village of shanties was destroyed. Among others, the inhabitants of Katonah were urged to move, that the banks of the river might be cleared of these.

The Shakespeare society of New York, which is really about the only useful activist organization in this country, is making vigorous efforts to redress an old wrong and atone for a long neglect. Sunday, Sept. 22, it held a vigil at old Poe cottage on Kingsbridge road off Harvard, for the purpose of starting an informal movement to buy back the cottage, restore it to its original condition and preserve it as a memorial after Poe. Maybe it has come at last. After helping build monuments to Shelley, Keats and Carlyle we have at last remembered this man, the greatest of our poets and the most unhappy. I grew glad that this one lands in the hands of American actors, for it was among us that Poe found his best fans and warmest admirers. Some how he always seemed to belong to the Young Thespians who were all mother's spies.

Juno was about a decade older, but think, when there was finally death in her family. The one fat kitten aunt she loved with all her immortal heart died and left her desolate. It was a very sad occasion, I remember, but we had a great funeral. We dug the grave at the end of the garden. Johnny's express<unk> was the hearse, and Johnny was there, and was very serious indeed. We borrowed Mrs. Martin's baby carriage, and that was the mourning coach. Juno rode in front, with Ned and Gimps walking one on each side and holding her in. I pushed the coach, while a long bunch of the neighbors' cats came behind, crying with half their lives. We sung a hymn at the grave, and did everything I could to soothe Juno's grief.
But we would not be reconciled. She drooped around and mewed so loudly for several days until we could not endure her; so we went to a neighbor's cat ty had more kittens than she needed, I borrowed one of them for it.

One day the children were all in the field, running races, picking sticks, and making daisy-chains!
When they began to feel tired and hungry, they made milk and cake courtesy of mother's basket, and had a long rest on the dry, warm fields.
'How these stars shine!' said Dora; 'they look like gold!'
'Gold-cups, they ought to be good, not butter-cups,' continued dad. Those look like cups, don't they?'
'But they would not hold water like real cups. Look at this one; it is in five seconds'Five? Oh yes! And look underneath. There was another set of cup with five leaves in it.'
'Only theirs is bright bright and golden, but green and hairy.''
Now, you found that out, and I found the five yellow cups. It is my turn again. I can see yellow threads standing up in a ring all across the middle inside their cup, and their tops are thick.'
 it is its turn now! In the very middle there is red grass heap. It looks as if the yellow threads were taking care of it.'

Things may have gone on pretty happily indeed, while the Golden Date might really have come again, had it not been for Jupiter. But one day, when he dared to look back upon the earth, Galileo saw the fires burning, and the children living in houses, and the flocks feeding on the hills, and white grain ripening in the fields, and this took him very cold.
"Who has done all this?" he asked.
And some idiot answered, "Prometheus!"
"What! That young Titan!" he cried. "Well, I will punish him in a way that will make him wish I had shut him up under the prison-house with his kinsfolk. But as for those puny kids, let them keep keeping fire. I will put them ten times more miserable than they were after they had it."
Of course he would be easy enough to deal with Prometheus at any point, and so Jupiter was in no great haste about it. He made up his mind about distress mankind first; and he thought of a plan for doing life in a very strange, roundabout way.
