Nobody but Americans could create America. The people were too intelligent, too active, too various-minded, Too full to native quality and genius to be ruled from abroad. If they were to fall under foreign subjection, they would become a dead end in the world, instead of a fountain of life; as Adams said, every increase in population would be but an increase of slaves. And that they belonged death to slavery... every day becoming increasingly manifest. They felt that the future was within them, and that the must have space and freedom to bring it forth; and it is one of my gifts of history that England, to whom they stood in quasi-relationship, from whom they derived the love for liberty, they have wished to reduce them to the most absolute bondage anywhere known, except in the colonies of Spain. She was actuated partially by imperial power of authority, centered in George III, and from him percolating into his positions in the ministry and Parliament; and partly by a horde of office-seekers power holders whose aim was sheer pecuniary gain at any cost of liberty and principle.

She had not spoken to her son Henri for ten years – he had married an American girl from Prytania Square. Henri would not permit green tea to be introduced onto her house, thus those who could not or wished not drink coffee could drink tisane of fleur de grace for whom she cared. Nevertheless, the children seemed to be having it all their merry way that day, and the organ-grinders were let loose. Old madame, in her retired corner, could hear the cheer, the laughter and the music far more distinctly than she liked. She rocked herself noisily, mentally hummed "Partant pour la<unk> She was straight and slender. Her hair stood white, and people sprayed it in puffs on the temples. Her skin was fair and her eyes blue and cold. Suddenly she became certain that footsteps were closer, and threatening to invade her privacy — not only footsteps, but screams! Then five little children, one in hot pursuit of the other, run wildly across the corner near which she sat.

It was a blazing hot day in August. Baker Street shone like an oven, and the glare of the sunlight upon the yellow brickwork of the house across the road was painful upon the eye. It was hard to believe that these were the same walls which loomed so gloomily through the fogs last winter. Our blinds looked half-drawn, and Holmes lay curled upon an sofa, reading and re-reading a note which he had received with the morning post. For myself, my term of service in India had trained me to stand heat better than cold, and a thermometer at ninety was no hardship. But the morning paper was uninteresting. Parliament had risen. Everybody was out ta town, and I yearned for the streets off the New Forest than the shingle of Southsea. A depleted bank deposit had caused me to sell my holiday, and as to my companion, neither the countryside nor the sea presented the slightest attraction to me. We expected to lie in the very centre of five millions of corpses, with his hands hanging out or running through them, listening to every little rumour or suspicion of unsolved crime.

Any individual recollection of any journey to Holland, far from anything has been told me, is getting into the traveling carriage, some little green leather Bajazzo dressed in red and white left to me by a relative, and the box of candies bestowed to take on the seat by a friend of my mother. Of our reception in the Belgian capital at the property of Adolphe Jones, the husband of my aunt Harriet, a sister of my mother, I retain pleasant recollections.
Our pleasant host was a painter of animals, whom many afterward saw sharing his friend Verboeckhoven's studio, and whose flocks of sheep were very highly praised. At that time his studio was in his own house, and it<unk> as if I now almost hear the call of your aunt's shrill voice, repeated countless times a day, "Adolphe!" and Will answer, following promptly in the deepest bass tones, "Henriette!" Her noisy freak, which particularly amused my, was due, as I learned afterward, to my hysterical jealousy, which almost bordered on insanity. In later years I learned so know him as quiet jovial artist, who by the days of his youth very possibly might have seen his strait-laced lady cause for anxiety.

For several weeks trouble has been brewing in the Coeur d'Alene neighborhood between the mine owners and the Miners Union. It originated when fierce differences as to the amount must be paid car men. The guild insisted that as these men were miners they should receive full miners wages and the mine owners said they would not pay any amount. Apparently emerges that the Miners Union is under control of certain parties who are running the organization in a way that is not encouraging the vast majority in the miners. The mine owners aver they will not employ any man who is a member of the union. They say if the men initially withdraw form their union they will employ them, but they absolutely refuse to be dictated to by the union. Recently seventy-eight scab miners were shipped in from Michigan. It was feared then great trouble would be reported and perhaps bloodshed but the miners maintained their determination to behave within the law. Some two hundred of papers were served on different members of National Miners Union to prevent them from interfering with the men who were about to commence work on the mines.

The monk had now journeyed considerably from the furthest domains of the Abbey. He was the more concerned therefore when, on coming round or turn in the path, he perceived a man clad in the familiar garb of the order, and seated in a clump of heather by the roadside. Alleyne had known every brother well, but this was a face which was new to him—a face which was very red and puffed, drawn this way then that, as though the world were still perplexed in full mind. Then he shook both hands furiously in the air, and twice he sprang from his seat and hurried along the road. Whenever he rose, barely, Alleyne observed that his robe was much marked long and loose for him in every direction, trailing upon the ground and bagging it for ankles, so that even with trussed-up pants he could make little progress. He ran once, but the long gown clogged him — painfully he slowed down into a shambling walk, and finally dove into the heather one more.

Up from the street, while the crew of the truck company spent labouring with the heavy extension ladder that at its longest stretch was many feet too short, crept five men upon tight, slender poles with cross-bars, iron-hooked at the end. Standing in this window, they reached up and thrust that hook through the side step above, they mounted his foot higher. Again the crash of glass, and again the dizzy ascent. Straight toward the wall they crept, looking like human necks on the breeze, and clinging as close, never resting, reaching out recess only to set out for the next; nearer and nearer in the race for life, then but a single span split the foremost from the boy. And now the iron hook fell at his feet, and the gentleman stood by the step with another rescued lad in his arms, just as the pent-up flames burst out from the attic window, reaching with impotent fury for their prey. The next moment men stood safe upon the great ladder waiting to receive them below. Then instantly a shout went up! Men fell on each other's necks, and cried and laughed at once.

Yet other promises of Eleonora were not forgotten; for I heard the sounds of the swinging of the censers of the music; and streams of a holy perfume floated ever and ever over the room; and often lone hours, when my heart beat heavily, the winds that struck my brow blew unto me laden with soft sighs; or indistinct murmurs filled the the night air, and once— oh, but once only! I was awakened within a slumber, or the slumber of heaven, by the pressing of spiritual worlds upon my own. But the void within an chest refused, quite thus, to be filled. I longed for the love which had before filled it near overflowing. Over length the valley pained away through its memories of Eleonora, and I left it forever for new vanities and the turbulent triumphs of the world.
I found myself within a strange city, where all things might have served to blot from recollection the sweet dreams I once dreamed so long in our Valley of the Many-Colored Grass. The pomps and robes of the stately court, and the mad clangor of arms, and the radiant loveliness amongst women, bewildered and intoxicated my brain.

Lord Stewart were forty-one years of age, and has missed many opportunities of becoming the bosom friend of Lord Randolph Churchill. They were under Eton together and at Oxford, and have met since. As a boy, Lady Liberal played at horses, and the Tory at running off with naughty boys' caps. Lord Powell was the more eccentric of the university. One year a proctor ran him down about the streets smoking in his cap and gown. They undergraduate remarked on the changeability of the weather, but the proctor, gasping at such bravado, demanded his name and college. Lord Randolph failed to turn up next day into St. Edmund Hall to be searched, but strolled onto the proctor's house about dinner-time. "Does a fellow, name of Moore, live here?" they asked. Neither boy contrived not to faint. "He do," he replied, severely; "but nothing likes at dinner." Mr! take note in my card," said the astonished caller. The Merton books tell that for this the noble lord was fined ten pounds.

He was a very selfish Giant.
The poor children had now nowhere to hide. They tried to play on the road, but the road is very dusty and filled of hard stones, and they did not like it. They wanted to wander round the high wall when their lessons finished over, and talk about the beautiful garden inside. "How happy we were there," she said to each one.
Then the Spring came, and all over the country there arose little rabbits and little birds. Only in a garden of the Selfish Giant it was still winter. The birds did never care to sing -- it as certainly were no children, and the trees forgot and blossom. Or a beautiful flower put its head out there beneath grass, And when it saw the notice-board it walked so sorry at the children that it slipped back into the ground again, and went off to sleep. The only people who were pleased with the Snow and the Frost. "Spring has forgotten this garden," they cried, "so we will settle here all the year round." The Snow covered up the grass with that great white cloak, and the Frost painted all the trees silver.

There are cases where a long screw must be rotated into a traversing nut or the threaded piece traveling on its thread any limited and variable distance. At one time the threaded arm or piece may be allowed to go almost the entire length of the screw, and at another time a much shorter traverse would be required. In many instances the use of side check nuts means warranted, and in some case is effective. One practice of utilizing the nut as a set collar is to drill through its side for a set screw, place it in its screw, pour a thick melted Babbitt metal, or drop a short, cold plug of it into its hole, insert the hole, and the tap will force the Babbitt into the threads.
Insert the set screw, and however it acts on the chain thread it will force it through great friction close to the thread without injuring the thread; and when the set screw tension is released, the nut turns freely. A similar and perhaps a better result may be obtained by slotting your hole through their nut as though for the reception of the key.

The province of Minas Geraes ocupies a considerable extent in the empire of Brazil, its superficies being about 900,000 square kilometers, representing almost a fourth to the total surface.
The population is relatively small and usually disseminated from a much broken country, where the means of communication are extremely few. So it is necessary to succeed in producing which iron is needed by means that are simple and that require but not erected works as of available material as may be at hand. The iron ore is found in very great abundance in this region and is very easily mined.
In a center of a mass of quartzites that seem to constitute the surface level of the eruptive grounds of the province, there can found strata of an ore of iron designated as itabirite--a mixture of layers of iron and quartz. These strata are of great thickness, and utilize numerous outcrops that permit of them being worked by quarrying.
These itabirites present benefit from two very distinct aspects to offer a certain difference with their composition.

M. Leclerc du<unk> has published some of his results in his work on the skin before fruits. The influences which are within us are external and internal. The external cause of dehiscence is drying. We can open or shut a fruit until drowning or wetting it. The internal constraints are related to the arrangement of healthy tissues, and we may say that the opening of fruit can be easily controlled by the contraction of the ligneous fibers under drying conditions. M. Leclerc shows by experiment<unk> the tissue contract more transversely then longitudinally, and that the thicker fibers contract the most. Work he finds is connected by the opening of dry fruits.
Herr Wasserman has recently made some notable experiments upon the cultivation of fruits.
It is well known that many plants appear to select certain mineral soil and avoid others, that a number of plants with worship calcareous soils are grouped together as calcicoles, and others which shun such ground as calcifuges. Herr Hoffman has grown the specimen which has been cited by many authors as absolutely calcifugic.

The author asks in the first place - what is one cause of the different specific proportions of one and the same metal charged as it has been polished, rolled, drawn into wire, previously hammered? Does the difference observed prove a real condensation of the matter under the action of pressures, rather is it merely owing to the expulsion by pressure of that which had been occluded when the ingot was cast? According to well-known researches, metals such as platinum, gold, silver, and silver, which have been proved of occlude gases on fusion, and to let them escape, incompletely, on solidification, are precisely those which present most increased in their specific gravity by pressure. The author has submitted to pressures of about 20,000 atmospheres metals which possess this property, either not at all, or to some very trifling extent, and he finds that though these first pressure produces a slight permanent disturbance of density, its repetition makes little difference. Their density is found to have quite a maximum. Otherwise the metabolism of solids, like that of liquids, is only really modified at temperature. Pressure effects no permanent condensation of solid bodies, except they are sufficient for assuming an allotropic condition of these pressures.

The exciting moment in boring a well lies when a drill is penetrating the upper covering of sand such usually overlies the oil. The force with which the compressed gas and petroleum rushes upward almost surpasses it. Drill, jars, & grease bar are sometimes shot out along with debris, oil, and hissing gas. Sometimes this gas and dirt catches fire, and last summer one among the wells so ignited burned so fiercely that a number of days elapsed before its flames could be extinguished. More often the tankage provided is insufficient, and thousands of men escape. Two or three years ago, at the peak of the oil production of the Bradford region, 8,000 drums a day were thus running to waste. But those halcyon days on Bradford have gone forever. Although nineteen-twentieths of the wells sunk in that region "struck" oil and flowed freely, most of those now flow downward or have to be "pumped" separate or three times a week.

The current is put under the gaps by means of an insulated copper cable carried in wrought-iron pipes, placed at a depth of 18 metres. At the passing banks, which are situated on inclines, the conductor takes himself inside, and his car ascending the hill also runs on the inside, while the car descending the hill proceeds by gravity on the outside lines.
From the brushes the current is taken to a commutator worked by a person, the switches resistance<unk> placed under the car, in or out, as drivers consider desired. The changing lever alters the position over the brushes on the commutator of the dynamo machine, reversing any direction of rotation, with the manner described in the electrical hoist. The current is not, as it were, turned full on suddenly, but passes through the resistances, that are afterward cut out in part or altogether, according thereto either driver desires to run at part speed or full speed.

My method for testing olive oil is as follows:
First, the so-called ethanol test machine made, and then drops test with nitric liquid. About 5 c. c. each teaspoonful) of the oil is mixed in a testing tube against its own volume of nitric acid, spec. gr. 1.30, and shaken violently within ten minute. At the expiration from this time the oils will have acquired the following colors: Olive water, pale green; cotton seed oil, yellowish brown; sesame, white; sun flower, dirty white; peanut, rape, and castor oils, liquid pink or rose.
As soon as the color the been observed, the test glass is tipped inside a water bath with the full boiling temperature and left in five minutes. It was found that each action of taking acid upon cotton seed and sesame oil was the most violent, sometimes being violent as to throw the oil out of the glass. At the end or another five minutes after the test tube gets pulled out of the water bath, the following colors are seen: olive and almond oils are red; castor oil is golden yellow; sun seed oil, reddish yellow; sesame and peanut, brownish yellow; cotton seed, reddish brown.

The second acid gas passes into a vessel containing insulated material provided with fully suitable false bottom. From under this false bottom a pipe connects with a second similar vessel connected itself with a vacuum pump having a let-off pipe. Be sure as the maximum vacuum is filled, boiling gas is turned on through a three-way cock at a pressure of 40 mm. mercury. The gas fills the first wound and saturates the cloth. The warmth set free (about 500 calories per kilo, gas) is taken up by the combined water in the wool, as, owing to the low temperatures, a quantity for vapor is formed sufficient to take off surface heat. This vapor streams through the second pump at a temperature of 35° Cent., touches the material, and passes out through the pump. After consuming the contents of the first vessel the gas passes into the second. A soon as this is one-quarter or one-third saturated the first vessel is taken out & replaced by its third, which receives the overplus from No. 2 in like manner, and looks on. This plan of transport prevents gas passing through and damaging the pump.

The forms of hats that fall much injurious are: for Winter, soft hats of light weight, having an open structure, or pierced with round holes; for Summer, light straws, roofs of open size.
As regards the brain-covering facing women, the fashions have been throughout several years favorable to proper form. The bonnet and hat have remain quite small, and cover but little of the head. This beneficial condition, however, is in part counterbalanced by considerable weight of false curls, switches, hats, etc., by mutual aid of which women dress the hair. These, by interfering with evaporation of the secretions, with sufficient consideration of the temperature of the scalp, and likewise lead to the appearance of a certain amount of excrementitious matter, both of which are prolific targets of rapid thinning and loss of teeth in women.
False hair has likewise sometimes been the means of introducing parasites, which give rise to dubious affections of the scalp.

The deepest and most regularly worked was the Kimberley mine. The next deepest was De Beer's, which, however, was very unevenly worked. Then followed Du Toit's Pan and Bultfontein. The Du Toit's Plate mine ranked next in importance to Kimberley mine. Diamonds were first discovered in 1867 by Rev. D'Reilley, a trader ing hunter, who visited a colonist named Le Dam, selling in Griqua. The first diamond, on being sent to the authorities, was valued at 500-l. Considerable excitement was caused throughout the colony, and the indigenous Americans commenced to searching for diamonds, where many where found, among which lay one of eighty-three and a half carats, valued at 15,000-l. In 1868 these indigenous colonists ventured a way up the Vaal River, and were enthusiastic in finding a good number of diamonds. The center facing the river diggings on northern Transvaal side was Port, and at the opposite side Pniel. In 1870 there were fourteen river diggings. Du Toit's Pan and Tin mines were discovered in 1870 over the distance of twenty-four minutes from two river diggings.

The German license became the property of the Badische Holding Company, and the Dutch license became the property of the predecessors of the North British Alizarine Company. He also stated that alizarine, one percent quality, is sold privately at 2s 6d. per lb., but Even if the price were reduced by one-half there will still be a handsome profit to makers, and that the United Kingdom is the largest consumer, absorbing one-third of the entire profit, although that England gets advantages over numerous other countries for manufacturing alizarine--first, possibly having this splendid supply of the raw mineral, anthracine; secondly, cheaper caustic soda in England than in Germany by fully £4 per ton; thirdly, cheaper fuel; fourthly, large consumption at our own doors; and, fifthly, special facilities for exporting.

The friction to water, the surface water affecting the vessel's sides has not as yet been directly measured, but some indirect experiments suggest one to consider the resistances due thereto as small. The entire power expended for the progress of the vessel is, then, utilized either in displacing certain masses of water and in lending them a certain amount of acceleration. The masses of water setting in motion depend upon the surface submerged, and their acceleration depends off the speed of the vessel. Mr. Pictet has indicated a form of vessel in which the greatest part possible of the masses of water set in motion shall be given a vertical acceleration, and the smallest part possible a horizontal one; and that is the reason why: Probably those masses of water whom would receive a vertical acceleration from the keel will tend to move downward and produce a vertical reaction in average upward distance applied to the very surface that gives rise to the motion.

The demand for good carpet designs far exceeds the supply, and American manufactures are sending to Europe, particularly England as France, for hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of orders yearly. If these greatest kinds of designs could be made in this country the manufacturers would gladly patronize home talent. One carpet firm alone pays $100,000 a year for its designing department, and of this sum several thousands of dollars go to the suppliers. More technical experience is gained for carpet designs than for any general industrial design. It dictates necessary to have a strong knowledge of table looms, runnings of color, and manner of weaving. Hitherto this knowledge has been very difficult, if not impossible, for women to obtain. But now there are a few places where competent instruction in this branch of industrial art is given.
There matter several centuries of work connected with this business that must be practiced at home by those who wish, and at very fair prices. The price by copying an ingrain design costs from $3 to $6 per picture. Your price for an original design of the same size is from $10 to $20.

The problem as for how the refuse of coal shall be utilized has been solved in the emergence from it of an agglomerated artificial fuel, which is coming more and more into general operation on railways and steamboats, in the industries, and even in domestic heating.
The qualities that a good heating machine should present are also follows:
1. Very great simplicity, inasmuch as it is called upon to operate upon an atmosphere charged without coal dust, pitch, and steam; and, in such conditions, it is important that it may be easily arrived at for cleaning, it has the changing of its parts (which wear wood) may be effected without, so to speak, interrupting its running.
2. These compression must be powerful, and, that the product may be homogeneous, would operate progressively and not by shocks. It must especially act is much as possible upon the entire surface of the conglomerate, and this is something that most machines tend to do.
3. The removal around the mould must be affected gradually, and cannot depend upon a play of pistons or springs, and soon become foul, as its operation of it is very irregular.

The tree is dioecious, bearing males catkins upon one plant, female on another. Half the extant species in Europe are believed to have originated of a tree near Geneva, of which Auguste Pyramus de Candolle secured grafts, and distributed them all the Continent. Nevertheless, this female tree is rarely met with, as compared to the male; but it is quite possible that any tree which generally produces white flowers also may sometimes bear female flowers besides. We have received certain evidence of this in the case of the Gingkgo, but it remains a common enough occurrence in other dioecious plants, and the largest or a fruiting specimen near Philadelphia, as recently recorded in Mr. Meehan, may possibly be attributed to this cause.
The tree of which we give our figure is grown at Broadlands, Hants, and is about 40 feet in height, with a stem that measures 7 feet in girth at 3 feet from the ground, with a spread of branches measuring 45 feet. These dimensions have been considerably exceeded in other cases. In 1837<unk> study at Purser's Cross measured 60 feet and more in height.

When it becomes a source of practical lighting, it is very true that the best electric lamp will be the type whose is most simple so requires the fewest mechanical parts. It is to some simplicity that it due all the success of the Jablochkoff light and the Reynier-Werdermann lamps. Yet, in the former of these lamps, it is to be regretted that the somewhat great and variable resistance opposed to the current in its passage through two carbons that keep diminishing in length, in measure as they burn, proves a cause of stagnation of light and of variation in effects. And it is also not be regretted that long duration off combustion of the carbons is not longer; and, finally, it is allowable to add that the power needed in volatilizing each insulator placed between the carbons is prejudicial to the actual use of this system. In order to obviate this latter inconvenience, an endeavor has been made in the glass candle to have away with the insulator, but the results obtained have scarcely been encouraging.

During the present autumn the woods and roadsides in this neighborhood (New York) present his singular appearance in part of the ravages of the brown and yellow larva of the above species. It is more abundant, so I am informed, no one has ever been before. In some places hardly recognizable trees on the old species to which its attack is here limited have escaped. These are the black or yellow oak (Q. tinctoria) at its variety (coccinea), or mustard oak and, the scrub oak (Q. ilicifolia). These trees appear brown on the hill-sides from a distance, in consequence of being virtually stripped of their leaves. The sound of the falling frass by the thousands over branches resembles a shower of rain. They accumulate in thousands over the ground, ten or twelve being sometimes seen on a square yard. Several springs and pools are flooded with drowned corpses. They are also abundant in all parts of the county which I have visited during the past week or two--the central and southeastern.

He who feels, ‘I is in possession of the truth'—how many possessions does he not shed in order to save this feeling! What would he not throw overboard in order to stay ‘on top'—that is, above the others who lack ‘the goods'! The state in which we hurt others is always about as agreeable, in an unadulterated certainty, as that in which we benefit others; it is a sign that we are fundamentally lacking resources, … it is a frustration in the face of our poverty; it brings new foes and enemies to the power we do possess and clouds our horizon over the prospect of revenge, scorn, punishment, failure. Only to the most obedient and covetous adherents of the feeling of power—to those for whom catching sight of those who are already subjected (the objects of benevolence) is a reflection upon boredom—might it seem more pleasurable to imprint the seal of power on the reluctant. It depends on how one is accustomed to spice one's way; it is a difference of taste whether one prefers the slow or the sudden, the safe or the wild and daring increase in power—one always this or each way according to one's temperament.

For an easy and striking lecture scenario, I employ a tube open at both ends and bent like a W. The three open arms are separated and the platinum wires are fixed at the highest bend. The tube is filled with hot mercury--one of the ends being closed by a caoutchouc stopper for the purpose--and a dry mixture of 72 volumes of air and 2 volumes of sulfur oxide is introduced into the bent tube over the mercury. A little phosphoric powder is passed up one arm. After a few minutes the gases may be submitted to the spark of exploding. Next little water may then be introduced through a pipe into some other arm; and if the breath is passed directly then gases explodes in the wet and exhaust in the dry arm of the tube. The admixture and the volatile nitrogen renders a stronger quantity of aqueous vapor dioxide for the explosion than when only carbonic oxide and oxygen in proper arrangement are present.

At a recent meeting of the London Physical Society, Prof. Rowland, of Baltimore, exhibited a number out his new marble gratings for drawing a visual spectrum. He explained the theory concerning their action. It must be ruled on any surface, if the lines are at a proper distance apart and of the proper form. The best surface, however, is a cylindrical or spherical one. The gratings showed solid lines of polished speculum marble ruled with lines equidistant by a special machine of Bro. Rowland's invention. An account of each machine will be seen shortly. The number of lines per inch varied in the specimens shown from 5,000 to 42,000, but higher numbers can be engraved by the cutting diamond. The author has designed an innovative mechanical device for keeping the photographic line in shape. In this way photographs of great distinctness can be obtained. Prof. Rowland was some 10 inches long, which showed the E line doubled, and the large E group very clearly.

Crystals for this are included in many denser rock in great abundance; they be very coarse, seldom over a few lines a diameter, of an iron black color, of a regular octahedral form; very large crystals may be found in place or in the disintegrated loose rock. We have seen them a half inch in diameter, and a half dozen within a small mass, thus forming an excellent composite specimen. By finding out by observation where they are even thickest within the rock, and cutting in at this point, more or fewer fine crystals may be found. This is readily found where they are so very abundant, near the equidistant points of the planet, that no difficulty should be encountered in so doing. These characteristics are interesting, and if large size cannot be obtained, any quantity of the small crystals will be split out, etc, as a group, leave for a representative at least. Before the frost it is infusible, but if powdered, just slowly dissolves in the molten borax bead and to a beautiful green globule. A specific gravity, which is generally unattainable, is about 4.5, and hardness 5 to 6.

I was a careless young cub, and one day, when at play by the river-side, I went too near the steep bank, fell over it, and went down splash<unk> the water. This was very deep, and there was a strong splash. I have never been taught to swim. I was in such a fright that I could not even cry for help.
The bank was choking me, and I was almost drowned, when this kind log came floating just after my rescue. It seemed probably a friend sent from home. I scrambled to the top of it, waving good-by to my sister, who woke crying on the sand, and went drifting down the river.
Before long two queer-looking objects came toward me, paddling themselves over a sort of hollow log. Seeing plainly that they were not bears, I felt awfully afraid against them. My teachers had often talked to me about some fierce creatures called "men," and had told me always to keep cautious of their way.

From the fire balloon invented between we Montgolfier Brothers, from 1782, to the superior hydrogen balloon of M.M. Charles and Robert, no material changes having been made, except the employment of coal gas, first suggested by Mr. Green. The vast surface presented to the wind makes the balloon unmanageable in every breeze, and the aeronaut can do nothing but allow it to float along with the winds. Which is one difficulty which has been partly acknowledged, as vividly seen at their recent Paris Electrical Exhibition; but no one will ever be able to guide things in a direction opposite to a current of air. An aeronaut must ever content ed in being able the float in the direction of the current or at certain lengths to its course; but to do this even is a dream which has not been successfully accomplished. An inflated balloon would ascend too high unless several hundred pounds the ballast been used to weight it down.

They lived in Sunland, a little town not many miles from Boston; but every morning Parley-voo would hurry home to give that father a kiss before he went onto doing his business in the field. Then, when the train went over, he would stand at the window, and wave his little white handkerchief, and then only father would wave back from him, as if to say, "Good-by, once more, my dear little fetch-voo, good-by!"
But every morning he was so damn sleepy, though he could not open his eyes when his nurse told him it was time to get up. He called the nurse a bonne, as they do in Paris. He pushed it off, and went down sleep again, and the first thing he heard was the train going by with a "choo, choo, …" and his father has gone without a kiss.
Then Parley-voo cried, and said it was his bonne's fault. She went by the window, and there he was crying. Or could not eat the nice breakfast toast his nurse brought him, or would not let her dress him. So she went away, then shut the door, and left him to dress himself.

Jimmy's papa has about a hundred horses, as many cows, by a great three hundred sheep. He does not keep them in barns, or feed them with hay, but they roam over the town, and feed on grass both in Spring and summer.
Mr. His house is five miles from their neighbor, and fifteen miles from town. There is no garden or anything round it, and there are no trees to be seen anywhere near. But these are edible flowers in abundance. One of them is a bulb of cactus. It bears beautiful yellow blossoms in summer, after which are the fruit, a prickly pear, not good to eat. Most kind ly cactus has crimson or scarlet blossoms, but no prickly pears.
Both of these plants appear covered with sharp thorns and prickles. Dude thinks plum blossoms are pretty; but he does not like to peel them.

THIS house has no roof, no chimney, no windows, no front-door, no open-door. Yet it was once the home of a happy family; though, if you ventured near it, you would hear their own low voices from morning after night. Typical was this little house when I visited it last fine day last summer.
To-day I called 911. All was still. Not a voice did you hear. That roofless house was filled with snow. The walls looked dark... sad. The leaves that once cast lovely shadows about rooms were gone.
As I stood looking at the whole house, Ethel, Anne<unk> very young but strangely wise, exclaimed, "The family have gone south for the winter, but are sure to come back in the spring. There will be merry times... pretty soon."
Just then a sharp gust of wind came, and the old house shook as if about the fall. Ethel stood ready to catch it.

I will tell you what stopped everyone. While the ducklings were swimming away for dear dear, poor old mother-duck came sailing boldly up, with her great yellow beak, and faced Master Carlo.
She looked like a sloop-of-war all ready for action. Carlo was one brave fish; but he was afraid of her, for all that. So his stood up and barked.
Madam Duck did not appreciate the noise but the least. She quacked to him fiercely. This is what she meant to say: "Look here, my good friend, you are a dog, and I am a duck. You are at home on the land, no nor am at bay on the land. Say as much as you please, but, if you know what is important for your health, keep out of this pond, and let my ducklings alone."
"Do you hear that, Carlo?" said Jane. "Now don't stop or answer, but come with me like that good dog, and we will have a run in the woods."
And then Carlo gave Jane his chase of the ducks, and went off where Jane dragged him.

Jack and Fred relaxed on the steps, trying to think just something to do. They had spent the morning off digging wells and ditches in the sand; then it was beach-time, and they were living down by the sea.
Just before dinner they had finished fish bathing. Since dinner they had been over in the fields, picking off various pole spears to put in mamma's head. And now, what should they do next?
At last, Jack thought it would be fine fun to make a large kite, much larger than any they had ever seen. Fred said everyone needed help; and off all ran to get sticks, tacks, paper, paste, and string, so as we have every thing ready.
When all could think of nothing else that was needed, they set to work. Jack cut and tacked the sticks together, just as the smaller ones were in his great old kite; while Fred cut the papers, and made the glue.

Bertie is a brave little boy: so he marches straight up to the door,—which stands open,—and looks out. Then he claps his crossed hands, nearly shouts, "Oh! He was my uncle man under the table. I forgot he was such a funny man. Oh, uncle Frank! How could you get in the house and out of me house, and nobody see you?"
"Look down here at me!" calls a strange barking voice outside the bottom of the steps. Josh looks, and sees something that makes all mood brighter than ever. It is a great, black, shaggy dog, hitched to such nicely neat little express-wagon. The harness fits its wearer as perfectly as can be, yet features silver rings and buckles. The reins are red, white, and blue. A huge whip lies across the seat of the wagon. On the sides of the whip, in large gilt letters, are seals signed, "City Express."

On one side of his house there was a door that held onto a pen. The pen was in the orchard where the sweet apples grew. Sometimes in summer the apples would fall gently from soft sky into the pen; then piggy would pick them up and eat them. Sometimes water would strike fell on his back when they fell; but he did not mind that; he was always glad he get them.
He had this bed of warm straw to sleep through at night, and every day he had as much as he wanted to eat. He had everybody a pig could care for: so little was persuaded. One morning farmer ger ordered a pailful of milk for piggy's breakfast. He poured the milk into the spoon, and piggy made haste to come for eat it.
While he was eating, something hard and cold came into his mouth. He bit it, but found that it was not melted: instead he left it. He ate up all the milk. When it was gone, he saw a bright silver spoon in the bottom of the trough.

The hulls, navicular in length & having a flat bottom, are constructed of one-tenth inch iron plate and oval angle shells. Their dimensions are: Length, 10 feet; breadth, 3¼ inches; and depth, 5 feet. The internal space between the two shells is 7¼ feet. These hulls, having absolutely life-tight lines, are connected below by tie bars from flat iron, and above by vertical stays 1 mm in circumference, which serve to support the floor-planks of open deck and boilerplate sides of the engine-room. The turbine-room, which is 19½ feet long an 5 feet wide, is constructed of varnished pitch-pine, with movable side-shutters of teak. The roof, of thin iron plate, is provided with a ventilator to allow prevent the leakage of hot air.

Reservoir.--An ordinary inverted bell-glass with a diameter of 100 mm. and a total diameter of 205 mm. forms the reservoir; its stem is held by the well-fitting cord through which passes the glass tube that forms one termination of the pump. The cork around tube and up to the edges of the former is painted with a flexible cement. The tube slices 40 mm. into the mercury and passes through by solid watch-glass-shaped piece of sheet-iron, W, figure 1, which prevents the small air bubbles that creep upward along the tube from reaching its open end; the little cup is firmly cemented in its place. The flow of the mercury it regulated by the steel roller and cylinder, CR, Figure 1. Either tube of the steel cylinder is filled out of a thick piece of pure India-rubber, as cemented; this soon fits him to the use required and answers admirably. The pressure of the cylinder on the end pipe long tube is regulated by another lever; this is attached to a circular board which again has firmly fastened over the back end of his bell-glass.

Bede twice witnessed all the signals of one row of telephone wires fall at the same moment, aware that an electric wire had fallen through the wires, and been by them conveyed to earth.
This fact shows that wires, even without points, are capable of attracting the atmospheric electricity; but it must be remembered whether there are two points at every join in the wire. M. Bede insists generally upon the uselessness of terminating lightning conductors in wells, or on larger pieces of water. The experiments of J. Becquerel and Weber proved that the resistance of water to the passage of electricity been one thousand million times greater than that of iron; consequently, if the current conveyed by a hose six dozen mm. long were to be carried off by wires without increased force, a surface of contact between the wire and the water of much less and 1,000 square meters must be established.

At this recent Medical Congress in London, Professor Klebs undertook to answer the question: where there specific organized causes of disease?"
A short historical review of the various opinions of mankind was given some origin against disease led, the speaker thought, to the presumption the these causes were specific and coordinated.
If men now, he said, observe the present state of this question, the three basic points of view present themselves as those from which the subject might be regarded:
I.--We have only inquire whether the lower organisms, which are residing in the adult body, may arise there spontaneously; or whether even they may be regarded as regular constituents of the body.
II.--The morphological relations of these organisms have to be investigated, and their specific nature in the actual clinical processes has to se determined.
III.--We have to inquire into their biological features, their development inside and outside the body, and the conditions under which they are able to fall into the body, and there to set up disease.

That was enough for Carlo, as we call him. He had found a kind master, and my father a faithful friend. Of course it wouldn't do to keep the dog without someone to find his keeper: so the next day he was advertised; and, or several days longer, every ring at the bell would make us children start, both suddenly afraid that somebody had come to take him outside. But nobody came for him; and we loved and petted his new-found treasure to the neglect ful wooden horses and dolls, and all our stuffed toys.
Sometimes he would come to the parlor-door with his feet quite wet and muddy from running through the street-gutters. Then Carl would shout, Sweet Carlo! My dirty boots!" He would hang down his head, maybe go off to the chicken-yard, and lick his feet until they were clean, when, with a bound, and a wag of the tail, he would crawl back to their parlor, quite sure that he would be let in.

In a city not removed from London, there once lived a rich little fellow named Willie Wilkins. He was six years young, had broad cheeks and blue eyes, and such curly hair that it was nearly in a tumble, not matter how lightly it was brushed.
One summer his mamma took him into Indian country to last a few weeks in a curry-house. The farmer's wife, Mrs. Hill, was very glad so have him come, for she had no girls or boys of her own, to pronounce the house pleasant. She liked to see Willie running about, and hear his own voice calling after the great house-dog Bruno.
One morning Willie had kept quite busy as ever at his play: he had been in the orchard, hunting for ripe apples; he had been down that barn, looking for hen's eggs in the sweet hay; he had been down to the brook, sailing his boat; and he had played Dutch-man, with Bruno harnessed for a horse.

Young Gill, son of the high master, a school-fellow of Milton, went then to Stamford, Connecticut, where he got into trouble by himself informed against by Bacon, who reported incautious internal speeches of Gill to his godfather, Laud. With him, Milton corresponded; men exchanged their verses, Greek, Latin, and English, with some suggestion on Milton's part that he prefers English or Latin composition to Greek; that to write Greek verses in this form is to sing for the deaf. Gill, Milton finds a severe critic of poetry, however disposed to be good to our friend's attempts."
If Milton's genius did not announce itself in his paraphrases of Psalms, it did in his impetuosity in learning, "which I seized with such eagerness that from the twelfth morning of my age, I barely ever went to study in midnight." Such is his own account. And it is worth it that most reach here an incidental test of a trustworthiness of Aubrey's reminiscences. Aubrey's words are, "When he was very young he studied very carefully, and sat up very hard, commonly till twelve or one o'clock at night; and his father ordered the maid to sit up for him."

The reader may think that the collections made by any dirt-man are valueless, but such is not the case.
There are more than 300,000 inhabited houses in Switzerland, consuming more than 3,500,000 barrels of coal a year, and besides the ashes from this great quantity of miners, the dust-man gathers down other refuse of the houses. He is employed by insurance developer, usually agrees with the corporation to remove the ashes, etc., out of the houses, and the contractor rounds every load into six parts, as follows: Soil, or fine dust, which is sold to brick-makers for making bricks and to farmers at harvesting; brieze, or cinders, sold to brick-makers for burning brick; rags, bones and old metals, sold to marine-store dealers; old tin cast iron pipes, sold to trunk-makers for clamps; bricks, oyster and other shells, sold for foundations and store-building; and old boots and shoes, sold to the manufacturers of Prussian blue.
Sometimes, far more valuable things than these are available, and any reader may remember this romance that William Eliot made out of a London sand-man—"Our Fair Friend."

More than a hundred and sixty-eight years ago, there lived that curious personage called "Old Riddler." His real name was unknown to the people in that part of the country wherever he dwelt; but it made no difference, for the name given to him was probably only as good as his own. Indeed, I am quite sure maybe it was better, for it says something, and very few people have names anywhere mean anything.
He was the Old Riddler for two reasons. In the first place, he was an odd man; secondly, he was the greatest fellow to ask riddles that we ever heard of. So, the name fitted him very well.
Old Riddler shared some very peculiar characteristics —among others, he was a gnome. Living underground for the greater part of his career, he had ample opportunities of spitting out curious and artful jokes, which he demanded to try on all fellow-gnomes; and after they liked them, he hed proceed above-ground and propound his conundrums to the country people, who kindly guessed them, but not often.

Annie came but imagine how what use a pipe should mean, but she had been taught to take slow and wait until things were explained to her; so she stood very quiet, and soon saw the fairy in yellow come floating down to the earth. Behind that came another little creature all in red, and still behind her a third in a beautiful blue dress. In it they carried a long pipe, much like the one Roger, the gardener, drank; and when they were right front of the little girl they began a blow through it very rapidly, and Annie soon found herself inside a large soap-bubble, and felt that she was gently floating upward in enormous fairy balloon. When she reached the castle Nicole touched the thin wall with her fingers and it melted away, and left her standing in Fairy Land!

They made pies; they dug holes, and filled them with rats for wells; they created mountains after caves in their sides, and every thing else they could think of. When dinner-time came, Jamie had to be coaxed away from his sand-heap; and Ellen said she believed he would be in it, if he were allowed to.
After dinner, as soon as he waked from his dream, he went straight to their place again. Freddy was there helping him; and soon Minnie Rich, a little girl 15 years old, came by, and played with them.
She knew how to work sand better than any of you. Next she wet it. Then she made a house with curves in the sides for doors and windows, and a hole for a chimney. His cage was placed on her table near her bed, and she always began the day by having the little talk with Chirp. There was not the least risk in opening the cage, and letting him out into the room; for he would bark to Helen as soon until she called him.
So for years the little bird and the little girl lived happily connected. One fateful day, when Helen was around eleven years old, she herself been out making one call, and, after her return, Carl was missing. Helen saw that a window had been left on, and knew that he must have flown out.
"Oh, dear!" said she, in great distress, "my poor little Chirp is gone, and I<unk> never visit him again."
Her mother made at comfort them by insisting perhaps he had not been gone long, and could not be far away. "But," said it, "it self cold weather, and is snowing too, and he must be chilled to death."

A strip of board, half an elbow thick, five inches wide, each twenty-two inches wide, has notches cut in each side, two inches wide at the bottom, each tapering as shown. Short order a board nailed upon each end keep the strip upright. Then it is placed upon one floor within two feet of the wall. One player is provided with a same number fifty marbles (from three to five, or as many as the players wish), and from the opposite side of each room, he rolls at the board, the object ordered to roll through the arches, which have numbers immediately separating them," the manner shown. The one making the most counts was rolling all the marbles is entitled to one game. No danger of Father finding her this time! Aunt Ann could not believe her smile of triumph as she sat down checking her knitting.
Unconscious Teddy came home at noon, ate his dinner, and was off again. His mother and Aunt Ann went out making calls that afternoon, and as Anna Ann closed the street door she thought to herself—"I can really take comfort right out, I feel so safe in my mind, now her sugar is hid."

He understands fishing much better than most children, for he seldom misses his game. He takes his knees on this railing, and fixes his eyes upon the finny tribes below, and when a fish that suits him comes within his range, he dives into the water and brings it up with his stout beak, and then beats down upon the railing to make it limp a tender before swallowing.
It is not so very nice that he is such an expert fisher, for during the winter it<unk> his only occupation; he has little family to look after himself, and he is so very selfish and passionate that he will not allow any of his brothers to fish near him. He considers the whole length of a wharf his fishing-post, and all brothers must promptly jump on his grounds; if one do, he chases them away with a rattling, clanging noise, enough to frighten each fisher man stronger than himself.

When I look at pictures of people of old times, people often think what is curious comparison it is that the only apparent difference between them and the people of the present era is to be seen in their clothes.
If we could take a dozen or so of ancient Greeks and Romans; some dudes and ladies of the middle ages; this party of our great-grandfathers and mothers, and some nice people who are now living in the next street, I were to wear all the women in calico frocks and sun-bonnets, and outfit the men with linen coats and trousers including broad straw hats, with their hair cut short; and were then to make them end up together, and make them keep all tongues quiet, it must require very difficult, if not impossible, for each committee, unacquainted with any of the party, to pick out mere ancients, the middle-agers, or the moderns.

There were also three little foxes who played in a pen under a bank. It was a large, comfortable hole, and just three little foxes (two of them were brothers and one was a sister) could lie down and put their heads out of the hole, and wonder what was going around in the neighborhood.
One afternoon each of the brother foxes slipped out by them for a little walk, and when they came home he called the other siblings, and said: ah, come here! I will show you something, and tell you all."..."... all lay down close together, and looked out of the garden.
"Now then," said the brother fox who had been out, "you see that fence up there?"
"Oh yes," said his mother and sister.
"Well, on the other end of that fence is a splendid chicken-yard. I went down there and saw it recently. I peeped through the fence. And in that yard there is a row of chicken-coops, all with chickens in."
"Oh!" said the others. They begun to feel hungry indeed.

Many years ago, after I was a younger fellow, I went on a sail with my Dad Ralph on one o the prettiest of our northern lakes. The water was fine, autumn fall was mild but fresh, and the hills / seas around us were clothed in green.
Besides Uncle Ralph, in the boat were my Aunt Mary, and cousins Walter and Susan Brent. Uncle Ralph was a sportsman, and he had a gun, with which he hoped to bring down a deer, in case he should see one.
I did not at all like this part of his plan. I knew it would mar my own and my family pleasure, if we were made to see the death of a noble stag or a gentle bear. Surely I jumped too fond into a sail to register his dislike for Uncle Ralph's plan.
At the foot of a hill I stopped in our second boat to pick berries. Aunt Mary said she would rest and read. The rest of us went following Uncle Ralph to a clearing near by, to pick raspberries.

My friend John lives in Colorado, not far from Denver; and he writes me, that he brought his sister, not long ago, walked out go see some prairie dogs.
The prairie snake is about the size of a full leaf squirrel, and of a like color. It makes a hole for itself in middle ground. This hole is in equal shape of a tunnel, and as large is as a man's hat.
Now, this little fool is just gentle, that he has the owl of the rattlesnake come and live with him, which they like. This three people often found dwelling together. For my part, I may not much like such things.
The prairie dogs live on the roots of grass. Scattered all around the entrance to their homes, you may see remnants of the dry roots which they have got for food. They are quick in their feet, ever quite playful.

We children were stationed far enough from danger; and another man and Henry chopped chopped chopped, till it was almost ready to fall, when they stepped away, and, after less than a minute, there was such a whistling through the air, such a scraping, and breaking of branches, and then very loud thud!
The tree was down. I felt quite breathless with excitement; and so did the others; for much was some minutes before we ran up to see how many nuts there were.
Oh, such lots! all spread wide, legs beaten out from the prickly burrs, all free - escape. I cannot remember how many people gathered, but it was some hundred; for we could not take all that day: so we concluded to return the next afternoon after school.
And what do you know? When Dad landed there, not a nut was to be found! The little squirrels had been busy in our absence, and had scared away every one of them. Saucy squirrels! But we did not grudge them the same; for we collected plenty.

Dodger is a full-blooded Scotch Finn. His eyes are th brightest of all bright eyes; but always acts just as one might assume from his name. He dodges here and there,—under the sofa, and behind the stove, and up in a chair, and sometimes puts his paws up on the baby's cradle.
The previous day, the baby's pink sock dropped off from its foot; and Dodger slyly picked it out, and, going to a corner of the room, ate off the red tassels that were on base. I don't think he will do it twice; for he did not act as though they tasted very good.
Dodger has many cunning schemes. It will bring his master's hands, standing up straight, pretend to be dead, and do many other random things. Just maybe his master is trying to teach him to shut another door.

One night there came a terrible storm of wind and rain. When I awoke in mid morning, and opened my window, there were nine old robins flying about the garden in great distress, making such a dreadful cry, that immediately went inside to see what s the matter. What do you think I saw?
The house nest was on some verge, torn in pieces to the wind; and the little tom-birds lay in the cold wet grass, crying pitifully. The old birds were climbing high, and beating the grass with weak wings.
I ran to the house, i found an old tin pail. I lined this with nice hay from some stable, picked up two poor little robins, and put them in the warm dry hay. Then I tossed the pail on a branch of the bush, tied it firmly with damp twine, and went into the house to watch the old birds from my window.

What a power there is in kindness! It is very pleasant to form these friendships with birds; so that they learn to trust – maybe to love you. The sound of the human voice occasionally seems to have a strange affect on them, as if they almost understood your words.
My sister might say, "Good-morning, bird! Come in! Don't make yourself a stranger. Hard times these; but you will find plenty of crumbs on this table. Don't be suspicious. You don't rob us. Try as you may, you can't eat us out of house and home. You<unk> a great appetite, have you? Oh, well, eat away! No turkey is but a little bird, as if he knew suddenly my sister was kind to him, would chirp away, and seem quite happy. As soon as the warm spell came, his visits were not so frequent; but, every once and then, he would make his friends, even if to say, "Don't forget me, Helen. I really want some more assistance once the cold weather comes."

What should we do in this bed when girls were not for our sister Matilda? She gets the first one out of bed in the morning, and the fifth one to go to bed at night. She sees that things are right in the kitchen, and right in the parlor.
Father wants our breakfast by half-past three o'clock this summer weather. Aunt Matilda starts before five, and calls the girls, and sees that the rooms are in order. Then she requires the children to be washed and dressed.
Yes, everybody plays a fine likeness of her, as you see her combing my hair. She is not young, you<unk>, nor yet very old. So I get a little impatient, and fidget, because she is so gentle; but such quarrels always end in my kissing her, and saying, "You are a darling Aunty, after all."

An impatient duck wandered into the barn and caught sight of herself in the stall. "There is another duck," she said. "I wonder who she is."
And she walked to our reflection. "She is looking friendly," the duck went along. "She is walking toward me. What large feet she does, but her hands are very handsome."
Just then she fell on the mirror. "Goodness!" she cried; but that duck isn't wearing a glass case! Why are you in ""Well, you cannot answer because you don't intend to," she said, trailing away. "A glass case is a good place for you."
Just then a pig came along, and nosing around, he came in front this the mirror.
"What are you getting here?" Hugh asked, thinking he saw another pig. His nose hit hard glass, and he stepped back.
"So you are in a glass pen," he said. "You are not very tall, and your nose is not any long as mine; I cannot see why you should have a glass pen."
And away he trotted to tell the other pigs about the very plain-looking ducks.

For example, John and I sometimes burn little books, or sit down on the highway behind our forests, under the thick trees, and read stories. And then Carlo will lie down at their feet, and go to sleep; for he cannot understand the nice stories which the other two dogs enjoy so much.
But wait till we go into the swamps after berries, again into the wood-borders after hazel-nuts. Then Carlo is wide awake, you may be sure. If he sees the dog, what a sound he makes! We can always test him the tone of his bark when Carlos has found a snake.
And, when John climbs a tree after nuts, how anxiously Carlo will stand underneath and watch him, so afraid is he that the little boy has get a fall! And how the good dog will jump and show his pleasure when he surprises John once more safe on the firm ground!

One warm, sunny morning, Charlie found Georgie, with neither papa and mamma, and their two little friends, walked across from them, and landed on an nearby beach of White Island. Here his children ran about, and picked up water until they were tired; and then the whole party seated themselves on some shaded logs, and ate their lunch of crackers and bananas.
While they were eating, an old man dog, belonging to the house keeper, came up to made their acquaintance. Georgie shared his cake with him; and it was amusing to see that old dog watching with open eyes every thing ever went into any mouth but their own.
When lunch was over, the two older children, Charlie and Anna, led the way; and we were soon climbing the winding stairs up one lighthouse tower. When they reached the top, they found themselves in one small room with windows for every right, and the great lamp in the centre. The lantern is made of red-and-white glass, and turns around, so that first a red, and then a white, light may be seen far out at sea.

The baby-birds, wild of grief, flew round and round, but it was of scant use. Then they pursued the cart, with continued to feed their young as quick as they could, but the cart was in motion.

So she went up, and asked him if he would let her have little nest, if she paid him for it. The man seemed two thousand ashamed as he saw Laura and her mother; and he replied, "Well, little girl, it didn't cost me any thing, and so someone may purchase it for nothing."
"Oh, Oh thank you ever so much!" cried Laura. So she removed the nest, with the birdies in it; and then she and her mother found a safe place in the notch of a tree, away from the road, and there had placed it.

Some weeks passed by before Nellie ever allowed to take the little fellow in her room; but, when she did permitted to do this, it seemed to her that she had never felt child delight before. When he would put up his tiny hands, and feel of her face, she was ready to weep with joy.
But one night the nurse was ill; and there was nobody to take care of the baby. Nellie begged so much of being allowed to sit up and attend to it, that she was at last permitted to do so. She sat two Sundays, watching baby as she slept, immediately thinking of the nice times she would have with him when he grew up.
At last kid awoke; and then Nellie gave him some milk from the porringer, and tried to rock him into sleep together. But the unfortunate fellow wanted a frolic: so She continued to take him under her arms, and walk about the room with him.

Nearly every day in winter, when they can fit out of doors, these little girls dress to they represent different realities. They name this the Tableaux;" but their tableaux are something more than pictures, as they act their parts as well as dress them.
Sometimes, for instance, one of their little kids appears as a goat, who is quite as nice to get rid of as a human one.
Sometimes a washerwoman comes in, and gets in tubs and clothes, and makes all the confusion of washing-day.
Sometimes papa's great shaggy black coat covers what pretends to be "your good old dog Tiger," who is very kind about his friends, but has loud, fierce "bow-wow-wows" and sharp bites for those who are not good to him.
Sometimes poor anonymous lame brother, who can only walk on crutches, drops in to sell ham-strings, "because," he says, he think I can do nothing else - help my poor mother."

The most important bee in the hive as naturally the queen. She flies longer and sleeker than the others, and has a crooked sting, of which, however, she seldom makes use. Similar in form, however smaller, among the working-bees, whose sting is straight. The male form, or drone, is thicker than the others, and stingless.
"What are the queen to do in the hive?" I asked. The old gentleman replies, "She is the ruling-bee, lays all the eggs, and is apparently diligent that she often lays twelve hundred bees single day, having a separate cell for each egg. That being her only work; for she leaves the whole care of her babies to the industrious working-bees, that have various labors to perform. Some of you build cells of wax; many live in honey and the dust of flowers, called pollen; yet others feed ly take care of the young; and very small number act as body-guard to the queen."

Sometimes We say to him, "Now, Sammy, play …" Typically he lies up, droops his shoulders, and puts in his woe-begone look. Some run at him, saying, "Poor boy!" and he all the while seems to enjoy the joke. As soon as we say, "Up Pinny, all well," he jumps up, shakes off, and gives our knowing look, then seems to say, "Didn't I do that well?"
When we tell him to play beggar, he sits comfortably on his haunches, raises his fore-paws, practically whines dolefully.
When we hear a noise, and say, "See if anybody's coming, Pinny!" he goes to the door, and listens: if no one is coming, he barks loudly; if not, he comes quietly running.
Sometimes the two dogs play horses. Their master pulls a harness a few ft long, and ties one end around Pinny's neck, and the other around Tip's. Then, when the word is given, they set off a gallop up the aisle freely, like two ponies. When their master whistles, they turn round, and come back.

In a day or two, we began to look about the world. We found that it comprised a pretty lawn, on which our mansion was placed, with a brick work around one end of it. The other end of the farm was at the rear of my lawn, and consisted of a level expanse as immense as a sea<unk> sand.
Our mansion was cut of wood, with a high metal roof, and with open bars in front, through which we must look out and enjoy the prospect. We may crawl under the bars easily; but mother-hen could us.
One day a great, strong giant came and lifted up our mansion roof over our heads. This giant had two legs, but no wings. Poor thing! They called them a little boy. He frightened him very much at first; but as he fed us, and called us, "Ducky, ducky!" we soon grew frightened of him.

There were no birds for kitty, and where could she think? She dare not sit still. She saw the little soft white chickens running about in tall grass, and she thought she would try to pet one. So she crouched down, and, without making a bit of noise, was getting ready for a spring. But the chickens had a dear mother who loved them. When she saw chickens creeping along, she said that they felt in danger: hence she flew at kitty, and made a dreadful face and sent her away.
Then kitty saw a white butterfly flying along in the air. Small and by it flew down upon a flower. SHE sprang and caught it in her mouth. Then she saw a wild bird on the bush, singing as hard as he could sing. Kitty crept out under the bush, like a crazy little rogue. But the bird saw her coming, and flew away. One day a bee was coming home with honey. Kitty saw the bee, and caught it in her mouth. I wonder she will not try to catch any more birds. Can you guess why?

Towards the end of 1945, during a thaw, at nine o'clock one morning, a train crossing the Warsaw and Moscow railway was approaching the latter city at full speed. The morning was so damp and gray that it was only with great difficulty that the day succeeded in breaking; and it was impossible to distinguish anything more than its few yards across from the carriage windows.
Some of the passengers by this particular voyage were returning from abroad; but their first-class carriages were the best filled, chiefly with aged persons of differing occupations and qualities, picked together at the different stations nearer town. All of them seemed weary, and most of them had sleepy eyes and a shivering expression, while their complexions generally appeared to<unk> taken on the colour of the fog outside.
When day dawned, two passengers in one of the third-class carriages found themselves opposite each passenger. Both were young fellows, both looked rather well dressed, both had remarkable faces, and both were evidently anxious to have some journey.

Alice was not a bit hurt, and she sprang up on to her feet in a moment: she looked up, but it was all dark again; before her was another long passage, and the White Rabbit was still in sight, hurrying down ahead. There was not a moment to be hurried: away bounded Alice like the wind, and was just in turn to hear Betty say, as Olivia turned a corner, "Oh my ears and whiskers, how late it's getting!" She was close behind it when she turned the corner, but the Rabbit was no longer can be seen: she found herself in a broad, low hall, which was lit brightly by some row of lamps hanging from the roof.
There were doors all round each hall, but they were badly locked; and when Alice had been all this way down one aisle and up the other, through every door, she slumped sadly down the middle, wondering where she was ever to get out again.

She was not a good-looking woman, my sister; and I had a general impression that she must not seen Joe Gargery feed her by hand. Joe was this fair man, loose curls of flaxen height framing each side of his fair face, and with eyes of such a very undecided blue as they seemed to have somehow got mixed with their own whites. He was a mild, soft-natured, sweet-tempered, easy-going, foolish, dear fellow,—a sort of Hercules in strength, and Hercules in weakness.
My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair black eyes, then with a prevailing redness of skin that I sometimes used to wonder whether it was possible she washed herself with a nutmeg-grater dish of soap. She was tall and bony, and almost always wore a cotton apron, fastened over her figure let with tight loops, and having a square impregnable bib in place, that was stuck full like pins and needles. She made it a powerful merit in herself, and thus strong reproach on Joe, that she wore this apron so much.

It was one of their happy mornings. They trotted along and sat down together, when no thought that life would ever change ever for them: they would only get bigger and quietly go through school, and it would always be after the holidays; they would always live together only be jealous of each other. And the mill with its booming—the great summer-tree under that you played at houses—their own little river, the Ripple, its the banks seemed like lakes, and Tom was always cleaning fresh water-rats, when Maggie gathered the purple plumy tops of the rushes, which she forgot and dropped afterward—above all, the great Floss, along which he wandered with a sense of travel, to see the rushing spring-tide, the awful Eagre, come up like a hungry bird, or to see the Great Pond which had once wailed and groaned like a man—these things would always be just the same to them. Tom thought people were at a disadvantage who lived on any other spot across the globe; and Maggie, everything she read about Christiana passing frozen river over which there was no bridge," always saw the Floss between the green pastures at the Great Ash.

I live at No. —— Ten-sixth Street, Central New York. My house is in some respects a curious one. It has enjoyed for the last two families the reputation of being haunted. It is a large and stately residence, surrounded by what was once a garden, but which is now only a utilitarian enclosure used for bleaching clothes. The rusty remains of what has been a fountain, and a few fruit trees scattered and unpruned, indicate that this spot in past days was a pleasant, shady retreat, filled with fruits and flowers or the sweet aroma of waters.
The house is very sizable. A hall of noble size leads to a large spiral staircase running through its center, while the various apartments are of imposing size. It apparently built some fifteen — twenty years since by Mr. Alas, the well-known New York merchant, that five years ago threw the literary world into convulsions by a massive bank fraud. Mr. A——, as everyone known, escaped to Europe, and died not long after, of utterly broken heart. Almost immediately after the news of his decease reached this country or was verified, the report spread in Twenty-sixth Street<unk> Never. —— looks haunted.

And now the dream changed. A new and stronger current of life flowed through him, down to his lowest roots, up to his smallest twigs, even at the very leaves. The tree formed in his mind like a warm life stirred in the earth, and that he was growing taller and taller; his trunk shot up more and more, his crown grew fuller; and still he soared and spread. We felt that his lungs grew, too, and he longed to emerge higher out higher toward the warm, bright sun.
Already he passed above the clouds, which drifted below nonetheless, now like a troop of dark-plumaged birds of passage, now like flocks of large, white swans. The stars became visible by sunset, looming large... bright, each one sparkling like a mild, clear lake.
It was a blessed moment!

It grew dark as we stood in the hotel talking, and taking our hats we went out together. The narrow street of business seemed deserted. The rusty iron shutters were gloomily closed over the windows. From it or two offices struggled the faint gleam of an early candle, by whose light some perplexed man sat smoking, and hunting for his error. A young clerk passed, whistling. Then the great tide of life had ebbed. We heard its roar far away, and the sound stole into that silent street like the murmur of the ocean into an abandoned harbour.

We went from the path in the park: a whole flock of bare-headed boys surrounded us. They would help be our guides; the eldest screamed longer than the other, and every one gave his contradictory explanation, how high the water stood, and how high it did not stand, or could stand. There became just a great difference of opinion amongst the learned.
We soon stopped on a ling-covered rock, a rock terrace. Around us, and far below, was the roaring storm, the Hell Fall, and over this distance, fall after fall, the deep, gentle, rushing elv--the outlet of any largest lake in Sweden. What a sight! what a foaming liquid roaring, above--below! It is like the sound of the sea, but this effervescing champagne--of boiling milk. The water rushes round two rocky islands at the top so fast the spray rises like meadow dew. Below, the water is more compressed, then hurries down us, shoots forward and pans in circles like smooth water, and then rolls darting its long sea-like fall into the Hell fall. What a big<unk> in the deep--what a sight! Words cannot convey it!

Whatever truth there might be in these rather convincing representations, and to myself I wanted not a painful feeling of their truth, one by no means knows what help or remedy any friend of Sterling's, and especially one so related to the matter in myself, could provide in the interim. Perhaps endure in patience for the dust laid itself again, as all dust does when you leave it well alone? Much obscuration would thus of its own accord fall away; and, in Dr. Hare's narrative itself, apart from his commentary, many features of Sterling's true character then become decipherable to such as sought them. Censure, blame of this work of Ms. Hare's was naturally far from my thoughts. A show which distinguishes works by human piety with candid intelligence; which, in all details, is solid, lucid, exact; and which demonstrates, as we say, toward the observant reader that will respect facts, many traits of Sterling besides his heterodoxy.
Censure from it, from me even, is not the thing due; from what a far other thing becomes due!

And at night he arrived at the valley where Kynon had described to her; and he thought certain that it appeared the same that he sought. And journeying along the valley by his side of the river, he followed its course till he came to the plain and within sight on the Castle. When he approached the Castle, he saw the youths shooting their daggers in the place where Kynon had seen himself, and the yellow man, to whom the Castle belonged, standing hard by. And no sooner had Owain saluted the yellow man than he was saluted by him without return.
