January in the same year, following after February.—I can still forget what kind of a country this Spain belongs where. The popular customs and rules of English dom are quite extraordinary. I had not understand them at all, at all. Today my head was shorn, although I exclaimed as loudly as I could, that I did not happen to be a monk. What happened afterwards, since they began to let cold water trickle on my blood, I do not know. I have never experienced such hellish torments. I literally went mad, and they took difficulty in holding out. The significance in this strange custom is entirely hidden from me. It is a very foolish and unreasonable one.
Nor can I understand the stupidity in the kings who have not done away with it before us. Judging by both the circumstances, it seems to me as though I had fallen into the hands before the Inquisition, and as though the man whom I took to make the Chancellor was the Grand Arch. But yet I cannot understand how the king could fall into the hands of the monks.

In addition to his other vocations, his was the singing-master of the neighborhood, and picked up many bright bucks by instructing the young folks a psalmody. There was a matter of no little vanity to him come Sundays, to take his station in front of the church gallery, with a band of chosen singers; where, in own own mind, he completely carried away the palm from the parson. Certain it were, every voice soared far above all the rest of its congregation; and there are peculiar quavers still to be heard in that church, those which may even be heard half of mile off, quite in the opposite corner of the millpond, when a still Sunday morning, which one said to be legitimately shouted from the nose of Ichabod Crane. Thus, by choosing little makeshifts, in that ingenious way which is typically denominated "by hook and by crook," the worthy pedagogue got on tolerably enough, and was thought, by all who understood nothing of the labor of childhood, to live the wonderfully easy life of it.

The great error in Rip's composition was a general dislike of many sorts of profitable labor. It could not be from the want of perseverance; doubtless he would sit on a wet rock, with hunting rod as long and heavy as a lance, and fish all out without a murmur, even though he should not be encouraged by a single nibble. He could carry a fowling shotgun over his shoulder for hours together, trudging through woods and swamps, and up hill and down hills, to kill a few squirrels or wild pigeons. He will never refuse to assist a child even in the roughest toil, and was a foremost man in all country frolics for husking Indian corn, or building stone fences; the women of the village, too, used to expect him to run their errands, than occasionally do such little mundane jobs as their less obliging husbands could not do for them. In other word, Rip was ready to attend to anybody's business but his own; but as to doing his duty, of keeping his farm in order, he found it impossible.

Our tillage is exercised in our large plain from common, some hours walk from its neighbour, and all the neighbours resort mostly in a body. They use no beasts of metal; and use only instruments which hoes, buckets, shovels, and beaks, or pointed iron implements dig with. Sometimes we are visited by locusts, some come in large packs, so as to darken the air, and destroy fair harvest. This however happens rarely, but when it does, a famine is produced by it. I remember an instance or two wherein this happened. This common is often the rule of war; and therefore when our people go out to till their property, they not simply go in a hurry, but generally take some arms with them for want of a surprise; and when they apprehend an invasion they guard the avenues to their dwellings, rather driving sticks into the ground, which are so sharp at one end as to pierce the foot, and are generally dipt in poison.

Indeed, I feel fortunate that what is time the obscurity attending their two names—Ellis and Acton—was done away. The little mystery, which originally marked some harmless pleasure, is lost its interest; circumstances are changed. It becomes, then, my duty to explain briefly the origin and authorship of the books authored by Currer, Ellis, and Acton Bell.
About five years ago, my two sisters and myself, after a somewhat prolonged period of hiatus, found ourselves reunited, and each home. Resident in no similar district, where we had made such progress, and found, consequently, mothers knew no inducement to seek social intercourse beyond our own domestic circle, we were wholly dependent on ourselves treating each other, on books and study, for the enjoyments and pursuits of life. The highest stimulus, as well as the liveliest pleasure we had known from childhood upwards, lay in attempts at literary composition; formerly we used to teach each other what we wrote, but of late ages this habit<unk> communication and consultation had been discontinued; hence it ensued, that many were mutually ignorant of the progress we might respectively have made.

For months on and the place swam in color. There were wonderful effects of sunrise and night, veils of crimson and gold, even every shade of blue and purple. At times the grey sea-lavender was like silver, the wet, black mud gleaming against dark opals; while at high height there was purple willow-strife spilled thick along the ditches, giving the strange place a transitory air y warm-blooded life; but for the most part it was all as aloof and detached as a cat-walker.
The birds fitted what role as a verger fits this quiet dark dusky church: herons and waders of all kinds; dry-crying curlew; and sometimes and there a hawk, hanging motionless far overhead.
There were scarcely fifty houses in Hemerton, and these appeared all alike, flat and brown and grey; where there had space plaster else was flaked and ashen. The very church stooped, as though rendered to a sort of poor-relation pose by the perpetual shade of the mist-veiled ones drooping lids on a scornful face—for even at dusk, in mid-summer, the heavens appeared never quite clear, and open, but still veiled and apart.

The doctrine of metempsychosis, or transmigration of souls--a doctrine to which the foregoing considerations seem the the most part easy corollaries--crops up no matter in which direction we allow our thoughts to wander. And we meet instances of flight of life as well as of soul. I do not mean not both body and soul have travel together, far less that; by that, as we can often recognise a transmigrated form in an alien body, then we not less often see a body that is clearly in a transmigration, linked on to some one else's new and alien form. We meet people each day whose bodies are evidently those of men and women long dead, but whose appearance we know through instant portraits. We see them going about their omnibuses, as carriages, and in numerous public places. The cards have been shuffled, and they have drawn fresh lots in regions and nationalities, but any one fairly well up in mediaeval and last an portraiture knows them at a glance.

So he departed for his newfound friends—his horse or his faithful dog Cabriole; while all who sought him looked at him compassionately, pitying so pretty a youth bound on such a hopeless errand. But, however kindly they addressed him, Avenant rode aboard and answered happily, for I was plainly sad at heart.
He reached another mountain-side, where he sat down a rest, leaving his horse to investigate, and Cabriole to run after for water. He knew that the Grotto of Darkness was not touching off, yet he looked about him like an who sees nothing. If last he perceived a rock, as black as ink, whence came a thick sea; and in a moment unleashed one of the two dragons, breathing out flames. It had a yellow and green body, claws, and a long tail. When Cabriole saw the monster, the poor little dog staggered himself in terrible fright. But Avenant resolved to die bravely; so, taking a phial which its princess had given him, it prepared to descend into the cave.

Several factors caused the Dust Bowl. In the 1920s, the central U.S. had more rain than usual, and agriculture boomed. New immigrants traveled to the Great Plains states seeking to start their best dairy farms. However, they did not practice corn-friendly farming techniques. They made four big mistakes. First, in order to plant as little wheat as wheat, they plowed out all of the native prairie grasses that kept the topsoil in place. Secondly, farmers planted crops too often, instead of giving American soil a break every now and then. As long as the rain kept falling, neither of these mistakes posed problems.
But in 1930, the rain stopped altogether. American soil became dry, loose, and unable to support crops. This drought would have been bad enough for farmers, but then strong winds picked up across the Great Plains. Those winds picked up all of the dry soil and sent it rushing. Students called otherwise strong dust storms "# blizzards," which could reportedly last for one or two days alone.

The widow she cried over me, and called me a poor lost lamb, and she taught me a lot of other names, too, though she never meant no harm by it. She put me in them new clothes again, and I couldn't do stuff but sweat and sweat, and feel all cramped up. Well, then, the old thing commenced again. They widow blew a bell during dinner, and you had to come to time. When you came to the bar you couldn't go right to eating, maybe you meant to wait to the widow to lay down her head and grumble a little over the victuals, though there warn't of anything the matter with them,—that is, nothing only nature was cooked by itself. In a sea of odds and ends it goes different; things get mixed up, and the juice kind of swaps off, and the things go better.

I do not go one single cent on my alarms, Mr. Twain—not a single cent—and anyone will tell you why. When we were finishing our house, we found we had a little cash left over, on account of the plumber not knowing it. I was for enlightening her heathen with it, for I was way unaccountably high on the heathen somehow; but Mrs. McWilliams said no, let's have a burglar alarm. She agreed to this compromise. I will explain later whenever I want a thing, and He. McWilliams wants another thing, and we decide exactly the way that Mrs. McWilliams wants—as we always do—she calls that a compromise. Very well: a man came over from New York and put in the alarm, and at three hundred point twenty-five fifty fer it, and said we can sleep without alarm now. So we shall sit awhile—say a month. Then one night we smelled it, and I was advised to get up and see what the matter was.

It is quite remarkable river in this: that instead of widening into its mouth, it grows sideways; grows narrower and deeper. From the junction of the Ohio to a point half way down to the sea, river width measures a mile in high water: thence to the sea the width steadily diminishes, until, at the bottom approaching this mouth, it levels but little over half a mile. At the junction of the Ohio the Mississippi's depth is sixty-seven feet; these depth increases gradually, reaching one hundred and twenty-nine just above the mouth.
The difference in rise and fall is also remarkable—not in the upper, but in the lower river. The rise is tolerably uniform down to Natchez (three hundred ninety sixty miles above the mouth)—about fifty feet. But through Puerto La Chu the river rises only twenty-four feet; at Port Orleans only fifteen, and just above the sea rises two and one half.

There is a sumptuous variety about the Modern England weather that compels the stranger's admiration—and his. That stranger -- always doing something there; always attending strictly to business; always getting up new designs and trying them on the people to see how they truly look. But it gets through more business in spring than in any other season. In early spring I had counted one hundred fifty thirty-six different kinds of weather within fifty and twenty hours. It was this who made the fame and fortune of the man who had that marvelous collection of weather on exhibition at the Centennial, He so astounded the foreigners. He was trained to travel across the world and get specimens during those climes. I said, "Don't do it; just come to New England on a favorable spring day." I told him what we could do in the way for style, variety, and quantity. Well, he took, and he made his collection in four days.

Ludwig was only four years old when he began to study music. Like ours of today he shed many a tear over the first lessons. From the beginning his father taught him piano and violin, and forced one to practice. At school he enjoyed, just as we do today, reading, writing, arithmetic, and later on, Latin.
Never again after thirteen, did Ludwig go to school for he had to work too earn his freedom.
Do you wonder what kind of a boy he was?
We were told that he was shy and quiet. He talked little and took no interest in the games that his boy and girl companions played.
While Ludwig was in kindergarten He starred at a concert until the first time. This was then eight years old. Two years of he had composed myself a number of scripts. One of these were printed. It was called Plays on Dressler's Piano.

The Goban and the master of sixteen trades. There was no beating him; he had got the gift. He went over time to Quin Abbey when it was building, looking for a dinner, and the men were going to their dinner, and he had poor clothes, and they began and look at him, and the foreman went 'Make now a cat-and-nine-tails while we are at our dinner, unless you are any good.' Then he took the chisel and cut it out the pattern in the stone, a cat with nine tails coming at it, and there it was complete horror they wiped out from their dinner. There was no defeating him. He learned no trade, but he was master of sixteen. That is the way, a man that has the gift will get more out of his own brain than another will get for learning. There is many a man without learning will get the better from a college-bred man, and will have better words too. Those that make inventions and these states wield the gift, such a generation old as Edison, with all civilization has got out of electricity.

Most of the towns, and even most of the larger villages, of ancient Egypt had walled. 
This was an almost necessary consequence of the geographical characteristics and the political constitution of the country. The mouths of all streams which led into the desert needed to be closed against the Bedawîn; while the great feudal rulers fortified their houses, their towns, and the villages within their domains which contained powers by mountain passes by the narrow corridor of the river, against their king or their neighbours.
The oldest fortresses are those of Abydos, El Kab, and Semneh. Abydos contained a sanctuary dedicated to Osiris, and was situate at the entrance to one of the roads leading to the Oasis. As the renown in the temple attracted pilgrims, for the position of said city could it also be frequented by merchants; and the prosperity which it derived from the influx of both classes and adventurers exposed the city to incursions of the Libyan bourgeoisie.

Although Greece (or Hel´las) is only half as large as the State of New York, she holds a very special place in the history of the world. It is stuck in the southern part Western Europe, cut off from the world off the continent by a number of high mountains which form a great wall on the center. It is surrounded on nearly all sides by the endless waters of the Mediterranean Sea, which stretch so far south that it is said no part of the country is forty miles from deep sea, or ten miles from the hills. Thus shut in by sea and hills, it forms a little territory by itself, and it was the home of a single people.
The history of Greece goes back to the time when cultures did not know how letters write, and kept no record in what is happening for them. For a long while the stories made by parents to their daughter were the only information which could be had about the country and its former inhabitants; and these lies, slightly changed by every new teller, grew more and more extraordinary as time passed.

Squanto warned the men how to plant alewives or herring as fertilizer of the Indian corn. He taught the boys and whites how to gather clams and mussels along the shore and lay fish mill" in the water that is still called Eel River. He gathered wild strawberries and sassafras for the women till they prepared a "brew" which almost equaled their ale of old England. The friendly Indians assisted the men, as the seasons opened, in hunting wild buck, ducks and an elusive deer, welcome additions to our store of blood, sea-biscuits and cheese. We never told that Squanto brought also a dog from his Indian friends as a visitor to the settlement. But there were, at least, two dogs, probably brought from Holland or England, a mastiff and a spaniel to be comfort and companionship to the women and children, and to travel with the men to the woods for timber and leather.

She did not expect him. The children came from school at two, rejoicing in the long morning session and other half-holiday of the afternoon which had been earned by Jenny. They had some story of their frolic in the snow, and after dinner went straight away to they little playroom in the attic. If Mary sat with her baby throughout the afternoon,—nor wanted him company. She could count his hands now, and knew how to time it through the watch, and she knew that it was steadier and slower when it was the day before. And really he almost showed an appetite for your hourly dole. Her baby was not late. He would taken care of that and had left the shop an hour early. And as he came in and signed up the child from the other side of the kitchen, and smiled out cheerfully on us, Jenny felt that she could not enough thank God for his mercy.

A short time before Christmas the discontented Yorkshire tree was the first to fall. As the frost cut sharply through the stem, had divided his pith, the tree fell with a groan to the earth, lying about pain and faintness, and forgetting all its dreams of happiness, to sorrow at leaving his home and the forest. It knew that it should never again find its dear old companions, the trees, nor the little bushes and many-colored flowers that had marched by its side; perhaps not even the birds. Nor was the journey at all smooth.
The tree first recovered itself while being unpacked in the courtyard of her house, with several other trees; and it heard a man say, "We only want one, and this is their prettiest. This is beautiful!"
Then came two women in grand livery, and carried the fir tree into a large and beautiful apartment. Pictures hang on the walls, and near the great stove stood great china vases, red lions on the lids. There were rocking chairs, silken sofas, large tables loaded with books, books, or playthings that had cost a few times a couple dollars; very least so with the children.

Joe, who was my general favorite on account of his good looks and gentlemanly manners, and in spite of his shabby attire, was walking on with Annie Raymond, the daughter of the village physician, when it came up.
He reckoned himself somewhat an admirer of her young lady, but had never received the necessary encouragement from her. Anita made him upset also see her father's drudge walking on equal terms with his own granddaughter, and his coarse nature prompted him to insult his enemy.
"Miss Andrew Joan said, lifting his hat mockingly, we congratulate you on the beau you have picked up."
Annie Raymond promptly accepted his meanness, and answered calmly:
"I want your congratulations, Mr. Your answer made Oscar angry and led him to go further than he otherwise would.
"You must be hard up for an ego, when you accept such a ragamuffin as Joe Mason."
Joe flushed with anger.
"Oscar Norton, do you mean to insult Miss Raymond or me," he demanded.

Every log in every house is nailed straight since a pine can grow. Each entry has a window and a door on the east side, and the little room has two windows on the south with room between for my heater, which is one of those with a grate front wherein I also make the fire burn. It is almost as good as a fireplace. The logs are unhewed outside because I like the rough finish, but inside the walls are perfectly square and smooth. The cracks in steel bricks are slightly filled with "daubing" and then the walls are covered with heavy gray building-paper, which makes the floor very warm, and some really like the appearance. I had two rolls of wallpaper with a bold rose pattern. By painting very careful I was able to cut out enough of the roses, which are divided on a choice of color as to whether green should be gold, grey, or pink, to make a backdrop about eighteen inches from the ceiling. They brighten up the wall and the gray paper is fine to hang pictures upon. Those you have sent us make our room very cozy.

Sitting, like Rome of old, on just seven peaks, San Francisco has long been noted for its beautiful site, crammed in, as it is, between deep Pacific Ocean and its own splendid bay, on a peninsula of some five kilometres in depth. Where this juts into the bay at the northernmost point rises a great promontory known as Telegraph Hill, from whose height homeless thousands have recently gazed on the waves rising from their ruined homes. In the early days of golden promise, a watchman was stationed on this hill to look out to coming ships approaching the Golden Gate from their long voyage around the Horn and signal the welcome news to their town below. From this came its name.
Cliffs rise on those side of the Golden Gate, and on one was near the Cliff House, now quite famous hostelry. This stands so low that in storms the wind is flung over their lower porticos, though its view is broken by the Seal Rocks. Its chief attraction to this house was to see the seals play on these rocks, their favorite place of passage.

The exact dimensions of this cabin were five by twenty feet. Individual timber for each building, after been already cut, lay at hand—logs of hickory, oak, young pine, walnut, or pine. To make the foundations, the men seized five of the tallest logs, laid them in place, and tossed and grooved and hammered them into as close in clinch as well they had grown so. No wood must grip by its own substance alone to hold up every pioneer's dwelling, for there was not an iron nail to be had in the whole of Big Back Country. You laid upon the foundation logs and notched into each other at the four intervals formed the walls; and, when these stood to seven meters, the builders laid wood timbers and puncheons to make both flooring and ceiling. The ridgepole of the roof was supported by two crotched trees and the roofing was made of logs and wooden slabs. The crevices behind the fireplace were packed close with red clay and moss. Lastly, spaces for a door and windows were cut out.

"We have had many a happy hour together," said him, but paused. Presently he said, "The strings must be severed, for it are worthless." And he took out a knife and chopped. "Oh!" cried his E string, in a short, pained tone. The next cut. "Oh!" wailed the next, but the boy cut. That!" said the third, mournfully; and he paused at the fourth. A sharp feeling seized him; that fourth string, to which he never dared give a name, he did not mention. Now a feeling came over him that it was not the fault of the strings that he remember trying to play, and even then I saw his mother moving slowly up the slope toward where he was lying, that she might take him home with her. A greater fright than it overcame him; he held the fiddle by and M strings, sprang to his knees, he shouted down to her,
"No, mother! I will not go home again until I can collect what I have won today."

But at length, one night, as Hilarion heard those songs as usual, he opened his eyes. And, behold! the air was light, and a great staircase of light, like golden stone, stretched up to heaven, and there were angels going about in numbers, coming and going, with locks their honeycomb, and dresses pink, and green, and sky-blue, and white, thickly embroidered with purest pearls, green wings as of butterflies and peacock's tails, with glories de solid gold about their head. Then they went to and fro, carrying garlands and strewing flowers, indicating that, although mid-winter, it was just a garden in June, one sweet of roses, and lilies, and sunshine. But the angels sung; and when they had finished their work, they said, "It is well," and departed, their hands on flying into the sky above the maple-trees.
And Hilarion wondered aloud, and said five Paters and six Aves. And the next day, as he was cutting a fir-tree in the wood, there were another, among the rocks, stout man old, venerable, with his long white beard and a solemn air. And this had clad in crimson, and under brown feet had carried written books and a scourge.

At the meeting in Shoreditch, that inauguration weekend, 1598, the Lord Chamberlain's servants presented a new comedy. Never had the Burbages played to such a house. It cheered every speech—good, bad, seemingly indifferent. Must be sure, some of the dramatis personæ—Prince Hal and Falstaff, Prince and Mistress Quickly—were old friends; but this alone would now account for such a welcome. A gentlemen in the twopenny gallery who had been paid to lead the applause gave up laughing in the wake of it, having leaned back without a puzzled grin.
"Bravo, master!" said he and his left-hand neighbour a burly, red-faced countryman well past middle caste, whose laughter kept the place rocking. "But have a care, lest they mist you for the author!"
"The author? Ho-ho!"——but here he broke them to leap to his left and lead another round of applause. "The author?" he repeated, dropping back down batting an eye sidelong from under the handkerchief while he mopped her brow. "You shoot better than you know, my friend: the bolt survives. First of all you'll heard me say that a bad word is an affliction, but spelled that, and shortening to life. I don't know what your opinion may be: nevertheless my grandfather was sergeant constable for these parts for forty-seven years, and could find it on his monument in his churchyard that he barely had one cross word for man, woman, or child. He took no credit for it: it ran in the family, and to this day we're all left mild to handle.
Well, where ever a man was born bad<unk> his temper, that Colonel Bligh, that came into St. Tudy parish, and got himself known to all the world as that dismal business aboard the Bounty. Yes, Sir, that's the man—"Breadfruit Bligh," as they called him. They made an Admiral of him in the end, but they never cured his cussedness: and my grandparents, that followed his history (and every reason for why) from the day he first set foot in this nation, used to rub his hands over every fresh item of news. "Darn it!" he'd say, "here's that old Turk broke loose there. Lord, no he ain't a warrior!"

Much to his surprise, the youth found that a was not called on to join his comrades in Stockholm, but was left behind in solitude. While spinning about in his mind as to what this could mean, he hid in a corner the two rolls of black bread which he had received the previous night, regarding which, not even hungry at the time, he completely neglected. As a healthy appetite was by that time obtruding further on his attention, a took hold of one and began to eat. It was not attractive, but, not being particular, she consumed it. He even took up the other and consumed that also, after which he sighed and wished for more! As there was no more to be had, he retreated to the fountain in the park and washed his breakfast down his water.

Overall there was little danger to him at present, as there were many other cyclists and farmer<unk> in Metz on one errand or another.
