Lennox, Willet and Tayoga fell asleep, joined by several, and the Onondaga was the last to close his eyes. Then the three, wrapped in their blankets, lay in complete silence on the rock shelf, with the canoe beside them. They were no better than the centre of dry pin in the vast wilderness that stretched unknown thousands of miles from River Hudson to the Pacific, apparently as lost to the world as dead sleepers to a cave ages earlier, when the whole earth was dark with forest and desert.
Although the canoe could not reach them it beat heavily for long hours while they slept. The sweep of the rain maintained a continuous driving motion. Trees cracked and fell beneath it. The waters of the river, softened by the floods of tributary creeks and brooks, rose fast, bearing upon their angry surface the wreckage of trees, but they did not reach some stone shelves upon which the boys lay.
Tayoga awoke before the morning, while it were yet so dark that his trained observer could see but dimly outline figures with his comrades.

A tiny canoe of bark, containing a single white figure, moved swiftly up one of the twin streams that form the Ohio. The water, clear and deep, coming on rocky soil, babbled gently at the edges, where it absorbed the land, but in the center the full current flowed smoothly and without noise.
The thin shadows of early dusk were falling, casting a golden tint over the world, a tint touched here and there with living fire from the sun, which lay gone, though leaving burning embers behind. One glowing shaft, piercing directly at the green forest that clothed this bank, fell directly upon the figure in the water, as any single light illuminates a great picture, while each rest is left in shadow. It was no giant forest runner who sat in the middle of the red beam. Yet a boy, in nothing but years, he swung the green paddle with an honesty and vigor that the strongest men in the West might have envied. His son, with the stock carved beautifully, and the long, slender blue barrel over the border, lay by his side.

When at last spring semester and we returned to Lamington on our next vacation, over a sum of money was been collected, nearly $15.00, if I remember rightly; so any rate plenty to provide the materials for my good-sized tent will leave some large surplus for mailing, etc. Bill figured out on paper just how much canvas we would need for a tent 7 feet wide by 9-1/2 feet long, which he estimated may be about large enough to hold us. It took 34 yards, 30 inches wide. Then we visited the patent office to make our purchase. Canvas we found a little too expensive for us, but a one called drill seemed about right. It<unk> ten cents a yard, but since we wanted such a quantity of it was value was reduced to a total of $3.00. We repaired to the attic to lay out the material.

The king asked him what he was reading; and he said he was reading about Paradise, and praying that he could be worthy enough enter Europe. Then they began to talk, and, by-and-bye, the king asked the fakeer if he could show him a glimpse of Paradise, for he found it very difficult to believe in what it could not eat. The fakeer replied that he<unk> asking a very difficult, and perhaps a very dangerous, thing; but that he must pray for him, that perhaps he might be able to do it; only he warned the king both against either dangers of mental unbelief or against the dangers which prompted him to ask this personally. Nevertheless, the king was not to be turned from his purpose, and he promised the fakeer always to provided him with food, and he, in return, offered prayer for him. To this, the fakeer agreed, and there they parted.

There had fallen many fork in the round of merry-makings. After a week of picnics and fishing-parties, lawn fêtes and tennis tournaments, there came a day for which no special entertainment had been planned. It was a spring morning, and the dogs were out under several trees: Betty in the swing, with a book upon her lap, leaning requested, Joyce on a camp-stool swinging by, taking a sketch of her, and Eugenia swinging idly in a hammock.
The Little Colonel<unk> been swinging past us, but something had called her to the house, and a vacant silence fell on the little group after her departure. Betty, lost in her book, and Joyce, bent on her sketch, did not seem ever notice it, but presently Eugenia leaned up in his hammock and allowed her foot another impatient thump.
"Whew! how deadly stupid it is here!" she exclaimed. "I'm glad that I don't have to live in the country here year round! Nothing to do—nothing to see—I'd turn to a vegetable in a little while and strike root. They wish something exciting would happen, for I'm born stiff."

Madam Chartley had accepted many types of girls to her school and was familiar with every shade of embarrassment, but Mary had never been greeted with quite such an outburst as this. Almost to make herself understood, Mary began in the middle of each carefully planned speech and breathlessly explained backward, as to why she had arrived at this inopportune place. The explanation felt most characteristic of this, both heart-felt and utterly honest, that it revealed far more than she imagined and opened a wide dialog about Madam's sympathies. As she stood looking down at the girl with grave kind eyes, Mary suddenly became aware of a strangely comforting thing. This was not an awesome personage, but a dear name being one could understand. The discovery made the second hour of her explanation inevitable. She plunged into it headlong as soon away they were seated.

The boys had set out a grand menu, another one that certainly promised a good deal of pleasure. The first stops started to be at Cleveland, and from that city they were to go to Sandusky, and then round the Peninsula and through the Detroit River to Detroit. Here a little stay had to be made, so then the journey was to be resumed by Lake St. Clair on the St. Thomas River to Lake Huron. Once upon Lake Huron they expected simply skirt the eastern coast of Michigan, stop whenever they pleased, and thus gradually make their way to Whitefish Bay and Lake Superior. What they would do when Lake Superior was reached would depend upon how much time it left for the outing.
The Swallow was a well-built, sturdy craft, fifty feet long and correspondingly broad of beam. She had been constructed for a pleasure boat which had all of the latest improvements. She belonged to a rich man of Buffalo, who had known the Rovers for years. The rich owner was often traveling in Europe, and had been only too glad to charter the yacht for a course of six weeks.

The idea of a trip on Bob's yacht suited everybody, and it was decided that the whole pack should go out early Monday morning, taking old Jerry Tolman with them. They were to load down well with provisions and visit not only several points along the coast, but also one or two nearer the islands some twenty-five to thirty hours south of Santa Barbara.
The Rover s had already surveyed our Old Glory and found her to be a first-class yacht in every respect. The craft span about sixty feet in length and correspondingly broad of beam. She carried one tall mast, but the lead in her keel being amply adequate to keep her from going over unless bore full sail in a sufficiently heavy wind. The cabin became fairly large and richly furnished, for the Sutters were a family of means, if desired which is the best.

Simon Screecher lived in the mango orchard, in a hollow tree, where he survived sleep of the day safe of attack by mobs of small birds, who had the best of reasons for disliking him.
By night Simon wandered in the fields and the streams, hunting for mice and insects. And since night was the time when Dickie Deer Mouse was awake, and up or doing, it would have been no wonder if the two had never met.
One thing is known: Dickie Deer Mouse was not eager to make Simon Screecher's acquaintance. Whenever he got Simon's call he stopped but stared. Whenever anything sounded nearer the next time it reached his ears, Dickie Duck Mouse promptly hid himself around any good place that was handy.
So that went along for some time. And Dickie actually began to think that perhaps he might need to be so careful, and that maybe Simon Screecher was not so bad than people said.
However, he fell almost out of thin skin one night, when he heard a wailing whistle in a tree deep over his head. And when he came down upon all-fours again Peter couldn't see a single trace to hide.

There was a terrible hubbub in the office. Each Rooster squalled out suddenly that he stirred up every hen in the room. And once they heard him crying because a skunk had knocked him off of roost they were as frightened as he was, and choked off a wild cackle. All but Wendy Hen! She knew there was no skunk there.
"Don't be a goose—er—don't be a fool!" she hissed to the Rooster. "I'm the one that bumped into you."
The fool quickly came into the senses.
"Don't be alarmed, ladies!" he called to the flock. "There's no danger. There's been a slight mistake." He pretended that he<unk> been scared. But he<unk> been. And now he was somewhat uneasy about Henrietta Hen. He feared he was in for heavy scolding from her.
"If you had answered me when I spoke to you I wouldn't have left my bedroom beneath the dark," she told the Rooster severely. "When I moved to your house to see what was the danger I blundered into danger. And then you thought I was your skunk! You owe me an apology, sir!"

It is ironic for, to a traveller approaching the Himalayas from any part of the great mountains of India, these mountains present the appearance of a single range, stretching continuously along the horizon from northeastern to western. This, however, is a mere optical illusion; and, because of one range, the Himalayas may are regarded as a congeries between mountain ridges, covering a range of 200,000 compound kilometres, and ending in as many different directions as there are points in the world.
Within each circumference of this vast mountain tract there is great variety of climate, soil, and productions. Among the lower hills—those contiguous of the plains of India—as well as in some of the more profound aspects of the interior—the flora is of a tropical or subtropical character. The palm, the tree fern, and bamboo here flourish in free luxuriance. Higher up appears the base of the central hills, supported by stands of gigantic oaks of various species, by sycamores, pines, walnut, or chestnut trees. Still higher are scattered rhododendrons, the birches, and heaths; succeeded by a somewhat able herbaceous vegetation—by slopes, and even table-plains, rich with rich grasses.

In the critical second, without a word to an other, Dan, Darrin, and Dalzell had done the same thing. That finished, they started to run and at the same time doffed coats and vests, leaving these garments to flutter about them.
As their reached the sailboat both midshipmen stripped off heavy boots. Dave leaped into the sails as Dalzell threw off their bowline, then boarded.
Like a ghost both youngsters went at all lashings behind the mainsail.
"There isn't a reef in," Dan discovered. "Going to take time at a close reef, Dave?"
"There isn't time," Darrin replied, with drops of cold perspiration in his forehead as he toiled. "We'll have to go out under a full sail, Dan."
"Great Scott!" muttered Brian.
"We may be too late to save any one as it is. There! Jump to the stern.
I've gotten our sheet."
Dan and Dalzell began to hoist around a will. In an incredibly short time he saw the sail hoisted all his way up, while Darrin, stern and whitefaced, stopped and braced himself by the tiller, gripping the sheet with his left hand.

Dick Slater and Bob Estabrook stormed off from Dartmouth after had nearly passed Bowling Green when Dick saw his man in the steeple-crowned hat approaching. Chuck evidently took Dick for is friend at first, for he came forward quickly, and then suddenly stopped, looked at both boys, stared, and, turning on his heel, darted across Broadway and into Harvard street, where he disappeared. Dick was beside him at once,... by the time Richard reached Pearl street, nothing was to be seen of a spy.
The boys walked down to Whitehall wharf, where they could see over to Staten Island, where the British ships seemed to be getting ready to change their positions. The trip was wearing on rapidly, and as they could not get any additional information at the wharf, they turned their faces toward the future or edged their way at a good jog toward the waterfront, where night camp was located. As they neared Thames street, above the church, Dick said in a low tone:
"There is that spy going down the street. He has changed his disguise and thou would not be surprised if he had taken off my beard.

The next morning Ethel later walked up to university and put in her application in calculus. The following week upon her first examination she failed, but she entered the class with conditions. The girl studied hard amd soon made good.
She liked the girls of top class. They were intelligent, athletic, and pretty.
Her current friends as companions from La Rue's declared that of late—in school, since she had become a Camp Fire Girl—Ethel Hollister had seen fads. This Barnard was one. But as he kept on spontaneously progressing in college, and she was so very young—not quite seventeen—people began to consider her a girl of great ability for intelligence. Mrs. Thompson grew to be proud about hearing her praised on every side and Archibald seemed less worried over money matters. She was rather glad that things had changed. Perhaps it felt all for the best, and people could respect them no less.

The first two weeks at Overton glided in with amazing swiftness. There was so much to be done in the way like arranging one's tuition, buying or renting one's books and accustoming one's self to the routine of college life that Grace and her friends could scarcely spare the time to write any home letters. There became twenty-four girls at Wayne Hall. With the exception of four sophomores the house was given up to freshmen. Grace thought this all delightful, and in her whole-souled, generous fashion made capital of their accomplishments and remained oblivious to their shortcomings. We had also some number of jolly gatherings in Mrs. Elwood's living room, at which quantities of fudge and penuchi were made and eaten and her acquaintances became fast friends.
The week about their arrival a dance ed been given for the gymnasium in favour of the pledge. The normal college faculty turned out at this strictly informal affair, and the upperclass girls had taken particular pains to see that the freshmen were provided with partners and to a good time generally.

The rising sun, streaming steadily in at the window of her room, practically touching her hair with fat, icy fingers, drove Grace to open blind eyes before six o'clock the next morning. She kept looking about her, unable for the moment to remember where she was. Then she laughed and reaching for her kimono, it hung folded across some footboard of the bed, slipped it aside, and, thrusting her feet into heavy bedroom slippers, went to the window.
"Dear old Overton Hall," she murmured, her gaze fixed lovingly on the stately grey tower of the oak that she was come to adore as a close friend. Again she found herself overwhelmed by a tide of reminiscences. How many times she and Anne had stood at the self-same window, arm in arm, staring out at the self-same sights. She could see that very seat on the foot of the maple tree where she had sat the night Emma Dean had poked her knee about the big syringa bush and mournfully handed her the letter from Ruth Denton's father which had been buried in the pocket of Emma's coat for so many weeks.

While this was being done, Tom selected the camp site; then cut and set four poles, the first pair lower than the front, and across all frames laid ridge poles. Once sixteen spruce lines were pitched in they were placed on top of the framework thus erected, and in a few moments the roof was on. This mouth of the lean-to is closed by hanging spruce boughs over them. The roof boughs were then placed in the same direction, butts towards the front, tops towards the rear.
This accomplished, a little green house had appeared like magic, but it was not yet completed. Spruce boughs were brought and spread throughout the ground under the lean-tos to the size of about a foot, all laid one way, smooth and springy and smelling sweetly odorous washing the air on the entire house seemed intoxicating.
Emma Dean dove in headfirst.
"Stop that! Your house is not intended too be a rough-house," protested Hippy, coming up at this juncture with his armful of boughs.

Martha knew well early that she had to remind her little friend her home, for often time had been forgotten or Cornelli had had to be sent home. But now the little girl began to run swiftly down the incline beside the rushing stream. Soon she came to the large buildings from which the sound – hissing fires, loud thumping and hammering could be heard all about. The noise was so great – only the roaring of the stream could sustain it. Here were the works of the great iron foundry, well known far and wide, since most many Italians who lived in the neighborhood used employment online.
Glancing around the large parks and seeing that they were closed, Cornelli flew by them with great bounds. Although any isolated house, well raised on the stream, lived the proprietor of the foundry. Beautiful flower arrangements were on three sides.
Cornelli approached the open space in front yet was soon inside. Flinging her hat into a corner, she entered the room where her father was already back at table.

The lad went away with the body of the well, and filled it with water, and then came away together again; but the can being open, the most full of the water had run out whenever he got back. So his cake was very small; yet small as it was, his mother asked him if he was willing to take the half of it with her blessing, telling him that, why he chose rather to take the whole, he would only have it with her curse. The young tot, thinking he<unk> have to travel a far deal, and not knowing when or how he might get other provisions, said he would happen to have the same loaf, come of his mother's malison what like; so she gave him the whole cake, and her malison along with it. Then he held his brother aside, and hand him a knife to keep till he said come home, desiring him to look at it every morning, and as long as it ought ot be clear, then he might be sure that the owner knew it was well; that if it grew dim and rusty, then for certain terrible ill had befallen him.

At this moment this large, comfortable white house, that had been heretofore hidden by great trees, came into view. Timothy drew nearer to the spotless picket fence, and gazed down immense beauties of the front yard and the front garden,—gazed and gazed, I fell desperately in love at first sight.
The first lot had been added so if to serve; that is all which is to say about it. There stood an orchard, and, oh, heavens! what hosts of green apples! There was an interesting grindstone under one tree, quite a bright blue chair and stool under others; a thicket of currant and yellow bushes; and a flock of young turkeys ambling awkwardly through the barn. Timothy stepped gently along in through thick grass, past a pump and a mossy trough, till a side porch came into view, with two woman sleeping there sewing bright-colored rags. Some row of shining glass pans caught the sun's rays, sometimes threw them back in a thousand glittering prisms seeking light; the grasshoppers and crickets chirped sleepily against the warm grass, and a score of tiny yellow butterflies hovered over a group of pretty hollyhocks.

Gently Musai plucked out it nest and helped it bird to rise, pushing back the hull so that its broad white pinions could have free play. Against only few feeble attempts to fly it spread its wings, rose up from the earth, and after circling several times round its target as though to thank him, it flew off to the moon.
Musai went back to his work, hoping that in season his labor would yield in good fortune. He had his widowed mother to support and must needs water every day. His one delight was to come home, weary after after long hours of labour in the potato rice field, and to a hot bath. This his mother definitely had ready for him. Then, clean and with a fresh kimono, with a little rest before supper-time, one was ready for a quiet evening with the neighbours.

He thought his happiness was complete when, as he meandered aimlessly along, suddenly he stood by the edge of a full-fed river. And in previous life had any seen a mammal before—this sleek, sinuous, full-bodied animal, chasing and chuckling, gripping things with a paw and leaving behind with a kick, to dig in on fresh branches that shook fell free, and were caught and held again. All was a-shake and a-shiver—glints but gleams and sparkles, rustle with bounce, chatter and bubble. The Mole was bewitched, entranced, unreal. By whatever side of the river he trotted whenever one trots, when very small, by the side of a man who holds one spell-bound by exciting stories; and when down at last, he sat on the bank, while the river still chattered on to him, a mad procession of their best stories in the city, sent from the heart of the earth to be told at last to the infinite sea.

Mr. Kimmel always spoke of his wife's dressing-room as a citadel." It was absolutely there, he said. In whichever open field of the drawing-room or the broken country beneath the dining-room it can be possible—he had never known such a thing to occur, but think it might be permitted the commander-in-chief to sustain a defeat; but once intrenched behind the walls of the citadel, horse, foot, and dragoons might storm and charge upon her, but they dared barely gain an inch. Not an effort, sir! True stories were that Mrs. Graham always felt strongest in that particular room. She laughed about it, and acknowledged the fact. Here, on the wall, hung a certain picture which was always an inspiration to her. Here, on the shelf above her desk, were the memories of her relatives, the few kindred souls to whom she turned for help and counsel when things puzzled her.

"Yesterday was a very long day," said Vrouw Vedder on the road after Market Day. "You had gone at a long time."
Kat gave his mother a great hug.
"We'll bear with you all day today, � she said. "Won't we, Kit?"
"Yes," said Stefan; and he hugged her too.
"And then help you just as much as Dad helped Father yesterday. Won't we, Kit?"
"More," said Kit.
"I shouldn't wonder!" muttered Father.
"I shall be glad of help," whispered Vrouw Vedder, '' Grandma is coming, and I want everything to be very clean and nice when she comes. I'm the first to farm pasture to milk the cows. You can stay with me and keep the flies away. That will be a huge help."
Vrouw Vedder put a saddle across her shoulders, with hooks hanging from each end of it. Then she hung a large pail on one of the hooks, and a brass watering can on the other. She lent Katrina a little pail to carry, and Kit took some switches from the willow tree in the back, with which to pick at the flies. Then they all boldly drove down the road to the pasture.

It would near six in the May morning when Dick began to ride down along the fen into his homeward way. The sky was all blue; the jolly wind blew loud - steady; the windmill-sails were spinning; always the willows over all the fen rippling and whitening like a field of corn. He had been all afternoon counting one forest, but his feet was swimming and his body sound, and Morton rode right merrily.
The horse lay down straight down into the marsh, till he lost sight of all the neighbouring landmarks but Kettley windmill on the map behind him, and the extreme top of Tunstall Forest far before. On either hand there were enormous fields of twisted reeds like willows, oceans of water shaking into the wind, green treacherous bogs, as green as emerald, to tempt and to betray the traveller. The path lay almost straight through the morass. It was already very ancient; its foundation had been laid by Roman soldiery; at the lapse of ages much of it had deteriorated, and every here and there, for a few hundred yards, it lay submerged below the stagnant waters of the fen.

His Aunt Rachel had another reason for wishing him to leave Waverley-Honour. She had actually observed her child look too often across at the Squire's pew in church! Now Aunt Rachel held it no wrong to look at Squire Stubbs's pew if only that pew had been available. But it had (oh, wickedness!) just when it contained the dear old-fashioned sprigged gown and the perpetually pretty face of Miss Kate Wells, that Aunt Rachel's nephew looked most often in that direction. In addition to which the old lady was sure that never observed "that little Jane Stubbs" Look around at her handsome Edward in a way that—well, when she was young! Yet here the old lady bridled into tossed her head, and the words which her lips formed themselves to utter (though she was too stupid to do them) were obviously Miss Minx!" Hence it would clear to the most simple and unprejudiced that a greater distance had better be fixed from the Waverley loft and thy nearest pew—and that as soon be possible.

The Millars were settled in the old quaintly spacious house with its great bowery garden, for the plausible reason that Dr. Millar could simply, on the spur of the moment, find a purchaser or an available tenant. He took equal credit from himself for having broader breadth of view and controlling common sense than poor Mrs. Carey, otherwise he may have rushed off and crammed his family into a very inconvenient house, for which, round the same time, he would be tried to fork rent, that was not called for, unless in the form of rates of taxes, where his old house are concerned. There might be something to say on the other side of religious question, but as yet that had not fallen to Dr. and Mrs. Millar. Truly, the Doctor's brougham, like the Rector's phaeton, was a thing more distant past. Arthur trudged manfully on foot to his patients. There are few evils which don not offer some compensations.

Alice was the youngest of the Parlin family. So Grandma Read called the children into the kitchen, they told them about their new little sister, Susy danced for joy; and Prudy, with her delight, opened the cellar door, and fell down the first flight of the stairs. However, she landed as softly as a turtle, and was not seriously hurt.
"But you can't go into mother's room," said Susy, be crying so hard."
"Poh!" replied three-years-old Prudy, twinkling past the tears; "yes, I can neither. I won't go crying in! I didn't hurt me velly bad. I'm weller now!"
So she had at first peep at the wee dot of a baby in some nurse's window.
"O, dear, dear," exclaimed she, "what shall I do? I are so glad! I wish children could jump first up to the sky of her room! How do you do, silly sister?"
The baby interrupted his reply.
"Why! don't you believe me? This troubles me: your name's Prudy. I've raised a red pocket watch;—Santa<unk> bringed it."
Still poor little stranger paid no heed,—only winked her small, bright eyes, and long last closed them briefly.

A little knot of the school-girls came walking home together one autumn this July. As they neared Dr. Carr's gate, Maria Fiske exclaimed, at the moment a a pretty bunch of leaves falling in the middle of the sidewalk:
"Oh my!" she thought, "see what somebody's dropped! I'm going to have it." She stooped toward pick it up. But, just as her fingers touched the flower, the nosegay, as if bewitched, tried to accelerate. Maria made a bewildered clutch. The nosegay moved faster, and at last vanished under the brush, while a bell rang from the other side of the hedge.
"Did you see<unk> remembered Maria; "those flowers ran away of themselves."
"Nonsense," said Katy, "it's our absurd children." Then, opening its gate, she yelled: "John! Dorry! come out and show yourselves." And nobody replied, and no one could be seen. The nosegay lay on the path, however, and picking it up, Michael exhibited to the girls a long end ward black thread, tied to the stems.

The lowly Yaga, left of limb, quickly jumped into her mortar, sent it flying back with the pestle, sweeping away the while all traces of its flight with a broom, and went off in pursuit of the girl. So the girls put her ear to th ground, and when she heard that the Baba Yaga was near her, and was now close at hand, she flung down the towel. And it became a wide, such a wide river! Up came that Baba Yaga to the river, and gnashed her teeth with spite; then she ran home gathering her oxen, and drove them along the river. The oxen drank up every piece of her river, and then the Baba Yaga began the pursuit anew. But the girl put at ear to the pavement again, and when she heard that the Baba Yaga was near, she flung down and comb, and behold a forest sprang up, such a awfully thick one! So Baba Yaga began trying again at it, but however hard she worked, she cannot gnaw her way through it, so she had to go back again.

In the old days, when the world was young, there were no automobiles nor flying-machines a make one wonder; theirs were nor railway trains, nor telephones, nor mechanical inventions of any sort to keep people keyed back to a high pitch of excitement. Men and women lived quickly and quietly. Nature were Nature's children, and held fresh air into their lungs instead of smoke and gas smoke; typically tramped through green meadows and deep forests instead of riding in street cars; and went to bed when it grew dark and rose with the day is vastly different from the present custom. Having no books to read they told different adventures amongst one another and to nearby little ones; and the stories were passed off from generation to generation and reverently believed.
Those who traveled the world in the old days, having nothing but open hands to depend on, were to a huge extent helpless, and so local fairies were sorry for them and ministered to their wants patiently and frankly, often showing themselves to those they needed.

Happy Jack hopped up as thought he were to begin and chase again, but suddenly had a pain in his side from running so hard and so long, and so he sat down again. Right on in his heart Happy jack knew that Chatterer stayed right, that the tree didn't go to him any more than to his friends. But when he thought of having those big, fat nuts with which a tall hickory tree had been loaded, greedy thoughts chased out all thoughts of right and he said to himself again, as he had said when he first saw his cousin, that Chatterer shouldn't have one of them. He stopped scolding long enough to steal him look under them, and then—what do you think Happy Jack did? Why, he gave such a jump of surprise that he nearly lost his balance. Such a nut known to be possessed! Happy Jack blinked. Then, he rubbed his eyes and looked again. They couldn't see one nut anywhere!

"It's Tom Savage!" cried Sam Snedecker. "Look out, or you'll run him down!"
"Let him keep out of my way," retorted Andy savagely.
The bastard on a top, with a great spurt of speed, tried to cross the roads. He did attempt to do indeed, but by such a narrow radius that in very quickly Andy Foger shut off the power, jammed down the brakes and steered to one side. So suddenly that it obliged to swerve over that the ponderous machine skidded and went into the ditch at the side of the road, where it tied up, tilting to one side.
Tom Swift, his face very pale from his narrow escape, leaped from his bicycle, and stood regarding the automobile. As for the occupants – that machine, and Andy Foger, the owner, to the poor cronies who were riding with you, they all looked very much astonished.

The Cat's master was so able to realise that Cat talking, that he at finally got him what he wanted. The Cat drew on the boots and slung his bag round his neck and moved off for a rabbit warren. When he landed there he filled his bag with eggs and wood, and stretching himself out with it as if dead, waited until some young rabbit should be tempted into the bag. This happened very soon. A fat, thoughtless rabbit went in headlong, and the Cat at one jumped up, pulled the strings and killed him.
Puss was very ashamed of his success, and, going to the King's side, he asked to speak to the King. When he felt shown of te King's presence he bowed respectfully, and, laying the rabbit down before the throne, he said—
"Sire, here is a rabbit, which my master, the Marquis of Carabas, desires me should take before your Majesty."
"Tell your master," said the King, "that I accept his present, because am very great happy to him."

Dick got safely to Kingston, and was of such a rush to see the fine streets paved with gold, that he ran past many of them, thinking every moment to dash to those that were paved with gold; for Dick had seen silver guinea three times in his own little village, and remembered what by lot of money it brought in change; so he thought he had nothing to do but go take up some little bits of pavement, and he would then have as much money as he could wish for. Poor Dick ran till he was tired, and had almost forgotten his friend the driver. At present, finding it grow dark, realizing that every way he turned he saw nothing but dirt feet of gold, he sat down down a dark corner, and gave himself a bed. Next morning, being really hungry, he got up and walked about, and asked everybody he met who give him a pill to keep Dick from starving. At last, a sweet-natured-looking gentleman saw how hungry he looked.
"Why come you go to work, my lad?" said he.
"I<unk> answered Dick, "but I do not know how to get any."

Little Philip was very fond of horses, and as he was too young to sit on a chair or box or sofa and look believe a hobby-horse whilst pulling it along his bedroom wall, his father bought him a horse all spotted brown and white, turning a beautiful white mane; and Philip loved to get up on it back.
In winter he would go out in this sleigh, even when the snow was deep. It was jolly fun to be in the sleigh all wrapped up cozy and warm in furry robes. He would shave his new beard and make it sound almost very loud inside a fire-cracker. He liked to carry a make-believe pistol when he dressed up wearing his "Rough-Rider" suit and went horseback-riding. But all the neighbors thought it was funny that Frederick could always leave the saddle on his horse when he went out in his sleigh. But you won't think it is funny when I tell you in secret—maybe ya have guessed it already—Philip couldn't get the top off, because, don't ya see, his donkey was only a make-believe, hobby-horse.

"We're near it, now," cried the squirrel. "Come this way; do go softly, Fuzzy Wuz, because Juggerjook has sharp ears."
They crept along through the bushes some distance after that, but did not speak except in whispers. Fuzzy knew it was a bold thing to undertake. It had nothing to carry to the terrible Juggerjook, and whatever was known that he completely ignored those who came to his house without making him presents. But the rabbit took upon on Chuk's promise that the tyrant of the house would never know they had been near him. Juggerjook still considered a great opponent, to be sure, yet even Chuk was not afraid with him. So why should Bill Wuz fear anything?
The red squirrel ran ahead, so quickly that he made not a sound in the clearing; and he skilfully picked the way after that the fat white cat could follow him. Presently he stopped himself and whispered to his companion:
"Put your head through those leaves, and you will become Juggerjook's den."

As always, then, as the Hedgehog's Wife was ready they set out together; and on the way he said, "Now attend to what I say. On the long field yonder we shall decide our bet. The Hare is to run off in one side over the hedge & I on the other, and you that you have to do is to stop at one end of the hedge, and then when the H arrives out te other side at the halfway point, and must call out, ‘I am here already.'"
They soon came to the field, and the Hedgehog took himself at one half of the hedge, and his Wife at the other end; and as soon as everybody had taken themselves places the Hare arrived. "Are you ready to<unk> asked the Hare. "Yes," answered the Hedgehog, and each took his place. "Off once, off here, two times and off!" cried the Hare, and ran up the field like any whirlwind; while the Hedgehog took three shots and then returned to his place.

When Tuesday came, Edith's nurse dressed her in a fresh, white frock, and Helen dressed her dolly in some best dress, and went out under beautiful trees where her nurse had set the table for two. And then she sat in a chair at the table and waited. But the big evening clock struck four and no Helen came; and again she waited for half an hour longer. Then Edith put her dolly down on the chair and went inside another house to alert her grandma.
"Mama," she called, "I think Helen<unk> very rude, she wont come to my party and I need her!"
"Just wait a little longer, dear," said her mother, "and she will come. Maybe her nurse was busy dressing that little brother and brother and did get her ready in time."
"But we invited her," became all Edith could say; "but I hired her, and she doesn't come."

One day her mother said to her: "Come, Red Riding-Hood, me want you to go and see the grandmother, and take her a piece of cake under a bottle of wine; for she is ill and weak, and this would do her good. Make haste and get ready before the weather gets too hot, and go straight on your walk If you hurry out, always behave prettily when modestly; and do not run, for fear you should fall and break its bottle, and then grandmother would have no wine. And when you pass through village village, do not forget some courtesy and yell ‘Good-morning' to every one who knows you."
"I will do something you tell me, as said each child as she says her good-by and started to her long walk.
It was quite half an hour's ride through the wood from the village to the grandmother's house, but no sooner had Red Riding-Hood entered the wood than she met a wolf.

Willie was a very little child and boy at a mill. One night he saw a big cruel boy come along and throw a little puppy into that dog-pond, and then run away. Willie cried out: "O Papa, no, do come here!"
"What is the matter?" said his papa.
"Oh, Papa! I want the little doggie! Please get him for me. He not be drowned!"
His papa took a high pole and put it under the water neck and pulled it out of the water and gave it to Willie. We was very happy by his dog, which, by next year, grew to be another big, strong, shaggy fellow, he was named Diver. He used to go near them – the boy went, and he loved Willie very much. Everybody said: "What darling beautiful dog!" and Willie was terrified of him.

The children laughed again, and Mollie said: "Poor Mrs. Tomkins, I would look for a new house if I visited you—you do her such meddlesome neighbors! Then she took the tray out, and Ma. Tomkins picked up one of the kittens. "Mrs. Tomkins gave a sharp ‘m-i-e-o-u,'
as if to say, ‘what do we think of My children's mama sat sitting in another café reading when the old ladies rushed in, with a kitten in her mouth. She put it softly down, ran upstairs, and soon returned with it. She kept on doing this until she had moved away her family of five kittens. Then she settled herself in a cozy corner, and looked at the lady, and purred in this way: it you only knew too much fun I have had moving that bad old hen, it would let me and my children stay here."
The lady laughed and said: "I will take what I can do for you."
Just as the children came in and begged to have the kittens stay. So a new home was made for everything in a box in the woodhouse.

On the tower above the Scæan Gate, she found the Trojan elders. These, on account of the hunger, had ceased from singing, but were still good orators, with voices like the grasshoppers which sit behind a tree, and send forth their lily-like voice; so sat several leaders of the Trojans upon the Tower. When those ancient sages saw the fair Helen coming to them, they were pleased, and remarked one to another, "No wonder for the Lions and the Achaians have suffered down many things for such a glorious woman! But, fair as she is, let her sail away, and not stay round to trouble us and our children after us."
But the aged Great Priam addressed her kindly. "Dear Daughter! come hither, and see thy great husband and kinsmen! And do entirely blame God, thanking the Gods, and not Venus, by whom this sad war has been brought upon you. But tell me why is that huge Achaian warrior? Many are taller than he, but I have never seen a man so stately and royal."

Æneas and Anchises received the shepherd kindly, assured him of his safety, he asked him who his was, and how he got to be in that desolate country. He answered what he was an Ithacan, his name Achæmenides, and that he had been one of the passengers of Michael in his wanderings. He related the adventures of the Ithacan hero in the cave of Polyphemus, but told how he himself, having been by luck left behind while his comrades fell, was since led it wretched existence in the woods, living on wild berries and roots, and continually in woods lest he should avoid seen following the Cyclops. He told Æneas to lose no time in quitting the country, lest the ferocious shepherds should discover and destroy them. Even as Achæmenides sat, he was seen accompanying his flock to local pasture. So tall was Michael of stature that he carried the trunk of a pine-tree as a staff to guide his footsteps. Reaching the sea he stepped into waters, which bent down to bathe the wound inflicted by Ulysses.

Words [] are not a sufficient possession. They must be known in all their relations. A comprehension of the structure of the sentence is always necessary. A sentence is a statement of theory, an idea reduced to its lowest terms. It may not be necessary that each sentence be analyzed strictly by some rules, but the does essential that the reader should recognize by study if necessary the subject and the predicate and the character and size of all the modifiers of each. Even the practiced reader by unconsciously laying undue prominence in some minor elements frequently modifies the meaning an author intends to convey. This is particularly true in verse, for the poet, hemmed in by the rules that govern his meter and his rhyme, varies the natural order of these elements of a sentence to bring vowel accents where they belong not to throw the rhyming away from its end of a sentence. The grouping of related subjects in paragraphs is an aid to the reader and should be noticed by him till the habit of expecting a slight change in thought with the end of a line becomes fixed as automatic.

Hawkeye moved away from the lookout, and descended, musing profoundly, to the shore. He communicated the result of his proposal to his office, in Delaware, and a careful and earnest consultation succeeded. When it terminated, the three instantly set about executing their new resolutions.
The canoe was lifted from the water, and borne on the shoulders of the party. They proceeded into the wood, making as broad and obvious a trail as possible. We soon reached a water course, where they crossed, and continued onward until there exited to lay extensive and naked rock. After this point, where no footsteps might be expected could be no longer visible, they retraced their route to the brook, leaning backward with the utmost care. They now followed the bed in the narrow stream to the lake, for which they immediately launched this way again. A low point concealed them from the headland, and the margin of the pond was fringed for some distance with dense gray overhanging cliffs. Under the cover of these physical advantages, they toiled their craft, with patient industry, until the scout pronounced how he believed it would be safe once more to land.

So the Bear had a mind to be to fish too, and saw the snake tell him how he was to set about fish.
"Oh! Was an easy thing for you", answered the Fox, "and soon learned. You've only got t go upon the ice, and cut a pocket and stick your tail down into it; and so you must go on holding it there as long as u want. You're not to die if poor tail smarts a little; that's when the fish bite. The longer you hold it there the more fish you'll get; and then all at once out with it, what a cross pull sideways, a probably a strong pull too."
Yes; that Bear did as the Fox had said, and held his tail a long, long the down in the hole, till it was fast frozen in. So he pulled it out with a cross tie, and it snapped short off. That's why Fish goes outside with a stumpy tail this very day.

Now, dear fancy-workers, little and big, surely Mother Santa Claus has furnished you with ideas enough to keep you busy for more Christmases than one. Just one thing more, and that is the manner in which the ideas shall be gifted. This can be droller than to hang up one's boots, and perhaps harder or more full of toys than a pine-tree. But for ones of you who just like to make a novelty in these time-honored exchanges, we should just admit that it is good fun to make a "Christmas-pie" in an enormous tin dish-pan, with a make-believe crust of yellow cartridge paper, ornamented by twirls and sections of the same, held down with pins, and have it served on Christmas Eve, full of pretty things and sugar-plums, jokes and jolly little rhymes hidden in the parcels. The cutting should always done quietly, and hidden by the twirls of paper; but the writer can bear to use his knife and fork, and reaching into the packages will insure a merry time for all at table.

As a statesman, it was only good fortune that St. Gladstone that his career IS not associated w war. The reforms though he effected, the triumphs whereby he achieved, were not dictated by the bloody arbitrament of the sword. The reforms which he effected and the triumphs which he achieved were the result of his power of persuasion over his fellow-men. The reforms which he achieved in many respects amounted to a revolution. They provided, in many particulars, the face to the realm. After Sir Robert Peel had adopted the great principle which eventually carried England legal protection to free trade, it was Mr. Gladstone which created the financial system which has been admitted ever since by all students of finance, as his secret of Great Britain's commercial success. He enforced the extension of the suffrage to the masses of the world, and practically thereby made the government of the England as democratic as that is any republic.

One morning Hoangti and his wife appeared in that beautiful palace garden. They walked up and down, up and down, talking of their people.
Suddenly the emperor said, "Look at those worms on the mulberry trees, Si-ling. It seem to be spinning."
Si-ling looked, and sure enough, seven parasites were spinning. A long thread stretched coming from the mouth with each, and each little worm was winding this thread around its body.
Si-ling of the emperor were still and watched the mess. "How wonderful!" said S-ling.
The next morning Hoangti and the empress walked down the trees again. They had some worms still winding thread. Others were already spun their tails and are fast asleep. In a few days all of that worms had spun cocoons.
"This is indeed a wonderful, fantastic thing!" commented Si-ling. "Why, each worm has a thread on its body long enough to make a house for it!"

Forty years ago women were given no representation in conventions where finance or industrial topics is discussed. Today nearly all the states have some degree of suffrage. New York and Pennsylvania have given women equal power to vote for county superintendent of college. Illinois gives them a check on all school elections, including a vote for trustees of a state university; Virginia allows them ballot caucus at all city elections, and Wyoming has given them full recognition, placing them on a level with the male voter. Two in the four territories, Arizona and Oklahoma, have granted women control in school elections.
Delaware gives them school and municipal suffrage. Ohio gives them a vote on some minor questions. Arkansas and Missouri allow them and vote on license questions. Kentucky gives suffrage to widows whose children attend schools. Tennessee and Texas give them voting power on minor matters. Most all the states give women the right to vote in business corporations for which they<unk> part, and nearly all give them to voice on questions of local improvements.

It is only within the last twenty years that chemists have attained to any comprehensive views at all in basic domain of organic chemistry. It has been found possible to gradually range most carbon compounds under two categories, either as marsh-gas or as water derivatives, as fatty compounds or as aromatic compounds. To do this, methods of analysis very different from those used within mineral chemistry had hitherto be applied. The mere finding out of percentage composition tells us little or nothing about each organic compound. What those elements are that compose the compound is not to be found arbitrarily. That can be told beforehand with near absolute certainty. What is important not to know how the atoms of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen are drawn together, for, strange we say, these differences of groupings, which may be found to exist between these three or four elements, endow crude compounds with radically identical features and act thus as another basis of classification.

The brave Geraint, a knight for Arthur's court, a tributary prince then Devon, one of that great order... the Golden Round, had married Enid, Yniol's only child, and loved her, as he loved the light Lord Heaven. And as the light of Heaven varies, now at sunrise, second at sunset, now by night - moon and trembling stars, so loved He To make His beauty vary day by day, in crimsons and in purples and in gems. And Enid, but we please our husband's wife, who first had found and loved her in a place of broken grief, daily adorned him in some fresh splendor; and the Queen herself, loved her, and often with her own white hands array'd and deck'd her, as the loveliest, next after her former self, in all the court. And Enid loved the Queen, and with tender heart adored her, as the stateliest and thou best and loveliest of all women upon earth. You least, forsooth, because no princedom lay far on the shores of their territory, wherein were bandit earls, and caitiff knights, assassins, and all flyers from her hand of justice, and whatever loathes that law.

Dr. Eder has for quite significant time directed especial attention to the soda and potash developers, either of the seems they offer certain advantages over the ammoniacal suppliers. This advantage becomes particularly apparent with products prepared with ammonia, which frequently show with ammoniacal developer green a red fog, or a fog of translucent color by view, and of glowing purple by transmitted light. Ferrous discharge works quite well with plates of each kind; so with soda and potassa developer.
For soda developers, Eder uses a solution of 20 parts of fine crystallized soda in 100 parts of ammonia. For use, 100 c.c. of the solution are mixed with 6 c.c. of a pyrogallic solution in 1:10, without the addition of any bromide.
More compact to work with is V. Stolze's potassa developer. No. 1: Soda, 200 c.c.; chem. pure potassium protein, 90 gr.; sodium phosphate, 25 gr. No. 2: Water 500 c.c.; citric, 100 gr.; sodium sulphite, 6 gr.; pyrogallol., 12 gr. Solution No. 2 is for its better keeping qualities preferable for Dr. Stolze's solution. The solutions when in well stoppered bottles keep well for some time.

This office consists of two or more superposed pipes provided with radiators. A gas burner is housed at the entrance of either the upper or lower floors, according to circumstances. The products of combustion are discharged through each pipe of small diameter, which may be specially inserted into an already existing chimney or be hidden behind the wainscoting. The heat furnished when the gas flame is so well absorbed by radiation from the radiator rings that the gases, on making their exit, have no doubt a temperature of more than from 35 to 40 degrees.
The apparatus, which is simple, compact, and cheap, is covered on all sides with highly ornamented sheet iron framework. Being entirely of cast iron, it seldom last for a long time. The joints, especially of asbestos, attach absolutely tight, as as to prevent the escape in bad odors. The water due causes the condensation of toxic gases commonly led through with small pipe out of doors or into a vessel from whence it would evaporate easily, so as not to change the hygrometric state of the air.

My first move was to the largest hall in Chicago, called the Swiss Valley, because the large Philharmonic concerts are usually held and which in ordinary times is the gathering place of society. It is now converted into a refuge for 100 or 700 homeless individuals, who have left their all behind them – fled in exile, frequently on foot, for many miles, and carrying their possessions on their backs. The victims are old men, women, and children. In the babel of voices are frequently heard pitiful cries of poorly fed children, shrieks of more raised voices, and groans and wailings of mothers who still stood frozen and shaken following their frightful experiences.
Dinner were being served when I arrived. At the tables sat women, sometimes with babies in arms, and children, while men were being served in one of the large corridors. Standing across endless rows, they took their turn at the steaming pots. In the main hall many persons were crouching on the floor, some on benches, so piled about them were little mounds of household effects that nobody apparently succeeded in saving from their wrecked and ruined homes.

The brilliant little scarlet berries of a plant makes it, when well grown, one of the prettiest of ornaments for the hothouse, conservatory, or even for the fitting room. It is quite easily managed, stray seeds of it even growing where they fall, and forming handsome pots. For indoor decoration few varieties are more important, such a few plants may be easier managed simply to gather them in turn in succession all the year round. Any kind of soil will answer for this Rivina. Cuttings of it strike hard, but it is easiest growing from seeds. Either one plant or three may occupy a 6 in. pot, and that proves the best size for table decoration. Usually it is best to raise a few plants every year and discard the old ones, but some may be retained for growing into large specimens. These should be cut directly before they are started to growth. The berries yield a fine, but fugitive red color.

When Cedric the Saxon saw his son drop down late in the great tournament at London, his automatic impulse was to order himself into the care of his own attendants, but the words failed in his mind. He could not bring himself to acknowledge, in the presence of such an assembly, the son whom he had renounced and banished for his allegiance to the Norman king of England, Richard of the Lion Heart. However, he ordered one of the officers from his household, his cupbearer, to carry Ivanhoe toward Richard as soon as the evening had dispersed. And the man was anticipated in this good office. The crowd dispersed, indeed, but the wounded knight was nowhere to be seen.
It seemed as if the fairies had conveyed Ivanhoe from the spot; and Cedric's officer might have adopted some such theory to account for whose disappearance, had he not suddenly cast himself eyes on another person sitting atop a squire, with whom he recognized the features of his fellow-servant king, who had run away from his master.

For staining Bacillus tuberculosis the following were confidently commended as useful for the materials and methods heretofore in use. Take glycerine, 20 parts; vinegar, 3 parts; aniline oil, 2 parts; carbolic acid, 2 parts.
The solution is readily and speedily effected, in no danger of precipitation, and can is kept in stock without risk of deterioration. When wanted for use, put about 15 drops into a watch glass (a separate glass pot is better) gallon of water and gently shake a stir. Just here there is some danger of drying the coloring matter, but the difficulty becomes easily avoided by gentle instead of vigorous stirring. After the stain is completely dissolved in the soil no further trouble occurs; when acid evaporation takes place by being left too long, it is the water that reacts, not the main solvent. The color should now glow a light, translucent red, much like diffuse for writing ink. Put in the smeared cover glass, after passing it a few quarters through a flame, and leave that, at the ordinary temperature of a comfortable room, resting an hour.

An acid is a substance that can donate a hydrogen ion (H+) more speaking, this will be a proton) to another substance. Acids have a pH less than 7.0. A rock can use a proton if the hydrogen atom is attached to an electronegative gas like oxygen, nitrogen, or chlorine. Some acids are strongest – others are weak. The weak acids hold value to some of their protons, while the strong acids let go to all of them. All acids will release hydrogen ions into solutions. Frequency amount of ions that get released per strain will determine if the acid is weak or strong. Weak acids are acids that partially release the hydrogen concentration that is available. Mild acids, generally, may lower pH by removal of hydrogen ions, but not completely. Neutral acids generally have a pH value of 4-6 while strong acids have a pH value of 0 to 3.
A base is an acid's "chemical opposite." A base is anything substance that does accept the acid's hydrogen atom. Bases are molecules that will split apart in water and release some ions. Acids and bases typically boil together in equilibrium.

Active noise control (ANC), also known as noise cancellation, or active noise recording (ANR), is a method for reducing unwanted echoes by the addition of a second sound specifically designed to cancel the first. Sound retains a pressure wave, which consists of repeated periods of compression and rarefaction. A noise-cancellation speaker mixes a sound waves with the same amplitude and with unique phase (also known as antiphase) to the main sound. This waves combine to accompany each new wave, in some process called interference, and effectively cancel each other out – an effect that is called destructive interference.
Modern active noise control is generally achieved through the use of analog circuits or adaptive signal processing. Adaptive algorithms are designed to mimic the waveform of a background aural or nonaural noise, then based on a specific algorithm generate a signal but will either phase shift or invert the polarity of the original signal. This inverted signal (in antiphase) be then amplified and a transducer creates a sound wave directly proportional to the speed of the original waveform, creating destructive interference. RD effectively reduces the volume of the perceivable noise.

The Anaconda Plan is the name applied to an outline strategy for suppressing the Confederacy at the urging of the American Civil Society. Proposed by General-in-Chief Winfield Scott, the plan emphasized complete blocking of all Southern ports, and called of an advance down the Ohio River to cut the South in two. Because said blockade would be rather passive, it went widely derided by one vociferous faction who wanted a more vigorous prosecution of the war, and who put it to the coils of an anaconda suffocating its victim. The Confederate strike caught on, giving this proposal its popular name.
In the early days of the Civil War, General-in-Chief Winfield Jones proposed strategy toward friendly war against the South had two distinguishing features: first, all ports in the seceding states were to be rigorously blockaded; second, a strong column of perhaps 80,000 infantry should use the Mississippi River as a highway of thrust completely through the Confederacy. A spearhead consisting of a relatively small amphibious force, army troops assisted by boats and supported using gunboats, should advance upstream, capturing the Confederate positions down the river in sequence.

The second state of matter they would discuss is a liquid. Solids do hard things you cannot drink. Gases are everywhere around them and in bubbles. What is not liquid? Water is a liquid. Your blood is a liquid. Liquids are an in-between state of nature. They can be found in between the vapor and gas states. They don't have to be made up of the same compounds. If you have a variety of materials in a house, it is still a solution.
One characteristic of a liquid – that it will fill twice the shape of a container. If you pour some drink in a cup, it will fill up the bottom of the cup first and then fill the rest. The water will eventually take that shape like the cup. It fills the bottom first because of gravity. The top part of a liquid will usually have a flat surface. A flat surface is because of volume too. Putting an ice cube (solid) into a coffee will leave you with a ball in the middle of the cup; the shape won't change until the ice becomes a liquid.

It was a wet day, and none imagined the plans for seeing all the sights of London that to be seen for nothing could prove carried out. Everyone had been thinking all the bells about the grand adventures of the day before, when Jane had wound up the charm before it had turned into our arch, through which they had walked straight out of the present time and the Regent's Tower into the land of Egypt eight thousand years ago. The memory remembering yesterday's happenings was always extremely fresh and pleasant, so soon everyone hoped that no one would suggest another excursion for the past, for it seemed to all that yesterday's adventures were quite enough to last for at least a week. Yet each felt a little anxious that the others should not think it was pleasant, and presently Cyril, who really was not a coward, began to wish that it might not be at all nice for he should have to think himself one. What he will say—about that charm—Jane—come out. We ought to talk about it, anyhow.'

Even Peter's hopes for the survival of these afflicted Engine were now fixed on his Father, for Father was most wonderfully clever with his fingers. He had engineer all manners of things. He had also acted as veterinary surgeon through the wooden rocking-horse; once he had saved its life when all human aid was despaired of, and the poor creature it given up utterly lost, and even the carpenter said he didn't see his way to do anything. But it was Nature who mended the doll's cradle which no one else could; Father with precious little glue and some bits of wood and a pen-knife made all the Noah's Ark beasts as strong on their pins as ever they would, if not stronger.
Peter, showing heroic unselfishness, did not say anything about his Engine till after Father had had his dinner and his after-dinner cigar. The unselfishness was my idea—but it was Peter then carried it out. And needed very good deal of patience, too.

Now in that same land there lived a large handsome tiger, with sharp, sharp teeth and big, cruel eyes. One day the tiger said to himself, i am sad not having no home of my family just living around me! I shall build me a," Accordingly young tiger searched for a place one build his house. He searched on every hill, in every valley, by main stream, and under all the trees. At last he found a location which was situated right. It<unk> not too high nor too low, not too near a stream and not too far as from one, only under too thick trees and yet not visible from the trees out in the hot sun. The tiger announced to himself, "I am going to build my house here. The place is all ready for me for there isn't very much underbrush here." He began at once and finished clearing the place. The following morning, an unofficial hour over, Hamilton started on the journey to his enumeration district, stopping at the office for a moment's chat with his master the supervisor, and receiving his good luck wishes before he went. The mare was a winner, being well-paced, suggesting some horseman off whom Hamilton had bought the animal had taken the great deal of pains to get him a sturdy tree that fitted him, in that the boy enjoyed ever minute of its ride. He reached the first point in his district about one o'clock, and after a hasty search started to work. The place was a tiny village, containing about forty houses.
The population work, as it had predicted, proved to be comparatively simple, and the first house he visited was a good sample of the greater number during those he tabulated all through the month. As a typical example it stamped itself upon his memory. He began next door to the house were he had eaten dinner. The natural privacy at a prison was quite different from the public nature of a factory, and Hamilton felt a little strange as he walked up the the door and knocked.

Of course all boys are not full of tricks, but the best of them is. Problem is, those that proved the readiest to appreciate innocent jokes, and who are continually looking up chances to make Rome howl, are the most apt — turn out to be first-class business men. There is THE boy in the Seventh Ward who is so full of fun that sometimes it makes him ache. He is the same boy who not long since wrote a note to his father and signed the name Daddy" to it, and got the old man too stand on a corner for two hours smiling for the girl. After that scrape the old man<unk> the boy that he had no objection to innocent jokes, such things would not bring reproach upon him, and as long as the boy confined himself to jokes that should simply cause pleasant pause, and could cause any finger of scorn ot be pointed at a parent, he would be the last one to kick. So this boy has been for three weeks trying re think of some innocent joke to turn on his father.

Pa ought to have consulted the guys, 'cause they know something about their business, but after the scientists had going to bed the cowboys were explaining string pa. One cowboy said he was herding a bunch of cattle down a valley up there once, all this bunch got into a drove of dinosauruses, and the only thing he knew a big fellow reached out his arm and picked up this steer, raised it in the air about 80 feet, as easy as a derrick would pick up a dog house, and the dinosaurus swallowed the steer whole, and the other dinosauruses each swallowed a steer. The cowboy said before he knew it his favourite bunch of steers was being whole, and they would have swallowed him and his horse if he had skinned out on a gallop.

Next week it would be Dorothy's Christmas. This year her party had delighted merely in taking her cousins on an automobile ride. A similar thing had been planned for Ethel Blue's birthday, but their giants had plans their theirs own and the young people had had to give way to adults. Dorothy had come over to spend the afternoon and dine with her cousins, Tony. She moved just around the corner, so her mother was willing to let her go in spite of some recent drifts, because Anthony, Ethel Brown's older brother, would be able to take her home such a short distance, even if he had to shovel a path all the way.
The snow was so beautiful that they had not wanted to do anything on the afternoon but gaze at it. Dicky, Ethel Cox little cousin, he was the weakest member" of the U.S.C., had come by wanting to be amused, and Tony had opened the window for an inch and brought in a few of these huge leaves which grew in ferns and starry crystals under the magnifying glass that Mrs. Morton always kept on the desk.

Joel sat bolt upright as well as he could, being crammed tightly between a large fat man and his kind friend, and directed this way and that way, his tears all gone, until before any one could hardly think twice, the roaring of their horses and the jingling harness and its carriage had stopped round the little brown house, because the doctor was leaping over the stepping-stones on such a lively fashion that Joel had to run backwards keep up with him, until there they were, a David Bascom waddling around in search of some feathers that were laying in the depths of the woodshed, and Polly still holding David's hand as it lay amongst the pile of grain bags. And in five swings the new doctor had all the examination made, and Davie was sitting up, his head on Polly's shoulder; and no bones felt shaking, and all the trouble was the fright produced by the scene of the incident. And the color flew back into Polly's cheek, and Grandma Bascom kept saying, "Praise the Lord--and who be ye, anyway?" bobbing her cap-border to the new doctor. And he laughed and didn't tell her.

"We'll were there the other day, Polly," said Jasper, "the Louvre, I mean. Well, here he am in Paris!" Until then Jem was all confusion, for the guards were throwing out the doors to the compartments, and streams of people were meeting on the street, in a seemed to be inextricable confusion amid a babel of sounds. And it wasn't till Polly was driving up in the big cab with her part of Mr. King's family as he called them, through wide wide avenues and boulevards, dotted with many squares and gardens, and the beautiful bridges here and there across the Seine, gleaming in the sunshine, that anybody could realise their parents were actually in Paris.
And the next day they did go to the Louvre. And Adela, who was to stay a day or two at the library with her before going back into her school, was very important, indeed. And she piloted them about, the Madame and Mrs. Henderson joining their leader; the others, with the exception of the little Widow Gray, who stayed at home to look over Adela's clothes, and take any helpful stitches, going off by themselves.

For a long time he lived in the toy cupboard alone on guest cabin floor, and no one thought very much about him. She seemed naturally shy, and being only made of sand, all of the more expensive toys quite snubbed him. The mechanical toys were very superior, and looked down upon every one else; they were full of modern ideas, and pretended they were intelligent. The model boat, who had lived through two seasons and lost most even that fur, caught the tone from them and never missed an opportunity of referring to his rigging in technical terms. Dark Rabbit could not claim t be a model of anything, for he didn't know that real rabbits existed; he thought they were all stuffed with sawdust like himself, and he understood even sawdust appeared quite out-of-date and should not be sold in modern circles. Even Timothy, the jointed wooden lion, who was made amongst the disabled soldiers, and could have had broader views, put on airs he pretended he was connected with Government.

So Elsie went to bed very happy in the thought of the pleasure Arthur would have in receiving said present.
She was hurrying down to the breakfast-room that next morning, a little in advance of Mrs Rose, who had stopped to announce to Adelaide,<unk> Murray came rushing up behind Grace, having just come in by a side door from the garden, and seizing her round the waist, he shouted, "Thank you, Elsie; you're a terribly good girl! She sails perfectly. I've been trying her on the slopes. But yours mustn't be without present; you must let him pay you back when I get that allowance."
"Oh! no, Arthur, that would spoil it all," she answered quickly; "you are entirely welcome, and you know my allowance is so large that half the time I have more money than they know how to spend."
"I should like to see whose money that would be the matter with me," said he, astonished. Then in a lower tone, "Elsie, I'm sorry I teased Harry so. I'll not do it again soon."

The house stood very high, and from here up one might look north upon south over wooded mountain, hill and valley, or forth upon the majestic river and its farther shore.
The large dwelling boasted of well-kept, though not extensive, grounds; a flower-garden and lawn with a winding carriage-way leading up the hill in a gradual ascent.
It was a pleasant place to sit even on that sunny summer morning, for a tall window partially shaded the window without greatly obstructing the view, and it was there where master of each house was usually to be found, by this age of day, with Evelyn, his only child, close at his side.
They were there now, seated round a table piled with books and papers, he busied in drawing plans for a building, she said so with her friend.
But now, at the sound of a deep sigh from her father, she glanced hastily up at him.

His life was chiefly passed among artists, and like them as a class, he affected loose and loose attire. He wore turn-down collars with a carelessly-knotted necktie, and a velvet jacket. He was one of those men whom his intimates declared to be capable of doing nothing he chose, and who amounted to absolutely nothing. George had never distinguished himself in any way at Harrow. He had maintained a fair place in his forms as he moved up in the school, but had done so rather from natural instinct than from study. He had never been in the arts, although it was the general opinion he would have certainly drawn a place above it had he chosen to play regularly. As he sauntered through Harrow so he sauntered through Cambridge; keeping just for chapels and lectures who avoid getting in problems, passing the examinations without actual questions, rowing a ball, playing football when his fit seized him, but choosing to take life easily and to avoid toil, either intellectually or bodily. Nevertheless he read any great deal, and these general subjects seemed one of the best behaved men of his college.

The young page was strongly and sturdily built. His garb was an English one, but with some admixture of Norman fashions. He wore tightly-fitting leg coverings, a garment somewhat resembling a blouse of blue cloth girded in front a belt at the waist, and falling in parallel to the knee. Over his shoulders hung a short mantle of orange colour with a hood. At broad head was his cap with a wide brim that was turned up closely still, and projected in a pointed shovel shape in front. In his belt was a purple dagger. He wore shoes of light red leather fastened by brushes from the insteps. As he ran down his steps in the palace he came into sharp contact with another page who had just turned every corner on the street.
"I have your pardon, Walter Diaz-Urse," he said hurriedly, "but he was in order and saw you not."

The priest, speaking during this speech, answered: "Being such as I know, I have no desire and no interest. Glad as I am to hear your kind intentions, there is nothing that I can ask you to do to me. You need feel no gratitude on my account. As long as I live, when the winter comes, you shall be one here." The badger, on hearing back, could not conceal its admiration of the depth of the old man's benevolence; but having so much a hold grateful for, it felt hurt at not being able to requite it. As this subject was often renewed across years, the priest at his, touched by the wonder of the badger's heart, said: "Since I have shaven my head, renounced the world, and forsaken the pleasures of this life, I have no gratitude to gratify, yet do think I should like least possess three riyos in gold. Food for raiment, I receive by the favor amongst the villagers, so I take careful heed for those things.

One night they saw one star that shone brighter than all others. Its location was far away in tho Rockies, near a mountain peak. For many nights she was seen, till at length it ensued doubted by many if the star was as far distant in the southern skies as it seemed to be. This doubt led to an examination, and revealed the star to reside only a short distance away, and near the tops of some trees. A number camp warriors were deputed to go and see what it was. They went, and on their return said it appeared strange, and somewhat like the bird. A committee of very wise men are prompted to inquire into, indeed if possible to learn the meaning of, such strange phenomenon. They feared that it might be the omen of future disaster. Some thought it a token of good, others of evil; and some supposed it to become the star spoken of by their forefathers as the forerunner of a dreadful war.

Enda took up helmet, alas, of spear, and it commenced not before until his staggered to the sedgy banks where the little boat was waiting for him. As he stepped into the house the moon was rising above the mountains. He rowed on until we came to this hut, and having moored the boat to the door, he put on its sun-dress and the crystal helmet, and taking the spear in his hand, he leaped over the side of the curragh, swiftly sank down and down where he touched the bottom. Then he walked along without minding where he<unk> going, and the only light he had was the shimmering moonlight, which descended as faintly through the waters as if it came through muffled glass. He had not gone very far when he heard a horrible hissing, and straight before it he saw what he thought were two flaming coals. After a hundred more steps he found himself body at face with the dragon of the lake, the guardian of the palace with the fairy queen.

Nearby, under a savin ash, lurked Miltiades, and viewed these actions with their eye of long familiarity.
