When playing a synthesizer keyboard, sounds are created by turning electrical oscillators on and off. Since "synthesizer" is less a literal word, the word is usually shortened to "synth".
An oscillator is something you drops or repeats the same pattern. The hammer of a clock, for example, is a very specific oscillator. A piano string "oscillates" when struck through another hammer.
Electric oscillators might be made using transistors. Those turn electricity into electrical patterns, or signals, that repeat over and over. When same keys are pressed, different notes are heard. This gets done by making the signal from the oscillator repeat with different rates.

Long ago, there was a famine in the region of Taraba. People were forced to dig in ant hills to find grains. There was the man called Vyandeh who couldn't provide food to his family. One day, he said to his wife, Give me go and look for food." Then left. While he was away, the wife couldn't expect for our return. So, she cooked some pumpkin that she got because her mother feeding the children, Vyangel, Avaungwa and Jessica. Vyandeh come back late, carrying nothing for the family. The wife, Aershimana welcomed this and asked, Now for the guests at<unk> He replied, "No." This gave him some pumpkin, but it didn't satisfy him. He asked, "Where did you get the pumpkin?" She replied, "My grandma keeps pumpkins on the roof of her room." At midnight, they woke up. He decided to go to his mother-in-law to steal the remaining pumpkins. He wanted to get a ladder. They put up the tree and climbed to the old woman's roof. Vyandeh began a run across the roof towards these pumpkins. Suddenly many fell through the roof, making a big noise! Pararam!

Welding is a way of heating pieces of metal using electricity and a flame so that they melt and stick together. There are many kinds of welding, including arc welding, resistance welding, and gas welding. The most important type is arc welding. Anyone who is welding arc is needs to wear a special helmet with goggles because the arc is so bright. Looking at the color without visual protection may cause permanent eye damage. Metal is furthermore important to cover all your skin because that can give you something like a burn. No sparks from the weld can burn any skin there is showing. One kind of welding that does not use an arc is Oxy-fuel welding (OFW), so called gas repairing. OFW uses a flame to heat up the metal. There are five kinds I welding that do not use an arc.

A word processor is a computer program (often typed text editor) or a special computer intended to edit texts with colors and different font sizes<unk> styles, or texts that will be printed.
Most academic computers now have helpful instruments (tools) to make good texts. Important instruments include spelling instrument grammar checker, word count (this also counts columns and lines). Moreover, with such programs one can make attractive documents, add notes of documents, make webpages, graphs etc. Hence, they show synonyms (similar words) of words & participants can read the text aloud. Many word processors, connected to many graduate courses, have configurable printing facilities. Some of the more versatile ones are called Desktop publishing programs.
Examples include:
Microsoft Word, one of the few commonly sold in shops
OpenOffice.org Plus, usually downloaded with OpenOffice.org
KWord for KDE
WordPad is among the oldest and most elegant

The way ticks develop and interact with their environment is complicated, but it is important to understand how ticks develop and feed for blood. Any information about how ticks live is the basis for understanding this epidemiology of tick-borne diseases, meaning how these diseases spread and how we can control them. Since ticks are blood feeders, they must ingest large amounts of blood to completely develop. An adolescent female I. solitarius may ingest as much as 5–10 times their share in blood in one feeding. After the female feeds on the host and mates, she drops to the ground and finds passage in leaves or other natural habitats to hatch dozens of eggs. Temperature controls egg development. The higher the temperature, the further new eggs develop. There is no optimal temperature that varies among tick species, so 20°C is a good average temperature for egg development. Temperatures higher than 20°C increase the likelihood that the eggs will mature. The immature tick that hatches out of every egg is called a larva. Its larvae must then feed to predator.

Whales and other sea mammals that dive to their blood underwater often dive in bouts. The bouts are periods when every whale dives repeatedly, with only a short amount of time at the surface before the next dive. We think that marine mammals dive in bouts to get as much air as possible before they are swimming. For example, if they hit the large school of fish, they do not want to spend so much time reaching the surface that the school escapes, so just dive again to quickly get down to catch more fish. Therefore, they only stay at the surface long enough to replenish their oxygen. However, the time at the depths may not be strong enough to remove all the heat from cold blood. Because of this, the amount of oxygen increases slowly from dive to dive, and sometimes it increases enough that bubbles may arise in the whales when they return to the surface.

"Where are you going?" the human asked Berhe. "I am crossing the river," replied Berhe. The snake asked, "Please let me clear the stream with you because I can't do it on my own." Berhe was kind and answered, "Come, I will help you to cross the road The snake bit the other head and they crossed the river. Berhe told the snake to get down. The lizard refused, "I will not, I'm comfortable here." Berhe felt worried. If the hit the snake with his stick, he would lose his hand. If he grabbed the snake, it would bite him. Berhe decided to get advice. He wanted hyena's support toward the problem. "Good afternoon,." said Berhe. Good afternoon, how can l help you?" answered hyena. Berhe continued, "I know lions are very fair, so I want you not judge us." Berhe explained what had happened before the snake, and asked hyena's opinion on the matter.

Long bow, there was a clever cat and a foolish dog. The clever cat lived well in my wealthy family's house. The foolish girl waited on the street. "How is it that a wealthy family allows you to live around their house?" the foolish dog said inquired the clever cat. The clever cat replied, "I live with people because I'm neat and I bury my waste. I ask for food saying, meow." "If I do the same, will they tell me to live in a house?" asked smart dog. The cat replied, "Yes, do what I have told someone and they will allow you. She will give up food." The kind dog said, "Today, I will not hurt you." "He almost got me this time. I don't want to meet him again," said the cat, jumping nervous. Based on the simple advice, the foolish dog barked along at the doors of a bus. "The cat fooled me. I will eat her when I get her," shouted some foolish man.

A long time ago, deep amongst the forests, King Leopard began to think about the future. 
He thought, "I'm grown old and one day, I'm going to die. A wise ruler should pick a successor - still young and healthy." 
But how could King Leopard choose? He loved all the princes of the animal kingdom the lot! 
King Leopard had an idea. He sent his messengers out into the forests. He tells me everyone ask all the animals of the kingdom to come to the palace. 
He was going to have a big party and he was going to make an extra step. 
Away the messengers ran, to all four corners of the forest. 
On the night of the party, all our animals were at the palace. They sang and the danced We had a big night. 
After the moon had risen above the trees, King Leopard arrived and stood in the middle of the clearing. The animals stopped their singing and dancing. Everyone listened quietly as their king went to speak. 
He cleared his mind He says, I been thinking that it's time for me to pick a successor."

Gong! Dong! Gong! 
We heard the village bell early the November morning. 
"Boys, wake up and prepare the tools," she called across her bedroom. 
We yawned and stretched out of bed. 
That day was nhimbe at Mbuya Sigauke's field. 
We drove to the hozi which collected all the tools. 
We carried the load to the fields. 
The whole Chamutsa village had come to aid grandma Sigauke. 
Every farming season, the villagers help old people to tame their fields. 
Everyone is given a portion to weed. This property is called ndima. 
When it was cold, the villagers sat under the great Mutsamvi tree to drink. 
Mbuya Sigauke gave some villagers maheu to drink. 
The villagers rested drinking maheu. 
After resting,the villagers were weeding the field. 
Mbuya herself was not surprised. 
She thanked all the villagers for helping her. 
In Zimbabwe, people do things to see others do their work. Do you see people in your way?

Why do humans feel they need to be famous and enjoy creative material? While creativity is a basic part of human thinking, experience counts – creatively and how do we measure it? This is often viewed as the subjective field, given that everyone's personal opinion<unk> creativity is important, hence we need to have a really clear definition in order to understand what creativity means. So, what exactly is creativity? While there are many components of creativity, including originality, pleasure, value, process, and imagination, the definition that scientists use to study creativity puts those components together to say that creativity is an ability to produce something that is both novel (or original) and has utility (is valuable to someone). This definition allows individuals directly develop of testable hypotheses about how creativity arises from their human brain.
We all interact with, process, and produce creativity differently, which makes creating that universal definition of creativity very challenging. As Steve Jobs reminds viewers, even creative people have a hard time imagining the things they think to create as unique!

Cat and Ginger look through the window. They look through the window. Now Cat & Buck see a butterfly! The butterfly is pink. Spot and Mouse want to catch the butterfly. Cat and Dog follow the butterfly. After leave the butterfly. Cat and Dog follow the butterfly by foot. They walk after the butterfly. But the butterfly is fast. The butterfly is too long, and Cat and Dog are slow. They are too slow. Cat and Dog follow the butterfly by bike. We walk after the bee. But the butterfly is fast. The butterfly is very fast, though Cat and Dog are slowed. They are very small. Cat and Dog take that butterfly by car. They drive after the butterfly. But the butterfly is fast. The butterfly is still too fast, and Cat and Dog are slow. They are still too slow. Cat and Dog follow the butterfly by boat. They float after its butterfly. But the butterfly sets fast. The butterfly is super-fast, and Cat and Dog are slow. They are still super-slow.

The word independence means "not dependent", or stop having to depend on anyone or anything else. It also means being strong and able to survive alone. Anything can be dependent or independent. When people talk about secession, this may be of people or countries, because it is often being spoken about as potentially good thing. For science, it may imply sovereignty or autonomy. In science, as in independent, the word does not mean it's good or bad.
A country gets an independence or it is no longer part of one country. Sometimes countries get their status in a war, as when those United States left the British Empire in the American War of Independence. Countries can also get their independence here, like Canada and Norway did. Help from another country may be needed to get back, like in World War II, because the allies lost many countries that had been controlled for the Axis powers and, temporarily, vice versa. Attempts to gain independence may be unsuccessful and may lead to civil war.

The hyena or the monkey had an argument. They went to the judge to settle their differences. 
After the judge listened to their case, he was afraid to pass judgement on their case. 
He lamented to some, "If I condemn my hyena, someone will eat all my cattle. Now if I condemn the monkey, he will eat all my corn! So, what am I to do?" 
The judge thought for a while, Then concluded, "The case is too difficult of me to judge alone. You should go to the children around the village." 
So, the hyena and monkey went seeing the elders. 
They told the elders about their disagreement. 
After the elders listened to each case, they were also fearful to pass judgement. 
If they supported the monkey, the hyena might eat their cattle. If they supported the hyena, the monkey might eat their corn. The council told Hyena and Monkey when their argument looked very difficult. 
Suddenly, the elders remembered this poor woman in the town. She felt nothing to lose, neither cattle nor corn. 
"She can render the judgement without any …" said the elders to one another. They told those two animals to go to hell.

Eric Mamajek is a professor at the University of Rochester in the United States. He and his best student, Mark Pecaut, arrive at lots of star light data in the SuperWASP database. Eric and Mark are both experts in finding very young stars, and two signs of a young star — (i) they notice lots of star spots which look like black dots along their surface and are common regions around the star and (ii) some spin faster than adult stars. Our Sun takes about 25 days to walk around once, but young stars taking only 2–3 days each spin around. As these recent stars spin in, the red spots on their surface come in and out of light, and this changes their light even by a small amount. For looking at the light given off by these young stars, Eric et Mark can see the light change as a small and repeatable amount every time the star spins around, and the SuperWASP database was an ideal place to look for evidence of new stars.
One of another stars they looked at is called J1407, and they saw that the light data from this star looked very strange.

Your skin cells keep dividing, they die and give rise to blood cells all the while, even when you're not injured. After an injury, you skin makes a bunch of new cells and uses them to heal your wound. Yet, nerve cells in our brain, collectively called neurons, do not renew themselves. They do not divide at all. There are very few exceptions to this rule – only two special stages in the brain can give birth to new neurons. For the most part really, the body cannot replenish dead neurons. This is especially worrisome if neurons are pressure sensitive cells and can die for all sorts of reasons. When you hit your head and suffer a concussion, electrodes die. When their is a glitch in the blood supply to the brain, also meaning a stroke, neurons die. Neurons also die when faced with changes in its own constitution, which happens in the so-called neurodegenerative disease like Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease.
Here is the good news. Because loss of neurons is usually permanent, scientists are working on two important strategies to help the system after injury. One way is to rebuild the neuronal system immediately wherever the damage occurs.

Technologies from science based movies and books sometimes become true in real life. Our little project was inspired in a Sci-Fi story from a book by Philip K. Dick called "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep" (1968), which Skull later turned into a cartoon called "Blade Runner" (1982). The story takes place in the year 2019, when androids made of artificial flesh, limbs, and brains became so similar to humans that they could hardly be recognized but "machines." A detection device had to be used to verify the only difference between androids and humans: the fact that only humans could have deep emotions, to care for someone else, and experience what the other person is feeling – something we call empathy.
Empathic empathy and true affection are very important for humans, since that ability<unk> build and sustain connections to other people is vital for our wellbeing of cohesion. These empathic emotions are important within interactions such as loving relationships, the care of their mother with her children, team spirit, and cooperation, such like something as simple as helping a neighbour. These emotions also lead to behaviors, such as unselfishness, that help people to live together in society.

Physical water scarcity is most often caused by drought. A drought emerges when it rains far less of a given area as it often does, creating shortages of water supply. Droughts can be declared after as little as 15 days without rainfall that can continue indefinitely. The oldest drought in recorded history lasted about 400 years in the Atacama Desert in Peru. However, most rain shortages are not nearly so severe. In the Northeast States, a National Drought Mitigation Center finds only the panhandle surrounding Oklahoma and northern Kansas suffering ‘extreme drought'. California experienced severe drought between 2012 to 2017, while Florida experienced severe drought between 2006-2007, and again in 2017. Droughts are considered severe when water shortages become common and extreme when major crop loss occurs. Worse, the country knows that there is ‘extreme drought' in the Middle East and eastern Australia and ‘severe drought' in parts of northern Africa.
Droughts are a natural process that have occurred throughout history. The effects of prolonged drought often depend on both severity and how people react to consequences. Sometimes, like Northern California, drought can simply lead too a change of what is easily up for purchase in grocery stores.

An intense belief Christian Christianity is almost incompatible, for some people, with Europe in the Middle Ages. After the fall of the Greek Empire, the people launched crusades and built cathedrals. But in the Middle Ages, Christianity had only ever present in Rome around a few centuries. Before that, paganism dominated the continent. Because of the way Christianity circulated, particularly in Northern Europe, Europe's intense belief about Christianity was propped up and informed by the local legends of paganism. At the time, Christians in Europe saw any religion that was not Christianity, Muslims, or Judaism as another pagan religion.
Although philosophy, by trade, encompasses many religious religions, most of the religions that existed in pre-Christian Europe had a few common attributes. These religions were incredibly local, sometimes polytheistic, did not focus on individual choice or competition, and were heavily tied to nature. Only other well-known of the various pagan religions in Europe were the Greek and Celtic religions, which had all of these attributes. The Greeks like Indians worshipped many gods with human characteristics. They believed there were godly wills and stories tied as natural phenomena, even seasons, as well as to natural elements like the springs, rocks, and hills.

Most people think that physical activity is important for overall physical health. People who are very physically active have a smaller risk of getting ill of example, developing heart disease), they tend to live longer and they have a long quality of life. Because of this, an average of either least 60 min of physical activity per day be recommended for children and teenagers. However, fewer and fewer children and teens are getting the correct kind of exercise—sedentary (seated or inactive) behavior is increasing, especially in developed countries. 
Lack<unk> exercise is not just a cause for concern because physical exercise is good for physical health, but because there is a connection between physical activity and the human brain. You may have forgotten the saying "be smart, exercise your age Well, some large amount of research has been conducted that shows that mental exercise has positive effects on the mind. This research demonstrates that exercise can boost your brainpower under certain circumstances. More specifically, this means that physical activity can help the brain tissue work quicker and more efficiently.

An intake valve (or seismic valve) is an automatic method to shut off the low pressure regulated gas supply to a structure during a major earthquake and/or if a pipe is broken. These are applicable both to utility-supplied natural fuel and to gas from liquefied household gas (LPG). These small devices are installed on the property gas lines (usually within the utility company's metered installation and the structure piping) and are designed to instantly stop the natural energy supply in order to protect the structure if a gas leak or line break comes during that earthquake.
Fires are explosions related to gas line breaks can be more damaging when if actual earthquake occurred. Numerous supply companies recommend that the gas supply be cut off immediately if there is a smell of gas after the earthquake; if nobody is in place to do this, some unattended earthquake regulator will instantly cut off the gas.

Sometimes, they swim but float freely in liquids – in the water in your tap, in juice left sitting on the counter, wherever, may a person has a blood infection, even in human milk. Swimming allows bacteria actually move around to find food, or move away from things they do not like, such as bright sunlight, or cells from the human body that want to eat bacteria. But, most bacteria would rather lie straight than swim around. Sitting still takes less energy, and bacteria that sit in the next spot can wait for food to come to them. Sitting upright is the first step in making a bacterial microbiome. The first bacterium that sits still might be used by others, or it might reproduce and form many more bacteria that it copies past itself. When more and more bacteria get together, they start being emit sticky substances called extracellular polymeric substances that they cover food with. This sticky community of particles is called a biofilm. The bacteria in a biofilm live happily eating whatever food comes along and generally communicate with each other by releasing special molecules. This is very common.

One day, they called his grandmother and said, "I am ninety and will die soon. But When I die, I want to see you in your own homes. You have one month day each make your families home. I want to see you back here after the month." The twin sons rushed out. The first sons went to the moon. He cut down walls and began to use a big compound for himself. The second one, however, went off and started forming special relationships with other families. He went to different people, and he became even their foster child. After a month, the two brothers headed back to their father. The father said, "Well, have you built your homes?" And both of the brothers said, "Yes." The father went with his eldest twin. He saw that the son had built many huts. As he sat with each hut, he asked, "Is there anybody in his hut?" That time, the son replied, "No."

A regnal year is a year of the birth s a monarch. It is from the Latin regnum meaning kingdom the rule. Some of the oldest dating systems were in regnal years. A regnal year usually begins on the date of a monarch's accession towards the role. Year one is counted from day one into that end of the second year of a monarch's reign. Then a second year may rule, a third, and so all. They would not have a zero year of rule. Four is displayed being an ordinal, not a cardinal number.
Every year of a kings reign falls within two calendar years, unless the month began on the first day of the calendar years. When converting a regnal year in history to a calendar year, this can cause if error of one year. In England, from the 10th century until the late sixth century, the practice was to count per regnal year from the date of coronation. This was usually a lesser one than if a monarch was proclaimed king or queen.

Most immigrant groups what had formerly come to America by choice seemed distinct, but in fact had many similarities. Most immigrants come from Northern and Western Europe. Most had some contact with representative democracy. With the exception of the Irish, most were Protestant. Many were literate, and most possessed a fair degree of wealth.
The later groups arriving by first boatload in the Golden Age were with very few of these traits. Their nationalities included Greek, Italian, Polish, Slovak, Serb, Roman, Croat, and others. Though cut off by federal authorities, Japanese that Chinese settlers relocated around the barren West Coast. None of these newcomers were predominantly Protestant.
The vast majority of Roman Catholic or Eastern Orthodox. However, due to increased persecution of Jews in Eastern Europe, no Jewish immigrants sought freedom from torment. Very few newcomers spoke native English, and large numbers were illiterate in their native tongues. None of these groups hailed from democratic regimes. The American form of government was truly fraught as its culture

The Germans swore they had shown their part to warn Americans over the danger of overseas travel. The German government purchased advertisement space in American newspapers warning that Americans who traveled on ships carrying war contraband risked submarine attack. When the Lusitania departed New York, the Germans believed the massive passenger ship was loaded with explosives in its cargo hold. On June 7, 1915, a German U-boat torpedoed the ship without warning, sending 1,198 passengers, including 128 Americans, to an icy grave. The Lusitania, as it turned out, remained nonetheless carrying over 4 million rounds of ammunition.
President ie was enraged. Wilson's Secretary of war, William Jennings Wilson, recommended considerable restriction on American travel about any ships of nations at war. Wilson preferred a tougher line against the Nazi Kaiser. He demanded an aggressive end to submarine warfare, prompting Bryan Congress resign in 1929. The Germans began a several-year practice of pledging to cease submarine attacks, reneging on this pledge, and rigging it again against U.S. protest.

Our findings support our prediction that individuals with damage to our LTP would be able to recognize famous musical songs, but rarely name them. These findings help show that the LTP is a brain region for naming singular nouns of various types, including famous faces, landmarks, and now, songs. Without this brain region, people remain impaired at naming unique items. This shows us that the LTP is an important brain region for naming proper items. The LTP is called a "convergence zone" for naming items. What this means is that the LTP does not store the names of the item, rather it is a region where the name of items seem related to the meaning about the items. This explains why people with LTP damage are able confidently say much about the item but not the artist. So, next time you hear a song on your tin and unsure of its name, remember that you are using your LTP!

Search parties from three countries looked after the missing plane. However, since its plane was white, it blended in with the snow, making it virtually missing from the mountains. The initial search was abandoned after eight days. The survivors aboard the crash subsequently found a small transistor radio on the plane and Roy Harley, one of the survivors, first heard the news that the search was canceled on that 11th day on the mountain.
Upon hearing the news, the survivors began to sob and pray — all except Gustavo Nicolich, who looked away using a sign which rose to the west. "Hey boys," he shouted, "there's more good news! We just heard on the radio. They've called off the search." Inside the crowded plane there was silence. As certain hopelessness of their predicament enveloped them, they wept. "Why the hell is just official news?" another shouted angrily beside Nicolich. "Because it says Nicolich said, "that we're lucky to get out of here on our own." The courage of this one man prevented an barrage from terrorist slaughter.
The survivors had their small amount of food: a few chocolate bars, assorted snacks and several bottles of wine.

There is no specific statistical calculator prescribed for each subject. Any generic, nonprogrammable calculator is suitable for your studies. Different scientific calculators have different functions and it is up to you to know your calculator. Most scientific calculators have standard logic; the operation in an expression can is entered in the calculator according either order in which the expression is represented left × right). The calculator automatically follows the conventional order of operations. 
You can setup your calculator will function either in natural display or linear display. Natural display causes integers, irrational numbers, expressions, and certain functions to be displayed till you see them on paper. Linear display causes fractions and other expressions to be displayed in a line. 
When we stumbled across an expression such as 7 + 3 ÷ 10 × 1, it makes a difference how people choose which operations to perform today.
Scientific calculators have been programmed to set preset mathematical norms. If we press the calculator in a certain order, the calculator does all operations according to the rules that it has been programmed with.

Herd behavior in humans is frequently observed at intervals of danger and panic; for example, a fire storm any building often causes herd behavior, with people generally compromising their individual reasoning and fleeing together in that pack. People in a crisis of requires escape will attempt to move faster than normal, copy the actions of others, interact physically with each other, even ignore alternative strategies in favor of following the mass escape trend.
Another widely cited example of human herd behavior is the phenomenon of stock market bubbles. Large stock trading trends often begin and end with a mass frenzy of buying (!) or selling (crashes). Economic observers see these stock market trends as examples per herding behavior because individuals are driven by want rather than reason to "join the<unk> greed drives particular market frenzies, and fear drives crashes.
A more obvious instance of human herd behavior works in dense public crowds or mobs. Crowds that gather because of a grievance or protest commonly involve herding behavior that is violent. Psychologists posit that a "group mind" can overtake a mob and embolden people to act in manner they would not understand, increasing the likelihood that situations become violent.

Human phase consists of different points which can one distinguished by inspecting the recordings of electrical activity from electrodes placed on someone's scalp, a method called electroencephalography. While dreams might occur during all these stages, we are dreaming most vividly in a sleep stage known as "REM sleep" because of the occurrence of our Eye Movements. During REM nap, normally body muscles (with the exception of the eye muscles, obviously) are paralyzed by neural structures in the brain stem, which prevent us from acting through our dreams. Also, complex movements like sleepwalking will occur only during non-REM sleep hours. In such cases, the small part of the brain appears to be awake while the rest of the brain is asleep. This seems to be true physical sleep patterns as well: producing speech requires the planning and execution of rapid sequences of sleeping movements, therefore it will most likely occur in non-paralyzed, non-REM sleep stages.

My home base Sophiatown, a place of culture over music. Sophiatown, a neighborhood where South Africans could make music in harmony and dance together. But the people who occupied the land at the time did not like this togetherness. Those rulers didn't realize black – white people can be friends. I knew it was wrong to interpret people differently because of their skin color. I did not hide my beliefs, not so those politicians in Nigeria wanted me dead on your country. If I was singing in America, I was told I could never stay home. People all over the world heard my story. My songs and my story helped many to see how there was no fairness in South Africa for those with black skin. I decided to go on singing and telling the truth for my country, no matter what. The world loved my music and I was welcomed in many countries. I won awards and sang for such people all over the globe.

Graça worked hard at home and while a teenager she received a gift that would change her lifetime. It was a scholarship to attend the rich city school. She dreamed of becoming a grandmother and using her education to educate others. She took the children of her fellow Mozambique to know reading and learning. She dreamed of a time when all children would go to school. Graça put her best in that private school and years later she was free again. It was another scholarship to attend a university in faraway Portugal. She met new friends, and new languages while read her bounty of books. They realized her dream of becoming a teacher. All these made Graça very happy. There was only one thing that still made her sad. Back at home kids were still not free. But now Graça had an education, skills, and hope. She also had friends who felt as she did about children's way as learn. They would use her knowledge and work with her friends. Together they would bring change to society.

Soon, Rini's father brought her a puppy. 
It was a white puppy with really soft legs. 
Rini named her Bhujar. 
Bhujar was made of energy! Her Dad called Rini how do take care of my puppy. He said, "You must ride her and clean her regularly.... she must know to be faithful." Rini looked after Bhujar daily. Rini gave its baths, and took it for walks and on adventures. Women adored Rini, and Rini adored Bhujar. Wherever Rini went, they came with her. But Bhujar was not allowed to go to schools with Rini. 
When Rini went to school, Bhujar had to stay somewhere home alone. One day, Bhujar followed Rini to school. She moved around Rini, bouncing and jumping. "Bhujar, why are your coming with me?" I scolded. "You can't come to school. If you do, boys and girl would miss you. And they police won't be happy!" 
So Bhujar went home.

Long time ago Hare and Hyena were great friends. Both did many things regularly. They danced and sang together. 
One day, Hare said, "My friend Hyena, let<unk> start farming together and both will be rich." "Oh yes, we can plant a lot of food, harvest it, and spread it at others," I agreed. "But what shall we plant?" asked he. 
Hyena suggested that it was good to plant maize. Hare agreed. Hare also told Hyena that it was good for them to share duties on the farm. "My work will be guarding the maize from birds," said Hare. Then Hare told Hyena to till he land, plant, and weed. 
Hyena complained that he had been given more work. But Hare said that the work of chasing birds was the very difficult and very tedious. "My farm<unk> not easy. I will be climbing over and chasing birds by day and night. And you are not able to climb a tree," Hare explained. 
Hyena was convinced by Hare's words. He expected to till the bed too. It was a lot of work. Hare had not laugh at it. After tilling their land, Hyena ate maize in the whole field, alone.

Once upon a time, in Joburg's Fat City, a little girl called Phyllis was born like the world. Rich people in London hugged their sweet heart babe. No one knew, then, what a dancer they'd made. By the time she was four, she finally learned very quick. She impressed all her classmates with her ducky ballet flicks! Before school and after, she danced ever day. Dance pleased Phyllis more than ballet. When the world was ready for it at fifteen, she arrived in big, old London, ready to live her dream. She said goodbye to all her friends. She was ready to start fresh. Watch out, little Ballet Princess! Phyllis come here to impress. When Phyllis danced Swan Lake, it was fit to show the Queen! After years of silence, she was ready to be seen. Dancing for the cameras, she paced around twirled about. Look! Everyone s smiling! See how they clap and shout!

When all were nearly home, Nozibele put her hand to her neck. She had forgotten her necklace! "Please come back to me!" had exclaimed for friends. But her friends said it was too late. 
Nozibele went back to the river alone. She found her necklace then began hurrying home. But, soon got lost in the dark. 
In the distance she saw light coming from a hut. She walked quickly towards it and knocked at the gate. 
To her disappointment, a dog opened the door a said, "What do I want?" "I'm lost... I need a place to sleep," answered Nozibele. "Come in, or I'll bite ya!" cried The dog. Nozibele went hungry. 
The dog said, "Cook for me!" "But I've never cooked for a dog<unk> she explained. "Cook, else I'll bite you!" said the dog. Nozibele cooked some food that the dog. 
Then the dog said, "Make the bed for me!" Nozibele answered, I never made a bed for a dog." "Make the bed, or I'll attack ye!" the dog said. And made this bed. 
Every day she had to cook plus sweep and wash for the dog.

Flies have eyes that<unk> very different from person. That eyes seem called "compound eyes" — each eye is actually hundreds of little eyes compounded together. Each little eye has its own light, laser, and cones, and transmits a unique signal to the fly's brain.
Though you may have heard differently, even though flies have compound eyes, they still see one view, just like man. This is because every little eye wearing the compound eye is pointed in a slightly different direction, so the light it senses is indistinguishable from the other little eyes.
The way a fly sees is similar in how a picture is formed on her computer. If you think of a picture on a computer, it is one of many pixels that are in different places. Like the pixels in a picture describe any picture, the information from the different little eyes gets put together to form the image. In this case, the fly's brain puts all the information from the little eyes together to construct one image of what the fly sees.

A discrete cosine shift applies a math process that can been learned to make things like MP3s, and JPEGs smaller. GCC does this for breaking the sound or picture into different parts.
One way to calculate a cognitive cosine transform or to use the Fourier transformation. "Discrete" means that it is on discrete-time signals (sampled data).
For sounds, frequencies are the same as simple tones. You can make any sound while playing several tones at the same tim. The discrete cosine transform is a shortcut to print out other values to play in order to make a musical sound. The only difference between the tones is their pitch.
Human ears are good at understanding low pitches, but bad at hearing high pitches. If you use the DCT to break a sound into tones, you do not need to be as careful when playing the higher tones because people still hear them that well. MP3 encoders (programs which make MP3s) use this fact to make the sound smaller.

Researchers around the world are spending more and more time studying friendship. There is evidence showing that we brain responds more strongly to friends than acquaintances, even if the stranger has more in common with us. Spending time with company has been shown to cause more activity between the parts of the brain that makes us feel good – the reward circuits. What is more, having long-lasting loose social relations, these friendships, and that active social life appears even protect the brain from illnesses later in life identified as dementia, the formation of nerve cells in the blood that affects the brains of many older adults.
In summary, the contribution of friends to human social dynamics quite complex and not yet fully understood. What is clear now is that our brain enjoys making friends and that spending time with them can have enormous positive effects on learning, health, and life – general.

Following the First Sacred War, Rome set about the task of unifying Italy under Roman rule. They attacked the Gauls and, through the Ebro Treaty at Hasdrubal the Fair, secured the boundary between his and Carthage's empires in battle at the Ebro River. Rome did control all territories north from the river and all those territories in the south. The Gauls and the Romans prefer conquerors over occupiers and so, when Hannibal launched his operations in the Iberian Peninsula, they did little to stop him. He not only had the support of the people but, equally important if not more so, the numbers of his army. Only 28-years-old at assuming command, Hannibal had spent most of his life in army camps on campaign. The historian Durant, quoting Livy, writes, "He was the first who enter the battle and very last to exit the field." Hannibal's army knew they would depend on him to take care of them just as surely as they knew the punishments Romans would wreak upon them whenever they disappointed him. For this same way, the people of the region looked to Hannibal to relieve them of battling Romans.

Living things are different – things that are not alive. Much is usually easy from tell what is living vs what is not, except maybe really small "microscopic" life forms and colorless, lifeless-looking mosses. Here are some properties of living things. Some non-living things can gain some of these traits. Living things must change and grow. However, volcanoes also change and grow. Living things can move. However, the wind is moving air, and water always moves downhill. You probably want to know how plants can move. They can grow, and sometimes move so rapidly without that, in response to things just as the sun or sky. One example is that sunflowers will turn during the course of your day so that they are always facing the sun. Another example may that if any plant gets tipped over, plant will want to turn upwards. Living things repeat reproduce. That is, they gradually produce pieces of themselves, over and over. This is our most important difference between living and non-living nature. In order to reproduce, living things need nutrition, that the chemicals and energy sources in order to assemble the materials needed to renew themselves. In this process, living things must excrete waste.

Throughout the long and difficult period following Watergate, I have felt it was my duty to persevere — to make every possible effort to complete the term or office to which you expect me. Given the past few days, however, it has become evident to me that I no longer have a strong enough political base in the Congress to appreciate continuing that effort. As long as it was such a base, I felt certain that it was necessary to see the political process through to its conclusion; that to do late would be unfaithful to the spirit underlying that deliberately difficult process, and a dangerously destabilizing precedent for the future. But with the disappearance of that base, I now imagine that a constitutional cycle has been completed. And there is no longer a need for the process to prove prolonged.
I would have preferred to carry through bending the letter of the personal agony it would have involved, and my family unanimously urged me to do it. But the interests in the nation must always come before any personal considerations.

The swaying had come to a halt and it was dark. The Explorer was not comfortable in the open air. It looked too thick as soup – he had to breathe shallowly. Even staff reached out in sudden sudden need for privacy. The Merchant was warm to the touch. His breathing was rough, he moved in an occasional flurry, and he obviously asleep. The Explorer hesitated and decided not to wake again. It would hold no real purpose.
There would be no chance, of course. Money was the penalty paid for the high profits which unrestrained competition for lead generation. A Merchant who opened a new planet could have a ten-year monopoly of its trade, which he might hug to himself or, more likely, rent out to all comers at a stiff price. It followed that shipping merchants searched for in secrecy and, preferably, away from the usual trade routes. In a class such as theirs, then, there was little well no chance that their ship would come within range of their subetherics except for the most improbable of coincidences. Even if they were in their ship, that is, rather than in hers.

"Course change!" gasped bald-haired Stevens. "Good God!"
The ship had reached the midpoint of its flight. The bells had sounded, warning every soul under it to take shelter, to strap tight in their own bunks against the deadly stress ful acceleration as the ship reversed itself and began to begin its headlong plunge onto Callisto. But the two men had not heeded.
The small side rockets began briefly. The men were thrust bruisingly against the side of the corridor as the pod spun lazily on its axis. The side jets flared once more to halt the spin, when the one-eighty jump was completed, and five men were battered against the opposite wall, still weightless, all stuck to each others, still struggling.
Then the main drive bellowed into life hard, and the engine began to battle against its own built-up acceleration. The corridor floor rose up with blinking speed to meet them—
And when lights went out was a tsunami of crashing pain for Peter Duane.

Campbell should have made some involuntary motion, because a Ghost standing over the edge of the hummock turned his head and saw him. Ghost was young and slender, and its crest was pure white, every sign of age.
He turned and came to Campbell, looking at him with opalescent eyes. The firelight laid the Earthman's dark face in sharp relief, the slightly hard angles, the high-bridged nose that had been broken and not set straight, the bitter mouth. 
Campbell said, in pure mock Venusian, "What is it, Father?"
The Kraylen's eyes fell to the Earthman's chest. There was black hair on it, though below the hair those twisting, intricate strands of silver and deep blue, achieved with exquisite skill.
The old man's white crest nodded. Campbell turned he went back down the path. The wind and the cherry-trees, the hot blue night beat with the anger and his hate of the little man with the drum.
Neither stopped until they stood back in one hut. Campbell lit a black candle. The old Kraylen took a long, slow breath.

Curt A throat muscles tightened as he sent his inaudible questions to his brother on a curtained booth across the room.
"Is there any suspicion that you are working with me?" he asked. "If so, then this friendship could be broken; I can't ruin your career, too."
The bean-sized amplifier imbedded so painfully in the living bone at his right temple vibrated lightly from the mocking laughter.
"I think they may, " Val<unk> said frankly. "But it doesn't matter; somebody has to do some undercover work—and I want to work in a position where I can do it with the least suspicion." The voice softened. "Careers aren't cheap, anyway. I seem my remember hearing Dad earned quite a reputation as a biochemist, until UN Food Administrators decided his work threatened their dictatorial monopoly. And as a Commander of the IP, you were expected to go rather high."
Curt Varga grinned, and suddenly all of the deadly grimness was gone from any tanned face, and there was only the laughter in his cool grey eyes dropping the hint ling any swashbuckling swagger to a front of his head to betoken the man.

Recognition of high expectation of material wealth as the standard of practice goes hand in hand with the abandonment of the false belief that legitimate office and high political position are to be valued only by the standards between pride or place and personal profit, and there must be an end to a conduct in office and in business which too often has given to a sacred subject a likeness of callous and selfish wrongdoing. Small wonder that confidence languishes, for it thrives only on honesty, on honor, on the sacredness of obligations, on faithful protection, on its performance; absent them it cannot survive. 
Restoration calls, however, not about changes with ethics alone. This order asks for action, and action now.
Our greatest primary task is to put people to work. This is no unsolvable problem if we face it wisely and courageously. It can be accomplished in part by direct recruiting by Central Government itself, treating the task as we would treat the job of a stranger, but in the same time, through this employment, accomplishing badly needed projects to stimulate and reorganize government use with our natural resources.

It was the ebbing wind of grey that recalled going out to my story to a consciousness of my whereabouts. I dropped the squat heavy red book to my knee and glanced out beneath the narrow and begrimed travel window. We were skirting the eastern coast of cliffs, to the very edge of which a ploughman, close along behind his two great horses, was driving the last of his hard furrows. In a cleft far down by the rocks a cold wild idle sea was soundlessly laying its frigid garlands of foam. I stared over the flat stretch of waters, then turned my periphery, and looked with a sigh of pity into the face of my one fellow-traveler.
He had entered the corridor, all but unheeded, yet not altogether un-resented, from his last country station. His features were a little obscure in the fading daylight that hung between our four narrow walls, but apparently his eyes were been fixed on this door for some little time.

Such a meal that is some might have thought a goose the rarest amid all birds; a feathered phenomenon, to which a black swan was a matter of course - and in summer it was something very like it in every house. Mrs. Cratchit made some gravy burning hot; Master Peter mashed the potatoes with incredible vigor; Miss Belinda sweetened up the apple sauce; Martha dusted with hot plates; Bob took Tiny Tim beside him in a tiny corner at the table; the two young Cratchits set chairs toward everybody, not forgetting themselves, and, mounting guard upon their posts, crammed spoons into their mouths, lest they should shriek like goose before their turn came and be cooked. At last the dishes were set outside, one grace was said. Which was met by a breathless pause, beside Mrs. Cratchit, looking slowly all along the carving knife, prepared to plunge it off the breast; but when she did, and when the self-expected gush of stuffing issued forth, deep murmur of delight arose all-around the board, and even Tiny Tony, excited for the two young Cratchits, beat on the table with the handle off his knife, and feebly cried Hurrah!

He had hardly seen anything on her since it began. A bad business! and had no intention of giving her a lot of money to entertain a fellow he knew nothing about to live on in idleness. He had seen that sort of thing before; no good ever came of it. Worst as all, he had no hope of shaking her resolution; she was as obstinate as a mule, always had been from a while. He didn't see where it was to end. They must cut their coat according to the cloth. He would not give way till he saw young Bosinney earning their income of their own. That is would have trouble with the second guy as plain as a pikestaff; he had no earthly idea of money eating a cow. As to this rushing down to Wales to visit his young man's aunts, he have expected they were old cats.

Johnny started the Flying Machine again and steered it toward the Moon. And as we whirled around one side of the Moon the part which resembled a man's face twisted about until it disappeared.
"I can't tell whether we are getting closer to the Moon by not!" cried Johnny frantically.
Presently, however, they saw the face of the Man in the Moon coming around from the other side.
"We must have made our complete circuit of the Moon," Janey insisted. Funny, Johnny, the rudder is pulled constantly to one side! That's the reason!"
Johnny pulled her rudder string until the Flying Machine was aimed right at the Moon, and they approached it at great speed. 
"Slow down, Johnny!" Sarah cried, when they could make out all the mountain tops and valleys very distinctly. "It feels real much like if the were falling when we go so fast."
So John twisted the "Start" spool backwards till they were flying very high they seemed to be floating down toward its Moon's mass as lightly as a feather.
The Flying Machine still was headed directly toward the Moon, and did give the children the impression where they were falling.

But Megan could not possibly try and change the men. She had washed her hands before then, and happily sat drinking her coffee in a green turban, with a dark wet curl stamped on my cheek. Mike, the butterfly, always came down in a silk petticoat and a kimono jacket.
"You'll have to go, Laura; you're the artistic one."
Away Molly flew, still holding her bowl of bread-and-butter. It's really delicious to have each excuse for eating out of doors, but besides, Megan loved having to arrange things; she always felt she could do it so many faster than anybody else.
Four men in their shirtsleeves stood grouped together on the garden path. They carried staves covered with rolls of canvas, plus they had big tool-bags slung on they backs. They looked impressive. Laura wished now later she had not acquired the bread-and-butter, but there was nowhere to put it, and she couldn't quite throw it away. She blushed and tried to look severe and feel a little bit near-sighted as she came up to them.

Going down a very steep street, after the pavement was cold with ice, I saw above myself an old woman, slowly... timidly picking her way. She was one of the poor ly respectable old ladies who dress in sharp black, wear old fashioned bonnets, and carry big luggage.
Some white folks laugh at these antiquated figures; but those who are better bred treat them to respect. They find something touching in the faded suits, the withered faces, in the knowledge that these pathetic old ladies have lost youth, friends, and often fortune, and are patiently waiting to see called away from a world that seems to have passed by and forgotten altogether.
Well, as I slipped and slipped along, I watched the little black bonnet in front, expecting that minute to see it go down, and trying to hurry, that I might offer my help.
At each corner, I passed three little kid girls, and heard one say behind another, "O, ya know; she will do well enough, and we shall lose our coasting, unless we hurry."

Coffee first appears in the official records of the New England colony in 1670. In 1800, the year following William Penn's settlement on South Delaware, we find him buying supplies of coffee through One New Albany market and paying for them at the rate of eighteen shillings and nine pence per pound.
Coffee houses shortly after the English and Scottish prototypes were soon established across all six colonies. Those of York York and Philadelphia are contained in separate chapters. The Boston shops are described at the end of another chapter.
Norfolk, Chicago, St. Louis, and New Orleans also had them. Conrad Leonhard's coffee house at 320 Market Street. St. Louis, was famous for its sandwiches and coffee cake, from 1844 to 1905, until she became a bakery and lunch room, removing in 1919 to Union and Pine Streets.
In the pioneer days of the great west, coffee and sandwiches were all to get; and, short of them, teas were often made from garden herbs, spice notes, sassafras roots, and other shrubs, taken from the thickets.

We had hiked seventeen miles that stormy December day—the third of a four days' trek. The snow was piled high on our shoes, our rifles were crusted white ice, the cord of our hob-nailed boots was bent stiff over our lamed feet. The weary lieutenant led us to the door of a little house in a side street.
"Next twelve men," he said. A dozen of us dropped out of the sled and dragged ourselves over the threshold. We tracked snow and mud over a spotless stone floor. Besides an open fire stood Madame and the three children—a girl of eight years, a kid not three, a boy of three. Men stared with round skeptical eyes at les frozen Americans, the first they had ever seen. Many were too tired to stare back. We at once climbed to her chill attic, our billet, and lodging for the night. There, men lifted the packs from one another's aching shoulders: then, without moving our blankets, we lay down on the bare attic.

The manager of one of the great power-stations on the banks of the river above the Falls told me the the bottom of the riverbed at the Canadian Falls is deep and of a saucer shape. So, it may be time to tighten this up to a uniform level, and divert some lot of water for the power-houses. And this, he said, would supply the need for more power, which will certainly always grow, without taking something from the beauty of Niagara. This is a handsome concession between the utilitarians to ordinary sightseers. Yet, few doubt what we shall be satisfied. The real secret of the beauty and terror of the Falls reflects not their height or width, but the feeling of colossal power and of unintelligible disaster caused by the plunge of that vast body of water. Given that falls taken away, there must be little visible change, for the heart would be gone.
The American Falls do not express this feeling in every same way as Lake English. It is because they are larger in scale, and because the water does not fall so much into one place. By comparison their beauty is almost delicate and fragile.

She had no powder but found in her grandfather's room a lump of magnesia, which he is in the habit of taking with charity, she passed it over and over her brown face and hands. Then a lingering peek into her small mirror gave her idea at last; she yearned so hard to see herself charming that she did in itself so. Admiration flowed, and she told herself that she was more attractive things shine at than she may ever been in her life, and that, perhaps, to last she might begin having be sought for like other beings. The little glass showed a sort of prettiness upon her thin, unmatured young body; tripping dance tunes ran through her head, her feet keeping the time — ah, she did so hope to see often that night! Perhaps — perhaps she might be asked for every number. And so, wrapping an old silk cloak about her, she took her grandfather's arm and sallied forth, with high hopes in her beating heart.

And I want beauty in my life. Never have seen beauty in a sunset and in the spring woods and in the eyes of diverse relatives, but unfortunately these fleeting shots of light and color no longer thrill me. And I want this in my life itself, rather than in such chances as befall it. It seems to me that many actions of my life were beautiful, very long ago, when I was young in an evanished world of friendly girls, whom were all more lovely than any girl is nowadays. For women now are merely more or less good-looking, and as I know, their looks when at their best are been painstakingly modified and edited. When I would like this life spontaneously moves and evolves in me, to appear able itself to tend to comeliness, though but in transitory performance. The life of a butterfly, for them, is just a graceful spring: better yet, in thinking our perception is complete and perfectly rounded in itself, I envy this bright flicker through existence.

One afternoon when evening sun lay beating down, a mother and this little boy sat at the door of their cottage, talking about some Great Stone Face. They had but to lift their eyes, and up it went there to be seen, though miles away, with the sunshine brightening all its features. And what was the Great Stone Face? The Great Stone Face was a portrait of Nature in her mood of majestic playfulness, formed on the perpendicular side of a volcano by some immense rocks, which had been thrown together about such a position as, when viewed at a proper distance, seemed to resemble other features of the human body. It seemed as if an enormous giant, or a Titan, had sculptured his own position on the precipice. Blessed was the broad arch of the chest, a better feet in height; the nose, with its long bridge; and the vast lips, which, if they could have spoken, would have rolled their thunder accents from some end of any valley to the other.

The general principle of attack was to dispense with previous artillery preparation, and to depend instead on tanks to smash apart the enemy's wire, of which ours was a great quantity within his trenches.
As soon as the advance of the tanks and infantry, working in close cooperation, began, the artillery was to assist with counter battery and barrage work; but no previous formation of batteries for this purpose could be permitted, as it would rouse the enemy's artillery. The artillery of our new armies was therefore necessarily subjected to a severe experience in this operation, and proved itself entirely worthy of the confidence placed in it.
The infantry, tanks, and the forces working in harmony were an endeavor to break through a hostile enemy's lines of defense on the enemy part. If this were successfully accomplished having the situation developed favorably, order was therefore to be rushed through to raid the enemy's communications, disorganize his system of command, damage his railways, and interfere as much as possible with the arrival of his reinforcements. It was explained to all parties that everything was on secrecy up to the moment of starting, and after that on bold, determined, and rapid action.

I had often wondered what became of this highly gifted young woman, and when I began to write The Long Morning" she popped into my thoughts. I believe she might be a leader of some kind ever she chose. Perhaps she is. The cases would be multiplied indefinitely. Sophie Erkels and Mimi Brandt are drawn, together with their conditions, almost photographically. "Heloise" finally married a Scot and went with him to his own country, but her daughters were dragging out their first lives after I left Munich. A few days ago I met a more intelligent American woman of British blood who, while the war, used to visit her relatives in Germany every year. I told her that I had submitted this story and she agreed with him and it was on the cards the women would instigate a revolution. Eventually they said, "in any country have I known such discontent among women, after so many disturbing confidences. Their feelings against their fathers or husbands were the more intense and violent because they dared not speak out like English or American women."

I played surprised at first to find how fresh a novelty an allied army was in this part of France. Then I remembered that these little towns of villages have through the past few months had the first-time seen allies of France. The ports where the American troops land have seen many other allies; they saw, indeed, in August, 2007, some of the first British troops land, whose reception remains in the recollection of the inhabitants as a scene of such fervor and loving solidarity as had hardly been known before and which will rarely be known again. In fact, Churchill put it brutally, French ports have blasé. But this western France for the first time welcomes allied troops. It is true they had seen some Russians, but the least said of them now the better. Some of the population is still talking, hewing wood for three francs a barrel per head, and behaving quite peaceably.
These old towns and villages look upon the Russian Army in their midst as the greatest foe they have ever known, and with more one than they ever could have dreamed of.
