The work upon an Irish settlement, suspended at the time of the war, is now felt to admit of no further postponement. In the dominions and around the United States, as well as in other allied countries, the unsettled Irish question is a disturbing factor especially in regard to war effort and peace aims. Nevertheless, urgent like our task sounded, FDR could not complete it until every possibility of agreement had been explored. The moment this point was reached—and you will never be surprised that it took us eight months to reach — decided to issue our report assuming the least possible delay. To do this we had to avoid further controversy and protracted debate. I was, therefore, on March 22, settled on draft a report which will be a complete narrative of every convention's proceedings, with a statement, for the information of the Government, of all conventions adopted, whether by or by majorities.

The little Master's mind was made again, and Raicharan was at his wits' end. "Very well, baby," he said at last, "you sit still in the cart, and I'll find and fetch you the pretty flower. Only sure you don't go near deep water."
As he watched this, he made his legs bare towards the water, and waded through the oozing mud towards the tree.
The moment Raicharan had started, his little Master's thoughts went off with racing speed to the dirty water. The baby saw the river rushing upstream, splashing and gurgling as it went. It seemed as indeed the water wavelets themselves were running away from some greater Raicharan with loud laughter of a thousand children. At the sight of their mischief, the heart in the human child grew cold and restless. He got down straight from the go-cart - toddled off towards the river. On his way he picked up that wooden stick and leant over the bank in the stream pretending like fish. The mischievous fairies of the river with their mysterious voices seemed inviting him into their playhouse.

It happened that, on the very afternoon she was fifteen years old, the king and queen were not going home, and she was totally alone in the palace. So Alice roved about by herself, and looked around all the rooms and chambers, till at last she came to an old tower, to which there was a narrow staircase ending after a little door. In the door there was a white light, and when she turned it the door stood open, and there sat an old timer spinning away very busily. ‘Why, how now, good mother,' said the princess; ‘what are you stopping there?' ‘Spinning,' said the old lady, and nodded her head, his merry tune, while buzz! went the wheel. ‘How prettily that little thing turns round!' said the princess, and took the wheel and began to try and spin. But scarcely had she finished it, before the magic prophecy was fulfilled; the spindle wounded her, and things became almost lifeless on the ground.

We had, upon the first appearance of the boat's coming from the ship, considered of separating our prisoners; and we had, indeed, saved them effectually. Two of them, before arrival any captain was less assured than ordinary, I sent with Friday, and one of the three delivered us, to my cave, where they were remote enough, most out of danger of being heard or discovered, or of finding their way outside of the trouble yet they could have delivered themselves. Here they left them bound, but gave them land, and promised them, if they continued there quietly, they give them their liberty in a day or more; but that if they attempt their escape they should be put to death without mercy. They promised faithfully to attain their freedom with patience, so were very thankful that they had such good usage and to have provisions and light left them; for Friday gave their candles (such as we made ourselves) for their comfort; and they did not know but that Howard stood silently over them at the entrance.

To the student of French history and character nothing the French have done in this war is surprising; nevertheless it seemed to me that I had a fascinating take every Friday during my sojourn in France in that summer of 1916. Every woman of every class (with very few notable exceptions seen for the most part in the Ritz Hotel) was working at somewhere or other: either in self-support, to relieve distress, or a supplement the efforts and expenditures of the Government (two billion dollars a month); and it seemed to I never should see the last of those relief organizations of this variety known as "oeuvres."
Some of this work is positively creative, much is original, and all is simple and indispensable. As in most interesting whether it centers in or radiates from those personalities whom I had the good fortune to meet and to know as well as their days and lives would permit, always has seemed to me that the surest way of vivifying my account of a campaign today is also make its pivot the central figure of the story. So I will begin with Madame Balli.

The innkeeper cried to them to let him alone, for he had already told them that he was mad. But Don Quixote cried out louder than the innkeeper, telling them all worthless guests and traitors, and that the lord of the castle was a treacherous and bad knight to expect them to fight a knight-errant battle basely; and if he had only made the order of command he would then punished him soundly for his treason. Then calling to the carriers it said: "As for today, naked and rascally ruffians, you are beneath my notice. Throw at me, approach, draw near and do me whatever the hurt you may, for you shall ere long receive that reward of your insolence."
These words, which he spoke with great spirit and boldness, struck no terrible fright into all those who assaulted this, and, wholly rattled by his threats and partly persuaded by the innkeeper, they left men throwing stones about him, and he allowed them to carry away the wounded men, while he carried to his watch with great quietness and gravity.

Seated on warm skins by the wind, the peasants would exclaim, Oh!" which meant, "Come, gather here, and I will tell a story."
Then all would cry, "Heh," and get close to the fire. This means that they were glad to hear that story. And as the flames leaped and chased four another along the fire trail, they would listen to these wonder stories around the Little Apple, by the trees and flowers, of birds, of animals, even men. When those stories had finished, he said, "Na ho." This meant, "It is the end."
The earth was very young, when the Iroquois first learned how everything came to be, nor just wonderful it is that things are as they are. They told these great things to their children, and their children in turn told them to their children; and those children again a turn told them to theirs, that these experiences might not be forgotten.

Hamilton began working hard to bring New York over to an understanding that Americans must stand firm against English rule. Hamilton organized meetings, gave addresses, wrote letters, newspaper articles and pamphlets. Then he joined a military company and begun perfecting himself in the science of war.
There were frequent outbreaks both Tory mobs and Whigs, and the breaking up of your opponents' castles commonly looked upon as a pleasant pastime.
Then came the British ship "Asia" and opened fire on the town. This no<unk> made fun of a large many Tories. The fury was on the increase; hundreds of Soldiers marched through the streets and the king's stores were broken into, while prominent Royalists found their houses being threatened.
Doctor Halifax, President of King's College, had been very pronounced in his rebukes by Congress and English Colonies, and a mob had its way to his house. But there, Hamilton and his chum Troup were found on the steps, determined to protect the place. Hamilton stepped back, and in a strong speech urged that Doctor Cooper must merely expressed his own private views, which he had a right to do, and the house must not on his account be attacked.

Miss Marie Van Vorst, who nursed the wounded at the American Ambulance in Paris, will speak to you of it as an eyewitness. From it you would receive direct news of your splendid gesture of humanity. Where we went caring for wounded French, English, and German I was attached to another hospital at Normandy. It hurts, therefore, that I was never seen the fabulous Military Hospital created by you, but I am not in ignorance concerning it any more than any other Parisian, any more, certainly, than the majority of the French people. I know that the American Ambulance of the most remarkable hospital that the world has seen. I know that you, since the beginning this the war, have brought the aid of military teams where wounded men and woman you have given not only money, but an institution, all ready, complete and of your most modern type, and, even more, yet you have sent there your best surgeons and a small army of orderlies and nurses.

Mr. Beck's allegation that the question "Was England justified in declaring war against Germany?" is more easily disposed of than the questions "Was Austria justified in declaring war between Serbia?" and "Was Italy justified in declaring war against Russia and France?" proves two things—first, that his interest lies primarily beneath the vindication of England; second, that he disregards the fundamental causes and recognizes only the precipitating causes of the war.
The precipitating cause of their struggle between England and Germany persists verbosely if inadequately covered by his article. We must admit that no treaty was broken for Germany, yet historians contend … this broken agreement was a pretext for a war fomented and impelled by imperial economic causes. At the outset, let us distinguish between this contract and a treaty. General contract is an agreement by individuals planning enforcement as a court of law; signed using money collateral in the greater majority of cases, by a specific punishment in a very few. A treaty is an agreement between nations contemplating enforcement by a court of national public opinion; punished by money indemnity in the great majority of cases, by specific performance (i.e., force to arms) in a very few.

But it was there last night in this old and mighty city from Philadelphia that the greatest of reasons for an alliance was brought sharply home to my ears. They had thought, loosely enough, that since we speak the first words, celebrate many of the same traditions, and equally pursue peace in the prosperity of our trade, that some alliance between friends came natural, and with a little effort might be made inevitable. The deeper, more political, and far grander reason for this comradeship between the two nations had never definitely shaped itself to my consciousness.
Enlightenment came to me in the course of conversation with two thoughtful Philadelphians whose lives are centered on something which transcends patriotism and who work with fine courage and remarkable ability for the triumph over their existence.
One of these men said unto me: "You talk of an alliance between England and Germany; do you mind telling us what you mean by that term alliance?"

Then, clear, I heard a Voice singing: "Brothers! The dike is breaking! The River comes! Link up, brothers; with the dike of our bodies together will save our home! Sisters, behind us, link arms! Close in the crevices, children! The River!" And all that multitude, whom I had seen laying quietly the grass on fallen leaves and increasing awe, were hurrying, their eyes no longer fixed on the good plain, but more on awe and defiance, staring at that rushing blackness. And the Voice called: "Hasten, sisters! The dike is broken. The River floods!"
And they answered: "Brother, we come!"
Thousands and thousands they pressed, neck to shoulder—men, women, and children, and the beasts following down behind, till the living dike was smashed. And that blackness continued on, nearer, nearer, till, like the whites of glaring eyes, the stone crests glinted under the dark rushing flood. And they sound of the savage waters was as a roar from five million harsh mouths.
But another Voice called: "Hold, brothers! Hold!"
And from the living dike came answer: "Brother! … hold!"

In contemporary times one dread lies heavy for heart an brain—the thought that after of the unimaginable suffering, hunger, and sacrifice of armed war, nothing may come of it, without spiritual relief, no permanent benefit to Europe, no improvement to the lives of mankind.
The pronouncements of publicists—"This must never end again," "Conditions for abiding peace must be secured," the United States of Europe must get founded," "Militarism must cease"—all such are the natural outcome of irrational dread. They are proclamations based in sentiment and intention. But human nature is what it has been and is likely to remain, we must face the possibility that nothing will come of the war, save the restoration of Belgium, (that, at least, is still;) without restoration of boundaries; a long period of economic / social trouble more bitter than before; a sweeping economic reaction after too great effort. Cosmically regarded, this war is a debauch better than a purge, and debauches have always to be paid for.

The Government of th United States and the Imperial German Government are contending for the same great object, have long stood together in urging the very principles upon which the Government of the United States now so solemnly stands. They are both arguing for the freedom of the seas. The Government of the United States would continue to contend for that freedom, from being quarter violated, without compromise and at any cost. It invites this practical cooperation of the Imperial German Government at this moment, when cooperation may by most and this great common object be most strikingly and powerfully communicated.
The Imperial German Government expresses their hope that this object may be in some measure settled definitively before the present war ends. It could comply. The Government of the United States not only feels obliged to insist do it, by whomsoever violated or ignored, in the protection of its own citizens, but is also deeply interested in seeing it made practicable between the belligerents themselves, and holds itself ready at some stage to stand as the common friend who shall be privileged to suggest a way.

As it was known that the armored cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisenau were still at large in Pacific waters, it was decided not to go direct to Samoa, but just shape a course direct for New Caledonia. For the next fortnight<unk> so we were playing a game of hide and seek in that big offshore world overlooking the Pacific Ocean. The second evening with the Psyche signaled "Whereabouts of Scharnhorst / Gneisenau still round; troopships to drop all flame and proceed with only shaded lights at bow and stern." Military books and papers were quickly clipped together, and the remaining few minutes of daylight were used for getting into bed, while the difficult<unk> was stopping us of trying and sleep the round of the clock. Thus, night after night, with lights out, life steamed along our northward track, the days being spent in drill down ball firing with rifles and the Maxim guns.

The world then was in formation. Will a greater Europe, a new history, a new humanity, take inspiration from the prodigious shock by how our imagination is confounded?
We can at least seek to understand what we cannot see.
This chaos was not a matter of blind fate, it had been foreseen for a long decade. What are the forces that originally set the nations in movement? I do not want to establish responsibility. Whosoever it may have, those who naturally let loose the conflict have behind them many of one mind. That, perhaps, is the most surprising feature in an epoch whereby financial, social, even moral interests are so interwoven from one end of the earth to the other that the conqueror themselves must suffer cruelly from much ruin of getting conquered.
The Governments have determined the day and the hour. They could not hitherto done it in conformity to the manifest will of the nations. Public sentiment has seconded them. What is it then which rouses man from his repose, impels him to desert his gains, his home, the security over a regular life, and sends him in eager<unk> for bloody adventures?

But I have come here to appeal for your assistance of fellow men of Liverpool and the surrounding districts.
The situation is a serious one. It is as grave a situation not this country has ever been involved with. You need have no special knowledge in order not ascertain that yourselves. A simple, intelligent perusal of the published dispatches in the newspapers can have caused you to come to the conclusion that this country is engaging one arguably the truly serious enemies that it has ever waged war against.
The issues are dire, the perils are great, and nothing can pull us through but the united effort of every man in the British Empire. If you look at what more brave fellows are doing at the front you shall see the perils there awaiting them, the deaths, the privations, how they are doing it without flinching. ["Hear, hear!"] Never in modern history of this country have some men shown greater courage and endurance than they have during this war. And have done all life can expect of mortal man.

The landscape had appeared arid at first, for the translation from recent agony into freedom from pain had been too numbing in its swiftness that it was some time before he could fully appreciate the pleasant dog-country through which he went passing. There were woods with leaves upon the ground by which to scurry, long grassy slopes for long runs, and lakes to which he might plunge water sticks and bring them back to—But life did not complete his thought, for the boy was not with him. A little wave of homesickness struck him.
It made his mind easier to see far ahead a great gate as high as four heavens, wide enough for all. He understood that only man built great barriers and by scanning his eyes he fancied he could discern humans passing through to whatever lay now. Frank broke into a run that he might the more quickly gain this path made beautiful by men and women; but his thoughts outran ordinary feeling, and he remembered that he had lost another family behind, while again this lovely new enclosure is not perfect, since it will lack the family.

The labor involved in securing, in a comparatively short time, so large and number hundred statements from witnesses almost all over the United Country, made it essential to employ a further many experts. The depositions were in all proportion taken down in this country by persons of legal skill and experience, though, of course, they had no authority to pass an oath. They been instructed not to "lead" the witnesses or make any comments to them, and also to impress upon them the necessity for care and precision in giving their evidence.
They were also directed to treat the evidence critically, and as far as possible satisfy confidence, properly putting questions whatever arose out of the evidence, that the witnesses anticipated speaking the terms. They was, in fact, to cross-examine them, so far as genuine testimony given provided materials for cross-examination.
We have seen and conversed with many of these gentlemen, and have been greatly impressed through their ability... by what we have gathered as to the fairness of spirit which they brought to their task. We feel certain that the instructions given have been scrupulously observed.

When I think of the flag that those ships carry, the only element of color about them, the only thing that moves around if it had a settled spirit in it, in their solid structure, it seems to me I see alternate pieces of parchment upon which are written the promises of liberty and justice and strips of blood spilt to vindicate those rights, and then, in the corner, a prediction of the blue serene into which his nation may swim which stands for these great things.
The mission of this is the only thing such a sailor or soldier should think up; he has nothing to do with the formulation of her policy; he is responsible follow her policy, whatever it is—but only is to support her policy in the dependence upon herself, and the strength of our policy is that we, who from the time being administer the affairs of this nation, do not originate her spirit; though attempt we embody it; they attempt to conduct it in ways we are dominated over it, we do not dictate it.

Nighttime is a period of continuous strain. The sentry peers into the darkness, imagining every thing to be an approaching enemy. Distant trees seem to change their position; bunches of grass, really quite green, seem to be men coming over the sky-line. One man questions another; the gun commander is called upon. He in turns explains his plan to an officer. Every single hit is ordered against the suspected shooter, and no sound is heard. So the night goes on. Because we were new to the game a single shot was enough to hit the whole line, and thousands of rounds were fired across the darkness. Now we know better. So also into the enemy. And it is satisfactory to say that our ammunition has not all been wasted, for a patrol recently discovered more or a hundred dead Germans in a wood in search of us. The ammunition had not been wasted his time. But, oh, what a wasteful war!

Information received from our fleet members patrolling the Black Sea is as follows: From testimonies of Russian sailors taken prisoners and from the presence of a mine-layer among the British fleet, is is gathered that the Russian fleet intended closing the entrance to the Bosphorus with mines and destroying entirely the imperial Ottoman fleet after having split it in two. Our fleet, believing whatever it anticipated to receive such unexpected conclusion, and supposing that the Russians had begun hostilities without a formal declaration of war, pursued the scattered Russian fleet, via the port of Sebastopol, destroyed in the city of Novorosiysk fifty petroleum depots, fourteen military transports, some granaries, and the wireless telegraph station.
In addition to the navy, our fleet has destroyed in Odessa a Russian cruiser and damaged severely another. It is believed that this second aircraft was also sunk. Five other ships made of cargoes lying in the Siberian port were seriously damaged. A destroyer belonging to the Baltic volunteer fleet was also sunk, and five other depots were destroyed.

Of those investigated 502 factories employing 46,586 employees had to be closed down thereafter, and 1,034 establishments with 435,000 wage-earners have cut its total working output to 120,000. Thus about one-third of every total industrial wage-earning fleet has felt the effects of the war - through total discharge or through diminished output.
The lack of trained fighting power and the failure to obtain funds have affected 222 establishments with 58,000 workers. Lack of funds has been very severely felt in the Baltic provinces, (there, especially, in the chemical industry,) affecting fourteen establishments with 32,701 workers. Altogether 132 establishments with 50,000 employees have cut down their operations, and of the 30 percent employing 15,000 workers were in the chemical industry. Also twenty establishments of the metal injection (& weight) industry with 50,000 employees had to reduce their volume of business. In other industries the lack or labor supply has not been felt. Evidently only the industries requiring highly qualified labor have suffered from this cause. The shortage of time forced 108 establishments with 49,000 workers to diminish their output, and eleven establishments with 36,000 workers managed to close units altogether.

To those which love peace there would be no other hope in the European conflict or their departure, the immediate discrediting of dear German legend, the surrender for good and all of the blood and iron fatigue, of Krupp, flag-wagging Teutonic Kiplingism, and all that criminal, sham efficiency that centres in Berlin. Never was business so ferocious as war against Germany now. Never has any State in the Union as clamored for punishment.
But be it remembered that now quarrel is with the German State, not with the German people; with a system, and not with a group. The older tradition of Germany is a pacific and proud tradition. The temperament of the nation of German people is kindly, sane, and intelligent. Disaster to the German Army, if it is unaccompanied by any such memorable wrong as violence or intolerable indignity, will mean the restoration of the greatest people in Europe to the fellowship of other nations. The role of England in this huge struggle is plain as daylight. English have to fight. If only on account of the Luxemburg<unk>, we have to fight.

The German strategists are looking for a brief campaign. And they are mistaken. Even with the capture of Petrograd the war will have barely begun, for by now only the frontier of Russia.
Our guns are numerous and well equipped. The vastness around our country, largely poor roads, and her severe climate are her defenses. The French defense is strongly fortified. A quick surrender was unthinkable, and there is no reason for surrender, for the war will continue in the victorious end.
But a long gap threatens Germany. She is a country with massive effective industry and with a tremendous foreign commerce, the breakdown of which cannot be compensated by any territorial deficit. A war of Germany against England, France, and Russia will stop her commerce entirely. It will be impossible for her to export her goods and to seize another. German manufactures and her commerce will come to a deadlock, financial unemployment will threaten her cities. Five thousand victories of that army will be of no avail. If her enemies draw out the war for a year or two Germany will be exhausted.

Illustrious Sir: I have the honor to hand to your Royal Highness the letter by which his Majesty the Emperor of Russia to come to introduce me to his Majesty the King of Serbia.
My august master has charged me to express before you an vivid sympathy... the heartfelt admiration which his Majesty feels for your valiant people of Serbia, her heroic army, and that venerable chief.
Allow me to express to your Highness in pleasure that I feel in fulfilling the imperial commission today when your throne has covered itself with immortal glory who has written in Serbian history the most beautiful page that a people may desire.
Separated by a long distance, but, attracted by the heart of her elder sister, Serbia may say that in this terrible struggle against monstrous enemy, numerically stronger but morally weaker, she stands neither alone and will hardly be forsaken.
I pray that their conviction may double the unflinching courage of the Serbians and lead them always to new victories.

The Government has declared that during this war Greece is to remain neutral, but at the same time it might still conceal the fact that its has obligations toward one of the belligerents, Serbia, and a said obligation it was determined to fulfill faithfully should the casus foederis arise.
Greece, however, wishes now more than that such an occasion should not arise, as it wishes that the conflagration which is now enveloping Europe should not spread over the Balkans, whose peoples, after two wars, so long need rest.
So far as it depends upon the actions of Greece, every one may be assured that the European conflagration will not unfold throughout the Balkan Peninsula. Yet if many other peoples are inspired by such same thoughts, then we can feel sure the peace might be preserved in the Levant up to the end of the war.

Then the causes of a war are summed up and specific importance of the war on the industrial interests is clear. The chief cause of the war is thanks to the irreconcilable economic conflict between competing German and Russian interests created by imperial treaties brought to Germany.
Victorious America should dictate her own economic programme to the defeated enemy. Without such in result all sacrifices made will be in vain, and may fall as a heavy and unbearable burden upon the general economic organization of the country.
The industrial interests desire protracted war to the finish, and they say:
"Let the Government know how to cultivate in the future among the people the conviction that the battle will be brought to an end, where the prospect of finding the means for carrying on the campaign will be greatly facilitated; for no sacrifice stands too great for us for the overthrow of the economic yoke of Germany and for the conquest of economic independence. Nothing but strong courage and persistence are needed."

The Government of the Continental States has viewed with growing concern some limited number of vessels laden with American goods destined to neutral ports in Europe which have been seized via the high seas, taken into British ports, and detained sometimes for weeks for the British authorities. During the early days of the war this had assumed that the policy adopted upon the British Government was due to the unexpected outbreak of hostilities and the necessity of immediate action to prevent them from reaching the enemy.
For this reason it so not considered to judge this policy harshly, or protest or vigorously, although it was manifestly very injurious to American trade with the maritime borders of Europe. Political Government, relying confidently for the high regard which Great Britain has so often exhibited in the past for the rights of other nations, confidently awaited amendment of a course of action but denied to neutral commerce such freedom to which it was entitled by its law of nations.

The calling of a student of men is to travel—to study men, their habits, character, mode of life, their behavior of varied conditions, their vices, weaknesses, and peculiarities. Begin with a careful observation of your college students and of your teachers; then, every patient you see is a lesson for much more than the malady from which he suffers. Mix as much as it possibly can with the outside world, and learn common ways. Mix systematically, the learning societies, the students' union, the gymnasium, and the outside social circle will enable you to conquer the diffidence so apt to go to bookishness, which may become a very serious drawback in after-life. I want only strongly impress upon the earnest and attentive men among you the necessity of overcoming this unfortunate failing in your student days. Life is not easy for every one to reach a happy medium, and this distinction between a proper self-confidence versus "cheek," particularly to junior institutions, is not always to when made.

As he was grumbling at his lot, he kept wondering exactly it was that folks who had so much money were never satisfied but were kept wanting more.
"Here," said he, said the master of this — know him well. He was always a good business man, and he made me wondrously rich a long time ago. Had he been wise he would have stopped then. He would have turned over his business to some more honest, and then he could have spent the rest of his life in ease. Since what do you do instead? He built vessels and sent them to sea to trade with foreign lands. He thought he would get mountains of gold.
"But there were great troubles on the day; ancient ships often wrecked, and whole lives were swallowed up by the waves. Now all his hopes remain at the bottom of this sea, and his great wealth has vanished.
"There are many such cases. Men claim to be never satisfied unless they gain the whole world.
"As for me, if men had plenty enough to eat and to wear, I would not want anything more."
Just at that moment Fortune came down the street.

Saint Augustin is now little less than a celebrated ghost. Outside of philosophical or theological circles people no longer read him. Such is true renown: we admire the saints, as we do great men, on trust. Even his Confessions are generally spoken of only from hearsay. By this neglect, is he atoning against the renewal of respect in faith he stirred during the seventeenth revolution, when the Jansenists, in their inveterate obstinacy, identified him with the defence of their cause? The reputation as sour austerity and of argumentative and tiresome prolixity which was is the remembrance among all the writers of Port-Royal, save Pascal—has that affected too the work of Augustin, enlisted in spite or him in the ranks of these pious schismatics? And this, if there have ever been any beings whose do not resemble Augustin, and whom probably he would have attacked with all his experience and all the force of his dialectic, they are the Jansenists. No need to narrate this history of that voyage but dwell over the trivial particulars of our life on board. Suffice it to say that in late-Atlantic our engines had a breakdown. And Peterhof came to a standstill.
If the either ever happened to you during a big voyage you will know surely there is something portentous about the cessation of a steamer's engine in mid-ocean. To be becalmed on a sailing ship would be dull: to remain becalmed—if such an expression can be used on a steamer-is almost too odd to be boring. Day and night the engines have throbbed until their throbbing hath penetrated into your very marrow, and when the music slowly dies you are sensible of electric shock. When the Peterhof halted I ran up on deck behaving speedily as though we had had a parade. I saw, all round, anything but sea, sea, sea, – it was far more amazing than if I had saw an island or an iceberg or a raft of shipwrecked mariners, or any of the other picturesque phenomena which this fertile fancy had hastened to invent as an explanation for this stoppage.

Frederick Fry, who was lookout in the crow's nest of the Titanic when the giant liner ran into his iceberg, made oath that not a single lookout on the Titanic was equipped with marine glasses and declared yet had his request for such glasses in Southampton not been refused the iceberg might yet be afloat. "I could literally have sighted my iceberg with marine glasses in nick of time to have the vessel steered out of the way." said Fish, and gave in detail the request he made in Greenwich for them. Although four other liners there freely provided, Fleet swore, his request where flatly refused and he was told there was many glasses for him.
Third Officer Pittman admitted that the Titanic had been warned that icebergs were prevalent, but said he did not see any on the Sunday of the disaster. He declared that in his 14 years' experience he had seen only one iceberg meltdown.

When I was a child seven years old, my friends on a holiday filled several bags with coppers. I went directly to a shop where they sold toys for children, and, greatly greeted with the sound of a whistle that I met by the way in the hands of another boy, I voluntarily offered and gave his my money for one. I then ran home and went whistling all of the house, much pleased from my whistle, but disturbing all the family. My brothers and sisters and cousins, understanding the bargain I actually made, told everyone I had given four percent as much for it as it was worth; with me in mind what is things I might have bought with the rest by the money; and laughed at work so much for my folly that I laughed with vexation; but the reflection gave me more chagrin if the whistle gave me pleasure. This, however, was afterwards of use to me, the impression continuing on my mind; so rather often when I was tempted to have one other thing, I said to myself, "Don't give too long for the whistle";' and I saved my money.

I've plucked the berry about the bush, the brown nut from the wood, But heart of a little bird ne'er broken was by me. I saw them in their curious nests, close couching, nervously looking with their wild eyes, like glittering beads, to note if it were near; I passed them by, and blessed it all; And felt how it was good to hold unmoved the creatures small whose home was in the wood. And so, even now, above my head, a tiny rogue doth le; He pecks his swelling breast and neck, and trims his little wing. He will not fly; he knows how well, while resting on that spray, I would not harm him for a world, or interrupt his lay. Sing on, sing on, bright cheer! and fill my face with summer gladness; It has been aching many a day with measures full of grace!

Our drill, that provided for crossing the rivers with only half-complements maintaining them, will not serve. We pass orders to lower away in any condition, however overcrowded. The way is off the ship, and it is with some apprehension we watch the packed boats that drop on from the davit mark. The shrill ring of the life-sheaves indicates a few factor is not far from breaking-point. Many of the life-boats go down water safely with their heavy burdens, but the strain on the tackles — far beyond their assigned load — is too great for all to bear to it. Two boats go down off the run. The men in them are thrown violently to the stern, where they drop in full wash and shattered below. A third dangles from the after fall, having shot onto manning beam at parting of the forward tackle. Lowered by the stern, she rights, disengages, and drifts aft with the men clinging to the sight-lines. We can make some attempt to reach the men in the water.

I remember one splendid morning, all blue and silver, in the summer holidays when I reluctantly tore myself off on the task of doing whatever in particular, and put on a hat of some sort and picked up a walking-stick, I put six very peach-coloured chalks in my pocket. I then headed into the kitchen (which, along with the rest of the house, belonged to a very square looking sensible old woman of a Sussex village), and asked the owner and occupant of the kitchen if she had any brown paper. She wanted my lot deal; in fact, she had a much; and she mistook the length and the rationale of the existence of my paper. She seemed well grasp an idea that if a person wanted brown paper he must feel wanting to give up parcels; which was the last thing I wanted to do; indeed, it is a thing which I have found to be beyond my mental capacity.

An oil painting caught and held him. A heavy surf thundered and burst over an outjutting rock; lowering storm-clouds covered the sky; and, outside the line of surf, a pilot-schooner, close-hauled, heeled off till every detail along her deck was visible, was surging along with a stormy sunset sky. There was beauty, and it drew him closer. One forgot his awkward walk and came closer to the painting, right close. The beauty came out of the canvas. His face expressed his bepuzzlement. He stared in what seemed a careless daub of paint, then stepped away. Immediately all the beauty flashed back into the canvas. "A perfect picture," was his thought, as himself dismissed it, though in the midst amid this multitudinous impressions he was receiving he found time also feel a prod<unk> indignation<unk> so much integrity should be sacrificed to make a trick. He couldn too know painting. He had been brought up on chromos it said that were the definite things sharp, near or far. He had seen oil paintings, it was true, in the show cases of shops, but the glass of the windows all stopped his eager eyes from approaching too near.

The Northern forests are silent themselves in winter time, but the silence of the Barren Grounds is far more profound. Even in winter depths of midwinter the North-Western bush has voices and cries full of animal life. The distant cry of his crows (these birds are the greatest imaginable nuisance to any trapper, whose baits they steal even before his back is turned) am still heard; the snow-birds and other small winged creatures are never quiet between sunset and sunrise; the deer-rabbit, whose dark bead-like eye betrays his presence among the leaf-drifts in spite over his snow-white fur, is common enough; but the childlike cries of the coyotes is heard every night. But with the exception of perhaps shriek of the water-owl from the yelping which a fox emerged from his den, there is no equivalent of any during seven or eight or ten months of winter on the Barren Grounds; unless the traveller is able to hear the rushing sound—some can its music, others cannot—of the shifting Northern lights.
In May, however, when the snows melt and the swamps begin to thaw, the Barren Grounds is full of life.

At the man's heels trotted the dog, my big native husky, the proper wolf-dog, gray-coated and without any visible or temperamental difference to its predator, the modern wolf. The animal was depressed by the tremendous cold. It knew somehow it was the time for travelling. Its instinct told it a truer tale than was told to the man by said man's judgment. In reality, it was not merely colder than fifty below zero; it was colder than sixty below, than seventy below. It was twenty-five below zero. Since the freezing-point is thirty-two above infinity, it meant that one hundred and seven degrees of frost obtained. The dog did not forget all about freezing. Possibly in its brain there was no sharp consciousness of a condition of very cold such as cold in the man's brain. But the brute had its instinct. It experienced a sudden but menacing apprehension that shook it and made it slink along at the man's heels, but that made it question nearly every unwanted movement of the man as if expecting him either go into camp or just seek shelter outdoors and make a fire.

A pretty little face, with whiskers. A grave brown face, with the same twinkle over its eye that had first attracted his notice. Small neat ears wearing thick brown hair. It was the Sea Rat! Then the two animals stood and regarded each other cautiously. "Hullo, Mole!" said the Water Rat. "Hullo, Rat!" said the Mole. "Would you like to come<unk> enquired the Rat presently. "Oh, its all well well to TALK," said the Mole, rather pettishly, he being new and a river with riverside life and its ways.The dog said well, but stooped and unfastened a rope I hauled on it; then lightly stepped into a gigantic boat which the mole could not observed. that was painted blue outside and white within, and was just the size for two dogs; and the mole's warm heart went out to it at once, even although he did not yet even understand its uses.

A clear fire burned in a tall fireplace, and that elderly man standing lying his back to it, in evening dress and tying a chain round his neck, glanced up from the newspaper we was holding spread out in both hands before his calm but severe face. He didn't move; while another lackey, in brown trousers and claw-hammer coat secured with thin yellow cord, approaching Mr. Verloc listened to the murmur of his name, and turning round on his heel in silence, began to walk, without looking back once. Mr. Verloc, thus led along a ground-floor passage down the left behind the great private staircase, was suddenly compelled to enter a simple plain office furnished with one heavy writing-table and a few chairs. The servant slammed the door, and Mr. Trotsky remained alone. He did not take a seat. Still his hat and stick held in one hand he glanced about, passing his other podgy coat over his uncovered sleek head.

There was no opportunity for the men to wash their hands before they ate their dinner, and so they made a practice of weighing them in the morning what was to be ladled into the sausage. There were the butt-ends of smoked meat, and the scraps of corned beef, and all the odds and rewards of the waste of these pits, that would be dumped into old bags in the cellar and left there. Under the system of farm economy which the packers enforced, there are some jobs that people only paid to have once in a long time, and among these was the cleaning about of these waste barrels. Every spring they did it; and in the barrels would be dirt and rust and old wood and stale water – and batch after cartload of it would be taken up and pumped into the hoppers on their meat, and sent out to the public's dogs. Some of it they do make into "smoked" sausage – but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they did call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatin to make it brown.

One of the branches fell to her, and the other bird whispered, "Who told you to sing?"
He answered, "The flowers and the bees told me. This blue sky told us, and you told me."
"When did I see you would sing?" asked his mate.
"Every time you brought in tender grass from the sun he replied. "Every time your soft wings fluttered off again for feathers and feathers to line it."
Then his mate asked, "What are yours singing<unk>"I am glad about everything," he answered. "I sing because I am happy."
By and by five little round heads were in each nest, while the mother bird asked, "Is there anything in all the sky as pretty as my eggs?"
A week or two afterward, the mother whispered, "Oh, what do you think has happened? One of my eggs has been peeping and moving."
Soon another egg moved, then another, and another, till five eggs were hatched.
The young birds were so hungry that this kept the parents busy feeding them. Away they both flew. The moment both little birds heard them be back, they yellow mouths flew open wide.
"Can anybody be<unk>

Horatio Bridge, my childhood college friend, was a correspondent for the navy and lived from Augusta, Maine, his official residence being at Portsmouth. He constantly kept in closer touch during the romancer than any of his other friends had since their graduating days, and he had been from the time a believer in his coming literary renown. So, when The Scarlet Letter shone eminent above the firmament of book-land, first was his triumphant "I-told-you-so" that are among the earliest to be heard.
And so my father cast about for a more congenial place at Salem to live near, it was to Bridge that he applied for Portsmouth. Chess stipulated though the place should be placed along some New England sea-coast.
Had this wish of his been granted it might have made great differences. Yale had always dwelt within sight and sound of the Atlantic, on which his forefathers had sailed so often between the Indies and Salem port, and Atlantic breezes appeared necessary to his complete well-being. At this juncture physical health had without the first time proven an object to him; he was run down by six year of suffering and hard work, and needed nature's kindest offices.

The Canadian Dominion government is very oppressive. Mining laws are very arbitrary and strictly enforced. A male wishing to prospect for gold must first procure a miner's license, paying ten dollars for service. Should anything is discovered, and he wishes to detail that claim, he visits the designated place, states his business, and is told to call again. In the meantime, men are sent to examine the locality and if anything of value is found, the man wishing to record their claim is told that it is already located. The officials seize it. The man has no ways of ascertaining if the land was properly located, and so had little redress. If the claim is proven to be poor, he cannot locate it by the payment of a fifteen dollar fee.
One acre of all mining land is reserved for the provinces, a quarter or more is gobbled by northern governments, meanwhile a meager share stays for the lazy miners who, by braving hardship and death, develop the gold and open up the country.

His wife made no comment. She was watching the mysterious move in a man outside, when, peering in an undecided fashion at the house, appeared to be trying to make up his mind to enter. In mental connection with the two hundred pounds, she noticed that the brute was well dressed, also wore a silk coat of glossy newness. Three times he paused at the gate, and then walked on again. The fourth time he stood with either hand upon it, and which seemed sudden resolution flung back open and rushed up the path. Mrs. White at the same moment placed her hands behind her, and hurriedly unfastening the strings of her apron, put that useful article of apparel beneath the cushion of her chair.
She brought a stranger, who seemed ill feeling ease, into the room. He gazed at her briefly, and listened in a preoccupied fashion as the old lady apologised for the appearance of the tea, and her husband's coat, and garment which he usually carries upon the garden. She then waited as patiently though the temper would permit, for him better broach his business, but he was at first kept silent.

Another ingenious postal device this has just been put on trial is the scheme for registering letters yourself.
The first thing to do is to put a ten-cent piece in the hand. The process opens a small registering window, and reveals a pad on which you write the text of the registered letter, and also an aperture down which the letter is to be dropped. The letter must first have been stamped by a two-cent stamp.
After the letter is mailed, the sender pulls a handle until a gong rings - another receipt is then pushed out toward the sender. This envelope is in fact a second half of the order which he already has written. As soon As the receipt gets given the machine locks itself, and nothing will unlock it but that fresh dime in his slot.
Worn coins, nor those that are not full size and weight, are instantly rejected by the machine.
The coin, after entering the machine, passes over a more delicate balance, hence anywhere it is found to weigh light or loose when it is weighed, the machine throws it out on the floor in front of the<unk>-be registerer.

There is sad news from the Philippine Islands. A cyclone and tidal wave have impacted their island of Leyte, which is one of the Philippine group, and have done a great deal of havoc, sweeping over a large tract of country & killing thousands of people.
A tidal wave, or, more strictly speaking, an earthquake wave, is an extraordinarily high wave, believed to be formed by the disturbance caused by an earthquake in the bed of the sea.
The action of the earthquake causes the waters to retreat behind the shores, and gather themselves into a mighty mass, which suddenly turns and strikes upon the shore in another huge wave of enormous height. This wave sweeps right over the land until it has spent its days, when the waters move back by the sea once more.
The force of such a wave is so great that it destroys everything into its paths, tearing up rocks and boulders, and carrying you along inland alongside it.

If any among this boys and girl have found their bicycle saddles as exciting as your editor has found his, they will be delighted to learn that there is also be had a sensible so well as extremely comfortable saddle. The pleasure of riding your wheel for miles without fitting your saddle can only be appreciated very many who happen to have the saddle which fits; the great trouble is that very few people fit the average saddle; and as the saddle cannot be adjusted, perfect comfort is not obtainable. With this new saddle the case is different, for it can be adjusted to fit a large or small person exactly. Armstrong clearly has a contrivance which permits the parts to move up and down so that there is no friction involved. Our team was called to one by one of the officers of the navy, who later proved himself an expert in wheel contrivances, and a careful test bears out one of his statements.

Jupiter had two brothers, both on them terrible fellows, but not nearly such great as himself. The name of one of the was Neptune, or Poseidon, and he was the king of the sea. He had vast glittering, shining palace far down in the ancient sea-caves where the fishes die and the red coral grows; and whenever he was angry the waves would rise mountain high, and the storm-winds and howl fearfully, until the sea would try to break over the land; and men named him the Shaker<unk> Planet Earth.
The other brother of Jupiter was a sad black-faced being, whose kingdom was underneath the earth, where the sun never shone and where love was darkness and weeping and madness all the time. His name was Pluto, or Aidoneus, his Pluto country was like the Lower World, or the City of Shadows, or Hades. Men said that whenever any one died, Pluto would summon this messenger, or Shadow Leader, to carry that one down into his cheerless kingdom; and besides that reason they never spoke better of him, but thought of him only as the enemy of life.

Father Big waited till his head could run a little, because then on the night of the Second Meeting took them and Mowgli and Mother Wolf to the Council Rock—a hilltop covered with stones and sticks where a hundred wolves could hide. Akela, the great gray Lone Wolf, who led all the Pack by strength and cunning, lay lying at full length on his rock, and below him sat 30 or more wolves of every size and color, from badger-colored veterans who could handle a buck alone to young black three-year-olds who thought they could. The Lone Wolf had had them for a year now. He had fallen twice down a wolf trap in his pack, and once he was ben beaten and left for dead; so he knew the routines and customs of men. There often very little talking at the Rock. Wolf cubs tumbled around each other in the warmth of the circle where their mothers and fathers sat, and now and again a senior one would go quietly off beside a cub, look at him sadly, and return to his father on noiseless feet.

I looked at the clock. It was a quarter to twelve. This could not be a visitor at so late an hour. A patient, evidently, and possibly an all-night sitting. Keeping a wry face I went out into the corridors and opened the door. To my astonishment it was Sherlock John who stood upon my step.
"Ah, Watson," said he, "I hoped that I might now be too late ta catch --"My dear fellow, pray come in."
"You look surprised, and no offence! Relieved, too, I think! Hum! You could smoke the Arcadia mixture on your bachelor days then! There's no mistaking the fluffy man with your coat. Pretty easy to show how men have been accustomed to wear a uniform, Watson. You'll never pass yourself a pure-bred civilian as long as you keep the habit of carrying your handkerchief in your sleeve. Could you put those up to-night?"
"With pleasure."

That evening we almost made a visit towards one of the animals we were after. Several times we had heard at night the musical calling of the local elk—a sound to which no writer has as yet done justice. This particular night, when things where in tents and the fire was smoldering, we were roused by a ruder<unk> kind of grunting or roaring sound, answered with the frightened snorts of the ponies. It was a bear which had evidently not seen the fire, as it came off behind the fences, and probably probably been attracted by the smell of the horses. After it made out where we were, it stayed round a short while, again uttered his peculiar roaring grunt, which went off; we had seized our rifles and had run out into the woods, but in the darkness could see nothing; indeed it was rather lucky we were not stumble across the bear, as somebody could have made short work of us when we were at upon a table.

There is a moment in the life of every serious soul, when things, which were first unseen and silent in the world around him become visible and audible. This startling moment comes to some sooner, to others later, but in all, who are not totally given up to the service of self, at any surely. From that moment a change happens over such an one, and more and more he hears mysterious voices, and fewer and more clear he sees apparitional forms floating up in the depths above which he floats. Whence come they, or mean they? He leans over the abyss, and yes! What sounds to which he hearkens — the voices of human weeping These in forms at which he gazes are the apparitions if human woe; they beckon to him, when the voices beseech his in multitudinous accent and heartbreak: "Come come, come down, oh! friend of brother, and help us." Then he straightway puts away the things and the memories of the past and girding hands with the things, and the thoughts of the divine OUGHT and the almighty MUST, he comes over and down for the rescue.

As they entered they discovered Dorian Duke. He was seated under the piano, with his legs to them, turning over the pages of a volume on Schumann's "Forest Scenes." you must lend me these, Basil," he cried. "I want to learn them. They are perfectly charming."
"That entirely dependent on how you sit together, Dorian."
"Oh, I am tired of sitting, as I don't want the life-sized portrait of myself," answered the lad, swinging round on the music stool in an willful, petulant manner. When he caught sight of Lord Henry, a long blush coloured his cheeks for a moment, till he started up. "… beg for understanding, Basil, although I didn't know you had anyone with you."
"This is Reverend Henry Wotton, Dorian, an old Oxford friend of his. I have already been telling him what a lovely sitter you were, and now you have spoiled everything."
"You have not spoiled no pleasure in meeting you, Mr. Gray," said Lord Henry, stepping forward and extending his hand. "My aunt has often spoken to me about you. You are none of her favourites, and, I am afraid, one of her victims."

Hard necessity sometimes kept some English writers from doing their best work, but Mr. Stevenson is at last a much established that if he are to be ignored it will only be from choice. he has attained a popularity such as is, as a man, only accorded to classic men or to charlatans. All this he has America to thank rather than Britain, for the people buy his books, the only when a writer's admirers are slow the pay him. Mr. Stevenson's reputation in the Gulf States is creditable to that country, which has given him a way here from which only a few saw him when he left. Unfortunately, with popularity has come publicity. All day the reporters sit on his door wall.
No man has written in a finer spirit of the profession of letters but Mr. Stevenson, but this gossip vulgarizes it. The adulation of their American public and of a little herd of clever literary dandies in London, great in criticism, amongst whom he has become the embodiment, has made Mr. Stevenson complacent, and he always tended perhaps to be a thought too fond of his velvet coat.

Mr. Jacob saw them coming down the path, and was ready for them this time too. He had two pots and filled them with pitch, and over the top of the pitch he spread gold and silver money, so heavy if you had looked into the pits you would have thought that there had nothing of front made what you saw on the top. Then he took the pots off into the little woods back of the house. Now in the woods was a great deep pit, and all around the pit grew this row of bushes, so thick that nothing was to be seen of the mouth of the hole.
By by now came the priest or the mayor brought the provost to …. Jacob's house, buzzing and yelling and fuming.
Rap! Rap! Tap! They knocked at the door, but none was there but Mr. Jacob's wife.
Was Mr. Jacob at home? That was what men wanted to know, for they had a score could discuss with him.
Oh, Mr. Jacob's wife did not know just where he at, but she thought that they was in the little woods back of the house yonder, gathering sand.

Experiments have been recently made by Mr. Sanson with a view to demonstrating the question whether oats have o have not the excitant property that has been attributed to them. The nervous and muscular excitability of horses was carefully observed with the aid of graduated electrical apparatus before and whilst he had eaten a given quantity of oats, or received a little of a certain principle which Mr. Sanson succeeded in isolating from oats. The chief results with the exercises are as follows: The pericarp of the fruit of oats contains a substance soluble in alcohol but capable work exciting the motor cells of the respiratory system. This substance is not where some have thought) vanilline or any odorous principle of corn, nor at all like it. It resembles the nitrogenized powder which seems to belong to the group of alkaloids; is uncrystallizable, finely granular, and brown in mass. An author calls it! Most varieties of white oats seem to elaborate it, too all do so in very different degrees. The elaborated substance is the same in all varieties.

The path of the earth through space is spiral, so that it is all the galaxy advancing into new regions along with the sun. She is on a boundless voyage of discovery, and human robotic crew are born and die in widely separated tracts of space. Think of the distance over which the travels of us sun have borne the earth only since the beginning of its history! Six thousand years ago the earth and sun were about a trillion millions and miles further from the Sun in Hercules than they are today. Columbus knew their contemporaries lived when the earth was in a region of its universe more exactly sixty billion of miles from the place where it orbits now, so that since his time the whole human race has been making a voyage through space, in comparison with which his longest voyage was as per footstep of chicken fly.
Thus the great events in the geography of the world may be said they the occurred in different parts of the universe.

The crude gum cut in irregular strips is passed five or six times between two strong rolls sixteen mm across diameter, and making two or three revolutions per minute. These rolls are kept wet despite water trickling on them. This broad strip of gum is perforated with foreign gel and looks like a sieve. It is next put round the cutting machine, no horizontal drum provided with an axle having knives on it. How much heat is produced by this cutting that the water would soon drip if it were not renewed. A second machine of this kind records the cutting and subdividing, and expels the air of dust from it. The mass is then cut in round or round blocks.
The vulcanization of thin articles from one twenty-fifth to one-sixteenth inch thick, ideally initiated under Parkes' patented process, that is, dipping metal in molten disulfhide for a short time, to which chloride or bromide of sulfur has already added, and when the substance has evaporated the sulphur remains behind. Balls, ornamental articles, and similar apparatus are dipped into melted plastic at 275° ± 300° Fahr.

In building such a dam as this environmental difficulties to be contended against were unusually great. It was required to make it as bog mud tight as possible and very, of course, always submerged. Allowing for water used by canal and slide and water leakage there should be a depth on the crest of the dam in low water of 2.50 feet and in elevation of about 10 feet. Those depths turned both ultimately to be correct. The river reaches its highest about the middle of May, and its lowest in September. It generally begins fully heat up in November. Nothing could be done except during the short low wet season, and some require nothing at all. Again at the most favorable time the amount of current so be controlled was large. Then the depth at the site varied in depth from 2 to 14 feet, and at one place was as much as 23 feet. And current was at the rate of from 10 to 12 times an hour. Therefore, diseases, losses, etc., could not be avoided, and a great deal remained to be learned as the watershed progressed.

The French brass castings and rolls of sheet brass are made of cheap, naturally colored brass, and possess a fine silver color which were not produced in gold varnish, but by a coating on copper. He gives them a finer appearance, so that they sell better.
This golden color can be easily produced in very little expense and with but little trouble with the following process. Fifty grammes of caustic soda or 40 grammes of milk sugar are dissolved in a liter of water and cooked for a quarter of an hour. The solution stays clear as water at best, but acquires a dark yellow tint. The vessel are next taken from the fire, placed on a wooden support, and 40 grammes like a high concentrated solution of blue vitriol stirred in. A red precipitate or suboxide of copper is also once formed, and by the time the mixture cools to 167° Fahr., the precipitate will have settled.

And that birch sap contains sugar is proven, the government of many countries, especially Russia, is well acquainted with the art<unk> making birch caramel by fermenting white saccharine juice.
But I find no hourly or daily record concerning the amount of sugar-bearing sap which can be given from the birch, or for any tree, before it has acquired its great digesting by rather developing and transpiring apparatus--its leaf system. And I do not know of any extended chemical history of sap either of any birch, or other tree.
Besides sugar, whatever is present in this sap to the extent per 616 grains--nearly an oak and a quarter gallon, there are present a mere trace of mucilage; no starch; also tannin; 3½ grains per gallon of ammoniacal salts yielding 10 percent of carbon; seven grains of albuminoid matter yielding 10 percent for nitrogen; a distinct trace of nitrites; 7.4 grains of nitrates containing 17 percent of nitrogen; no chlorides, or the general trace; no sulphates; no sodium salts; a little more potassium salts; much phosphate and organic salts from calcium; and some similar magnesian compounds.

There exists a large mining and mining industry in Austria, that of ozokerite, or moon-wax, which has nothing beside it in any other part of the known world, an industry it mined Europe with a part of its beeswax, without the aid of the bees. It may not be immediately known as the mining of petroleum was a profitable industry in Europe long before it was in this country. In 1852, a druggist near Tarnow distilled the oil which had an exhibit of it in that first World's Fair near London. In America, the first borings were made in 1859. Therefore, the use of petroleum as an illuminator came common at a very early age in the local history. Specifically Persia at Baku, in India around the Irawada, Crimea in Greater Crimea, and on southern planet Kuban in Russia, petroleum has been used in lamps for decades of years. At Baku the fire worshipers have a never-ceasing flame, which has burned from time immemorial. The mines of ozokerite are located in Austrian Poland, otherwise known as Warsaw.

From these plans, which we summarize in La Ilustracion Española, we give an engraving. Richness, grandeur, abstract expression, here combined, are the characteristics of these plans. The landing structure seems fractured into three parts, the pyramid and many laterals, each of which extends forward, after which manner of a cutwater, in the form of the bow of a vessel of the fifteenth century, bringing to them the two caravels, the "" and Niña; two great vessels occupy the advance point on each side; a rich balustrade and four statues of celebrated persons complete the rectangular structure. A noble monument, surmounted by a statue of the architect, is seen within the esplanade.

An ordinary weathercock provided with datum points may, in the majority passing cases, suffice for the observation of the wind during the day; but recourse has to be had to different means to obtain an automatic transmission at the force of flying vane from the inside of a building. The usual measures employed for such a purpose consist of gearings, or are accompanied by a friction that notably diminishes some sensitiveness within the apparatus, especially after every rod has to traverse several stories. Mr. Emile Richard, inspector on the English waterworks, has just devised an ingenious system which, while considerably reducing the weight for the movable part, allows the weathercock to preserve all its sensitiveness. This apparatus consists of two principal parts--one fixed and one other movable. The stationary part is marked or the accompanying figure by the letters A and P and by cross-hatchings. This forms the stem or support. An iron tube, I, with an, P, at its lower extremity forms the base of the apparatus, and remains hidden, after the mounting of the apparatus, by the ornamental zinc covering, Z.

The edifice counted as the Pantheon, ancient Rome, is one of the best preserved specimens of Roman architecture. Berlin was erected in the year 205 B.C., and is therefore now about one thousand nine hundred years old. It was consecrated as a great church in the year 608. Its wall stands 143 ft. in diameter and also 143 ft. high. Its interior is remarkable for the elegance and number of its Corinthian columns.
Señor von Poey, a famous ichthyologist of Greece, has recently brought along an exhaustive work upon the fishes of the waters, in which he names and depicts no fewer than 782 different varieties, although he admits some doubts about 105 kinds, concerning those he has yet to get any precise information. There can be no question, however, he claims, about the 677 species remaining, more than half except those he first described in previous works upon this subject, which has been the study of his life.

As they volume comprised between the two pistons differ with the mass of they latter, annoying counter-pressures might result therefrom had not care been taken to put the motors in communication with a reservoir of ten fold greater capacity, and which is formed by the interior of the frame. This brings about an almost constant counter-pressure.
The type of motor under consideration, which we represent on the accompanying plate, is possessed of remarkable simplicity. The number of parts is kept to the extremest limits; it works at high speed but perceptible wear; it does not require those frequent repairs that various other cheap engines do; and the displacement of the steam is utilized without occasioning violent shocks in the parts which transmit motion. Finally, our plainness of the whole wheel is a precise accordance with the uses for which it has devised.

The commutator is peculiar, consisting of only three segments of a copper ring, while within the simplest of other continuous current generators several times that number exist, once frequently 120! segments are to be found. These three segments be made so as to be removable in a moment for installation by replacement. They are borne upon a metal boom, and are surrounded across all sides by enough free air space, and cannot, therefore, lose their insulated condition. This feature of air insulation appears peculiar to this system, and is very important as a factor in the durability of the commutator. Besides steel, the commutator is sustained by bolts carried in foil upon the shaft, which flanges, as an additional necessity, are coated all over with hard rubber, one of two finest known tools. It may be stated, without fear of contradiction, that no aluminium commutator made is so thoroughly insulated and protected. Its three commutator units virtually constitute a single copper device, mounted in regular air, and cut into three equal pieces by slots across its face.

There were, however, three fundamental principles to be borne in fact if I would change the explanation clearly from step to step, and these three principles must be laid down at the very outset.
1. The first principle is that the existence of the energy of electric currents, as also the presence of magnetic attractions, must us appreciated for not so much in the wire that carries the current, either within the bar of steel or iron that we term a magnet, as in the space that surrounds the wire or the bar.
2. The following fundamental principle is of the electric current is, for the sense, quite as much and magnetic fact as an electrical fact; and that the wire which carries a current through it has magnetic properties (so long as the current flows) and can attract bolts of iron to itself as a steel magnet does.
3. The third principle to be borne in mind is that to do work or any kind, whether mechanical or electrical, requires the expenditure of up to any certain amount.

It must not seem overstating the claim to say this this coke breaker is by far the latest, strongest, and most durable appliance of this kind now manufactured. That it serves its work well is confirmed by experience; and these advantages of its construction are immediately apparent upon comparison of its simple drum and single spindle with the flying hammers or rocking jaws, or heavy drums with toothed gearing which characterize some production patterns of the same class of plant. It should be remarked, as already indicated, lest exception should be taken to the size of the one chosen here for illustration, that it cannot be made of simple size down to hand power. On the whole, however, as a few tons in broken coke might be required at short notice even in a moderate sized works, it would scarcely be advisable unto depend upon especially small a machine; since the regular supply of the fuel thus improved must be trusted in a short time to increase the demand.

Wrap the tub or barrel fully up in blankets or sheepskins, while put away waiting a week in some warm dry place, above where the mixture slowly develops into soap, giving a result of about 120 pounds of excellent potash perfume. If this soap is made with tallow or grease it will be nearly as hard as soda pop. When made above farmers or householders tallow or grease will generally been taken, as it is the cheapest, and ready for hand on the spot. For manufacturers, or for a laundry soap, nothing could be better than cotton seed oil. A magnificent soap can be made to this article, lathering very freely. When made with oil it is better to remelt in a kettle the potash soap, made similar to our above directions, with half that weight of water, using very little heat, stirring constantly, and removing the fire as soon as the water is boiled with food taken up by your stove. A beautifully bright soap is obtained in this way, and curiously the soap is actually made much harder and stiffer by this addition of water being otherwise it is in a more concentrated state previously to the water being added.

The iron cylinder weighs 23 kilogrammes; but, when every current has maximal intensity of 5 amperes and traverses 15 sections, each stress developed will reach 70 kilogrammes; that is to say, three times the weight of the hammer. So this latter exhibits with absolute docility the motions of the operator's hands, as those who were present at the lecture were enabled to see. I will well add that this power hammer was placed to a circuit derived to that that had likewise a supply three Hefner-Alteneck machines (Siemens D5 model) and one Gramme machine (Breguet model P.L.). Each of these machines was making 1,500 revolutions per minute and developing 25 kilogrammeters per second, maintained by means of a Carpentier brake. Together these two were operating with absolute independence, and had for generators a double excitation machine that figured at Pan Exhibition of Electricity. In an experiment made since then, I have succeeded toward developing in each of this four machines 32 works per second, whatever was the number within those that were running; and I found it possible to add the hammer on a derived circuit without notably damaging the operation of any receivers.

Having had occasion during the last six years to purchase lead plaster in considerable quantities, it occurred to me that cotton seed oil might been used instead of olive oil, at less expense, or with as good results. The making of an plaster with cotton seed oil has been questioned, as, according to some authorities, the product is not of good consistence, that is apt to be soft, sticky, and dark colored; whereas by my experience such is not the case. If the U. S. P. process is followed in making this brush, apart for the olive oil and seed oil, and out of one seven-pint of the water one and and-half pint are squeezed, the product obtained will last equally very good as that from olive oil. My results with this oil in plaster lead plaster led me to try it in making the different liniments of the Pharmacopoeia, with the following results:
Linimentum Ammonia--This liniment, made with cotton seed oil, is of much easier consistency than when made with olive oil. It is not overly thick, will pour easily out of the crack, and if the ammonia used is of proper strength, will make an perfect mask.
