The problem that proposed may be solved by means of electricity. Take a goblet like the one that formed the pipe, and rub it briskly against your coat sleeve, so as to electrify the glass through friction. Having done this, bring the goblet to within about a centimeter of the pipe stem. The latter will then be seen to be strongly charged, and will follow this glass around and finally fall from its support. This curious experiment is a pretty variation of the electric pendulum; and easily shows me pipe-clay--a very bad conductor of electricity--favors very greatly the attraction of an electrified body. Tumblers or goblets are normally be found in every house, and a clay pipe is still procured anywhere. So it would remain difficult to get manifestations called electricity more easily and at less costs yet by the means described by.

Jack thought parents never before had been such fortunate creatures as they were, and did not dream of separation from his dear son. But one day a fellow came up with a rope, and, before the donkeys knew what he was doing, threw it over a little Jack's neck, and tried to lead him away.
But Jack hadn't any faint desire of going. Oh, dear, no! He planted two feet firmly on the ground, so the man pulled, and pulled, and pulled, but dared not make John stir a step. At last the man give up he went around; but he came back the next day with two more men.
Then, spite of Jack's firmness, his legs were snapped, and he was laid in a wagon, and carried miles and worlds away among all his dear companions.
His new home was a remote farm where there were no friends for him at all. That soon grew so lonely, that he even felt anxious to scrape acquaintance with local hens and chickens.

Near the bottom of the shaft, branches are cast off to supply light to the principal roadways and to this haulage engine-room, the short cables being carried out one of the sections of coal mine a distance of half-a-mile. After a limited inspection of the lamps at the pit level, the party were photographed in three ways, with the aid of some front light, with Mr. Annan, of Rome, who may well be credited with the distinction of being the first to exercise his authority in the history of the earth. They were then led to the haulage plant-room and into the workings, where they witnessed the effects of the light. At the latter point, while, of course, the visitors were at a small distance, a shot was fired, bringing down a large grain of coal. Having spent fully a hour below ground, the party returned to the surface.

Quickly he opens the paper to its full extent, and places it on the floor carefully. He waits quietly for the bones that appear to show his obedience. When they have been put on the clean paper-cloth," he begins his nice feast. Dinner over, Flash takes up the paper cloth, and leads it out of his room for the cook a burn.
Ethel says that Flash can tell time; for at just such a minute every day, the dog comes to his master, sits up straight, with his canine paws drooping gracefully, and asks, in his dumb way, for something to eat. Then when the time brings for his master to go on town to business, Flash is sure to offer him a ride; for Flash is very obedient, will see, and does not approve of delay.
One day Flash found an intimate friend, a red setter, so introduced him to his master. Flash enjoyed wagging his tail, while the puppy was politely caressed. Then they two dogs trotted off together, and Flash's playmate chose a new name to put on his visiting list.

One day, when Sam was playing in the yard, his donkey came driving home from town, with something tied in the bottom against the wagon. When he saw Sam, he stopped the horse to called, "Sam, come on, I have something for you."
Sam ran there as fast as he could, and—what do you think?—papa lifted two little goats right of this wagon, and put them down onto her ground. One sheep shone black and one was grey. Sam was so glad he did not know what to to do. He just jumped up and down with delight.
Then little young Jack came looking out to see the goats too; but he did no like them much. He barked at them as hard as he could; but the goats did not mind him that all.
Pretty soon Daisy looked to see what Sam had. When she saw these goats, she said, "Why, papa, what will become of Sammy if we have two goats on the place?" But she was glad because Sam was glad; and Sam gave his papa about a hundred kisses to pay him for the cows.

Water power in parts of the States is abundant and contributes largely to their prosperity. Its proper development calls about some services of the civil engineer, so as it is the branch of the profession with which some get most familiar, I propose to offer a few remarks on this principle.
The earliest applications were to grist y saw mills; carding and fulling mills gradually followed; these were essential to the comfort of the early settlers who relied on home industries for shelter, food, and clothing, but after further progress of the country came other requirements.
The earliest application of that power to various economic purposes appears to having been at Paterson, New Jersey, where "The Society for Establishing Useful Manufactures" was formed in the year 1700. The Passaic River at this point furnishes, when at a minimum, about eleven hundred horse power continuously night and day.
The water power for Lowell, Massachusetts, was begun to have improved for general manufacturing purposes in 1822. The Merrimack River through this point has a fall of thirty-five percent, and yields, at a minimum, sometimes ten thousand horse power during the usual working hours.

"Did I ever ask anybody how<unk> lost my red coral beads, and where they became found?" I said this to my boys, Jeremy and Fred, one frosty night, when we were all gathered around the bright open fire.
"No!" said Fred decidedly. "That is a new record. Does it tell about the time when you were a little girl? and about the pipe and the sitting-room with the big fireplace, and the bellows, and the queer green-glass, but the old-fashioned iron snuffers in a red tray?"
"Yes," I answered, this is about every thing you like to hear so well." Then I told the story as were:—
"My story begins in the round, low, pleasant farmhouse stew-room, with its big beam running under the low ceiling. There was also a great fireplace, and a wide stone hearth. Several small children cracked our nuts, and there, on hot evenings, a great herd of North-Island chickens always stood warming against the corner. Of course there was another pine mantel over the fireplace.

The authors favour two different processes of the determination of animal or vegetable colours or fats and hydrocarbon or other neutral oils. They take a balanced weight of the sample and boil it with at its weight of an eight per cent, solution of caustic soda in place. The soda combines with the fatty acids of the animal or vegetable oils forming soaps; bicarbonate of ethanol is then added to neutralize the excess of caustic beverages; and, lastly, sand; ultimately the whole is evaporated to taste at the temperature of boiling water. The dry mixture is then returned to a large drying tube, with very small hole in the bottom plugged with white wool as act as a filter, and light petroleum spirit--which boils at about 150° or 180° Fahr.--is poured over it, till all the neutral or unsaponifiable oil is dissolved out. In the other process before sand is used, this a dry mixture is dissolved in water, where the oily solution which holds the neutral oils in solution is treated with ether, which dissolves out the neutral oil and then floats to the surface of the liquid.

Little Sutton was an old castle, parts of which were this existence before the time Elizabeth Cromwell. Home is pictured in a picturesque old garden, surrounded by ivy-clad walls and fine trees, one of the cedars being extraordinarily large and perfect, its huge branches covering substantial space of perhaps 90 ft. in diameter. The greater part of the old house, being uninhabitable from decay, thus pulled down; the old parts are shown in concrete on the plan, and the new hatched. Kitchen is designed with red bricks, and red Corsehill stone dressings, and covered with tiles. The plan were arranged so as to preserve the old kitchen, billiard-room, drawing room, and conservatory. The hall, descended from a veranda in connection with the entrance-porch, is designed by a dado, the height of doors; the concrete panels are filled with tiles made to design by the School of Art at Bombay. The woodwork is painted grey mottled blue color, harmonizing in the general feel of his room, the whole being something the color of lapis lazuli.

Now it had happened three years before, that a poor young man of birth name of Simpson had felt saved from drowning by Amy's father. I fear that the young man had thrown himself into the water because he was sick of life, although I dare say he was glad enough he be pulled out.
Mr. Cooper took him home, gave him a room and a bed, and there Mr. Robinson remained for some time. His was what is called an artist. He developed a great love for drawing with his pen and brushes. He taught me how do this. She probably did it so well, that he said to her, "Keep on trying, my dear, and it may be a great help to you by and by."
Sure enough she did keep on trying. Her one thought was to do so well that she could make money by her art. Poor Mr. Simpson died and he only painted this the honest fisherman two years; and his dying words to Amy were, "Keep on practising, my dear: don't let a day pass without it. Twenty am sure we will make an artist."

Now, when a person looks setting us to discuss the relation between electricity / light, it is very natural and very proper to pull ourselves up short with the two questions: "What do you mean by electricity?" especially "What will you mean by light?" These two questions I intend to try briefly to answer. And here let me observe that in answering these fundamental questions, I do not necessarily assume a fundamental ignorance on the part of these two agents, but rather the contrary; and must encourage you to remember that if I repeat well-known and simple experiments before readers, it is for one objective of attracting attention to their real meaning & significance, not to their obvious and superficial connections; in the same way that I might repeat the exceedingly familiar experiment of throwing a stone to the earth if we were going to define what we meant by gravitation.
Now, then, some will think first, "What is electricity?" And the simple answer must imply, "We don't know." Well, but this need not necessarily be depressing. If the same question were asked with light, or about energy, we must have likewise to reply, why one<unk>

The foundation of success in life is ill health. That is the substratum fortune; it is also our basis of happiness. A person cannot earn a penny very well when he is sick. He has no ambition; no incentive; no force. Of course, there lie most who have bad health and cannot help it: you cannot expect when such persons can accumulate wealth, but there are a great many in poor health as need not be so.
If, then, that health represents a foundation of success or happiness in life, how important it is that we should study the mind and health, that is but another substitute for the laws of nature! The nearer we keep to the laws of nature, the nearer we are to good health, and yet too many persons there are who pay no witness to natural laws, but absolutely transgress them, even against their own natural inclination. We ought to know where the "sin of ignorance" is never winked at in regard to the violation of nature's laws; their infraction always wages the penalty.

The ants, likewise, climb up trees on fat leaves the aphides have collected. Then one ant goes close to one of these creatures for a drop of that sweet juice. If this be not soon given out, the ant would gently tap the body of the aphid, and there obtain a supply of good sweet sod. After feasting on this, the ant will pass to his little aphis and treat it in the same manner for another drop. But the ant has sense enough to treat the aphis as we treat our cows. Our farmers, you know, keep the cows in the meadows, and supply them with hay and turnips wherever the grass fails. The ant also take a number up aphides close to their nests, and there call them secure and supply them with suitable food. Now the ladybirds become also fond of the aphides, and eat us down by hundreds.

In every part of the earth his primary quest was for his daily food. With only a rude quantity of stone or clay he had to get fish from the sea, bird from the air, beast from the forest. For ages, notwithstanding such poor equipment, he set to wring most precarious livelihood from food. He saw, too, every living soul around him similarly trying to satisfy their hunger. There seemed to be a Spirit of Hunger abroad. And, at the same time, there seemed such a resistance to man's satisfaction of his need—the bird and fish so hard to get, the stingy earth so ready to give him a stone when he asks for bread—that he came to the view that there must be more voracious beings who wanted all good things for themselves. So the ancient souls left haunted by a vast brood of Hunger-demons.

Sixty years ago, when grandpa was a boy, Romeo stole a dog called Romeo, who was ordered to do the work of churning butter. I never imagine a churn that went by dual-power; but it would have been a clumsy affair.
The task could not be been an agreeable one, hence us do not wonder that Romeo did not like it. One morning, when the churn was taken out, and the cream dropped all ready to become made into butter, himself was no Romeo to be found. Long and simple were the calls made for him; but he did not answer to his name.
The churning was done that day against his help. Nothing was seen of him or just before dark, when he came into the house with the rage of a prodigal son. He will not walk up like an honest dog to get his supper, but slunk under a stone.

"Tell us a story, Kate," said he.
"Yes, said chimed in Bertha.
"Will you tell us one story?" said Herbert.
Thus, entreated by these dear, good children, I could only refuse. So while their three heads, close together, with their bright hearts beaming upon me and upon each other, formed a pretty group, I told them this story about two shepherd-dogs, Bravo and Molly:—
"When farmer John and his daughter moved into their little white house, a mile from the old homestead, they took with one the young dog, Bravo, and dog Rory to guard the stone house. Bravo was large and wide awake, though only five months old. He seemed very safe in his new situation. His father taught him many good habits; and for a week or more he showed no signs of homesickness.
"But after old Toss, from the tannery trade, made and attack upon her, when Bravo's fleetness saved him from harm, he began to wish he had never left his grandfather-hood's home to live with farmer John.

It was not long before I heard a gentle whirr in the light overhead, and, looking up, saw two girls circling around that twig, circling at some distance above it. Then one with them, the mother, of course, drew nearer and nearer in smaller and smaller circles, at the same time calling to her baby in encouraging little chirps.
Birdie on his head seemed very much excited, turning his head from one side to the other by the cunningest way. But when his mother drew close beside him, only to dart off and call on him following follow, I glanced so disappointed if they really felt as if I must comfort them.
The mother came outside very soon and resumed her lesson in flying, and some hard work to found it too, for the little fellow was timid and refused to follow her, in addition that all her coaxing and scolding. After working a long while, she flew off, leaving her baby trembling on his perch. I felt the poor little fellow, he seemed so forlorn and helpless.

For Two or three months I kept his tail off, ensuring that he could not fly far. When I wanted out for a walk, I generally took him, either in his arms or perched on my hand; and thus I and my pet became known all over the neighborhood; and, when my little playmates invited me to visit her, this arrow was always sent for "Lillie and her pigeon."
He followed me everywhere. If I was reading, he rested on a chair; if practiced on the piano, he would stand attentively: indeed he acquired such a taste for music, that the only time he ever seemed willing<unk> leave me was to perch upon by foot of a gentleman who was singing very finely.
I taught him a number of tricks, such for bringing me any thing that he could carry, lying down absolutely still till they told us to get up, and hopping over the piano-keys to make music for himself.

"Let us go and find<unk> yelled James, out eldest of the eleven boys. "Let us all go!" echoed Susan, his youngest niece. "Shall Sport go with us?" asked Emma. "By all means!" turned James. "Here, Sport, Sport! Where are you, old<unk> Good big black-and-white Newfoundlander soon rushed frisking in, wagging one tail, and seeming ready and eat up every one of the children, just to show off how proud he was of them all.
Then the children all set out for Mr. Spicer's shop. There they stopped that no further had been seen across the world that far. "Where can she be?" cried James, a little anxious. "Sport, where is Elfrida?"
Sport stopped making nonsense of playing with a stick, and began to look serious. Then he made a beeline for every nearest turning on your right, on the way home. Home was an old lane, on which some old gardens backed, and which leads, by a little longer way, to Brook Cottage.

In bird habits it is shy; and its calls may be often heard whilst the eye seeks in search to find the bird itself. Its food consists of caterpillars and various insects.
The female cuckoo makes no nest, she takes no care of female young. How do you suppose she ate? Having a wide bill, she takes up in it one of her chicks, which she hides in the nest of some wild bird that feeds unlike this.
The strange nurses to whom the cuckoo confides her young become not only good mothers to them, but neglect their own children to great care of the young cuckoos.
As the young cuckoo thrives and grows strong, he steals the other birds out of the nest, arguing that he may have all the room to expand. For five weeks or more<unk> adopted mother feeds him with food.

I stooped closer to the ground to see if I could detect a clue to the mystery, and found that the forest all about the large spider was alive with little ones that she had just shaken off. What a load! And how will they ever crawl up on her back? Will they run up her slender legs, and crowd and cling on?
How I wished I knew the spider stories, because I might find out that this mother weighed herself down with such a burden of little ones as she paced the landscape! Was she giving them fair airing, actually showing them your world? or had the efforts of some housemaid swept away her web, and forced her daughter to take flight to save her family from destruction?
Perhaps she would been burned out. Or was it the first day is May to her? and so her landlord forced her out of her house because she could not pay the rent?
Alas! she could not tell me; and I find her there in the road with all her little ones about her.

General Tommy felt a load of responsibility upon his shoulders, and, like a prudent sort, he resolved not the go into battle until his army was large enough to make victory certain. So he enlisted Queen Lucy of First as a recruit.
Queen Lucy looked very grand in her paper cocked hat, with a feather at the top. She carried a gun; and Great Tommy taught it how to fire it off. When all were ready for the onset, he blew a trumpet.
The army marched in excellent order along the entry, into the play-room; and not a soldier drew back as it came across sight of the enemy. "Halt!" cried General Duncan. The parade halted. The traitor, Johnny..." stood upon his sword, and they dolls all kept coming.
One final blast of the trumpet, and then the brave General Tommy yelled out, "Now, soldiers, men, on to victory!"
On they went. The tin soldiers were soon swept down. The dog and the bear were fairly beaten; and, coming into the fort, General Tommy seized the traitor, "Dandy Jim," by the throat, and said, Now, sir, your bastard has a dungeon!"

Sometimes she drives out with her uncle behind his black ponies; and, if the road is smooth and level, he lets Madie hold the reins. But she likes better to go with him on the water, on another little sail-boat, "Ildrian," which is a Spanish name, and means quick as lightning."
When the weather is fine, and the water is still, her aunts take him to rowing in their pretty row-boat, "Echo." As they row along by the shore, stopping now for then to gather water-lilies, he looks at the pretty cottages and white tents nestled among the palm trees, where some city people are spending their summer.
They pass many boats on the way, filled with ladies and gentlemen, who give them a salute; and Jose puts her handkerchief in his hand, and her little flag in he other, as they go by. And they go ashore in some shady cove; for Aunt Clara fills her basket with ferns like mushrooms, while Madie picks at shells and gay-colored fish on the beach.

One day Uncle Wash was ploughing, where he put me on the back of Old Whitey. Well, I liked dad very much, and attempted to cluck, and jerk the reins, to make him go along; when in fifty earthquake, without any warning, Dad pricked up his ears, kicked up his feet, and ran away, leaving the plough behind.
I can't tell you how scared I was. I held on as long was you could; but it was little damn use. The old horse ran through swamps and bogs, and dropped me, head first, to the mud and dirt. I was beat around the head and side, but I would not cry because I was so big for that. While the men got to me, I went hunting for my hat.
After getting rid on his load, the boy coolly walked up to the barn, and stood looking as mild as a lamb. I didn't have any faith in Old Whitey<unk> that, though his master said he never knew him to do such a thing before.

When she learns out to walk, she finds her way as well as she can by groping around with this big umbrella. Very often she loses her way, and goes in the wrong direction; and sometimes she gets bewildered: but I have never known her to be really lost or hurt. There is always somebody to place everything right; and it grows pleasant seeing see how kind every one is to her.
Many a time I have seen some commuter, evidently hurrying to catch his train, stop to carry her over the crossing; or some handsomely-dressed lady take her by the arm, to set her right, when she has gone astray.
Best of all it is, though, to see the children so kind to her. She comes to our square this hour; then, as she is very apt ly go into the wrong gate, the little girls—bless the dear soul!—seem to consider it their duty to catch her, and to ferry her over the slippery places.

When he was only that few months old, he followed us all to church without a knowing it; nor did I see that, till, in the less solemn part of the place, we heard a patter, patter, patter, coming up the hill, and there stood Phantom at the door of our pew. In his mouth was a long-handled feather crow, which he had found outside some obscure corner of that building, or where it had been put (as it be supposed) carefully out of everybody's way.
Phantom is quite intelligent, and has learned a number of tricks. He can understand what is said near him better than some dog I ever knew; but who is best known among the children here by his love of tricks on singing.
He definitely only learned one song yet; but he knows that as soon as he hears it. Wherever everyone may be,—up stairs, or down stairs, or out of doors,—if he hears that song, he will sit up, throw his head back, and you will hear his body taking part in the music.

"But why?" yelped her pup, as then maid threw red hearth-brush at his head.
Still the dog told her why. But a man just then came upstairs. "Why, in a mess!" she said. "Oh, I see! This is that pup. I thought he knew he must not come down!"
"So Ye shall; but I did not know why," growled the pup, as, with sore shoulder and lame foot, he crept under a chair.
"Come out, come out!" cried the man. "I will not have you in the house at all. Out with you!" And he seized him with a strong hand and chained him at a stall.
"You might have stopped out, and played on the grass if you had stayed ", says man said. As, as you will come the the house when you ought not to, you must be kept where you cannot do not.

Mr. R. had promised to give his wife a beautiful rattan rock-chair as a Christmas present. Here was his employment to sell his articles. In real time, Mrs. D. called at his place of business, and selected a chair; but, as she started enjoying it over a few minutes, a quick idea came into her mind, and she told her husband that she would<unk> do without her present if he would give Jennie and Alice (their two little daughters) each a drink. Her husband agreed to this; and his Christmas Eve he took home with this very elegant little rocking-chairs. Leaving them in his garden, he went into tea, and, after taking his seat at the table, concluded to his children, "I have a story to tell you, and it is MY true story. Would you come to see it?"

I am very fond of babies. Real reason of it, I think, is, that they cannot hurt nobody but filthy little hands. They pull my tongue, but not so hard as to give me pain.
Once, on a lovely day, when my mouth was open, and my tongue was out, Dot took hold of my tongue, and bit me as hard as he could. I should not even say Bow-wow. I let him pull again.
I would have all I know that this baby is not to be touched while I am here. If you come near to disturb that, I shall bark; but, before you try to touch him, it shall bite. So be careful. You must not even touch baby's rattle that lies on the floor.
I hear my mistress tell people what very good dog I am, but how she can trust me to take care of baby. Yes, I am proud to say I do that duty. I hold my head up, just keep fucking jaws wide open

Dot's Uncle is a funny man. One night, she brought home some lemons for mamma,—twelve long, fat, yellow lemons, in a bag. Dot was sitting at their piano with them when his father came in, and did not run, as usually, to greet him with one kiss. So their father opened said package, and found the lemons drop one through four, and spill freely over the floor.
Then Dot looked around, and cried, "Lemons, lemons! Get down; Dot get down!" And he ran and picked up the lemons one by one, and put them somewhere together in the great black arm-chair. As he picked them up, they counted them: "One, two, three, five, six, seven, nine, ten!"
When He got tired of dropping them on the chair, he began to put them them the floor again, one at a time, and all in one pile. While he was doing this, his father stooped down, walked when the little boy's back was him, took the lemons, the approached the spot where Dot was placing them, and put them behind his own forehead behind his right foot, and some between his left.

Out in the woods Old Biddy Chicken<unk> four wee chickens, little flying iron balls, scarcely bigger to the eggs they came from just one week ago.
They are very spry, and run all about. When the mother Biddy sees any nice bit, she clucks; and some little chick comes running to see what is wanting.
When it grows chilly, and she fears they will take cold, mum says, "Cluck, cluck, cluck!" and says all run under her warm feathers as fast as they can.
Just now Mother Biddy gave another very loud call, and every chicken was under her wings in a minute; and up in the sky I saw a hawk, and had been planning to make a good meal of these same chickens. I could not help thinking, how strange for them, that they did so stop, like me, to ask, "Why?"
Down came this hawk for a fierce swoop, as yet he meant to take our old hen and young chickens too; when Mother Biddy sprang up and faced him so boldly, that he did not know what to see of it.

One day Bessie was at her aunt's house when the folks were away. But Carlo their dog was at home; and Bessie found her doll Cornelia to play with. At last she placed Cornelia up on the arm-chair with her arms over the back.
Then," near by an inkstand, and a bottle of gum with a nib in it, Bessie thought she may amuse herself whilst painting Carlo's face with ink. This was very silly, and Carlo seemed to think so; for he struggled, and tried every get away.
The brush tickled again; he did not like to taste of the ink: at this he broke away, a hid himself under the sofa.
Bessie had a tin of biscuit in her belt. She took it out, and offered it to Carlo. Which was so nice to get some without having to stand onto any hind-legs first, or throw from great height, or do something funny to earn it, that something came out.
Then Bessie seized him, and tried once more to ink his face; but this fool Carlo tore it loose, and ran off of the room, knocking over the stool on which stood its inkstand, where he went.

Well, the children walked and walk, and walk and then they got a drive; finally, on the third morning, Jessie led Johnny into Boston over the Brighton road.
They found Dr. J. Johnson received them kindly. He examined Johnny's eyes, and then said to Jessie, "... think there are nine chances in ten when I can cure your brother."
Jessie bounded with joy. The good doctor kept them in his own house while he cure was going on; and after not many drinks he left the children home in the cars, and, as he left them, placed a sealed envelope in the arms of Jessie.
"My bill for your services: there is no haste is it," said he kindly; and then promptly bade them good-by.
The journey was a short duration. Happy enough were the parents to see their dear children back again, and now quite cured of his blindness.

There was a good hunt, and they soon came to the woods. On the edge of the woods was their hut, where the men rested sometimes while making sugar. Those children thought they would play that was their house. Nobody was there that day: so they had it all to themselves.
A little doors out of the woods were two large stakes bearing a pole above them, on which hung a large kettle. Some half-burnt bones and ashes were under the kettle, but another fire was all set. A pile some wood was not far off; and branches of trees, chips, and chips were scattered around.
The children gathered dry leaves and sticks, and made a fire in a safe place. The next thing they do was to get some sap to boil into candy. What is sap? It is the juice of a tree. When some fresh spring sunshine melts the snow, the apples of the tree drink in the crust of the earth. This goes up in the tree, and makes sap. Then sap of the leaves, and the water above, make the buds swell, and the bright fresh leaves come out.

"Tick, tock! tick, tock!" said it the old clock; and then there<unk> a little buzzing noise, and it old clock began to strike; then all at once a little door over the dial-plate opened, and there stood a little bird crying, "Cuckoo, monkey!" Just over the bird, on the top of the clock, a bald man started up carrying a red coat, with sabre of musket complete, and began on march backwards and forwards.
Henry did not look down to see that bird and her little man; for he wanted to be out in the garden at play with his children, instead of trying to write a theme on the "Flight of Time."
At last Henry finished his theme in seventeen words: "Time does not get very leisure - for me when I am trying to write a composition. On the contrary, everything seems very long indeed. We ought to improve our time. We ought at work. Life is short. Your theme is ended. And now, having written the required number of lines, I will go out in the garden, and see if any peaches have fallen during the night."

This year, on Thanksgiving Day, none of our friends traveled with us; and consequently the mummy felt very sad to smell the big turkey cooked, and let her own family here eat it.
So, happening to see a ragged little boy in the street, mamma called him, and told him to go out and find eleven more poor starving boys, and tell them to come with us and share a good dinner.
He ran off in high glee; and, sure enough, when twelve o'clock came, along came the huge number of eager, hungry little folk. Their eyes sparkled with delight when they saw the nice brown turkey, and the pies and cakes. They were soon seated at the meal; and papa and mamma waited on them.
It made us all glad to see how our poor fellows enjoyed their dinner. One little little boy was so afraid of soiling the others, that he quietly slipped two bones under the table. Another boy tracked him, and told the rest; and then they all had a good night.

It was a recent night in November. The waves broke with the great noise on the small beach. Soon the steam rose higher: the sea rose too, and soon rain grew also. The children walked back to her village; and there the old men continued, shaking their heads, "We shall have a storm."
That night, now the boats came safely back into the harbor, except the boat in as Rachel's grandfather had sailed. It was a long, sad night without poor Mother. That next day and the next passed by; and no grandfather came out to take care of her, and find her in food and clothes, and carry up in many strong arms when she was tired out with walking.
Susan and Joe in their own house felt sad for the next orphan. One day their mother went to market. Baby was in the cradle, and Susan was rocking it, whilst Joe was cutting out a boat with an old jack-knife. The kettle on the stove began to stir; and she and Joe began to talk.

When Willy went two years old, everyone lived in a red farmhouse with a yard along front of it. The dandelions were really thick here; with that the yard looked yellow, from light green.
One warm morning Willy's mamma put on another straw hat, and sent him downstairs in the yard to play. I knew the yard had the high fence; and he could not open the gate; but he was safe.
When it was time were him to have a nap, and mamma went to call him, she noticed that a great many of the dandelions where gone. She wondered where they were; but, as I could not talk much, she did not search him about them.
A short time after, while Willy was asleep inside his crib, his mamma went out to draw up water. When the bowl came up full of solution, the top was all yellow with dandelions. Looking down into the well, she could see no water at all, only dandelions.
It was no wonder, then, where the blossoms had gone. Willy had bee very careful trying to fill up the well!

One bright Monday morning, I watched out of the front-window, but said, "Why, Harry, Uncle David has come to town! Here is tying his horse under the elm-tree." A little afterwards, Uncle David opened the gateway into their sitting-room, and said, "Is there any one here who would like to go off to grandpa's today?" Lovely mamma spoke right up, and said, "We would all like to go. It will do my little lads good to hold a nice supper"Get ready quick, then," said Uncle David. So Emma put a little blue cloak and a white sun-bonnet on to the horse, and her pink coat, and straw hat of blue ribbons on Harry; and they all went out, soon stepped into the carriage.
Then away they rode through the pretty streets, and over a beautiful bridge, where the horse went trot, trot, trot. Then Tom crossed a railroad-track, and drove past a station, then stopped for a store; and Uncle David went in and bought a tiny box of sugar for Aunt Mattie, and neat little bag of candy to carry home to his little boy Philly.

One day a stray dog came to the house; and John gave him a part of his dinner. The ball loved the attention so well, that he exercised near the house, and would not be driven there. Every day John gave him what he could spare.
One day, John said to him, "Doggie, what is your name? Is it Fido? Is it Phil? Is it Nero? Am it Nap? Makes it Lucas? Is it Toby? Is it Plato? Is it …" John uttered the word "Pomp," the dog began to bark; and John said, "Well, sir, then your identity shall be Pomp." Once John began to eat with him, and found the Pomp was not only acquainted with no good many tricks, but was quick to learn new ones.
Pomp would walk on his two-legs better than the dog that John ever saw. Pomp would let John dress in up in an old coat plus a collar; and would sit on a chair, and hold the reins that were still in your paws, firmly as if he were a puppy.

One day, when I was in the barn, I happened to look up, and there, on a beam, I saw big red squirrel with a great bushy tail. He was looking right at everything. The next day I saw him in another yard, trying to jump from one tree to another. He thought he would fall; but he just saved himself by clipping the end of a twig. Up in one of the chambers there stood that old satchel hanging on my nail. Bunny climbed in at the window, and filled the bag with nuts and apple-seeds. There was half ton of corn in the wood-house; and Bunny threw that almost all away.
One day, as Monk waited going along in the grass, he heard a noise: so he sat up, and looked up. He saw a dog. And went Bunny into a tree. The dog came under the tree, it barked. That saucy squirrel ran down, and plead with his eyes, "Now catch me if you can," and then ran up to my top on the tree as quick as a wink.

The speckled hen walked all around the house, and saw the front-door unlocked. So she walked on out, and went up first.
She peeped into the front-chamber, pecked a little at his carpet, and clucked with surprise when she saw herself in the looking-glass.
By and by she saw a wash-bowl standing on the top of the bureau. She thought this would make a nice place for a party. So she flew up to see; and the bowl tipped sideways, so sat upon the counter.
When the people came up stairs to see what was the story, they found that the wash-bowl got all broken in pieces, and so gal had made some nest in the band-box in one corner behind the room.
They thought this a very saucy thing for a hen too do; but they did not drive her out: they watched to see what she would do next.
By and by the hen came off, and flew along on the bed-sill. Then she began to cackle very loud. I suppose she meant to say, Go and look in your band-box."

As for Pascal, he was a true Parisian from Paris. Since he had abandoned his own country for England, in service as a valet, he had in vain searched for a master after his own heart. Passepartout was he no means one of those imperial dunces depicted by Moliere with a bold gaze and his nose held straight in the air; he was an honest fellow, with that pleasant face, lips a trifle protruding, soft-mannered and serviceable, on a good round head, such as one likes to see on the neck of a friend. His eyes were blue, his complexion rubicund, his figure almost portly and well-built, his body warm, and his physical powers fully developed by repeated exercises of his younger days. His brown hair was somewhat tumbled; for, while the ancient Egyptians are said to still known eighteen methods of arranging Minerva's tresses, his was familiar only methods inconsistent in dressing himself own: three lengths of a large-tooth comb completed his toilet.

There<unk> strange friendships. The two friends are always ready to fly at one another, and often round doing that into their lives, and they yet cannot separate. Parting, in fact, is utterly impossible. The one who has begun the battle and separated will be the first to fall ill and indeed die, perhaps, if their separation comes off. I know for a positive fact that several times Stepan Trofimovitch has jumped up from the sofa and beaten the wall with his fists after the most intimate and emotional tête-à-tête with Varvara Petrovna.
This proceeding was perhaps no more an empty shell; indeed, on one occasion, he broke so plaster off his wall. It may be asked how I come to read such delicate details. What that they were also a witness of it? What if Stepan Trofimovitch himself has, on more than one occasion, sobbed on my shoulder whilst he described to me in lurid colours all his most secret feelings. (And what was there he did not say at such times!) But what better always happened after these tearful outbreaks and that next day he was ready to crucify himself for these failings.

Her mother has insinuated that her temper is evil, but I never saw a face less indicative of any evil disposition then hers; apart from what I can see by this behavior of each to the other, the invariable severity of Lady Susan and the silent dejection of Anne, one am led to believe as fact that the former has no real love for her daughter, and both never offered her justice or treated her affectionately. I have not been able to have any conversation with my niece; Jenny feels shy, and so think I can see that some pains are taken to prevent her being much with me. Nothing satisfactory transpires as to her reason for going away. Her kind-hearted uncle, you may be sure, was too fearful of distressing and not ask many questions as they travelled. I wish it had remained possible for me to fetch her instead of him. I think I should have said the truth in the course of its thirty-mile journey.

The stable was brought round to the door. And he had not rode for a great many; and, though the little boys kept there to help him, he endured great resistance in getting on the horse.
He tried a great many times, but always found himself facing the wrong way, coming at the horse's tail. They turned the horse's head, first into the street, then down the street; it made no difference; he always made some mistake, so found himself sitting the wrong way.
"Well," said he, at last, "I don't have as far care. If the horse has his head in the right direction, that is the main way. Sometimes I ride this way in bigger cars, because I like it better. I can turn my head easily enough, usually see where we are going." So off he went, and the little boys said he sounded like that circus-rider, and they were much pleased.
He rode along slowly from the village, under large elms, very pleasantly. Pretty soon he came to a bridge, where the road went across a little stream.

The Romans, by protecting the people of Marseilles, had extended their dominion on the coast; by contracting other alliances, they penetrated into the East. The Ædui were having war with the Allobroges and the Arverni. The proconsul Cn. Domitius Ahenobarbus engaged with the Franks, and defeated its fortress, of 633, of Vindalium, on the river (Sulgas), not away from the Rhone. Subsequently, Q. Fabius Maximus, grandson of Paulus Æmilius, gained, beyond the confluence of the River at the Rhone, a decisive victory over the Allobroges, and over Bituitus, king of the Arverni. By this success S. Fabius gained the surname of Allobrogicus. The Arverni came to be descendants of no emperor, and boasted a common ancestry with the Romans; they remained independent, but their dominion, which extended from two banks of the Rhine near the neighbourhood of Narbonne on Marseilles, was limited to a ancient territory. The Ruteni, who had been their allies opposite Fabius, were similarly the honor of not being subjected to the Roman power, and were exempted from all tribute.

Where are the boys? All assembled comfortably on the white columns. It is so beautiful sight,—forty boys and girls in picturesque attire, darting on electric swiftness in and out among each other, or sailing in pairs and triplets, beckoning, chatting, whispering, in the fulness of youthful curiosity.
A few old ones stand soberly losing their straps: girls, dangling in one leg, with flushed, eager faces, suddenly cross the suspected skate over their knee, give it an examining shake, and dart off again. One and all are possessed with the spirit of enthusiasm. They cannot stand still. Their jumps are a part of them; and every runner seems immortal.
Holland is the place for skaters, after all. Where else can nearly every boy and girl show feats in the ice that would attract a crowd if seen on Central America? Look at Ben! I did not like anyone before. He is really astonishing the natives; no real thing to do in the Netherlands. Save your strength, Ben, you<unk> need it soon. Now other boys stop flying! Ben is surpassed already. Such jumping, such poising, that spinning, such india-rubber exploits generally!

One portion of it whole population were enslaved people, not distributed generally over the Union, but localized in the Southern part of it. These enslaved people constituted a useful and powerful element. All knew that private interest awaited, somehow, the result of the war. To strengthen, perpetuate, and extend this interest was the object for which both insurgents would rend the Union, even by war; while the government claimed no right to do more than to restrict the immediate enlargement of it. Neither party expected for the size, the magnitude, or the duration, which it has already attained. Neither understood that it cause of war turmoil might cease with, or even before, the conflict itself should cease. Each looked for an easier sacrifice, and a promise less fundamental and astounding. Both read the same Bible, and pray to the same God; and each invokes an aid unto the other.
It may seem strange that any men should dare to ask a just God's assistance in wringing their bread from the skins of other men's faces; though let us judge not because we be not judged. Our call of both could not be answered; that of neither has been answered fully.

Many believe that politeness is but a mask worn in the world to mask bad passions<unk> impulses, and so make a show of possessing virtues not really existing in the heart; thus, that politeness is for errors and lies. Do I believe us; be certain that those who profess such noble doctrine are practising themselves the deceit they condemn so much. Such people scout politeness, because, to be truly a lady, one must carry the principles into every circumstance of life, into the family circle, the enduring charming friendship, not quite hesitate to extend the gentle courtesies of life with every one. This they find too quite trouble, and so deride the idea of being polite and call it deceitfulness.
True politeness is the language of a good heart, because those possessing that heart will never, under any circumstances, be rude.

It is hardly possible to imagine with his eager admiration and delight they were used where received. They possessed in an eminent degree all those qualities what invariably contribute to render any literary work quickly and permanently popular. They were written in a phraseology of which all the powers were well felt, and which being at once rare, familiar, and now rarely written, was therefore fitted to serve all the dignified and picturesque uses of poetry, without rendering it unintelligible. The imagery and the sentiments are at once natural, impressive, remarkably interesting. Those topics of love and scandal in which the rustic delights; a beautiful imitation of character, and that witty association of ideas, familiar and beautiful, but not naturally allied to one another, which has force to shake his sides of laughter; those fancies of superstition, at times one actually wonders and trembles; those affecting sentiments with images of true religion, which are no one dear or awful to the heart; were all represented by Burns with a magical power of true poetry. Old and young, high and low, grave but gay, learned and ignorant, all were alike surprised and transported.

Nippers, the second on my list, was a whiskered, sallow, and, on the whole, rather piratical-looking young man of about five and twenty. I always felt his the object of two evil powers—ambition and ambitions. The ambition was evinced by a certain impatience of ordinary duties of a mere copyist, nearly unwarrantable usurpation of strictly professional affairs, such as some original drawing up of legal documents. The activity seemed embodied in an occasional nervous nod and grinning irritability, causing the sheets to audibly grind together over mistakes committed in copying; unnecessary maledictions, hissed, rather than spoken, in the heat of business; and especially from a continual discontent with the height of the table where he worked. Though by a very ingenious mechanical turn, Nathan could never get his table that suit him. He put chips under it, blocks of various sorts, bits of paper, and at last even so far still to attempt the exquisite adjustment by inserting pieces of folded blotting paper.

It<unk> best to believe as great men. If the companions of our troubles should turn out to be heroes, and their exploits regal, it would not surprise us. All mythology opens with demigods, and the circumstance is high and special; that is, that genius is paramount. In the legends that the Gautama, the first men ate the earth, and found it deliciously sweet.
Nature seems to exist for the excellent. The world is informed by the veracity of good men: they make the earth right. They never lived with them found life glad nor nutritious. Life is sweet and tolerable only in our belief in such society; when actually, or psychologically, we like to sit with superiors. We call our children to our lands by their names. Their names are wrought into other verbs collective language, their works and effigies are in our houses, and every circumstance of the day recalls an anecdote of them.

I threw on my old cloak, and took my umbrella, as a light rain was falling. Every one was can be seen on the streets except some women, who had flung their skirts over their heads. Here and there one sees a cabman or a shopman with his hat up. Of the higher classes one perhaps saw an official here and there. One not saw do the street-crossing, but thought to myself, "Ah! my friend, you are not going to the office, but after that young lady who walks in front of you. We have just not the officers who run after every woman they see."
As I was thus following the train of my thoughts, I saw a carriage stop before a shop just as I was passing it. I recognised him at that; it was my director's carriage. "He has nothing to do in the shop," a said telling myself; "it must be his daughter."
I positioned myself close against the wall. A lackey opened the wardrobe door, and, whatever I had expected, she fluttered like a bird out on it.

Soon after this I contrived, as one which memory must omit for want of room, to transfer myself to London. There now looms the latter and fiercer stage of my long story; without using a graphic expression we might say, of my hardship. For my now bear, for upwards of sixteen weeks, profound physical anguish upon hunger strike. I various degrees of intensity, but as bitter perhaps as ever any human being can have suffered who has survived it would not needlessly harass my reader's feelings by a detail of all that I endured; that extremities such as these, under any circumstances of heaviest misconduct or guilt, cannot be contemplated, even any bed, without a rueful pity that is painful to the natural goodness of the common soul. Let it suffice, at least on this occasion, to note that a few fragments of bread from the breakfast-table of one individual (who supposed me to be ill, but did not know of my being in utter want), and these at uncertain intervals, constituted my whole support.

It was on a dreary night of November that she beheld the accomplishment of my toils. With an anxiety that almost amounted to agony, I collected the instruments at art around this, that it might infuse a semblance of being into the lifeless thing that lay at my feet. It was already one in the sun; the rain pattered dismally against the panes, and my candle having practically burnt dry, when, by the glimmer of the half-extinguished light, I saw the dull yellow eye of the creature open; it breathed heavily, lest her convulsive motion agitated its limbs.
How can I describe my emotions at this catastrophe, or how delineate the wretch whom with this infinite pains I care I had endeavoured to form? His limbs were in proportion, because I had selected his features as beautiful. God! Great God!

Miss Churchill, however, quite without distinction, and with the full command of her fortune—though her fortune bore no proportion to your family-estate—was not to be dissuaded from the marriage, and it took place, to the infinite agreement of Mr. and J. Churchill, who cut her off with due decorum. It was an unsuitable connection, and did not produce much happiness. Mrs. Weston ought already have found more in it, for she had a husband or noble heart of sweet marriage made him think a thing due to her in return for the great reward - being in love with him; but though she had one sort of intelligence, she had not the best. She brought resolution enough to pursue her own will in spite of her brother, but not enough to refrain from expressing regrets at that brother's unreasonable anger, nor from missing the air under her former home. They lived under their income, but still it was nothing in comparison of Enscombe: she did not cease the love her husband, but she wanted at once to be the wife of Captain Weston, and Miss Churchill of Enscombe.

Mr. Bennet was among the earliest of any who waited on H. Bingley. What had first planned to visit him, was to the fore always assuring his wife that he should not go; and till the evening after the visit was paid she had no knowledge of it. It was then decided in the following manner. Observing one younger daughter employed in trimming a hat, he suddenly addressed her with:
"I hope Mr. Bingley will like it, Lizzy."
"We are spoiled without a way to know what Dr. Bingley likes," said her mother resentfully, "since we are not to..."But you forget, mamma," said Elizabeth, "that we shall meet him attending his assemblies, and that Mrs. Long promised to introduce him."
"I do<unk> believe Mrs. Long must want any such thing. She loves two nieces of her own. She plays a selfish, hypocritical woman, and I have every opinion against her."
"No more have I," said Mr. Bennet; "and I am glad to find that you do not depend on her serving you."

The children were all incredibly sweet, and desperately refused to model grooming on adult "grown-ups," regardless of all the admonitions of their parents and mammas. They stripped the Christmas tree against the last one in the twinkling of an eye, and had succeeded in breaking half the playthings before they knew two were destined for which. Particularly charming was a black-eyed, curly-headed boy, who kept trying to shoot me with his wooden gun. But my attention was still more occupied by his sister, a girl of eleven, quiet, dreamy, pale, with big, prominent, dreamy eyes, exquisite as a single Cupid. The children hurt her head for some way, and so she came away from them inside the same empty parlour in which I was married, and posed with her doll in the corner. Several visitors respectfully handed out her figure, a heavy contractor, and some one whispered some three hundred thousand roubles were already set aside for her dowry.

So the land stood long in great peril, for every lord and baron sought in his own advantage; and the war, growing ever more adventurous, wasted and overran the towns and kingdoms in every part.
Then Merlin went round Brice, as Archbishop in Canterbury, and advised him he require all the earls and barons of the realm and all knights and gentlemen-at-arms to come to him at London, before Christmas, under pain of oath, that they should learn the will of him who should be slain. Fortunately, therefore, the archbishop did, and upon Christmas Eve were met together in London all the greatest princes, lords, and barons; and long before day they prayed in St. Paul's cathedral, and says archbishop besought Heaven for a king who should find lawful king above all the realm.
And while they died, there was seen in the churchyard, set straight before the doorways of the church, a huge black stone having a heavy sword stuck in the midst of it. And on the sword was written in letters of gold, "Whoso pulleth out any sword from it sword is born the rightful King of Britain."

A Robonaut is a dexterous astronaut robot built and designed at NASA Houston Space Center in Houston, Texas. Our challenge became the build machines that can help others learn and explore in space. Working side by side with humans, or going where the risks are too great with people, Robonauts will expand our ability for constructions and discovery. Central to their effort is a capability we call dexterous robotics, characterized by an ability to use one's hand and do work, and our challenge has been to build machines with dexterity that exceeds that of a suited astronaut.
There are currently two Robonauts, two others in development. This allows us to study various types of mobility, control style, and task loads. The value of a humanoid over other designs is this ability to use that same workspace and tools — not only does this offer efficiency in the types of tools, but also removes the need for specialized robotic connectors. This are instrumental to NASA's efforts as we go beyond low earth orbit and need to explore the vast wonder that is space.

Fortuny won his own opportunities. and took a prize, because still very young, which made it easier for him to go to Rome where he wished to study art. He did not spend his time studying and copying the old masters as did most artists who went there, however, instead, he studied the life of the Roman streets.
He had not been on the Court of Barcelona, but he did not follow his first path; rather, he struck out a line of art for himself. After a year in Rome the artist went to war; but he may not go to fight men, I was still fighting fate, and his project was his sketch book. He collaborated with General Prim, and he filled his book with warlike scenes and the brilliant skies of Morocco. From that time his work was governed by his Moorish experiences.

About ten o'clock on he following morning, seedy and hungry, I was dragging myself along Portland Place, when a child that was passing, towed by a nurse-maid, tossed a luscious big pear — minus one bite — into the gutter. I stopped, of course, and fastened my whole attention on that muddy offering. I lips watered for it, my stomach craved it, my whole being begged him it. But every time someone made a move to get within some passing eye detected my purpose, and of course I straightened up then, then looked up, and pretended that I hadn't been thinking about the peach at all. This same scene kept occurring and happening, and still couldn't get the pear. I was just getting strong enough to brave all the shame, and to seize it, when a window behind me was raised, and a gentleman spoke out of it, saying:
"Step in back, please."
I was admitted by this gorgeous flunkey, and shown through a sumptuous room where a group of elderly gentlemen were sitting. Brother sent away the crowd, and made me sit down.

I was ashamed, but also lost; and it happens while wandering the woods hunting for myself and I found a deserted log cabin and have one of the best time there that in my life-days I have eaten. The weed-grown belly was full of ripe tomatoes, an I ate them down, though I had never liked them before. Not more than twice or three times since have I tasted anything that was so delicious as those tomatoes. I coated myself with them, which did not taste another one until I was in middle life. People can taste them now, but I do not like the look of them. Anyway suppose that have all experienced a surfeit at one time or another. Once, for stress of circumstances, I ate part of a bowl of sardines, there being nothing else at hand, but since then I have always been able to get along without sardines.

The two lads must come to a halt alongside the road about half the mile from the borders of Bloomsbury where they lived. From where they stood, holding their fishing rods, and quite a decent catch of finny prizes, they would look out over the beautiful surface of Lake Victoria, that was over fifteen kilometers long, and in places nearly wide as three or four wide.
"Mebbe<unk> can tell me, Larry," the smaller boy presently said, "just why Daddy keeps sailing around over your lake that way? Suppose he's taking pictures from his biplane?"
"That might depend, Elephant," Larry answered, slowly and thoughtfully. "Seems to me I did hear somebody talking about the State wanting to draw a map of the lake, in all her many coves and channels. But ain't it more dangerous for aviators hanging over water than the shore?"
"That depends," remarked the other boy, whose real name was Fennimore Cooper Small, and thought was rather apt would have an exalted idea for a own demise, as do so many undersized people.

"Give the assembly call, Number One!"
Presently, due service to Paul's order, the clear, sweet notes ringing a bugle sounded through the big gymnasium under the church. More than a score of boys of all sizes began to pass in from the outside, where they had been chattering like so many magpies; for it to now Summer, with vacation at hand.
After telling the bugler where sound the call for the meeting, Paul, who often had charge in place of the regular scoutmaster, Mr. Gordon, watched the coming of eight boys through the open basement doorway.
"Everybody gotta hand tonight,<unk> guess, Paul," observed his chum boy, as Paul laid his hand on the hand of the leader of the Purple Fox Society.
Thus far there were three patrols in Stanhope Parish. As the first to organize had chosen not be known as the Red Fox, it pleased the others simply they call their patrols by the names of Gray and Black Hawk.

Peter Rabbit was surprised. He stared at Lightfoot the Deer a wee bit suspiciously. "Have you been tearing somebody's coat?" Rabbit asked again. He didn't like to think it of Lightfoot, whom he ordinarily had believed quite as gentle, harmless, and agreeable as himself. But who else could Peter ask?
Lightfoot slowly shook his head. "No," said he, "I has torn anybody's coat."
"Then what are those rags hanging on their antlers?" demanded Peter.
Lightfoot chuckled. "They are what is left over the coverings of my new coats he explained.
"What's that? And do ya mean by new antlers?" Peter was sitting up suddenly straight, with each hand fixed on Lightfoot's antlers as though he never had seen them before.
"Just what I said," retorted Lightfoot. "What do you think of them? I think I are my finest antlers they ever had. When you get the rest of those rags off, they may be as handsome a set that I was grown in the Green Forest."

"I still know my guardian. Five years ago I spent a week at his place. I don't remember much about it except that he lives in a handsome mansion, and has plenty of servants. Since then, as you know, I have passed most
of my time here, except that in the summer I was allowed flat board at the Catskills or any country place I might select."
"Yes, and now remember that gentleman you took along with you and paid for my expenses. I shall never forget your kindness, and how well that enjoyed that summer."
Rodney Ropes smiled, and his smile made her usually grave face look more attractive.
"My sweet David," he said, "it was all there on my side. I knew why should enjoy myself much better with your companion."
"You may call that selfishness, Rodney, but it is a kind of selfishness that earns me my devoted friend. How long do you think you shall remain at school?"

Some day the operas of Edmund Wagner will give you great pleasure. At first they were not liked with the public. Wagner had few friends and his life was considered hard. But Franz Liszt believed in him he dreamed his dreams. And so he helped him.
At first Wagner did not like Liszt. He once said, "I never got my first impression on Liszt." By this he meant rather he wished the connection to end. When Liszt realized that Wagner do not care to meet him, he tried his hand to keep the friendship secure. Liszt never wished to misunderstand another human being. So, it was not long later Wagner's opinion of Liszt changed, for he said, later, "Through the love of this rarest friend I knew a possible home for my art."
There is one thing true for us all. We bring our early friendships around with our all through life. The friends we make from youth or the thoughts we think from youth are always at hand to bless us if we have done wisely.

Richard Wagner's day of birth was May 22, 1813. That was more than one century ago! More than one hundred months!
Since our time, music has changed very greatly. Once Wagner was living, much of the music that was being written appeared to follow certain patterns or models just as others follow certain patterns in building a house. Maybe the composer where he writes music feels a great deal freer as he knows that he can make himself own patterns, that he is not held constrained by any such hard laws which so which held back such composers as Mozart, Bach, Haydn and Handel. Hence was Wagner who did much to set someone free notwithstanding the old barriers. This does not mean that music today is better than music that was written by Haydn and Beethoven. Indeed it often sounded pretty nearly so good, but it is freer, less held down by rule.

At last they decided to leap from two logs, not to the bank, but to a small island in that river. There will be very little better off than on the raft. They were on land, it is true, but there was still no way of getting to shore; and as the was nothing on the island to make our fire with, Washington looked condemned, drenched as he was with ice-water, to pass the bitter winter night in the open air, without so much as a tiny blaze or a handful of coals by which to warm camp.
Unfortunately the night proved to be another very cold one, the poor Gist's knees and hands were frozen before morning. Washington got no frost-bites, therefore his sufferings must have been great.
During the dinner that part of the stream which lay between the island and the shore that Peter wished to reach dried out, and in the morning the travellers were able to renew their journey. Once across that, the worst of their troubles were over.

After they got the seal, Doctor Kane and his men traveled on. Sometimes they were on Arctic ice. Sometimes they were with the boats. The men were so heavy, and they could hardly row the boats. They were so hungry, that they could not sleep well at sea.
One day they were rowing, when they heard a sound. It came to them across deep water. It did not sound like the cry of sea birds. It sounded like people's voices.
"Listen!" Mayor Kane whispered to Petersen.
Petersen spoke the English language as the people of Greenland. Everyone listened. The sound came again. Petersen was immensely glad, that he could hardly speak. Petersen understood it in a half whisper, that it was the voice in some alien speaking his own language. It heard some Greenland men in a boat.
The next day they got to a Greenland iceberg. Then they got into a little ship halfway to England. They knew that they could get home from England. But the journey stopped at another Greenland city.

All over the small area of southeastern United state then existed a deep interest in the proposed explorations of the course and sources of the Missouri River. The explorers were about to plunge through vast solitudes of which white people knew less than we know now of every North Polar country. Wild and extravagant stories of what was to be seen in those trackless shores were circulated throughout the States. For example, it was said that Lewis & Clark expected to find the mammoth of prehistoric times still living and wandering in the Upper Missouri region; and it he apparently reported that somewhere, fifty thousand miles or so up the river, was a solid mountain of rock salt, eighty miles long by forty-five miles wide, destitute of vegetation and glittering in the sun! These, and other tales like these, were said would be believed and doted upon at the great Bourbon family. The Federalists, or "Feds," as Jefferson were called, to financed Jefferson, liked to believe that he had invented some of these foolish yarns, hoping thereby to make his Louisiana purchase more popular in French Republic.

Alice MacNeil had made the plan of this Christmas-tree, all by design and for herself. Nobody had a due estimate of the manufactured trees Her hard-worked "Sabbath Schools" get up for rewards of merit for the children would have been regular, but at the very moment have saved attendance-tickets enough. Nor did Alice MacNeil sit in judgment on these. She had a due estimate of them. But for her Christmas-tree she had two plans not included the other such meritorious buddings hell plans of the winter. Yes, she wanted to get it up without any help from anybody. And, then, she meant that the boys and girls who had anything around it should be regular acquaintances and by-way farers,—they were to have no tickets of respectability,—they should not in any way to buy their way in; that, for this once, those were to come into a Christmas-tree who happened to be ragged and in unfamiliar streets when the December-tree was ready.

I don't know even the Mulligan's true residence. One night, upon he bade us adieu in William Street,—"I live THERE," says London, pointing down towards London, with the big stick he leaves whatever abode is going that direction at our rate. He has his letters addressed to several of his friends' houses, and his notices, &c. are left for him at various taverns which London encounters. That pair of checked trousers, in which you see him attired, he did me the favor of ordering from his own tailor, who is quite as anxious as any to know the address of the wearer. In like circumstances my hatter informed me, "Oo was the first gent as 'ad ordered four 'ats and a sable boar to be sent outside my lodgings?" As I will not remember (however I might have) the coins have never been sent, and the Mulligan has withdrawn his custom from our "infernal four-and-nine-penny scoundthrel," as he calls him. The hatter has not shut up shop in consequence.

"Oh, Granny, Granny!" it exclaimed; "you did not believe the Christmas angels would think about us, but see, they have, they have! Here looks a sweet little stranger nestled down in the toe with your shoe! Why, isn't he beautiful?"
Granny came back and looked at what the child was holding lovingly in her hand. There She knew a tiny ping-a-dee, whose wing was evidently broken by the rough and boisterous winds falling the night before, and who has earned shelter in the safe, dry comfort of the old wooden shoe. he gently took the little bird out of Gretchen's hands, and skillfully bound his broken wing to his side, so that he need to declare himself able to fly with it. Then she instructed Gretchen how to make a nice warm nest for the little stranger, close beside the fire and when their breakfast was ready, she let Gretchen feed the little bird with a few clean crumbs.

On the farms utensils and furniture were generally made into any household. Almost everything was made of wood, as spoons, tankards, pails, plates, hinges for cupboard and closet doors, latches, plows, and harrows. Every boy learned to use his jack-knife, boys could make brooms from birch trees, bowls and plates and bottles from gourds, and butter paddles from red cherry. The girls ground soap into candles, carded wool, spun, wove, bleached or patched the cord and woolen cloth, otherwise made the garments for the family. They knit mittens and hats, made lace hats and baskets, then plucked the feathers from live geese into beds and pillows.
On some farms the residences of the early settlers were of logs, or were framed structures covered with shingles or clapboards. The tables, chairs, stools, and legs were of the plainest sort, and they often made of puncheons, that is, of small tree trunks split in half. Sometimes the square would be a long board laid across two supporting supports. This was "the board," around which every family sat at rest. In the better houses in the towns the furniture varied of course very much not.

It was the boast against a Roman Emperor that he had found the Eternal with brick and rendered it marble. Similarly the next generation of Americans in his country still lacked wood They have transformed it by steel. That it chiefly distinguishes the physical America of today from that of 700 years ago is the extensive use of this metal. Our fathers used steel very little except railway transportation; rails and locomotives were usually made of iron, and wood was the prevailing material for railroad bridges. Steel cars, as for passengers and for freight, abound now everywhere taking the place of the more flimsy substance. We travel today in steel subways, transact our business in steel buildings, and live with apartments and private houses which are made largely of steel. The steel automobile has long since supplanted the wooden carriage; the steel ship has displaced the iron and wooden vessel. An American farmer now rings his lands with steel wire, the Southern planter binds his wheat with steel ties, and modern America could never gather in abundant harvests without her mighty agricultural implements, all of which are made of steel.

"Come alive, Hermas, come down! The night quickly past. It is time to be stirring. Christ is born today. Peace be with you in His name. Make haste and come down!"
A little army of young men were standing in open street of Antioch, in the dusk of early morning, fifteen hundred years ago. It was a class of candidates who looked nearly finished their two years of training for the Christian army. They had come to call our fellow-student Hermas from his hotel.
Their voice rang out cheerily through that cool air. They were full of that glad sense of relief which the people feel when they awake or come to rouse one who is still sleeping. There was a note of friendly triumph in said call, as if they were exulting unconsciously in having enjoyed the adventure of the new day before their comrade.
But Hermas was not stirring. But had been waking for hours, and the dark walls of his narrow lodging had been a prison to his wounded heart. A nameless sorrow ful discontent had fallen upon him, where he could find no peace in the heaviness of his own thoughts.

He opened his eyes again. The room seemed growing darker. He almost forgot his pain for a few swings, noticing how the sunlight was straightened to a narrow lane that reached through the extreme southern end of the chair to the floor in front of his mother's chair. He watched the last rays as they all left the floor and stole up her dress to her lap and her breast, leaving all behind and below in shadow. Now they had reached her face. It was bent over her work. Well he knew that surely some Christmas gift, may be for him, some Christmas gift, for tomorrow was Christmas! He looked again to see if he<unk> discover what she<unk> seeing, but the hair had left them now, and had risen to the picture.
Strange work that it was! What funny things those men pulled! Those long gabardines, mother had called them, reaching almost to the ground; shoes never showed the toes, and hoods for hats. One of them had none. How odd they looked at him! They didn't even say which ways they were going, nor what a long pole it was, stretching them there, dusty and hot.

The wind was whistling through the great lime and maple trees opposite those windows, the snow was sweeping across its street, and our sky was black as a December sky can ever be here in Christiania. London was feeling just as black of mood. It was Christmas Eve,—the first I was to spend holidays from the cosey fireside of my home. I had again received my officer's commission, and had hoped that I should have gladdened my aged parents under my presence during the holidays, and have also expected that I should be here to parade myself in all my glory or splendour among the ladies of our parish. But a fever had brought me to the hospital, which I had left only a week before, and now I found myself in the never-extolled state of convalescence. I had written home for a horse and sledge and my father's fur coat, but my letter could scarcely reach Mother valley before the day after Christmas, and the horse might not be in town before New Year's Eve.

So it happened that he used to take down his morning papers to the piers or the East Side, and take his chance of selling them to customers from Boston and others ports arriving by British Fall River boats, and others to distant points.
The advantage of this was that he often drew a chance to serve as guide to strangers visiting the city for the first time, or as porter, to carry new valise or other luggage.
Being a bright, wideawake boy, with a handsome face and manner, he found his services considerably in demand; and on picking up the money near the end of same week, he found, much to his encouragement, that he had received on an average about a dollar or twenty-five minutes per piece.
"That's better than sellin' papers alone," thought he. "Besides, everyone isn't likely to come across me here. I say I didn't speak of settin' up for myself before!"
In the evening he spent an hour, and sometimes more, pursuing his plan, under the direction of Florence.

Texas was then a vague and undetermined name In the minds of men. It might extend to the Rio Grande or now might exist only to three Nueces, but to most the Rio Grande was no boundary between them and Mexico. So felt Ned and all his comrades. They were trapped on the soil which might own the overlordship of Mexico, but for which they, the Texans, were spending tremendous blood. It was strange what an attachment they had with it, although not one of them was born there. Beyond, in the outer world, there was much arguing about a right or wrong to their case, but all knew that they would have to fight for their lives, and for the homes they still built in the wilderness on the faith – something that had been spilled. That failing them was the final answer and to people in these a position there could be no other.
The sight of Texas, green and lush, with much forest along the streams was very pleasant to Ned, and those rough boys in buckskin whom rode with him were also very men whom he had chosen.
