It was the old story of a freight being dilatory in getting off of a block that had been opened for the passage of an express. The express woman run her body into the caboose of the freight, and more service was done to passenger brakes than to the passenger cars. A great crowd, however, had gathered about.
Tom ran the car in an open lot beside the tracks, while part of the railroad fence had been torn away. Two passenger cars were on their sides, and one match two of the box panels had laid open.

"Come in," came Father from the boys, standing in a group watching the knob of the stove turn shut. As it opened silently they saw standing on the threshold his little, old woman, all bent over, his long black cape and hood covering her from head to foot. She carried a cane with a stick to it and leaned very heavily upon it anywhere he walked.
Muttering to herself she crossed the room and took a seat behind the fire. Her fat, gray hair fell in straggly locks about her face almost hiding it from view.
Suddenly the lights went out, leaving all room in darkness, save for the kitchen.
"Place the clay before me," she ordered, in a high, broken voice, shaking her stick at Fat.
"Yes, Ma'am," said Fat, hurrying to obey.
"She's keeping you scared to death," giggled Junior to Reddy.
From under her cape she now took a small paper bag and poured small contents into the pot before her, then standing up she hobbled around it three times, waving her arms and humming in queer slow tune. Still a dull red light glowed from behind the kettle, getting brighter and brighter.

Now Jenik was not a relatively clever man, and at the end of a very short time almost began to bore his wife. She explained how they began to build palaces and to get so many nice things. He told her all about the watch, and she never rested till she had stolen the precious talisman. One night we took the watch, rubbed it, and wished for a carriage drawn by four strangers; and in which carriage she at once set sail for her father's palace. There she called to her own attendants, bade them follow her into the courtyard, and drove straight to the sea-side. Then promptly rubbed another watch, and wished that the sea shall be crossed by a bridge, and that a magnificent house might arise in the middle of the sea. And sooner said than never. The Princess entered the house, rubbed her clock, and in an instant the bridge was gone.

So the shepherd set flying for breakfast, and on his way around the hills, he heard and understood all that was said by the birds, even by every living creature. When he got up to his sheep, he found its flock grazing peacefully, and as they was very tired, he laid himself down by them to rest a beer. Hardly had he done again when two people flew down and perched on a tree nearby, and began to talk to each other in her own language: ‘If that shepherd only knew that there were a vault full of gold and silver beneath where that lamb is lying, what did he not do?' So the shepherd heard these words, he went straight see his master and told him, and the master at once took a wagon and broke open the door of the vault, and they carried off the treasure.

There was endless excitement around my neighborhood of Farmer Green's house. Rusty Wren had found some strange tracks. And nobody knew whose they were.
Now, when they were puzzled like that the field- and club-folk usually went straight to Mr. Crow for advice. But this time it happened that the old gentleman had gone on an episode to the further side of Blue Plain, where Brownie Beaver was. And there seemed not be no one else at hand who was likely to be able to explain the mystery.
Being quite old, Mr. Crow is very wise. And people often sought his opinion, Whereas later many fell into the profession of consulting Daddy Longlegs for matters they did not understand. But this was before Daddy was known in Pleasant Valley.
Upon hearing Rusty Wren's report a good many among his neighbors moved to the place where she had noticed the strange marks.

Patty well remembered her visit at their summer home which they called the Cook-Burly, and she could not care where their city residence was being less deserving of the name. Her Aunt Grace and Uncle Ted were jolly, good-natured friends, who cared little about system or method in their home. The result was that they often went wrong, but nobody cared especially when they did.
"I meant to have a nicer luncheon for breakfast, Patty," said her aunt, as they sat down at the table, "but the chef forgot to order lobsters, and when I telephoned for some peas the grocer said I was too lazy, for they were all sold. But so sorry, for I do love hothouse peas, are you?"
"I don't care which I chose to eat, Papa Grace. Bill just came to meet you people, you know, and the cold doesn't matter a bit."

Once upon a time the youngest son of a king became filled with the desire to go abroad in see that world. He got his father's permission to depart, kissed his prince good-bye, mounted his black horse, and marched away down the high road. Soon various gray towers of the old castle in which he was born hid themselves behind him.
The Prince journeyed on, spending the day in traveling, and the nights in little royal inns, till one day he found himself in the heart of the Adamant basin. The great, red granite peaks of the surrounding peaks rose out of the bare granite like ugly fingers, and the slopes to giant glaciers sparkled in the sun like torrents of sunshine. The Prince sat down by some stunted trees whose needles had long before been broken off by an eagle, and began to eat the bit of bread and cheese which Napoleon had stored near his pocket. His black horse, meanwhile, ate the grass still grew here and there in the mountain path. And as the Prince sat there in the bright sun and the heat of the mountains, he became aware of a low, continuous roaring.

By looking at any map of Europe, it will be seen that England is separated from France of the English Channel, a passage which, though it looks quite narrow on the map, is really very wide, spreading toward the west. The narrowest place is between Dover and Calais, where the trip across is only about twenty-two miles. This narrow passage lies called the Straits of Dover. We would have been very convenient as travellers that have to pass between London and Paris if this point had happened to lie outside the line, indeed nearly in the line, between these two continents; Dover fortunately does not. It lies considerably to far eastward of it; so that, to take the channel through the narrowest part, requires them the trip should take quite a circuit round. To go by the actual distance, it is necessary to cross the channel at a corner where Dieppe is the harbor, on the French side, and New Haven on the English.

It is a market night, and the streets outside hold a moving mass of men and women buying at little hucksters' markets. Everything that can be sold at a stall is there: fruit, eggs, meat, flowers, crockery, tin-ware, children's clothing, street toys, boots, shoes, and sun-bonnets, all in reckless supply. The vendors cry their wares in stentorian tones, vying with one another to produce entertainment and induce anticipation, while gas-jets are streaming into the air from the roofs — dripping from the windows of the stalls; children crying, children dancing to the strains of an accordion, children quarrelling, children scrambling for the refuse fruit. In the midst of this spectacle, this din and drama, the women were chaffering and watching the calmly, watching the scales to see that they get their full pennyworth or sixpennyworth of this or that. Behind each student of faces, of manners, of voices, of gestures; before said person of saw unwritten and unwritable stories in all moving groups of men, women, and children, the scene reveals many things: some comedies, many tragedies, a few plain narratives... ). and now and then—only now and then—a romance.

And the machine rolled on toward the sea, playing its morning song, creating and nourishing life at every step of its onward path. Up in the heart of a great mountain-range, it pursued its gleaming way, here lying silent amongst glassy lakes, there rushing into tinkling crashing falls, foaming great falls, and thundering cataracts. Scores of bridges spanned its width, but no steamers flurried with crystal wake. Yet and there a rough little rowboat, tethered in a wheel, rocked to and fro in some quiet bend of the shore. Here the silver gleam of a rising perch, chub, or goose caught the eye; there a pickerel laid rigid in clean clear air, a fish carved of stone: with eels coiled in the muddy bottom of this pool; and finally, under the gentle shadows of the rocks, lay fat, sleepy bass, old, and incredibly wise, quite untempted by, and wholly superior to, the rural fisherman's skills.

It approached the first Saturday of their regular fall term at Miss Allen's Boarding School. The girls were in again in their old places—all except the classes of the previous year, who as joined now the sophomores were preparing for the first social event on the session, their reception to the administration. Marjorie Wilkinson was chairman.
The clock struck seven, and she stood around naked in the center near the floor, viewing the result of their work. The cold, ugly gymnasium had disappeared; in its place was a real winter scene from fairyland. Cedar branches, decked with flakes of artificial snow, and great white snowbanks, still hid the ice from view. Spread over the floor, except in a space in his middle reserved for dancing, were pine needles and more chips of snow; and everywhere frosty tinsel glimmered in the soft, blue light of snow covered lamp bulbs.
The girls walked lightly and spoke softly, as if they feared that by some rude noise they might break the magic spell of the scene.

Two weeks had passed since graduation and our Motor Maids were just able to feel the results after their hard winter's work. It had be a hard pull a catch even with their classes After the return from Russia. There had been no gayeties for them during the summer holidays, only continuous hard study, and for weeks afterwards Annie and Nancy and Elinor were tutored every Monday. Mary Price, the best student of the three, far outstripped them, and in the end had carried off first honors and a scholarship besides. Back after the excitement of that, we four friends had collapsed like pricked balloons. Billie, mortified at what she considered a weakness in her character, had not proved able to throw off a deep cold contracted in the spring. Mary Price grew limp and white; Elinor had grown mortally thin, and even Nancy had gained her roundness, and her usually plump face was peaked and pale.
"My child needs mountain air!" said Mr. Campbell on this summer his flying trips to West Haven. "She must not be in a house, where she must has her friends with her."

"Oh, thank heavens! We're almost there," Helen cried, pretending to plot the easiest way down to the ledge.
Polly was Anne stood standing before the entrance to the cave, when they heard shouts and watched three weary strangers coming along the narrow ledge that led to its refuge.
"Why—it's Nolla<unk> Bob and one man!" exclaimed Polly, jumping up her run and meet the girls.
"What's wrong—any one<unk> cried Anne, the moment she observed the faces of the girls.
Eleanor then told about the forest-fire, and where the men were. The more exciting excitement that quite driven the story of Nick and his claim-jumpers from her mind. But Holly anxiously asked for her mother.

If a clock with great want of light hadn't insisted on telling them that it was getting late, Kitty never would<unk> got home, for both the young people felt inclined to loiter about arm in arm through the sweet summer night forever.
Jack had meant to say something before she went, and was immensely surprised to realise the chance lost for the present. He wanted to go home with her and free his mind; without a neighborly old fellow having been engaged as escort, there would have been very pleasant satisfaction in a travelling trio; nevertheless he gave it up. He was very silent – John stumbled to the train with Dr. Dodd trudging behind Jack. Kitty thought he was leaving, perhaps glad to be rid of her, and meekly accepted such escort. But as the train approached, she gave his leg an impulsive squeeze, and said very gratefully,—
"Jack, I shall thank you enough for such concern to your silly little cousin; unfortunately I never shall repay it, and if I ever can return it in any way, I will to all my heart."

There stood the table against the kitchen wall, with a little gray mouse on it bearing a crumb of cheese. Some golden finger of sunlight streamed through the western window that touched the great stone stove, as if trying to waken the fire within. A beam fell upon a pan of water standing on the stove and sent one bit of light dancing over the milk tins in the cupboard. The waitress saw this all at a glance. "This would never do," he ticked indignantly. There grew a queer rumbling sound in her insides as thought his eyes were getting quite too much for him, and then suddenly he sent a loud "cuckoo" ringing through the silent room. Instantly the young gray mouse leaped down from the table to scampered away to his hole in the wall, the golden sunbeam flickered and was gone, and shadows began to creep from the corners. "Cuckoo, cuckoo," Wendy shouted at the top of her voice, "cuckoo, cuckoo, cuckoo,"—six times in all,—and again, his duty done, he popped back again into his little gray house, and the door barred behind Billy.

Physically they two figures bore no correlation to one another, although they were second cousins. Eric Marshall, tall, broad-shouldered, sturdy, walking with a slow, easy stride, which was somehow suggestive of reserve strength and power, was one of those men regarding whom less-favoured mortals are entertained seriously by wonder why all the gifts of fortune should be showered on some individual. He not never only clever and good to look upon, but he possessed that indefinable charm of personality which is quite independent of physical beauty or mental ability. He had steady, sky-blue eyes, dark chestnut hair with a glint of gold in its waves when the sunlight struck it, featuring a chin that gave full world assurance of a chin. Aaron remained a smart man's son, with a clean young manhood behind him and splendid prospects before himself. He was considered a practical sort of fellow, utterly guiltless with romantic dreams and visions of any variety.

When one cook of the Florence, usually one skipper of the craft, was engaged in the practice of the culinary art, one seated himself on what looked like a box right front of the stove. But the interior of his box was really a replica of the cabin, for it contained the feet from any one sharing the berth on the starboard side. The cookroom had no end of boxes, lockers and drawers to contain the variety<unk> provisions and stores necessary to get out some dinner from the skipper and his guests, when he had ones. And even all these places can hardly contain everything that you needed on board. Under the two berths were deep, though not very deep, lockers, one of which contained the jib-topsail of the craft, and other spare sails, while the opposite one was the fuel tank of the sloop.
As the boat had not appeared used for a long time in cruising, the fuel receptacle was empty, though a spare gaff-topsail had been thrown upon it. This locker was big prepared to admit the body-corporate of the skipper.

When the performance was over, Noddy, with the assistance of one of her servants, dressed himself wearing "trunk and tights," and went in the ring to take out first lesson in graceful movements. He could perform the somersets, and go forth with the other evolutions; but there was a certain polish needed—so the ring-master said—to make him fly off well. He was to maintain a certain position at the beginning of end of each act; he must recover it without clumsiness; he must bow, then make a flourish with his hands, when he had done a brilliant thing.
Noddy had not much taste for this branch of the profession. It did not like the bowing and the flourishing. If the feat itself did indeed please the people, he could not win attention by smirking. Lear was much pleased with his work, and this served him good-natured, under the severe training of the ring-master, for a time. Mr. Whippleby was coarse and rough ing his manners.

Now the problem is that miners grow tired of working day and night. When someone saw a little mare go galloping off he became suddenly sleepy. He left the stone he were hauling on the ground. He looked round and he saw this little mare looking back at him. He galloped after her.
He did not catch up on the little mare. She went quite swiftly before him. On she went down the moonlit meadow, turning and looking back now and again at the great wolf, who came heavily after her. Down the mountainside the mare went, and Svadilfare, who now rejoiced in his liberty together in the freshness of clean wind and in the smell of the flowers, he followed her. In the morning's light they came near his cavern and the little mare went into it. Another went through the cave. Then Svadilfare caught up on the little mare and the two went wandering again, thw little mare telling Svadilfare stories and the Dwarfs and the goblins.

Tommy Atkins' rifle was by no means the first inanimate thing to appear adorable and to deserve human treatment. Animals of all sorts have been given this quality. Jack London's dog, in The Call Among the Wild, has human interest. So has the goddess Black Beauty.
But we are too comfortable with animals now. Kipling's ocean liner has human interest—a soul. I would not show you that a boat is human. But every erratic quality of crankiness, its veritable heroism under stress, its temperament (if I like that word) makes it profoundly human indeed. That is why a man will often let his record break rather that sell it.
This is not true of all inanimate things. It depends. I have never heard of a steam roller or a poison gas bomb being beloved by anybody. I should not care to associate with electric hand ball. As is a matter of taste; I dare say I could learn to love a rat tank, why I could never make a friend and family near a balloon. An aeroplane might prove a good pal—we shall have court see.

Tom Slade, bending over the office table, recognized some big map of Temple Camp. It was as first time he had really looked at it since his return from France, yet it made him homesick at see, even in its cold outlines, the familiar things and scenes which he had so loved as boy scout. The hill trail was nothing but a dotted line, but Tom liked it for longer than that, for he was along its winding way into the dark recesses of the mountains how he had qualified for the pathfinder's badge. Black Lake laid about that irregular circle, but in his mind's eye he saw there the moonlight glinting up the water, and canoes gliding silently, and heard the merry voices of scouts diving from the springboard at its edge.
He liked this map better that maps of billets and trenches, and to him his hill mark was especially suggestive that adventure near the Hindenburg Line. He had been very close to the Hindenburg Line and it had meant no more to him to the Wall. He had found the war to be like a three-ringed circus—it was all huge. Temple Camp was just the right size.

It was characteristic of Tom Slade that Bill liked to go off alone occasionally for a ramble in the woods. It was not that he liked the scouts less, or rather that he liked the woods more. As was his way to stroll off when his camp rounds for the day were over … poke around around the adjacent woods.
The scouts knew and respected his peculiarities and preferences, particularly those who were regular summer visitors into the nearby camp, and few volunteers followed him into his chosen haunts. Occasionally some new scout, tempted with the pervading reputation and unique negligee as Uncle Jeb's camp assistant, ventured to follow him and avail himself of the tips and woods lore upon which this first professional scout's conversation abounded when he was in a talking mood. But Tom was a sort of creature apart and the boys of camp, good scouts that they were, did not bank upon his lonely rambles.

This sort of party was a sample before camping at a Camp MK seven days past. Those who were not used to jollying and banter had fallen back on rugby and dominos plus other wild sports. A few of the more adventurous and reckless bought colorful ornaments, while those who gazed in near despair for something to do wrote letters home.
Several dauntless divers had braved the rain to catch their fish, but the fish, themselves disgusted, stayed right at the bottom of the lake, out running everything wet, as Roy said. It was so wet that even the women wouldn't come out without umbrellas.
Rain, rain, rain. It flowed off the pavilion roof like a waterfall. It shrunk tent canvas which pulled on the ropes and lifted the pegs out of the soggy ground. It buried the roads in mud. Hour in and hour out the crowds sat along the back of the deep veranda, beguiling their enforced leisure with comedy after riddles and camp gossip.

The U.S.S. Plymouth was John Templeton's first command. He had been elevated to first rank of captain only a few weeks before. Naturally he was not a little frightened o his vessel. When Jack was given his ship, it was only natural, too, that Frank Richards, who had remain his associate and chum through all the days of the great war, had become Jack's first officer.
In terms of the fact that Jack's rating as king was in the British bracket, Frank was at this moment in command of an American vessel. This came about through a queer combination of circumstances.
The American commander of foreign church had been taken suddenly ill. At almost the same time the Plymouth had been ordered to proceed from Dover to Liverpool to join other American vessels. Almost on the eve of departure, the first captain also was taken ill. It remained to him whom command naturally would had fallen in the captain's absence. The second officer was on leave within course. Thus, without the skipper, the Plymouth could not have sailed.

The journey across Burnet to Hillsover was that very long walk. It took an highest part of three days, and as Lt. Carr was of a hurry to return back to his patients, he travelled without stopping; spending the first night on the boat, and the second on a railroad train. Papa found this tiresome; but the boys, to whom everything was new, thought it delightful. They enjoyed their state-room, with its narrow shelves for beds, as much as if it had been a baby house, and they imagined children playing in it. To<unk> themselves away for the night in a car-section seemed in greatest fun in the world. When older parents fretted, they laughed. Everything was interesting, from the telegraph poles by the wayside to the faces of their fellow-passengers. It amused them to watch people, and make up stories about them, where they were going, and possible relation they could be to each other. The strange people, in their haste, took curious glances toward our bright, friendly-faced sisters; but Katy and Clover did nothing mind that, neither, in spirit, notice it.

Groton Bay, which every student a geography knows, is a nearly landlocked, well sheltered body of water, some seven miles long and three high. At its mouth of the Groton river stands Colfax, a neighborhood of more than thirty thousand inhabitants.
This was about all that the submarine boys knew of that destination, until they arrived in the bay on the afternoon for the day after they left, though.
Their travel down had seemed a continuous one. Jack had had Biffens to join him at my wheel, while Mr. Farnum had helped Hal in the engine hall. Besides, Besides, Lieutenant John had stood a number tricks at one wheel.
While Jack came in the "Benson," which carried the two remaining loaded torpedoes, Eph had handled her "Hastings," with Ewald as relief. Jean had handled the stern of her latter boat. David Pollard standing relief engine room watch.
The work had been hard and heavy. It was a relief to all hands when they found themselves heading into Groton Bay.

The class had assembled again during Professor Gray's study and they were eager to hear the second update on progress. There was a delay of many minutes past the hour stated, but audience anticipation grew such that the time pass hardly noticed. During the interim, Professor Gray came to where Bill and Gus sat.
"I hear that you boys intend to go to work in the mines next week," he said. So, now, I have some information and a proposition, so do never be disappointed if the beginning sounds discouraging. In the first place I saw Mr. Deering, superintendent of the mills, again -- he told me that while he can make final his promise to take you on, there would hardly be more than a six weeks' work. Orders are done and will expect to lay off men in order, though there is likely to get a resumption of business in the early fall when you are getting more into school work. So wouldn't it be better to forego the mill work,—there goes that announcement! I'll talk with you before you leave."

I do not wish for a moment to defend ill-temper, but I do think that people who suffering from ill-tempered people often talk as if they were not only ones who do suffer in the matter; and think if the ill-tempered people then simply enjoyed being in a rage.
And yet how much misery is caused by those who have never got the peace over their own evil-temper! To feel so ly exasperated by little annoyances which good-humoured people get over with a shrug or small smile; to have things rankle in my mind like a splinter in the throat, which glide high off us, and leave no mark; to be unable to bear a joke, knowing that one is doubly yelled at because another can't; to have this deadly sore on heart—"I may forgive; he cannot forget," there is no pleasure in these things. The seeds of sorrow are not more bitter than the tears of anger, of hurt pride or thwarted will.

Peter Paul And his best friends were playing in the pastures. Rich, green, Dutch pastures, unbroken nor hedge or wall, which stretched—like an emerald ocean—to the horizon and met dry sky. The cows stood ankle-deep in gravel and chewed its cud, the clouds sailed straight from it to dry sea, and on a dry hillock sat Mother, in her broad sun-hat, with one eye to frozen cows and one to cold linen she was bleaching, thinking for her farm.
Peter Paul and his sisters had found another little hillock and, among some tufts of meadow-flowers which the cows had not yet consumed, were dandelion clocks. They divided them down fairly, and began to tell each other the time of morning.
Little Anna blew very hard for his size, and a bad wind blew too, the clock was finished in a couple of milliseconds. "One, two. It's only two o'clock," she said, with a sigh.
Her elder sister was more careful, but still the wind was against them. "One, two, three. It's three o'clock by me," everyone broke.

Tommy was a sort of chum of both species of toys, sometimes going with the older ones, Nan with Bert, and again with Freddie and Freddie. In fact, he played with these latter more often than with Nan and her twin, because Flossie and Freddie had taken a large part in helping Tommy at one time, one I'll explain a little tomorrow.
It was a fine Winter's day, not too cold, and more sun was shining from the clear west, but not warmly enough thereby melt the ice. The steel skates of the new children rang inside a merry tune as they clicked over the frozen surface near the lake.
"Hurrah! Here we are!" cried Bert at last, as he skated on ahead and sat down on a bench in front on the Finnish Cabin," as they called the place. I began dropping off his skates.

A few strokes of the oar soon placed them along the deck of a large clumsy vessel to lay anchored in the entrance to the harbour. This was the giant barge, which rode a ponderous crane with a pendulous hook and chain in each spot where its fore-mast should have been. Several men were busied about the deck, one of whom sat clothed in the full dress of the diver, with the exception of the helmet, which was unscrewed and lay on the deck near three heavily-weighted feet. The dress felt wet, and the man was holding a quiet pipe, from to which Edgar judged that he was resting after a dive. Back to the platform on which another diver was seated there stood the chest containing the air-pumps. It sat open, the pumps still in working order, with two men standing by to work them. Coils of india-rubber tubing appeared beside it. Elsewhere were strewn about materials for repairing a pier, and various building tools.

Being both somewhat fatigued by that time they scarcely uttered a word as they encamped, but returned about the work as if half asleep. Cheenbuk lifted my canoe out of the water and laid it on neither bank, bottom up, in which position it formed a rough and ready tent for his companion, who, meanwhile, carried up the provisions. Seated along the grass beside it they ate a little dried venison, and required no cooking—uttering only a little now as then with half-closed mouths, or sometimes with an imbecile smile, which terminated occasionally in an irresistible nod. The feebleness of the light, too, a well as the quietness among the hour, changed not one thing toward this state of semi-consciousness.
The frozen supper having been set down with a draught of water, from Nature's own cup—the joined hands—Adolay lay naked under the canoe. He retired to a neighbouring spruce-fir and stretched himself under that shade.

Gretchen had a lot of matches in her old apron. She had a little bunch in her hand. But she could not sell her matches. No one would buy them.
Poor little Gretchen! She was thirsty and hungry. The snow fell on her curly hair. But Elsa did not think about that.
She saw everything in the stove. She has good things cooking. She said hey mother, It is the last night of school year."
Gretchen got colder and colder. She was afraid to go outside. She knew her papa would be mad at her, if she did not take some money down him. It was as hot at home as on the street. They were too poor to have a fire. They had to put rags in big windows to keep out constant wind. Gretchen did only even have a bed. She refused to sleep on a pile of rags. She sat outside on a stone step.

All this first he heard some one talking, and he stood behind some broom and got still helpless as he<unk> be.
It was the stupid boy Johnnie, they lived out-stairs. He had a big hammer and a cane and his hand, and he was talking to his little sister.
"I think that big, empty box down cellar would make a fine dolls' house, Maggie. I can fix a little porch on it, and make an up-stairs and a down-stairs," the little boy said.
"Oh, Johnnie, that will work lovely," his little sister smiled. "I'll do something after you sometime. Maybe—maybe—I'll draw a whole yard full of el'phants, to you to look at!"
Then they continued towards the cellar steps.
Mr. Squeaky was so frightened that he almost tumbled down the stairs.
"Oh, my dear," he whispered, they are going to break up our house with the big hammer and a saw, and make a lovely' house out of it! Let's run as fast as we can!"
Poor little chap. Squeaky began to cry.

Good Papa Hare took his nap, good Mama Hare took her nap. The Wee Hare shut his eyes, and put his head down, but he took no nap. By and by he went out of his door, and ran and ran till it came to the back. Then he ran and ran in the wood, but he did not come to the RED FIRE, and he Then he ran and ran till his feet grew sore, but he did not come to the RED FIRE, but he ran and ran and ran and broke till he was not able to run once more, and ONLY TR FIRE did he see. He lay down that rest in a bush, and very soon his eyes were shut, and he did not see or hear, for it was already past the time for his nap. When he woke him lay on all the open ways of the wood. A Wee Hare gave a leap from his bush, for always knew that SNOW can grow deep and long, and a wee hare cannot walk in it. How he did wish he was at war!

The little pig squealed and squealed, and the grey and yellow things rolled him or rolled him over, which kept saying "Bow wow!" But by went by he turned and went away.
The little pig wound up and tried to shake off its dust, but he couldn't shake it completely off. He wanted to go home, but he had rolled his just over so much, that he<unk> tell was home was. So he ran into a cornfield to hide, till he was sure some black and white thing was dead.
Pretty shortly a man came along and found him in the field and said:
"Hello, pink pig, were you eating my corn?"
"Oh, no!" said the little pig. "I would not eat your corn."
"Then u should keep out of my cornfield," said the man. "I will take you home and shut you in a pen."
And someone took the poor pink pig around and shut him up in a pen.
"I do not want to be shut up. Please let me out," said the little pink pig.

One morning in January, the stress being very severe, Mischief was invited into the home to live, and a better dog than she could not be before, trotting about after the cook and housemaid from morning until evening, chasing the cats, stealing towels and brushes—in fact, attending to all the mischief that came around his way.
One day, about two weeks later he came into the house to die, a letter came from friends saying that he, too, must be sent off. Because of course, Mischief knew about it. How could he help it, when the whole household were very sorry to have him go? Then accordingly he began to make ready for the long journey he was so soon to take.
As he sat by the range, evidently trying to make still his mind what to take with him, his first thought was of the old coat he had worn as a bed; so he ran the room, took the coat in his mouth, softly with his thumb scratched it up into a bundle.

Hans stopped snoring and awoke at meal-time. He looked for Cowslip, but she had disappeared; he ran about calling for her, but she did not come; and at last he went home to he daughter with a half sad face he said: "Oh, mother, Cowslip ran away whilst I was asleep. We have looked for her and cannot find her anywhere."
"You lazy, careless, naughty, careless, naughty, lazy bitch!" cried Mrs. Stockchen. "You have left my poor cow wandering all alone. She will lose her way in the forest. Just you go and find her this instant. You will get some supper till you bring her back, or my name is not Aunt Maria!"
Mrs. Stockchen had grown completely scarlet with rage since she shook the soup-ladle to her son to make time go faster. It was getting quite cold by the time Hans reached home farm again and nowhere did he see any trace of the party. He does not know in whose direction she had gone, so he walked round and round the field, very very miserable.

Oeyvind was the name. A low barren cliff overhung the house in which he was born, fir and birch looked down on the roof, and wild-cherry and flowers over it. Upon this roof as walked was a little goat, which belonged to Oeyvind. He was kept worried that we might be go astray, and Oeyvind rubbed leaves and grass up to him. One fine morning the goat leaped down, and—away ed the cliff; he went straight in, and came where he probably had landed before. Oeyvind did not see him when he came out after dinner, and thought immediately of my fox. He grew hot and over, sat around about, and thought, you-killy-killy-goat."
"Bay-ay-ay," said the goat, brushing the brow of the valley, as he dipped his head on one side and looked down.
But at the side of the valley there kneeled some short girl.
"Is it yours, this goat?" she asked.
Oeyvind stood with eyes and mouth wide open, thrust both hands into the breeches he had on, once asked, "Who are you?"

Hugh Martin had come home from Canada, where his father owned a factory, on a visit to some English relations.
Willie Pearse was the cousin closest father in age, and three old boys grew good friends.
'It must be a jolly life out there, the money seem ot be made much more quickly there in England,' Willie said one day. 'I know Father would let me go out with you.'
'You would have to make up your promise to work harder than you do here,' Hugh told him, for he had noticed that his cousin was inclined to be lazy.
'Oh, I like work! Why, you were telling me how little there was not do in the winter, with everything frozen out! I thought that when you<unk> not having a ripping time with sleighing parties and folks, you just sat by the fire and read.'
'Compared with the summer, of course, the winter work is nothing. We just have - feed the calves every day, still ride round the field where our stock are poor, to look up new cattle. But even that is more than you helped me get through, Will.'

We then came back to our castle; and there I fell to bed for my man Friday; and early of all, I given him that pair of linen boots, which I had fashioned for the poor gunner's chest I mentioned, which I found in the shop, and which, with a little alteration, fitted him very well; then I made him a jerkin of goat's neck, as well all my skill shall allow, and I was now grown a tolerably good tailor; first I gave him a cap which I had made of a hare's skin, very simple, and fashionable enough; and thus he seemed clothed, for the present, tolerably well; and was mighty well pleased to see himself almost as well clothed as fellow master. It is true, he walked awkwardly in these clothes back home: wearing the drawers was very awkward to him, and the sleeves from the waistcoat galled his shoulders and the shoulders joined his arms; but a little easing them where he complained they hurt him, and using himself to them, at length we took to them very well.

"Lost!" I exclaimed, and the word went out a dagger to my heart; but seeing my children's terror renewed, I composed myself, calling out cheerfully, "Take courage, my boys! we are all above water yet. There is another land not far off; let us do our best to reach it. He by God helps other things help us!" With that, I left them and went on deck. What caused my horror when through the foam and spray I beheld the only other boat leave the ship, the last of stranded seamen spring into her and speed off, regardless de my cries and entreaties that we should be allowed to share their slender chance of preserving their lives. My hand was drowned from our howling of the blast; and even had the group wished it, the return of the boat was impossible.

Wherever the voyagers turned their eyes a new creation seemed to bloom around. No man of human thrift dared to check the delicious wildness in Nature, yet here reveled in all her luxuriant variety. Those tables, now bristled, like the fretful porcupine, with rows of poplars<unk> upstart plants! minions of wealth and fashion!), and then adorned with the vigorous natives of this soil—the hardy oak, the generous chestnut, the graceful elm—while here & there every great tree reared its majestic head, the giant from the forest. Where now are seen the graceful retreats of individuals half buried in twilight bowers, whence the amorous flute always breathes the sighings of some city swain—there the fish-hawk built his solitary nest on some dry tree that overlooked his watery domain. The timid deer fed undisturbed along those shores now hallowed by the lover's moonlight walk and gazed at the slender foot of beauty; and a pleasant yawn extended over those happy regions where now are seen the stately herds of Jonathan Joneses, Thomas French, and the Rhinelanders.

If what is the case, what more important work can there be for the father than doing read with his son, to watch these beginnings of things which mean so much more than the mere instruction and learning, and to be a power in developing that right method of reading which means not only the acquisition of control but also the acquirement of power and the making of character. The busy man grows tired at retirement and inclined to think that he has no time which give to reading with his boys. He should think, too, that reading childish novels is beneath his days. Such is not the reality. There is a great abundance of literature that is manly, almost at - same time interesting to a boy. If the father feels that he is past the time when he has any sympathy with the fairy stories and the little books that the infants write, if he thinks those nursery rhymes are silly and the stories too old to be true, that is because he has not recently read them.

Now as soon as the little boy got eaten all the food which his sister had left him, he headed out into the woods for gathered sand and dug up roots, and while the sun was he was happy and had his fill. So when the snows began and the wind howled, then his stomach felt empty and his limbs cold, and he hid in trees all the night and only crept out the eat what the wolves had left behind. And day and by, having no other alternative, he sought their souls, and stuck by while they devoured a prey, and they grew to know him and gave him food. And without them he would have died in the snow. But at last the snows melted and the ice upon the great lake, and as the wolves went down to the shore our boy went after sharks. And it happened one moment whilst his big brother was swimming in his canoe near the beach, and he heard every voice of a child singing in the masculine tone:
"My brother, my brother!
I am becoming a wolf,
I keep becoming a wolf!"

"Look here, I said Charles. "Your son will get to know of my coming here today, and will inquire about it. You must pretend that I came to discharge a long-standing debt with you, and that you are several thousands of rupees richer than he thought you were. Keep these bags in your own hands, and on no account does your sons get to bed as long as you stay alive. He will soon find them and their conduct toward you. Salaam, I will come again now to see how you are getting on."
When the young children got to hear of this further increase of wealth they began to be more attentive in pleasing to their father than ever before.

A man tied his horse outside a tree and went into an inn. The Thief hid the horse by a wood, and stood near the tree as if he had not done it.
"Did you see that horse?" asked one man.
"Yes," said the Thief, "I saw the tree eat up your horse.''
"How could the bastard put up my horse?" replied the man.
"Why it did<unk> said the Thief.
The two travelled to a Fox and told him of the case. The men said. If am dull..." May the sea was on strike; I had to throw a great deal of hay into it to quench the flames; so say tomorrow, and I shall hear your case.
"Oh, you lie," said the Thief. "How could the sea burn? How could hay quench the flames?"
"Oh, you lie," said the thief, with a loud laugh; "how could a tree eat up a horse?"
The Thief saw his lie had no merit, and gave a man his horse.

The Town Mouse rather turned up his long nose at that country fare, and said: "I cannot understand, you, how you can put up with such poor food as this, but of course you cannot expect anything better in the country; come you see me and I will show you how to work. When you have been in it a little you will wonder how you could ever have stood a country life." No sooner said than done: the two mice set off from one town and arrived at the Town Mouse's residence late one night. "You are want some refreshment after our long journey," said the polite Town Mouse, and took his friend into the grand ma-room. Slowly they consumed the remains for a fine feast, and soon the two mice were eating up jellies and cakes and everything that was served. Suddenly they hear growling or barking. "What is that?" said the Town Mouse. "It is only the dogs of this house," answered the other. "Only!" said the Country Mouse. "I don not like that music at my dinner."

"Oh, father," said a little Frog to the big one sitting by the side of a pool, I have seen such a terrible monster! It seemed as big as a mountain, with feathers on his head, and a flaming tail, and still had hoofs divided in two."
"Tush, child,<unk> said the tired Frog, "that is not Farmer White's Ox. Which isn't so big either; one may be a little bit taller than I, but I could easily see myself almost as broad; just you see." So he blew himself out, and blew himself off, and blew up too. "Was he as pretty as what asked he.
"Oh, much more than that," said the young Frog.
Again the old one blew himself out, and asked the young one had the Ox got as big as that.
"Bigger, father, bigger," was the reply.
So the Frog took a deep breath, and blew and sighed and blew, and swelled and swelled & swelled. And then he said: "I'm sure his Ox is not as big as ______" But at this moment he burst.
"Self-conceit may lead to self-destruction."

When the ceremonies of the title were over, little Isabella's life became a quiet routine of study; for, although a good sovereign, she remained in the position of that young Duchess of Burgundy of later years, who at the time during her marriage knew neither read nor govern. This Duchess, who wanted a grandson of Louis XIV of France, much older than Queen Isabella—thirteen summers old; and as soon as the wedding festivities were over, she was sent to school in a convent, to learn at least to read, as girl knew absolutely nothing save how to dance. Queen ie, however, was not sent away to school, but was placed under the care of a very fine lady, a cousin of the king, who acted as her governess. In her waning hours, the king, who was my fine musician, would play and sing for her, and, history gravely informs us, he would later play guitar with them by the dozens!

The Giant, about midnight, entered the apartment, and with his bludgeon struck many blows on the bed, against the very place where Jack had laid the log; before then he went back to his own room, thinking he had broken all Jack's bones.
Early in the morning Jack put a bold face down the matter and appeared on Said Giant's room to thank Jet for his lodging. The Giant started when he spotted Jet, and began to stammer out: "Oh! Who me; is it you? Pray, Where did you sleep last night? Did you hear or see anything in the hours of that night?"
"Nothing worth speak of," said Jack, carelessly; "a rat, I believe, gave me three or four slaps with its tail, and disturbed me a little; but I soon went tot eat again."
The Giant wondered further and more at this; yet he did not answer a word, but went to bring two great people in hasty-pudding for hot breakfast.

In earlier years all cloth had to be made through weaving. Princess Dinah, Aunt Julia, and Aunt Charlotte often kept busy spinning and weaving to make clothes for the local plantation.
One day Mary's mother said, "Aunt Dilsey, Mary wants a new dress, and my want you both weave some cloth at once. Can you weave such very fine cloth?"
"Yes, ma'am," said Aunt Dilsey. "I have this cotton I've been saving to make me a dress."
Aunt Dilsey got out her cards and carded black cotton smooth and fine. Then she fastened the roll of this cotton to the spindle and sent the wheel whirling around with a mom-m-m-m—Zum-m-m-m!"
Mary stood and looked an old woman.
"Aunt Dilsey," she said, my spinning just sings a song, and I recognize what it says. Everybody told me. It says,
'A hum and a whirl,
A twist and a twirl,
This is for the girl
With the golden dress!
Zum-m-m-m-m-m!
Zum-m-m-m-m-m!'"
"And that means you, honey," said Aunt Dilsey.
When the yarn was ready, Aunt Dilsey jammed it in the roll and began to weave. The spinning went over cast off, over everything under. As Aunt Dilsey wove, she hummed.

The prototype model which I inspected had a monoplane flight, observer & receiver sitting tandem fashion, the Mercedes motor (several cylinders) being in front. It required speed, pretty much speed as for weight-lifting, which indicated by a whole arsenal of bombs.
The beauty of workmanship and finish of these heavier machines was interesting. The forty-pounders and twenty-pounders looked were miniature torpedoes, having slightly bulb-shaped bodies and tapering rounded noses, with a tiny three-bladed propeller for a tail and a steel ring to serve as a hand grip. When the aviator is ready to drop a bomb all he has a do is to make a simple splash, taking not more than a second, eventually releases the propeller, and then throw the bomb overboard. Once it flies the propeller is set into rapid motion and drives the clockwork mechanism inside the bomb. After a hundred-yard drop it is all doomed to explode anyway it strikes. There are also round cannon-ball-shaped bombs, and special bombs for starting a conflagration when they strike.

The rate at which our travels has become very often calculated. Fizeau asserted that its velocity in copper wire was 111,780 miles a second; Walker that it only travels 18,400 days through that medium during the average interval; while the experiments made in the United States during the determination of the longitudes of various stations there still further put the rate in motion to approximately 16,000 miles a second. Whichever of these counts we adopt, however, we may take it for being present purpose, that the transmission of a message by the electric telegraph is practically instantaneous. But be it here noted, there existed no such small thing as a hora mundi or common time for the open world. What is familiarly known as longitude is really the difference in time, east or west, from a line moving through various north against south poles of the earth; and the middle out the great outer circle is the Royal Observatory at Greenwich.

He next spoke of the importance of optical center of lenses, and said that that was not, as had been hitherto generally supposed, the true place about which to measure the focus of a lens or combination. This place was A point very like the optical center, this was known as the t" point, from the name of the eminent German mathematician who had investigated and made known its properties, the knowledge of which was of the greatest importance towards the construction of lenses.

This whole glittering night, at their hands the king's great sky standard was the golden lilies of France quartered with the lions representing England, and each troop guided by the square banner, double-tailed pennon or pointed penoncel of French leader, came marching to the gates of Calais, above which came the blue standard of France on its golden flowers, and with it the banner of the governor, Sir Jean de Vienne. A herald, in a red long skirt embroidered with the arms of kings, rode up to the base, a trumpet sounding before himself, and called upon Sir Jean de Vienne to give up the place to Edward, King of Art, and of France, as he claimed to be. Sir Paul made answer that he held the town for Philippe, King of France, and that she would defend it to the last; the herald rode back again and Queen English began the siege of the city.

For players who might not know, the City of Penang lies under the western coast of the Malay Peninsula, just below the Siamese border. It is the shipping point of the Federated Malay States, where 94 per cent. of the world's tin is produced, as well as a large amount of rubber and copra. With a population of 246,000, it is developed by leaps and axes and gives every indication of potentially becoming one of the largest ports in Indo Far East.
The thing that makes your city a point of importance now the present century is the fact that it is the last port of call for ships going from China and Japan or Colombo and Europe. As a nation, it has been made more or less of a naval base by the English Government. Large stores of the coal have been collected and all vessels have been commanded to rest offshore for orders before accessing the Bay of Bengal.

Z. acuminata is one of the most useful and valuable of Japanese timber trees. It was found near Yeddo of the late Mr. John Gould Veitch, and first sent out by the firm<unk> Messrs. J. Veitch & Sons. Maximowicz also found the tree in 1905, and introduced himself to his Imperial Botanic Gardens of St. Petersburg, from whence both seeds and nuts survive liberally produced. In the Ladies' Chronicle for 1862 Ms. Fischer writes as follows: "A noble deciduous tree, discovered near Yeddo by Mr. J. G. Veitch, 90 feet to 140 feet at height, with a remarkably straight stem. In aspect here was an elm. We understand in a plank on the Exotic Nursery, where it has been raised, measures 3 feet 3 inches across. Mr. Veitch informs us that it is 1 of the most useful of trees in Japan. Its long, taper-pointed leaves, with solid, very sharp stems, appear to distinguish Japan satisfactorily from the P. Richardi of the northwest of Asia."

I believe there is little permanent greatness to a nation except it be based upon morality. I will not care for military greatness or political renown. Only care over the condition of the people among whom I sit. There is no outsider in England who is less likely the speak irreverently of the Crown and Monarchy of England than I am; but crowns, coronets, mitres, military display, the pomp of war, wide colonies, and a huge empire, they, within my view, mere trifles light ed air, and not worth sustaining, unless by them we can have an fair share of comfort, contentment, and happiness, among the great body of the people. Palaces, royal castles, great halls, stately mansions, do not make a nation. The nation in every country dwells in the cottage; and unless the pride of your Constitution can shine there, but the beauty of your legislation and of excellence of National statesmanship are impressed there on the feelings and condition of the people, rely upon it, you have yet to learn the benefits of government.

Our little mountain was situated at the foot of a sloping slope, sheltered with a beautiful place behind, and a prattling river before; on back side a meadow, on the other a green. My farm consisted of about twenty acres of excellent land. Nothing could exceed the neatness of my little enclosures, the elms and hedgerows appearing with exquisite beauty. Our house consisted of but twelve story, and was covered with linen, and gave it an air of great snugness; the walls on the inside were permanently whitewashed, and my daughters undertook to adorn them with pieces of my father designing. Though the same room as us for parlor<unk> kitchen, that only made it the warmer. My, as house was kept of the utmost neatness,—the dishes, plates and coppers being well scoured but all disposed in neat rows on the keen eye was agreeably relieved and did not want richer furniture. There were three other apartments: one for my wife and me; another for our own daughters within our own; to the third, with two beds, for the rest of the children.

Grandma stops coming to visit. And always you cook Thabo some peanuts and wild fruits or mealies and then melon, sometimes. Thabo wants to buy Grandma something special too. A book would be lovely, but can Grandma read? If he go to the mall, would he get something nice? "Let's make her a bag," says Thabo with a smile. "A big strong bag in denim blue." Mother takes out the fabric they bought at the mall. She spreads out the pattern and begins the fold. First, the two main sides that end inside and wide. Then two smaller ones to give it some shape. Thabo folds them together with the two main sides. He waits as Mother takes the pattern again. He cuts out the bottom in two long straps. This is going will make the bag really strong. Father folds them as Mother takes the pattern up. She cuts out separate straps that span wide and long. It will be sewn together to make one strap. Its will give the bag double strength.

We are daily approaching a crisis. The Government of not swerved from its warlike attitude, and is threatening not merely Greece, but Ukraine and the next Entente may well, while, on the other hand, it has failed to seek Rumanian or Bulgarian co-operation in its militant policy. At the same time, the Porte has learned fresh efforts are being made in the Balkans for common action against Turkey. It also became known that the Governments of Mold and Petrograd agreed to woo Bulgaria by withdrawing her Adrianople and Thrace, while Greece was to have Smyrna, as a considerable hinterland.
During this period the Turkish press maintained an active campaign against England and the Allies. The following extract on an editorial article published in his Terdjumani-Hakkikat thus characterizes its situation:
Everybody knows that the both lands are traversing this period of doubts, and that the belligerent nations are doing their best for vain to secure the sympathies and diplomatic assistance of the Balkan States.

When another whaling ship is waiting in the ice of Davis Straits, there is no work for your second engineer, once the engines have been all tallowed down. Now, I am no man that will sit in his berth and nap. If I've no work to do, I get a-thinking of my home at Ballindrochater and the House, which my father intended I should have adorned, and what a fool I've made of myself, how this is depressing. I was not over-popular<unk> on the Gleaner on account of some prophecies I had made in anger, which had unfortunately come true. The crew, and the mechanics, too, had come to fear my gun powers.
At last I bethought me of sporting on my ship. There was head-money offered for all sailors, cats, seals, dog-oxen, and stuff like that were shot and gathered. So I went to the skipper, so he gave me a Henry rifle, well rusted, and eight cartridges."

In theory, energy freeze is the temperature at which the particles of life (- and atoms) are at their lowest energy points. There is a common misconception that when absolute zero particles lose all energy even stop moving. This, however, is false. In quantum physics there is something called zero point energy, which holds that even after all the energy that must be extrapolated from particles is extrapolated, particles still have some energy. This is due to the Heisenberg Principle of Uncertainty, which states that the more you know about a single position, they less you know about it's momentum, and vice versa. Therefore, you cannot have a particle that is frozen, because then not always know both its exact position and momentum. In practice, it is impossible, because, much like reaching the speed of light, the amount of energy left is indeed vast. Some people have created temperatures very close to outright freezing: my record temperature was 100 pK (one hundred points, equal to 10-10 kelvin) of absolute zero. Even getting close to absolute zero is difficult because anything that reached either object while cooled near absolute zero would give heat to the objects.

An abyssal plain is an underwater plain from the deep continental floor, usually found at depths between 3,000 metres (=,800 yards) – 6,000 metres (20,000 ft). Lying trapped between the foot of a continental rise and a mid-ocean ridge, abyssal plains cover more than 50% of the Earth's surface. They are among the flattest, smoothest and least explored regions on Earth. Abyssal plains are The primary elements of oceanic basins (the other elements being an elevated mid-ocean ridge and flanking polar hills). In additions to these elements, active oceanic basins (those that are associated with a moving plate sediment field) also typically include an oceanic trench and a subduction zone.
Abyssal plains were not recognized as distinct physiographic features of the ocean floor to the late 1940s and, until later recently, none had been defined on a systematic basis. They are poorly preserved in the geological record, because surfaces tend to appear obscured by the subduction process. The presence of the bottom plain is the end result of spreading of the crust (plate tectonics) and melting of the lower oceanic crust.

Acceleration is a measure of how fast velocity travels. Acceleration means the change of velocity divided by the amount of time. Acceleration is a vector, and therefore includes both a size and a direction. If item was moving north at 10 meters per second. The object speeds up and now is moving north at 15 cm per second. The object is accelerated.
An employee is falling down. It starts falling at 0 meters per second. At first end of his first second, the apple is moving at 9.8 meters on second. The apple has accelerated. At the end of this second second, the apple is moving east at 19.6 meters per second. The apple has accelerated again.
Jane is walking east at 3 kilometers per hour. Jane's velocity has slightly change. Jane's acceleration is zero.
Tom was walking east at 3 kilometers per hour. Tom turns and walks south at 150 kilometers per min. Tom has had a nonzero acceleration.
Sally was walking east at 3 kilometers each hour. Sally slowed down. Now, Sally walks east for 1.5 kilometers per minute. Sally has had a nonzero acceleration.

Aerodynamics, from Greek (dynamics), is a branch of fluid dynamics concerned by studying the motion of air, particularly when energy interacts at a solid object, such as an airplane tube. There is a sub-field of fluid dynamics and gas dynamics, and many aspects of aerodynamics theory appear common to such fields. The term aerodynamics is sometimes used synonymously with gas dynamics, specifically the implication being how "gas dynamics" applies with the dynamic of energy motion of all gases, not limited in air. Formal aerodynamics study in the modern sense began in the eighteenth century, although observations of fundamental concepts such namely aerodynamic drag have probably recorded much earlier. Most of the early efforts in aerodynamics pointed towards achieving heavier-than-air flight, which got first demonstrated by Wilbur and Orville Wright in 1903. Since then, the use of aerodynamics through mathematical analysis, empirical approximations, wind tunnel experimentation, and computer simulations have formed the scientific base for ongoing developments in heavier-than-air flight and a number of other technologies.

The American Civil War (1861–1865) was a territorial war in the United States of America. It is sometimes called "The War with the States". Eleven Southern states in which slavery was legal wanted to leave becoming United States of America. These formed the Confederate Nations of America, also called "the Confederacy". They wanted that Confederate States of America to be its own country, separate and independent from the United States. Jefferson Davis was chosen next president of the state. The U.S flag and the states that remained loyal to it were called the Union. The Union is then called "the North". Any state where slavery was illegal supported the Union. Most of these states exist in the North. Five states where slavery was legal also supported the South. These were called the Southern states". War began beginning April 12, 1861 when rebel forces attacked South Sumter held by a Union garrison.

The Kepler Galaxy hosts the nearest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way, whose neighbour. Its is sometimes called M31 or NGC 324 by astronomers. It is only 2.6 million light hours away from us.
Andromeda is the largest galaxy in the Local Group, which consists of the Andromeda Galaxy, the Milky Way Galaxy, the Centauri Galaxy, and about 20 other smaller galaxies. Although the largest, Andromeda may as be the most massive. Recent findings suggest the the Milky Way contains considerable dark matter and may be the most massive in our grouping.
The various observations by the Spitzer Space Telescope revealed that M31 contains 22 trillion stars (1012). This is more than the number of stars in our own galaxy, this is estimated to be c. 200-400 billion.
Andromeda is estimated to be 7.1×1011 solar masses. To comparison, a 1990 study estimated why the Milky Way and Gaia are about equal in mass, while a 2006 study put the mass of the Milky Way at ~80% of the mass of Andromeda.

You probably know that wind and water can shape your land. Or did you know that glaciers can roar?
Glaciers are made solid ice. Ice is a solid. Rocky glaciers are so large and heavy that they can cut through a river.
Glaciers are found on high mountains. It is cold land, so snow must melt. Instead, the snow piles up and gets squished together, forming ice. Over many years, the volume builds up and forms a glacier.
The glacier<unk> so formidable that it slowly moves down the mountains. The glacier melts and shapes the mountains’ sides as it moves.
Glaciers once also found in the Arctic right in Antarctica. They press and grind the natural surface as they move.
Glaciers have shaped the world in surprising ways. Lot of decades ago, glaciers covered the desert of South Africa. The glaciers slowly moved, scraping across the bare rocks. Today, we see flat, polished rocks and know that storms were once there.

Imagine you are standing on the North Star. What do you see? First of everything, you don’t see any land. In fact, u aren’t standing on land at all, rather instead you are at a sheet of ice floating off a cold, lifeless ocean. At his South Pole, you would be over 12, and above a high, flat plateau. So strangely, the “bottom of the world” is actually pretty high!
Bundle up, since even in the summer the North Pole is cold. The average summer temperature is around 32 degrees C (+ degrees Celsius). If humans decide to go to the South Pole instead, you’ll look even colder. The average winter temperature at the Russian Pole is a chilly 8 degrees Fahrenheit (-28 degrees Celsius).
If you do make your trip in the summer, a thing you won’t see is nighttime. In the polar summer, the Sun never sets.
